description: The A.H. Robins Company said yesterday that it plans to establish a substantial reserve against its 1984 earnings for claims related to the Dalkon Shield, an intrauterine birth- control device discontinued by the company 10 years ago.

description: b-Net income which includes an extraordinary gain of $2,043,000.

title: VOTE AIDS KENNEDY ALLY'S EFFORT TO HEAD DEMOCRATIC COMMITTEE
description: The Democratic National Committee voted today to extend the terms of 25 at-large members, giving Paul G. Kirk Jr. a procedural victory that his supporters said would clear the way for his election Friday as national party chairman.

title: Six Years Later
description: The McBurney School on West 63d Street includes among its graduates J. D. Salinger, Felix Rohatyn, Ted Koppel and Henry Winkler. But for the sixth straight year, they will gather tonight at the school and remember Harry Lois, the three-letter star and all-city athlete who collapsed and died without warning in 1978 at the age of 20.

title: One Dead in Wave of Attacks On Vehicles in the West Bank
description: An Israeli who was wounded by a firebomb thrown at his car in the occupied West Bank last Saturday died from his wounds today.

title: REXHAM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: BURNDY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a nonrecurring gain of $1,182,000.

title: TEAMSTERS' FUND HEAD DEFENDS 3 DISMISSALS
description: George W. Lehr, executive director of the Central States, Southeast and Southwest Areas Pension Fund of the teamsters' union, does not understand what all the fuss is about.

title: Life Sentence Imposed In Rape of Children
description: A 19-year-old teacher's aide was sentenced today to life in prison after being convicted of rape and indecent assault of children at the day care center where he worked.

title: MARY KAY COSMETICS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $10,876,000 on the sale of land for the quarter and year.

title: Bowing Out
description: Irene Epple of West Germany, an outstanding skier on the women's World Cup circuit since 1973, has decided to relinquish her career to pursue the study of medicine she began in the off-season last year. ''My recent results haven't been that good and I thought I should make way for some younger girls,'' said Miss Epple, who is 27 and who was second to

title: AGS COMPUTERS INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Chin Takes Lead After Figures
description: Tiffany Chin of Toluca Lake, Calif., whose poor scores in compulsory figures cost her a chance at a medal at the Winter Olympics last year, won all three figures she traced today to lead the women's competition at the United States Figure Skating Championships.

title: Who Next for the U.N.?
description: It's been America's habit to plant large reputations on the small pedestal of the United Nations, mostly for the political convenience of Presidents. The main ambassadorship to the U.N., usually carrying cabinet rank, is a highly visible job for rewarding friends, co-opting rivals or mollifying constituencies. Hence the baton was passed, with nonconforming interludes, from Henry Cabot Lodge to Adlai Stevenson and Arthur Goldberg, then to Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Andrew Young and Jeane Kirkpatrick.

title: DAY OF REFLECTION AND FAREWELL FOR DELBELLO
description: He paused for just a moment near a granite column and gazed into the swirling snow. Then, for the last time as Lieutenant Governor, Alfred B. DelBello strode quickly away and the Capitol faded gently into a shroud of whiteness.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 1, 1985
description: The Economy

title: NEWS SUMMARY;

title: SOVIET FINDING NEW AUTO ERA A GIDDY EXPERIENCE
description: In his rush to match the West, Nikita S. Khrushchev is said to have predicted that one day Russia, too, would have traffic jams.

title: JAZZ PIANOS, 88 KEYS TO THE CITY
description: JAZZ pianists in styles ranging from ragtime to stride to be-bop can be heard this weekend up and down Manhattan, in surroundings from the spectacular to the mundane, accompanied by food for the gourmet or for the snacker or nothing more than a drink.

title: PROVIDENT INSTITUTION FOR SAVINGS IN THE TOWN OF BOSTON reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $288,000 from the distribution of preferred stock of the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. and a gain of $3,294,000 on the sale of a building. c-Net loss.

title: Iona Upset By 102-85
description: Jim McCaffrey set a Hart Center and Metro-Atlantic Conference record with 46 points tonight to lead Holy Cross to a 102-85 upset victory over Iona.

title: Western Union Lending Accord
description: The Western Union Corporation said it had reached an agreement with its 31 lending banks that would provide it with $33 million in exchange for accounts receivable.

title: BOOKS: COOK TRIM
description: -CALORIE

title: REPORT FAULTS ENVIRONMENT AGENCY
description: The New York State agency responsible for protecing the environment is so lacking in funds and manpower that basic laws go unenforced and the well being of residents is jeopardized, leaders of the Assembly charged today.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;   Morgan Analyst Plans Wider Scope
description: Barton M. Biggs, who has been picking stocks and moving markets for the last 12 years at Morgan Stanley & Company, is broadening his focus. To date, Mr. Biggs has primarily limited himself to comments on American equity markets; now he intends to take on the world.

title: LEADING INDICATORS DOWN 0.2%
description: The index of leading economic indicators, which is intended to predict the nation's economic course, fell two- tenths of 1 percent in December, the Commerce Department reported today. This small but surprising decline left the index barely above its August level.

title: 'STAR WARS' PLAN AT ISSUE IN CANADA
description: President Reagan's ''Star Wars'' research on putting an anti-missile system in space is developing into a potentially volatile issue in Canadian politics.

title: Looking Toward Life After Flutie
description: Boston College has just received the word: There is indeed life after Doug Flutie. The quarterback, who signed with the New Jersey Generals of the United States Football League for perhaps $7 million over five years, may be gone, but he is far from forgotten. His alma mater has been informed that Boston College has been selected to play Brigham Young in the third annual Kickoff Classic next Aug. 29 in Giants Stadium. The Classic, which had been played on the last Monday in August, will now be on the last Thursday of the month.

title: TRUMP STRIKES OIL, BUT MORE OF A LEAK THAN A GUSHER, ON THE WEST SIDE
description: In the last year, Donald J. Trump has bought the St. Moritz Hotel, opened a huge gambling casino in Atlantic City, taken over the largest tract of undeveloped land in Manhattan, offered to build a $250 million sports stadium in Queens and the world's tallest building in Manhattan, and signed the country's leading college quarterback, Doug Flutie, to play for his football team.

title: 2 Magazine Ventures To Use Sunday Papers
description: Two entrepreneurs, both former newspaperwomen, are busily creating mass monthly magazines that will use Sunday newspapers as delivery vehicles.

title: The Pope's Call Twenty-six years ago an extraordinarily charismatic Pope named John XXIII called for an Ecumenical Council, only the 20th in nearly 2,000 years of church history. He intended, he told a visitor, to open the window and permit fresh air to blow through the Roman Catholic Church. He summed up the idea of that council, Vatican II, in one word:
description: aggiornamento , a bringing up to date.

description: President Reagan recently authorized a merger of talks on reducing medium-range and intercontinental-range nuclear weapons if such an arrangement was proposed by the Soviet Union, according to Administration officials.

title: Fires in Florida Prompt Emergency Declaration
description: Fires enveloped 50,000 acres of southern Florida today as Gov. Bob Graham declared a state of emergency, allowing the use of National Guard helicopters.

title: 2 BRINK'S WORKERS HELD IN VAULT PLOT
description: Two employees of Brink's Inc. are facing Federal charges that they plotted to rob the armored car service's main vault in San Francisco to help finance an anti-Semitic extremist group that was plotting to take over the Federal Government.

title: A JAZZ FETIVAL AT HOME
description: Stay-at-homes can have a jazz piano solo festival this weekend that is not limited to those pianists who are in town. With records, the piano fare can be spread to include those who are playing elsewhere and even those who will never be heard again.

description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $108,000 from the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. dividend. c-Comparable year-ago share earnings are unavailable as the company went public in November 1983.

title: Eastern Talks With Unions
description: Eastern Airlines technically defaulted on $2.5 billion in bank loans last night when its three labor unions failed to agree to wage concessions before a midnight deadline.

description: The world is awash in oil. With or without permission from the OPEC ministers meeting in Geneva, prices are tumbling.

description: The bassist Ron Carter will lead his quartet tonight through Sunday at Lush Life, Bleecker and Thompson Streets.

description: b-Includes a tax credit of $400. c-Includes a tax credit of $17,000 and a gain of $72,200 on the sale of retail stores.

title: 'STAR WARS': NO SIGN OF EMERGING CONSENSUS
description: President Reagan's proposal to develop a defense against nuclear missile attack has attracted both more support and more opposition since he put forward the idea almost two years ago.

title: 2 RIGHTS OFFICIALS BACK HIRING CURB
description: The chairman and vice chairman of the United States Commission on Civil Rights voiced strong support today for a Supreme Court decision that curtails affirmative action programs when they come in conflict with seniority plans.

title: PUBLISHING: SHORT STORY READINGS
description: IN recent years, collections of short stories by Eudora Welty and Saul Bellow have climbed onto The New York Times best- seller list, and a perusal of the spring catalogues of commercial and university presses underscocores the impression that the short story is praticularly robuts. A further indication of that can be seen in the clebration that gets under way next week at Symphony Space, the performing arts center on Broadway and 95th Street.

description: ''HEAVENLY BODIES,'' which has the manner and look of the world's longest music video, finds the activities in and around an exercise parlor called Heavenly Bodies to be a microcosm of life as it's lived - and loved - overnight.

School Prayer Law Blocked
description: A Federal judge today blocked enforcement of West Virginia's new school prayer law after a hearing in which witnesses said the measure makes children pray when they may not want to.

5 INQUIRIES IN PROGRESS
description: Five investigations into the conduct of the New York City Medical Examiner's Office under the Chief Medical Examiner, Dr. Elliot M. Gross, are under way. Dr. Gross has said he expected to be ''completely vindicated'' by the investigations.

title: Latin-Jazz Quintet
description: The alto saxophonist Paquito D'Rivera and his Latin-jazz quintet will appear tonight through Sunday at the Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, below 11th Street. Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is an $8.50 cover and a one-drink minimum. Information: 255-4037.

title: Datapoint Offer Ends; Fight Is Set
description: Asher Edelman, the New York investor, notified the Securities and Exchange Commission that he had withdrawn his offer to buy the Datapoint Corporation for $23 a share.

title: CuomoPicksAuthorityChief
description: Governor Cuomo has nominated William D. Hassett Jr. as chairman of the State Dormitory Authority. Mr. Hassett, the State Commerce Commissioner from 1979 to 1981, has also served as chairman of the Urban Development Corporation and the Battery Park City Authority and as a trustee of the State University of New York. The nomination is subject to confirmation by the State Senate.

title: INDIANA FALLS, 72-59, WITH STARTERS BACK
description: Coach Bobby Knight returned four veteran players to the starting lineup tonight, but Iowa, led by Greg Stokes's 21 points, extended Indiana's Big Ten Conference losing streak to four games with a 72-59 victory.

title: TAIWAN'S ESTABLISHMENT IS SHAKEN BY MYSTERIOUS SLAYING IN CALIFORNIA
description: The slaying of a Chinese-American author in California has created a national scandal here.

title: Films About Harlem
description: Performances by the Negro Ensemble Company and screenings of independent films about Harlem are featured this weekend as part of a six- week festival running through March 18 at Aaron Davis Hall at City College, Convent Avenue and 134th Street. The company will perform ''Ceremonies in Dark Old Men'' today at 12:30 and 8 P.M. and tomorrow at 3 and 8.

title: Phillips Net Drops 31.6%
description: The Phillips Petroleum Company reported yesterday that fourth-quarter profits fell 31.6 percent to $169 million, or $1.10 a share, from $247 million, or $1.61 a share, a year earlier. Revenues were flat at $4 billion.

title: JEREE PALMER KEEPS ON DOING WHAT SHE'S DOING
description: Jeree Palmer can't remember a time when she didn't want to be a performer, but once she achieved her ambition, it wasn't quite enough. She was singing with the New Christy Minstrels and in cabarets, she was sometimes the opening act for Jerry Lewis, Bill Cosby and Alan King when they did club shows. She appeared on television in daytime serials and Bob Hope specials, and one day she decided she had gone about as far as she could go in that area.

title: JURORS IN CBS CASE GET PREVIEW OF SUMMATIONS
description: The jury in Gen. William C. Westmoreland's libel trial against CBS in Federal District Court in Manhattan was given an unexpected preview yesterday of summations likely to be delivered by both sides in a month.

title: AMISTAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including nonrecurring net income of $519,000 from a change in tax law.

title: U.S. to Seek Concessions for Ending Car Quotas
description: Bill Brock, the United States trade representative, will lead a special negotiating mission to Tokyo in mid-February to impress upon the Japanese the importance Washington attaches to a relaxation of Japan's restrictions on imports, Administration officials reported today.

title: THE POWER OF FRANK STELLA
description: THERE has been no doubt whatever throughout the last 25 years that Frank Stella, born in 1936, is the strongest American painter of his generation. He laid claim to that title with the black paintings that Dorothy Miller showed in a group exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art in the winter of 1959-60, and despite one or two divagations either into sweetness or overcomplication, he has held on to it ever since.

title: A LEGENDARY 'LOST CITY' IN ANDES GIVES HINT OF MYSTERIOUS CULTURE
description: High in the Andes of Peru, explorers have examined and photographed in great detail the remains of a legendary ''lost city'' that archeologists believe may rival the spectacular Inca ruins at Machu Picchu.

title: JAMAICA STRUGGLING TO MEET FUND GOAL FOR YOUTH FESTIVAL
description: With encouragement from the Reagan Administration, Jamaica is organizing an international youth conference and festival for early April as a show of solidarity among young people in the non-Communist world.

title: Ken McIntyre Trio
description: The saxophonist Ken McIntyre will lead a trio Sunday at 3 P.M. at the fourth-floor loft of 109 West Broadway, above Chambers Street. Admission is $5. Information: 619-4879.

title: SILTEC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HOUSE BUDGET PANEL BEGINS ORIENTING NEWCOMERS
description: The House Budget Committee, one of the most important committees in Congress, should logically be a place where experience is important. But unlike other major committees, the House Budget Committee rotates its membership. Every two years there is a trade-off: an infusion of new blood for a hemorrhage of experience.

title: Coalition Opposes Firefighters' Pact
description: A coalition of city unions yesterday called on the firefighters union to reject the terms of a tentative contract agreement with the city.

title: MILLER'S 68 LEADS CROSBY GOLF
description: Lanny Wadkins, the fastest man off the mark on the Professional Golfers' Association Tour in January since Johnny Miller won three tournaments each in the winters of 1974 and 1975, slipped a bit today. Wadkins had his first round of the year over par, and it was Miller who came in with the lead among the early finishers in the 44th Bing Crosby National Pro-Am.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;   Merrill Lynch Is Sued Over Pricing of 'Tigers'
description: A group of Michigan investors filed a class action lawsuit in the United States Court for the Southern District of New York earlier this week asserting that Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith ''fraudulently omitted to disclose'' important information about zero coupon Treasury-backed securities known as Treasury Investment Growth Receipts, or ''Tigers.''

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball

title: SEALED AIR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
RESTAURANTS
description: TWO years ago, a shiny little blue and white takeout-restaurant sprouted in Manhattan's inhospitable badlands along Eighth Avenue near 43d Street. Called Barking Fish, it was run by Arthur DeCuir, a native of Louisiana who had worked in some of the city's plush restaurants before deciding to offer his native Cajun and Creole cuisine to New York - ribs, crayfish etouffee, po-boy sandwiches, crab gumbo, catfish, jambalaya. Before long, he had a thriving business. The only problem was, he seemed to spend as much time fending off robbers and thugs as he did deep frying.

title: Bridge:Agreement Settles the Issue Of the Status of South Africa
description: The most contentious issue on the international bridge scene seems to have been put to rest in the past year, amicably and sensibly.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A news analysis article in Metropolitan Report last Friday about Ariel Sharon's libel suit against Time magazine incorrectly described the handling of a poll on Senator Barry Goldwater by the publisher Ralph Ginzburg. The poll was not fabricated. The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit found in 1969 that Mr. Ginzburg had tampered with the poll results, printed misleading versions of the responses and added material he had actually written himself.

title: DOCTORS FIND ANTIBODY TO SUSPECTED AIDS VIRUS
description: Scientists have identified an antibody that in laboratory experiments has been found to inactivate the virus suspected of causing acquired immune deficiency syndrome, a leading AIDS researcher said today.

title: DYNAMICS' DEFERRAL OF U.S. INCOME TAX
description: The General Dynamics Corporation, the nation's largest military contractor, has not paid any Federal income taxes since 1972, although the company reported more than $2 billion in profits during that time, according to company documents and Congressional staff members.

title: KIRKPATRICK ASSERTS SOME IN WASHINGTON DISTORTED HER VIEWS
description: Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, who will leave her United Nations post in March, said today that she was convinced that her views had been ''misunderstood'' and distorted by key Administration officials.

description: Darryl Dawkins, as talkative as ever and missing none of his charisma, returned to the Nets' lineup tonight. His appearance gave the Nets 12 players in uniform for only the second time this season, and they used the full roster to wallop the struggling Los Angeles Clippers, 122-99, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

They got a break on capital gains. The amount of time investors need to hold stocks or other assets for profits from their sale to be eligible for preferential tax treatment was reduced to six months and a day from one year and a day.

Fourteen of its baseball alumni are now in the big leagues, and most of them will return next week for the annual baseball game against the varsity team.

title: ARE CAR PHONES SAFE?
description: Has anyone stopped to consider the safety problems of car telephones? Advertisers of the new service, obviously trying to downplay the issue, show pictures of cool executives cruising down uncrowded highways, one hand on the wheel and one on the set. But what about the hard-driving, get-it-done- yesterday type fighting his way to work on a crowded urban highway? Will he see those distant brake lights while he's absorbed with closing a multimillion dollar European deal? A few years back, we had a President who was partisanly described as having trouble chewing gum and walking at the same time. Can we expect as much from the average driver?

title: ART: THE HUMAN FORM IN WORK OF 12 SCULPTORS
description: THE importance of ''Figures,'' an exhibition at P.S. 1 in Long Island City, Queens, is that it raises the issue of the human figure in contemporary sculpture. The influence of Minimalism was such that for a long time human imagery was almost inconceivable to sculptors with radical aims. In recent years, as modernism has lost much of its authority, the work of sculptors who started out with one foot in Minimalism, such as Joel Shapiro and Alain Kirili, has included increasingly direct references to the human figure. If their work is seen alongside some of the 1980's work of Nancy Graves, Bryan Hunt and John Duff, it is clear that a sculptural momentum toward the human figure has been building.

title: A JAZZ FESTIVAL AT HOME
description: Stay-at-homes can have a jazz piano solo festival this weekend that is not limited to those pianists who are in town. With records, the piano fare can be spread to include those who are playing elsewhere and even those who will never be heard again. A recorded sampling of the pianists who are in the clubs right now could include George Shearing's ''Live at the Cafe Carlyle'' (Concord Jazz), recorded last year with the bassist Don Thompson, who is still playing with Mr. Shearing; Barbara Carroll's ''At the Piano'' (Discovery), recorded in 1980 when she was at the Bemelmans Bar, where she is playing this weekend; Judy Carmichael, who is at Hanratty's, playing solos on ''Jazz Piano'' (Progressive); Terry Waldo, now at the Pizza Piazza, playing with a trio on ''Wizard of the Keyboard'' (Stomp Off), and Brooks Kerr, who is at Gregory's on Sunday from 5 to 10 P.M., with drum accompaniment on ''Soda Fountain Rag'' (Chiaroscuro). Pianists in the contemporary mainstream can be heard on Tommy Flanagan's ''Thelonica'' (Enja); Hank Jones's ''Tip Toe Tap Dance'' (Galaxy); Oscar Peterson's ''Live at the Northseip Toe Tap Dance'' (Pablo); Jimmy Rowles's ''Plays Ellington and Strayhorn'' (Columbia), and McCoy Tyner's ''Echoes of a Friend'' (Milestone). For piano solos with more traditional roots, there are Dave McKenna's ''Giant Strides'' (Concord Jazz); Ralph Sutton's ''Off the Cuff'' (Audiophile); Dick Wellstood's ''From Ragtime On'' (Chiaroscuro), and ''Teddy Wilson Revisits the Goodman Years'' (Storyville). A choice selection of the work of some of the great pianists of the past could include ''The Remarkable Art of Tatum'' (Audiofile) by Art Tatum; ''Fats Waller piano solos, 1929-1941'' (RCA Bluebird); ''Solo Recital, Montreaux Jazz Festival 1978'' (Pablo) by Mary Lou Williams; ''Quintessential Recording Session'' by Earl (Fatha) Hines (Chalroscuro); ''The Best of Erroll GArner'' (Mercury); ''Pure Monk''by The lonious Monk (Milestone), and ''Eloquence'' by Bill Evans (Fantasy.)

title: ART: ROBERT SMITHSON, PRE-MINIMAL PAINTINGS
description: ROBERT SMITHSON (1938-1973) is so well known as a sculptor of Minimal austerities in the mid-60's - and later, as founding hero of the Earth Art division of the movement - that his early work comes as a bit of a shock. He started out as a painter, and the high-key fantasies he produced - combining abstract with figurative elements - look very much at home in the context of today's neo-Expressionism. The work, so out of sync with Smithson's Minimal image, has been buried since a 1961 presentation of it at the Galleria George Lester in Rome. But now's the time, if ever. And at the Diane Brown Gallery, 100 Greene Street (through March 2), the first full presentation in this country of his pre- Minimal painting from 1959 to 1962, we see his poetic imagination in riotus bloom. Even as a teen-ager, Peter Halley reports in a catalogue essay, Smithson had tuned into Abstract Expressionism, and was also responsive to Dubuffet. We have no trouble discerning that in the painting ''Purgatory,'' in which a heavy, erratic grid on a white ground reveals through its openings fierce, crudely drawn faces and toothy mouths, a la de Kooning and Dubuffet. But, young, restless and a closet romantic, he took cues from everywhere. Pursuing further the mythic element in Abstract Expressionism, he looked into such European movements as Surrealism and Symbolism. An interest in Catholicism led him to the primitive mysticism of Byzantine painting. From Rome, which he visited in 1961, he got a concept of religion as theater, and William Burroughs's ''Naked Lunch'' acquainted him with the ''savagery'' of Pre-Columbian art.

title: Stage: 'Harrigan 'n Hart' Opens at the Longacre
description: MIDWAY Through Act I of ''Harigan 'n Hart,'' the new musical at the Longacre, the 19th century American vaudevillian Edward Harrigan imagines a brand new breed of entertainment. ''Something New, Something Different'' is the title of the song that Harrigan (Harry Groener) sings, and what it promises is a novel theatrical form in which populist storytelling, music and dance will all march hand in hand. What Harrigan is doing, of course, is launching a revolution that would lead to the modern Broadway musical as we now know it. Or as we usually know it. At ''Harrigan 'n Hart,'' no one need ever fear that something new or different might happen. One must worry instead whether anything will happen at all.

In it, David Attenborough looks at the world, and finds it inviting. In the first of 12 episodes, he shows us how the earth was formed, how continents moved, and how flora and fauna proliferated. We have seen this on television before, of course, but Mr. Attenborough's series is special. For one thing, it looks spectacular; for another, there is Mr. Attenborough, blessed with a quirky charm. title: L.I. GOLF CLUB EMBROILED IN BUILDER'S ZONING FIGHT
description: To an outsider, the fight to save the Hauppauge Country Club suggests a football game in which both sides wear the same color jerseys and run for the same goal posts: Everyone wants to save the club, but no one can agree how it is to be done. On one team is a developers group, the Holiday Organization, which entered into a contract to buy the 25-year-old golf course here in 1983 for $9 million. Last June, a principal in the Westbury, L.I., Company, Gerald Monter, filed a request with the Smithtown Planning Department, which has jurisdiction over Hauppauge, asking that the 135 acres of the course be rezoned to allow the construction of condominiums. Mr. Monter, a 63-year-old former high school shop teacher, argues that the only way to preserve the private golf course, which he says loses money each year, is by building on it. He proposed the construction of 300 condominium units (later reduced to 203 units) clustered on 50 acres around the club's fairways. The $45 million project would be marketed as a ''golf course community.'' Alternately, Mr. Monter said, if he were denied the rezoning he would destroy the course and build 203 single- family homes spread out across the full 135 acres. The latter option would require only minimal approval from the local authorities, since the current zoning, written many years ago, allows that level of density. Thus were the lines blurred. If local residents, many of whom opposed the development at the club, won their fight to keep the land from being rezoned, they might lose the club entirely.

title: POPE AND THE POOR: DOCTRINE DEFINED
description: When the Vatican issued its criticism of the theology of liberation last year, it promised to come up with its own version of the theology that would at once express orthodoxy and a commitment to the poor. During the first half of his trip through South America, Pope John Paul II has done just that. He has elaborated a social doctrine that, if ever put into effect, would change the face of Latin America.

title: Blalock in a Tie
description: -Jane Blalock missed a four-foot putt and bogyed her final hole today, dropping into a tie with Cathy Morse at five-under-par 67 in the opening round of the $200,000 Elizabeth Arden Classic at the Turnberry Isle Country Club.

title: DANCE: BALANCHINE'S 'TCHAIKOVSKY SUITE'
description: ''TCHAIKOVSKY SUITE NO. 3'' is one of George Balanchine's most romantic ballets and the New York City Ballet gave it an impassioned performance on Wednesday at the New York State Theater. First, there was the scrim, used for the first time in years. It gave the ballet's ballroom set a mistily haunted look in the first three movements, making the fourth movement's glittering light and costumes and sudden change of style even more brilliantly surprising.

title: SHORT-TERM RATES RISE SHARPLY

title: UNADULTERATED VIEWS OF MORT SAHL
description: In his 31-year career as a professional satirist and fearless skeptic, Mort Sahl has become legendary for bursting balloons on every side of the political and social spectrum. The 57- year-old comedian, who arrives at the Bottom Line tonight for two evenings, lives in Los Angeles and writes screenplays (the latest project is ''The Last Anchorman,'' for the director Karel Reisz). But he still comes out from time to time to play clubs.

title: WEINBERGER, IN ERROR, SAYS SOVIET DOWNED OWN MISSILE

title: Michigan Bank's Plans
description: The Michigan National Corporation's new chairman and chief executive said the bank intends to remain independent, despite merger overtures from Comerica Inc. ''Just because we receive an offer doesn't mean we have to accept it,'' Robert J. Mylod said Wednesday during the company's annual economic outlook conference. Comerica, the state's second-largest bank holding company, sent a letter to directors before Mr. Mylod's appointment offering to open merger discussions. Michigan National is the state's third-largest banking company.

title: ANGER AND DOUBT IN UPSTATE AUTO DEATH
description: It was near midnight when the Patrons of Husbandry, Chapter 1015, ended their meeting in the Wadhams Grange on Route 22 and drifted out into the clear, sub-zero cold of this tiny hamlet near Lake Champlain.

title: KNICKS BEATEN IN KING'S RETURN, 105-104
description: Spurred by the return of Bernard King after a three-week absence because of a sprained ankle, the Knicks responded with an inspired performance. But inspiration was not enough against the Los Angeles Lakers, who rallied from a 15-point deficit for a 105-104 victory tonight at the Forum.

title: NOMINEE TO HEAD INTERIOR DEPT. SAYS LAND SALES WILL BE STOPPED
description: Donald P. Hodel, President Reagan's nominee to be Interior Secretary, said today that the Administration's program to reduce the national debt by selling Federal land had not worked and would not be pursued.

title: COST OF GASOLINE AT LOWEST LEVEL IN RECENT YEARS
description: Gasoline prices in the New York metropolitan area have tumbled to their lowest levels in years, generating fierce competition among service stations as well as distributors.

title: MARKETING A PERFUME: THE STORY OF GIORGIO
description: The strong, sweet smell of Giorgio - ''the scent of the century,'' as its creators like to call it - wafted through the door of a Hotel Pierre suite the other day. Inside, Gale and Fred Hayman of Beverly Hills were waiting to talk about Giorgio, the phenomenon that has rocked the fragrance industry. They have been divorced for seven years but are still in business together.

title: COMP-U-CHECK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
HECLA MINING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $879,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary gain of $770,000 for the year. c-Net income. d-Including extraordinary gains of $389,000 for the quarter and $7,075,000 for the year.

title: A TOWN WITH 2 MAYORS FINDS MORE IS LESS
description: Stafford Township, a rural community of 11,000 people near the New Jersey shore, has two Mayors these days. And that has created no end of problems.

title: NORWEGIAN BRINGS VOLLEYBALL FINESSE
description: In Al Scates's 23 seasons as volleyball coach at U.C.L.A., a period

title: PONTIFF BRINGS HOPE TO ECUADOR SLUM
description: At 6:30 this morning, the crowds had already started to gather in this slum neighborhood on the edge of the Ecuadorean city of Guayaquil.

title: GUARDIAN INDUSTRIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MASLAND, C. H. & SONS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Actress Calls Fainting On 'Donahue' a Hoax
description: An actress said yesterday that she and two other women were hired by a professional hoaxer to faint on the ''Donahue'' television program last month.

title: ;   Stratus Computer And I.B.M. in Pact Stratus Computer Inc., a Marlborough, Mass., company, said it had signed a contract with the International Business Machines Corporation to sell it selected products of the Stratus fault-tolerant computer line and to grant I.B.M. the right to market the products. Fault-tolerant computers continue to function despite internal component breakdowns.
description: Terms of the deal were not disclosed. I.B.M. said no timetable had been established for when the company would market a fault-tolerant computer line.

title: ARNOLD J. MORWAY
description: Arnold J. Morway, a researcher for the Exxon Corporation who developed a waterproofing formula for tanks used during the D-Day invasion, died Tuesday at Rahway (N.J.) Hospital.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Company Briefs column in Business Day yesterday incorrectly described a project involving the Control Data Corporation and Wang Laboratories. It involves an integrated office system that will link Wang computer hardware with Control Data business software and data bases.

title: U.S. Reports Crackdown On Soviet Jews
description: Eleven Soviet Jews were arrested and four were sentenced to labor camps in the last six months as part of a major crackdown on Hebrew teachers and other Jewish cultural activists, the State Department said today.

title: ON THE UPPER WEST SIDE, THE SZECHUAN EMPIRE
description: Glenna Stein looked up from her showered chicken with ginger sauce, glanced at her husband, who was poking around with his chopsticks in scallops among black pearls, and said calmly, ''Arthur, I think I'm turning Sichuanese.''

title: Books of The Times;   Shades of Black Death
description: THE WALL OF THE PLAGUE. By Andre

title: HAWKEYE BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: SCREEN: 'TORCHLIGHT,' CAUTIONARY TALE ABOUT COCAINE
description: When Lillian (Pamela Sue Martin), a successful artist, meets Jake (Steve Railsback), a prosperous young architect, he is in the process of driving around Los Angeles delivering Valentine's Day bouquets to several different recipients. He presents one to Lillian, then whisks her to the top of his latest skyscraper, though she is afraid of heights. ''If it's not scary, it's not fun,'' he says, and apparently Lillian believes him. After they get married, Jake persuades Lillian to celebrate their anniversary while allowing him the kinky erotic privilege of piercing her ears.

title: MRFY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss c-After a gain of $249,000 from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting.

title: DEMOCRATS PICK A KENNEDY ALLY AS PARTY'S CHIEF
description: Paul G. Kirk Jr. was elected chairman of the Democratic National Committee today at a meeting marked by agreement among party leaders that the Democrats must reshape their message so as to remain the majority party.

title: TSI INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $290,000 from tax credits.

title: COMPUTER CONSOLES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $3.2 million for the quarter and year.

title: KOTT'S THEATER OF REINTERPRETATION
description: Though individual critics have had a dramatic effect on the theater of their time, Jan Kott is one of the few about whom it can legitimately be said that he has altered our perception of masterpieces.

title: DETECTION SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Bouncing Back
description: Mike Rozier, the 1983 Heisman Trophy winner who bought his way out of his contract with the defunct Pittsburgh Maulers presumably so he could jump to the National Football League, found himself back in the United States Football League yesterday after signing a multiyear contract with the Jacksonville Bulls. Rozier, who had failed to work out a satisfactory deal with the Houston Oilers, the team that holds his N.F.L. rights, will not be the only former Heisman Trophy winner in the Bulls' backfield.

title: Chess Match Delayed; Site Will Be Shifted
description: The chief referee of the world chess championship match said today that the 48th game had been postponed by preparations to relocate the contest.

title: CREDIT MARKETS ;   Interest Rates Increase Again
description: Short- and long-term interest rates rose for the third consecutive day, as securities dealers prepared for next week's heavy supply of new Treasury issues and a Federal Reserve monetary policy that seems to be less generous than early last month.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 13.

title: Seoul Leader to Meet With Reagan in April
description: The White House announced today that President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea would visit President Reagan sometime in April.

title: TAKE A NEW PATH, NADER URGES CONSUMERS
description: Ralph Nader was the main speaker before this week's annual conference of the Consumer Federation of America, ending a six-year absence from meetings of the organization.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;   Lubavitcher Leader Marks 35th Anniversary
description: On the 10th of Shebat in the year

title: Relief for City Budget Heartburn
description: Mayor Koch's financial plan for the next five years includes heady, billion-dollar housing initiatives, plans for educational expansion and enhanced transit safety. But at the heart of the plan's first segment, covering the year beginning in July, all seems tranquil. That presents a rare opportunity to reflect on how the city achieved such fiscal tranquillity, and why it won't last forever.

title: Letter: On Deregulation ;   Note the Shrinking Government
description: To the Editor:

title: British Oil Drilling Up
description: A record 106 oil and gas wells were drilled around Britain in 1984 and 23 of them struck fuel, the British Energy Minister, Alick Buchanan- Smith, said today.

title: JOBLESS RATE UP AS WOMEN SEEK WORK
description: With an unusually large number of women looking for jobs in January, the nation's unemployment rate rose two-tenths of a percentage point, to 7.3 percent, despite a solid gain in the number of people working, the Labor Department reported today.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Auto Racing

title: Murphy Studies Employee Buyout
description: The G.C. Murphy Company, apparently seeking to ward off a possible takeover attempt, said it was considering having an Employee Stock Ownership Plan buy the company for $42.50 a share, or $174 million.

title: MPSI SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: REBOUND FROM LONG DECLINE IS SEEN IN ST. LOUIS
description: There are many who say St. Louis has been in search of past glory ever since the end of the World's Fair of 1904, when ''Meet Me in St. Louis'' was being sung throughout the nation.

title: JUDGE HALTS ABORTION PLAN OF 2 CLINICS
description: Two Planned Parenthood clinics in upstate New York may not provide abortions, a judge ruled today in a suit initiated by the Roman Catholic Diocese of Albany.

title: LTV Loses $246 Million Including 2 Write-Offs
description: The LTV Corporation, citing unfavorable operating costs in its steel operations, reported yesterday that it had a loss of $246.7 million in the fourth quarter of 1984, compared with earnings of $7.5 million, or 4 cents a share, a year earlier.

title: CAROLINA FREIGHT CARRIERS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
EXECUTIVES OFFER TO BUY MULTIMEDIA
description: Multimedia Inc., a major broadcasting and publishing concern, said last night that a group including some of its top executives had offered to buy the company.

title: Pabst Pushes Tie To G. Heileman
description: The Pabst Brewing Company said that it had asked the Supreme Court to clear the company's proposed $70 million acquisition by the G. Heileman Brewing Company. The proposal currently is being challenged on antitrust grounds by the Stroh Brewery Company of Detroit and the Christian Schmidt Brewing Company of Philadelphia.

title: Give New Teachers a Boost
description: Governor Kean of New Jersey proposes to pay newly hired teachers a minimum of $18,500, creating perhaps the highest statewide minimum teachers' salary in the nation. The Legislature, which proposes its own similar increase, is ready to do something to attract more gifted teachers. It matters less who gets the credit than that this important measure gain the passage it deserves.

title: POPE RENEWS CALL FOR CHURCH UNITY
description: Pope John Paul II arrived this evening to begin his mission to the divided Peruvian Roman Catholic Church and delivered a pointed warning against unorthodoxy and ''passing ideologies.''

title: AUDIOTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: SURGE IN SPENDING ON SPACE WEAPONS SOUGHT BY REAGAN
description: President Reagan's military budget calls for a surge of new spending on nuclear weapons and space research with the aim of giving the United States a strong bargaining position in talks with the Soviet Union on arms control, according to budget documents prepared by the Pentagon.

title: TOP WEST GERMAN ARMS EXECUTIVE IS ASSASSINATED
description: The chief executive of a major West German manufacturer of engines and turbines for the military was shot and killed today by two assailants who came to the door of his home outside Munich. The terrorist group known as the Red Army Faction took responsibility.

title: SOUTH AFRICA TEMPORARILY HALTS THE RELOCATION OF BLACK SETTLEMENTS
description: The South African authorities announced today that they were temporarily halting the relocation of black people living in areas deemed to be for whites only. They said policies affecting the practice were under review.

title: New State Bank Head Reported Heather L. Ruth, a bond expert who participated in the rescue of New York City from bankruptcy, has been chosen by Governor Cuomo to become New York State Superintendent of Banks, according to banking sources.
description: Neither Mrs. Ruth nor state officials would comment on the reports. Mrs. Ruth is currently executive director of the Public Securities Association, a trade group of 300 banks and investment firms that underwrite and deal in municipal bonds and Government securities.

title: BOITANO WINS TITLE IN FIGURE SKATING
description: Brian Boitano performed seven triple jumps tonight and won the men's title at the United States Figure Skating Championships.

title: CINCINNATI MICROWAVE reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary non-cash charge of $1,019,000 for penalty on early retirement of bank debt. Share earnings for the previous year are not available because the company went public in December 1983.

title: SRI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income. The company said revenue figures include net investment income of $8,565,000 for the latest quarter, $32,496,000 for the latest year, $7,807,000 for the 1983 quarter, and $29,759,000 for the 1983 year.

title: KANSAS GAS AND ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Payment Due
description: Sid Fernandez, the Mets' lefthanded pitcher who compiled a 6-6 record with a 3.50 earned run average after being called up from the minors last July, signed a one-year contract that is expected to bring him about $80,000, double the major league minimum he made last year. The contract leaves the Mets with 17 unsigned players, including

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A chart in Business Day yesterday listing profits of the major military contractors and the taxes they paid misstated those of the Martin Marietta Corporation. The company earned $490.2 million from 1981 to 1983 and got tax refunds totaling $94.2 million.

title: CLARK EQUIPMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $1,801,000 for the quarter and $4,768,000 for the year.

title: STAGE: IN NEW HAVEN, 'THE COMMON PURSUIT'
description: Picture ''The Big Chill'' populated by wildly fictionalized caricatures of Kenneth Tynan, Ian Hamilton and Clive James - or ''Merrily We Roll Along'' transplanted to London's toniest literary warrens - and you'll have an idea of the indecent pleasures to be had in Simon Gray's new play, ''The Common Pursuit.''

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;    Fishcakes for Charity
description: Among the cooks at tommorow's annual ''Men Who Cook'' benefit for the Children's Art Carnival is City Councilman Frederick E. Samuel.

title: BENJAMIN R. BRITT JR.
description: Benjamin R. Britt Jr., a former marketing and advertising executive, died of a heart attack last Saturday at his home in Manhattan.

title: DIRECTORS GUILD OF AMERIAC ANNOUNCES AWARD NOMINEES
description: The Directors Guild of America announced the five nominees for its 1984 award today. The winner of the Guild competition almost always also wins the Academy Award for best director.

title: FIRSTGULF BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SCOUTING ;   Making the Team
description: Any day now, baseball players will be flocking to Arizona and Florida for spring training. And any day now, they will be joined by this year's class of aspiring umpires, including three pioneers of sorts: the first graduates of the New York School of Umpiring to be selected for the major leagues' evaluation camp.

title: GOD'S PARTY
description: To the Editor:

title: A NEW PARTY LEADER
description: In choosing Paul G. Kirk Jr. today as the new chairman of the Democratic National Committee, party leaders have turned to a man who has been closely identified with the kind of liberal politics that many Democrats now blame for their party's slippage with voters. That Mr. Kirk, a former aide to Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, could overcome such a handicap is seen by some as a testament to his political skills and the credibility he has established with party leaders, including many in the South.

title: RESULTS OF HOLIDAY SACRIFICES MEAN MORE GIFTS FOR NEEDIEST
description: Although the festivities are past, The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund continues to receive contributions that represent the savings from holiday gifts not given or greeting cards not exchanged.

title: CONSUMER SATURDAY
description: If the New York State Public Service Commission has its way, customers of the Consolidated Edison Company will soon be receiving more detailed, less confusing bills. The commission is developing a ''plain language'' utility bill, which it hopes will answer customers' questions and reduce their complaints.

description: Dwayne (Pearl) Washington scored

title: YEAR'S CONSTRUCTION OUTLAYS UP 19%
description: Construction spending rose 19 percent last year, the biggest yearly increase in more than three decades, the Government reported today.

title: Texaco Halts Sale
description: Texaco Inc. said it had terminated the proposed sale of some agribusiness properties it acquired in its acquisition of the Getty Oil Company.

title: DESIRE UNDER THE PALMS
description: HALLANDALE, Fla.

title: South African Rebels Assail Terms for Mandela's Release
description: The outlawed black nationalist organization of the jailed South African black leader Nelson Mandela today denounced the South African President's condition that Mr. Mandela would be freed only if he disavows the use of violence against apartheid.

description: Trans World Airlines yesterday opened the United States' first trans- Atlantic passenger service using planes powered by only two engines. In the past, United States airlines have always used three- and four-engine craft on flights to Europe.

description: A car bomb exploded outside a crowded mosque in the northern city of Tripoli during Friday prayers today, killing at least 10 people, the police said, and wounding 60, many seriously.

description: Under sometimes intense cross-examination, the second child to testify about sexual abuse at the Virginia McMartin Preschool stuck to his story today that he had been repeatedly molested there.

title: 13 DONOR NATIONS FORM AFRICA FUND WITH WORLD BANK
description: A group of 13 industrialized nations and the World Bank today pledged more than a billion dollars to establish a new fund for long-term economic help to African nations suffering from famine and economic collapse.

title: 'DALLAS' STILL DOMINATES U.S. TELEVISION RATINGS
description: Dallas'' continues to dominate the the American airwaves.

title: RULING ALLOWS CUBAN OUSTER
description: Associate Justice William H. Rehnquist of the Supreme Court late today refused to block the Federal Government's imminent deportation of a group of illegal immigrants from Cuba being held in the Federal Penitentiary in Atlanta.

title: MILLER AND ARCHER LEADING IN CROSBY
description: Johnny Miller, whose new long- shafted putter helped him take sole possession of the first-round Thursday, did not have quite the same success with it today. Miller bogeyed the 18th hole at Pebble Beach and fell into a tie for the lead with George Archer after two rounds of the 44th Bing Crosby National Pro-Am.

title: Stock Margin Laws Are Obsolete
description: The Federal Reserve Board wants Government to stop regulating stock market ''margin requirements,'' which limit the amounts investors can borrow when buying stock. The Fed thinks the industry can set its own loan limits subject to Federal scrutiny. It's a sensible proposal. Markets and investors have radically changed since margin limits were legislated after the 1929 crash.

description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 42.

title: 3d Member of Family Slain in Ulster Attack
description: Guerrillas shot and killed a part-time soldier today as he sat in a school bus waiting to take children swimming.

title: CHERIMOYA: EXOTIC AND COSTLY TREAT FROM WEST
description: To some it tastes like a pina colada without rum; to others, a cross between a strawberry and a pineapple. For natives of the Caribbean the cherimoya is a fruit that can be plucked from backyard trees for nothing. For New Yorkers, it is one of the most expensive fruits on the market, topping even such luxuries as cherries in January and peaches in December. But it is delicious.

title: U.S. SAYS SOVIET VIOLATES ABM TREATY
description: The Reagan Administration, in a report to Congress, charged the Soviet Union today with a violation of a 1972 treaty and expressed concern that Moscow was preparing a nationwide defense against missiles.

title: Get on the Mule Train
description: It may be that a mule is an animal

title: Frank Scott of Canada, A Politician and a Poet
description: Frank Scott, a Canadian politician, award-winning poet and former dean of the McGill University Law School, died Thursday at his home in Montreal. He was 85 years old.

title: Hundreds in Florida Battle Giant Brushfires
description: Nearly 500 firefighters, some using bulldozers, struggled today to contain a 4,000-acre brush fire in southwest Florida that destroyed 12 homes and forced evacuation of 200 people.

title: OFFICER INDICTED IN BRONX SLAYING BACK ON PAYROLL
description: The police officer who was indicted for manslaughter on Thursday in the death of Eleanor Bumpurs was restored to the Police Department payroll yesterday, a day after his suspension without pay.

title: ETHIOPIA WILL REPORTEDLY ARM FOOD CONVOYS
description: Ethiopia plans to use armed convoys to transport famine-relief supplies into its northern provinces, where guerrillas have been active, a high-ranking United Nations official said here today.

title: Signs of Cyanide Poisoning Reported Showing Up in India
description: Survivors of a poison gas leak at a Union Carbide pesticide plant in Bhopal are showing signs of cyanide poisoning, a doctor investigating the aftereffects of the chemical disaster said today.

title: HISTORY ISN'T WHAT IT ONCE WAS
description: With the passage of time, the past recedes from the present. It becomes more remote. Isn't that how we usually think about history (when we think about it at all)? I wonder.

title: THE PRESS, THE HOUSE, THEN BACK
description: When Richard D. (Max) McCarthy of The Buffalo News strolled into the House chamber a few years ago, no one in Congress so much as raised an eyebrow over his presence in a place off- limits to reporters.

description: A dispatch Jan. 24 from Khartoum, the Sudan, on rebel charges that Ethiopia killed a group of prisoners incorrectly characterized the Ethiopian city where the incident reportedly occurred. The city, Asmara, is inland from the Red Sea.

description: Brazil's President-elect, Tancredo Neves, today called on the United States to reduce its ''very cruel'' interest rates.

description: Harry Usher, who took office yesterday as the new commissioner of the United States Football League, has one distinction already: a clause in his three-year contract that will give him a small percentage of the revenues generated by the next television contract the U.S.F.L. signs with a major network.

title: TAFT TO BUY 12 STATIONS FROM GULF BROADCAST
description: The Taft Broadcasting Company said yesterday that it had agreed to buy five TV stations and seven radio stations from the Gulf Broadcast Company of Dallas for $755 million.

title: GENERALS' NAYLOR OUT FOR YEAR
description: The Generals and one of their players, Frank Naylor, parted company today at the airport in Orlando, Fla. The Generals then flew here for the opening exhibition game against the Memphis Showboats Saturday as Naylor, on crutches with his left leg in a cast, flew home to Philadelphia. He will not be playing football again this year.

title: Cosmos Finances Are in Question
description: Giorgio Chinaglia, the president of the Cosmos, indicated yesterday that the team was operating with money it had deposited in a letter of credit when it joined the Major Indoor Soccer League, and he acknowledged that the team's financial condition was ''not the rosiest.''

title: SUIT ON TOY PLANT ENDED IN MIDWEST
description: The Hasbro- Bradley toy company has agreed to keep a Playskool factory operating with 100 workers until November while it helps retrain and find new jobs for 580 others laid off from the plant.

description: Helgi Tomasson, the choreographer and principal dancer with the New York City Ballet, has been named to direct the San Francisco Ballet, effective in June. Mr. Tomasson will serve under a three-year contract.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: PUTTING IT TOGETHER Some time ago Dick Hyman, the man who plays piano so charmingly and composes just as nicely for Woody Allen films, wrote an ambitious jazz concerto and called it ''Concerto Electro.'' The movements were played in one place or another but no one ever sat down to perform it all at once in New York City, a state of affairs that will be rectified today at 8 P.M. at the Third Street Music School Settlement, 235 East 11th Street, between Second and Third Avenues (777-3240).

title: XTRA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $954,000 from discontinued operations.

title: THAIS PLAY DOWN HANOI'S PROPOSALS TO U.N. CHIEF
description: The Thai Government today dismissed as ''nothing new'' Vietnam's proposals to Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar on ways to negotiate an end to the war in Cambodia.

title: SCOUTING ;   Coast to Coast
description: It may not be as well known as the Tour de France (2,500 miles on bicycle) and it may not be as official as the new Tour de Tropicana (1,200 miles). But the third annual Race Across America is a bicycle saga that is more of a coast-to-coast ordeal: 3,047 miles from the pier in Huntington Beach, Calif., to the boardwalk in Atlantic City.

title: COPING WITH A STRONG DOLLAR
description: After four years of watching from the sidelines as the dollar soared, the Federal Government has grown concerned enough over the dollar's value that it has been making efforts to nudge it lower. Both the lowering of interest rates and the recent direct intervention in the currency markets suggest a shift in policy.

title: James Wright, Ex-Aide O
description: James Francis Wright, former executive director of the Delaware River Basin Commission, died of cardiac arrest Tuesday in Santa Rosa, Calif. He was 70 years old and lived in Santa Rosa.

title: REAGAN BUDGET TO SHOW DEFICIT SHORT OF TARGET
description: The budget President Reagan will send to Congress next Monday shows the deficit declining to $144.4 billion in the fiscal year 1988, far short of the Administration's target of $100 billion, according to budget documents obtained today.

title: Bumped, Molinari Says
description: Representative Guy Molinari, Republican of Staten Island, had a reputation as a hard worker as the ranking Republican on the Investigations and Oversight Subcommittee of the House Public Works and Transportation Committee, particularly in investigations of charges of mismanagement of toxic waste programs of the Environmental Protection Agency under Anne McGill Burford as Administrator, and of the safety practices of the Federal Aviation Commission and the airline industry.

title: FLUTIE'S CLAUSES SEEM TO BE COMPLETE
description: After weeks of haggling that involved as many as eight lawyers in one marathon session, the great Doug Flutie contract sweepstakes will come to a close Tuesday when the Generals unveil their new quarterback in the Trump Tower. But the two sides still could not agree late yesterday on whether the contract would be worth $5 million or $7 million over the next five years.

title: BANKS AND BRAZIL RESOLVE BIG ISSUES
description: Brazil and its bank creditors achieved a breakthrough yesterday in talks on stretching out repayments for about half of Brazil's $98 billion debt, the largest in the developing world.

title: David Miron, the First Israeli On the U.N. Secretariat Staff
description: David Miron, the first Israeli on the staff of the United Nations Secretariat and a specialist in management and administration, died Monday of a heart attack at his home in Geneva. He was 68 years old.

title: Storage Chief Cites Gains
description: The new chairman of the Storage Technology Corporation, Ryal R. Poppa, said yesterday that the company's cash position has improved in the last three months, brightening the company's prospects of emerging from Chapter 11.

title: WARNACO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
description: Results for 1984 include the operations of Olga Co. since its acquisition on June 3, 1984.

TNP ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
EASTMET CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

description: The original copy of the Emancipation Proclamation, handwritten by President Abraham Lincoln, will be on display all this month at the New York State Museum, on Empire State Plaza in Albany.

title: FALLS CITY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SCOUTING ;   The Fast Golfer
description: Lanny Wadkins is not only a good golfer but a fast one, among of the fastest on the PGA Tour. And in many tournaments these days, he feels like a man in a traffic jam.

title: WOMEN'S GRIEF GIVES RISE TO ACTIVISM IN EL SALVADOR
description: Elvia Cosme Hernandez describes herself in a soft voice as a typical mother of two young children, except that, she says, her husband, sister, uncle and cousin were either killed by Salvadoran Government security forces or made to ''disappear.''

title: RULES BROADENED TO EASE FARM DEBT
description: The Reagan Administration, bowing to demands of farm state congressmen, agreed today to make it easier for farmers to obtain Federal help in reducing their debts and avoiding default.

title: Coghlan Wins
description: Eamonn Coghlan won the mile in 3 minutes 59.05 seconds, and Mark McKoy of Canada beat Roger Kingdom, the American Olympic gold medalist, in the 50-yard hurdles at The Toronto Star track meet tonight. McKoy was timed in 5.95 seconds. Kingdom was second in 6.05.

title: BROADVIEW FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a gain of $1,878,480 for the quarter and year from the distribution of Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. preferred stock. c-Including a tax credit of $3,740,000 for the quarter and year.

WESTMORELAND COAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a writeoff of coal assets amounting to $57,500,000. c-Net income.

description: Mike Giomi, the Indiana University basketball player who was dismissed from the squad by

title: Staten Island Bird Walk
description: Cardinals, blue jays, chickadees, mourning doves and sparrows are among the species that may be sighted on a bird walk tomorrow morning from 9 to 11 at the Clay Pit Ponds State Park Preserve, Carlin Street and Sharrotts Road, in Charleston, S.I. Participants should dress warmly and bring binoculars. There is no charge, and the walk takes place rain or shine. Registration is required: (718) 967-1976.

title: CNA INCOME SHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CITY JOBLESS RATE UP SLIGHTLY
description: The unemployment rate rose slightly in New York City last month, although less than expected, as holiday jobs ended and the cold weather slowed outdoor construction, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics said yesterday.

title: Bridge:Is It Duplicate or Rubber? Number of Deals Is a Clue
description: The number of deals that are played in any form of duplicate bridge is predetermined. The number in a social bridge game is flexible and varies with circumstances, although on this side of the Atlantic it is usually divisible by four.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;   Bellamy Lineup Changes
description: Even before her unofficial mayoral

title: ZYGO CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Inmates Take Hostages At Indiana Reformatory
description: Inmates in the maximum security section of the Indiana Reformatory, armed with homemade weapons and angered over what they said was abuse of prisoners, took two employees hostage today. Seven guards and two prisoners were wounded.

title: CENTRAL LOUISIANA ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BOY, 4, RESCUES FATHER
description: Brandon Bowen, a 4-year- old who loves tinkering with the jack in the family garage, used the device to save his father, who had been pinned under a two-ton truck.

title: U.S. REPORTED TO WEIGH OPEN AID IF NICARAGUA'S REBELS CAN UNIFY
description: The Reagan Administration is exploring the possibility of encouraging Nicaraguan rebel groups to form an umbrella organization that could openly receive aid from the United States, according to a well-placed official on Capitol Hill.

description: Facing Federal drug charges can be a distracting experience, but apparently not for

title: BRUNSWICK MAKES BIG COMEBACK
description: Three years ago, the Brunswick Corporation was an object of scorn on Wall Street. To fend off a takeover attempt by the Whittaker Corporation, Brunswick had been forced to get rid of its medical products division in a $425 million stock swap with the American Home Products Corporation.

title: KEYSTONE CAMERA PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from operations sold or held for sale of $1,745,000 for the quarter and $3,715,000 for the year, and gains from the forgiveness of debt of $1,685,000 for the quarter and year. c-Net loss.

title: May Stores Stock Purchased The May Department Stores Company, which has been a rumored takeover target, said the Crown Books Corporation and certain affiliates had purchased fewer than 1 percent of May's common shares. James Abrams, vice president for corporate communications, said, however, ''We don't know of any interest by Crown to purchase more of May's shares.''
description: Crown Books, a retail discounter of books, is jointly owned by the Dart Drug Company of Landover, Md. and Thrifty Drugs.

title: Austrian Official Wins A No-Confidence Vote
description: Defense Minister Friedhelm Frischenschlager, who greeted a war criminal released by Italy with a handshake last week, survived a no-confidence vote in a special session of Parliament today.

title: Roberta Ann Caplan to Wed George Baumgarten
description: Dr. and Mrs. Paul S. Caplan of Pittsburgh have announced the engagement of their daughter Roberta Ann Caplan to George Alan Baumgarten, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry W. Baumgarten of New York. An April wedding is planned.

title: GATEWAY TENANTS SUE OVER RENTS
description: CONTENDING that the Department of Housing and Urban Development was allowing rents at Gateway Plaza in Battery Park City to rise to free-market levels, the tenants' association there has brought suit in Federal Court asking that the development's 1,712 apartments be subject to Mitchell-Lama rent regulations.

title:
CAMERA;

TONING TECHNIQUES FOR UNUSUAL PRINTS
description: Sandy Sorlien is a freelance photographer and writer. Most people have seen monotone photographs in shades of sepia or brown either in museums or books. Although many of these pictures were made in the 19th and early 20th centuries, the brown color is not due to aging or yellowing. Rather, the original image was brown from the sensitizing and developing techniques used in those days.

title: Soviet Denies Violating 3 Arms-Control Pacts
description: The Soviet Government press agency Tass today denied United States accusations that Moscow had violated arms agreements, branding the allegations as unfounded and designed to complicate future negotiations.

title: CLASSIC 60'S SOUL RETURNS TO THE MARKETPLACE
description: Advances in synthesizer and keyboard technology have effectively remade the sound of pop music in recent years, but when it comes to pop singing, the standards set by soul music some 20 years ago remain unsurpassed. Pop singers with roots in the 60's, Mick Jagger or John Fogerty, for example, still measure their performance by the yardstick of 60's soul singers like Solomon Burke or Otis Redding. More surprising, even today's younger pop stylists - Prince, Michael Jackson - look to the great soul singers for inspiration.

title: SWEDEN PLANS NEW 'COLONIAL' TIES
description: SALEM NEARLY 350 years after their ancestors were displaced in the New World by the Dutch, representatives of Swedish business interests are preparing to trade again with the natives, although their original clients, the Indians, are long gone.

title: WRESTLING WITH THE LAW OF GOD
description: THE GATE BEHIND THE WALL A Pilgrimage to Jerusalem. By Samuel Heilman. 201 pp. New York: Summit Books. $15.95.

title: Poll Says 72% of Americans Favor Executing Murderers
description: Seventy-two percent of Americans interviewed recently favored executing murderers, the highest percentage since 1936, according to the Gallup Poll. Support has risen sharply since 1966, when 42 percent of those interviewed by Gallup favored the death penalty.

title:
GARDENING;

GROUND COVERS FOR LIGHT SHADE
description: WHEN talking about ground covers for shade, we are not talking about difficult shade that is dark and dense. Nor are we talking about a site with intense competition from shallow roots.

title: TOPICS
description: ''ENGINEER to conductor - if you can hear me, give me a Number One. Waiting for the go- ahead.'' My first thought after a busy Monday is that my life will fritter away beneath the catacombs of Manhattan on a train struggling to emerge from the tunnel that links Penn Station to the rest of humanity.

title: A MASTER OF COMPROMISE TAPPED FOR THE TREASURY
description: WASHINGTON ''ARE you listening, Darman?'' the news reporter shouted at the walls inside the White House.

title: Foreigners Barred in Punjab
description: India extended curbs on foreigners' entering Punjab state today until April 2, saying they could not enter without permission. The measure has been in force since troops took control of the state in June to end a violent campaign by Sikh militants for a separate nation.

title: TOSE SAID TO FACE NEW PERIL
description: If Leonard Tose fails to demonstrate within the next six weeks his ability to retire two outstanding loans from a California bank, he may lose his majority ownership of the Philadelphia Eagles, several National Football League executives say.

title: Poll Finds 62% Favor President at New Term
description: In the first month of President Reagan's second term, 62 percent of the public approves of his performance in office and 29 percent disapproves, according to a Gallup Poll of 1,523 adults taken Jan. 11-14. The President received a similar rating immediately after his re-election in November.

title: MOST FELONS PUT ON PROBATION STILL A THREAT, RESEARCH FINDS
description: The majority of felons who are released on probation rather than sent to prison pose a serious threat to public safety, a Rand Corporation report said today.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN;
description: JOAN LEE FAUST This Week:

title:
MEN'S STYLE;

NEW DIRECTIONS
description: THE CONSERVATIVE DRESS OF a successful French businessman makes a properly pin-striped Wall Street banker look almost jaunty by comparison. And for the upwardly mobile younger Frenchman, there is le style anglais , an English look of gray flannel trousers, well-cut hacking jacket, button-down shirts.

title: A Korean Exile's Long Journey Home
description: Sanford J. Ungar's article, ''A Korean Exile's Long Journey Home'' (Dec. 23), offers an informative account not only of South Korean opposition leader Kim Dae Jung but also of the recent political history of the divided nation. It contains, however, a few assertions that require elaboration.

title: WITH VICTORY IN MT. VERNON, DEMOCRATS LOOK AHEAD
description: ''WHEN we sent out the announcements for this victory breakfast,'' Thomas F. Carty, the Democratic Party's county chairman said last Sunday, ''some wags wanted to know what we had won. Well, the people of Mount Vernon gave us the purpose last Friday.''
