title: MARCOS ORDERS REVIEW ON JAILING OF DIRECTOR
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos, responding to pressure from opposition groups, has ordered a review of subversion charges against an award-winning film director whose movies deal with anti-Government themes.

title: FRESH READINGS, POLEMICAL ASIDES
description: Germaine Bree, the author of ''Twentieth Century French Literature,'' is working on a book about French writers since 1950. THE INNOCENT EYE

title: ADAPTING TO THE HIGH COST OF HOUSING
description: ''I DEEPLY resent being driven out of Morningside Heights,'' said Michael Jahn, an author of 30 mystery novels and a public-relations specialist. ''I've been here for 18 years - the characters in my book, 'Night Rituals,' are based on people I know from this neighborhood.

title: CONNORS FALLS, 6-1, 6-4
description: Stefan Edberg upset top-seeded Jimmy Connors today in the semifinals of the $315,000 National Indoor tennis champhionships. The 19-year-old Swede controlled the match from the first serve to win by 6-1, 6-4.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A work by Piero della Francesca was incorrectly described in a caption as being in the Town Hall of Sansepolcro (Travel, Dec. 16). The work, a detail from Piero's fresco cycle of the Legend of the True Cross, is in the Church of San Francesco in Arezzo.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article about compact trucks last Sunday in section 12, the special automobile section distributed in New York City and the suburbs, misidentified an analyst for Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc. He is Harvey Heinbach.

title: STAGE: A NEW LOOK AT 7 DEADLY SINS
description: Nagle Jackson's ''Faustus in Hell,'' a circumnavigation of the world of John Faustus, friends and temptors, begins on an enticing note of self-mockery. Barry Boys, playing Mephistophilis as a cynic of the arched-eyebrow school, informs us that Hell is a theater and that we are about to see the 73,452d performance of a play that will run ''until eternity.''

title: HOMICIDE COUNTS DROPPED FOR DOCTOR IN ABORTION OF 32-WEEK FETUS
description: Murder and involuntary manslaughter charges against an obstetrician who aborted a 32-week fetus have been dropped, but he has been ordered to face lesser felony charges.

title: PILOBOLUS EXPANDS ITS DRAMATIC FORMS
description: ''Pilobolus doesn't leap forward, it ectoplasms its way along,'' declares Jonathan Wolken, one of the founding directors of the free-wheeling dance troupe that returns to New York this week after a three-year absence. ''True to our biologic nature,'' he adds (the company's namesake is a vigorous genus of fungi that thrives on horse manure), ''we grow amoeba-like. We don't solve problems, we engulf them.''

title: TOPICS
description: The holidays are over. On the table where red and white carnations nodded, now slender spears of narcissus bloom. The guests have vanished.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: THIS year may be a historic one for wildlife enthusiasts in New Jersey. It is likely that the osprey, a large brown- and-white fish hawk once common in coastal areas, will become the first species to be removed from the state's 11-year-old endangered species list.

title: A DRIVE-IN OASIS FOR SUBURBANITES
description: IN our struggle with the stresses

title: WHAT'S DOING IN PALM SPRINGS
description: In the southern California resort of Palm Springs, one can buy a custom- made bikini ($45) or rent a private villa with swimming pool, tennis court, indoor and outdoor whirlpools and complimentary luxury car ($460 a day).

title: 2 Homosexual Students Win Ruling on Military
description: The Philadelphia Commission on Human Relations has decided that Temple University helped the United States military services discriminate against two homosexual students.

title: BLACKWOOD OUTLINES GOALS AS MAYOR
description: MOUNT VERNON

title: ON THE JOYS AND STRESSES OF A NO. 1 RANK
description: WHEN St. John's moved into first place this week in the national polls, the sports fans of the city, reputedly sophisticated, blase, and pro-oriented, donned their raccoon coats, dusted off the white bucks and chanted, ''We're No. 1.''

title: Emergency Medical Service Defended
description: Concerning the article ''Medical Services Under Scrutiny'' (Jan. 13), I would like to point out that Nassau County, on balance, has excellent emergency medical service. The system is not perfect.

title: State Agency Applauded for Role
description: I would like to applaud the state Department of Human Services for advancing the care of mentally troubled youth.

title: VERBATIM: MEESE ON THE STAND
description: 'I feel that for over 25 years every act that I have done, every conscious effort that I have made, has been to uphold the highest standard of any position in public or in private life. If I had the chance to do over some of the things that we've talked about, I would do them over.

title: TIGHTENING RULES ON RENTING
description: EVER since condominium and cooperative ownership gained wide popular acceptance a decade or so ago, owners and their managers have been trying to formulate equitable policies on absentee investors and their tenants.

title: THE LASTING IMPACT OF GERALDINE FERRARO
description: With respect to Geraldine Ferraro's dictum to her husband that ''My daughters will each have an extra trust fund on Monday morning,'' reported in Maureen Dowd's article, I wonder if, in the spirit of equity, Mrs. Ferraro would advocate her daughters' being obliged to register for possible conscription for combat service. Her son must. BURTON SEIWELL

title: POLICE WILL HUNT DRUGS IN SCHOOLS
description: Undercover police officers will be allowed into the city's public schools to investigate suspected drug dealing under a plan agreed to by the Police Department and Board of Education.

title: Pedroza Keeps W.B.A. Title
description: Eusebio Pedroza successfully defended his World Boxing Association featherweight title today with a 15-round decision over his fellow Panamanian Jorge Lujan.

title: SPECIAL PROGRAMS BID FOR ALL GIFTED PUPILS
description: LAST year, a Wallingford boy who had run away from home was found sleeping in a classroom where he had taken a class for gifted students. He told the police it was the only place where he had ever felt understood.

title: Holiday Displays In Public Schools
description: Francis Griffith's letter to the Long Island editor (Jan. 13) about American Jewish Congress and the Nassau Civil Liberties Union's concern for religious holiday celebrations in public schools requires our clarification.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: Twenty years ago, when Meredith Monk started putting together dreamlike dances with music based on repetition and non- European vocal techniques, she was out on the fringes of the avant-garde. She was making multi-media events before the term ''performance art'' was coined - pieces that combined dance, film, slides and original tunes - and looking toward Far Eastern and Eastern European musical models. She has been called a ''collagist,'' a ''fabulist choreographer,'' ''a master of the spectacular'' and a creator of ''ongoing process theater.''

title: U.S. Delays Sales of Arms To Middle East
description: The Reagan Administration decided last week that it was better to alienate Saudi Arabia than Congress. Sales of new arms to the Middle East, including 40 F-15's to the Saudis, will be held up for several months pending a review of how peace and stability are affected by arms shipments to the region.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A front-page caption last Sunday with a picture about the Republic Day parade in India incorrectly identified one woman watching the parade. She was Sonia Gandhi, wife of Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi.

title: BERGEN SEEKING FUNDS
description: Bergen County transportation officials are applying for Federal funds to rehabilitate the 62-year-old Market Street Bridge over the Passaic River in Elmwood Park.

title: R. Bradlee Boal Wed To Elizabeth A. Green
description: Elizabeth A. Green, the daughter of Katherine A. Cooney of Stony Point, N.Y., and the late Joseph A. Cooney, was married yesterday to R. Bradlee Boal, the son of Howard W. Boal of Southbridge, Mass., and the late Thayne Lee Boal. Justice Vincent A. Gurahian of the New York State Supreme Court performed the ceremony in the chapel at the Church Center for the United Nations.

title: Christy Anne Eberstadt, Musicians' Agent, Weds
description: The Brick Presbyterian Church was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Christy Anne Eberstadt, a daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Frank V. Deegan of Brentwood, Calif., and Chester Van Alen Murray, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Emmet Van Alen Murray of Greenwich, Conn., and Quogue, L.I. The Rev. Herbert B. Anderson performed the ceremonmy.

title: LEADERS OF ALIEN SANCTUARY DRIVE SAY INDICTMENTS POSE CHURCH-STATE ISSUE
description: The Government says that when it began a 10- month undercover operation this month that resulted in the indictment of 16 church workers on 71 counts of transporting and harboring illegal aliens it was nothing more than routine law enforcement.

title: CONCERT SERIES FILL SCHOOLS, LIBRARIES
description: schools, conservatories, the network of public libraries - are also likely sources of public concerts of high interest and at low, or no, cost.

title: HELP FROM A FLYING THINK TANK
description: -estate lawyer from White Plains, a planner from Salt Lake City, an architect from Houston, an economist from Boston, a landscape architect from Denver, and a government professor from Harvard, fly to a small isolated city in southeastern New Mexico for a four-day stay; take them on plane, boat and bus tours around the city; interview public officials, community leaders, students, businessmen and other local residents; take 2,000 photographs; hold a public hearing in a jam-packed auditorium; lock them in a room for 48 hours and ask them to prepare a 100- page comprehensive report analyzing the city, its people, its problems and make major recommendations in regard to the future of the city for the next 50 years; hold an evening public meeting to discuss the report; fly out of the city the very next morning on the first plane - and what do you have? A Rudat, of course.

title: HELP IN MANAGING THE ELECTRONIC DESK
description: ABOUT the time that the Osborne Computer Corporation was making its big splash with the first

title: The Trouble With the Joint Chiefs
description: Next to the President, the chiefs of the armed forces are the highest ranking officers. Their power is tightly confined by making them a committee, the Joint Chiefs of Staff, allowed only to advise the President and Secretary of Defense. But the price of protecting civilian control in that way is a command system that creaks with inefficiency.

title: Q&A
description: Question:

title: Jackie Collins Case
description: Jackie Collins, the author, sued the Flynt Distributing Company for invasion of privacy, charging that a magazine it distributed, Adelina, had published a nude photograph and had incorrectly identified the woman pictured as Miss Collins. The author's lawyer said the photo had been republished twice despite a court order against this.

title: RECAPTURING THE SCENT OF MEMORIES
description: My earliest memory as a traveler is, curiously enough, not a sight, but a smell: the overpowering and, to me (then age 6) totally captivating smell of chocolate that ravished my nostrils as my parents drove our ancient Ford touring car through the town of Hershey, Pa. Now, many decades later, I have only to sniff - or even just glimpse - a Hershey bar, and that trip, the old Ford, return vividly. And I recall a whole series of family excursions in that car, with dramatic scenes of struggle as, in the menace of a summer storm, we all piled out to wrestle the top up or to snap on the pesky isinglass windows.

title: HOCKEY REMAINS HIS GAME - AT 76
description: EVERY now and then, after being checked into the boards or while nursing some soreness after a game, Steve Bekasi thinks of retiring as a hockey player. But those are fleeting thoughts, and week after week, from November until June, Mr. Bekasi returns to the ice to play the game he still loves at the age of 76.

title: STAFF CHALLENGES NUCLEAR OFFICIAL
description: The General Public Utilities Corporation's struggle to reopen its undamaged nuclear reactor at Three Mile Island has come under a new cloud.

title: Watchdog Gets Bitten
description: In a case directly involving the Civil Rights Commission, the Government last week decided not to appeal the conviction of the commission's Atlanta regional office of violating the Federal Equal Pay Act by paying a female employee less than male coworkers with nearly identical jobs.

title: Deportations Upheld
description: The Reagan Administration last week got a green light to begin deporting the more than 1,500 Cubans who arrived from the Cuban port of Mariel in 1980 and wound up in the Atlanta penitentiary.

title: Jets Finally Win In Boston Garden
description: Brian Mullen set up goals by Randy Carlyle and Dale Hawerchuk less than 2 minutes apart in the second period, and the Winnipeg Jets went on to their first victory in Boston today, beating the Bruins by 4-3.

title: COASTAL FUNDS FACE A CUTOFF
description: WASHINGTON THE Coastal Zone Management Act, the 1972 Federal law that spawned New York State's coastal erosion and tidal wetlands legislation and more than 25 waterfront revitalization projects on Long Island, will be eliminated from the Reagan Administration's fiscal year 1986 budget, according to an Administration official.

title: A Hairy Relationship
description: I AM THINKING OF MY hair. I am proud of our relationship. It is a good relationship. My hair and I have been good for each other.

title: REVISIONS IN LAWS ON HOUSING URGED
description: With key state housing laws due to expire in the current legislative session, tenant advocates began a campaign here this week not only to extend the laws but also to strengthen them.

title: Staying Put
description: Cris Collinsworth, the former Bengal wide receiver who jumped to the United States Football League for this year after signing a five-year $3 million contract with the Tampa Bay Bandits in 1983, has been told by the Bandits' owner,

title: ANTI-SANDINISTAS' DIFFERENCES CLOUD TALKS ON UNITED FRONT
description: Unity among Nicaraguan rebel groups, which the Reagan Administration is reportedly considering encouraging, might be difficult to achieve because of persistent political differences and personal animosities, according to representatives of groups gathered in the Miami area.

title: THE PRESIDENTIAL LINE TO AND FROM CAPITOL HILL
description: As the Senate Judiciary Committee members questioned Attorney General-designate Edwin Meese 3d last week, M.B. Oglesby sat behind his White House desk, eyes glued to the television and telephone in hand. That was to be expected. As President Reagan's assistant for legislative affairs, Mr. Oglesby is charged with keeping tabs on important matters before Congress, arguing the Administration's case to the members, and listening to and conveying their concerns back to his boss.

title: Introducing Ford's New Merkur
description: Dear Sir/Madam,

title: MEMPHIS STATE WINS, 91-82
description: Keith Lee had 25 points and 12 rebounds today to lead Memphis State (17-1, 7-1) to a 91-82 victory over Virginia Tech in the Metro Conference game. Memphis State also got 18 points each from William Bedford and Vincent Askew.

title: HIGH FINANCE MAKES A BID FOR ART
description: -based auction house, was one of the more intriguing takeover contests of 1983, however trivial it may have seemed in terms of numbers. It pitted a pair of turnaround prospectors, Marshall S. Cogan and Stephen C. Swid, co-chairman of General Felt Industries, a New Jersey carpet and furniture manufacturer, against management of the glamorous Anglo-American institution and its white knight from Detroit, A. Alfred Taubman, a leading developer of shopping malls.

title: MUSIC: BALTIMORE OPERA'S 3 PORTRAITS OF WOMEN
description: For its third production of the season, the Baltimore Opera Company is offering a challenging triple bill under the title ''American Portraits,'' consisting of short operas by American composers about American (even if the inspiration for one was Swedish) women.

title: ABROAD AT HOME
description: Even in this conservative state, South Africa is an issue. The Legislature is expected this session to consider bills requiring state pension funds to sell shares in companies that operate in South Africa. Across the country, across ideological lines, there is a concern about America's relationship to apartheid.

title: SUDDENLY, OWNING PEOPLE WAS WRONG
description: DAVID BRION DAVIS ranks high among the elite historians of New World slavery. His prizewinning ''Problem of Slavery in Western Culture,'' published in 1966, was followed nine years later by a second volume that carried the story from 1770 to 1823, and a third has been promised on ''the age of emancipation'' (to 1890). ''Slavery and Human Progress'' interrupts the sequence to ''view the subject from a somewhat different perspective'' but still remains in the realm of the history of ideas.

title: Iraq Reports Raid Off Iranian Oil Island
description: Iraq said today that its jet fighters had raided a ''very large naval target'' in the Persian Gulf as part of its attempt to blockade the Iranian oil terminal at Kharg Island.

title:
WINE;

A TASTING OF BOTTLES FOR $5 OR LESS
description: FORTUNATELY, for those of us unable to regularly afford Lafite or La T^ache with dinner, many area wine shops carry a wide array of inexpensive reds. In fact, with the strength of the dollar in Europe and the increased use of labor-saving techniques in grape harvesting, crushing and winemaking, bottles selling for less than $5 are no longer rarities.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
description: ROMANTIC AFTERNOON

title: A FATHER FINDS FORGIVENESS
description: MY son Edward Salim never sleeps with me. He is 7 years old and the oldest of our three children. When the others have had nightmares or heard strange noises or awakened in the middle of the night and don't know why, they hustle down the stairs, rap at our door and slip into bed with my wife and me. Edward Salim fights his own demons, returns to sleep and does not appear downstairs until daybreak.

title: Everton Expands Lead, Defeating Watford, 4-0
description: Everton opened a 4-point lead at the top of the English League's First Division soccer standing Saturday, crushing Watford, 4-0, today with a strong performance in the second half.

title: BRIDGE QUAKE SENSORS SOUGHT
description: -engineering professor says that the George Washington and most other long- span suspension bridges should be wired with instruments to determine their resistance to earthquakes and to detect any need for reinforcement.

title: February 3, 1985
WASHINGTON
description: Among the many puzzling pleasures and trivial pursuits in

title: OPERA: ROY HART THEATER TRANSFORMS 'PAGLIACCI'
description: Anyone who enjoyed Peter Brook's ''Carmen'' and would like a rather bolder operatic rewrite should investigate the Roy Hart Theater version of ''Pagliacci,'' which opened a multi- week run (Thursdays through Sundays) Thursday night at La Mama E.T.C., 74A East Fourth Street.

title: What does a psychiatrist do?
description: Dr.

title: Lower-Fares Program For Aged Is Widened
description: The Transit Authority this week will begin accepting Medicare cards as valid identification for the reduced-fare program for the elderly, the authority announced.

title: A Belated First
description: Ronald V. Blackwood made history last week as the first black to be elected a mayor in the state of New York.

title: Lenin's Mausoleum To Close for Repairs
description: Lenin's mausoleum in Red Square, a top Moscow tourist attraction, is to be closed for two months for cleaning and repairs, the daily newspaper Vechernyaya Moskva reported today.

title: ALAS, POOR DESDEMONA, PILLOWED TO DEATH
description: The other evening at the Metropolitan Opera's ''Otello,'' while the deranged Moor was engaged in trying to snuff the life out of poor Desdemona with a pillow, I found my concentration wavering. That tired but handy critical cliche about the ''willing suspension of disbelief'' came to mind and would not leave, prompting me realize that I didn't know the rest of the phrase. I looked it up later and, as you undoubtedly recall from Eng. Lit. 101, the author was Coleridge. He alludes in his ''Biographia Literaria'' to ''that willing suspension of disbelief for the moment, which constitutes poetic faith.'' Desdemona's death scene in this Franco Zeffirelli production, I am sorry to say, often required more powers of suspension than I was able to muster for the moment.

title: PITCH FOR EXPANSION TEAMS IS MADE BY A SENATOR
description: SLADE GORTON cannot throw as hard as Dwight Gooden nor hit as productively as Don Mattingly. His name even sounds as if he should be the hero in a John Tunis baseball novel. In fact, Mr. Gorton has made an impact in a more significant way than Gooden and Mattingly, and he may make an even greater impact in the coming months.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;

I SAW AN EAGLE IN ITS NATURAL HABITAT
description: I SAW an eagle. Not in a zoo, but

title: Hearing Praise
description: Retiring is turning out to be something of an extended process for Ray Meyer, who stepped down as DePaul's basketball coach after last season and has been kept busy ever since receiving awards and listening to encomiums on his long career. He'll be getting another earful today when the Dapper Dan Sports Club in Pittsburgh presents him with its first Farewell to Sport award, to be given annually to a recently retired sports figure who has contributed to sportsmanship and shown a ''commitment to excellence.''

title: AMERICAN HISTORY ARRIVES IN EUROPE
description: THE European view of the United States suffers chronically from double vision. The perception of the American present is clear and vivid, if seldom free from distortion. In striking contrast, the image of the American past - if it registers at all in the minds of most Europeans - is blurred and indistinct. On the one hand, the senses (not to mention the sensibilities) of Europeans are constantly assailed by the sights and sounds and tastes of a whole range of contemporary American phenomena -- from cruise missiles, high interest rates and apparently nonstop electioneering to Michael Jackson, Billy Graham, J. R. Ewing, McDonald's hamburgers and Coca-Cola. The impact of American power, American products and American popular culture is an everyday fact of life for West Europeans.

title: SCOOTING OVER THE ICE AT 80 M.P.H.
description: GREAT SOUTH BAY lay frozen and white, stretching south to a horizon marked by the ragged gray line of Fire Island's windy dunes. Against this wintry background a sail appeared, then another and another as a whole line of sails tacked windward and came hurtling across the ice toward the Bellport shoreline. The hollow rumble of their small wooden hulls broke the frigid stillness as they careened past the village dock, where race officials recorded times.

title: CONCERT: NATIONAL SYMPHONY
description: Washington's National Symphony paid one of its regular visits to Carnegie Hall Friday night. Mstislav Rostropovich, the music director, conducted, Isaac Stern was soloist in the Mendelssohn Violin Concerto, and the other music was by Beethoven and Ezra Laderman.

title: EXPLORING UNDERWATER OFF BELIZE
description: With a short stroke of its flippers, the lead sea turtle banked out of the underwater canyon, leveled off, then began to swim toward the coral reef. Deft and quick - an impressive water ballet for something about the size of a Honda Civic. There was no way anyone with a scuba tank on his back was going to catch that speeding reptile. But Turtle No. 2, a smaller creature half the size of a padded green sofa, might be within striking distance. Angling up from below and to the side, the dive master gave two quick fin kicks, reached out and grasped the turtle's shell. I came up from behind and pulled myself onto it.

title: POETS IN THEIR LETTERS
description: William S. Peterson teaches Victorian literature at the University of Maryland and has edited Robert Browning's letters to F. J. Furnivall. THE LETTERS OF ELIZABETH BARRETT BROWNING TO MARY RUSSELL MITFORD 1836-1854

title: BEST SELLERS February 3, 1985 Feb. 3, 1985
description: Fiction*1

title: DAIRY PRINTS PHOTOS OF MISSING CHILDREN
description: HAVING one's child abducted is ''a frightening reality'' for parents today, said Michael A. J. Guida of New Britain. So Mr. Guida and his wife, Judith, who have three children, are doing their part to help find some of the estimated 1.8 million missing youngsters in the United States.

title: COPTER RUN PROVES HIT WITH GAMBLERS
description: ATLANTIC CITY

title: SHOTS OR NOT?
description: A Shot in the Dark. By Harris L. Coulter and Barbara Loe Fisher. 431 pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $19.95.

title: 'STOMPIN' AGAIN!' OVERDOES IT
description: WITH ''Stompin' Again!,'' the Downtown Cabaret Theater is not overdoing a good thing; it is overdoing two good things.

title:
INVESTING;

GROWTH STOCKS OUTPACE THE MARKET
description: ''THREE months ago, it seemed that there weren't any growth-oriented investors,'' Ralph Wanger, president of the Acorn Fund in Chicago, said last week. ''Everybody said they were a value manager. But I think we're going back to growth.''

title: NORFOLK BUSING CASE VIEWED AS KEY TO KEEPING U.S. SCHOOLS INTEGRATED
description: The children at the Young Park Elementary School seem oblivious to the momentous legal and political struggles over their education.

title: Apology in Austria
description: It was a ''misjudgment'' on his part, said Austrian Defense Minister Friedhelm Frischenschlager last week, to show up for the homecoming of a Nazi war criminal who had been released from an Italian prison.

title: HOUSE THE HOMELESS UNDER TAX SHELTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: BOOKS FOR BEDTIME, LANGUAGE FOR DINNER
description: MANY people I know read books just before going to sleep at night, and they differ widely in the kinds of books they choose. It's a question of what sort of vision of the world - and of yourself - you want to close your eyes on. You can either interpose a diversion between your day and your sleep, or you can elect to continue the struggle.

title: A Blackout in Outer Space
description: The space shuttle Discovery touched down at Cape Canaveral last week, bringing smiles to some uncharacteristically tight lips. The three-day mission was the spacecraft's first military venture, and the normally publicity-conscious National Aeronautics and Space Administration blacked out all communications with the ground to ''deny our adversaries'' information, as an Air Force general put it.

title:
DINING OUT;

OTHER THAN FAST FOOD
description: FINDING eating spots that serve something other than fast foods has become increasingly difficult in White Plains. In that area, places that cook fresh ingredients with care and imagination can be counted on the toes of a sloth's foot. Thus, when a restaurant with a respectable genealogy comes to town, it generates more than a little interest. The Landing's co-owner Max Buser's past credits include Chase Landing in Scarsdale and Brasserie Swiss in Ossining, modest but viable credentials. So we expected more from The Landing than it ultimately delivered. Although it rustles up a decent burger and a good-looking chef's salad and some dishes had the interest of Swiss touches, in general, diners might find they could get better main dishes elsewhere.

title: A KING DAY CONFLICT
description: To the Editor:

title: SUNDAY SPORTS Auto Racing
description: IMSA 24 Hours, at Daytona, Fla., conclusion. John Paul Jr. won the pole position Thursday with a course- record time of 1 minute 41.490 seconds, or 126.278 miles per hour over the 3.56-mile road circuit. (Television - WTBS, 2:55 P.M.) Basketball

title: A Tale of Tolls And Honesty
description: A recent routine trip through the Larchmont Thruway toll booth became an unusual experience, worthy of comment. I was driving my son to La Guardia and was busy talking to him as I handed the toll collector a $5 bill for the 40-cent toll. The coins were put in my waiting hand but I drove off before receiving the bills. I hadn't gone more than 100 yards before realizing what I had done. An unforgiving mistake. There was no way to back up.

title: FIREMEN SIFT THROUGH RUBBLE FROM FIREHOUSE THAT BURNED
description: Eight of the 30 members of Fire Department Rescue Co. 1 shoveled and picked their way last week through a pile of rubble three stories high - what remained of a burned building. They dragged out an assortment of things, from charred timbers to green metal lockers twisted by heat.

title: LILCO LOOKS FOR NEW REVENUE SOURCES
description: THE Long Island Lighting Company went courting on Wall Street late last month, but the company and its potential suitors - several hundred members of the New York Society of Security Analysts - were a little too shy to allow either side to predict a warm relationship.

title: Kundera and the Antinovel
description: To the Editor:

title:
ART;

AN 'OUTPOST' CELEBRATES ITS 10TH YEAR
description: FOR 10 years, the Matrix Gallery of Hartford's Wadsworth Atheneum has served as an outpost of new or not yet assimilated art ideas. It operates as a foil to the august permanent collection of the Atheneum, working to fine-tune the public's appreciation of art.

title: STRICTER TOXIC-WASTE RULES ARE BEING DRAWN UP
description: OVER the next few months, the State Department of Environmental Protection will be putting the finishing touches on a plan to regulate the storage, transportation and disposal of hazardous wastes.

title: IONA DEFEATS FORDHAM
description: The intensity of the Iona-Fordham basketball rivalry reached a new level today in a game won by Iona, 66-65, as the teams engaged in a brawl that resulted in three ejections, three technical fouls and a delay of about 20 minutes.

title: Miss Kleber To Be Wed
description: Dr. and Mrs. Herbert D. Kleber of North Haven, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Pamela Roanne Kleber to Rees Edward Eric Shad, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John S. R. Shad of New York and Washington.

description: To the Editor:

description: JOHN DORNBERG is a foreign correspondent and author who has written from Germany, Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union for more than 25 years.

description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas B. Hubbard of New York have announced the engagement of Mr. Hubbard's daughter, Amory Ann Hubbard, to Richard Temple Millard, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert C. Millard of Pebble Beach, Calif. A May wedding is planned.

description: * Rates on most adjustable mortgages are set 1 to 3 percentage points above these indexes.

title: POPE PRESSES ATTACK ON ADVOCATES OF VIOLENT CHANGE
description: Pope John Paul II stepped up his attacks today on advocates of violent social change, warning against what he called ''anti- Christian methods'' and ''class hatred.''

title: OILERS OVERHWELM RANGERS IN 5-1 ROUT
description: The Rangers lost again tonight and left Northlands Coliseum repeating one word: ''Shoot.''

title: ART: THEODOROS STAMOS'S GREEK-INFLUENCED COLOR
description: As a label, Abstract Expressionism has never really filled the bill. A term that covers well enough the catabolic painting of Jackson Pollock, Willem de Kooning and Franz Kline can hardly do duty for Barnett Newman's stripes, much less the hazes of Mark Rothko and the primeval-looking organisms of William Baziotes. It sits ill, too, on the work of Theodoros Stamos, whose automatism is not unrelated to Baziotes's. Nevertheless, Stamos counts as an Abstract Expressionist, one who, though some 20 years younger than the movement's founders, rose to fame with them during the 1950's.

title: LIBERATION THEOLOGY AT GROUND LEVEL
description: The posters welcoming Pope John Paul II to this shantytown on the bald hills of gray sand along the coast near Lima depict the accomplishments and struggles of its 300,000 residents, 75 percent of them under the age of 25 and 70 percent unemployed. Community solidarity has triumphed over poverty, the posters say. They show brick houses replacing straw shacks, desert plots turned into gardens, and residents protesting water shortages and rising bus fares. ''To live in Villa El Salvador is to live like this,'' is the message for John Paul's visit here.

title:
GARDENING;

GROUND COVERS FOR LIGHT SHADE
description: WHEN talking about ground covers for shade, we are not talking about difficult shade that is dark and dense. Nor are we talking about a site with intense competition from shallow roots.

description: Michael Billington is theater critic of The Guardian in London.

description: To the Sports Editor:

title: FATAL BLAST IN AKRON IS LAID TO FLAMMABLE WASTE
description: City officials say the explosions and fires that killed three men last December at a city garbage recycling plant occurred because of wastes sent there by a New Jersey company.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

HOW HOMEWORK IS MISUSED
description: YOUNG children love it. Older children hate it. Parents dread it and teachers must mark it. Homework, that age-old institution, is supposed to represent the best kind of partnership between school and home. But does it serve that function?

title: NIGHT ON THE TOWN CAN BE ARRANGED
description: FOR all the cultural and gastronomical treats served in the state, sometimes Connecticut residents wanta night or a weekend ''on the town,'' and that town is Manhattan.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

WE'RE HALFWAY TO SPRING
description: WE are halfway through winter. Never mind if the cold nips at your heels and pushes you indoors as soon as possible, lest you freeze in your tracks.

title: Mary-Louise Dewey Plans To Wed Kevin Fitzgerald
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward Dewey of Lincoln, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Mary- Louise Dewey to Kevin F. Fitzgerald, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James R. Fitzgerald of Garden City, L.I.

title: HIGH SCHOOL COACH IN MIAMI RESIGNED
description: An examination of allegations against a high school football coach in Miami has disclosed several errors in a New York Times article about him.

title: New Plan on Disability Covers Mental Illness
description: The Social Security Administration, responding to harsh criticism from Congress, has proposed to broaden eligibility for disability pensions to people with mental disorders.

title: Sarah L. Woodfin Weds J. H. Wynn
description: The wedding of Sarah Linda Woodfin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul B. Woodfin of Brooklyn and Bar Harbor, Me., to James Howard Wynn, a son of Esta Wynn of Brooklyn and the late Leon Wynn, took place yesterday at the Brooklyn home of the bride's parents. Michael Grupp, a leader of the Ethical Culture Society, officiated.

title: FUGITIVES' TRACER VANISHES HIMSELF
description: Ernest R. Keiser, a man the Federal Government has relied on to bring back some of its most notorious fugitives, is now a fugitive himself. His disappearance has left behind a series of puzzling questions about his secretive life and his relationship with the Government.

title: ORDERS FOR A LAWYER TO PAY LEGAL FEES IS REVERSED
description: A Federal appeals court has reversed a decision that required a lawyer in a civil-rights case to pay $19,000 in legal fees.

title: DONOVAN CO-DEFENDANT SAYS HE WAS OFFERED DEAL
description: A central figure in the investigations of Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan says Federal and local investigators offered to help him get leniency in his own criminal cases in exchange for providing damaging information about Mr. Donovan and other politicians.

title: ST. JOHN'S ROUTS UCONN BY 97-64
description: A month ago, Connecticut came within 6 points of upsetting St. John's, then ranked third. Yesterday, top- ranked St. John's won in a rout, and the difference was essentially the story of the Redmen's success in their last eight games.

title: Israelis Arrest Dozens In a Palestinian Camp
description: Israeli troops have arrested dozens of Palestinians in a refugee camp in the occupied West Bank, military sources said today.

title: Mary Carpenter, A Writer, Is Wed
description: Mary Wootten Carpenter and Adam Desmond Zagorin were married yesterday in the Manhattan apartment of her mother, Mrs. Charles Thieriot of Locust Valley, L.I. Judge Walter M. Schackman of the New York City Civil Court officiated.

title: 'That Dread Ogre,' Mammography
description: Breathes there a woman with soul so dead that she did not identify with Anne Donlon Achenbach's description of her emotions when faced with that dread ogre, mammography (''When the Doctor Says It's Time for an Appointment,'' Opinion Page, Dec. 30).

title: THE BIG BROTHER: IRAQ UNDER SADDAM HUSSEIN
description: EVERY DAY, Iraq and Iran shell each other's positions, adding new casualties in their protracted border war. And every night, ''Aloha,'' a glittery American floor show in Baghdad's fanciest hotel, brings a touch of Las Vegas to the land of Sinbad and Ali Baba.

title: Mexican Meat Roll
description: ONE OF THE pleasures I have found in writing about food - day after day, week after week, month after month, year after year - is an occasional glance backward. Such remembrances of meals past might include an especially spicy stew enjoyed in an Abyssinian home in Ethiopia; my first taste of a white truffle while dining alone at Passetto's Restaurant in Rome many a Christmas ago; a picnic at Tanglewood; a freshly caught trout cooked on the banks of a small stream in upstate New York, and so on.

title: CRIME
description: For a while Lillian O'Donnell became too involved with her heroine, Norah Mulcahaney. When the series about Norah, a New York police officer, started in 1971, Mrs. O'Donnell adhered closely to the standard form of the procedural. Of course, there was one major difference - as a woman in a man's world, Norah had special problems.

title: NAMING NAMES
description: The Life and Death of Marilyn Monroe. By Fred Lawrence Guiles. Illustrated. 501 pp. New York: Stein & Day. $17.95.

title: NORWALK CONVERSION
description: For decades, the 85-foot-high Romanesque Revival clock tower on the old Joseph Loth Company building has been a local landmark in Norwalk, Conn. Now the 80-year-old manufacturing facility, which was built as a hat factory and served most recently as an auto-accessory plant, will be converted into 132 rental apartments.

title: TWO ACTORS EXCEL IN 'OF MICE AND MEN'
description: IN ''Of Mice and Men,'' John

title: Doubting Cuba's Red Carpet
description: Fidel Castro cordially welcomed two visiting American Congressmen last month, but the State Department last week said that niceness was not enough.

title: ON CARAVAGGIO
description: Frank Stella is an abstract artist whose Charles Eliot Norton lectures at Harvard last winter discussed the relevance of Caravaggio's art to the history of painting up to the present.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: HEROES. By David Shields. (Simon & Schuster, $16.95.) ''What thou lovest well remains / the rest is dross.'' This would seem to be the wisdom granted to a middle- aged sports reporter, Al Biederman, in David Shields's first novel, ''Heroes.''

title: A SHADOWY TALE: GROUNDHOG FORECASTS CLASH
description: The controversy began early yesterday morning. Chuckles, a groundhog at the Lutz Children's Museum in Manchester, Conn., emerged from his wooden barrel at 7:03 A.M., saw no shadow, and employees of the museum began packing their sweaters in mothballs.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''An unfortunate assumption has been made - that when technology arrives here, it is transferred.

title: THAIS, SEEKING NEW IMAGE, LOOK TO OLD NAME
description: Nearly half a century ago, long before there was a Burkina Faso, a Brunei Darussalam, a Zimbabwe or a Zaire, the ancient Kingdom of Siam changed its name to Thailand.

title: STUDY OF ARMS RACE URGED FOR SCHOOLS
description: WHEN June K. Goodman, the chairman of the State Board of Education, returned last fall from a statewide conference on the nuclear arms race, she decided to propose a policy encouraging the schools to study this topic. At the time, she did not think she was proposing anything extraordinary, she says now.

title: IN BRIEF: RECENT FILMS ON CASSETTES
description: The following recent theatrical films are now available for home screening. Excerpts are from reviews by Vincent Canby.

title: GRATUITOUS INSULTS; Petracide
description: What's the cultural equivalent of genocide? Call it ''petracide,'' or the destruction of ancient stonework, with a resonance of patricide. It occurred recently when nine bombs damaged Borobudur, a Buddhist temple in Indonesia that is among the treasures of Asia.

title: SHOSTAKOVICH ORCHESTRA ROLE
description: MAXIM SHOSTAKOVICH, the conductor and son of the Soviet composer Dmitri Shostakovich, has been named musical adviser to the Hartford Symphony Orchestra while the symphony seeks a new conductor.

title:
ART;

AN ABSORBING INTRODUCTION TO WRIGHT'S USONIA
description: UTOPIAS are usually thought of as fictional things - inventions through which the shortcomings of real life can be illuminated. But for 35 years a Utopia has been functioning in Westchester County. It is a modified commune to be sure, but one dedicated to carrying out the visionary ideals of the man who was its inspiration.

title: BUDGET BATTLE SHAPES UP OVER BENEFITS FOR VETERANS
description: When President Reagan submits his 1986 budget to Congress tomorrow, few items will provoke more opposition than his effort to restrict benefits for veterans.

title: BAD CHILDREN'S BOOKS DRIVE OUT GOOD
description: THE facts of life in the marketplace are threatening children's books with a choice between gloss or loss. Good children's literature has historically been supported by institutions. Traditionally, publishers estimated that 85 percent of juvenile books were sold to libraries. That figure has recently dropped to as low as 25 percent for some publishers. The $100 million per year earmarked for school library books and materials in the late 1960's and early 1970's under Title II of the Education Act of 1964 has dwindled drastically because of Federal ''consolidation'' of educational funds to cover an increasing number of programs, ranging from extending school hours to the purchase of everything from computers to athletic equipment. Good recent books go out of print because school and public libraries can't afford replacement copies and publishers can't afford storage space.

title: OPERAS BY STRAUSS AND D'ALBERT MAKE THEIR WAY TO DISK
description: George Jellinek is host of the syndicated radio program ''The Vocal Scene.''

title: Peter T. Damon Wed To Marcia Newmaker
description: Marcia Jean Newmaker, a daughter of Dorothy Walsh Newmaker and John W. Newmaker of Warren, Pa., was married yesterday to Peter Townsend Damon, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence B. Damon of Chestnut Hill and West Harwich, Mass. The Rev. Donald E. Bitsberger performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer in Chestnut Hill, assisted by the Rev. George Albert, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: CHILLY MOVIES NOURISH WITH FOOD FOR THOUGHT
description: What's it about?'' is usually the first question. If you answer that it's about these two New York City slobs - youngish men with no visible means of support - and the cousin of one them, a young woman who frowns a lot, and how, in the middle of winter, the two slobs borrow a beat-up car and drive to Cleveland to see the cousin, and then the three decide to go to Florida, where nothing much happens, the questioner is likely to lose interest and ask about some movie other than ''Stranger Than Paradise.''

title: HECKLER PUTS OFF ACTION ON BARRING USE OF 6 DYES
description: The Secretary of Health and Human Services, Margaret M. Heckler, has postponed for two months any action on a recommendation that she ban the use of six color additives that have been found to cause cancer in laboratory animals.

title: DWINDLING GERMAN CLUB KEEPS SINGING
description: NORBERT DIGNUS, Hans Helbig and Karl Boger remembered the better times, when they did not need to worry about good turnouts for their club meetings. They glanced about the room at the handful of members, then shook their heads. Someone suggested that the bad weather had kept a lot of people away.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;

JOBS AND VETERANS
description: More than a decade after they came home, the county's Vietnam veterans have found a home.

title: CASSETTES: FROM MODERN DANCE TO DIANA ROSS
description: Diana Ross in Concert RCA/Columbia 80 minutes. $29.95

title: PLANNING COUNCIL ENDORSES 2 HOSPITALS FOR CARDIAC SURGERY
description: planning agency in New Jersey has recommended that state regulators allow Hackensack Medical Center and University Hospital in Newark add open- heart surgery programs.

title: RECESSION IN ISRAEL IS SLOWING SETTLEMENT OF THE WEST BANK
description: -Occupied West Bank - Israel's economic recession appears to be doing what years of Peace Now demonstrations and political debates have not: slow the growth of Jewish settlements in the West Bank.

title: CHILDREN ARE GIVEN IDENTIFICATION TAGS
description: AS part of a new Lifesaver Identification Program, police officers in Fairfield have been visiting local classrooms and distributing identification tags to children in kindergarten through second grade.

title: BOOKSHELF
description: Additional titles of interest

description: To the Editor:

title: Susan Sheresky To Be the Bride Of Bart Walker
description: Lyn Revson and Kenneth Sheresky, both of New York, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Sheresky, to Bart A. Walker, a son of Roland Walker and Dr. Norma S. Tucker, both of Baltimore. A June wedding is planned.

title: OPERA: STUDENTS DO A WOLF-FERRARI WORK
description: Ermanno Wolf-Ferrari was one of several interesting and able Italian composers of the generation just after Puccini - the generation during whose careers Italian opera somehow lost its way and its standing, despite the best efforts of Montemezzi, Respighi, Alfano and the surviving verismists. Wolf-Ferrari was the classicist of the group, and the comedist. His series of operas on the plays of Goldoni (he also drew on Moli ere, Perrault and Shakespeare) comprise what is very probably the most distinguished body of works in the opera buffa tradition after Donizetti's.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: BOBBY: Breakthrough of a Special Child. By Rachael Pinney and Mimi Schlachter with Anthea Courtenay. (Marek/St. Martins's $13.95)

title: AND NOW, AN UPDATE ON THE TROJAN WAR
description: He spoke, and as he spoke the end of death closed in upon him, and the soul fluttering free of his limbs went down into Death's house mourning her destiny, leaving youth and manhood behind her.

title: HOUSING HARD TO FIND FOR THOSE WITH CHILDREN
description: THE classified advertisement in a local newspaper read: ''Caldwell - Modern 4 1/2, 2 large BR apt. . . . adults only.'' Size was not a factor, as another advertisement made clear:

title: A FLAW IN RADICAL TAX REFORM
description: It would appear that the climate for a flat or modified flat tax is as favorable as could be. But there is one factor, overlooked so far, that may give pause to many people who are so enthusiastic about tax simplification. That is the probability that radical tax reform could, over time, lead to a more intrusive Government.

title: U.S. INVESTIGATES HELICOPTER SALES
description: The Commerce Department said today that it had evidence a West German businessman had illegally shipped to North Korea as many as 82 Hughes helicopters with potential military applications.

THE word ''crack-up'' brings to mind, inescapably if momentarily, the fine collection of F. Scott Fitzgerald's writings under that name edited by Edmund Wilson. If, as Fitzgerald wrote of his own breakdown, the test of a civilized intelligence is the ability to hold two opposed ideas in the mind simultaneously while retaining the capacity to function, then R. Emmett Tyrrell Jr.'s relentless jeremiad on contemporary America, ''The Liberal Crack-Up,'' reflects an obsessed intelligence.

title: By Meryle Secrest   Illustrated 310 pp. New York:   Holt, Rinehart & Winston. $18.95
description: IF, like Samuel Johnson, we ''esteem biography as giving us what comes near to ourselves, what we can turn to use,'' then the life of Kenneth Clark (1903-1983), as told by Meryle Secrest, the author of ''Being Bernard Berenson,'' presents a model of worldly success.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: FRIENDS OF THE ARTS is donating half of its

title: Officer Indicted In Bumpers Case
description: Since the death last October of Eleanor Bumpurs, the 66-year-old Bronx woman shot by a police officer during an eviction dispute, police officials, coroners and community activists have debated whether one or two shots struck Mrs. Bumpurs. The significance of the argument became clear last week when a grand jury indicted the man who fired the gun.

title: SCIENTISTS SAY MEDICARE CUT WILL LIMIT RESEARCH
description: New limits on Medicare payments will hamper clinical research, which could delay the development of cures for major diseases and ultimately drive up the nation's bill for health care, according to two researchers writing in The Journal of the American Medical Association.

title: Landlord 'Victims'
description: To the Editor:

title: A SINFUL PASTICHE AT MCCARTER THEATRE
description: PRINCETON RECIPE for theatrical nouvelle cuisine: Mix one part Marlowe (''The Tragicall Historie of Doctor Faustus''), one part Goethe (''Faustus'') and one part Moli ere (''Don Juan'') - more or less.

title: Italian Printers Go on Strike
description: A 24-hour national strike by printers, called to press demands involving wages and other matters involved in contract negotiations, prevented Italian news agencies from distributing their reports today and was expected to pre=vent publication of newspapers on Sunday.

title: THE BEST CONVERSATION IN AMERICA
description: THE ability of a writer to capture the speech of his characters is often underestimated or even dismissed in favor of other qualities, but it is far more important than subject matter or theme if his stories are to have life. Comte de Buffon said ''Style is the man'' and it follows that a writer who has the power to reproduce his character's voice has taken hold of the character himself, and the story starts from there.

title: CBS NEWS IS CHANGING, CAUTIOUSLY
description: ''Whatever we do,'' said Edward M. Joyce, the president of CBS News for the past 16 months, ''there is always a Greek chorus in the background humming, 'This time they've gone too far.' ''

title: Correction
description: In the review of Gerald Rosen's ''Growing Up Bronx'' - Fiction In Short (Jan. 13) - we neglected to mention that the novel is available in a cloth edition for $18.95.

title: The Lasting Impact Of Geraldine Ferraro
description: Maureen Dowd's assessment of the Ferraro factor in the 1984 election is depressing to feminists (''Reassessing Women's Political Role: The Lasting Impact of Geraldine Ferraro,'' Dec. 30).

title: Jennifer Cartmell to Marry Charles Hays in Spring
description: Mr. and Mrs. Peter Cartmell of Rumson, N.J., and Tequesta, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter Jennifer Banks Cartmell to Charles F. Hays, the son of Mrs. Orville E. Hays of Great Bend, Kan., and the late Mr. Hayes. A May wedding is planned.

title: COLUMBIA REMOVING ASBESTOS FROM ITS BUILDINGS
description: All 265 buildings owned by Columbia University are being inspected for asbestos, and the substance has been removed or sealed in 200 places in 30 buildings.

title: Ending 421a
description: To the Editor:

title: Losing More Ground
description: This year's budget-cutters' bible seems to be ''Losing Ground,'' Charles Murray's book appraising social policy in the last 30 years. The Reagan budget coming tomorrow is likely to propose deep reductions in education, child nutrition and housing assistance, and elimination of programs like the Job Corps, revenue sharing and urban development grants. In agency after agency, officials cite the Murray book as a philosophical base for these proposals, for it concludes that social-welfare programs, far from relieving poverty, increase it and should be stopped.

title: BANKERS CAUTIOUS ON PLAN TO AID FARMERS IN DEBT
description: Bankers across the Farm Belt say a debt-relief plan being shaped by the Reagan Administration could help some farmers but could leave many without funds or credit to buy supplies for the planting season.

title: Deborah Perruzzi to Wed
description: The engagement of Deborah A. Perruzzi to Ian C. Gatehouse has beenannounced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Richard J. Perruzzi of Newton, Mass. Miss Perruzzi is the assistant coordinator of gynecology at Preterm Inc. in Brookline, Mass. Her fiance, the son of Jean J. Gatehouse of Locust Valley, L.I., and the late Woodrow G. Gatehouse, is an area marketing specialist at Integrated Capital Services in New York.

title: Patterns For Spring
description: ACCESSORIES, are the finishing bits and pieces of fashion - the scarf, shoe, stocking, earring, bracelet, brooch, even an occasional vest - that spell out individuality. It is how they are put together that makes one woman look different from another - even if they happen to be wearing the same things. Be that as it may, any woman with a flair for mixing patterns will have a field day this spring.

title: INSTALLING A FILTER TO IMPROVE THE QUALITY OF DRINKING WATER
description: ALTHOUGH most of us take the quality of the water that comes out of our faucet for granted, it is amazing how many gallons of bottled water are sold through supermarkets and grocery stores. The reason is that many homeowners are not entirely happy with the way their domestic water supply tastes, looks or smells when it is used for drinking, mixing beverages or even cooking.

title: THE NETWORKS HAVEN'T QUITE FORSAKEN QUALITY DRAMA
description: Think a moment - on which television outlets did you first see the following productions: Katharine Hepburn in ''The Glass Menagerie,'' Laurence Olivier in ''The Merchant of Venice,'' Carol Burnett in ''Friendly Fire,'' Colleen Dewhurst in ''The Women's Room,'' Christopher Plummer in ''Cyrano de Bergerac,'' Julie Harris in ''The Little Moon of Alban,'' Henry Fonda in ''Gideon's Trumpet'' and Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne in ''The Magnificent Yankee''?

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

LESSONS TV CANNOT TEACH
description: EACH year, many of us choose to renew old resolutions rather than make new ones. Farmington residents are no exception. Repeating an experiment begun last year, they again pledged to unplug their televisions, swapping hours of video viewing for more creative pastimes. During the month-long ''turn off,'' Farmington children saw fewer cartoons, fewer commercials. Instead, they heard stories read by their parents.

title: EVEN AS IT SPLITS, OPEC STILL HOLDS A WHIP
description: GENEVA SHEIK Ahmed Zaki Yamani, the Oil Minister of Saudi Arabia, strode into the Grand Ballroom of Geneva's Intercontinental Hotel Thursday afternoon, arm in arm with the Oil Minister of Algeria, Belkacem Nabi. Fingering finely worked silver worry beads, Mr. Yamani told newsmen that OPEC's 13 members had agreed to adjust its complex price system to assure it a firm stake in a soft oil market.

title: Margriet E. Yonkman to Wed Michael J. Finnegan
description: Mrs. Raymond B. Rudy of Greenwich, Conn., and Frederick A. Yonkman of Ridgefield, Conn., and New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Margriet Ellen Yonkman, to Michael Joseph Finnegan, a son of Dr. and Mrs. John Gerard Finnegan of Rye, N.Y. A March 16 wedding is planned.

THE EMPHASIS SHIFTS FROM RARITY TO QUALITY

description: Valerie Brisco-Hooks, who won three gold medals at the Olympic Games, established a world indoor best in the women's 440-yard run tonight with a time of 52.99 seconds at The Dallas Times-Herald Invitational meet.

title: Seoul Jails 50 Students
description: Fifty students have been jailed for from 3 to 20 days for leading demonstrations calling for a boycott of National Assembly elections on Feb. 12, court officials said today. The students, from four universities, led campus and street protests over the last week accusing President Chun Doo Hwan's Government of trying to rig the elections.

description: IN a four-month period early last year, prices at a Manhattan condominium project were raised 20 times, or about once a week. And the changes were not simple: Sometimes apartments in only one section of the building, or those with a particular characteristic - a certain view, for instance, or a certain size terrace - were increased in price.

description: Japan's opposition parties, which have been denied political power for almost the entire postwar era and are tired of it, are exploring ways to regroup into new alliances.

description: In an effort to improve their finances, an area in which they say they have serious problems, the Cosmos are on the verge of selling Roberto Cabanas, the only player left on their roster of substantial value to foreign teams.

title: FROM PARIS, ACCESSORIES BY THE YARD
description: Hats and shoes were relatively subdued in the spring and summer couture shows here. The familiar turbans, pillboxes, berets, cartwheels and boaters were prominent in daytime headgear, though designers did get a little fanciful for evening. Shoes tended to be high-heeled pumps, though the heels could be in a contrasting color, as at Yves Saint Laurent, and two-tone effects were popular everywhere.

title: Governors Join To Raise the Drinking Age
description: If the governors have their way, it will soon be impossible for anyone under the age of 21 to buy a legal drink in New York, New Jersey, Connecticut, Massachusetts, New Hampshire or Pennsylvania. At a meeting last week, the Coalition of Northeastern Governors committed themselves to press for the establishment of a uniform drinking age by June 1.

title: TOM MCMILLEN'S LOFTY GOALS
description: INSIDE the local Friendly Ice Cream parlor, a handful of customers were eating breakfast, their steaming cups of coffee looking like little chimneys keeping them warm on a snowy morning in suburban Maryland. A man bundled in a parka talked about how difficult it was driving on the snow-slick roads, but the view from a comfortable booth in a warm place was picturesque, like a scene Tom McMillen might paint for his personalized Christmas cards.

title: Koch Offers Innovations, put Few Price Tags
description: More police officers in the subways, 100,000 new or renovated apartments and houses, stepped-up efforts to prevent high school students from dropping out - these proposals topped a plate of initiatives outlined last week by Mayor Koch in his ''State of the City'' message. The Mayor, who is running for re-election this year, might not unreasonably expect that his menu could appeal to a wide range of New Yorkers.

description: About 70 people, most of them American military personnel stationed at an air base near Athens, were wounded tonight in an explosion in a crowded bar, a police spokesman said.

title: WAS STALIN INEVITABLE?   RETHINKING THE SOVIET EXPERIENCE;   Politics and History since 1917.   By Stephen F. Cohen.   222 pp. New York:   Oxford UniversityPress. $17.95
description: BEST known by his pathbreaking biography of Nikolai Ivanovich Bukharin, Stephen Cohen is one of the outstanding figures in the generation of ''Sovietologists'' who first made their mark in the 1970's. In part because of their frequent visits to the Soviet Union, scholars of this generation combine a sharply critical view of the Soviet political system with a sense of respect and even kinship for Russians they know - not a few of whom are intellectual dissidents. While fully aware of the limited influence of these acquaintances on Soviet politics, the new Sovietologists are apt to be impressed by the dissidents' picture of Soviet society and history. Having come to know a post- Stalinist and postrevolutionary Russia that differs in many ways from the ''totalitarian model'' used by the older generation of Western Sovietologists, it is not surprising that one of them should ask whether or not the time has come to sketch out an alternative view of Soviet history. This is what Stephen Cohen, a professor of Soviet politics and history at Princeton University, has undertaken in ''Rethinking the Soviet Experience.''

title: CAN JERUSALEM'S UNITY CABINET GET ITS PEACE ACT TOGETHER?
description: Anyone interested in discovering why the Camp David peace process has lost momentum would have done well to spend an afternoon last week watching the negotiations at Beersheba's Desert Inn Hotel, where Israel and Egypt haggled over the fate of 750 yards of sand containing a topless beach club and a 12-story hotel.

title: A BIT OF BOMBAY AT MODEST PRICES
description: BERRY'S OF BOMBAY is actually of Flushing, Queens. The small storefront Indian restaurant, which opened about six weeks ago, deserves the devoted following it seems to be building. The food is good - sometimes emphatically so - and the prices are extremely modest.

description: IN the stunning baseball game that concludes ''Things Invisible to See,'' Death, who has assembled a baseball team called the Dead Knights, tells his newest recruit: ''We're losing. Can't you see? Do you think Gehrig and Waddell and McGinnity and Jennings couldn't hit if they wanted to? . . . They want the living to win. Even the umpire wants the living to win. They remember how it was. All the pain, all the trouble - they'd choose it again - they'd go extra innings into infinity for the chance to be alive again.''
