title: KOHL BECOMES EMBROILED IN A SILESIAN FANTASY
description: In the year that a divided Europe is marking the 40th anniversary of the end of Hitler's war, one might have thought that a West German chancellor would be doubly cautious about doing or saying anything to suggest that Germans still nurture designs on their eastern neighbors. But last week Chancellor Helmut Kohl stumbled into an embarrassing embrace with fringe right-wingers in his Christian Democratic party, who regard sizeable chunks of southwestern Poland as eternally German. What seemed a political farce, though, hinted at a deeper shift in Bonn's approach to Eastern Europe.

title: Afghanistan Says China Is Arming Insurgents
description: Afghanistan has delivered a protest note to China's charge d'affaires in Kabul, complaining of Chinese military support for rebels fighting the Soviet- backed Government, the Soviet party newspaper Pravda said today.

title: PLAN TO SELL LIBRARY PROTESTED
description: COLD SPRING HARBOR'S historic Main Street was predictably deserted last Sunday night, but upstairs in the firehouse meeting room, lights blazed and coffee perked.

title: SPECIAL SOVIET CENSUS RAISES UNUSUAL ISSUES
description: The Soviet Union, beset by rapid social change, completed its first special mid-decade census last month as an aid in drafting economic and social plans for the next five years and over the longer term, to the year 2000.

title: BAR HONORS 'OBSTINATE' POLISH LAWYER
description: Two years ago, the Polish Government adopted a regulation forbidding defense lawyers from appearing in court after turning 70 years old. At the time the law was enacted, Wladyslaw Sila-Nowicki was 69.

title: SELECTING ZERO-COUPON MUNICIPALS
description: Most of the zero-coupon bonds sold to individuals are backed by Treasury securities and their payoff is taxable, unless the bonds are used as investments in tax-exempt Individual Retirement Accounts, as many of them are. Lately, however, zeros backed by tax-free municipal bonds are also gaining popularity, particularly among people in high-tax brackets.In fact tax-free municipals have become one of the hottest investments around as the prospect of tax simplification prompts the wealthy to replace the tax shelters they would ordinarily buy.

title: Time to Eliminate The Party Lever
description: The League of Women Voters of Connecticut would like to thank The New York Times for the informative and balanced discussion of the party lever (''Should Constitution Continue to Require the Party Lever?,'' Dec. 9).

title: A SHOW ON THE SUN KING THAT MISSES THE MAN
description: WASHINGTON

title: PRIVATE RIGHTS, PUBLIC FEARS
description: PUBLIC officials in New York, notably Mayor Koch, have lamented from time to time that they cannot force the emotionally disturbed to accept treatment. Many people have felt a similar frustration when unable to convince family members or friends who they think are suffering from emotional disorders to seek help. New York laws forbid government officials and individuals to require people to accept psychiatric care against their will, unless psychiatrists determine that they are a danger to themselves or others.

title: Contention Over Gross's Work
description: RECONSTRUCTING the history and inner workings of a medical examiner's office can be almost as arduous as the detective work of forensic medicine. A series of articles last week in The New York Times suggested, however, that a clear and disturbing pattern has evolved in the New York City Medical Examiner's Office since Dr. Elliot M. Gross assumed command as Chief Medical Examiner in 1979. The Times reported that doctors in the Medical Examiner's Office and other independent pathologists contend that Dr. Gross produced misleading or inaccurate autopsy reports on at least six people who died while in police custody.

title: HRUDEY SHUTS OUT PENGUINS
description: Kelly Hrudey stopped the Penguins cold tonight, 4-0, and the Islanders won for only the second time in 10 games.

title: ATLANTIC CITY SEEKS TO REGAIN CONVENTION TRADE
description: ATLANTIC CITY AS THIS resort slowly gains more hotel rooms, it also is regaining convention business.

title: IN CELEBRATION OF BOOKS: A LIBRARIAN REMINISCES
description: IN a more prudish time, a teacher of teachers once said - apropos of teaching

title: WHY DID BALANCHINE ALLOW BALLETS TO DISAPPEAR?
description: The New York City Ballet has just revived George Balanchine's 1958 ballet, ''Gounod Symphony'' and while it is clearly major Balanchine, various aspects of the revival raise some questions. One is whether Balanchine consciously allowed some of his ballets to drop out of the repertory for artistic reasons - and not through attrition or accident. Another issue is whether the revivals gain or lose when they are presented in different contexts from those in which they were last seen.

title: The Authenticity of 'Marthe'
description: To the Editor:

title: DEBATE OVER BILL TO CREATE A LAW-GUARDIAN AGENCY
description: SUPPORTERS say it would provide effective lawyers for children, but critics say it is a blatant political stratagem that would make it less likely that children would be properly represented in court.

title: WINTERING AROUND MUNICH
description: Besides all its other charms and attractions, Munich is the gateway to the Bavarian and the Tyrolean Alps. A dazzling array of ski resorts and winter sports areas is no more than two hours' drive along autobahns and many of them are served by special, nonstop trains that leave from the Hauptbahnhof, the main station, on weekends. It is only 55 miles - an hour's drive by American standards, shorter by breakneck German criteria - to Garmisch-Partenkirchen, scene of the 1936 Winter Olympics and the leading winter sports center in the Bavarian Alps ever since, thanks in no small measure to the Zugspitze, which at 9,782 feet is Germany's highest mountain.

title: Janet Sproul Betrothed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Albert Edgar Sproul Jr. of Demarest, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter, Janet Elisabeth Sproul, to John Howland Robinson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Horace Brookes Blackwell Robinson of New York. Miss Sproul, an assistant vice president of Lloyd's Bank International in New York, and her fiance, a partner in the New York law firm of Cuccia Oster & Robinson.

title: PESTICIDE PLANT STARTED AS A SHOWPIECE BUT RAN INTO TROUBLES
description: Union Carbide already had more than three decades of experience and a solid reputation in India when it made its initial stake in Bhopal in 1969 with the opening of a factory to produce pesticides.

title: A RETURN TO FAVOR FOR R.O.T.C. PROGRAMS
description: WHEN Marine Corps Capt. Stephen B. Cooperider visits Sarah Lawrence College in Yonkers later this week, he will be looking for a few good women. He will, however, settle for one.

title: Painful Sale
description: Denny McLain, the former Detroit Tiger pitcher who is on trial in Florida on a variety of Federal charges, including drug possession with intent to sell, extortion and loansharking, said he had been forced to sell his two Cy Young award trophies to finance his defense. ''I'm devastated,'' he told The Detroit Free Press.

title: 26 Food Outlets Cited by City
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 26 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: Kirkpatrick Bows Out
description: Putting some of President Reagan's frustrations and her own to rest last week, Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the United States chief delegate at the United Nations, announced her resignation and return to writing and teaching at Georgetown University. ''In private life, perhaps even more than in public life,'' she said, ''I can speak out clearly.''

title: Amtrak
description: To the Editor:

title: WARRIORS ROUT KNICKS BY 114-98
description: The worst team in the league met the league's worst road team tonight, and the result was a testimonial for the home-court edge. The Golden State Warriors came into their game against the Knicks with the league's worst record (10-35) and a string of 16 consecutive losses, one short of a club record. But playing before 9,321 fans in their home arena, the Oakland-Alameda County Coliseum, the Warriors won, 114-98, extending to 15 the Knicks' club-record road losing streak. The outcome was actually decided when the Warriors hit their first 13 shots of the second period to turn a close game into a rout. They outscored the Knicks, 33-5, over a span of about 8 minutes to build a 28-point margin, 62-34, that was never seriously challenged. The Knicks, who dropped their third straight game over all, fell to 17-31. They were led by Pat Cummings, who had 27 points. Bernard King, back for his second game after missing eight games with a sprained ankle, added 23 points but did not play in the final period. For the Warriors, Eric (Sleepy) Floyd was most productive, scoring 26 points, mostly on some stellar outside shooting. Purvis Short, who leads the Warriors in scoring this season, finished with 23.

title: GENERALS CAPTURE EXHIBITION OPENER
description: Herschel Walker scored the first touchdown of the exhibition season today for the Generals, who went on to beat the Memphis Showboats, 16-3.

title: FROM ENGLISH PUB TO CHINESE PAGODA
description: The strangest thing about walking around Epcot Center, the 260- acre extravaganza of exhibits and rides on international and futuristic themes that is the latest addition to Walt Disney World in Florida, is not the bizarre sensation of being in a stage-set version of France one moment and Morocco the next. What is much stranger than that is how, after but a few minutes, all of this rampant architectural make-believe no longer seems so strange at all - how this place in which you prance from an English pub into a Chinese pagoda without missing a beat begins to feel almost normal.

title: Vietnamese Guns Pound Rebels in Cambodia
description: Vietnamese gunners pounded Cambodian Communist rebels today in a continuing offensive.

title: JACK KEMP'S YEAR OF DECISION
description: JACK KEMP IS ON HIS WAY TO the White House. As he gets off the elevator in the Rayburn House Office Building on Capitol Hill, he sees a boy carrying a stack of boxes and gives the startled lad a playful cuff on the shoulder. Kemp does not walk to the car, he bounces toward it, emitting waves of restless energy the way a radiator spreads heat. The snazzy silver Thunderbird with the plush red seats is already at the garage door, and he is momentarily embarrassed by the automotive finery. It's leased, he protests, not owned. As the Thunderbird leaves Capitol Hill, Kemp recognizes a journalist in the car in front. At the next red light, he lunges out the door and shouts at the reporter, ''When are you going to interview me?''

title: Carolyn D. White Becomes a Bride
description: Carolyn Day White, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel W. White Jr. of Tryon, N.C., was married yesterday to Philip Severn Wallis, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George R. Wallis of Bedford, N.Y. The Rev. Frank Griswold performed the ceremony at St. Martin-in-the-Fields Episcopal Church in Philadelphia.

title: SOMETIMES, SOMETHING SEEMS TO WORK
description: NO CEASEFIRES The War on Poverty in Roanoke Valley. By Edwin L. Cobb. 176 pp. Cabin John, Md. Seven Locks Press. $13.95.

title: Carl Fisher's Montauk Plans
description: The interesting account of Carl Fisher's development of the Montauk area (''Fisher's Montauk Legacy Getting a New Look,'' Dec. 23) omitted two facets of its history, one of which I observed personally.

title: The Fourth Generation Of Rockefellers
description: Kathleen Teltsch's article, ''The Cousins: The Fourth Generation of Rockefellers'' (Dec. 30) was one of the most interesting I have read.

title: SHINNECOCK DOCK CENTER OF DISPUTE
description: AFTER weeks of bickering, it looks as though officials of Suffolk County and Southampton Town will meet on resolving their differences over allocating slips for the new commercial fishing dock at Shinnecock Inlet.

title: PRIVATE SCHOOL ENROLLMENT TAKES OFF
description: Tim Combs of Carlisle, Ohio, had always attended public schools. But last fall he transferred to Dayton Christian School for his senior year of high school, because his parents thought the atmosphere would be more wholesome.

title: KEAN SHIFT TO THE LEFT SETS STAGE FOR RACE
description: TRENTON GOVERNOR KEAN made it all the way back from the conservative side of the political spectrum last week when he delivered his budget message to the Legislature, which called for more spending on welfare programs and education aid and for a new program for the medically needy.

title: MUSIC: BARTOK AND ROCHBERG SONGS
description: The League-ISCM concert at Carnegie Recital Hall Thursday night attracted the group's customary small coterie of friends and colleagues. It is a shame, for much of this music could have appealed to more - and more kinds of - people.

title: STATES FEAR U.S. ATTEMPT TO INFRINGE ON THEIR REVENUE
description: As the Reagan Adminstration searches for ways to reduce the Federal deficit, state governments are celebrating their sound fiscal condition and some state officials are preparing defenses against what they fear would amount to a Federal raid on state treasuries.

title: PIER RESTAURANT
description: Construction began recently on a 600-seat seafood restaurant at the tip of an abandoned railroad pier just south of the Lincoln Tunnel in Weehawken, N.J.

title: Lois M. Lightner To Wed in April
description: Leon John Lightner of Livingston, N.J., has announced the engagement of his daughter, Lois Marie Lightner, to Kenneth Charles Nichols Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Nichols of Short Hills, N.J. An April wedding is planned.

title: Getting Burned On Wine Coolers
description: When New York State passed a law allowing grocery stores to sell a fruit juice and wine drink called a cooler - but only if it is made with New York grapes - a California concern marketing a competing brand popped its cork. Loretto Winery Ltd., whose sales in New York are restricted to liquor stores, contended that it would be hurt if customers could stock up at more convenient groceries.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: LEWISBORO
description: LEWISBORO, a sparsely populated town of 9,000 in northern Westchester County, is really a union of hamlets sharing a school system with neighboring Katonah. There are three small retail areas but no true center, and residents are more likely to say they are from the hamlet of South Salem or Cross River than from the Town of Lewisboro.

title: New Drug for Genital Herpes
description: The first oral drug for the treatment of genital herpes, which was approved last week by the Food and Drug Administration, is due to be in America's pharmacies next week. Zovirax, available only by prescription, will cost $15 to $17 for the 25 capsules needed to treat an average five-day outbreak of the disease.

title: Working With Hitchcock
description: To the Editor:

title: The Man From Stratford?
description: To the Editor:

title: Collecting Old Fishing Tackle
description: OLD fishing rods, reels and lures have become highly prized antiques, a puzzling phenomenon to one who has never collected anything save books, functional woodworking tools and lugubrious reflections on what might have been.

title: 56 WAYS TO TOUR JACKSON, N.H.
description: If you are lucky enough to find a copy of ''Reminiscences of Jackson 1900-1950,'' a remarkable oral history of the New Hampshire village compiled by sixth graders at Jackson's white-clapboard grammar school, you can read about the grand era of the White Mountain resorts, such as Gray's, the Eagle Mountain House and Wentworth Hall. These Victorian buildings, white giants with peaked roofs and sprawling porches, were sized to their setting: the Mount Washington Valley, which lies at the foot of the Northeast's highest mountain (6,288 feet), and at the edge of the timberland that is now the White Mountain National Forest. In the winter the hotels' horse-drawn sleds would meet guests at the Glen railroad station, south of Jackson (the station is now occupied by a ski club), and from there would take them off to snowshoe, to climb and, starting in the 1930's, to careen down the snowy hillsides on wooden slats.

title: Teen-Age Police
description: In a move to bolster the two-man police force in Paw Paw, W. Va., as well as provide a wholesome activity for the town's youth, Chief Tracy Grady set up a volunteer teen-age police program last September.

title: Teamster Prosecutions Reported to Be Sought
description: The Federal authorities here have recommended that Jackie Presser, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, and two other people be charged with illegal payment of union funds to nonexistent employees of Teamsters Local 507, according to published reports.

title: No Headline
description: Members of Congress did not get their first look at Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger's budget until today, but over the last two months they have seen a great deal of Mr. Weinberger himself.

title: A SOLITARY LIFE IS STILL WORTH LIVING
description: HOTEL DU LAC By Anita Brookner. 184 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $13.95.

title: A Break For the Farmer
description: Beginning this week, at least some debt-burdened farmers may be able to avoid default with the help of new Government guarantees.

title: BENEFITS OF BIOMEDICAL RESEARCH FAR OUTWEIGH THE COSTS
description: To the Editor:

title: Hotel Aids Cancer Patients
description: Cancer patients undergoing outpatient treatment at hospitals in the Boston area may now stay free of charge on weekdays at the Westin Hotel in Copley Place here.

title: GROUP TO PROMOTE ALTERNATIVE ENERGY
description: OWNERS of small power plants around Connecticut have formed an association to discuss ways to encourage the development of alternative energy sources.

title: RECYCLING A GYM
description: When St. Augustine's Elementary School in Ossining, N.Y., was torn down a few years ago for the sake of a road-widening project on Route 9, its gym, housed in a 1960's annex behind the 60-year-old school, was spared.

title: Andrea Visich Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward T. Visich of Westwood, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Andrea Jean Visich to Timothy Charles Coumbe, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Coumbe of Westfield, N.J. A November wedding is planned. Miss Visich, an executive secretary with the Associated Merchandising Corporation in New York, is a student at the Bergen Community College in New Jersey. The future bridegroom, who attended the University of Virginia, is with the United Parcel Service in Saddle Brook, N.J.

title: THE IRISH FLAIR WITH POTATOES
description: For many, the potato is synonymous with Ireland, south and north, which is not surprising since most Irish regard the potato warmly, as somewhat of a national vegetable.

title: WHAT PART SHOULD THE PUBLIC PLAY IN CHOOSING PUBLIC ART?
description: One of the hottest issues in the growing field of public art, the part that the public plays in choosing it, will be aired at a hearing March 6, called by the New York regional office of the Federal Government's General Services Administration. The hearing is sparked by ''Tilted Arc,'' Richard Serra's highly controversial curving wall of rusted Cor-ten steel, 120 feet long and 12 feet high, installed on the plaza of the Federal building complex at Foley Square in 1981. To be sure, the work - which bisects the plaza like the business end of a giant cleaver - was commissioned and paid for by the remarkable Art-in-Architecture program of the General Services Administration, which is responsible for the construction and care of Federal buildings. But in view of continuing protests about ''Tilted Arc'' (two months after its installation, some 1,300 Government employees who work in the building signed a petition for its removal) the agency is considering its relocation.

title: VIEWS DIFFER ON PESTICIDE BAN
description: TRENTON A TOP state agricultural official and the sponsor of the so-called antipesticide bill disagreed last week over the reasons for the Department of Agriculture's recent ban on the use of chemical pesticides for treating gypsy-moth infestations.

title: Claudia J. Shapiro To Wed a Lawyer
description: The engagement of Claudia Jane Shapiro to Paul R. Taskier has been announced by Carol A. Shapiro of Washington and David I. Shapiro of Lorton, Va., parents of the future bride. Her fiance's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Henry T. Taskier of Fanwood, N.J. A June wedding is planned.

title: FUNCTIONAL BEAUTY
description: TRENTON BYRON TEMPLE'S covered jars are the stuff of still-life painting. One can almost see them lined up on a canvas by Morandi, who is known for his rendering of simple kitchen forms.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THERE ARE ALTERNATIVES! Four Roads to Peace and Security. By Johan Galtung. (Dufour Editions, Cloth, $35. Paper, $10.95.)

title: Miss Feldman Married To T. L. Buckmaster 2d
description: Sheila M. Feldman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Feldman of Great Neck, L.I., was married yesterday to Thomas L. Buckmaster 2d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas E. Buckmaster of Sewell, N.J. Judge Ruth Bader Ginsburg of the United States Court of Appeals, District of Columbia Circuit, performed the ceremony at the Jefferson Hotel in Washington.

description: Indecent Welcome

title: The 'Lost City'Of Gran Pajaten
description: Mankind's enduring fascination with legendary ''lost cities'' caught fire again last week from the report that archeologists had come upon what may be the remains of a mysterious civilization that flourished in Peru from A.D. 500 to 1500.

title: MANY DONORS TO THE NEEDIEST HAVE ALSO KNOWN HARDSHIP
description: Victims of misfortune or tragedy - ill health, a broken home, child abuse - are often singled out for attention by contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund who have known such hardship personally or by association.

title: Article 014192 -- No Title
description: After two years of delays, New Jersey has committed $25.5 million in state funds to go with $30 million in Federal funds so that construction can begin on a railroad linking Atlantic City and Philadelphia.

title: NETS TOPPLE 76ERS
description: Micheal Ray Richardson refers to himself as ''a scorer.'' He calls Otis Birdsong, his backcourt mate, ''a shooter.''

title: A NEW-FOUND PEP AT P. & G.
description: PROCTER & GAMBLE, it is often said, resembles the long- slumbering giant of legend who wakes to discover the world has changed.

title: CONSUMER RATES
Andrea Harris, a Lawyer, Wed to Steven B. Cohen
description: Andrea S. Harris, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert S. Harris of Pittsburgh, was married yesterday to Steven B. Cohen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence H. Cohen of Little Neck, Queens. Rabbi Moshe V. Goldblum performed the ceremony at the Beth Shalom Synagogue in Pittsburgh.

title: THE WAR FOR INSTITUTIONAL COMISSIONS
description: EVERY piece of turf in the securities industry is being fought over, and none more viciously than commissions from the institutional equity business.

title: WHEN POTTERS' WHEELS WHIRRED
description: and, perhaps, inclination - early Long Islanders were a very practical breed. So when they discovered rich clay deposits running from Brooklyn to Greenport, rather than continue to import earthenware and stoneware from the Netherlands and old and New England, as far back as the 17th century, they began exploiting this natural resource.

title: BUSINESS NOTES
description: SYNTREX INC., an Eatontown based company that designs and sells office computer systems and names them for planets, also brings high technology into its public relations.

title: PRISONERS OF IDENTITY
description: ON its simplest level, Siegfried Stander's latest novel, ''Into the Winter,'' is about race, specifically the troubled relationship between emergent black Africa and white resistance, or indifference, to the new order. Beyond that, the book is about power, and its ineffectiveness if it is not acknowledged by those it is supposed to influence. Told with taut and compelling economy, the story is about two men - J. H. Van Zyl, an old Afrikaner cattle drover, and John Barunje, a young, black, London-educated game warden of a black-ruled country on South Africa's border. The story is also about two animals - a lone bull elephant, migrating south to die, and a buffalo that hovers in the elephant's tracks like an acolyte.

title: Protection
description: On the theory, perhaps, that a little quarterback can use some big help up front, the Generals are reportedly trying to sign

title: WHY MIGULIN MATTERS
description: THIS ambitious novel will probably surprise those who think of Yuri Trifonov as a writer of small-scale and minutely observed emotional detail - the ''Soviet Chekhov,'' as many have described him. In ''The Old Man,'' one of the last works Trifonov completed before he died in Moscow in 1981 at the age of 55, the walls containing Trifonov's cozy fictional world burst wide open. History - especially the bloody and complicated years of the civil war that followed the Russian Revolution - rushes in. It becomes, in fact, the protean and elusive protagonist.

title: Bhopal
description: To the Editor:

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: Get ready for a feast. Sunday the Regency Theater, which consistently presents the classiest retrospectives devoted to the masters of the commercial cinema, begins a nine-week program of films by Alfred Hitchcock. The series is by far the most comprehensive Hitchcock retrospective to be seen in New York since his death in 1980, and will present 41 of the 53 films he directed, including his first, ''The Pleasure Garden,'' a silent made in 1925, and his last, ''Family Plot'' (1976), featuring the supremely, disarmingly dizzy performance by Barbara Harris.

title: NEW GEAR SPANS THE GAP BETWEEN COMMONPLACE AND HI-FI
description: An invisible wall runs clear across the fruitful field of audio. On one side of the great divide lie the carefully tended acres of high-fidelity; on the other side sprawls the swampy patch of commonplace sound gear. A few companies straddle the wall and produce both kinds of equipment. Yet even in these ecumenical firms, engineers on the prestigious hi-fi side seldom talk to their mass-marketing colleagues. The wall stands impenetrably between them and their design attitudes. As one of them puts it, ''It's the custom system vs. the boom-box.''

title:
ART;

HE BLAZED ARTISTIC TRAILS
description: -1916) opened his summer art school at Shinnecock in 1891, he was one of the best-known and most respected figures in the American art world. His dapper, cosmopolitan air, sociability and personal confidence were already legendary.

title: M. Harvey Sherman, 67, Dies; E
description: M. Harvey Sherman, former assistant executive director and director of administration of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, died of a heart attack Jan. 25 in Boca Raton, Fla.

title: ;   THE ARMY'S LONG WAR AGAINST UMBRELLAS
description: To the Editor:

title: COONSKINS AND CONDIMENTS
description: Perhaps few readers of THE AMERICAN HISTORICAL SUPPLY CATALOGUE: A Nineteenth-Century Sourcebook (Schocken, Paper, $16.95), a fascinating compendium of 19th-century products available today, will feel a need to order a corset, a coonskin cap or a Cumberland all-purpose buggy (fringe optional), but the book is valuable as a breezy introduction to social and technological history. Three types of items are included - replicas (copies of old products), reproductions (products made by the same techniques, sometimes even with the same molds or dies, as the originals) and products that have been ''in continual production.''

title:
CABLE TV NOTES;

AN EXTRAORDINARY TEDDY BEAR JOINS THE DISNEY FAMILY
description: Will there soon be a SuperTed pavilion in Disneyland? The prospect seems unlikely. Nevertheless, the neighborhood

title: NUMBER ONE COMES HOME
description: A standing-room crowd of 6,192 basketball fans - excluding those who would be sorry and ducked out for popcorn - was on its feet and cheering like mad at St. John's Alumni Hall yesterday afternoon, as the drama built to a near fever pitch with shouts of ''He's Number One.''

title: NEW & NOTEWORTHY
description: Makers of the Postwar World, by Richard J. Barnet (Simon & Schuster, $10.95.) Our reviewer, Daniel Yergin, described the alliance as the ''political, military and economic relationships'' that tie the nations together. Writing in 1983, he said that ''The Alliance'' ''combines lively narrative history with deft political analysis and vivid, psychologically acute portraits of the men who created and have led the alliance.''

title: NEW AMERICANS: MAKING THE MOST OF OPPORTUNITY
description: HAVE you tried any bulgoki lately? Or have you dug your chopsticks into a rice bowl filled with steaming hot japchae? These are Korean dishes on the menu of a new Japanese and Korean takeout restaurant in Suffolk County. Reference to Korea may evoke memories of a war that took place in the 1950's or of the Olympics to be held in 1988. But Korea is also the source of a new stream of immigrants to America, people who tend to be quiet, hard-working entrepreneurs. Recently I met two of them.

title: ITALIAN THE WAY IT SHOULD BE
description: MIES VAN DER ROHE had it right when he said, ''Less is more.'' That can apply as much to restaurants as to modern architecture, as Pasta Nostra, a new trattoria on revitalized South Washington Street in South Norwalk so capably demonstrates.

title: 1960 Sit-In That Started Protests Is Re-Enacted
description: One of the four black students who ordered a snack at a segregated lunch counter 25 years ago, touching off civil rights demonstrations across the South, re-enacted that event Friday.

title: PROPELLED INTO SLAM
description: Just how far the organizing bodies of bridge should go in restricting bidding conventions is a hotly debated issue. Officials and experts have substantial areas of disagreement.

title: CUOMO CONDEMNS REAGAN POLICY ON SCHOOLS
description: The Reagan Administration's policy on education reflects ''a dangerous philosophy'' that benefits the wealthy and limits the prospects of less fortunate Americans, according to Governor Cuomo.

title: 'AROUND HERE, WE HAVE BANISHED THE VOICE'THE ART OF THE KNOCK
description: MOST of the more or less interrelated stories in ''The Art of the Knock,'' a first collection by Philip Graham, concern themselves with silences between people and attempts to fill the emptiness. Mr. Graham, who teaches at Southern Illinois University and has published stories in many magazines, offers characters who engage in ritualized acts that form fleeting connections but result, paradoxically, in deepening their sense of isolation. Though aching for closeness, the characters refuse to answer the phone, stop others when they try to talk, lie to each other outright. Elements of the real and the fantastic are so naturally balanced that after a while we begin to take their juxtaposition for granted. The voice in which the stories are told is cool and dry, the writing spare.

title:
GARDENING;

GROUND COVERS FOR LIGHT SHADE
description: WHEN talking about ground covers for shade, we are not talking about difficult shade that is dark and dense. Nor are we talking about a site with intense competition from shallow roots.

title: A YOUNG ACTRESS ADOPTS OLD WAYS
description: With her smooth forehead and serious eyes, her features softened by the glow of a kerosene lamp, the young Amish widow in the blue dress looks as if she belonged in a Vermeer painting. In a bare kitchen, amid jars of golden peaches, she moves and talks with quiet grace. Her face is composed; her eyes, shadowed by straight, dark brows, are rich with feeling.

title: HOW A HERO GETS DOWN FROM A DIVING BOARD
description: Zick Rubin is the Louis and Frances Salvage Professor of Social Psychology at Brandeis University and the author of ''Psychology: Being Human.'' CHANCING IT Why We Take Risks. By Ralph Keyes. 311 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $15.95.

title: REAGAN BUDGET TIGHTENS LID ON SOCIAL SPENDING
description: PRESIDENT Reagan is about to take the wraps off his new budget, and when he does, it will show plenty of red ink for the coming fiscal year and an only gradually diminishing red tide reaching far into the future.

title: NOT QUITE A BEST SELLER
description: Several hundred journalists and representatives of state and local governments swarmed into the main Government bookstore here today to buy advance copies of President Reagan's 1986 budget.

title: About Men ;   In On the Game
description: MY FRIENDS said: ''Man, Cab Calloway ain't got no radio show! Fats Waller ain't got none! What makes you think somebody's gonna give you one?''

title: Sarah Shinn Has Nuptials
description: Sarah LeBaron Shinn, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Latimer Shinn of New Vernon, N.J., and Manchester, Vt., was married yesterday to Dan Negrea, a son of Mrs. Alexandru Visan of Bucharest, Rumania, and the late Adrian Negrea. The Rev. George Chorba performed the ceremony at the New Vernon Presbyterian Church.

title: Miss MacKenzie Is Wed in Capital To Sam B. Rovit
description: The marriage of Abigail Caitlin MacKenzie, the daughter of Mrs. Jo W. Saxe of Washington and Kenneth MacKenzie of Chicago, to Sam Brian Rovit, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Earl H. Rovit of New York, took place yesterday. The ceremony was performed at the Women's National Democratic Club in Washington by the Rev. Louis L. Mitchell, an Episcopal priest, and Rabbi Harold White.

title: FLORIDA AIR TRAFFIC WARMING UP
description: -to-Florida travel increases this month, Northeastern International Airways, which filed for bankruptcy, is planning to increase its once-a-day flights from Long Island MacArthur Airport.

title:
DINING OUT;

ADD A STAR IN PASSAIC COUNTY
description: IT IS always gratifying when a restaurant

title: Sports of The Times;   How Ethiopia Touched a Poet
description: ALEX English learned about the famine in Ethiopia the way so many other Americans had - after a good dinner.

title:
ANTIQUES;

CHINESE COLLECTION IN GUILFORD
description: AFTER the War of 1812, growing numbers of American trading ships chartered a course for China. Because there were no canals, the long sea route took them around Cape Horn and more often than not the voyage and return trip took as long as three years.

title: POLAROID GROPES FOR ANOTHER WINNER
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

title: FRANCE'S AILING AUTO INDUSTRY
description: PARIS FOR France's embattled automobile industry, 1985 may prove to

title: THE MACHO MAKER OF NINETEEN EIGHTY-FOUR
description: Virginia Held, a fellow at the Center for Advanced Study in the Behavioral Sciences in Stanford, California, is the author of ''Rights and Goods: Justifying Social Action.''

title: NEW COMPETITION HURTS THE RETAIL
description: THE changes that are forecast for the retail securities business may fundamentally change the nature of the industry. The traditional revenue base of the retail brokerage firm is in jeopardy. But that is not the only threat to our future. More important, our relationships with our clients are going to be severely challenged, according to a recent study by the Securities Industry Association. The products and services offered by competitors of brokerage firms will continue to evolve. The dollars and resources that we must commit to new technologies will continue to rise.

title: WAYS TO FIX TRANSIT HUB SOUGHT
description: A TEAM of engineeers began last week to work on solutions to the structural problems in Stamford's new $35 million transportation center. The center was designed to replace the city's old rail station, but work on it was stopped in November.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: Behind some inane or puzzling titles can lurk some good vintage films, as happens this week on cable. Take the 1961 ''A Cold Wind in August.''

title: A TAPED REMINDER OF THE AMERICAN HOSTAGES IN BEIRUT
description: OVER the past 10 months five Americans have disappeared in Beirut, presumably kidnapped and held by Moslem terrorists hostile to the United States. Unlike the 53 Americans held by the Iranians in Teheran, the Beirut hostages had been largely ignored by their countrymen until last week when one of them made a 56-second appearance on a video tape.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: WHAT SHE TOLD HIM. By Carolyn Doty. Viking, $16.95)

title: UNION NEAR SALE OF COMPLEX
description: AFTER more than a decade of pressure from Federal and state officials, the International Union of Operating Engineers Local 138 is on the point of selling the Colonie Hill catering complex in Hauppauge.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Shane Rawley, the Philadelphia pitcher who had a 10-6 record after going to the Phillies in a trade with the Yankees last June, has signed a three-year contract, the Phillies announced. . . . This is a recorded announcement:

title: THE DISASTER IN BHOPAL: LESSONS FOR THE FUTURE
description: In this teeming central Indian city where an industrial gas leak in December killed more than 2,000 people, the problems and dilemmas faced by multinational companies in developing countries come into sharp focus.

title: U.S. AGENCY INVESTIGATES CHARGES MADE BY EX-WORKER AT SHOREHAM
description: The Federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission has begun an investigation into charges by a former quality-control inspector that he witnessed numerous violations at the $4.1 billion Shoreham nuclear power plant.

title: STAGE COSTUMES IN NEW SPOTLIGHT
description: -SOTO is having a ball. He's ensconced in the loft at the Maguire Theater on the campus of the State University of New York at Old Westbury, rummaging through more than 1,000 theatrical costumes that hang from every available rack, beam and pipe. Almost overnight, the university has acquired what is believed to be the largest collection of theatrical costumes of any institution of higher education on Long Island.

title: Second of two articles on zero-coupon securities. ;   SELECTING ZERO-COUPON MUNICIPALS
description: -coupon bonds sold to individuals are backed by Treasury securities and their payoff is taxable, unless the bonds are used as investments in tax-exempt Individual Retirement Acccounts, as many of them are. Lately, however, zeros backed by tax-free municipal bonds are also gaining popularity, particularly among people in high-tax brackets. In fact, tax-free municipals have become one of the hottest investments around as the prospect of tax simplification prompts the wealthy to replace the tax shelters they would ordinarily buy.

title: THE ALPHABETICAL ISSUES FROM A TO D
description: At 12:01 A.M. Feb. 17, new postage rates will go into effect. The new rates will be 22 cents for first class mail single ounce and 14 cents post card rate. With rather short public notice, the United States Postal Service released last Friday,

title: V-E DAY, THE RIGHT WAY
description: There is something remarkably wrong-headed but also funny about current efforts to celebrate the 40th anniversary of V-E Day, the Allied triumph over Nazi Germany, in May without at the same time embarrassing the Germans - our Germans, that is, the West Germans. It would be a mistake not to include them. Our enemies in 1945, they are now among our most important democratic allies.

title: TESTING FOR TRAITS THAT MAKE A MERGER
description: WHAT makes for effective management? Much of the early psychological research on this question was based on the assumption that managers possessed unique personal traits, such as intelligence, independence, self-confidence, etc., which set them apart from their subordinates. But this line of research led to disappointment. For one thing, it was felt that a list of such traits falls short of accounting for the unique aura that surrounds those in the corporate as well as the political world who truly lead.

title: By D. J. R. Bruckner. With ''Van der Steen About Himself,'' Translated by Ralph Read.   Illustrated. Unpaged. New York:   From International Publishing. $12.95.
description: GERMAIN VAN DER STEEN (1987-1964) was a French painter from a Dutch family, who at various times taught school, was gassed in World War I, ran a drugstore with his wife, and worked for the French Government. With - it would seem from reading his frank and rather naive autobiography - little encouragement from anyone, particularly his immediate family, he also produced fanciful portraits of cats. In the last 20 years of his life, he began to exhibit successfully in France and occasionally in other European countries.

title: QUALITY OF FORENSIC EVIDENCE HAS THE EXPERTS WORRIED
description: ''Let conversation cease. Let laughter flee. This is the place where death delights to help the living.'' That grim inscription engraved in Latin at the entrance to the New York City Medical Examiner's building at First Avenue and 30th Street has long been the guiding principle for a group of physicians and laboratory technicans who play vital roles in homicide investigations and the dispensation of justice.

title: 3 Chicago Firemen Killed
description: Three firefighters were killed Friday when the roof of a burning building collapsed under them. The deaths occurred as firefighters were trying to put out a blaze in two buildings on the city's Northwest Side in 14-below-zero weather.

title: THE LASTING IMPACT OF GERALDINE FERRARO
description: I probably qualify as one of those feminists who are out of touch with average American women, but it makes me cringe to see women describe themselves as weak and bitchy. When I look around, I see strong women everywhere - police officers, emergency medical technicians and, the women I know best, fellow physicians who routinely stay awake 36 hours to care for patients.

title: U.S. ENVOY'S GOAL: BETTER TIES TO GUATEMALA
description: In his first five months in office, the new American Ambassador to Guatemala has appeared especially concerned about improving ties between the United States and the country's military Government after years of strained relations because of continuing human rights abuses.

title: SAVING FARMLAND FROM SUBURBAN SPRAWL
description: MUCH of the state's abundantly fertile farmland is scenic and flat, making it ideal for crops and pasture. But it also is precisely what developers in the expanding suburbs have in mind when they search for new sites for houses.

title: Crime Protection Called Illusory
description: Street crime is epidemic in Plainfield. Financial resources are strained and citizens run from their cars to their homes to avoid being the next statistic.

title: BRIDGE REPAIRS OUTPACED BY RATE OF DETERIORATION
description: NEW JERSEY's vehicular bridges are deteriorating faster than they can be repaired, state transportation officials and engineering experts say.

title: ENGINEERS AT WORK ON TRANSIT CENTER
description: A TEAM of engineeers began last week to work on solutions to the structural problems in the new $35 million transportation center in Stamford, Conn. The center was designed to replace the city's old rail station, but work on it was stopped in November.

title: Headliners;   The Man Who Slipped By
description: The high point of Robert Latta's trip to Washington was an unescorted tour of the White House on the day that President Reagan was sworn into office.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: ALPINE SKIING, COUNTRY RENTAL
description: Off-Trail Skiing In the Alps Under the auspices of a company called Le Grand Ski, the phrase ''off the beaten track'' takes on a special meaning.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: GUSTAV MAHLER, RICHARD STRAUSS: Correspondence 1888-1911.dited by Herta Blaukopf. Translated by Edmund Jephcott. (University of Chicago, $22.50.)

title: THE PUBLIC AT LAST FINDS BENITA VALENTE
description: EARLIER THIS WINTER, ISAAC STERN GATHERED A few musical friends to play at a gala benefit for his beloved Carnegie Hall. The morning's rehearsal was like a party: everyone was kissing, pinching cheeks, whispering to those last seen at dinner in Rome, Vienna or Paris. It is this careless glamour that stamps music's stars. Galas are barometers; they measure whose careers at any given moment warrant an invitation. Playing for any gala of Isaac Stern's is the ultimate compliment. It did not go unnoticed, by all those international visitors, that sitting in the darkened house that morning, quietly waiting to rehearse, was Benita Valente.

title: IN SEARCH OF PRACTICAL SOLUTIONS FOR THE ISLAND'S TRAFFIC WOES
description: AS Dr. George Bugliarello states in ''Rx for the Island's Traffic Ills'' (Opinion Page, Jan. 6), drivers have at one time or another experienced the frustration of a traffic jam. While he goes on to recommend solutions to the traffic problems on our overburdened highways, one cannot overlook the serious traffic problems occurring on many of our main roads in Nassau County.

title: LAKE DISTRICT
description: To the Editor:

title: ART-SUPPLY MAKERS TO LABEL HAZADOUS ITEMS
description: Manufacturers of fine-art supplies used by hobbyists, schoolchildren and professional artists will soon begin to use labels that warn consumers that some of the products contain chemicals linked to such chronic diseases as nervous disorders, respiratory ailments and fetal damage.

title: A GALLERY FOR ILLUSTRATORS ONLY
description: ''ALL that I have done in the past, all that I could do in the future, would be utterly forgotten in a preciously few years except by a few friends and relatives, perhaps.''

title: Red Army Group Claims a Victim
description: The Red Army Faction, once known as the Baader-Meinhof gang, had been relatively quiescent since Ulrike Meinhof, Andreas Baader and other leaders died, evidently as suicides, in West German prisons in 1976 and 1977. But the leftist terrorist group seemed to catch fire again in December, and last week, it claimed responsibility for killing Ernst Zimmermann, who headed one of West Germany's largest defense contractors.

title: HIS FIELD: SWEET CHARITY, LEFT, RIGHT AND CENTER
description: FOR a man involved in many charitable endeavors, Edward W. Stack of Glen Head frequently finds himself in an unusual amount of controversy.

title: END TO PARTY-LINE VOTING GAINS IN CONNECTICUT
description: The State House of Representatives has approved an amendment to the State Constitution that would ban the party lever - which allows a voter to cast a ballot for all candidates on one ticket by pulling a single lever.

title: LEBANESE CABINET HAS CRISIS MEETING
description: The Lebanese Cabinet met in a marathon emergency session today to deal with a series of major crises, any one of which could bring it down.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM MODERN DANCE TO DIANA ROSS
description: Produced only 12 years after the 1962 Cuban missile crisis it so painstakingly re-creates, ''The Missiles of October'' is one of the granddaddies of television's ''docudrama'' form. Beginning on Oct. 16, a Tuesday, it proceeds through a grim countdown of 13 days in which, an unseen announcer declares, ''the world came to the brink of nuclear war.''

title: Egyptian Leaves for Talks
description: Egypt's Foreign Minister, Esmat Abdel Meguid, left today for official visits to London, Washington and Paris. Egypt has repeatedly called on European nations to play an active role to help settle Middle East disputes, and official sources here said Mr. Meguid would reassert this view in discussions with officials in London, his first stop.

title: ACTING COMPANY TO APPEAR AT PURCHASE
description: PURCHASE ''THERE must be theater here!'' declared Joan Vinton, the director of the Performing Arts Center at the State University of New York at Purchase for the last two years.

title: DANCE: THE SAMUL-NORI ENSEMBLE
description: The four musicians in the Korean ensemble known as Samul-Nori are all virtuoso percussionists. During the first half of their concert at the Asia Society on Friday night, their drumming - modulated into sounds of any nuance - could lead to total astonishment. One could also wonder why a dance critic had been especially invited to the performance.

title: REVIVING A MUSICAL AND AN AGE OF OPTIMISM
description: Attending the Broadway revival of ''The King and I'' recently, I was reminded of the time when Rodgers and Hammerstein were viewed as pop deities in somewhat the same way that the Beatles and Bob Dylan came to be idolized by the rock counterculture a decade and a half later. When ''The King and I'' opened in 1951, World War II was only six years gone. Still flushed with victory, America was settling into the nesting, fortress mentality of the postwar baby boom. Official optimism was the cultural order of the day.

title: SUHARTO AND ISLAM CLASH ON PRINCIPLE
description: ''Narrow acts of fanaticism,'' President Suharto called them. ''Forms of extremist activity that are harmful to all of us.''

title: SUPERSTARS OF MUSIC HEADING HERE
description: THE superstars are coming. These are the artists who are guaranteed to pack a house and gladden the hearts of many a local presenter suffering from mid-season box-office doldrums.

title: Lynne Damien Is Engaged To David John Champoux
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph L. Damien of Old Town, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter Lynne Marie Damien to David John Champoux, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Champoux of Lynn, Mass.

title: NEW CASTLE FAIREST IN STATE FOR TAXES
description: -tax assessments in the state, followed closely by Mount Kisco, according to an ''honor roll'' issued last month by the New York State Board of Equalization and Assessments.

title: ADVISING CATERPILLAR'S NEW PREISIDENT
description: MOVING earth is its mission. A road is being built in Jakarta, a sewer laid in Secaucus, fields cleared in Weisenau - wherever the heavy construction work goes on, you notice its mighty yellow monsters, hauling away mountains of dirt so that they can be dumped somewhere else. Caterpillar - or ''Cat,'' as it is called - has been hailed as a national treasure. It is by far the world's largest maker of earthmoving machinery, a crown it has proudly worn for decades. But now it is in trouble.

title: AFTER 50 YEARS, 'PORGY' COMES TO THE MET AS A CERTIFIED CLASSIC
description: When George Gershwin's ''Porgy and Bess'' opened at the Alvin Theater in 1935, it received the chilly reception all too familiar for visionary works of art. Many drama critics championed the ''folk opera,'' as Gershwin described it, but their musical brethren ranged from the befuddled to the belligerent. The production ran for only 124 performances and lost its entire $70,000 investment. Gershwin spent his own $10,000 in royalties paying the copyists and he died two years later, believing ''Porgy and Bess'' had been a failure.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: * THE LOG CABIN MYTH: The Social Backgrounds of the Presidents. By Edward Pessen. (Yale University, $16.95)

title: 'Hoping (in Vain) To Empty the Nest'
description: I've just finished reading ''Hoping (in Vain) to Empty the Nest'' (Opinion Page, Jan. 13). Marge Stickevers writes amusingly of a phenomenon that retards the growth of our children into adults.

title: MENTALLY DISTURBED USE POETRY AS PATH TO REALITY
description: Karen Chase is a poet. She also teaches mentally disturbed young adults at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center's division here to write poetry.

title: Carnegie has Chairman of Board
description: The Carnegie Corporation of New York, one of the country's leading foundations, has elected Helene L. Kaplan, a New York lawyer, as chairman of its 19-member board.

title: Barbara Anne Babenzien Marries Herman Tarnow
description: Barbara Anne Babenzien, a senior account executive at Liz Claiborne Sportswear in New York, and Herman Harris Tarnow, a partner in the New York law firm of Tarnow & Frank, were married in Boca Raton, Fla., yesterday. Judge Robert Gross of the Palm Beach County Court performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Robert Babenzien.

title: Amy Brady Is Engaged
description: The engagement of Amy Brady, associate director of the Pace/MacGill Gallery in New York, to Bryce C. Legg, a paralegal at the New York law firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Owen A. Brady of Hunt Valley, Md., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is a son of Barbara Blair of Oakton, Va., and the late William Beale Hibbs Legg Jr.

title: BUDGET SAID TO ASK END TO AID FOR AIR SERVICE
description: The Reagan Administration plans to ask Congress to end subsidies that assure commercial air service for 135 communities, hoping to save $45 million in the next fiscal year, according to officials in the Administration and in Congress.

title: Zoo Biz
description: Hoping to lift sagging attendance, the Miami MetroZoo added a special exhibit last October: a specimen that cavorted in a grassy pen with 14 giant tortoises and appeared to thrive on hamburgers, french fries and Coke fed by a keeper.

title: Dead Miners' Families To Share $5.15 Million
description: The families of seven coal miners killed in an underground explosion in 1981 near Topmost in eastern Kentucky will share $5.15 million to be paid by two coal companies, a lawyer for the families says.

title: Kean's Budget: Thinking Big
description: Governor Kean of New Jersey, a Republican, last week presented an election-year spending plan that his opponents said looked very much like a traditional Democratic blueprint. Mr. Kean's proposed $8.8 billion budget, which represents an 11 percent increase over this year's budget, contained heavy spending for programs that the Democrats claimed they had proposed first.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Postparty Depression

title: ;   Lake District
description: To The Editor: The story on England's Lake District (Travel, Dec. 2), which my wife and I toured last August, brought back many pleasant memories. Your readers may be interested in some notes on our own experience.

title: NON-ACADEMY GRADUATES GET TO NAVY JOBS
description: For the first time in its history, the United States Naval Academy is on the brink of losing its position as the source of a majority of the nation's front-line commodores and admirals.

title: Dr. Ellen Olson Becomes Bride of Thomas Flohr
description: Dr. Ellen Marie Olson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter E. Olson of Sanger, Calif., was married yesterday to Thomas M. Flohr, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Flohr of Blackhawk, Calif. The nondenominational ceremony was performed by the Rev. Robert H. Tarr, a Methodist minister, at the Cypress Inn in Carmel, Calif.

title: DANCE: A MULTIMEDIA PIECE BY LINDA MUSSMANN
description: Linda Mussmann gave one much to ponder in the new multimedia work she presented Thursday night at the West 19th Street Studio, 512 West 19th Street. Even its title, ''Avoidance and Peculiar,'' was enough to furrow the brow. One's efforts to unriddle that title were not necessarily aided when, during the course of the piece, someone remarked, ''Avoidance and peculiar are ways of opening doors and thinking about others.'' Now what, exactly, did that mean? And yet it did make a kind of sense.

title: Ellen Weinstein to Wed Lawyer
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Edward G. Weinstein of New York and Sagaponack, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Ellen Sue Weinstein, to Stephen James Adnopoz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Adnopoz of Hamden, Conn. A September wedding is planned.

title: BEHIND THE MASK
description: A STRINGENTS and facial masks are routinely used by millions of women to cleanse their skin, stimulate circulation, refine skin texture, control oil and moisture levels and even to banish lines and wrinkles.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: TWO WINTERS AND THREE SUMMERS, By Fyodor Abramov, Translated by D. B. Powers and Doris C. Powers. (Ardis Publishers, Cloth, $19.50. Paper, $7.50)

title: THE OVERSEER'S HOUSE
description: THE Overseer's House on the Croton Aqueduct in Dobbs Ferry has seen better days. Its listing on the National Register of Historic Places has given it attention but not preservation. The once-graceful columns are listing, the porch floor lacks several sections, and a visitor named JOHN is remembered in vivid blue paint splashed across the whitewashed brick wall.

title: 2 KILLED IN PLANE CRASH IN SOUTH JERSEY WOODS
description: Two men were killed Friday night when a twin-engine airplane crashed into woods in this Cumberland County community, about four miles from the Millville Municipal Airport, the authorities said today.

title: A KOREAN EXILE'S LONG JOURNEY HOME
description: Sanford J. Ungar tries to draw a parallel between the lives of Benigno S. Aquino Jr. and Kim Dae Jung, a Korean expatriate, and alleges that ''despite threats from Philippine President Ferdinand E. Marcos and his wife, Imelda, he (Aquino) had decided to go home to try to unite the democratic opposition to the Marcos regime.''

title: LIVELY GATEWAY TO THE ALPS
description: A dewy orange disk, the sun, was pasted in the sky over the white Nymphenburg Palace, which glowed in the snow like some central European Taj Mahal. Out on the bumpy ice of the canal old men hunched over their curling stones - with long straight handles adorned with colored tassels to distinguish the teams - grunting and calling out in the choppy Bavarian idiom as the opposing stones clacked off one another, spinning into the snowbanks. In the middle distance - the scene seemed an updated version of a Brueghel oil that might hang in Munich's Alte Pinakothek - children scampered about with hockey sticks, chattering merrily. On a stretch of shoveled ice unto herself, a sleek woman in a big hat was trying to get the hang of a new-looking pair of skates (or was it skating itself?), making cautious, mincing steps; the seat of her leather pants was dusted with snow, hinting at setbacks in this wobbly enterprise.

title: No Headline
description: Sierra Club Stand On Resource Recovery The Environment column of Jan. 20 may have given some readers the impression that the Sierra Club in New Jersey opposes resource-recovery facilities.

title: HOW TO SET UP A MATING ATTACK
description: There was no surprise in the outcome of the Balatonbereny (Hungary) International Tournament: Gyula Sax, a 33-year-old Hungarian grandmaster, had the highest ranking on the International Chess Federation's computer and he captured first prize.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE REWRITE MAN.By Brian Forbes. (Simon & Shuster, $16.95.) Harvey Burgess, a writer who earns his living by altering the creations of others, finds various ways to describe his vocation and none are particularly favorable.

title: STATE MOVES AHEAD ON BRIDGE REPAIRS
description: HARTFORD ONE year after Governor O'Neill gave the General Assembly his plan for renewing the state's transportation network, more than 100 contracts totaling $42.5 million have been awarded for the repair of state-owned bridges.

title: U.S. FINDS RUSSIANS FAVOR TRADE BUT IT IS UNLIKELY TO RELAX CURBS
East Undergoes Surgery
description: Senator John P. East, Republican of North Carolina, underwent surgery Friday to remove an obstruction from his urinary tract, his office said. The operation was described in a statement by Dr. Kevin O'Connell, chief of urology at Bethesda Naval Hospital, as ''common surgery,'' and the obstruction was said to be benign.

title: Miss Schechner To Wed in April
description: An April wedding is planned by Marjorie Schechner and Thomas Allen Gart, her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Schechner of Maplewood and Deal, N.J., have announced.

title: Courts Too Easy On Drunken Drivers
description: Publicity, victim distress and public outrage be damned - drunken driving seems not only to thrive in practice, but to be condoned in court.

title: HOOSIERS' HEADSTRONG COACH FINDS THE PAST IS NOT ENOUGH
description: AFTER days of debate as intense as the Bob Knight era has known, the red-clad patrons filled Assembly Hall last Thursday night to get down to the business that their coach has made into an overpowering psychological art form at Indiana University - winning through intimidation.

title: CHINA TO STEP UP WESTERN IMPORTS
description: A senior Chinese economic official said here today that China would substantially step up its purchases of Western machinery and other high-technology items this year as part of a drive to quadruple its wealth by the end of the century.

title: SCIENTIST CHALLENGES FOSSILS MARY LEAKEY FOUND 7 YEARS AGO
description: A South African anthropologist said today that Mary Leakey, the famed Kenyan researcher, mistakenly chiseled an ''artificial heel'' into some fossil footprints of apelike men because her eyesight was failing.

title: Emily M. Bateson To Wed an Editor
description: Mr. and Mrs. Adams H. Nickerson of New York and Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Nickerson's daughter Emily M. Bateson to Thomas C. Cooper, a son of Malcolm E. Cooper of Dorset, Vt., and the late Marian Curtin Cooper. A June wedding is planned.

title: INQUIRY SAYS RECORD DEALERS WITHHELD FAMINE RELIEF FUNDS
description: The cover of a top-10 single record says that all profits it generates will go to help famine victims in Ethiopia. But an investigation by the Connecticut Attorney General has found that six record stores in the state have not been donating their profits from the record, ''Do They Know It's Christmas?''

title: ARCHER FIXES SIGHTS ON '88 OLYMPICS
description: ERIC E. HALL of Bolton was 19 years old when he began competing in archery contests to earn extra money, and in six years, he has compiled an impressive record.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE ENCHANTRESS. By Han Suvin. (Batam, $16.95.)

title: CLAY-POT COOKING KEEPS IN JUICES AND TAKES LITTLE WATCHING
description: ONE of the more satisfying methods of cooking is braising, allowing food to cook slowly, covered, in a small amount of liquid, often after a preliminary browning. A vessel particularly suited to this technique is the clay pot.

title: SHAKE-UP IS REPORTED IN CUBA'S COMMUNIST PARTY HIERARCHY
description: The Central Committee of the Cuban Communist Party gave strong support to Fidel Castro this week and demoted a top party official who was apparently a leading critic of Mr. Castro's foreign policy.

title: DECISION ON LOW-COST POWER STIRS PROTESTS
description: WHITE PLAINS

title: Celebrating the Death' of Quotas
description: The death of numerical quotas as a device for remedying the effects of discrimination was announced to the President last week by the chairman of the Civil Rights Commission, Clarence M. Pendleton Jr. He based his diagnosis on recent court decisions, in particular a Supreme Court ruling in June that Memphis could not lay off white firefighters with seniority to preserve the percentage of blacks called for under a plan to remedy past discrimination.

title: Landslides in China Kill 60
description: Heavy rains in Shaanxi Province have caused landslides that have killed 60 people, buried whole villages and devastated farmland in the last two months, China Daily reported today. In the worst incident, in early December, 20 farmers died and 10 were dug from debris after a 300-foot ridge crashed down on a hamlet.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER: GOING WITH YOUR VIDEOCAMERA
description: When he arrived at the Siberian seaport of Nakhodka last June 16, Keith A. McKinley was elated. He had just spent several days with Japanese friends north of Tokyo, followed by a two-and-a-half-day voyage on the Soviet motorship Khabarovsk from Yokohama to Nakhodka across the Sea of Japan - and he had videotaped it all. ''The three hours of recorded tape chronicled these events and the very pleasant life aboard the Soviet vessel,'' Mr. McKinley, a lawyer from Osage, Iowa, recalled recently. ''The ship, its crew, the food, the entertainment and an idyllic crossing had all been delightful.''

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption accompanying the article on misericords (Travel, Dec. 30) incorrectly identified a church. The picture showed a bank of misericords from the church in St. Martin aux Bois, near Paris.

title: KENYA'S RURAL CLINICS FACE INCREASING STRAIN
description: KISUMU, Kenya

title:
WEEK IN BUSINESS;

JOBLESS RATE RISES, AS DOES JOB TOTAL
description: Better or Worse? The rise in the nation's overall unemployment rate to 7.3 percent in January, from 7.1 percent in December, drew mixed reactions. Optimists said the 350,000 jobs created during the month was a positive sign, but did not offset the number of people entering the job market. Pessimists said most of the new jobs were in the service sector, not the more basic industrial sector. They noted that the jobless increase heightens fears of a growth recession, when the economy expands so slowly that not enough new jobs are created.

title: Dorothy Whitmarsh, a Vice President At a Brokerage, Wed to John Sprague
description: Dorothy Sutton Whitmarsh, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore F. Whitmarsh of New York and Upper Brookville, L.I., was married yesterday to John Arthur Sprague, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Wallace A. Sprague of Short Hills, N.J. The Rev. Susan Harris performed the ceremony at St. James' Episcopal Church in New York.

title: Castro Called Willing To Cut Africa Force
description: Cuba is ready to reduce its military presence in Africa and has already sharply cut the number of troops stationed in Ethiopia, according to the Cuban leader, Fidel Castro.

title: THE LASTING IMPACT OF GERALDINE FERRARO
description: Maureen Dowd's article was an insightful overview of the 1984 election and Mrs. Ferraro's impact on it.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: MEN AND ABORTION: Lessons, Losses, and Love.

title: WINTERDANCE UNDER WAY IN YONKERS
description: WINTERDANCE, a performing arts festival sponsored by the City of Yonkers and now in its third year, is continuing its stated purpose of bringing professional dance to the county in what would ordinarily be an off season in Westchester.

title: The Democrats Settle on a New Chairman
description: For a while last week, it looked as if the Democrats' latest electoral embarrassment would be entirely of their own making. As the campaign for the party chairmanship headed into its final days, Nancy Pelosi, a former state party leader in California, accused officials of the A.F.L.- C.I.O. of mounting a sexist attack on her candidacy in an attempt, she said, to aid a rival, Paul G. Kirk Jr. She complained, ''They use some of the language of the day: 'She's an airhead,' ''

title: WILIAM KANE DIES: CHAIRMAN OF A.&P. DURING EARLY 1970's
description: William J. Kane, a former clerk who rose through the ranks to become chairman and chief executive of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, the food retailing concern, died Friday at his home at Franklin Lakes, N.J. He was 72 years old.

title: Carolyn Davis to Wed A Law School Student
description: Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Edward Davis of Glen Ridge, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Carolyn Woodbury Davis, to Matthew Forbes Erskine, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Linwood Mandeville Erskine Jr. of Worcester and Paxton, Mass. A June wedding is planned.

title: BHOPAL
description: To the Editor:

title: RESCUING CLEVELAND SCHOOLS MAY BE HARDER THAN EVER
description: Frederick D. Holliday came to Cleveland 27 months ago to take over a deteriorating, financially troubled public school system in a city that was still divided over a 1976 desegregation order. Until Dr. Holliday killed himself last week, the schools appeared to be improving, though probably not as quickly as he would have liked.

title: ROUTE 25A PROJECT GETS A GREEN LIGHT
description: AFTER more than a year of revisions, the State Department of Transportation has decided to go ahead with a $2.5 million plan to straighten one and one-fourth miles of Route 25A between Little Neck Road in Centerport and Woodbine Avenue in Northport.

title: LOOKING FOR A HANDLE ON INTELLIGENCE ACTIVITIES
description: When Senator Dave Durenberger, the new chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee, held the panel's first public meeting last week, he told his colleagues that serving on the committee was a ''thankless duty,'' but an intriguing one. ''There is a good deal of mystery - and a lot of curiosity - about what this committee does,'' the Minnesota Republican said.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MONDAY, FEBRUARY 4, 1985

title: Dr. Carol M. D'Aquino Married to an Internist
description: Dr. Carol Madeleine D'Aquino, a clinical physician for the Public Health Service at Woodhull Hospital in Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Dr. David Dannon Goldstein, an emergency-room internist at Bailey Seton Hospital in Clifton, S.I. The Rev. James Lisante, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Renaissance Country Club in Roslyn, L.I. He was assisted by Rabbi Irwin Lowenheim.

title: NOT ONLY MEESE IS NOW ON TRIAL
description: No President in modern times has put up a more moralistic front and done less to enforce ethical standards in government than Ronald Reagan. His nomination of Edwin Meese 3d as Attorney General follows the ugly pattern. It makes a mockery of the messages we hear almost daily from the White House about what makes America great.

title: NAME THAT CONGRESSMAN
description: For those who pride themselves on Congressional lore, here is a quiz based on recent research by Roll Call, the newspaper of Capitol Hill. The answers are elsewhere on this page.

title: Precisionist Wins Strub Stakes by Nose
description: Precisionist beat Greinton by a nose and joined some elite company today when he won the Charles H. Strub Stakes at Santa Anita Park.

title: RANGERS FALL, 4-1
description: Yes, they got shots. But no, the Rangers didn't win.

title: With Davis Back, Suns Win, 120-109
description: With Walter Davis playing for the first time this season, the Phoenix Suns overcame a 30-point performance by Jack Sikma and held on to defeat the Seattle SuperSonics, 120-109, tonight.

title: Again, the Malpractice Crunch
description: It wasn't all that long ago that $54,282 was a handsome annual income for a New York physician. But it's what a Long Island obstetrician must now pay each year just to insure himself against malpractice suits. The costs of such insurance are soaring. State officials talk about letting one insurance company raise next year's premiums by 52 percent. That alone could add as much as $20 to the cost of an office visit.

title: STREET-SMART RAPPING IS INNOVATIVE ART FORM
description: Two years ago, Joseph Simmons was sitting in class at La Guardia Community College in Queens, jotting rhymes and observations in his notebook to pass the time. ''One thing I know is that life is short,'' he wrote - hardly a surprising observation, since the class was in mortuary science. ''The next time someone's teaching, why don't

title: 8 CASES: EXPLANATIONS BY CHIEF MEDICAL EXAMINER AND THE ISSUES INVOLVED
description: Dr. Elliot M. Gross, New York City's Chief Medical Examiner, issued statements yesterday explaining his position on some of the cases for which he has been criticized. Following is a brief account of each case, a statement by Dr. Gross and a description of the issues involved.

title: Stratus Computer Head Plots Concern's Course
description: William E. Foster, president of Stratus Computer Inc., is a man who follows the strategic course he and other executives plot for the company.

title: ST. JOHN'S CAN'T AFFORD A LETUP
description: St. John's moves into the last five weeks of its regular-season schedule as the nation's No. 1 college basketball team. But the Redmen have been more of a curiosity than a national surprise thus far.

title: Spending Is Reduced For Executive Office
description: President Reagan's 1986 budget calls for a $5 million decrease in executive office spending, including minor cuts in maintaining and operating the White House.

title: 16 Hurt in Elevator Accident
description: Sixteen people were injured Saturday when an elevator carrying conventioneers from the 20th floor of the Radisson South Hotel malfunctioned and dropped to the first floor before emergency brakes stopped it. The passengers were attending a three-day state Jaycees convention. The elevator was taken out of service while inspectors for the state and the Otis Elevator Company investigated, a hotel spokesman said.

title: The Quilted Senators
description: The National Peace Quilt will be

title: TRANSIT OFFICIALS FEAR BUDGET CUTS
description: Public transit services across the country ''will begin an immediate, unavoidable and massive decline'' if the Reagan Administration's planned cuts in transportation aid are enacted, according to a report made public this weekend by the American Public Transit Association.

title: BEHIND SMILE, TROUBLED MAN
description: The athlete perhaps best personifies the modern American dream. He enjoys the riches of a lottery winner and the adulation of a national hero. He is a role model for youngsters and a source of escape for those who toil in a more pedestrian world.

title: In Re Teaching
description: In a city where a half-dozen law

title: The U.N. Today
description: Feb. 4, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: U.S. DAY-CARE GUIDELINES REKINDLE CONTROVERSY
description: Since the Federal Government's announcement last month of model day-care guidelines urging employee background checks and other policies designed to counter child abuse, the proposals have been drawing criticism from some child-development experts, day-care professionals and national lawmakers. These critics have revived a decades-old controversy over attempts to set minimum national standards for day care.

title: O'MEARA CAPTURES CROSBY BY 1 SHOT
description: Mark O'Meara sank three consecutive putts late in the final round, saving par at the 17th from a plugged lie in wet sand to preserve a one-stroke lead and win the 44th Bing Crosby National Pro-Am tournament today.

title: COLD-WEATHER CRIME
description: To the Editor:

description: As a pupil at Public School 161 in the

title: A Farewell Party
description: Like some of the departing Treasury officials, many members of the first Reagan Administration used the post-election interregnum to take new jobs. But few are getting a send-off like Robert C. Odle.

title: NEW ARMS AND EXPANDED FORCES SOUGHT BY PENTAGON
description: President Reagan will send Congress a military budget Monday that seeks to sustain his expansion of American forces and modernization of equipment for the duration of his second term in office.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;   Three Years Of Serving the Homeless
description: Guests. That is not a word usually associated with the homeless. But the Rev. Thomas F. Pike said it is used by the congregation of St. George's Episcopal Church on Stuyvesant Square to speak of the 20 or so homeless men and women who are given shelter there every night.

title: Festival Presents Work Of Young Playwrights
description: Four plays by writers between the ages of 15 and 18 will be produced this spring as part of the Young Playwrights Festival. The plays were chosen in a nationwide school contest sponsored by the Foundation of the Dramatists Guild to develop an interest in writing for the theater.

title: SANDINISTA CHIEF SEES NEW DANGER OF U.S. INVASION
description: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra said today that the Reagan Administration was turning its back on a political settlement in Nicaragua and was considering ''a military solution'' to overthrow his leftist Government.
