title: GEORGETOWN REBOUNDS, 56-39
description: Patrick Ewing scored 18 points and keyed a tenacious defensive effort that helped Georgetown snap its two- game losing streak today with a 56-39 victory over Arkansas.

title: PROBLEMS OF PARENTAL NARCISSISM
description: A 10-year-old boy came home from

title: JAPANESE CARS IMPROVE IN CRASH-TEST RATINGS
description: Japanese cars, long superior to American cars in fuel economy, are beginning to challenge Detroit in ability to survive crashes, according to an analysis of Government and insurance company findings.

title: GREEK POLICE SAY A BOMB CAUSED EXPLOSION AT BAR NEAR A U.S. BASE
description: The Greek police said today that an explosion in a bar in an Athens suburb that wounded 78 people, most of them American military personnel, was caused by a bomb apparently planted by an anti-American terrorist group.

title: MusicNoted in Brief;   Woody Herman Sextet In the King Cole Room
description: Woody Herman has put his big band on hold for 10 weeks while he presents a ''Jazz Cabaret'' in the King Cole Room of the St. Regis- Sheraton Hotel.

title: HANOI LEADER WANTS BETTER TIES WITH PEKING
description: Vietnam's Communist Party leader has acknowledged in a speech marking the party's 55th anniversary that there are ''shortcomings and mistakes'' in Vietnam's economic and ideological affairs, according to reports from the Vietnam News Agency.

title: Player Held At Gunpoint
description: Tony Neal, Fullerton State's top scorer and rebounder, was abducted at gunpoint Saturday night by a man who robbed him and threatened to kill him before freeing the athlete north of here in Los Angeles County, authorities said.

title: PRESIDENT FOCUSES ON DOMESTIC CUTS TO REDUCE DEFICIT
description: President Reagan will send a $973.7 billion budget to Congress on Monday that proposes to sustain a buildup of the military while shrinking the domestic budget, mostly by curtailing programs that benefit the middle class.

title: EAGLE SURVEY TESTS SKILLS OF SPOTTERS
description: Armed with binoculars and telescopes, they searched from helicopters, airplanes, canoes, motorboats, ferries, cars and on foot.

title: 'DIRTY DOZEN: NEXT MISSION,' ON NBC
description: They don't make wars like they used to. Guys like William Bendix and Anthony Quinn hit the beach at Guadalcanal; Brian Donleavy protected Wake Island. These were real guys. They looked like the rest of us. The new guys look only like one another. In ''The Dirty Dozen: Next Mission'' we can hardly tell them apart. They are in the ''NBC Monday Night at the Movies'' on Channel 4 at 9 o'clock.

title: 'THE KING AND I': A TV MARKETING SUCCESS STORY
description: A New Yorker active in the theater industry went for a haircut recently. He had gone to the same barber for 12 years and the barber had rarely talked about theater. This time, however, he not only brought up the subject but asked a favor. Could his customer help him get tickets to ''The King and I''?

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;   No Winter Wonderland For the Road Racer
description: Both Currier and Ives would have

title: A Hint of Wisdom in South Africa
description: Armed with new constitutional powers, South Africa's President P. W. Botha now talks of some new concessions to a powerless black majority. He hints at reviewing cruel housing laws and providing some form of ''consultation'' with blacks inside the airtight compartments of apartheid. But more surprisingly, he has dared mention the hitherto unmentionable - the possible release from prison of Nelson Mandela. That could be something.

title: NEWS ORGANIZATIONS IGNORE TIME SET ON PUBLISHING
description: A White House restriction on news reports about details of President Reagan's 1986 budget was widely ignored this weekend as some news organizations said that others had ignored it.

title: LIBYA PLANNING TO FREE 4 BRITONS
description: Four Britons detained in Libya since last spring will be released Monday into the custody of Terry Waite, a special envoy of the Archbishop of Canterbury, a spokesman for the Archbishop said today.

title: A Glitch in Spanish Deal
description: It could be rain in Spain for A.T.&T. if Madrid won't assure Washington that the Russians will not pick up any technological secrets from a $200 million microchip factory that the telephone company is planning with Compania Telefonica Nacional de Espana.

title: New Wildfire Contained Near a Miami Airport
description: Firefighters contained a new wildfire late today that burned 400 acres of grass and woods just five miles west of the busy Miami International Airport, the authorities said.

title: CITY BALLET: 'POULENC SONATA' AND 'CALCIUM LIGHT NIGHT'
description: A repeat performance of ''Poulenc Sonata,'' Peter Martins's most recent ballet, was offered by the New York City Ballet on Saturday afternoon in the New York State Theater. The program also included ''Calcium Light Night,'' the work with which Mr. Martins made his choreographic debut in 1977. The two ballets are similar in several ways. They are small in scale, yet rich in detail and, although both are plotless, they are filled with dramatic implications. Both were also well danced.

title: ELIZABETH TAYLOR: JOURNAL OF A RECOVERY
description: Elizabeth Taylor slipped on a pair of reading glasses, opened a blue notebook and extinguished her cigarette.

title: Lisa Kurzner Marries L. W. Bloomenkranz
description: Lisa Kurzner, the daughter of Wilma Kurzner of New York and the late Dr. Martin M. Kurzner, was married at the Carlyle yesterday to Lawrence William Bloomenkranz, a son of Mr. and Mr. Sol Bloomenkranz of Paris and Calpe, Spain.

title: Jazz Highlights
description: The concert series ''Highlights in Jazz'' will celebrate its 12th anniversary at 8 P.M. on Feb. 13 with performances by Doc Cheatham, Phil Bodner, Ray Mosca, Marty Napoleon, Major Holley, Glenn Zottola, Loren Schoenberg, Carrie Smith, and a surprise guest at New York University's Loeb Student Center, 566 LaGuardia Place. Tickets are $7.50; $6 for students. Information: 598-2027.

title: Insurance Ban In Louisiana BATON ROUGE, La. Feb. 3
description: Louisiana insurance

title: REPUBLICANS SEE OPPORTUNITY
description: As President Reagan sets out his budget and political agenda, Republican leaders are, for the fifth time in three decades, talking hopefully of a political realignment that would clearly make theirs the nation's majority party.

title: ;   HOW TO SAVE S.R.O.'S FROM WRECKER'S BALL
description: To the Editor:

title: SANTE FE NEWSPAPER APOLOGIZES AGAIN TO SETTLE LAWSUIT BY INDIANS
description: For the third time in five months The Santa Fe New Mexican has publicly apologized to a local Indian tribe for printing photos of tribal religious dances taken from a low-flying airplane.

title: Cross at the Red
description: Some local customs cannot be

title: LEADERS IN BOTH PARTIES EXPRESS DOUBT ON REAGAN PLAN'S FATE IN CONGRESS
description: Congressional leaders from both parties, armed with advance copies of President Reagan's budget, voiced doubt today that Congress would readily embrace Mr. Reagan's proposals to increase military spending and impose deep cuts in domestic programs.

title: Camacho Signs With King
description: Don King has concluded promotional agreements with Hector (Macho) Camacho and the Forum in Inglewood, Calif., according to Bobby Goodman, King's matchmaker.

title: NEW YORK A BIG LOSER UNDER REAGAN BUDGET
description: President Reagan's proposals to reduce Federal support for local governments would cost New York City between $600 million and $700 million in the coming fiscal year and could lead to higher transit fares, cuts in services and layoffs, city officials said today.

title: Highlights of the Budget
description: Following are highlights of the budget for fiscal year 1986 that President Reagan is to send to Congress Monday: Outlays. Projected to rise $14.6 billion in 1986, to $973.7 billion. Revenues.

title: Limited House Arrest Expected
description: Kim Dae Jung could be subject to the same form of limited house arrest as Kim Young Sam, another dissident leader, a Western diplomat in Seoul said today.

title: POP: ASHFORD & SIMPSON AT RADIO CITY MUSIC HALL
description: Buoyed by the biggest hit of their 15-year career as a performing duo, Ashford & Simpson rolled into Radio City Music Hall on Friday with an act designed around their number-one pop-soul hit, ''Solid.'' An emphatic mid-tempo celebration of long-lasting conjugal bliss, ''Solid'' has helped give the husband-wife team their first number-one album ever on the black music chart. Its popularity suggests that after dabbling in social realism and conceptual song cycles on recent albums, pop romance is finally Ashford & Simpson's true forte. With gracefully choreographed stage movements built around Mr. Ashford's song lyrics and professional lovebird dialogue, they are something like the pop-soul equivalent of Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers and Steve Lawrence and Eydie Gorme, all rolled into a single package.

title: JAZZ: THE MARTY EHRLICH TRIO
description: Marty Ehrlich has played one wind instrument or another with just about every major new-jazz musician in New York. Tuesday at Sweet Basil he emerged as a worthy bandleader with the trio that appears on his first album, ''The Welcome.''

title: 3 Oil Concerns Settle Charges
description: Three major oil companies have agreed to pay a total

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I beg you, with pain in my heart, and at the same time with firmness and hope, that you reflect on the roads you have taken. In the name of God, change roads!'' - Pope John Paul II, urging nonviolence in Peru's political struggle. (A1:3.)

title: Advertising;   Bojangles Account To Scali
description: SCALI, McCABE, SLOVES has won the competition for the Bojangles of America account. And that means more chicken on the table.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
description: GLITZ. By Elmore Leonard. 251 pages.

description: WASHINGTON A strong new American policy has

title: Market Place;   Exhilarating Stock Week
description: THE Dow Jones industrial average eked out a

title: Treasury to Sell $19 Billion Package
description: Treasury auctions will dominate the credit markets this week, as the Government will sell a $19 billion package of notes and bonds to retire about $8 billion of maturing debt, and raise $11 billion to pay for the Federal budget deficit.

title: UNASSUMING YANKEE FACES HIGH HOPES WITH APLOMB
description: EVANSVILLE, Ind.

title: OUTDOORS: ART OF SPEARING EELS
description: WEST TISBURY, Mass.

title: EUROPE'S SURPRISING RECOVERY
description: Analysts are being pleasantly surprised by the economic recovery that began in Britain in 1982, gathered steam last year in Germany and now is taking hold in virtually every country from Scandinavia to the Mediterranean.

title: FRANK OPPENHEIMER, NUCLEAR PHYSICIST, DIES
description: Frank Oppenheimer, a nuclear physicist whose left-wing associations contributed to the end of the government career of his older brother, J. Robert Oppenhemier, died of cancer yesterday in his home in Sausalito, Calif. He was 73 years old.

title: Northern Irish Politician Plans Talks With I.R.A.
description: John Hume, the leading Northern Ireland politician from a nationalist party that rejects violence, said today that he planned to meet with leaders of the Provisional Irish Republican Army in spite of opposition from the Irish Prime Minister and British authorities.

title: Stars and Copyrights
description: The Library of Congress has

title: Greenland Out of E.E.C.
description: Greenland has dropped its affiliation with the European Economic Community, becoming the first territory to leave the Common Market since the founding Treaty of Rome went into effect on Jan. 1, 1958.

title: POPE BEGS REBELS TO END PERU WAR
description: Pope John Paul II issued a dramatic plea today to guerrilla fighters in this rugged Andean mountain province to lay down their arms and ''seek the roads of dialogue and not those of violence.''

title: FRANCE'S FADING REDS
description: PARIS The French Communist Party,

title: WELL, IT WAS SO COLD THE TOWN STAYED INDOORS
description: Temperatures soared to 15 degrees above zero here today, allowing Dale Albrecht a chance to do something besides try to get frozen cars started.

title: TEXT OF BUDGET MESSAGE PRESIDENT REAGAN IS SENDING TO CONGRESS TODAY
description: Following is the Budget Message that President Reagan is to send to Congress on Monday:

title: THE THEATER: 'CHARLEY BACON AND HIS FAMILY'
description: Hollywood, as seen by Arthur Giron in his new comedy, ''Charley Bacon and His Family,'' is a lunatic-land in which everyone is crazy to be connected to the movies and is desperately trying to restrain Charley Bacon. Charley's parents are extras; his mother's hands stand in, or rather hand in, for those of Joan Crawford. At home she could pass for a Mommie Dearest. The father of Charley's girlfriend tyrannically guards the gate at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer and is also the watchdog of his daughter's virtue.

title: TAXATION, CHOWDER AND TROUT
description: Despite a half-dozen losses over 60 years, a campaign to bring a sales tax to Oregon has a good chance of success this year, in the view of lobbyists and political writers here.

title: Reagan Commends Israel
description: Israel made public a message from President Reagan today commending Israel on its economic efforts. In a letter written to Prime Minister Shimon Peres last Wednesday reciprocating season's greetings, the President wrote: ''The efforts of your Government to strengthen Israel's economy are to be greatly commended. You can be assured of my continued interest and sympathetic concern as you carry on with this difficult undertaking.''

title: MONDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: St. John's at Seton Hall , at South Orange, N.J., 8 P.M. Since being elevated to the No. 1 ranking one week ago today, the Redmen had little trouble with Providence and Connecticut last week. But Seton Hall, another of the have-nots in the Big East, could be dangerous in its small home arena.

title: GIFTS TO NEEDIEST CASES FUND EXPRESS CONCER FOR THE AGED
description: To be old, poor and sick is to be among the neediest,'' Beatrice W. Greenbaum of Great Neck, L.I., wrote at the beginning of a note explaining her contribution of $100 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund in memory of her mother, who died recently.

title: STAGE: 'IMPACT,' POLICE STORY
description: Juan Shamsul Alam's ''Impact'' is a play that wants desperately to say something important on the subject of rape. But except for crudely re-stating the obvious - that society's victims become its predators - all it does is rub our noses in psychological cruelty and poorly simulated physical violence over the course of two interminable acts.

title: Toxic-Waste Suit Settled in Jersey
description: Four residents of this city who sued the state and others for failing to reduce hazards at the site of the Chemical Control Corporation here have received a $186,000 settlement.

title: BANK RESULTS SHOW DIVERSITY
description: Earnings statements for the fourth quarter and all of last year show mixed results among the nation's 15- largest banking companies. Analysts expect this trend to continue, they said, because deregulation is rapidly changing the financial environment.

title: WARRIORS' 33-5 SPREE DOOMS THE KNICKS
description: A large, plain sign hangs above the blackboard in the locker room of the Golden State Warriors at Oakland Coliseum Arena. It reads: ''The Second Half Is Ours.''

title: MORE RIDERS NEEDED FOR TAXI PLAN TO WORK
description: To the Editor:

title: Offers Mass in Lima
description: The Pope returned here tonight to offer mass before hundreds of thousands of people at the city's race track. In his sermon, he said priests should be ''before everything, true teachers of the faith, the truth and the spiritual life, and not mere human leaders.''

title: EUROPE'S ROUNDTABLE PROMOTES GROWTH
description: In 1972, a group of chief executive officers from leading American corporations, convinced that the business community was widely misunderstood, formed the Business Roundtable to get their point of view across to Government officials and the general public.

title: CONDITIONS FAVOR BOND RETIREMENT
description: The sharp drop in bond yields and rise in bond prices in recent months is a tremendous benefit to many local governments and corporations that are using the opportunity to refinance outstanding bonds sold when interest rates were much higher.

title: MUSIC: 'HUMS AND SONGS OF WINNIE-THE-POOH'
description: A setting of ''Hums and Songs of Winnie-the-Pooh'' by the prodigiously gifted English composer Oliver Knussen provided the most enjoyment on the New Music Consort's Thursday evening program at the Manhattan School of Music.

title: STAGE: ALBERT INNAURATO'S 'COMING OF AGE IN SOHO'
description: It's no secret that Albert Innaurato's new play, ''Coming of

title: A PRAVDA TALE OF AEROFLOT'S UNFRIENDLY SKIES
description: A night on a wooden chair in a strange airport, followed by a morning in which the passengers themselves had to push the ramp up to their plane, has drawn a cry of protest from a Pravda reporter.

title: SWISS SKIERS TRIUMPH
description: Two young Swiss stars, Pirmin Zurbriggen and Michela Figini, won the downhill races today at the World Alpine Ski Championships.

title: Draft Opinion in Trial In Atlanta Is Published
description: An early draft of the opinion of the Georgia Supreme Court in the case of Wayne B. Williams, who was linked to a series of child slayings in Atlanta, said Mr. Williams did not have a fair trial and his murder conviction should be reversed, according to a report published today.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: Gamble Is Given High Eagles Post
description: Harry Gamble said today that he had not hesitated when the Philadelphia Eagles owner, Leonard Tose, asked him to take over as general manager of the team.

title: Speculum Musicae Plays Milton Babbitt
description: Quite enough has been said about the complexities and structural rigors of Milton Babbitt's music. Wednesday night at Columbia University's McMillin Theater, the new- music group Speculum Musicae made a strong case for Mr. Babbitt as one of the most original, eloquent and widely misunderstood composers of our time.

title: Ski Aerodynamics
description: For the United States Ski Team's downhill racers, the highlight of the season came yesterday with the World Championships in Bormio, Italy. But it began in a six-by-seven- foot room in Buffalo, where they experienced wind speeds of 70 to 80 miles per hour and adjusted to the best aerodynamic positions for speed on snow.

title: COACH REPORTED OUT
description: The Black Hawks fell to the St. Louis Blues, 6-4, tonight for their fourth straight defeat, and after the game, three Chicago television stations reported that the Chicago Coach Orval Tessier had been dismissed.

title: REQUEST FOR SPACE WEAPONS REFLECTS EARLY GOALS
description: A breakdown of the President's $3.7 billion budget request for development of space-based antimissile weapons indicates a new emphasis on short-term applications, as well as an acceleration of the long-term basic research advertised by the Reagan Administration.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;   Hershey President Elected Chairman
description: The Hershey Foods Corporation said that Ralph A. Zimmerman, its president and chief executive officer since Jan. 1, has been elected chairman. His promotion was one of a number made by Hershey, all effective March 1.

title: BLINDERS OF THE LEFT ON NICARAGUA
description: To the Editor:

title: Futures/OptionsH.J. ;   Arcane World Of Arbitrage
description: WHENEVER stock brokers or analysts are at a loss to explain brief but sharp price movements, as has been the case recently, many of them attribute the cause to ''arbitrage operations'' or to developments in the equally esoteric index futures and options markets.

title: Washington Watch;   The Turnover At Treasury
description: WASHINGTON

title: DEFENDS POLITICAL ROLE
description: Desmond M. Tutu, winner of the 1984 Nobel Peace Prize, was enthroned today as Johannesburg's first black Anglican bishop and offered theological justification for a political ministry against South Africa's racial policies.

title: CONCERT: JOSEPH FUCHS PLAYS
description: Joseph Fuchs, the American violinist, made his New York debut in 1920, and there he was Wednesday night at Alice Tully Hall playing with the same care and passion that, by all reports, he possessed 65 years ago. The evening was long and arduous, and Mr. Fuchs took a big part in every piece.

title: 'CHILD MURDERS' SPARKS DEBATE ON DOCUDRAMAS
description: When a television network presents a ''docudrama,'' a dramatization of real events that blends factual depictions with fictional scenes, conversations and characters, what standards are applied to insure fairness and accuracy, and to prevent distortion of fact for the sake of dramatic impact?

title: Unwanted by Hospitals, Stabbing Victim Dies
description: A stabbing victim without health insurance died after being shunted 20 miles to San Francisco when four hospitals refused to accept him for surgery.

title: A SOVIET DEFECTOR SAYS HE WAS A SPY FOR U.S. FOR YEARS
description: For 32 months before his defection to the United States in 1978, Arkady N. Shevchenko, a top Soviet diplomat, passed Soviet secrets to American intelligence agents while serving as Under Secretary General of the United Nations, the defector says in a new book.

title: Deborah Stargatt And a Researcher Wed in Delaware
description: Deborah Hannah Stargatt, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce M. Stargatt of Wilmington, Del., was married at the Hotel du Pont there yesterday to Dr. George J. Feldman Jr., the son of Mr. Feldman of Washington and the late Marion Schulman Feldman. Rabbi Kenneth Cohen, assisted by Cantor Emil Hager, performed the ceremony.

title: BE HONEST, MR. TRUMP
description: Tomorrow morning, Doug Flutie won't be a football player, he'll be a happening. When he arrives at the Trump Tower on Fifth Avenue, next door to Tiffany's, a doorman dressed like a Buckingham Palace guard will usher him into what most people would call a lobby, but what Donald Trump calls an atrium. Donald Trump's atrium is six stories high, with a waterfall splashing in the glitter of bronze and marble and leafy plants. Usually a pianist in a tuxedo is playing music for Donald Trump to make real-estate deals by, or for people to shop in the arcade by, but tomorrow the pianist should be accompanied by a flutist.

title: Egypt Cuts Oil Price by 50/
description: Egypt, which two weeks ago walked out of the conference of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, on Friday cut the February price of its benchmark crude oil 50 cents a barrel, to $27.50.

title: MUSIC: HAKAN HAGEGARD
description: When Alban Berg orchestrated his ''Seven Early Songs'' in 1928, the pitch levels he elected turned out to be most easily singable by a high voice. Recently, however, Hakan Hagegard had the scoring transposed down into his baritone range, and on Wednesday night, he and the Boston Symphony performed the songs at Carnegie Hall.

title: Daylong Salvador Truce Allows Inoculation Drive
description: Fighting stopped in El Salvador for a day today as health officials began an effort to vaccinate 400,000 children against diphtheria, tetanus, whooping cough, measles and polio, the authorities said.

title: GROSS RESPONDS TO ALLEGATIONS OVER AUTOPSIES
description: Dr. Elliot M. Gross, New York City's Chief Medical Examiner, defended himself yesterday against allegations that he had issued misleading or inaccurate autopsy reports, some involving people who died while in the custody of the police.

title: Mars May Add Agency
description: In an unusually enlightened fashion for an advertiser, Howard L. Walker, regional president of Mars, the candy company, has informed the press that because of business growth Mars is contemplating retaining a third agency. Reports that it is visiting agencies, therefore, should not be construed to mean dissatisfaction with either of its current longtime shops, D'Arcy MacManus Masius or Ted Bates Worldwide.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Sky Watch map that appeared yesterday indicating the position of the stars and moon in the night sky was out of date. A current map a

title: U.N. Chief in Singapore
description: The United Nations Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar, said today that Hanoi wants a ''peaceful and negotiated settlement'' to the Cambodian problem but remains far from the positions of the regions's non-Communist countries. Mr. Perez de Cuellar conferred last week with officials from Vietnam, Laos and Thailand about restoring peace in Cambodia.

title: Sharon Halpern Married to Kenneth Kleinerman
description: At the Lincoln Square Synagogue in Manhattan yesterday Sharon Ann Halpern, a daughter of Dr. Howard M. Halpern of New York and Thelma Peskin Halpern of Tel Aviv, was married to Kenneth Kleinerman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Meyer Kleinerman of Washington. Rabbi Hillel Klavan, assisted by Rabbi Abraham Weiss, performed the ceremony.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: Consolidated Foods Corp., Chicago, has elected John B. McKinnon executive vice president.

title: FOYT'S TEAM TAKES DAYTONA 24 HOURS
description: Engine problems crippled Al Holbert's Porsche 962 in the final hour of the SunBank 24 Hours of Daytona sports-car race today, and a 962 driven by A.J. Foyt, Al Unser Sr., Bob Wollek and Thierry Boutsen slipped ahead to win.

title: Airbus Interim Chief
description: The partners of Airbus Industrie, the European jetliner consortium, were unable to agree on a successor to Bernard Lathi ere as chief executive, but agreed to appoint an interim head. Meeting in Munich, West Germany, the partners decided to appoint Roger Beteille, currently executive vice president and general manager, to take over Mr. Lathi ere's job until a permanent selection could be made, the consortium announced on Friday. Mr. Beteille has indicated that he intends to step down eventually for health reasons.

title: Suspect Held in Hanging Of an 8-Year-Old Girl
description: A 36-year-old man was arrested today and charged with first-degree murder, kidnapping and rape in the death of an 8-year-old girl found hanging from a tree limb, the authorities said.

title: ON PARADE: THE TOMMY'S NEW GUN
description: For the first time in 20 years, the British infantryman is being re-equipped from head to toe.

title: Strikes in Bangladesh Protest Military Rule
description: Anti-Government strikes by doctors, engineers, students and lawyers paralyzed several Government offices in Bangladesh today and prompted the closing of universities and colleges, officials said.

title: 12 YEARS OF HIDING TO END IN AN OFFICIAL PAROLE
description: After Richard Gartner escaped from prison in 1972, he returned home, started a family and a business and paid taxes under his own name. But in his mind, he never stopped running.

title: SOVIET ASSAILS MILITARY SPENDING
description: Tass, the official Soviet press agency, attacked President Reagan's 1986 budget today, saying its military spending provisions showed the United States was determined to have military superiority.

title: CONCERT: THE NEW MUSIC ENSEMBLE
description: Although the title ''Berlin: The Cabaret Years'' was something of a misnomer - most of the material had little to do with either Berlin or cabarets - the New York New Music Ensemble's Tuesday evening concert at Symphony Space was a pretty exciting affair. The ensemble, under the direction of the pianist and composer Robert Black, presented works by Hanns Eifler, Ferruccio Busoni and Paul Hindemith, and concluded with a selection of theater songs dating from 1928 through 1943.

title: Gadusek Takes Title
description: Bonnie Gadusek captured the $140,000 BMW tournament today with a 6-4, 6-3 victory over Pam Casale of Westfield, N.J.

title: AT L.I. HIGH SCHOOL, RACIAL FLUX CREATES PRESSURES AND PRIDE
description: Not long ago, Lucille Giambalvo, president of the Elmont Memorial High School P.T.A., got a phone call from a friend selling a house.

title: THE CALENDAR
description: Monday

title: STUDY EXAMINES ADVERSE EFFECTS OF PSYCHOTHERAPIST-PATIENTAFFAIRS
description: Women who have sexual affairs with their psychotherapists are more likely to suffer adverse consequences in direct relation to the severity of their original psychological problem, according to a study published in the current volume of The Journal of Consulting and Clinical Psychology.

title: CARNER WINS BY SIX STROKES
description: JoAnne Carner, though troubled by a pulled muscle in her left shoulder, fired a 2-under-par 70 in the final round today and coasted to a six-stroke victory in the $200,000 Elizabeth Arden Classic women's golf tournament.

title: EDBERG TROUNCES NOAH IN U.S. FINAL
description: Stefan Edberg ended his best week of tennis today by trouncing Yannick Noah, 6-1, 6-0, in the final of the National Indoor championships.

title: Leo Burnett Executives Are Shifting Titles
description: For the Leo Burnett Company, the Chicago giant, the week ended with major management changes affecting at least 10 of its very top people.

title: BRIDGE: ;   The Oddball Opening Lead: Method Behind the Madness
description: Many years ago one of the game's most prolific writers, Terence Reese, coined the term ''oddball.'' It was to describe situations in which a defender plays a conspicuously abnormal card to alert his partner to the need for some decisive action.

title: The Editorial Notebook;   A Self-Service Service Corps
description: The City Volunteers, unmistakable in their red caps and sweatshirts, are fanning out around New York, the vanguard of an experiment in service with national implications. By June, more than a thousand of them will be working in hospitals and nursing homes, repairing parks, distributing surplus food to homebound poor people - a colorful, practical demonstration. Yet its outcome probably will turn less on practicality and more on New York's answer to the underlying abstraction: service for whom?

title: STRATEGIES FOR THE BUDGET
description: Tomorrow President Reagan presents to Congress a budget that will be his answer to the Federal deficits that haunt an otherwise spirited economy. The budget accommodates the President's commitment to smaller government with his commitment to a growing military. He is proposing severe cuts in domestic programs with the exception of Social Security. After inflation is figured in, total spending would decline.

title: CONCERT: RAGTIME AND JAZZ
description: The new music organization called Continuum chose its name for didactic purpose, to assert the view that ''the recent Western musical tradition is basically an unbroken one,'' and didactic programming is its stock in trade. The retrospective and illustrative programs it has been giving for 18 years have the quality of lectures in a well-planned, passionately taught survey course in music history.

title: Women's Record Set for Attendance
description: Ohio State defeated Iowa, 56-47, today in a game that drew an overflow crowd of 22,157, shattering the attendance record for women's college basketball.

title: People
description: Phil Slott was named chairman of BBDO International in London.

title: Cefalo Cancels His Wedding
description: Jimmy Cefalo, a wide receiver for the Miami Dolphins, chose to run a reverse on his wedding day.

title: U.S. Officials Postpone Plan To Kill Wild Cattle in Alaska
description: Federal wildlife officials have postponed a plan to shoot 350 head of wild cattle that are trampling three wind-swept islands in the Aleutian chain.

title: MAY IS NEW TRUMP TARGET
description: Mark May, one of the celebrated ''Hogs'' who made up the offensive line of the Washington Redskins, is the next prize being sought by Donald Trump, the owner of the Generals.

title: RECOVERY BY NETS HAS GOOD TIMING
description: Finally, the Nets are approaching complete health. In retrospect, that fact might have been more significant than their 5-point victory over the Philadelphia 76ers in a nationally televised game Saturday.

title: Jeanne McAlister Becomes a Bride
description: Jeanne Dorris McAlister, a daughter of Dr. Edward H. McAlister of Rochester and Dr. Irma Hilton of New York and Weston, Conn., was married yesterday to William Jeffries Griffiths, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick T. Griffiths of Dallas. The Rev. Daniel R. Heischman, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Waldorf-Astoria.

title: Holiday Inns Offer
description: Holiday Inns Inc. announced yesterday that it had extended its offer to purchase for cash up to 8 million of its common shares until Tuesday and would pay $49 a share even if holders had already tendered their shares for less than that amount. Holiday Inns said that 6,218,19 shares had been validly tendered at or below $49 per share as of midnight, Feb. 1. On Friday, Holiday Inns shares closed at $48.75, down 25 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: MUSIC: AT CARNEGIE HALL, LOS ANGELES ORCHESTRA
description: Scarcely had the touring Los Angeles Philharmonic left New York than they were back again, this time with Michael Tilson Thomas leading a largely fascinating collection of pieces at Carnegie Hall Saturday night.

title: A CENTURY LATER, HUCK'S STILL STIRRING UP TROUBLE
description: ''They'll be arguing about this book in 2085,'' Meshach Taylor, an actor, said to loud applause from an audience of 200 who for more than an hour had clapped, stomped, booed, hissed or shouted in a rousing debate about ''The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn.''

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: JAZZ There is a smidgen of irony in the fact that, just as the big-band idea is undergoing a small renaissance in the club circuit, that Woody Herman, whose Young Thundering Herd exemplified the big band, should be making the rounds these days with a smaller ensemble. Mr. Herman and his six- member Woodchoppers have taken up residence through April 13 in the King Cole Room of the St. Regis Hotel, 55th Street and Fifth Avenue (872-6140).

title: FEISTY BROOKLYN IS AMBITIOUS IN DIVISION I ROLE
description: Marvelous Marvin Richardson dreams of dormitory life close to his home in Brooklyn, being in a conference and playing in a new gymnasium before large, cheering crowds.

title: GOSPEL SONGS: LITTLE CEDRIC
description: The Kitchen rang to gospel songs Thursday, as Jesus was praised with and without a backup band.

title: Hockey Buff's Plea
description: Dr. Martin Grossman is a dentist who, by any definition, has a remarkable involvement with ice hockey. He has been a Ranger season-ticket holder for 25 years. His son, Jay, started skating at 5 and now is a goaltender at Union College. Six years ago, Dr. Grossman's daughter was born in Madison Square Garden during a Ranger game. (His wife, who had insisted on going to the game, was taken to the first-aid station.)

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: Has a goaltender ever scored a goal in a National Hockey League game? Did he do it by shooting the puck into an empty net?

title: SALES ARE DISAPPOINTING FOR LOW-ALCOHOL BEER
description: In an age that exalts lean looks and healthful habits, many beverage manufacturers have found that the ''low'' road - as in low-fat milk and low-calorie soft drinks - is a sure road to travel.

title: Grumman to Buy More State Power
description: Governor Cuomo has approved a contract for the sale of 10,000 kilowatts of low-cost nuclear power from the State Power Authority to the Grumman Corporation on Long Island.

title: DROUGHT WEAKENS AGE-OLD SOCIAL FABRIC IN CHAD
description: Many pairs of eyes watched anxiously as gruel was ladled from two large caldrons into the enamel or tin bowls that children thrust up at women serving two waiting lines.

title: STUDY DISCOUNTS ROLE TAXES PLAY IN PLANT MOVES
description: A state legislative report has concluded that business taxes and tax incentives in New York do not play a significant role in the decisions businesses make on where to build new factories.

title: BROOKLYN HOSTEL GIVING YOUNG MEN A NEW START
description: For 19-year-old Jesse, the building is a refuge from his aunt's apartment, where he said cousins tried to induce him to snort cocaine and smoke marijuana.

title: BLIND MEN, ELEPHANTS AND IDEALISM
description: It is evening and David A. Stockman sits in his office, his tie loosened, his eyes weary, chain-smoking as he examines final changes in the Reagan Administration's budget.

title: THE TIME A.C.L.U. GOT THE BETTER OF C.I.A.
description: To the Editor:

title: CHARITY AND MEDICAL ITEMS CHANGED
description: The income tax code has long provided incentives for certain activities, such as contributing to charity and political campaigns, as well as tax benefits to alleviate some personal hardships, such as large medical bills or property that is stolen or destroyed. A variety of changes has been made in all of these areas for 1984 tax returns.

title: Jewish Settlers Block Roads in West Bank
description: Jewish settlers blocked main roads in the occupied West Bank for two hours today in protest at Arab attacks on Israeli vehicles in the area and the Government's policy toward the attackers.

title: SEAGA SAYS NEW UNREST WOULD DOOM JAMICA TOURISM
description: Prime Minister Edward P. G. Seaga says Jamaica's daily earnings from tourism have been cut by more than half, and if there are more demonstrations like those that erupted here in mid-January ''we can write off the tourist industry.''

title: Go Ask Shultz
description: President Reagan is reported to

title: SIGNAL LOSES DECISION IN MERGER PRICE SUIT
description: The Chancery Court of Delaware has decided that the Signal Companies should have paid $22 per share, instead of $21, when it bought out shareholders of UOP Inc. in a 1978 merger. Total damages to be paid by Signal are expected to amount to more than $7 million.

title: SLOW THE MIDEAST RACE
description: The Reagan Administration's decision to suspend new arms sales to the Middle East was a dramatic and welcome step. The next step should involve both superpowers in a comprehensive effort to slow the arms race in the Middle East.

title: ECONOMIC UPSWING SEEN BY PURCHASERS
description: After several months of increasingly negative reports, the National Association of Purchasing Management said yesterday that the economy reversed its downward trend in January and that the outlook is positive for the remainder of the year.

title: New Deposits At Thrift Units
description: Savers deposited $4 billion more in savings and loan associations than they withdrew in December, a sharp decline in the growth of new deposits, the Government reported. The Federal Home Loan Bank Board said Friday that the December deposit growth compared with an increase of $7.3 billion in November.

title: SOUTH KOREA SAYS DISSIDENT WON'T BE SEIZED ON RETURN
description: The South Korean Government said today that it would not send the opposition leader Kim Dae Jung back to prison when he returns home Friday from two years of exile in the United States.

title: U.S. TO RULE ON LIFTING MOVIE ANTITRUST DECREES
description: The Justice Department's antitrust division is expected to rule imminently on an issue that could radically affect the movie business by changing the way films are distributed.

title: A TREATY OBLIGATION AT THE WORLD COURT
description: To the Editor:

title: Time Goes Outside For Promotion Chief
description: For the first time, one of the magazines of Time Inc. has gone outside the corporation and hired a promotion director from the creative department of an ad agency.

title: A Confrontation
description: He had been acclaimed a national hero when he won a gold medal at the 1984 Summer Games, and when he went to visit his manager the night after a professional triumph early last month, Mark Breland proudly wore his Olympic team emblem on his jacket.

title: TEXT OF STATEMENT ISSUED BY GROSS IN RESPONSE TO ALLEGATIONS
description: Following is the text of a statement issued yesterday by Dr. Elliot M. Gross, New York City's Chief Medical Examiner, regarding allegations about his handling of the office and its affairs:

title: JUSTICE DEPARTMENT PLAYS DOCTOR
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFS ;    Debt
description: Citizens Utilities Co. is offering to buy five issues of its 9.75 percent industrial development revenue bonds due 2012.

title: DEBT CRISIS SEEN AS ENDING
description: When Brazil and its bank creditors conclude an agreement in the next couple of weeks, as is expected, to reschedule the largest foreign debt in the developing world, the flowing champagne will celebrate not just this $45 billion deal, but also a milestone.

title: PAPAL MESSAGE HEARTENS CITY RAVAGED BY TERROR
description: Pope John Paul II talked directly here today to the Maoist rebels of Shining Path. He called them ''men who have put their trust in armed struggle and been tricked by false ideologies.''

title: Concertino Ensemble At Carnegie Recital Hall
description: In 1981, Theodore Platt emigrated to the United States from the Soviet Union, and within five months of his arrival here had begun to organize the New York Concertino Ensemble. The group, composed entirely of Soviet emigres, has performed quite a bit in the New York area, but its concert at Carnegie Recital Hall on Tuesday night was apparently its first in a midtown Manhattan hall.

title: Alcan Sells Stake
description: Alcan Aluminum Ltd. said Friday that it had sold its Mexican fabricating interests to Aluminio S.A. de C.V., in which the Aluminum Company of America has a 44 percent interest, for $35 million.

title: TAIWAN MAGAZINES PLAY 'MICE' TO THE CENSOR'S 'CAT'
description: For Antonio Chiang, editor and publisher of The Eighties, advertising is not a concern. ''We have never had an advertisement in our magazine,'' Mr. Chiang explains. ''No one would dare.''

title: No Headline
description: MONDAY, FEBRUARY 4, 1985 International

title: Remembering Owens
description: When he was a kid in Pittsburgh, nearly half a century ago, Herb Douglas had an Olympian hero: Jesse Owens. It was 1936, and Owens had just won four gold medals in track and field in Berlin.

title: Connecticut Is Site Of Radar Project
description: A prototype of a sophisticated weather radar system designed to replace the one used by the National Weather Service since 1957 is to be placed here, according to state officials and the Sperry Corporation.

title: TWO LEWISES HAVE AN IMPACT ON MEET
description: Carl Lewis is the unquestioned centerpoint of the indoor track and field carnival, whether winning events or generating controversy.

title: Top Economist Named At Merrill Lynch Unit
description: Donald Straszheim, chief domestic economist at Wharton Econometrics Forecasting Associates since 1981, has been named president and chief economist of Merrill Lynch Economics Inc.. The appointment is effective nnext Monday.

title: SUBURBAN AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PROGRAMMING: GOING BACK TO BASICS
description: IN the early days of personal

title: CITY GAS CO OF FLORIDA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
THA MAHDI AND NIMEIRY, SUDANESE HERO AND ANTIHERO
description: To the Editor:

title: ELECTRONIC ASSOCIATES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
description: b-Net loss.

title: CONTINENTAL AIR LINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $6,072,000 for the quarter and $21,113,000 for the year and a gain of $9.6 million for the year from aircraft sales. c-Net losses. d-Including a gain of $13.4 million from aircraft sales and a charge of approximately $18.5 million related to Chapter 11 reorganization filing expenses.

title: DIGILOG INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DURAKON INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $222,000 for the quarter and $478,000 for the year and a gain of $379,000 for the quarter and year on the disposal of discontinued operations. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $67,000 for the quarter and $229,000 for the year.

title: AVEMCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After capital losses of $147,000 for the quarter and $269,000 for the year. c-After capital losses of $255,000 for the quarter and $108,000 for the year.

title: Provincetown International
description: Provincetown International Ltd., a New York-based financial services holding company, sold shares of two insurance brokerages, Frank B. Hall & Company and Alexander & Alexander Services Inc., on the open market for $35.6 million.

title: BUSINESS DEDUCTIONS: THE RULES ARE STRICT
description: For many Americans, finding ways to justify writing off trips, meals, parties, a portion of the house and all sorts of other expenditures as business expenses is a challenge.

title: SAHARA RES RTS reports earnings for Qt to Dec 31
U.S. IS REBUFFED ON VISIT BY SHIP TO NEW ZEALAND
description: The United States said today that New Zealand had ''definitively turned down'' an American request for a port visit by a Navy destroyer because Washington would not say if it carried nuclear arms.

title: Leucadia, Minstar
description: The Leucadia National Corporation, a New York-based holding company, told the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had bought 7.1 percent of Minstar Inc. and might ''seek control of the company.''

title: ;   WHO SHALL RESERCH AND WHO SHALL NOT?
description: To the Editor:

title: INDIAN SAID TO CONFESS SPYING FOR EAST EUROPEANS
description: A businessman described as a key figure in a widening espionage scandal was quoted today as having said at a closed hearing that he had passed Government secrets to diplomats from East Germany, Poland and France.

title: INDICTMENT STIRS 250 IN POLICE UNIT TO SEEK TRANSFER
description: All 250 officers in the Emergency Service unit of the New York City Police Department decided yesterday to demand transfers, the head of their union said, to protest the indictment of a fellow officer in the death of Eleanor Bumpurs.

title: REAGAN CUTS: THE OUTLOOK
description: Despite bipartisan criticism of President Reagan's proposals for sweeping cuts in domestic programs, his 1986 budget package is being treated more seriously than his last two budgets as a framework for squeezing Government spending and curbing deficits.

title: 'Day of Peace' for Salvador
description: A one-day vaccination campaign reached at least 227,000 children and also gave this tormented nation a day of peace, according to President Jose Napoleon Duarte.

title: 'Goldberg Variations'
description: Charles Rosen, the pianist, will play Bach's ''Goldberg Variations'' on Monday at 8 P.M. at Symphony Space, Broadway at 95th Street. Tickets are $8, or $6 for students and over- 65's. Information: 864-5400.

title: ZAPATA CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Hedberg Joins All-Stars
description: Anders Hedberg of the Rangers, Bryan Trottier of the Islanders and Kirk Muller of the Devils were among eight layers added by Coach Al Arbour to the Prince of Wales Conference team today for the All-Star Game. The others named to the squad that will face the Campbell Conference in the game next Tuesday night in Calgary were: Mario Lemieux of Pittsburgh, Bill Hajt of Buffalo, Mark Howe of Philadelphia, Ron Francis of Hartford and Mike Gartner of the Washington Capitals. The first 12 on each squad were chosen in a vote among members of the ProfessionalHockey Writers' Association.

title: FIRST FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN OF AUSTIN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Letting Cops Walk a Beat Again
description: In New York City as elsewhere, the radio-dispatched patrol car is the basic tool of police work. It allows relatively few officers to cover large areas, responding in minutes to calls for help. Yet in focusing on faster response, the police have sacrificed their involvement in the community. That turns out to have been a serious loss.

title: 3 Frozen Bolivian Accounts
description: Three bank accounts of the Bolivian Embassy in Washington have been frozen by a United States District Court in a tangled lawsuit by an American company that contends Bolivia owes it money. The case demonstrates the difficulties that might face American banks if they sought to attach assets of debtor countries.

title: Debt
description: Atlanta Gas Light Co. filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a proposed offering of $50 million of 10-year first mortgage bonds, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

title: Knight Chain Net Up 14.6%
description: Knight-Ridder Newspapers Inc. today reported fourth-quarter earnings of $46.2 million, or 70 cents a share, up 14.6 percent from $40.3 million, or 61 cents a share, last year. Revenues reached $451.7 million, up 10.5 percent from $408.7 million, the company said.

title: CPC INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss. c-After a special net writeoff of $55.4 million for the quarter and year. Year-ago results have been reclassified to conform with the currenty year's presentation.

title: Directors Briefed
description: Directors of BankAmerica, at a regular board meeting yesterday, questioned Samuel H. Armacost, the president and chief executive officer, for about half an hour about the collateralized mortgages, according to sources within the company.

title: SYSTEMS ASSURANCE CORP reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
description: b-The company said it had no revenue in the 1983 year. Systems Assurance said results for 1984 are not comparable to those of the prior year because the business the company was then engaged in was discontinued in late 1983.

title: Kornhauser Gets Tarkett Account
description: Kornhauser & Calene has won the agency competition for the Tarkett account.

title: CBS, Ziff-Davis
description: CBS Inc. said it had completed the previously announced purchase of the consumer magazine publishing operations of the Ziff-Davis Publishing Company. The price was $362.5 million. CBS said the antitrust division of the Justice Department had told the company that it had no objections to the transaction.

title: A.T.&T. VIDEOTEX PLAN REPORTED
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company is preparing to enter the videotex business in a joint venture with Chemical Bank, sources in the industry said today. The venture is also expected to include Time Inc. and the Bank of America as smaller participants.

title: Budget Bluster
description: President Reagan's fiscal plan for his second term is honest, but not sound.

title: FILM: 'SHIVERS,' DRAMA OF POST-STALINIST POLAND
description: ''Shivers'' was shown as part of last year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 4. The film opens today at the Public, 425 Lafayette Street.

title: HOSTAGE TO 'STAR WARS'
description: The Soviet-American decision to resume arms control talks on March 12 arouses even less euphoria in Europe than Washington. President Reagan expects long years of negotiation. Europeans predict an early impasse that will plant a land mine under the Western alliance.

title: 3 YUGOSLAV DISSIDENTS GIVEN MILD SENTENCES
description: The most significant political trial in post-Tito Yugoslavia ended today with the conviction of three dissidents on charges of disseminating ''hostile propaganda'' against the state.

title: MOURNING: NEW STUDIES AFFIRM ITS BENEFITS
description: PSYCHOLOGISTS, using modern research methods, are probing one of the universal themes of human existence: the anguish that follows the death of a loved one.

title: DATACOPY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CITY BALLET: LECTURE-BENEFIT
description: THE NEW YORK CITY BALLET'S education department usually concentrates on two kinds of programs. It sponsors lecture-demonstrations for young people in various schools; it also invites children from the public schools into the New York State Theater for a lecture-demonstration with City Ballet professionals.

title: KUHLMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes gains of 13 cents a share for the latest quarter and 17 cents a share for the quarter a year ago from restoration of unneeded reserve for physical inventory shortages and obsolescence that did not materialize.

title: NEW HEAD FOR SATURN UNIT
description: William E. Hoglund, a financial executive who has demonstrated a flair for automobile marketing, today was chosen president of the General Motors Corporation's Saturn subsidiary.

title: SUPERIOR ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Likely Offerings Of C.M.O.'s Up
description: Although the supply of new collateralized mortgage obligations, known as C.M.O.'s, has been light so far this year, the supply of potential offerings is building rapidly.

title: Mesa's KN Stake
description: The Mesa Petroleum Company said it had acquired 643,000 shares, or 7.2 percent, of KN Energy Inc. for investment purposes.

title: KNIGHT-RIDDER NEWSPAPERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NATIONAL INTERGROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes gains of $7.3 million, or 36 cents a share, for the quarter and extraordinary gains of $5.8 million for a special stock dividend of Freddie Mac preferred and $1.5 million from the defeasance of debt by the First Nationwide Financial Corp., a unit, for the year. The latest year results also include a nonrecurring charge of $16.9 million associated with the sale of 50 percent of National Intergroup's interest in the National Steel Corp. to Nippon Kokan K.K. c-Net losses includes a non-recurring charge of $55.6 million for the liquidation of the National Pipe and Tube Co. and the writeoff or sale of certain other steel-related assets for the quarter and the year and a $100 million non-recurring charge related to the sale of the Weirton Steel division and an extraordinary gain of $22.1 million on the exchange of debt for equity for the year. Sales reflect the sale of the National Steel interest and a change to an equity basis of accounting for National Intergroup's remaining interest in National Steel.

title: HALL, FRANK B & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

title: GRUMMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

description: National Intergroup, benefiting from cost-reduction programs and a restructuring, reported yesterday that it had net income in the fourth quarter of 1984 of $12.8 million, or 44 cents a share.

title: ART WORLD SUBTLY SHIFTS TO CORPORATE PATRONAGE
description: Last Friday, an exhibition of batik textiles from Java's north coast opened at the Cooper Hewitt Museum in New York. The show is one of a series of art museum exhibitions sponsored by the Mobil Corporation in recent years - others including art from Cameroon, Nigeria and New Zealand - whose aim is as practical as it is artistic.

title: Largest Shareholder Will Be Itel's Chairman
description: The Itel Corporation yesterday named Samuel Zell, its largest shareholder, as chairman, to succeed Herbert Kunzel. The change will take place after the annual meeting on April 18.

title: GUARDING AGAINST STATIC CAN SAVE PRECIOUS DATA
description: AT the computer, it will happen every now at then. In a flash, thousands of volts of static electricity leap from fingertip to metal, and from there to the metal-oxide semiconductor chips. The little blue spark brings a yelp of surprise from the user, but nothing compared to the blue oaths that follow the discovery that a memory chip has been shocked into permanent amnesia.

title: NORTH CAROLINA NATURAL GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

description: A Federal grand jury in New York is investigating the collapse of a mortgage securities deal that has cost the BankAmerica Corporation $37 million, according to a state regulator from Delaware.

McDonnell-I.A.E.
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation has signed an agreement with International Aero Engines to use its V-2500 engine to power a new version of the MD-80 airliner to compete with the European Airbus, the two companies said. I.A.E. has sent a team to Long Beach, Calif., to help in the technical development of the plane. The MD-80 began scheduled passenger service in October 1980. The 150-passenger A320 Airbus will also use the V-2500 engine, which will begin ground testing early next year and is scheduled to enter service on the A320 in April 1989.

Tickets are $8.50 to $11, and can be charged by calling 831-8603.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: BODY BENDERS The Pilobolus Dance Theater, the rubbery rebels against corporal rigidity, are back in New York - for the first time in more than three years - this time for a month, starting tonight at 7:30 P.M., at the Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street (242- 0800).

title: Norwest in Talks to Sell Mortgage Unit to G.M.
description: The Norwest Corporation said yesterday that it was holding ''preliminary discussions'' to sell its troubled mortgage-banking subsidiary to the General Motors Corporation.

title: 2,300 British Miners Return
description: More than 2,300 coal miners returned to work today after the collapse of negotiations to end their 47-week-old walkout, the National Coal Board said. Arthur Scargill, a mineworkers' union leader, raised new hopes for talks by saying the board had sent him ''probably the most conciliatory letter we have had in months.'' He gave no details and a board spokesman said he did not know about the letter.

title: Wells Fargo To Realize Gain
description: Wells Fargo & Company said it expects to realize a first-quarter pretax gain of about $50 million from the sale of its Wells Fargo Mortgage Company to a limited partnership to be organized by Integrated Resources Inc. The sale of the residential mortgage banking unit is for about $180 million, plus the assumption of certain liabilities. Wells Fargo said it expects to close the sale, which is still subject to regulatory approval, in the first quarter.

title: REFORMING THE SCHOOLS
description: WHO should control the reform of the public schools? A battle is shaping up between those who want the states to impose new standards and those who view this as unwarranted interference with local control.

title: THE BIG SAUDI MOVE IN PETROCHEMICALS
description: The natural gas the Saudi Arabians once wastefully flared off as a byproduct of oil production is now being harnessed and turned into petrochemicals. The Saudi dream of industrialization is coming true.

title: Texaco Sale
description: Texaco Inc. said that it had completed the $95 million sale to the Power Test Corporation of substantially all of the Getty Oil Company's gasoline stations and marketing activities in 13 Eastern states and the District of Columbia. Power Test, which had about 430 service stations, bought 321 service stations and 9 marketing terminals formerly owned by Getty, which was acquired by Texaco last year. Texaco assigned leases of an additional 239 service stations to Power Test, which also assumed contractual obligations to supply another 1,300 Getty-branded gas stations.

title: STAGE:'FORBIDDEN BROADWAY,' CABARET REVUE AT PALSSON'S

After that indictment, one might well wonder what was left for the show to spoof. ''Forbidden'' fans need not worry. Gerard Alessandrini, the ingenious inventor of this always topical cabaret revue (at Palsson's Supper Club) has an arsenal of sabers up his satiric sleeve.

description: The French couture designers can afford to relax. Their spring and summer collections, shown this week to enthusiastic crowds, were a triumph.

title: Empire, Ward
description: Empire of America, a Buffalo- based savings bank, said it would open three financial service centers in Montgomery Ward stores in Houston starting in May. The move will mark the first time Ward's, the nation's sixth-largest retailer, has opened such centers at its stores. Moneyplex Inc., a subsidiary of Empire, will offer banking, investment, insurance and real estate services by subleasing space in the centers, Empire said.

description: In a victory for a beleaguered Washington utility system, a Federal appeals court today upheld contracts that require residents of three Northwest states to continue paying for three nuclear power plants, two of which have been mothballed.

Clue, a successful board game for 37 years, is about to become an $8 million motion picture.

title: CONNECTICUT BUYERS FOUND FOR THRIFT UNIT
description: A group of seven Connecticut banks and thrift institutions agreed today to buy Permanent Savings, this state's largest state-chartered savings and loan company. It had been threatened by failure because of its large portfolio of fixed-rate mortgage loans carrying low interest.

title: Topics ;   PRESERVATION TALES;   A Conductor's DutyA young woman riding in a nearly empty subway car last week noticed a man directly opposite performing most obscenely. Ashamed and afraid to raise a fuss, she moved to the next car. There she found a conductor and reported the man's behavior. The conductor said, ''What do you expect me to do, call a cop?'' and turned his back. The young woman was abashed, until she noticed that the misbehaving man had also come to the car. ''Could you help, please?'' she asked again. The conductor shrugged, and disappeared into his compartment.
description: No harm was done, except to the woman's nerves: she walked to a third car, which was fuller, and buried herself among its passengers.

THE EARLY SIGNS OF MIDDLE AGE
description: I was startled the other day to hear an old friend, a college classmate, refer to himself as being ''in early middle age.'' He might have become middle-aged, I thought, but me? Of course not. Since then, however, I've had to admit that, at age 42, I see signs of the same malady in myself. For the aid of others who may not be aware of this condition overtaking them, I list the principal symptoms I've identified:

A PSORIASIS TREATMENT
description: PSORIASIS is a mysterious, troubling and sometimes severe disease best known for the thick, scaly plaques that often erupt on the skin. Many different treatments have been tried for the skin lesions including sunlight, steroid hormone preparations and all manner of creams and salves, but the underlying cause of the eruptions is unknown and the effects of treatment are often disappointing.

title: 'STAR WARS' RESEARCH FORGES AHEAD
description: DEFENDERS and detractors may fight over the feasibility of ''star wars,'' Congress may blanch over its vast budgetary implications, and governments may engage in wary diplomacy over its futuristic goals. But at laboratories around the country there is little hesitancy as thousands of scientists push technology to the limit in what is being envisioned as the biggest research project of all time.

title: 'Harrigan 'n Hart' Closes
description: ''Harrigan 'n Hart,'' the $2 million musical starring Mark Hamill and Harry Groener and directed by Joe Layton, closed after its Sunday matinee at the Longacre Theater. It had played 5 performances and 24 previews. The show was based on the lives of Edward Harrigan and Tony Hart, a vaudeville team popular in the latter part of the 19th century.

title: POPULATION CATFISH ROW ON THE MET OPERA STAGE
description: What's this? It is not A"ida's Egypt or Carmen's Seville or Butterfly's Japan up there on the vast Metropolitan Opera stage, but Catfish Row in the Deep South. A man in an electric- blue suit, vanilla spats and bowler oozes seductively through the crowd, bad-mouthing the Bible and singing the praises of ''happy dust'' and booze.

title: JOHN WEXLEY, 77, PLAYWRIGHT, SCREENWRITER AND AN AUTHOR
description: John Wexley, author of ''The Last Mile,'' one of the most famous of prison dramas, died of a heart attack Monday. He was 77 years old and lived in Doylestown, Pa.

title: Poland Bars Solidarity Exile
description: Poland today barred the return of Seweryn Blumsztajn, a former Solidarity official. He was told that his Polish passport was no longer valid and was put back on the Air France flight on which he had arrived. Mr. Blumsztajn was in Paris in late 1981, when martial law was declared in Poland, and has been an exile here since then.

title: Stag's Leap Problem TO THE LIVING SECTION:
description: I thought your article on the dispute about Stag's Leap (Wine Talk, Jan. 9) was generally thorough and interesting, but I did wonder if one point was made. That point might best be expressed by a question: Would there be any effort to create an appellation in the name of Stag's Leap if Warren Winiarksi had not chosen it for the name of his vineyard and winery? If Winiarski had named his vineyard Hawk Crest (his secondary label) and won the Paris tasting with such- named wine, Stag's Leap today would still just denote a rock on a ridge, not an area, not a name others were trying to cash in on.

title: ECONOMIC GOALS CITED BY REAGAN
description: In an optimistic assessment of the economy's performance over the last four years, President Reagan urged Congress today to press on with his goals of less government and sustained growth by enacting his new budget and continuing the programs he began in his first term.

title: Boston Exchange Chief
description: Charles J. Mohr resigned yesterday as chairman and chief executive of the Boston Stock Exchange to become executive vice president and a director of Colonial Management Associates Inc., a Boston-based mutual fund.

title: A SURGE IN TRAVEL TO EUROPE
description: Fueled by the continued strength of the dollar, another surge in travel to Europe is in the making, and the major international airlines are already adding flights and destinations for the peak summer season.

title: HOOPLA AND GLITTER MARK FLUTIE'S DEBUT AS GENERAL
description: The security guards looked like offensive linemen. They were broad- shouldered and formidable, packing walkie-talkies and casually brushing aside photographers and reporters who blocked their path to the podium. Hidden behind their massive bodies, partially obscured from view but nicely protected in the pocket, strolled Doug Flutie, the hottest property to hit New York since Trump Tower.

title: Iran Reports 2 Civilians Died in Iraqi Air Raids
description: Iran said 2 civilians were killed and 20 were wounded in Iraqi air raids today, and Iraq reported stepped-up air attacks on Iranian positions on the southern war front.

title: Military Contracts

Also, the McDonnell Douglas Corporation said the Air Force had awarded it a $169.4 million contract to build 28 upper-stage rockets that will be used to launch a series of new navigation satellites.

title: Books: Unmarred Soul
description: LISA H. The True Story of an Extraordinary and Courageous Woman. By Richard Severo. 180 pages. Harper & Row.$13.95. THE victim of a disfiguring injury or disease who is turned into an outcast by society has often been a subject of literature. From Victor Hugo's ''Hunchback of Notre Dame'' to Bernard Pomerance's prize-winning play ''The Elephant Man,'' authors have sought to glorify the individual's courage to rise above suffering brought on by the vagaries of unkind circumstance.

title: EASY WAY TO MAKE SAUSAGE AT HOME
description: MAKING sausage at home has often been presented as a forbidding piece of work. Cooks are given the impression that they cannot even contemplate the task without a high- powered grinding machine, a stuffing tube (unavailable in most neighborhoods) and a supply of casings. Predictably the response to this litany of sine qua nons is almost always, ''Thank you very much, but if it's all the same, I'll take non.''

title: KNICKS END ROAD SLUMP AT 15

But during tonight's frantic finish against the Seattle SuperSonics, the game was in the hands of King, and he helped the Knicks end their road slump at 15 games.

title: JAN. 21-31 CAR SALES OFF 4.1%
description: Sales of new American-made automobiles slipped 4.1 percent on a daily rate basis in late January from an extremely strong period last year, the six major auto makers reported today. The daily selling rate for the Jan. 21-31 period was 26,850, compared with 28,002 in 1984.

description: As buyers continue to switch to larger and more expensive cars, the auto makers are turning to a variety of incentives to promote slower-selling small models.

It is the first telephone company in the nation to be given approval to participate in a cable television venture. The Justice Department said the proposal does not require a waiver of the line- of-business restrictions in the 1982 judicial order that approved the breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

title: BRIEFINg;   Republican Liberals?

Beneficiary of the $35-a-person affair is Modrn-Pac, a group founded by Representative Bill Green of Manhattan that raises money for Republican candidates of the kind that used to be called ''liberal.'' The reception is only four blocks from the Capitol, so any of those attending can hustle over for the Reagan speech if they want to balance out the evening politically.

description: A Soviet airliner able to carry as many as 90 passengers crashed near Minsk on Friday, according to reports reaching here today. Officials gave no casualty figures, but a newspaper called it ''a catastrophe.''

title: THEATER: '3 GUYS NAKED,' A MUSICAL
description: THE three guys in ''3 Guys Naked from the Waist Down,'' the new musical at the Minetta Lane, never go naked - but they often do seem to be jumping out of their skins. In this portrait of three stand-up comics, the performers are forever clowning, running and singing at the highest imaginable pitch; such is the show's voltage level that a fast descent down a fire pole can almost qualify as an introspective moment. But the riotous activity, while dizzying, is rarely aimless. When we catch our breath, we realize that the young talents behind ''3 Guys'' are trying to bring fresh forms of stylistic vitality to the musical.

title: SEEKING AND FINDING RARE WINE BOOKS
description: -book collector who finds that elusive first edition on the back shelf of a used-book store. It's in mint condition, signed by the author and priced at only a few dollars. It happens, but rarely, which is why it makes a good story. More often, the person who collects out-of-print, rare wine books finds those treasures through a bookseller who specializes in them.

title: JWT Group Unit Has Jacobs Coffee Account
description: Jacobs-Suchard of Geneva, whose variety of coffee brands dominate the market in Germany, France and Canada, has arrived in the United States in the form of a subsidiary named the Jacobs Coffee Company, which will soon have its headquarters in Delavan, Wis. But instead of going head to head with General Foods' Maxwell House or Procter & Gamble's Folger, it will attack the high end with Johann Jacobs Super Premium Coffee that is now being sold in the San Francisco market.

title: Italian Rail Notes
description: The Italian State Railways is issuing $460 million of floating-rate Euronotes due in 1995, through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets, to refund $225 million of floating-rate notes and to prepay a $230 million syndicated loan, both due in 1988. The notes, which are guaranteed by the Italian Government, pay interest semiannually. Interest will be adjusted monthly at the higher of the mean of bid and offered rates of six-month interbank deposits in London or the offered rate for one-month interbank deposits.

title: French Official Ends Talks In U.S. on Strategic Defense
description: The French Foreign Minister, Roland Dumas, ended his talks in the United States today, getting an assurance that a policy of nuclear deterrence would not be abandoned until a ''safer strategy,'' such as a space-based defensive shield, can replace it, a senior American official said.

title: Video Cattle Auction

The 7,015 head of cattle offered at the auction will remain at their ranches, but videos of them will be shown on a large screen at the Livestock Exchange Building, market officials said today. The auction, run by Mountain State Video, will also be shown by satellite in Garden City, Kan., and Denver.

description: Well, groundhogs couldn't agree, so why expect two-legged weather forecasters to have the same predictions?

description: What a relief to read ''For Many Young Professionals the Way to Eat Is on the Run'' (Jan. 30).

description: David A. Stockman, the budget director, today called the military pension system a ''scandal,'' saying the military would put its pensions ahead of national security.
