title: MASTERS AND JOHNSON TV FILM IS SET
description: ABC has reached an agreement with Dr. William H. Masters and his wife, Virginia E. Johnson, to dramatize their professional and personal relationship for an upcoming television movie.

title: MUBARAK SAYS THE ISRAELIS AREN'T FLEXIBLE ENOUGH
description: President Hosni Mubarak accused Israel today of not being flexibile enough in the search for peace.

title: COLONIAL LIFE & ACCIDENT INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Appeal Set onAbortion Rule
description: State officials today announced that they would appeal a court ruling last week that prevented two abortion clinics from opening. The decision was a victory for the Roman Catholic Diocese of Albany, which had challenged a State Health Department decision to allow the clinics, here and in Hudson, to open. Justice Harold J. Hughes of State Supreme Court here ruled that the state had ''capriciously'' licensed the clinics, to Upper Hudson Planned Parenthood.

title: SHEARS AND WHISKS
description: STURDY kitchen shears are a valuable tool in any cook's kitchen. They come in handy for cutting through the joints of poultry and game, removing fish fins, cutting through kitchen twine and, in a pinch, clipping recipes from newspapers or removing itchy labels from new shirts. One should not use regular household scissors for food preparation; after a while, they will become dull and begin to smell like a butcher's shop.

title: ANOTHER DISSIDENT SENTENCED IN YUGOSLAVIA
description: Another dissident, Milan Mladenovic, was convicted Monday of antistate activity and sentenced to 18 months in prison, the newspaper Politika said today.

title: PROTESTING OFFICERS REQUEST PROSECUTORS AT ARREST SCENES
description: Some police officers in the Bronx and Brooklyn, as part of a protest over the manslaughter indictment of a fellow officer, sought yesterday to have an assistant district attorney come to the scene before they would make arrests or intervene in emergencies.

title: People
description: Shepherd Brandfon named president of World Tennis Inc.

title: LIBYA FREES 4 BRITONS AFTER 8 MONTHS
description: Libya released four Britons today who had been held for eight months in a diplomatic dispute arising out of the shooting of an unarmed police constable in London last April.

title: 'SEXUAL ABUSE OF CHILDREN,' ON HBO
description: ''SEXUAL ABUSE OF CHILDREN: BEYOND THE SECRET'' is meant to disturb, but not upset, enlighten, but not intimidate. Therein, its strength; therein, its weakness. The Home Box Office production is a docudrama, which means that things are, but they aren't. Old newspaper clippings, live interviews and staged sequences mingle. The docudrama will be seen at 10 tonight.

title: AaState Wage Bill
description: Former State Senator Albert Wald, who sponsored New York State's first minimum-wage law, died Friday at his home on Park Avenue. He was 96 years old.

title: Coomo, Como, Cuomo
description: It was nice, said Mayor Raymond Flynn of Boston, to be here visiting ''Governor Coomo.''

title: HOMESTEAD FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest quarter and year nets include a pre-tax gain of $15.2 million from the sale of certain G.N.M.A. mortgage-backed securities. The net for the latest quarter and year also includes an after-tax gain of $487,000 which represents the recently issued Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. preferred stock.

title: Required Reading;   President Giraffe
description: Representative Patricia Schroeder, Democrat of Colorado, in remarks on the House floor, Feb. 4:

title: CREDIT MARKETS ;   Slight Drop Posted In Interest Rates;    3-Year Notes Yield 10.40%
description: Interest rates fell slightly yesterday as the first leg of the Treasury's three-part note and bond financing was well received by investors.

title: Adviser to Peres Named
description: Avraham Burg has been appointed Prime Minister Shimon Peres's adviser for Jewish Diaspora Affairs, Mr. Peres's spokesman, Uri Savir, has announced. Mr. Burg, the son of Josef Burg, the Religious Affairs Minister, will be responsible for liaison between the Prime Minister's office and Jewish groups in the United States and around the world.

title: 9 KILLED AS PALNE HITS ALASKA RIDGE
description: A commuter plane crashed into a wooded hillside Monday night, killing all nine people aboard. The authorities said today that the pilot aborted his first landing attempt just before the accident because of poor visibility.

title: STIRRING UP NEW ONE-POT MEALS
description: -pressed lives, probably the most sensible meals to make are those that can be prepared in an hour or so (excluding cooking time) on a weekend afternoon. They should also be the kind of foods that keep well in the refrigerator or freezer for later consumption and that require the least number of pots and pans.

title: Ohlmeyer Resignation
description: The Ohlmeyer Communications Companies announced yesterday that Philip Howort, 41, and president of Ohlmeyer Advertising, was resigning for personal reasons. Mr. Howort, who started his career in the media departments of ad agencies, was in a number of important programming production jobs before returning to the agency side.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: WHEN thinking of winter feasting, what comes to mind is a dish from winters past - winters of a childhood spent in Burgundy, although in France this dish is more closely associated with the regions of Alsace and Lorraine. The dish is choucroute garnie, as the French call it, or braised sauerkraut with sausage and pork.

title: THE G.O.P. AS MAJORITY
description: In preparing for the State of the Union Message tonight, President Reagan has undoubtedly given considerable thought to the question that both parties are vigorously debating - whether the Republicans are on their way to becoming the majority party. In the end, however, the answer may have little to do with anything that he could say about particular programs or proposals.

title: INMATES UPHELD ON RIGHT TO SEE STUDY ON ATTICA
description: A Federal appeals court yesterday upheld the right of inmates in New York State prisons to receive a report highly critical of the Attica prison administration. The state's Correction Commissioner had ordered the report withheld from the prisoners.

title: Filing by Disney
description: Walt Disney Productions filed a shelf registration for 3,333,308 shares issued in connection with its acquisition of the Arvida Corporation.

title: Whither General Gorman?
description: When Gen. Paul F. Gorman, commander of United States forces in Latin America, announced his retirement from the Army in December, colleagues speculated that something must have happened, that he had been told he had little chance of becoming Army Chief of Staff, a career-long dream. But Administration officials say the White House and top Reagan advisers elsewhere are eager not to lose his services. They want to keep General Gorman in the Government by offering him a choice between director of the National Security Agency and deputy director of the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;   Florida and City Agency Back Toll Bridge Issue
description: A $140 million financing by the State of Florida, on behalf of the Jacksonville Transportation Authority, was offered yesterday with a maximum yield of 9 3/8 percent for $54 million of bonds due in 2015, through underwriters led by Citibank. For shorter maturities, bonds were offered with yields ranging from 8.90 percent in 1989 to 9 percent in 2000 and 9.30 percent in 2010.

title: TALK ON TRAIN TRAPS SUSPECT IN A SHOOTING
description: A woman whose daughter was shot in a robbery attempt has led the police to a suspect after overhearing a 14-year-old boy tell a companion on a subway train that he had shot a woman in Dorchester the night before.

title: THEOLOGIANS FAULT REAGAN ON BIBLE ARMS LESSON
description: Several theologians and biblical scholars yesterday criticized President Reagan's use of Scripture to appeal for support for the Administration's proposal to increase the military budget.

title: SRI LANKA GIRDING FOR LONG BATTLE
description: Waves of bombings, killings and arrests have spread through the northern and eastern regions of this island nation in recent months, creating new fears in the Government that the insurgency of Tamil separatists will continue and perhaps grow.

title: STANDING IN LINE PERSISTS AS SCOURGE OF SOVIET LIFE
description: A group of Western reporters had gathered outside a courthouse here one wintry morning to await the outcome of a dissident's trial.

title: ICAHN BIDS $8.1 BILLION FOR PHILLIPS
description: Carl C. Icahn, the New York financier, offered yesterday to buy the Phillips Petroleum Company for $8.1 billion. He valued the leveraged buyout at $55 a share, half in cash and the other half in notes. He also threatened that, if Phillips turned that offer down, he would try to take over the company anyway.

title: DANCE: PILOBOLUS OPENS AT THE JOYCE
description: LEAVE it to Pilobolus to open its first full New York season in three years in a snowstorm. Named after a fungus, this once highly innovative dance group always did have a special relationship with Mother Nature. Much of its choreography looked nothing if not organic and it wasn't unusual to see the dancers identify strongly with faun and fauna.

title: AGAIN, SUCCESSION AND SOVIET POLICY
description: The disappearance of Soviet leader Konstantin U. Chernenko from public life during the past month raises once again the question of the Soviet succession and the future direction of Soviet society.

description: Carl C. Icahn once confided to an acquaintance: ''Chess was one thing I was really good at. I could have been a master or something, but there was no future in it.''

description: President Reagan plans to set legislative priorities for his second term with an upbeat State of the Union Message Wednesday. In the address, White House officials said today, he will seek to reach out to minority groups, emphasize deficit reduction and tax simplification and stress his desire to ease the threat of nuclear war.

title: Senator's Shuttle Flight Is Delayed for a Week
description: The next space shuttle flight, which had been scheduled for Feb. 20 with Senator Jake Garn, Republican of Utah, aboard, will be delayed at least a week because of trouble with thermal tiles and a backlog of paperwork, the National Aeronautic and Space Administration said today.

description: The sleek, white offices of the Institute for Coordination of Computer Techniques tower over a group of aging tenements that are still pocked from World War II shellings. The contrast neatly reflects the soaring position that the computer software industry holds in Hungary's otherwise pedestrian economy.

G.M. bought a 12.6 percent stake in the company and received warrants to buy an additional 13.3 percent over the next five years.

title: 2 in House Seek Study Of Airline Inspections
description: The chairmen of two House panels yesterday called on the General Accounting Office to investigate how the Government conducted airline safety inspections.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: A FRIEND whose uncle had recently died offered Terry L. Morton some of the deceased man's clothing. Mr. Morton, a fashion designer who lives on upper Park Avenue, chose a few items to keep and suggested the friend bring the rest to one of the many thrift shops that dot his neighborhood. Included in the collection was an alpaca cardigan, a corduroy car coat, new trousers, never-worn socks and an Italian jacket with a Saks Fifth Avenue label. This was definitely not a bag-man's wardrobe. Mr. Morton stuffed everything neatly in a large plastic trash bag, and feeling, he said, like a tardy Santa, went on his way.

Sales rose 8.2 percent, to $887.5 million, from $820.3 million. For the full year, net income increased 28 percent, to $113.5 million, or $3.11 a share, from $88.7 million, or $2.40 a share, in 1983.

title: Hawaiian Volcano Silent
description: The Kilauea volcano fell silent today, ending its latest eruptive phase. Unusually strong southerly winds wafted filaments of rock from Kilauea's fire fountain over the landscape as far away as Hilo, the island's major city, 25 miles away, geologists said.

title: IS A DEGREE PROPERTY IN DIVOCE?
description: A degree is not property to be included in a divorce agreement, a state appellate court ruled in overturning a settlement for a woman who worked as a waitress to help put her husband through medical school.

title: Bowater Inc. Issue
description: Bowater Inc., the largest producer of newsprint in the United States, today is offering $125 million of 12 3/8 percent sinking-fund debentures due in 2015, at a price of 99.40 to yield 12.45 percent, through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation. The debentures, rated A-2 by Moody's and A by Standard & Poor's, yield about one percentage point more than the 12 percent Treasury bonds due in 2013. Because of sinking-fund payments beginning in 1996, the average life of the issue is 22.4 years.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: WHAT'S YOUR GAME? Two exhibitions in town have board games as their theme, and it's your move as to which one you go to first. The new one, opening today in the first-floor rotunda of the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue at 103d Street (534-1672), takes board sports from the earliest to latest creations. The other, at the Museum of American Folk Art, 125 West 55th Street (581-2474), concentrates on the games made by craftsmen, amateur and pro, of yesteryear America.

title: Reagan Library Site Chosen
description: A site overlooking Stanford University has been chosen by a school trustees' committee for the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library, officials said Tuesday. If the university board and Mr. Reagan agree, construction could begin in 1987. The site that was chosen was unincorporated Stanford property next to the school's Center for Advanced Study in Behavioral Sciences.

title: Lions Name Rogers
description: Darryl Rogers and the Detroit Lions made it official yesterday. Rogers, a former Michigan State coach who spent the last four seasons at Arizona State, has agreed to a five- year contract as the Lions' head coach.

title: A DEFICIT DISASTER ISN'T IMMINENT
description: Almost daily we hear that deficits are a national calamity. While they are a serious matter, we should not overstate their adverse consequences for the economy. If the dire consequences that some predict fail to materialize, public complacency about the real dangers could easily follow.

title: United Is Staying With Discount Fares
description: United Airlines yesterday dealt a blow to a new American Airlines fare plan by deciding to stay with 90 percent of its less restrictive discount fares.

Westmoreland in Vietnam for two years, testified yesterday that General Westmoreland acted improperly in 1967 by delaying a cable to Washington reporting higher enemy strength because it would be ''a political bombshell.''

Dunlop Holdings
description: Dunlop Holdings P.L.C. said it welcomed the decision of its principal creditor banks to take a neutral position for the duration of BTR P.L.C.'s attempts to take over Dunlop. Dunlop, a holding company whose operations manufacture a number of products, including tires and sports equipment, said the banks had reconfirmed support for Dunlop's financial restructuring, including the extension of loans beyond the previous deadline of March 31. The banks support possible revisions to the $142 million refinancing package on terms that will be beneficial to Dunlop shareholders.

title: Jackson Has Pneumonia
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson was admitted to the Howard University Hospital Tuesday night with a severe case of bronchitis and pneumonia that caused part of his right lung to collapse, doctors said today. But the 43-year old civil rights leader was reported to be in good condition with a ''good to excellent'' prognosis.

title: TWO VOYAGERS IN MINMALIST TERRAIN

title: THE NEXT GOAL: COMMON SENSE
description: ASK a human assistant to prepare a monthly sales report, and chances are he or she would use some common sense. The report would not be sent out until sales from all of the company's branch offices are included, and calculations - commissions, inventory levels, and the like - are finished. And if the assistant values continued employment, copies of the completed report would be sent to the boss, the chairman of the board and the company president.

title: Key Rates
HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: ALTHOUGH walls and ceilings made of gypsum board panels - commonly referred to as drywall construction - are less prone to developing cracks than those made of plaster, this does not mean that gypsum board walls and ceilings never need repairs. Cracks will sometimes develop in joints that originally were properly filled with tape and joint cement, or nails will sometimes work loose because of warping and buckling of the framework inside the wall or because the wrong kind of nails were used.

RATE SWAPS DRAW CONCERN
description: For many corporate treasurers the financial world is much safer these days because of a new technique to manage risk called the interest rate swap. But accountants and banking regulators are growing increasingly concerned that not enough is known about the risk it poses to the financial institutions that arrange and stand behind the burgeoning amount of these swaps.

COMBINING FUN WITH FUNCTION

''They're functional things that happen to be fun,'' said Michael V. Prince, the vice president of Straight Lines, who is shown above in the company's boutique on the sixth floor at Bloomingdale's.

title: Banner Bob Wins
description: Banner Bob, whose recent morning workouts had been astounding the clockers, proved he was no morning glory today by running the best race of the year by a 3-year-old in the $76,200 Hutcheson Stakes at Gulfstream Park. The attractive bay colt ripped off seven furlongs in 1:21 3/5 in scoring a 2 1/2-length victory and emerge as one of the early favorites for the spring classics.

title: NEW ZEALAND REBUFF: A BAFFLING FUROR
description: New Zealand's armed forces have fewer than 12,700 men; its navy consists of four frigates, six patrol boats and seven helicopters. Moreover, the Soviet Union has no vital interest in the Southwest Pacific and has paid little attention of any kind to the region. Yet in the last few days United States officials have treated a refusal by New Zealand's Prime Minister, David Lange, to permit a port visit by an American destroyer as a major foreign policy crisis, as a matter of ''grave concern,'' and an event meriting possible economic retaliation against New Zealand's lamb, wool and butter exports.

This generous program - with James Levine conducting and playing the piano - offered the Beethoven E flat Quintet and the Octets of Stravinsky and Schubert.

title: No Headline
description: A Volunteer to Run the Schools New York's Mayor Koch has renewed his offer to exercise greater authority over the Board of Education and to be held accountable for the performance of the public schools. He again proposes enlarging the board from 7 to 15 members, and increasing the mayor's appointments from 2 to 10.

title: ESSAY ;   AMERICAN REVOLUTION II
description: WASHINGTON Presidents, as their years go by, change their view of the State of the Union. The first assessment is usually bad, to leave room for improvement; Jerry Ford went as far as to say, candidly, ''The State of the Union is not good.'' It always gets better.

description: An attack on the military pension system by David A. Stockman, the budget director, drew angry responses today from veterans' groups, Pentagon officials and some Congressional champions of the military.

title: Test Missile Is Destroyed
description: The Air Force destroyed an unarmed Minuteman 3 intercontinental missile in flight today after a problem was detected in a test over the Pacific, Tech. Sgt. Fred Bolinger said. He said he did not know how many others had been so destroyed but that it was not the first.

title: THE STAGE: 'IN JUNGLE OF CITIES'
description: BERTOLT BRECHT'S third play, ''In the Jungle of Cities,'' is a poetic scream of nihilism that lends itself readily to experimental theatrical techniques. Written in 1922, it was Brecht's first work to be set in Chicago, a city that remained for him a symbol of crime, corruption and worship of money.

title: BATIK FROM JAVA: HISTORY IN CLOTH
description: WHILE batik has obscure roots in Indonesia's past, the craft reached its highest refinement on the north coast of the island of Java from about 1850 to 1940. An exhibition, ''Fabled Cloth: Batik From Java's North Coast,'' which opened recently at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum, brings together some 50 examples spanning that period of excellence. Nearly all of the fabrics, which are about 3 feet wide and 7 or 8 feet long, were used as sarongs, worn by women, or as the larger kain panjang, worn by men. Unfurled at the Cooper-Hewitt, they resemble airy, unframed paintings.

title: THE DEMOGRAPHICS OF STEAM GRATES
description: On the Ellipse, a large grassy area just south of the White House, a man slept on a grating as a cold rain gave everything a thin glazing of ice. The man was so bundled against the cold that little of his features could be seen within the tiny puff of steam that rose from the grating. It was midday, and the man was sleeping. He finally moved, his hand rising to his face, and the only thing identifiable about him was that he was white. In this city, with its predominately black population, most street people seen in the downtown area are whites. Why? Marie Nahikian, chairman of a local group, the Coalition for the Homeless, says one explanation may be that Washington's blacks are more willing to care for their poor than the considerably more affluent whites. ''There are black homeless people,'' Miss Nahikian said, ''but the black community does take care of its own. There are two Washingtons - the local Washington and the Federal Washington. In the local Washington, it is possible that blacks in the local community tend to double up more than whites.'' By some estimates, Washington has as many as 15,000 homeless of all races. Other cities, such as New York, probably have more. But in Washington, the homeless who occupy doorways and gratings in the shadow of the nation's greatest public buildings are a particularly poignant sight. A hundred yards or so from the man on the Ellipse, four men had set up an encampment on 18th Street near Constitution Avenue, across from the headquarters of the Daughters of the American Revolution.

title: DESIGN NOTEBOOK
description: I HAVE at home a new book that is shaping up as the enemy of sociability. It is not that it preaches rudeness, or parsimony, or the use of horse fat in toasted sandwiches. If anything, it speaks up for flawless housekeeping and an atmosphere of nonstop happiness. But what happens is this. People come into the house, they see this book on the table, they open it at the first of its 408 heavily illustrated pages and for the rest of the day neither meat, drink nor sensational news can reclaim their attention. They are lost to us, the way Lewis Carroll's Alice was lost when she stepped through the looking glass.

description: Donald J. Barhyte, chief financial officer and treasurer of Multimedia Inc., had hoped his group's offer to take the company private in a leveraged buyout would go through without a hitch.

title: Highlights in Jazz Series
description: The 12th season of the Highlights in Jazz series begins next Wednesday at 8 P.M. with a concert featuring Doc Cheatham, Marty Napoleon, Carrie Smith and others at the Loeb Student Center, 566 La Guardia Place. Tickets are $7.50 ($6 for students). Information: 598-2027.

title: Earnings Climb 30% At Ogilvy & Mather
description: Ogilvy & Mather International ended the year on an upbeat note as far as earnings went.

description: BASEBALL

description: The company said that the latest quarter and year nets include a credit of $1.7 million, or 8 cents per share, from a special dividend paid by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board in the form of F.H.L.B.B. stock.

title: BULGARIA AND U.S. TRADE CHARGES ON DRUG TRAFFIC
description: Bulgaria and the United States exchanged accusations today over drug smuggling, with the Bulgarians charging that the Americans, for political reasons, had halted talks aimed at cooperative control of narcotics and arms traffic.

title: Comic Book Hero
description: Bobby Orr played on two Stanley Cup-winning teams, led the National Hockey League in scoring twice, and was the youngest player inducted into the Hockey Hall of Fame. He certainly was a winner.

description: b-Net loss.

title: INDIA REPORTED TO EXPEL 3 SOVIET BLOC CITIZENS
description: Soviet and Indian officials here declined today to confirm or deny a report that a Soviet citizen ''attached to the embassy'' had been expelled from New Delhi, along with an East German and a Polish diplomat.

title: Lorraine Rowan Cooper, 79; Wife of Ex-Kentucky Senator
description: Lorraine Rowan Cooper, wife of John Sherman Cooper, a former United States Senator from Kentucky, died Sunday after an illness of several months at the Wisconsin Avenue Nursing Home in Georgetown.

title: TWO FILMS TOP OSCAR NOMINATIONS
description: With 11 nominations apiece, ''Amadeus'' and ''A Passage to India'' swept the 57th Academy Award nominations announced today.

title: OLSTEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
Yanks Sign Armstrong
description: Mike Armstrong , the Yankee relief pitcher who had filed for salary arbitration seeking $375,000, signed a one- year contract for $325,000, plus incentive bonuses keyed to the number of games he appears in.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Knicks vs. Trail Blazers , at Portland, Ore. When the Knicks played the Blazers at Madison Square Garden last Dec. 1, Clyde Drexler, the Portland swingman, left the arena on a stretcher after a foul by Ken Bannister of the Knicks. Drexler required six stitches over his left eye. However, he had already contributed 25 points and 12 rebounds to Portland's victory. (Television - Channel 9, 10:30 P.M. )

title: HALIFAX ENGINEERING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $95,590 for the quarter and $208,255 for the 9 months. c-Net income after losses from discontinued operations of $4,778 for the quarter and $272 for the 9 months. The latest quarter and year include a $175,000 reserve for an account receivable of doubtful collectability.

title: U.S. LAUNCHES INVESTIGATION OF MENGELE CASE
description: Attorney General William French Smith announced today that the Justice Department would open an investigation into the whereabouts of Josef Mengele and into reports that the Nazi war criminal had been held and freed in the American occupation zone of Vienna after World War II.

title: GRANT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Easco Discloses Bylaw Changes
description: The Easco Corporation has changed its bylaws to require shareholders to give advance notice if they intend to seek board representation or to present matters for a shareholder vote.

title: GENERALS TRADE SIPE TO BULLS AFTER FLUTIE REPORTS
description: Doug Flutie met Brian Sipe for the first time early today in the locker room at the Generals' training camp. The veteran graciously welcomed the rookie and as the day proceeded the two quarterbacks went through two practice sessions side by side. A few hours later Sipe was gone.

title: A 26-YEAR-OLD RUNS ARCANE SWAP TEAM
description: GIVE or take a billion, the First Boston Corporation has handled $15 billion worth of interest rate and currency swaps in the last three years. But each time he gets wind of a new transaction, Leon Kalvaria, the 26-year-old vice president who heads the swap group, still scrupulously fills in the diagram - two boxes with countervailing sets of arrows - that is printed on his group's memo pads.

title: CBS Station Vignettes Include Commercials
description: CBS's five owned television stations have come up with a way of profiting from the current trivia craze.

title: REAGAN SKETCHES LEGISLATIVE GOALS FOR NEXT 4 YEARS
description: President Reagan urged the nation today to forge ''a second American revolution of hope and opportunity'' with an agenda of tax revision and economic growth and the elimination of the threat of nuclear war for the next four years.

title: HIGH PLACE OF PATIENCE
description: LAST June, when most investors were worrying

title: MURIEL GARDINER, WHO HELPED HUNDREDS ESCAPE NAZIS, DIES
description: Dr. Muriel Gardiner, a wealthy American psychoanalyst who during her student days in Vienna smuggled false passports and money to help hundreds of people escape from Fascist- controlled Austria, died of cancer yesterday at the Princeton (N.J.) Medical Center. She was 83 years old and lived in Hightstown, N.J.

title: ELEGANT TOUCH FOR FRONT DOOR
description: SOLID brass door knockers make an elegant addition to any entrance door. The Renovator's Supply carries eight different types. An unusual one is the pineapple knocker. In solid cast brass, it measures 5 3/4 inches high and 3 3/8 inches wide, and costs $15.95. For horse lovers, Renovator's also carries a bridled horse with a horseshoe handle ($19.95).

title: Union Enterprises Opposes Offer
description: Union Enterprises Ltd. said it had advised shareholders to reject the Unicorp Canada Corporation's bid for the company, calling the offer ''both unfair and inadequate.'' Unicorp, an investment holding company, said it had acquired 13.8 percent of Union and planned an offer for all remaining shares in a transaction valued at more than $400 million.

title: THOMAS INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Sales for the 1983 fourth quarter and year are restated to reflect a change in financial statement presentation of the discontinued electronics division. Results are adjusted for a 10 percent stock dividend paid Jan. 1.

description: Woodcarving, Ukrainian Museum,

title: Dominican Shopkeepers Strike Over Austerity
description: A shopkeepers' strike to protest Government austerity programs spread today through parts of this city, which was already paralyzed by transport operators who shut down because of huge increases in fuel prices.

description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif.

title: KNOCK AT THE DOOR MAY BE A SOLIDARITY SALESMAN
description: 29 - So many Poles spend so much of their time waiting for a ''kolporter'' that one might conclude that there is a revivalist cult of the American songwriter here.

title: PLICE PROTEST: WARD IS SILENT
description: For three days, police officers have been staging protests over the manslaughter indictment of an officer who shot an emotionally disturbed woman.

title: An Activist for Jews in Soviet Is Sentenced to Labor Camp
description: A court in Odessa has convicted a Jewish activist of anti-Soviet slander and has sentenced him to three years in a labor camp, dissident sources here said today.

title: SCHLESINGER SAYS DISTRUST HINDERS FOREIGN POLICY
description: Former Secretary of Defense James R. Schlesinger asserted today that President Reagan's main difficulty in winning support for his Pentagon budget, Nicaragua policy and missile defense proposal was Congressional distrust of Administration objectives and credibility.

title: WINTER CARE FOR AN ARRAY OF SUCCULENTS
description: WHEN Frank Bowman says ''If in doubt let them do without,'' he's not being heartless. He is instead providing the best advice possible for owners of succulents who might otherwise kill their plants with kindness at this time of year.

title: High-Roller Found Dead
description: A Texas gambler who lost $1 million on a single roll of the dice less than three months ago was found dead at the Marina Hotel here Monday, an apparent suicide, the police said. Sgt. Frank Jergovic said that the gambler, William Lee Bergstrom, 33 years old, of La Grange, Tex., had swallowed the contents of various unidentified capsules and left a suicide note containing instructions to cremate the body.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;   Intermountain Offering $775 Million in Bonds
description: The Intermountain Power Agency, a Utah organization that is constructing two coal-fired plants to supply electricity to southern California, is offering $775 million worth of bonds to refinance 13 and 14 percent bonds it sold in 1981.

title: EXHIBIT: MOVABLE BUILDING MODELS
description: ''DINING Building With Window Chairs'' - one of 50 hand-built architectural models now in ''Small Buildings,'' a show of the work of the New York architect Allan Wexler at the Ronald Feldman Fine Arts gallery in SoHo - appears to be a wooden garden shed, but, in fact, the structure shelters a wall-to-wall table inside and might be called a dining folly.

title: METROPOLITAN OPERA: 'PORGY AND BESS
description: IN a year that marks the golden

title: MURDEROUS CHILD IN 'THE BAD SEED'
description: IT is comforting to believe in inherited evil; it explains so

title: PHELPS DODGE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a pre-tax charge of $195,000,000 relating to the restructuring of certain operations.

title: WRIGHT CONFIDENT ON SPEAKER POST
description: Saying that he was trying to dispel ''intrigue and speculation'' in Democratic ranks, Representative Jim Wright asserted today that about three-quarters of the current House Democrats had promised to vote for him as Speaker when the 100th Congress convenes in 1987.

title: 'SURVIVING,' MOVIE EXPLORING TEEN-AGE SUICIDE
description: ''SURVIVING'' is a serious production, meant to be seen by adults. Do not dismiss it for its seriousness, however; it is also an enormously watchable production. It deals with teen-age suicide and with how families cope, but it is saved from glumness by intelligence and juicy acting. In particular, we see actresses acting; three women carry the show. The ''ABC Theater'' production, three hours long, will be seen at 8 o'clock Sunday night on Channel 7.

title: Hook Rejects Bid
description: Hook Drugs Inc. said its board had unanimously rejected an unsolicited $31-a-share tender offer by the Rite Aid Corporation. In urging its shareholders to reject the bid, valued at about $135 million, Hook called it inadequate. Hook said it had authorized its legal and financial advisers to explore all alternatives.

title: Nurses in Jersey End Strike
description: Registered nurses at United Hospitals Medical Center today unanimously ratified a three-year contract, ending an 11-day strike.

title: BLOCK ACKNOWLEDGES FARM PROBLEMS
description: Agriculture Secretary John R. Block said today that American farmers could not expect much improvement this year in the prices they receive but would enjoy better times in the long run if they supported President Reagan's new farm policy and his efforts to reduce the deficit.

title: SEVERAL LARGE CONTRIBUTIONS BOLSTER NEEDIEST CASES FUND
description: While gifts of all sizes are appreciated equally by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, the fund has been fortunate in recent days to receive several large donations.

title: THE NEW YORK TIMES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a charge of 8 cents a share for retroactive wage adjustments. c-Includes a first-half nonrecurring gain of 22 cents a share from divestitures.

title: CALFED INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary net gain of $3,744,000 for the quarter and year from a Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. stock dividend and a tax credit of $6,217,000 for the quarter.

title: SCHLUMBERGER UP
description: The Allied Corporation reported yesterday that it had a net income of $99 million, or 97 cents a share, in the fourth quarter of 1984.

title: South Africans Will Consider Allowing Interracial Marriage
description: A special legislative panel will consider repealing South African race laws that prohibit interracial sex and marriage, Home Affairs Minister F. W. de Klerk said today.

title: Mexico's Austerity Plans
description: The Mexican Government said today it would cut public spending by about $470 million and sell 236 state-run enterprises as part of its economic austerity program.

title: HARVARD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ASSOCIATED HOSTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
CONVERSION BATTLE ON UPPER EAST SIDE
description: The last time the American Invsco Corporation came to New York to convert a rental apartment building into a cooperative, the result was one of the most bitter conversion battles in New York real estate history. Tenants accused the company, at that time the largest apartment converter in the United States, of harassment, coercion and misleading and inadequate disclosure.

title: METROPOLITAN OPERA: GERSHWIN'S 'PORGY AND BESS'
description: IN a year that marks the golden

title: A Popular Verdict in Poland It is always a sign of progress when a police state seriously prosecutes police crimes. The stiff sentences that Poland has imposed on four officers of the Interior Ministry for the murder of Father Jerzy Popieluszko sets a welcome new standard of accountability. Similar crimes with less-famous victims too often went unacknowledged and unpunished. Ideally, the fate of Captain Piotrowski, Colonel Pietruszka and Lieutenants Pekala and Chmielewski will deter others in the security apparatus from giving and following murderous orders.
description: But what of the regime's responsibility? While it is unlikely that General Jaruzelski himself ordered the murder of the pro-Solidarity priest, the official explanation strains credibility. It is that the murder was actually a plot by hard-line conspirators to discredit the regime.

title: CONRAC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a nonrecuring charge of $1,081,000. c-Including a nonrecurring gain of $7,152,000 from the settlement of a civil antitrust suit against American Telephone & Telegraph.

GENEX CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

title: Bangladesh Doctors Strike
description: About 27,000 Government doctors, engineers and agriculture specialists went on strike today demanding withdrawal of some administrative measures they say affect their services. The professionals are demanding better service facilities and withdrawal of a Government order placing services of rural doctors, engineers and agriculturists under the authority of the 460 rural subdistricts.

title: COURT REBUFFS DUARTE ON ELECTION LAW
description: The Supreme Court of El Salvador ruled today that President Jose Napoleon Duarte acted unconstitutionally when he partly vetoed and published a new electoral law in December.

title: WHITE HOUSE TAX PLAN IS DELAYED UNTIL SPRING
description: Administration officials said today that it might be well into the spring before the White House completes drafting a tax bill to send to Congress. But they pointed to President Reagan's strong endorsement in his State of the Union Message Wednesday night as an indication that the President was fully committed to press for enactment of sweeping tax legislation this year.

title: A $25 PASS OPENS DOOR TO 15 EAST SIDE EVENTS
description: THE Upper East Side is hardly known as a theater district. Yet it contains a surprising number of theaters, surprising even to the theaters themselves. Many of them have been East Siders for nearly a decade or more. But few are close neighbors. Many are tucked away on residential streets. And all have heard audience members say: ''You know, I live just a few blocks away and I didn't know until now that you were here.''

title: U.S. SAYS ALL G.I.'S WILL QUIT GRENADA
description: The Reagan Administration said today that all foreign troops, including 250 United States military personnel, would be withdrawn from Grenada over five and a half months starting in mid-April.

title: CBS PRODUCER REASSERTS POLITICS LED TO LOW ESTIMATES OF ENEMY STRENGTH
description: George Crile, the producer of a disputed CBS documentary on the Vietnam War, testified yesterday that he believed when the broadcast was made that Gen. William C. Westmoreland had reduced enemy strength estimates in 1967 for ''political reasons.''

title: AMERICAN WATER WORKS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DYCO PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

title: Batterymarch To Oppose Tie
description: Batterymarch Financial Management said it plans to vote against National Intergroup Inc.'s proposed merger into the Bergen Brunswig Corporation.

title: Economic Scene ;   Reagan's Revolution
description: President Reagan's State of the Union Message may not have made a lot of fresh news. But it was, as Representative Les Aspin of Wisconsin put it, a remarkable piece of ''show biz,'' from the President's call for a Second American Revolution, his modest bid for a place in the history books next to George Washington, to his shy enjoyment of a Congressional first, the enthusiastic singing of ''Happy Birthday, Mr. President'' by Republicans and Democrats alike.

title: GUARDSMEN TRAIN FOR MOUNTAIN WAR
description: Pfc. David Rondeau stretched out on a boulder one weekend in January, a gory simulated wound on his thigh. Staff Sgt. Brian Hall spread simulatedblood on the snow around Private Rondeau, then hiked to a nearby ledge where he lay down under a pine tree.

title: Article 013744 -- No Title
description: Arrived in a big box from Boston: Flutie's $750 shoulder pads and rib protector he wore at Boston College to protect a slight shoulder separation last fall.

title: TRANSCO ENERGY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Right-Hand Men on Arms
description: When the widely heralded arms control talks with the Soviet Union open in Geneva on March 12, the publicity spotlight will be on the three chief negotiators for the United States: Max M. Kampelman, former Senator John Tower of Texas and Maynard W. Glitman. But the key operatives may actually be their respective top assistants, each of whom will be, in effect, a chief of staff, processing papers and handling both substantive and political questions just below the highest level.

title: THE DANCE: 'SWEET SATURDAY NIGHT' IN BROOKLYN
description: THERE could be few more exciting and heartwarming salutes to Black History Month than ''Sweet Saturday Night,'' a celebration of 300 years of black street and social dance. Lenwood Sloan and Mikki Shepard have put together a sumptuous-looking production, which is at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue, through Sunday. Under Mr. Sloan's direction, it moves quickly, explodes with infectious exuberance, and has a few funny and poignant things to suggest about the black experience in America and its vibrant continuity.

title: CHEVRON, TEXACO TO SELL SOME CANADA HOLDINGS
description: The Chevron Corporation agreed today to offer for sale its 60 percent share of Gulf Canada to a Canadian-controlled purchaser. Analysts said such a sale, if it occurred, could be valued at $1.5 billion to nearly $2.5 billion in United States dollars at current exchange rates.

title: 4 POLISH OFFICERS SENTENCED TO JAIL IN PRIEST'S DEATH
description: Four state security policemen were convicted and sentenced to prison today for their role in the abduction and murder of a pro- Solidarity priest.

title: Making Progress
description: Theotis Brown, the 27-year-old running back for the Kansas City Chiefs who suffered a heart attack Wednesday, had a bit of good news yesterday when his cardiologist said that an enzyme injection had dissolved a clot in a coronary artery and that he had no further blockage. ''Hopefully, this will limit the extent of damage,'' said

title: Despite Talent, Blazers Sink in the West
description: The questions have haunted Jack Ramsay, the Portland Trail Blazer coach, for months: Does he regret making the trade that sent three solid players, as well as a first-round draft pick, to Denver for Kiki Vandeweghe? And how about the rookie Sam Bowie? Would Michael Jordan have been a better choice?

title: Italy Asks Extradition
description: Italy has asked Bulgaria to extradite a Turkish businessman, Bekir Celenk, on charges of plotting to kill Pope John Paul II in 1981, the Italian news agency ANSA said today.

title: CORRECTION
description: A headline in some editions of Sports Pages yesterday incorrectly reported the result of the basketball game between Arkansas and Southern Methodist. Arkansas won, 69-66.

title: Envoys Lose Tax Exemption
description: If American diplomats must pay sales taxes abroad, then foreign envoys must pay up in the United States, the State Department announced today.

title: SCHLUMBERGER LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
The Mind of Congress
description: The National Enquirer is trying

title: Diner's Journal
description: THE celestial theme among New York restaurants continues unabated. First there was Pig Heaven, a new Chinese restaurant at Second Avenue and 80th Street, then Duck Heaven, a restaurant-carryout at Broadway and 95th Street, and now Ham Heaven, a hot new lunch spot in the City Hall area, at 49 Warren Street (513-7224).

title: Farewell, 'Mr. Mayor'
description: It would be impossible to mistake

title: RANGEL SEES A REAGAN 'HOAX'
description: Representative Charles B. Rangel, the Harlem Democrat, sharply criticized President Reagan today for his tribute to one of Mr. Rangel's constituents, Clara Hale, in the State of the Union Message Wednesday night.

title: FOUR FREED BRITONS LEAVE LIBYA
description: Four Britons freed after nine months' detention in Libya flew home to an emotional welcome today, and Col. Muammar el- Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, said he hoped his diplomatic rift with London would end ''as soon as possible.''

title: AUSTRALIAN TAKES MIDDLE POSITION IN THE U.S.-NEW ZEALAND DISPUTE
description: Prime Minister Robert Hawke of Australia said today that Australia would hold separate military exercises with the United States and New Zealand until an apparent breakdown in military cooperation between the United States and New Zealand could be repaired.

title: DOW CLIMBS 9.49 IN HEAVY TRADING
description: The stock market rally, which turned one month old yesterday, celebrated by producing sharp gains in heavy trading. The Dow Jones industrial average was up 9.49, at 1,290.08, tying its second-highest mark, set Monday.

title: IN CONGRESS'S COURT
description: With a State of the Union Message setting out his conservative agenda, President Reagan gave new impetus to the cause of tax reform in Congress, but made no visible converts to his strategy for reducing the Federal deficit. The optimistic thrust of his address, with its evocation of a bright American future, showed that the President was tilting quite openly toward the growth-oriented philosophy of Young Turk Republicans in the House of Representatives, rather than the austerity being preached by more traditional Republicans in the Senate.

title: Please Don't Shoot the Iron Horse
description: To the Editor:

title: Katy Unit in Talks
description: The Missouri-Kansas-Taxas Railroad, a subsidiary of Katy Industries, said it was in talks on a possible sale or merger, but it declined to identify the possible buyer. The merger must be approved by the Interstate Commerce Commission. Katy owns 98 percent of the Dallas-based railroad.

title: A 'Sympathetic Ear' For Children of Drug Users
description: ''An American hero.'' A lot of people in New York knew that those words described Clara Hale long before President Reagan offered them in his State of the Union Message.

title: LIBERATION THEOLOGY'S FOUNDER DEFENDS DOCTRINE
description: The priest who is widely credited with first developing liberation theology today strongly defended the teachings while criticizing efforts by some Peruvian bishops to develop a competing theology.

title: G.O.P. LEADERSHIP SEEKING A FREEZE IN SOCIAL SECURITY
description: Business leaders said the President's budget should have done more to narrow the deficit. Page D1.

title: Market Place ;   Diverse Views Of Du Pont
description: Shares of E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company finished 1984 at 49 1/2, after dropping 4.8 percent for the year. But yesterday the stock of the nation's largest chemical producer sold at 54 1/2, its highest price in 13 months. On the New York Stock Exchange, Du Pont closed at 53 7/8, down 3/8.

title: Man Is Accused Of Blocking I.R.S.
description: A man identified by his lawyer as a city sanitation employee was charged yesterday with assaulting and interfering with I.R.S. agents last month.

title: MORALISM'S LIMITS
description: It is ''no virtue'' to be tolerant of

title: Shiites Seize, Then Free Cypriot Plane in Beirut
description: Gunmen seeking freedom for jailed associates seized a Cyprus Airways jetliner at the Beirut airport today and threatened to kill 12 hostages, but surrendered five hours later, Lebanese officials said.

title: Oakland in Brooklyn
description: The Oakland Ballet will appear at the Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts at Brooklyn College tomorrow at 8 P.M. and Sunday at 2. Tickets are $8, $10 and $12. Information: (718) 434-1900.

title: RESIGNATION AT LOGAN In a move that had been
description: widely expected within the apparel industry, Richard J.

title: AMAX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SUNDSTRAND CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
'WHERE THE GREEN ANTS DREAM'
description: SOMETIMES while watching a Werner Herzog film, whether it's ''Even Dwarfs Started Small'' (1969), ''Aguirre, the Wrath of God'' (1972), ''The Mystery of Kasper Hauser'' (1974) or ''Fitzcarraldo'' (1981), I get the feeling that this intense, hugely gifted German director can only get a fix on himself within the universe when he's in the company of the physically deformed, the mentally retarded or culturally primitive.

title: ANDERSON CLAYTON & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago second quarter and 6 months results have been restated to reflect $6,153,000 of tax credits.

title: ILLINOIS UPSET BY MICHIGAN STATE, 64-56
description: The guards Scott Skiles and Sam Vincent scored 24 and 20 points, respectively, to lead Michigan State to a 64-56 upset of Illinois in a Big Ten Conference game tonight.

title: Manila Murder Trial Put Off for 2 Weeks
description: The trial of Gen. Fabian C. Ver and 25 others accused in the assassination of the opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr. was postponed today for at least two weeks as a hearing meant to speed up proceedings turned into a three-hour quarrel.

title: Tap-Dance to Jazz
description: Jazz with tap-dancing will be presented tonight and tomorrow from 10 P.M. to 2 A.M. at the Jazz Cultural Theater, 368 Eighth Avenue above 28th Street.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Buckhorn Inc., Columbus, Ohio, a maker of re-usable plastic shipping and storage containers, metal shelving and rubber products, said Roger W. Roth had resigned as executive vice president and director.

title: MOORE MCCORMACK REOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $2,482,000, or 29 cents a share, from disposal of discontinued operations. The company said that the share earnings are after deducting preferred dividends. The company also said the fourth quarter earnings for both years do not include any contribution from the 20 percent owned LNG transportation project.

title: DEMOCRATS: NO EMMY, PLEASE
description: The ABC broadcast of ''Dynasty'' clobbered the Democratic response to President Reagan's State of the Union address in the television ratings Wednesday night, and a lot of Democrats here are pleased that it did.

title: CORDURA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Trade Deficit Is Confirmed
description: The United States had a record trade deficit of $107.6 billion last year on a balance-of-payments basis despite the first improvement in exports since 1981, the Commerce Department said today.

title: SRI LANKA REVOLT: MANY SNARED IN POLICE DRAGNET
description: Several dozen women stood silently outside the drab, barricaded police headquarters of this quiet fishing town this morning. They were waiting for word of their husbands, brothers and sons.

title: Treasury Dealers' Capital Guidelines
description: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York yesterday proposed voluntary standards of capital adequacy for dealers in United States Government securities. The standards are a response to the collapse in recent years of several dealers.

title: STOCKMAN: THERE HE GOES AGAIN
description: Once again David A. Stockman was, in his own prophetic words, ''in hot water.'' Especially with President Reagan.

title: CARAVAGGIO AT MET, AN AGE COMES TO LIFE
description: ''THE AGE OF CARAVAGGIO'' at the Metropolitan Museum of Art is on every count a most remarkable achievement. It has great paintings. It has paintings which, though not so great, have something irreplaceable to tell us. It has a schema, an argument and an armature. It brings instruction, it brings delight, and it also brings a terror that is all too topical. What more can we ask?

title: Military Contracts
description: The General Dynamics Corporation has been awarded a $114.8 million contract for work on Tomahawk ground-launched cruise missiles, the Navy announced. The work is to be performed in San Diego. The Navy also said the Raytheon Company had been awarded a $73.2 million contract for equipment for the MK-74 missile fire control system.

title: PARTIES MANEUVER IN WAKE OF NORTH CAROLINA VOTES
description: Since Senator Jesse Helms won re-election, defeating Gov. James B. Hunt Jr., North Carolina Republicans have been seeking converts while North Carolina Democrats have been seeking new directions.

title: CENTENNIAL GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net losses.

title: ENTRE COMPUTER CENTERS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
NEW GUIDELINES ON LEAD ISSUED
description: The Federal Centers for Disease Control has lowered the amount of lead in the blood that is considered poisoning and recommended today that all children be screened.

title: Return From U.S. Exile
description: Mr. Kim's return to South Korea today ended more than two years of exile in the United States.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;   Price Corp. Financing
description: The Price Communications Corporation, which owns two television and six radio stations, is offering $75 million of subordinated notes and 1.5 million shares of common stock. The 11 3/4 percent notes due in 1995, rated B-2 by Moody's Investors Service and B- by Standard & Poor's, are offered at 84.55, to yield 14.75 percent through Morgan Stanley & Company, the sole underwriter.

title: FAIRNESS DOCTRINE DEBATED
description: The president-elect of the Radio and Television News Directors Association told the Federal Communications Commission today that news organizations often decide against covering controversial issues for fear of being confronted by groups displeased with the coverage and threatening action under the Fairness Doctrine.

title: Another Goalie Hurt
description: Hubert Birkenmeier, the Cosmos goalie, suffered a broken cheekbone in the team's 9-2 loss to San Diego Wednesday night and will be out for four to six weeks, club officials said yesterday. Both the injury and the loss added to the ill fortune that has dogged the Cosmos this indoor season.

title: Continental Illinois
description: Duff & Phelps today raised its rating on the Continental Illinois Corporation's long- term debt to an investment grade. The rating was upgraded to 9 - equivalent to middle BBB - from 12 - equivalent to middle BB.

title: FILM: 'HEAVEN HELP US' FROM MICHAEL DINNER
description: ST. BASIL'S, the Brooklyn parochial school at which ''Heaven Help Us'' takes place, is not the usual setting for schoolboy comedy. But then, ''Heaven Help Us'' is not the familiar assemblage of gags and antics, though it contains enough of these to draw a teen-age crowd. The director Michael Dinner, making his feature debut, and the screenwriter Charles Purpura have an unusually good feeling for the time, the place, the characters as kids and the adults they later turned into. It is this last group at which ''Heaven Help Us,'' like ''Diner'' and the current ''Flamingo Kid,'' is principally aimed.

title: HOW PHONE COMPANIES TRY TO MAKE RATES FAIR
description: To the Editor:

title: One Who Got Away The Cincinnati Bengals said they had given up hope of persuading
description: Cris Collinsworth to stay with the team after the wide receiver turned down the club's final offer and said he planned to honor his United States Football League contract with the Tampa Bay Bandits. When Collinsworth signed a five-year, $3 million future contract with the Bandits 19 months ago, the Bengals came under heavy criticism from other National Football League clubs for letting such an outstanding player get away.

description: I T'S possible to get around town on subways and

description: Robert W. Holton, director of the serious music division of the Belwin Mills publishing corporation for the last 14 years, a panel member of the Opera Musical Theater program of the National Endowment for the Arts and the recipient of the 1982 National Opera Institute Award for services to American opera, died of cancer last Sunday. He was 62 years old.

title: ARMSTRONG RUBBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a gain of $2.3 million, or 24 cents a share, from the sale of a warehouse.

description: Results for the latest periods include nonrecurring credits equal to 95 cents a share for the quarter and $1.03 a share for the year reflecting the elimination of deferred taxes relating to certain life insurance policy reserves as a result of the Tax Reform Act of 1984.

title: House Refuses to Seat Republican of Indiana
description: The Democratic-controlled House today turned back a Republican attempt to seat Richard McIntyre as the Representative of Indiana's 8th District while a House committee is investigating the disputed election.

title: Times Co. Shows Rises
description: The New York Times Company reported yesterday that its net income in the fourth quarter of 1984 rose 32 percent, to $27.6 million, or 70 cents a share, from $20.9 million, or 54 cents a share, in the period a year earlier.

title: Key Rates
92-Foot Shot on the Mark
description: Bruce Norris of Marshall

title: Best Man, Busy Man
description: Representative Jim Wright of Texas, the House majority leader, figured he would have nothing much to do yesterday in between a morning floor fight over a contested Indiana election and a mid- afternoon news conference where he planned to announce that he had locked up enough votes to become Speaker after Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. retires in 1986.

title: U.S. Begins New Drive To Eradicate Rubella
description: Rubella is at its lowest point ever in this country, but the national Centers for Disease Control, citing the danger still present for pregnant women and their babies, has begun a new drive to wipe out all traces of the disease.

title: Texas Air Makes Debenture Offer
description: The Texas Air Corporation is offering $30 million of 10 percent exchangeable subordinated debentures due in 2005 at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Kidder, Peabody & Company.

title: ITALIAN PREMIER URGES FRANCE TO EXTRADITE TERROR SUSPECTS
description: Prime Minister Bettino Craxi urged the French Government today to extradite Italian terrorist suspects, noting that some of them might have been involved in recent attacks elsewhere in Europe.

title: Quartet at Jazz Center
description: The drummer Horacee Arnold will lead a quartet, with David Friedman on vibraphone, John Purcell on saxophones and Anthony Cox on bass tonight at 9 and 10:30 P.M. at the Jazz Center of New York, 380 Lafayette Street near East Third Street.

title: AUCTIONS
description: ONE of the largest, most diverse collections of model ships ever auctioned - from a Korean turtleship to a Maori war canoe to a frigate to the liner Normandie - will be sold by Christie's at the Seamen's Church Institute of New York and New Jersey on Tuesday.

title: Black History Month
description: Black History Month celebrations continue this weekend with three films, ''African Musician,'' ''Music From Oil Drums'' and ''American Music from Rock to Pop,'' being shown free today at the Jamaica Arts Center, 161-04 Jamaica Avenue, Queens, at 11 A.M. Information, (718) 658-7400. Tomorrow, ''Stories and Songs from Africa, a free lecture- demonstration, will be featured at the Brooklyn Children's Museum, 145 Brooklyn Avenue, at 2 P.M. Information, (718) 735-4400.

title: Two-Way Race For Horse of Year
description: At about 11 P.M. Pacific standard time in Los Angeles Friday, the name of the North American Horse of the Year for 1984 will finally be announced at the Eclipse Awards dinner. This will be the second year that the winner has been kept a surprise, a way of titilating the guests paying $150 a plate for dinner, but it also effectively buries news coverage of the announcement.

title: Frederick McLaughlin Dead; Active in Educational Affairs
description: Dr. Frederick C. McLaughlin, a former director of the Public Education Association, died of a cerebral hemorrhage Tuesday at Huntington (L.I.) Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived in Huntington.

title: TWO AUTHORS VENTURE INTO ALIEN LAND OF THEATER
description: When a novelist decides to work in theater, he journeys into an alien land. Authors usually write alone and reach their audience indirectly, through the printed page. Theater is perhaps the most social of the arts, a collaboration between playwright, director, actors and designers that often resembles nothing so much as group therapy.

title: FARRELL TRYING TO ENLIST SUPPORT FOR MAYORAL BID
description: Taking politicians by surprise, Assemblyman Herman D. Farrell Jr., the influential Manhattan Democratic leader, began seeking support yesterday for a bid for the Democratic mayoral nomination.

title: FRIDAY'S (TGI) INC(N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
The Myth of the Medical-Insurance Crisis
description: To the Editor:

title: Martha Is Hurt
description: Moe Martha of the Penguins suffered a contusion in his lower spine when he was checked hard against the boards by Tim Higgins 13:08 into the second period. He was taken to nearby Riverside Hospital for X-rays and observation.

title: Topics ;   Louder Than Words ;   A Telling AbstentionThe Reagan Administration has discreetly signaled the failure of its quiet diplomacy in Chile. It abstained yesterday as the Inter-American Development Bank voted to approve Chile's application for a $130 million loan.
description: For an Administration that has gone out of its way not to embarrass right-wing dictators, this abstention will speak louder than a hundred speeches. Chile is obviously doing something very wrong.

title: LEVER GETS 300TH AS DEVILS TRIUMPH
description: Despite a lethargic second period tonight, the Devils defeated the Pittsburgh Penguins, 6-3, and then reflected on their pleasant but unfamiliar position of being a playoff contender this late in the season.

title: COAST BANK MORTGAGE LOSS RISES
description: The BankAmerica Corporation announced yesterday that it had substantially increased its loan-loss reserve for the fourth quarter, cutting its earnings by $29 million. The move was taken to account for losses the bank may record in connection with its role as an agent for mortgage- backed securities that apparently were sold fraudulently.

title: CANADA PLANS PANEL ON NAZIS
description: The Canadian Government will set up an independent commission to investigate whether there are Nazi war criminals in Canada who can be prosecuted, extradited or deported, the Justice Minister, John Crosbie, said today.

title: BAN ON BEER ADS IS CALLED UNLIKELY
description: The chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, James C. Miller 3d, said today it was unlikely that his agency would promulgate any rules to bar beer and wine advertising from radio and television.

title: CARLISLE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A Sweet Victory Turns on Sour Note
description: In a surprising finish, Markus Wasmaier of West Germany edged Pirmin Zurbriggen of Switzerland by five-hundredths of a second to win the men's giant slalom today for his first major international victory.

title: CROSS, A T CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
AT THE MOVIES
description: GARY COOPER is, indirectly at least, part of the inspiration for ''Witness.'' Edward S. Feldman, the film's producer, says he thought of Mr. Cooper's performance in ''Friendly Persuasion'' when it came to casting the leading role of John Book, the Philadelphia policeman who goes into hiding with an Amish family. ''I thought of Gary Cooper wearing that Quaker outfit,'' Mr. Feldman recalled, ''and I asked myself, 'Who today is a reactive kind of actor who would also look funny in an outfit like that?' '' Harrison Ford came to mind, and the movie was on its way.

title: PHILLIPS SWEETENS PACKAGE SLIGHTLY
description: The Phillips Petroleum Company, bowing to widespread Wall Street grumbling, sweetened the value of its multibillion-dollar recapitalization program yesterday.

title: Newark Losing Police Director
description: Police Director Hubert Williams announced today that he would resign in May to become president of the Police Foundation, a study group based in Washington.

title: RUTGERS PRESSES EFFORTS TO JOIN TOP TIER OF UNIVERSITIES IN U.S.
description: For years, Rutgers, the State University of New Jersey, has been overshadowed by its Ivy League neighbors of the East and the great state universities of the Middle West and the West Coast.

title: HAIG BLAMES REAGAN FOR 'STAR WARS' DISPUTE
description: Former Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. blamed President Reagan today for some of the controversy surrounding the Administration's space weapons program.

title: HUSKY OIL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a $6.1 million charge on the sale of shares of a subsidiary, Husky Industries, for the quarter and year. c-After a $203.7 million gain on the sale of the company's Husky Oil Co. unit.

title: NORTON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest fourth quarter and year nets include a gain of $4.1 million from the partial sale of safety products business. The quarter a year ago includes a gain of $9.7 million from the partial sale of proppants. The prior year net includes gains of $18.2 million from the partial sales of safety products, proppants and the sale of Norton's interest in a Japanese joint venture.

title: Edward D. Mitchell, 95, Dies; Founded Beneficial Standard
description: Edward D. Mitchell, a Polish immigrant who made a fortune, lost it in the Depression and then recouped by building the Beneficial Standard Corporation, died Tuesday. He was 95 years old.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: VANESSA, a charming Greenwich Village restaurant with a turn-of-the-century ambiance and Art Deco highlights, has always been an audacious and experimental place. The most recent chefs - Anne Rosenzweig, who now presides over the new Arcadia uptown, and the current culinary commander, 30-year-old Christian Marteau, formerly of Michel Guerard - are not afraid to detour from the main road in hopes of discovering something new. For diners, this can mean a colorful and exciting trip, as long as they watch out for occasional potholes.

title: Topics;   Louder Than Words
description: Crimes of Conviction Pity the judges of Yugoslavia. They must pretend to be independent even as they hand down verdicts that sustain the myth of Communist infallibility.

title: Venezuela Bank Action
description: The Venezuelan Government said it would liquidate Banco Nacional de Descuento, one of the nation's biggest banks, which has been closed since June.

title: INFORMATION ON FESTIVAL
description: Following is a list of the members of Eastside Theaters and the productions being offered during their festival.

title: Computer-NBI Tie Is Called Off
description: Computer Consoles Inc. and NBI Inc. have terminated a previously announced merger agreement less than a month after it was reached.

title: HOUSTON INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
EX-HEAD OF HERTZ
description: Walter L. Jacobs, founder of the automobile rental business that became the Hertz Corporation, died Wednesday of a circulatory ailment at Cedars Medical Center in Miami. He was 88 years old.

title: EASTERN IN ACCORD WITH PILOTS
description: Eastern Airlines said yesterday that it had reached a tentative agreement with its pilots' union on terms that generally follow the recommendations of its labor consultant, William J. Usery.

title: ART: SUPER-REALISM OF DONALD R. WILSON
description: AN acquaintance recently exclaimed, upon seeing work by Donald Roller Wilson: ''He doesn't know

title: Thomas Is Confirmed As Head of the E.P.A.
description: The Senate today approved the nomination of Lee M. Thomas to head the Environmental Protection Agency, completing action on President Reagan's choices to lead three Federal agencies that make environmental policy.

title: GRENADA GUN CASE: JAIL FOR 7 BUT NOT ADMIRAL
description: Five soldiers and two marines who tried to smuggle captured Soviet-made rifles home after the invasion of Grenada were court-martialed and sentenced to prison, but the admiral who commanded the Grenada operation got only a ''caution'' after doing the same thing, officials said today.

title: Order in the Court
description: Only two of the nine members of the Supreme Court, Associate Justices Harry A. Blackmun and William H. Rehnquist, were present in the House Chamber Wednesday night for President Reagan's State of the Union Message - a relatively slim showing for the judicial branch of Government. (The three other men visible in frock coats were members of the staff of the high tribunal.)

title: Press Assailed in Boston Case
description: The lawyer for a 14-year-old youth accused of attempted murder said today that the mother of the victim in a widely publicized street holdup had mistakenly identified his client as the assailant.

title: Sanction Recommended In 1983 Mercy Killing
description: An examiner recommended today that the Wisconsin Board of Nursing revoke the license of a nurse who disconnected the respirator of a dying man.

title: WINE BAR: ART OF DARKNESS
description: The entrance is a study in understatement. A door opens to reveal a blank wall with a long see-through slot. Through it a shadowy, cavernous space is glimpsed. A small illustration of three birds and the Italian words I Tre Merli - ''the three blackbirds'' - on a plaque on the door are the only clues. What is it? A new wine bar and restaurant at 463 West Broadway, near Houston Street, in SoHo.

title: A SOUND WAY TO CURTAIL ABORTION
description: The Archbishop of Boston, Bernard Law, has pledged the resources of his diocese to help every woman who is contemplating an abortion - regardless of faith - to give birth to her child and raise it. With this, the church has once again taught liberals something about how to approach a complex issue: ''pro- choice'' or not, the most effective way to curtail abortion is to support the welfare state.

title: THE DANCE: PILOBOLUS PRESENTS TWO NEW YORK PREMIERES
description: THE second program Pilobolus Dance Theater delivered in its season at the Joyce Theater on Wednesday could be called ''Pilobolus Without Tears.'' The essential Pilobolus comes through here: metaphors created by the most unexpected of body shapes.

title: DANIEL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $500,000.

title: Pabst Officially Neutral on Bid
description: The Pabst Brewing Company directors would support an offer by the S&P Company for all Pabst stock at $10 a share - about $64 million - but probably will be precluded from doing so, the Milwaukee- based brewery's president and chief executive said today. William F. Smith Jr. said in a statement that Pabst was therefore officially taking a neutral position on the offer by S&P, headed by Paul Kalmanovitz, a California brewer. Mr. Smith said Pabst might be precluded from formally approving the S&P offer under terms of an agreement with the G. Heileman Brewing Company of La Crosse, Wis.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Julio Franco, the Cleveland shortstop who faced an arbitration hearing tomorrow, signed a one-year contract with the Indians. No details were announced. . . .

title: Long-Term Bond Prices Off Sharply New 30-Year Issue at 11.27%
description: Long-term bond prices declined sharply, as dealers sought to attract investors to the $5.75 billion of new 30- year Treasury bonds auctioned yesterday - as well as to notes offered earlier this week in a $13.25 billion auction.

title: CHANGES IN 3-STATE AREA PRESENT A MIXED PICTURE
description: The sequel to the agonizing process of filling out Federal income tax returns is the agonizing process of filling out state and local tax returns. Some taxpayers will find the task less burdensome this year, but others will have new burdens.

U.S. and Laos to Search For Missing Americans
description: The United States announced today that it would conduct a joint excavation with Laos from Feb. 10 to Feb. 21 of the site where a United States C-130 cargo plane crashed in southern Laos after it was shot down in December 1972.

title: ARAMS FIGHTS PROPOSED CODE FOR SENTENCING
description: The state's proposed new sentencing code is ''particularly lenient'' on people who commit white-collar crimes, Attorney General Robert Abrams testified today. He said more of them should go to jail.

title: PORTLAND, ORE., HAS A NEW MAYOR AND A NEW STYLE
description: The full- bearded, barrel-chested man in the deerstalker cap shrugs out of his red- checked Mackinaw and hitches up his knickers, ignoring his drooping left sock.

title: FLUTIE SHOCKED BY SIPE TRADE
description: Although Doug Flutie regards himself as an extremely competitive athlete, he deplored the Generals' trade of Brian Sipe to the Jacksonville Bulls.

title: EGYPT READY TO ALLOW BAIL FOR BRITON IN PLOT
description: Egypt's Interior Minister said today that the Government was prepared to release a British citizen who was detained in connection with a purported plot to kill an exiled political opponent of the Libyan leader, Muammar el-Qaddafi.

description: Results for the latest third quarter and 9 months include operations of Pharmassist Inc. and Yahr-Lange Inc. which were acquired in November 1984.

title: LAWSUIT SEEKS TO REDUCE DELAYS IN ARRAIGNMENTS
description: Saying that people arrested by the police wait as long as two days before being seen by a judge, the Legal Aid Society filed a lawsuit yesterday aimed at forcing New York City to reduce the time between arrests and arraignments.

description: b-After tax benefits of $156,200 for the quarter and $618,900 for the 9 months. c-After a tax benefit of $337,000.

description: Thousands of police officers marched outside State Supreme Court in the Bronx yesterday to protest the manslaughter indictment of the officer who shot Eleanor Bumpurs Oct. 29.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST

title: Biochemist Wins Wolf Prize
description: Donald F. Steiner, a University of Chicago biochemist, was named recipient of the $100,000 Wolf Prize in medicine for his discoveries on insulin, a hormone that helps the body control the use of sugar, the university announced today. Israel's Wolf Foundation, which awards the prize annually, cited the 54-year-old scientist for his discoveries about insulin that have improved treatment of diabetes.

title: TRUST PLAN PRESSED BY BALDRIDGE
description: Secretary of Commerce Malcolm Baldrige said today that he would press for a relaxation of the nation's antimonopoly laws to help industry compete with the record tide of imports.

title: Chernenko Is Reported At a Politburo Meeting
description: Konstantin U. Chernenko, who has been ailing, addressed the weekly Politburo meeting today, according to a regular Politburo communique.

title: Transactions

title: MAINTAINING THE HIKING TRAILS
description: Occasional wanderers on the more than 700 miles of hiking trails maintained by the New York-New Jersey Trail Conference are often unaware that those pathways to relaxation are not simply laid out and forgotten.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;   President Resigns At New York Air
description: Lawrence J. Twill, president and chief executive of New York Airlines since last May, resigned yesterday.

description: b-Includes tax benefits of $1.5 million for the latest quarter and $750,000 for the year-ago period. First quarter results include gain of about $1.4 million on the sale of real estate.

description: IT'S a long way off, but something to look forward to, both because of the subject and because new musicals are few and far between
