CAMPBELL SOUP OFFICIAL TO HEAD CITICORP UNIT
description: Citicorp said yesterday that James R. Emshoff, an executive at the Campbell Soup Company for the last six years, had been named president of Citicorp Diners Club Inc., the domestic arm of the company's travel and entertainment card subsidiary. The appointment is effective immediately.

title: Busch Earnings Rise
description: The Anheuser-Busch Companies said today that net income increased 7.3 percent in the fourth quarter over the comparable period a year ago. Earnings were $71.9 million, or $1.38 a share, up from $67 million, or $1.25 a share. Revenue rose 5.5 percent, to $1.73 billion, from $1.64 billion.

title: ISRAEL SAID TO ACCEPT INSTALLATION OF VOICE OF AMERICA TRANSMITTER
description: Israel has informed the United States that it will permit the installation of a Voice of American transmitter in Israel to enhance American broadcasts to the Soviet Union, political sources said today.

title: TRAVELERS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes realized investment gains of $1,600,000 for the quarter and $27,000,000 for the year. c-After realized investment losses of $3,900,000 for the quarter and $30,200,000 for the year.

title: The President's Trick Candles Once again, it was skillful theater. Fresh from his starring role in the second Inaugural, President Reagan brought some unusual guests to his fourth State of the Union address. His Administration has done nothing to deserve credit for the achievements of Jean Nguyen, a Vietnamese refugee girl about to graduate from West Point, or Clara Hale, who cares for the babies of addicts in Harlem. But he is entitled to credit for giving them, and what they represent,
description: respect.

title: Killer Found Hanged in Cell
description: A death row inmate, convicted in the 1984 slayings of a man and a woman, died Wednesday after apparently hanging himself in his cell, a prison spokesman said. The prisoner, Allan Wayne Tucker, 23 years old, had fashioned a noose from a sheet and was found hanging from a heating vent in the rear of his cell about 3:45 A.M., said Vernon Bradford, state Department of Corrections spokesman. Mr. Tucker was pronounced dead at the scene by a prison doctor and his body was taken to Alachua General Hospital in Gainesville for an autopsy, Mr. Bradford said.

title: MASCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1984 results include the restatement for a company acquired on a pooling of interest basis.

title: ISLANDERS WIN ON 4-GOAL RALLY
description: The Rangers should be shuddering and the Islanders should be relieved. But at this point in a mixed-up hockey season, their emotions are flipflopped.

title: COMPUTER PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
AROUND THE WORLD ;   U.N. Says It Assured U.S. on Population Aid
description: The United States has been assured that none of its funds for United Nations-aided population programs would be used for abortions, a high United Nations official said today.

title: CORRUPTION CAMPAIGN IN SOVIET TAKES ITS TOLL
description: Writing home from a labor camp recently, a young man convicted of draft evasion sent his parents a recipe for preserved tomatoes given him by the manager of a leading Moscow restaurant. The secret, he wrote, is in the vegetable oil.

title: FOR FANS OF THE BLUES, LIFE IS ROSY IN NEW YORK
description: NEW YORK blues fans have been lucky this winter; a dozen first-rate Southern musicians have braved the north winds. The streak continues Sunday night when three soloists and a duo bring Mississippi Delta blues and East Coast Piedmont blues to the new auditorium of the Borough of Manhattan Community College.

title: Outbreak of Hepatitis Linked to Indiana Dentist
description: An Indiana dentist was responsible for transmitting hepatitis to eight of his patients, two of whom died, Federal health officials said today.

title: Dr. Clement Vose, 61, Professor at Wesleyan
description: Dr. Clement E. Vose, the John E. Andrus Professor of Government at Wesleyan University and a scholar of constitutional law, died of a stroke Jan. 28 at the Veterans Administration Medical Center in San Juan, P.R. He was 61 years old and lived in Middletown, Conn.

title: 'GREAT ICE TIME' IN THE PARK
description: For all of them the common denominator is the ice. Early every Saturday and Sunday morning from the latter part of November to the last week of February the hockey players and the figure skaters begin arriving at the Lula D. Lasker Rink in upper Central Park well before it opens to the public.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The President has given the tax debate a new sense of urgency.'' - Senator Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jersey. (A21:2.)

title: Landlord Indicted In Harassment
description: A landlord was indicted yesterday on charges of conspiring to terrorize and force tenants out of two apartment houses on the Upper East Side in order to convert them into luxury dwellings.

title: N.Y. PHILHARMONIC: JESSYE NORMAN SINGS BERG
description: A COMPOSER'S mature masterpieces shed their light and grace on his entire output. If Telemann, say, had left one towering, imperishable work, we would be happy to plow through his many hundreds of minor efforts in the conviction that they would tell us something valuable about his progress toward immortality. Unfortunately, not many composers are able to put us to such effort. Most, like Telemann, let us off easy.

title: Laurence, Charles Gets New Del Account
description: Laurence, Charles & Free, one of the Mickelberry companies, has received an additional assignment from Del Laboratories, Farmingdale, L.I. It is for Quencher Cosmetics, which the client acquired in December from Chattem Inc. of Chattanooga, Tenn.

title: PUBLISHING: A NEW BOOK ON INVASION OF IWO JIMA
description: BILL D. ROSS has had hundreds of bylines since he went to work 45 years ago on a weekly newspaper in Cherokee, Iowa. But he will become a book author for the first time on Feb. 19, the 40th anniversary of the invasion of Iwo Jima, when Vanguard Press publishes his ''Iwo Jima: Legacy of Valor.''

title: Olympic Skater Wins in Sweden
description: Katarina Witt of East Germany, the Olympic champion, won the women's title at the European Ice Figure Skating championships Thursday for the third successive year.

title: Aitken to Lead Flute-In And Play a Solo Recital
description: Flute recitals were once rare, but Jean-Pierre Rampal has changed all that.

title: PUERTO RICO PANEL TO SEEK CAUSE OF PREMATURE SEXUAL DVELOPMENT
description: After two years of controversy, Puerto Rico's new Secretary of Health has named a panel to seek the possible causes of premature sexual development in young girls, a condition that can result in stunted growth.

title: PENTAIR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
U.S. Abstains in Vote On Loan for Chileans
description: The United States delegate, Juan Manuel Casanova, abstained from voting today when the board of the Inter-American Development Bank voted a loan of $130 million to help small businesses in Chile.

title: KEEP THE RUSSIANS FROM THE MIDEAST
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz reportedly has assured Israeli Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin that despite scheduled U.S.-Soviet talks on the Middle East, the U.S. remains opposed to an international conference in which the Soviet Union would participate.

title: By John Gross;
description: FRAGRANCE: The Story of Perfume

title: JERSEY RITE OPENS THE POLITICAL SEASON
description: Almost 1,800 New Jersey business and government leaders rode a special train to the nation's capital today in an annual rite that signals the start of the state's political season.

title: FORMER OFFICIALS CALL ARMS BUDGET 'UNBALANCED'
description: President Reagan's military budget is ''bloated and unbalanced,'' lavishing money on nuclear weapons and the Navy ''at the expense of nearly everything else,'' a group of former Defense Department officials associated with Democratic administrations said today.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: Opera singers are said to eat sparingly before a performance and heartily after the last curtain call, but as the line goes in Gershwin's ''Porgy and Bess,'' which had its premiere at the Metropolitan Opera Wednesday night, it ain't necessarily so.

title: Walk Into Shape
description: Horses aren't the only ones that get trained into shape at race tracks.

title: RONALD REAGAN, GARDENER OF THE GOVERMENT
description: When President Reagan sent his 1986 budget to Congress this week, most of the attention focused on new proposals to cut spending and abolish Government programs.

title: BAY STATE GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Net income reflects reductions equal to 60 cents a share for the latest year and 87 cents a share for the previous year after asset writedowns of the company's Bay State Exploration Inc. subsidiary.

title: KERR-MCGEE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income. Results reflect charges of $88 million for the latest fourth quarter and $26 million for the year-ago foruth quarter.

title: SOFTWARE PIRACY FROM A HOSPITAL CHARGED ON L.I.
description: A former official at University Hospital in Stony Brook, L.I., was indicted yesterday on charges that he had unlawfully duplicated the hospital's $300,000 computer software system and sold a copy of it to a hospital in Philadelphia.

title: ART: THE PAINTINGS OF JOHN ALEXANDER
description: JOHN ALEXANDER is one of the few younger artists with the will and the credibility to remind the young turks of Neo-Expressionism what solid pictorial structure and art-historical knowledge mean. The work of this Texas-born artist, who lives in New York, both speaks the language of current Expressionist painting and remains at a distance from it. Alexander has a passion for paint, and he is heavily dependent upon line. His paintings are also large and filled with floating animals, skulls and ghostly, graffitilike heads.

title: Supervisor Pleads Guilty in Accident
description: A Town Supervisor from upstate New York has pleaded guilty to a charge of driving while intoxicated in connection with an accident that killed a pedestrian last year.

title: CITY LEADERSHIP URGING PRESSURE ON SOUTH AFRICA
description: Depositing municipal funds in banks that do business with the South African Government would be prohibited under legislation introduced yesterday in the City Council.

title: Federal Reserve All data in millions of dollars
description: LatestPreviousYearWeekWeekAgo

title: THE SCREEN: 'FAVORITES OF THE MOON'
description: ''FAVORITES OF THE MOON,'' which comes to us as the winner of the 1984 Venice Film Festival jury's grand prize, is the kind of absurdist comedy that one either takes to immediately or finds insufferably arch, which is pretty much the way I feel about it. You can laugh with it, if you're willing to believe that the film makers are as witty as they keep announcing without demonstrating, or you can be awestruck by the amount of care, money and talent that appear to have been spent for so little effect.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article by The Associated Press in Business Day on Wednesday about MTV Networks Inc. misstated the company's revenues for 1983 and 1984. They were $109.5 million last year and $49.8 million in 1983.

title: Swiss Prices Up 3.5%
description: The cost of living in Switzerland rose 3.5 percent during the year ending Jan. 31, the highest 12-month inflation rate in nearly two years, the Federal Office of Industry, Trade and Labor said today. Prices were up 1 percent from December, the office said.

title: NEW BRUNSWICK PREMIER IS UNDER FIRE AGAIN
description: The Premier of New Brunswick, acquitted a week ago of marijuana possession charges, has become embroiled in a new dispute involving drugs.

title: NATIONAL FUEL GAS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The share earnings restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in May 1984 and a 10 percent stock dividend in June 1984.

title: Transactions
description: WEDNESDAY BASEBALL

title: WOMEN'S HOME OUSTING OLD-TIMERS
description: For five years, the St. Mary's Residence for Working Girls has been home for Harriet Lee Boiko - a 51- year-old divorced secretary who earns $16,000 a year.

title: Advertising;   A Marketing Critique
description: At some point during the breakfast speech yesterday by Alvin A. Achenbaum, his hosts must have wished they could buy back the invitation. Because there he was, a respected marketing consultant and former senior executive at both Grey Advertising and J. Walter Thompson, denouncing and demolishing just about all the currently popular marketing practices. And before members of the American Marketing Association New York Chapter, to boot.

title: PRIEST AND 2 MEN KILLED IN CHURCH
description: A man upset that girls had read aloud from Scripture at a special children's mass opened fire with a shotgun in a Roman Catholic church here today, killing a praying priest, a janitor and a parishioner.

title: BANK IN BOSTON FINED ON SHIFTS IN CASH ABROAD
description: The First National Bank of Boston pleaded guilty in Federal District Court here today to failing to report $1.2 billion in cash transfers with Swiss banks and was fined $500,000.

title: TOLL IN BULGARIA'S TURKISH UNREST IS PUT AT 100
description: Security forces are reported to have killed as many as 100 ethnic Turks, during roundups to force them to adopt Bulgarian names.

title: 10 STATES FACE FLU EPIDEMICS
description: Epidemic levels of influenza were reported in at least 10 states today while the death toll from flu and pneumonia continued to rise in 121 major cities in the United States.

title: Family Media Inc.
description: Family Media Inc., a closely held publisher, said that it had purchased Savvy magazine.

title: Jackson's Lungs Are Cleared
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson was reported to be resting comfortably after doctors removed a blockage of mucus from his lungs in a nonsurgical procedure this morning. He is being treated at Howard University Hospital for bronchitis and pneumonia.

title: Merengue Festival
description: The annual Festival del Merengue, featuring bands from New York and the Dominican Republic, will take place tomorrow at 7 P.M. and Sunday at 2 and 7 at the Felt Forum, Eighth Avenue at 34th Street.

title: U.S. CITES CONTINUED DROP IN UNION MEMBERSHIP
description: The Federal Government has issued new statistics that document the belief that organized labor's membership continues to decline in number.

title: UNITED ENERGY RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a writedown of $48,000,000 on oil and gas properties of Cotton Petroleum Corp. c-After writedowns on oil and gas properties of Cotton Petroleum Corp. of $38,000,000 for the quarter and $73,000,000 for the year.

title: MANVILLE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income. c-After a gain of $7,068,000 from discontinued operations.

title: A Trusty Solution ;   To Probation Problem
description: To the Editor:

title: CLUB MED'S BIG PLANS IN U.S.
description: The image of scantily clad vacationers frolicking on secluded beaches in exotic locales has become almost synonymous with Club Mediterranee. The 11th-largest hotel chain in the world, which bills itself as ''an antidote for civilization,'' now wants to move a little closer to home - home, that is, for North American and Asian tourists.

title: Career's End
description: A day after undergoing spinal fusion surgery at a Minneapolis hospital,

title: New West Side Paper
description: The West Side Spirit is to make its

title: FILM: 'WITNESS,' A TOUGH GUY AMONG THE AMISH
description: ''WITNESS,'' which opens today at the Astor Plaza and other theaters, is the story of John Book (Harrison Ford), a tough, gun-toting Philadelphia narcotics detective who, to escape his own murder by fellow detectives with connections to the drug trade, must hide out with Amish farmers in Pennsylvania Dutch country.

title: CALIFORNIA REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including a capital gain of $1,852,000, or 65 cents a share, for the quarter and a gain on the sale of real estate investments of $2,660,000, or 94 cents a share, for the year. c-Including a gain of $1,088,000, or 45 cents a share, on the sale of investments.

title: BRIDGE: TWO OF 1985'S MAJOR EVEVTS OVERLAPPING ON THE SCHEDULE
description: Officials on three continents are wrestling with the worst scheduling confusion in the history of the game.

title: Shadowboxing Down Under
description: New Zealand's Prime Minister Lange has a problem: A lot of his voters believe the only good nukes are no nukes. The same problem besets Prime Minister Hawke of Australia, also the leader of a Labor Party with a strong anti-nuclear flank. Both want to placate that sentiment without disavowing the 1951 Anzus defense pact with the United States. The result has been diplomatic shadowboxing in which real interests can be hurt if Washington responds to a feint with a punch.

title: BUSINESS REVIEWS THE BUDGET
description: The budget that President Reagan sent to Congress Tuesday called for the lowest rate of growth in spending in 20 years, but still totaled a record $973.7 billion. Mr. Reagan is proposing to eliminate more than 25 social programs while scaling back spending in many others. If enacted, the President's program would lead to total nonmilitary spending reductions exceeding $38 billion in the fiscal year 1986 alone.

title: BRIEFS
description: Communications Satellite Corp. and Turner Broadcasting System Inc. said Comsat would carry Cable News Network to Europe, beginning Sept. 15.

title: WOMEN ARE CLEARED FOR DUTY ON MISSILE LAUNCHING CREWS
description: The Air Force has decided that women can serve in underground bunkers as launching control officers for its most advanced strategic nuclear missiles, but only on crews with other women.

title: ALLIED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $1 million for the quarter and year. c-Net loss. d-After losses from discontinued operations of $351 million for the quarter and $389 million for the year, a credit of $39 million for the year from an accounting change and income of $26 million, or 32 cents a share, for the quarter and $47 million, or 61 cents a share, for the year on equity in earnings of Martin Marietta and gains on the sale of Martin Marietta stock in the third and fourth quarters of 1983.

title: Season Maker
description: It has been almost two months since the Niagara University basketball team upset St. John's, 62-59, at the Niagara Falls Convention Center, but the memories linger on for the Purple Eagles. A five-game winning streak has lifted their record to a ho- hum 13-8, but they remain conscious that the embarrassing defeat they inflicted on the Redmen is the only loss suffered this season by the No. 1 team in the nation.

title: REAGAN BUDGET WOULD CUT FUNDS FOR INVESTIGATIONS OF U.S. WASTE
description: The Reagan Administration, which has often declared war on ''waste, fraud and abuse'' in the Federal Government, is proposing to reduce the size of most of the bodies investigating such problems.

title: BELL & HOWELL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $615,000 for the quarter and $7,215,000 for the 9 months and income from discontinued operations of $9,342,000 for the 9 months.

title: HOME FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN(ATLANTA) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Ford Car to Have Four-Wheel Drive
description: The Ford Motor Company plans to introduce a four-wheel-drive version of its Mercury Topaz subcompact in about a year, officials of the company said today. And they said other models with four-wheel drive might follow.

title: Town Settles Lawsuit Over Fatal Car Accident
description: A woman who sued this town for negligence in the deaths of her husband and daughter, who were killed in a car crash with a driver she contended was drunk, will get $237,500 in an out-of- court settlement, officials said today.

title: Jobless Claims Up by 3,000
description: First-time claims for unemployment compensation rose to 394,000 for the week ended Jan. 26, up 3,000 from the previous week, the Labor Department reported today. The total number of people collecting jobless benefits under state programs was 2,504,000 for the week ended Jan. 19, down 36,000 from the previous week's 2,540,000, the department's Employment and Training Administration said. The figures are adjusted for seasonal variations.

title: Trombone at Carnegie
description: The trombonist Craig Harris will lead a group in new compositions tomorrow at 8:30 P.M. at Carnegie Recital Hall, 154 West 57th Street, as part of the hall's new-jazz series. Tickets are $10 through Carnegie Charge, 247-7800.

title: Debt
description: Boston Financial Ltd. of Australia has signed an agreement to issue $50 million, in U.S. currency, of two-year Euronotes in Hong Kong, through underwriters led by BT Asia.

title: Nassau Executive Seeks Re-election
description: Francis T. Purcell, as expected, today formally announced his candidacy for re-election to a third four-year term as Nassau County Executive.

description: Dr. Vera D. Rubin, an anthropologist and the director of the Research Institute for the Study of Man, died yesterday at her home in Manhattan. She was 73 years old.

title: COMPUTER IMPORTS SOUGHT BY SOVIETS
description: The Soviet Union is negotiating to buy large numbers of Western-made personal computers, including Apple and I.B.M. models, according to industry sources.

EXPRESS FIND BONUS IN SELLING TO N.F.L.
description: In an effort to ease its financial strain, the Los Angeles Express of the United States Football League gave permission to an agent representing three Express players to pursue contracts for them with National Football League clubs.

title: Great Northern Modernization
description: Robert F. Bartlett, president of the Great Northern Paper Company, said the company planned a $155 million modernization of its East Millinocket newsprint mill.

title: MAJOR ISSUE IS RESOLVED ON BUS-SHELTER CONTRACT
description: The major obstacle to the construction of the first new bus-stop shelters in nearly a decade was cleared away yesterday when a contractor provided the city with $13.6 million in financial guarantees.

title: Delayed Space Flight Is Now Set for March 3
description: The next space shuttle flight, with Senator Jake Garn aboard, will be launched March 3, 11 days late because of troublesome thermal tiles, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced today.

title: SHARED MEDICAL SYSTEMS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Money Fund Assets Decline Assets of the nation's money
description: market mutual funds fell $867

title: Yankees Relive Good Old Days
description: George Steinbrenner insists he looks more like Butch Cassidy, but the principal owner of the Yankees is meant to resemble Jacob Ruppert, the Yankee owner from 1915 to 1939 in a color photo on the cover of The Sporting News this week.

title: 'Poison Ivy' TV Film, Summer Camp Revisited
description: Eight weeks of summer camp will be transformed into two hours of tedium Sunday night at 9, when Channel 4 broadcasts a made-for-television movie titled ''Poison Ivy.''

description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given.

title: GITOU KNOOP
description: Gitou Knoop, an abstract sculptor well known in the New York art world, died of a heart attack on Thursday in Paris. She was 75 years old.

title: FOUNDED THE JAGUAR CONCERN
description: Sir William Lyons, the founder of Jaguar Cars Ltd., died in his sleep this morning at his home near Leamington Spa in Warwickshire. He was 83 years old and had been in poor health for several years.

description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $47,000 from the closing of a store. c-Net income.

title: MAIN STREET TURNS OUT FOR LEWIS CENTENNIAL
description: Phyllis Olson played the piano. Kathy Lieser baked a cake. Joe Kiselewski couldn't make it because of a bad cold. But Mary Hanson came out, even with all the sidewalk ice. The postmaster was there, and Jeanine Wolbeck. And Al Tingley and Dave Jacobson seemed to get along for once.

title: WALTERS, LONGTIME DIPLOMAT, GETS KIRKPATRICK POST AT U.N.
description: Gen. Vernon A. Walters, an experienced envoy and former Central Intelligence Agency official, was nominated by President Reagan today to succeed Jeane J. Kirkpatrick as chief United States delegate to the United Nations.

title: U.S. Lease Ban Ends For Kuwait
description: The Interior Department, reversing a two- year-old ruling of former Secretary James G. Watt, has decided to make Kuwait eligible to acquire mineral leases on Federal lands, ending a dispute that has troubled relations between the two Governments.

title: Con Ed Urges Phasing Out a Hidden Tax
description: To the Editor:

title: CHESS TITLE GAME ADJOURNED
description: The 48th game of the world chess championship match was adjourned today with the challenger, Gary Kasparov, having what chess experts described as good winning chances.

title: STATE BACKS LODGING PLAN FOR HOMELESS
description: An experimental plan to place homeless families in New York City in private homes has received the tentative backing of the State Commissioner of Social Services.

title: Killings in El Salvador Said to Be on the Rise
description: After a lull of almost a year, political assassinations by extremist groups are on the rise again in El Salvador, according to the human rights office of the Roman Catholic Church and United States officials.

title: Corporate Free Ride
description: To the Editor:

title: City Reportedly Seeking N.F.L. Cardinals for Shea
description: The St. Louis Cardinals and New York City are exploring the possibility of the team's moving here, according to a source familiar with the city's search to find a team to replace the Jets, who moved to Giants Stadium last season.

title: TIES WITH U.S. STILL SOUND, NEW ZEALAND LEADER SAYS
description: Prime Minister David Lange said today that President Reagan's statement that he still considered New Zealand a friend after an American ship was refused a port call indicated that the military cooperation between the two countries was not dead.

title: WEST VIRGINIA'S KANAWHA VALLEY CALLED LAX ON POLLUTION PERIL
description: Toxic air pollution and other environmental threats to public health are inadequately addressed in West Virginia's Kanawha Valley, a report by the Environmental Protection Agency says.

title: PHILADELPHIA SUBURBAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
No Headline
description: Almost everyone knows someone who does a recognizable impression of Marv Albert, the ubiquitous sports announcer whose descriptions of basketball, hockey, boxing and pro football have been filling airwaves for two decades. Albert constantly has people collaring him to display their impressions of his play-by-play technique.

title: SOME FILIPINOS SEE '87 VOTE THIS YEAR
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos has said that the next presidential election will be held 1987, but recent actions by opposition and ruling party politicians alike suggest that some of them think this could be an election year in the Philippines.

title: New Japanese Envoy Due
description: Yoshio Okawara, the Japanese Ambassador. is leaving his post in mid-March and retiring after serving for 42 years in his country's diplomatic corps.

title: O'Meara Gains Tie In Hawaiian Open;    North Is Co-Leader
description: Mark O'Meara, winner of last week's Bing Crosby National Pro-Am, took advantage of ideal playing conditions for a 6-under-par 66 that put him into a tie for the second-round lead today in the $500,000 Hawaiian Open.

title: CUOMO CHIDED BY HEAD OF BOTTLE-DEPOSIT PANEL
description: The chairman of the commission overseeing the state's bottle-deposit law accused Governor Cuomo today of intimidating the panel by making statements that put undue pressure on it.

title: TRIANGLE PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Cardiff-Conwed
description: The Conwed Corporation said its board had approved a sweetened tender offer from Cardiff Acquisitions Inc. The offer was valued at $28.50 a share, or about $35.1 million. Last November, Conwed, which makes ceiling products and office furniture, rejected a $21.50-a-share unsolicited bid from Cardiff as inadequate. Cardiff, a unit of the Leucadia National Corporation, already owns 25.7 percent of Conwed.

title: Happy 39th 35 Times
description: President Reagan's ''White House News Summary'' Wednesday, his 74th birthday, had a caricature of him by Jim Borgman of The Cincinnati Enquirer. He responded in kind to the Summary staff.

title: Ecuador Cuts Oil Price
description: Ecuador's oil ministry announced a $1 cut in oil prices today, saying its oil would now be sold at $26.50 a barrel on long-term contracts. Ecuador had been charging $27.50 a barrel since March 1983. Official figures show crude contract sales by Ecuador, a minor member of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, have fallen to 94,000 barrels a day, from 141,000 last November.

title: GIBSON, C. R. CO.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Foul in Seoul
description: Whatever happened at Seoul's airport, they weren't exactly throwing posies yesterday when the exiled Kim Dae Jung returned to South Korea. The country's best-known opposition leader was hustled away from the Americans who accompanied him, and they in turn were roughed up by security police. So with the whole world watching, South Korea's military regime bared its fists in an inexcusable and juvenile show of pugilism.

title: THEATER: 'CLIFFHANGER' BY JAMES YAFFE
description: Cliffhanger,'' James Yaffe's new play at the Lamb's Theater, would appear to have the necessary ingredients for a thriller. It takes place in a lonely house in the Rockies. The hero is an idealistic, elderly professor of philosophy pushed past the point of ethical behavior. The central subject is academic rivalry. But the mystery is cozy when it should be threatening.

title: STORAGE EQUITIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PHILLIPS, ICAHN ARGUE ON NOTE PLAN
description: A major Wall Street battle broke out yesterday between the Phillips Petroleum Company and Carl C. Icahn, its unwanted suitor, over whether Mr. Icahn could profit from a defensive tactic intended to deter him.

title: NUCLEAR AGENCY HEARS DISPUTES OVER SHOREHAM
description: Lawyers for New York State and Suffolk County clashed today with representatives of the Long Island Lighting Company over its application for a low-power operating license for the Shoreham nuclear plant.

title: Sabovcik Wins Skating Crown
description: Jozef Sabovcik of Czechoslovakia, the bronze medalist at last year's Winter Olympics, won the men's title at the European figure skating championships today. He did so despite falling on his opening jump the triple axel, and being outskated in the free-skating program by Vladimir Kotin of the Soviet Union .

title: Cosmos Defeated
description: Helmut Dudek scored three goals to lead the Las Vegas Americans to a 12-3 romp over the Cosmos tonight in a Major Indoor Soccer League game.

title: STATES' STUDY DISPUTES ADMINISTRATION ON SURPLUS
description: Most states have at best a marginal surplus and at least 17 are likely to raise taxes this year to make ends meet, according to a survey released today by the National Governors Association.

title: MAYOR BACKS JURY ON GOETZ: QUESTIONS ACTION ON OFFICER
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that he agreed with the grand jury that refused to indict Bernhard H. Goetz for attempted murder and disagreed with the grand jury that indicted a police officer for manslaughter in the Eleanor Bumpurs case.

title: REMATCH AT END OF COMEBACK TRAIL
description: Gulfstream Park is billing the Donn Handicap here Saturday as more of a prizefight than a horse race. A press release says that Time for a Change and Dr. Carter ''will renew their storied hostilities'' in the mile-and-an-eighth race. The track is calling the race ''The Great Rematch'' and has fashioned an ad that looks like a boxing poster, with a picture of the two pugilists snout to snout. You can almost hear Dr. Carter calling his opponent ''a chestnut- livered son of a Damascus'' and Time for a Change calling his gray rival ''a whale with a glass ankle.''

description: The visit to Washington this week

title: Town Would Recognize Domestic Partnerships
description: An ordinance that would recognize domestic partnerships between unmarried people has been tentatively approved by unanimous vote of the City Council in this city formed last November.

title: THE BEANPOT RUNNETH OVER WITH UPSETS AND SOCIALIZING
description: Things haven't gone quite the way they were supposed to at the 33d Beanpot tournament.

title: IN BROOKLYN
description: That the name of Long Island attaches to so many things in Brooklyn is evidence of the fact that Brooklyn is indeed part of Long Island, and this can be seen with the Long Island Historical Society, which is awaiting approval to change the name it has held since 1863 to the Brooklyn Historical Society.

title: LONE STAR FACING CHALLENGES AND INDEPENDENCE
description: When the oil and gas business went into decline several years ago, the Lone Star Steel Company, the nation's market leader in the production of welded steel pipe for the industry, suffered severely.

description: Federal investigators looking into an incident involving the takeoff of a Continental Airlines plane at New York's La Guardia Airport last month photographed damage marks yesterday on a dike off the end of the runway used by the plane.

title: N.H.L.
description: Bob Carpenter scored two goals, tying the National Hockey League record for most goals by an American-born player in a single season, as the Washington Capitals routed the Los Angeles Kings, 6-1, tonight.

title: HOMELESS PROMPT AID TO NEEDIEST
description: The plight of the homeless is stressed by many donors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, expecially in these times of harsh weather.

title: 'SBLOOD! STILL FEUDING OVER THE BARD
description: Shakespeare's plays are palpable hits this season in London and Washington (the Royal Shakespeare Company is performing there after a successful Broadway run), and the latest BBC versions are being shown on public television in the United States. Yet Shakespeare scholars are still dueling on both sides of the Atlantic. In broadsides, lectures and books, they are advancing new myths and old theories, including that hoary question: How could a scantily educated small-town actor write the greatest works in the English language?

Methods to Improve And Repress Appetite
description: A method of regulating appetite and the efficiency of food utilization, invented for the Texas A & M University System, at College Station, employs interferon. Joseph M. Cummins, a faculty member, obtained patent 4,497,795 this week.

title: REAGAN DEFENDS MILITARY PENSIONS
description: Telling an anecdote about a military officer's hardships, President Reagan has disagreed with an assertion by the budget director, David A. Stockman, that military pensions are a ''scandal.''

title: BRIEFS

title: Vermont Drops Abuse Case
description: Attorney General Jeffrey Amestoy has decided not to appeal a judge's dismissal of the last three child abuse petitions from Vermont's ill-fated raid on an Island Pond religious sect, where no witnesses came forth. However Mr. Amestoy said today that prosecutors would continue to press simple assault charges against Charles Wiseman, an elder of the sect, the Northeast Kingdom Community Church, who is accused of beating a 13-year-old girl intermittently for seven hours.

title: SLEEPY FACE BELIES THE INTRIGUE IN A KENYA RESORT
description: A sunny somnolence seems to ooze through this coastal town like spilled honey, blending gently with a good-natured eccentricity that has moved some visitors to call this area the Southern California of Kenya.

title: PRETORIA'S NEW TIES WITH BLACK NEIGHBORS SOUR
description: In marked contrast to a euphoric mood in this region less than a year ago, South Africa's relations with neighboring black-governed nations appears to have soured.

title: Chernenko's Physician Says Leader Is 'Well'
description: Konstantin U. Chernenko's personal physician said today that the Soviet leader was ''well'' despite worldwide speculation that the Soviet leader is seriously ill.

title: Party Chief Going South
description: Paul G. Kirk Jr., the new chairman of the Democratic National Committee, plans to go south to bind up the party's wounds. Mr. Kirk, a former aide to Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, is said to be determined to end the estrangement from the national party that some Southern Democrats have felt in recent years. Mr. Kirk wants to confer with Southern state party chairmen, governors, state legislators and former President Jimmy Carter in Atlanta late next week.

title: Coach to Step Down
description: Joe Mullaney, the Providence College basketball coach whose team has been struggling with a 9-12 record, said he would step down at the end of the season but would keep his post as associate athletic director. In announcing his decision, Mullaney said he had not been pressured by Providence officials, but he did not mention Providence fans, who have been vociferous in expressing their disappointment over the team's showing.

title: KOREAN DISSIDENT IS TOLD TO REMAIN INSIDE HIS HOUSE
description: Kim Dae Jung, South Korea's leading dissident politician, was confined to his house here today as a dispute swelled over a roughing-up that he and supporters suffered at the hands of the police when he returned home from exile in the United States.

title:
THIS GOVERNMENT IS OFF OUR BACKS?;

'BABY DOE' MAY BE UNDONE
description: -ON-HUDSON, N.Y. - The Baby Doe amendment, an intelligent compromise in the controversy over treatment of premature and severely handicapped newborns, is about to be overridden by ideologues in the Reagan Administration.

title: Verdict on Jersey Woman Is Due Feb. 27 in Nigeria
description: The verdict in the case involving Marie McBroom, a New Jersey woman facing death by firing squad if convicted of illegally trafficking in oil, will be handed down Feb. 27, a special military tribunal announced.

title: Studds Leads Panel Again
description: Representative Gerry E. Studds, Democrat of Massachusetts, today regained the chairmanship of the House Coast Guard and Navigation Subcommittee. Mr. Studds, who lost the post when the House censured him in July 1983 for a homosexual relationship with a 17- year-old page 10 years earlier, pledged to protect the Coast Guard from proposed budget reductions.

It in fact uses pink and yellow gingham and flowered chintzes in such strictly North American styles as shirts, boxer shorts and clamdiggers.

title: Register to Sell Honolulu TV Unit
description: The Des Moines Register and Tribune Company has agreed to sell its Honolulu television station, NBC affiliate KHON, to the Burnham Broadcasting Company of Chicago. The sale of KHON is expected to be closed this summer as liquidation of the Register and Tribune Company continues.

title: Downed Power Lines Halt L.I.R.R. Service
description: Three downed electrical power poles halted service on the Long Island Rail Road last night between Freeport and Wantagh and caused delays of up to an hour and a half on the South Shore line that runs from Pennsylvania Station to Montauk.

title: Scott Doesn't Fear Coghlan
description: Steve Scott has run the mile in six indoor track meets this winter, finishing second, fourth, fifth, second, second and first. He has run against Eamonn Coghlan in four of those races and has lost every time, once by a hundredth of a second and once by eight-hundredths of a second.

title: HIGH-TECH VALENTINE CARDS

description: The trial of two bellmen charged with selling David Kennedy cocaine that was part of an overdose of drugs that killed him has been delayed, partly because of an investigation into possible tampering with evidence.

title:

description: Congress has approved legislation that declares that a local school district implementing a desegregation plan shall not be eligible for Federal monies if ''secular humanism'' is taught in its classrooms. ''Secular humanism'' is not defined in the legislation, and the districts are responsible for determining whether they are teaching it.

description: The Defense Department said today that it was investigating an admiral's attempt to bring Soviet-made rifles back from Grenada as souvenirs. Another inquiry is reportedly being conducted to see if lower-ranking servicemen sentenced in arms cases were treated fairly.

title: CBS TURNING CAMERAS ON ITS DECISION-MAKERS
description: CBS has been turning the television camera on itself lately and finding the task is not an easy one. The network has hired a documentary film maker, Tom Spain, to take a cinema-verite peek inside the network's conference rooms and corner offices ''to capture on film some of the way our business works,'' said George Schweitzer, vice president for communications for the CBS Broadcast Group. The film is not intended for broadcast; rather, it is to be shown to CBS's affiliated stations, community groups and other interested parties.

title:
Patents ;

Plating Speeded By Laser
description: WASHINGTONStaff scientists at the International Business Machines Corporation were granted a patent this week for a technique that uses a laser beam to deposit very fine lines or spots of gold or other metal on a metal base. Gold can be deposited 20 times faster than by previous methods.

title: THE VERDICT IN POLAND
description: The trial of four security policemen for the murder of a pro-Solidarity priest has ended with all sentenced to long prison terms and with the Government asserting that justice was served and full public disclosure made. But on the streets and in the coffeehouses, many Poles have been openly critical of the prison sentence handed down to the key figure. They say they feel that Grzegorz Piotrowski, the leader of the mission that stalked the Rev. Jerzy Popieluszko, should have been given a death sentence, which could then have been commuted. Instead, he was sentenced to 25 years in prison.

title: MAN WHO DROVE ON SIDEWALK GUILTY OF MURDER AND ASSAULT
description: A man who drove a speeding automobile down a crowded sidewalk here in July, killing a tourist from New York and injuring dozens of other pedestrians, was convicted today of first-degree murder and 48 counts of attempted murder.

Even when they try to learn a foreign tongue, he continued, they suffer because they do not have the Slavs' ear for languages.

And sadly, the performance of President Fernando Belaunde Terry was just as predictably negative.

The 40-year-old right-hander spent last season with the Chicago White Sox, where the American League's designated hitter rule kept him out of the batter's box after 17 bat-swinging National League seasons with the Mets and the Cincinnati Reds.

Among the facts that must be included in this statement is a table showing the buyer how $1,000 a year deposited in an account will multiply up to age 70 at the rate of interest being offered, depending on his or her age.

Results for the latest quarter include sales of wind energy facilities by the company's Tera Power Corp. subsidiary.

description: Stock prices rose modestly yesterday, but despite a few attempts the Dow Jones industrial average failed to break its record.

description: Speculation that the Belzberg brothers of Canada would try to acquire Safeway Stores Inc. pushed Safeway stock up sharply in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, traders said.

description: French researchers reported yesterday that a new drug appeared for the first time to have inhibited reproduction of the virus believed to cause acquired immunity deficiency syndrome, or AIDS.

title: D'AMATO CALLS PROPOSAL ON SENTENCING A SHAM
description: Proposed sentencing guidelines are ''a mockery and a sham'' and fail to deal with criminal cases like the 1982 rampage of rape and violence at a Long Island diner, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato testified today.

description: A senior Treasury Department official said today that the large flow of United States dollars in cash between Switzerland and the First National Bank of Boston resembled a classic money-laundering operation.

Net income for the year-ago quarter included a nonrecurring gain of 16 cents a share from favorable adjustments, of which 11 cents resulted from the settlement of tax issues relating to discontinued operations.

title: MIXUP FATAL TO BABY STUDIED AT FEDERAL CLINIC
description: A 20- month-old boy being treated at the research hospital run by the National Institutes of Health died last month after hospital personnel gave him an intravenous solution containing an excessive amount of salt, an official said today.

description: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said today that it had asked the General Motors Corporation to recall more than 1.7 million A-cars because of ''significant safety problems'' involving rear brake lockups.

description: For years, Robert B. Claytor, the chairman and chief executive of the Norfolk Southern Corporation, has been seeking ways to keep pace with his major rival, the CSX Corporation.

title: Times-Mirror
description: The Times-Mirror Company said it was discussing the possible sale of its newsprint and forest products operations to the Boise Cascade Corporation. Mark Schwanbeck, a Times- Mirror spokesman, which lists The Los Angeles Times, The Denver Post and The Dallas Times Herald among its holdings, said the discussions represented ''part of an asset re-allocation program,'' intended to concentrate the company's efforts in the communications industry. At the end of 1983, the newsprint and forest products unit had assets of $471.2 million.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary yesterday of Dr. Vera D. Rubin, an anthropologist who was director of the Research Institute for the Study of Man, misstated the date of a memorial service. It will be held Feb. 23 at 2 P.M. at Teachers College of Columbia University.

title: AIR MIDWEST INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SHOT FROM 92 FEET IS CALLED A RECORD
description: It was a desperation heave, a one-in-a million toss. The basket by Bruce Morris from just over 92 feet still had the Marshall University campus buzzing today.

title: FORMER GUARD AT INDIAN POINT FILES SUIT
description: JOSEPH M. CORRIGAN, a 25-year-old Carmel resident, says he blew the whistle on Indian Point and that that was what got him dismissed as a security officer there two years ago. His ''crusade,'' as he calls it, led him to criticize nuclear-plant safety at a public hearing in July 1982, while employed at the Indian Point 3 nuclear facility in Buchanan. For that, he says, his superiors called him on the carpet and subsequently dismissed him. Since then, he has written to Prisident Reagan and to the Nuclear Regulatory Commission about his case and has initiated a suit in State Supreme Court in Putnam County for damages against his former employer and two plant unions - Local 1- of the Utility Workers of America and the Nuclear Security Officers Benevolent Association - claiming that they disregarded his rights and that the unions had failed to institute grievances on his behalf. No hearing date has been set. The former employee, the New York Power Authority, says Mr. Corrigan was dismissed on Jan. 10, 1983, for not showing up for work on three occasions, not because of his views on security matters. Mr. Corrigan, who charges that the authority's case was ''manufactured against me to have me removed,'' compares himself to Karen Silkwood, the plutonium-plant critic who was killed in a mysterious car accident in Oklahoma in 1974.

title: BEST SELLERS Feb. 10, 1985
description: Fiction*1

title: 5 PROTESTERS STAY IN JAIL UNDER INDEFINITE SENTENCE
description: Five protesters arrested at a 1984 demonstration at a cruise missile engine factory began their 13th week in jail today under an indefinite sentence for contempt of court.

title: S.A.T. COURSES PROLIFERATE L.I.
description: WHILE school districts throughout Long Island are suffering the ill effects of dwindling school enrollment - in some instances closing facilities - private courses designed to prepare high school students for the Scholastic Aptitude Test (S.A.T.) are proliferating.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS Foiling 'Disaster'
description: Ellenville, N.Y. - where the population was reported as 4,500 in 1950 and 4,500 in 1980 - faced an unfamiliar experience a year ago: turmoil.

title: Elizabeth Grover to Wed
description: Capt. Royal Edward Grover, U.S.C.G., retired, and Mrs. Grover of Ledyard, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Lennox Grover, to Norman Ilsley Adams 4th, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Adams 3d of Wilton, Conn.

description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline

Kennelly at the South African Consulate in New York City against apartheid policies raises a question of whether they are misdirecting their priorities at the expense of the very people they claim to support.

title: CAPTURING OLD ECHOES IN THE NEW PEKING
description: HARRISON E. SALISBURY, a former New York Times editor and correspondent, is completing ''The Long March: The Untold Story,'' to be published by Harper & Row in September.

title: Vacations Apart
description: To the Editor: Apropos of ''Two for the Road'' (Travel, Dec. 2): My hus

title: 'Contra' Violence Violates Medical Neutrality
description: To the Editor:

title:
MANAGING CREATIVE PEOPLE;

SOOTHING TEMPERS AND EGOS
description: THERE is one point on which all managers of creative people seem to agree: Running a creative shop is no picnic. It means catering to fragile egos and explosive temperaments without letting prima donnas ride roughshod on management or their own colleagues. It means maintaining a flexible working environment without letting chaos triumph over order. And it means knowing how to say ''no'' to some ideas without discouraging their proponents from readily offering others.

title: Anne King Markey, Lawyer, to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Markey Jr. of Green Village, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Anne King Markey to Kishore Mahbubani, the permanent representative of Singapore at the United Nations. The wedding is planned for late next month.

title:
CAREFUL SHOPPER ;

All Sorts of Coats And More Besides
description: The Burlington Coat Factory Warehouse opened at the former site of Korvette's in the Midway Shopping Center on Central Park Avenue two years ago and has much more than coats - indoor and outdoor clothing for the entire family, including shoes, accessories and disposable diapers, plus jewelry, handbags, leather and furs.

title: DANCING ON THE LIGHT SIDE
description: Mitchell Rose has been called the Woody Allen, Steve Martin and Ernie Kovacs of dance. Others have seen in him a terpsichorean Mel Brooks and Groucho Marx. And then there was the critic whose thoughts turned to ''the tradition of Chaplin, Keaton and Tati.'' Mr. Rose describes himself as ''the global village idiot,'' in which guise he will appear with five dancers at the Theater of the Riverside Church on Thursday through Sunday.

title: IN SEARCH OF GLAMOUR ON THE SEA
description: Somewhere, in that section of my mind that stores glamorous images, there are countless ships. These ships are all the product of movies seen in my youth. They have suites rather than staterooms, none smaller than the size of most present-day New York apartments, and all with flower- filled living rooms. The bedrooms are invariably furnished with satin-covered double beds and the dressing tables are always laden with crystal perfume atomizers and silver-topped brushes and bottles.

title: MANY PORTS IN A STORM OVER NAVY PLAN
description: Every boat owner knows that the vessel itself is only half the worry. You also need a good place to tie it up. Last week, the Navy found a docking problem on the other side of the world that it hopes will not spread homeward.

title: General Dynamics Withdraws Bill to U.S. for Company Trips
description: The General Dynamics Corporation, the nation's largest military contractor, has agreed to withdraw a bill for $491,840 charged to the Federal Government for corporate airplane flights its chairman made to his farm in Georgia, the St. Louis Post-Dispatch reported in its Sunday issue.

title: CHONGQING TRANSFORMED
HELP SOUGHT FOR CRIME VICTIMS
description: GARY MERTON attended every session of the trial of Cory Barton, the teen-ager accused of killing Mr. Merton's 16-year-old daughter, Shari Ann, but after the guilty verdict, he nearly missed the sentencing. The date had been changed, and no one had told the Mertons.

title: DANCE: BAROQUE GROUP TRAVELS BACK IN TIME
description: The Dance Theater Workshop's Bessie Sch"onberg Theater is usually a home for dance at its most up to date. But in ''Les Caract eres de la Danse,'' presented there Thursday night, the audience was taken back to the Baroque era by the New York Baroque Dance Company, directed by Catherine Turocy, and Concert Royal, a group directed by James Richman that specializes in performances of Baroque music on instruments of the period.

title: A WOMEN'S ASCENT ON WALL STREET
description: If Jane Gross had presented similar profiles of Karen Valenstein's male colleagues, I wager that their two-month calendars would tout just as many business meals and trips. Investment bankers, whether male or female, lead frenetic lives.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article Feb. 3 on the disappearance of Ernest R. Keiser, who has aided in Federal efforts to capture fugitives, contained an incorrect location for the headquarters of Interpol. It is in Paris.

title: Chinese Hotels
description: To the Editor: ''China's New Hotels'' (Travel, Dec. 2) took me back to Sep

title: STATE LEADS DROP IN DIVORCE RATE
description: THE nation's divorce rate has been declining for three years, and Connecticut has been leading the decline with the lowest percentages of divorces per population in the nation.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: AT an age when most aspiring members of the judiciary haven't even reached the bench yet,

title: THOSE TROUBLED GERMANS
description: WITH CALCUlated impertinence, Otto Schily turned to the large, uncomfortable-looking man seated before him and asked in a rasping voice: ''Mr. Witness, do I understand your answer to mean that you consciously violated this article of the Constitution?''

title: Comings and Goings
description: Matt Young, the Seattle pitcher, has reached agreement with the Mariners on a one-year contract that will bring him an estimated $115,000, with $90,000 in incentive bonuses keyed to his number of starts and innings pitched. . . .

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: UNION POWER AND NEW YORK: Victor Gotbaum and District Council 37.By Jewel Bellush and Bernard Bellush. (Praeger, Cloth, $33.95. Paper, $14.95.)

title: NEW G.O.P. OFFICIAL FOCUSES ON YOUTH
description: TED HIGGINS, who was recently elected chairman of the College Republican National Committee, dates his involvement in politics to his days at White Plains High School. ''I watched America drifting downward under Carter,'' the 23-year-old Mr. Higgins recalled. ''I was aware of skyrocketing inflation and I saw the Soviets on the march all over the world.''

title: REAGAN HAS OPPONENTS PLAYING BY HIS RULES
description: PRESIDENT REAGAN paused a few minutes in the chambers of the Speaker of the House last Wednesday night before making his State of the Union Address. Typically, he passed the time not in solitary reflection but swapping jokes and stories with Congressional leaders, downing a glass of Perrier to wet his throat. Others found him in an easy, genial mood. That infectious buoyancy soon gave a lift to his performance before the television cameras, and bolstered his confident promise of ''a second American Revolution.''

title: COZZENS SCORES 30 AS ARMY UPSETS IONA
description: Randy Cozzens scored 30 points and passed for 8 assists today as he almost personally created Army's 76-73 upset of Iona.

title: WHAT SHE WAS SILENT ABOUT
description: Carolyn Heilbrun is a professor of English literature at Columbia University. VIRGINIA WOOLF

title: MY LIFE AS A WRONG NUMBER
description: I, too, have faced the dilemma of being confused with Bruce Weber the fashion photographer.

title: Data Update
description: * Rates on most adjustable mortgages are set 1 to 3 percentage points above these indexes.

title: Marvin Miller, Actor on TV; Appeared in 'The Millionaire'
description: Marvin Miller, the actor whose character disbursed a fortune every week on the 1950's television series ''The Millionaire,'' died Friday of a heart attack. He was 71 years old .

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: ANNA FREUD: A Life Dedicated to Children. By Uwe Henrik Peters. (Schocken, $24.95.)

title: 'Glitz'
description: HOW good is this novel? Probably the most convincing thing I can say on the subject is that it cost me money. After finishing ''Glitz,'' I went out to the bookstore at my local mall and bought everything by Elmore Leonard I could find - the stuff I didn't already own, that is.

title: Visiting Soviet Doctor Changes His Statement
description: A Russian whose presence here revived speculation about Konstantin U. Chernenko's health today denied being the Soviet leader's personal doctor.

title: A LIBRARY OF TOYS ADAPTED FOR THE DISABLED
description: AT first glance, it appears to be an ordinary playroom, similar to those found in most schools or institutions. Jack-in-the-boxes, toy clocks, musical instruments and hundreds of other popular children's toys are neatly arranged on shelves, ready to be set into motion by eager children. Other toys, with missing or broken parts, sit in a pile in the corner of the room, awaiting repairs.

title: Maureen A. Ryan To Marry in June
description: The engagement of Maureen Ann Ryan and Christopher Conroy Smith has been announced by Miss Ryan's parents, Mr. and Mrs. James Vincent Ryan of Rye, N.Y. Mr. Smith is a son of Mrs. Joseph A. McManus of Rye and the late Walter J. Smith. A June wedding is planned.

title: MISERICORDS
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: Land-Use Policy: A Further Word In his letter (''On Uses and Abuses of Land in North,'' Jan. 13), William Stelle, a respected lay municipal planner, finds it ironic that an attorney who is helping a client secure permission to develop land adjacent to the Interstate Highway 684 interchange with State Highway 172 more intensively than with one house per four acres (which is all that local zoning permits) is also concerned with the tremendous need for housing generated by the huge office and commercial developments of the last two decades in Westchester County!

title: U.N. BLACKLIST POSES BARRIER FOR A CONCERT
description: Plans for a United Nations concert to raise money for African famine relief have been held up because some of the entertainers who were originally invited have performed in South Africa and are on a United Nations blacklist aimed at combating apartheid.

title: A GROUP FOR POLIO SURVIVORS WHO HAVE NEW SYMPTOMS
description: IN 1944, during a major polio epidemic, Barbara McManus, at

title: SEEKING SAFE TOYS THAT SELL
description: IN 1200 B.C., children played with a Cypriote terracotta horse. By 400 B.C., an Egyptian ivory mechanical dog was the rage. And miniature Medieval knights and silver rattles from the 18th century are still among the most beautiful toys around.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN;
description: JOAN LEE FAUST This Week:

title:
THE REGION;

Police Protest Indictment in Bronx Shooting
description: It did not matter to the police last week which of two blasts from a police shotgun killed Eleanor Bumpurs in the Bronx in October. It mattered only that Stephen Sullivan, a 19-year veteran of the force and a volunteer who had accepted the hazardous job of subduing emotionally disturbed people and dealing with terrorists, had been indicted for manslaughter in the case. Thousands of off-duty officers gathered outside the office of the Bronx District Attorney, Mario Merola, to tell him to ''stop fighting cops and start fighting crime.''

title: THE MAN BEHIND THE BUDGET
description: HARTFORD AS Governor O'Neill outlined his proposed $4.4 billion state budget last Wednesday to a joint session of the General Assembly, Anthony V. Milano, a soft-spoken man with a thick folder of papers, watched intently on the sidelines in the Hall of the House.

title:
NUMISMATICS;

A NEW COMPETITOR FOR THE KRUGERRAND
description: South Africa's Krugerrand, long-time ''king of the hill'' among bullion-type gold coins, will soon have a challenger. A legal-tender one- ounce gold coin called the Angel will be introduced in the United States next month by the Isle of Man, a small, self-governing British dependency located in the Irish Sea off the northwest coast of England.

title:
ANTIQUES;

BOARDWALK SHOW AND CAR AUCTION
description: ATLANTIC CITY THE star quality of a combined antiques show and auction of ''collector cars'' is expected to compete with the gambling casinos here next weekend.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: More than 70 camps from all over the country are sending representatives and exhibits to the County Center in White Plains from noon to 4 P.M. today to provide information for prospective campers and parents.

title: Topics;   Driven; He Should Know
description: If all goes well, the drinking age throughout the Northeast will be 21 by June. New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Rhode Island have already fallen into line.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;

A CALL TO AN OLD FOE-NOW BEST FRIEND
description: I WOKE up to the sound of moaning. Ignoring it, I rolled over,

title: LAB THEFTS PLAGUE CAMPUS
description: A PAIR of microscopes valued at $20,000 were stolen recently from the State University of New York at Stony Brook, less than three months after money had run out for a security program in a theft-plagued building on the campus.

title: TECHNOLOGY TRANSFER FOR MUTUAL GAIN
description: THE Soviet Union's return to arms-control talks in Geneva is generally considered to reflect strategic considerations. In this view, Soviet leaders are trying to head off a competition in space-based defensive weapons, where the United States has the edge. But economic factors, which have helped thaw United States-Soviet trade relations as well, may be just as important. Thus, the Reagan Administration's negotiating strategy in both arms and trade talks must be based on a realistic assessment of the Soviet economy.

title:
GARDENING;

PROPAGATING YOUR OWN GROUND COVERS
description: A READER notes that buying a sufficient number of ground-cover plants for a large area could be quite costly. This certainly can be true. If one desires quick coverage, it is still the most logical choice. However, if speed is not important, propagating one's own plants may be an alternative.

title: NEW ZEALAND ON SHIP BAN: ISSUE OF PRIDE
description: The spray-painted words ''No Nukes'' are daubed on the entrance to the Victoria Tunnel, on the way from the airport to downtown Wellington. A sign on St. Andrew's Church, just down the street from the nation's Parliament building, tells visitors that the church has been declared ''a nuclear-free zone.''

title: Annrea Sutton Weds Eugene Maleska
description: The marriage of Annrea Neill Sutton of East Falmouth, Mass., a portrait painter, to Eugene T. Maleska of Wareham, Mass., the crossword puzzle editor of The New York Times, took place yesterday at the Unitarian Church in Barnstable, Mass. The Rev. Kenneth Warren performed the ceremony.

title: FAIRCHILD UNVEILING JET TRAINER
description: WHEN one of the Island's leading aerospace concerns, the Fairchild Republic Company, a year ago built the last A-10 Thunderbolt II attack plane for the United States Air Force, it was as if a dark cloud had draped the sprawling complex in Farmingdale.

title: MUSIC: MEREDITH MONK IN 10-YEAR RETROSPECTIVE
description: Meredith Monk has been celebrating her 20th year before the New York public this season - with ''The Games'' at the Next Wave Festival last fall, with showings of her films at the Whitney Museum beginning in a few weeks, and with a mostly musical night at Carnegie Hall on Thursday.

title: INDIA'S SPY SCARE SLOWS ARMS DEALS
description: Indian officials, concerned by the uncovering of a major espionage network, have slowed talks on buying billions of dollars worth of advanced weapons from Western countries competing for the contracts, a Western diplomat says.

title: ROYAL SHAKESPEARE VISIT
description: The British are coming - the Royal Shakespeare Company, that is - to Montclair State College this week to teach and perform. Five actors will take part in four public performances while on the campus to conduct classes and workshops for speech and theater students.

title: TEST IS CALLED SUCCESSFUL IN PREDICTING SUICIDE
description: The sense of hopelessness among those contemplating suicide is the strongest predictor of which people will actually go on to kill themselves, according to a study done at the University of Pennsylvania School of Medicine.

title: 16 ARE GIVEN MARKEY RESEARCH SCHOLARSHIPS
description: The Lucille P. Markey Charitable Trust, which is devoted to basic biomedical research, has awarded its first scholarships to 16 young scientists. The Markey scholars will share $700,000 for the first year, with the prospect of larger awards in the future.

title: STATISTICALLY, AT LEAST, IT IS RATHER SAFE DOWN THERE
description: There is an image of New York City's subway system, derived in large part from the appearance of the trains and stations, as a lurid underground kingdom ruled by murderers, rapists and muggers where a subway rider's life sometimes has less value than a token. But the crime statistics belie at least part of that image. The subways are not the cleanest transportation system in town, but they are often the fastest and, by any measure, the safest.

title: FROM THE PULPITS TO THE BARRICADES
description: In the 1960's and 70's religious leaders were prominent among those who marched for civil rights and an end to the Vietnam War. Today, after a period of relative quiet, social and political activism by church figures is again on the rise. Now the causes include the welfare of illegal aliens from Central America and the fight against racial segregation in South Africa.

title: A DEBATE ON THE U.S. AND THE 'CONTRAS'
description: Congress is facing a choice between covert and overt aid to the ''contras'' fighting a guerrilla war against the Nicaraguan Government. The objections to the aid, however, carry the same force, whether or not the operations are kept secret.

title: Architecture
description: To the Editor:

title: Robert B. Huff Marries Jean Smiertka, Lawyer
description: Jean Smiertka, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Smiertka of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Robert Byron Huff, a son of Mr. and Mrs. C. Clayton Huff of Longboat Key, Fla. Msgr. Vincent Jeffers performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Perpetual Help Roman Catholic Church in Pelham Manor, N.Y.

title: Teacher Idea Flunks
description: To the Editor:
To the Defense Of Coach Knight

title: Award in L.I. Brutality Case
description: A Long Beach, L.I., man has been awarded $250,000 for damages he suffered when he was beaten by two Nassau County narcotics officers while being arrested in 1978, court officials said. A State Supreme Court jury made the award late Thursday to Edward Good, a 34-year-old steamfitter, who suffered a broken nose and contusions. Mr. Good was charged with obstructing governmental administration.

title: A Woman's Ascent On Wall Street
description: I have reserved a place in my briefcase for Jane Gross's article on Karen Valenstein (''Against the Odds,'' Jan. 6).

title: THE STAGE IS SET FOR BETTER RELATIONS
description: AFTER a six-year hiatus, the United States is again prepared to engage in old-fashioned business diplomacy with the Soviet Union. This, in any event, is the clear message that Lionel H. Olmer, the Commerce Department's Under Secretary for International Trade Administration, conveyed to his Soviet counterpart, Vladimir N. Sushkov, when they met in Moscow early last month.

title: Merida Welles to Be a Bride Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Welles of Washington of the engagement of their daughter Merida Welles to William Grisard Holman Jr., the son of Carol Holman Wakelin of Washington and the late Captain Holman, U.S.N. A May wedding is planned.
description: The future bride, a candidate for an M.B.A. degree at Columbia University, attended Smith College and graduated from the University of London. She is a granddaughter of the late Sumner Welles, Under Secretary of State in the Administration of Franklin D. Roosevelt and a drafter of the Atlantic Charter.

title: KEEP PRESSING MANAGUA
description: As Congress considers once again whether to continue funding the ''contras'' fighting in Nicaragua, it should take careful account of the larger context in Central America - in particular, the growing security ties between Nicaragua, Cuba and the Soviet Union. If Jiri Valenta is coordinator of Soviet and Eastern European studies at the United States Naval Post-Graduate School. it fails to do so, it may miss a critical opportunity to use the contras to exploit tactical differences between Moscow and Havana. Nicaragua's international connections are a consequence of the way it consolidated its revolution following Eastern European and Cuban models. The Nicaraguan leadership began by creating a classic Leninist ''vanguard party'' - the Sandinista front - to coerce and indoctrinate the people. By now, the revolution is in its second phase, characterized by increasing bureaucratization and the formation of a ''new class'' - the Sandinista leaders and their wives and mistresses - that is as privileged and corrupt as the displaced pre- revolutionary elite. Consolidation of power on the home front has been accompanied by increasing support for guerrilla movements in neighboring nations and growing military ties with Moscow. The Nicaraguans claim that they no longer provide material support for the Salvadoran guerrillas, but, as one Sandinista official confessed to me, ideology dictates that the revolution spread through the region; otherwise it will perish. This only accentuates the East-West nature of the conflict.

title: INCIDENCE OF ARRESTS UP AMONG OFFICERS, DEPARTMENT REPORTS
description: A total of 81 New York City police officers were arrested last year on various criminal charges, according to a department report released last week. The total represents an increase of 25 arrests over 1983 and the highest overall figure since 1975, when 86 officers were arrested.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

TAKING A RISK: MY DAUGHTER'S PASSAGE TO INDIA
description: JUST before I finished speaking with my daughter in New Delhi on the night before Indira Gandhi's funeral, I decided to wish her a happy birthday. From my window, my world had never been more still. Clouds hung over the dead oak leaves like shrouds. Nothing moved in the thick blackness. From her roof, where she had gone to glimpse her world, smoke rose from every direction to seek the gaudy sun. Everything, she said, seemed in flux.

title: ANTIQUES View;   A COLLECTION BUILT ON CHILDHOOD MEMORIES
description: James Smith 2d remembers, as do most of those who grew up in America between the 1890's and World War II, the thrill of riding the tallest horse on the merry-go-round, the sweetness that lingered after tasting gum balls bought from a penny machine, the pride of winning a coin-operated baseball game and the joy sparked by the crashing cymbals and blaring brasses of the Calliope as the circus parade approached.

title: BASIC TOOLS FOR DO-IT-YOURSELFERS
description: ALTHOUGH it is often a lack of knowledge and experience that will discourage a homeowner from tackling simple repair and maintenance jobs, in many cases the neophyte hesitates to do even the simplest of chores because he or she does not have the right tools. This is particularly true of many apartment dwellers, first-time homeowners and older homeowners who in the past were able to call in a handyman. That all-around handyman can no longer be found in most communities.

title: UCONN REPORT SCORNS 'INTELLECTUAL POVERTY'

They were not only cheering for Miss Nguyen. They were also cheering the showmanship of a President who was celebrating his 74th birthday with a typical star turn.

title: PHYSICIANS HAVE AN IMAGE PROBLEM-IT'S TOO GOOD

The A.M.A. says it will seek new laws to limit settlements, ask courts to limit lawyers' fees and urge the medical community to do a better job of removing incompetent doctors from practice.

title: UNDERVALUED RIOJA
description: THE RIOJA REGION OF SPAIN REMAINS ONE of the world's least appreciated producers of fine wine. This is unfortunate, particularly in this country, because the soft, round, easy-to-drink Rioja reds are wines in the American manner. They are much closer in style to California cabernets than they are to the Bordeaux on which they are based. What's more, they are exceptionally good bargains at the moment, thanks to the strength of the dollar abroad.

title: OUR WORLD IN A BASEMENT

Now It Really Is Their Center
description: ''Who owns New York?'' is the way the college song begins, and generations of students have spelled out the answer: ''C-O-L-U-M-B-I-A.'' Undergraduate overstatement to be sure, but the university did include in its portfolio an exceedingly valuable chunk of the city - 11.7 acres under Rockefeller Center. Last week, it decided it was high time to sell.

title: A PAGAN LOVE ON VALENTINE'S DAY
description: There is no entry for ''Love'' in the New Grove Dictionary of Music, but music is helpless without it. Few singers open their mouths without this powerful - if undefinable - emotion issuing forth. Neither do musicians escape its draw - unable perhaps of making their instruments say the word itself, but still creating their compositions - and even their instruments - in its name.

title: The Processing Process
description: FOR A LONG TIME after going into the writing business, I wrote. It was hard to do. That was before the word processor was invented. Whenever all the writers got together, it was whine, whine, whine. How hard writing was. How they wished they had gone into dry cleaning, stonecutting, anything less toilsome than writing.

title: SUNDAY, FEBRUARY 10, 1985
description: International

title: 'THE ATLANTA CHILD MURDERS': A TRIAL BY TV
description: ''The Atlanta Child Murders'' is trial by television. We are meant to weigh evidence and then pass judgment, not minding that television already has passed judgment for us. The evidence is television evidence. Regular rules do not apply. Therefore, a smile is meaningful; a leer says something else. Truth shall be known by a character's persona. Jason Robards, the defense attorney, could not possibly be on the wrong side; he's far too decent for that. At the same time, it's clear that Rip Torn, the prosecutor, is only another politician. Great performances and high moral purpose march hand in hand in the CBS ''docudrama,'' while the trial that convulsed Atlanta is staged in our living rooms. The depiction is gripping, but it's questionable whether it should be depicted at all.

title: No Headline
description: On the Matter Of Manners I was greatly disturbed by the story by Helen Frank (''Whatever Happened to Manners?'' Jan. 13) and worried that her credentials as a psychotherapist may impress young parents unsure about the subject.

title: WHAT HAS ARCHITECTURE TO DO WITH THE QUALITY OF LIFE?
description: It is in the nature of architecture that not only must its art always be defended, but also its practicality. It is attacked, it would seem, from all sides. Why should buildings be thought of as art when their real purpose is to give us shelter, goes one argument. And then there is the counter to this, which is to concede that buildings have an esthetic presence but to say that this esthetic presence does nothing to make our lives any easier.

title: Sipe Passes for Score, But Bulls Lose, 20-10

In addition to being smart and hard working, we are told that Mrs. Valenstein has ''ascended'' on Wall Street because she is tough, can swear, tell dirty jokes, drink with the boys and not let her family get in the way.

title: GREAT DANCERS MADE GREAT MUSICALS IN HOLLYWOOD
description: So much has been written about the demise of the Hollywood musical that the chronicling itself is turning into a minor art form. The latest entries here are an anthology of film clips called ''That's Dancing!'' and a book with the same title by Tony Thomas. Mr. Thomas's book project was obviously timed to coincide with the release of the film as part of its promotion. His introduction includes an inside look at the travail involved in the assembling of the movie, which was modeled after ''That's Entertainment.'' Despite its nod to the compilation film that inspired it, ''That's Dancing!'' by Mr. Thomas (Harry N. Abrams, New York. $35) stands on its own as a study of dancing in film musicals.

title: Brokerage Stocks Surge
description: Brokerage stocks, among December's worst performers, were the biggest gainers in January's rally: as a group, their prices rose 29.4 percent, according to figures compiled by Standard & Poor's. That should be no surprise, since brokerage stocks have a high ''beta'' factor - that is, when their prices do finally rise, they do so at a higher rate than market prices in general. Historically, they climb at a ratio of about 1.85-to-1 relative to the market as a whole, says Perrin H. Long Jr., an analyst with Lipper Analytical Services. That makes brokerage stocks an attractive investment in a rally, Mr. Long said. ''If you thought the market was going to go up another 200 points on the Dow, why not buy the brokerage stocks, instead of trying to figure out which stocks would go up?'' he said.

title: A MAY-DECEMBER MARRIAGE
description: Chuck Barris's account of striving to conceive a child was a heartwarming story, but I was disturbed that a large dose of misinformation seemed to contribute to his turmoil. Low body temperature in a woman is generally not a reliable measure of ovulation.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: To contemplate the photographic images of Paul Caponigro is to escape from the hustle and bustle of life into a still, silent world of stones, deserts, trees, flowers, skies, waters and woods that must be real, since it can be photographed, but seems as remote and insubstantial as a dream. There are no people in it, and virtually no signs of people except prehistoric monuments, deserted villages and temples of a mysterious Eastern religion.

title: IN LONDON, A FINE HOME FOR A MAJOR COLLECTION
