title: POPE'S MESSAGE DEPENDS ON WHO DOES THE LISTENING
description: Among the burdens that Pope John Paul II bore during the visit to South America that ended last week were those laid upon him by Luis Ortiz, a salesman, and Maria Hernandez Soliz, a housewife. Others expected thoughtful or inspiring words from John Paul during a stop in El Guasmo, a shantytown slum on the edge of the Ecuadorian city of Guayaquil. But Mr. Ortiz and Mrs. Hernandez expected nothing short of a miracle. ''Things change in every country he visits,'' Mr. Ortiz said with conviction, adding that no one could ignore the Pope's appeals on behalf of the poor. Mrs. Hernandez was sure of change ''because I have faith in him.'' Such was the responsibility that John Paul carried as he addressed millions of people in Venezuela, Ecuador, Peru and Trinidad and Tobago. As the head of a church that is governed from Europe, the Pontiff oversees an organization that is strongest in the third world and, by the year 2000, will have a majority of its membership in Latin America. Moreover, it is in Latin America where, from the Vatican's point of view, some of the most troublesome movements within Catholicism have taken root. Most notable among these is the theology of liberation, which sees a special responsibility for the church to lift up the poor, and often advocates radical politics as the way to do it. Yet at the end of the Pope's 12-day trip, many questions remained unanswered.

title: CORRECTION
description: A photograph that appeared in last Sunday's Long Island Weekly section incorrectly identified the Cold Spring Harbor Library. The photograph actually showed Cold Spring Harbor's school district administration building.

title: Hurdle for Dohrn
description: A major hurdle remained for Bernardine Dohrn last May after she passed the New York State bar examination: before she could practice law, she would have to be approved by the State Supreme Court's Committee on Character and Fitness.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: ''La Boh eme'' may not strike everybody as ideal Valentine Day fare, but no one would deny that Puccini's opera about life among the Bohemians in 19th-century Paris has a lot to do with love. And so, on Thursday night at 9, Mimi, Rodolfo, Musetta and Marcello will sing their hearts out in an Arts & Entertainment presentation of ''La Boh eme.''

title: REAGAN'S HIGH RISK GROWTH GAME
description: ALL last week, in his budget message, annual economic report and State of the Union address, President Reagan laid out the game plan for his second term. He means to consolidate the conservative revolution in public policy - he calls it a Second American Revolution - that he began four years ago.

title: SUING GOVERNMENT: A CURRENT CASE MAY AFFECT RULES

description: A friend who never has kind words for the subway surprised us recently with an encomium to an unknown conductor last heard from on an E train. He treats the passengers as if they are his, and the subway's, guests.

description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Wendell Gardner of Washington and Southampton, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter Joan Blake Gardner to Douglas Gregory Cook, the son of Mrs. William Batten of Newport, R. I., and Charles Edward Cook of Providence, R.I. The wedding is planned for June.

title: Nina LeRoy Plans to Wed
description: A June wedding is planned by Nina LeRoy, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. G. Palmer LeRoy of Bedford, N.Y., and Nantucket, Mass., and Ogden McClurg Hunnewell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James F. Hunnewell of Westwood, Mass. and Prouts Neck, Me., her parents have announced.

title: FOR MANY, THE OLD-FASHIONED VEGETABLES TASTE BEST
description: One of the few things to mar the pleasure of seed catalogue browsing is finding a mainstay variety no longer listed. Though it may be available, few have the stamina to comb through pages.

title: UPSTATE POWER LINE WILL BE THE SUBJECT OF ADDED HEARINGS
description: The Army Corps of Engineers plans to conduct new public hearings on a proposal to build a 203-mile power transmission line in New York State.

title: Loren Gelberg Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Gelberg of Teaneck, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Loren M. Gelberg, to Lloyd M. Goff, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Goff of Plainview, L.I. An April wedding is planned. Miss Gelberg is a counselor at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in New York. Her fiance is a principal of the Goff Security Bureau in New York.

title: THE LIFE WE LIVE AND THE LIFE WE WRITE
description: WHERE does autobiography end and fiction begin? Best seller lists and publishers' catalogues assume we know the answer to this question, as they assume there is a clear- cut difference between fiction and nonfiction. Many writers are not so sure. The strongest and most passionate writing always comes out of our own experiences and obsessions - but how we transform these obsessions depends on the writer, or even on the writer's mood, at a given point in time. In some ways, I knew my 18th-century historical novel, ''Fanny: being the True History of the Adventures of Fanny Hackabout-Jones'' to be a truer spiritual autobiography than my other novels, ''Fear of Flying'' or ''How to Save Your Own Life'' or even my most recent, ''Parachutes and Kisses.'' In seeking to devise a historical fable for myself, I was forced to reveal my own obsessions to myself in a very distilled way. But to most readers, the more a book resembles the outer structure of an author's life, the more ''autobiographical'' it will be presumed to be. That there is autobiography within fiction and fiction within autobiography comes as no surprise to the author or reader who knows exactly what Gustave Flaubert meant when he said: ''Madame Bovary, c'est moi.''

title: LILCO'S ELECTRICAL CAPACITY SCRUTINIZED
description: NEW YORK STATE'S eight major electric utilities have 273 power plants with a total capacity of 30,000 megawatts, about 40 percent more than peak demand. But the other seven are likely to penalize the Long Island Lighting Company this year because it has not contributed its share to meeting the state's power needs.

title: JAZZ: TONY TAMBURELLO
description: Tony Tamburello, who has taken over the piano at the Carnegie Tavern, has a fascinating combination of modesty, brilliance and background. Initially, he may seem to be an unusually good but self-effacing cocktail pianist, as he weaves long medleys made up of one or two choruses of melodies that float over a light and swinging beat.

title: THE BACKYARD RESCUERS
description: John Withee never planned to be a bean collector.

title: VERBATIM: THE LIMITS OF POWER
description: 'The United States has lost its pre-eminence. While it remains the leading nation on the international scene, its power, which earlier was scarcely disputable, is now very much disputable. Simultaneously - and not simply by coincidence - national unity has been fractured, both in terms of the national consensus and in terms of the agreement between the executive and legislative branches.' James R. Schlesinger

title: Cross-Subsidy
description: Plan Defended

title: MUSIC: DEBUTS IN REVIEW
description: The New York Chamber Winds, an ensemble of 16 young musicians from the Juilliard and Mannes Schools of Music, made its formal debut on Feb. 2, under the direction of Yves Abel.

title: FURNITURE FOR THE BEDROOM IS WHIMSICAL AND FUNCTIONAL
description: THE exhibition of contemporary, handmade furniture at The Elements Gallery in Greenwich through Feb. 23 concentrates on the bedroom. Some 20 artisans have contributed such obvious pieces as beds and chests of drawers, along with less essential items such as bookcases, rocking chairs, desks, screens and chaise longues that can add immeasurably to the comfort of a room spacious enough to accommodate them.

title: INNAURATO SURVIVES A PERIOD OF ADJUSTMENT
description: Albert Innaurato made his New York playwriting debut in 1976 with ''The Transfiguration of Benno Blimpie,'' a tragicomic nightmare about a young man who was literally eating himself to death. Later that year he followed it with ''Gemini,'' domestic comedy variations on the subject of sexual and familial identity. In tandem, the two plays established Mr. Innaurato as one of the most original playwrights of his generation.

title: Riley Calls for Fewer Games
description: Pat Riley, who is coaching the Western Conference team in the National Basketball Association's All-Star Game on Sunday, sparked widespread discussion this morning by saying that the league should work toward reducing the 82-game schedule.

title: Docudrama Strikes Again
description: It's happening again, on CBS tonight and Tuesday: the artful mingling of fact and fiction in a lengthy ''docudrama.'' As has become the vogue in television films, ''The Atlanta Child Murders'' will exploit still-raw events by having famous actors portray both real and invented characters, speaking both factual and made-up dialogue.

title: ON MOTHERSHIP AND AUTHORHOOD
description: Waiting, Near Christmas

title: Article 016833 -- No Title
description: Families of 24 miners who contracted cancer after working in Utah uranium mines will be paid $1.2 million by the Foote Mineral Company in a partial settlement of a Federal court suit, lawyers have reported.

title: No Headline
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl gave qualified endorsement today to the proposed American research into a space-based missile defense system, but asked that its ultimate benefits be extended to Western Europe.

title: CHARGES IN BOOK ON TOXIC WASTE CALLED FALSE
description: An assertion in a new book that a former New Jersey Congressman sought to protect state officials by preventing a House hearing from pursuing issues of toxic-waste dumping has set off a flurry of protests.

title: STUDIES OF SUBURBS DECLINE
description: THE Institute for Suburban Studies at Adelphi University, established in response to the academic ferment of the 1960's, is no longer accepting degree candidates, according to Hugh Wilson, the director of the institute.

title: Seat-Belt Offer
description: In a safety program stressing that ''seat belts are life belts,'' General Motors began to give free life-insurance policies last April with all its new cars and light trucks.

title: CHALLENGE FACING LOS ANGELES MAYOR
description: At 67 years of age, Tom Bradley is trying to become the first person elected to a fourth term as Mayor of Los Angeles. In a race in which the main issue so far has been an accusation that he really wants to be Governor of California, Mr. Bradley appears to have a solid lead over his opponent, City Councilman John Ferraro.

title: TV REPLAY USED AS GENERALS LOSE
description: For the first time in any football game, a television replay system was used tonight to review an official's decision made on the field. The occasion was a United States Football League preseason game in which the Tampa Bay Bandits defeated the Generals, 21-7.

title: LIGHT BEAMS BRING OLD RECORDS TO NEW EARS
description: Before the phonograph, music was instantly perishable. It vanished with its own sound. True, ever since Guido d'Arezzo invented it 900 years ago, there was notation. But as any musician will admit, musical script bears only a distant relationship to the reality of music. Gustav Mahler was aware of this when he declared, ''Music is what lies between the notes.'' And later Ralph Vaughan Williams voiced the same feeling when he said that ''until actual sound is produced, music does not exist.''

title: PAIR OF COMEDIES AT THE HARTMAN
description: ONE tends to associate the playwright Peter Shaffer with epic theater and lofty themes. ''The Royal Hunt of the Sun'' was about the conquest of Peru, ''Equus'' probed the morality and psychology of passion, and the nature and divinity of genius inspired ''Amadeus.''

title: THE CLOUDY OUTLOOK FOR GIBRALTAR'S COMMANDING VIEW
description: Behind the dickering by Spain and Britain last week over the status of Gibraltar lie strategic military questions. Madrid wants the talks to lead to the sovereignty that Spain lost to Britain in 1704, but diplomats and military officials worry over Spain's still wavering allegiance to the North Atlantic alliance and its possible effect on the security of one of the most sensitive maritime passages in the world.

title: GETTING TO THE HEART OF VALENTINES
description: ON THURSDAY, valentine cards will fill mailboxes across the state, bearing romantic, albeit mass- produced, messages of love.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE MAKING OF A MOONIE: Choice or Brainwashing? By Eileen Barker. (Basil Blackwell, $19.95.)

title: HEROIC SURGERY, HEROIC PATIENT
description: LISA H.

title: 2 LOTS AT HUNTINGTON STATION STIR A VISION
description: What is the first impression commuters have of Huntington when they get off the train, Philip Clementi asks - and before one can say ''parking lots,'' he goes on to describe his vision of a ''pretty development of interesting stores, maybe a small park and a theater'' across Broadway from the Long Island Rail Road station.

title: NEWARK'S LOW-INCOME HOUSING TO BE REBUILT
description: City officials have outlined a five-year, $300 million plan to rebuild Newark's low-income housing projects.

title: JEROME ROBBINS, PATHBREAKER
description: ''Choreographing a score is like exploring a new territory,'' Jerome Robbins said recently. Mr. Robbins should know, for he has been unusually adventurous since he made his choreographic debut with ''Fancy Free'' in 1944. He has created jazz ballets and also ballets to Bach and Chopin. He has choreographed a ballet with a film sequence, a ballet in slow motion and a ballet to no music at all.

title: BITTERSWEET STAR OF BRITISH BREAKFASTS
description: The scene was a small literary dinner party near Regent's Park in London. One smart young woman, her face dusted with sparkle, gave out a sigh of relief as she collapsed into a chair. The weekend had been a fatiguing one, she said - she had spent it in the country making marmalade with her mother.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: SO LONG, AND THANKS FOR ALL THE FISH. By Douglas Adams. (Harmony Books, $12.95.)

title:
CABLE TV NOTES;

COMEDIANS GET A GREEN LIGHT
description: Steve Schneider writes frequently on developments in cable.

title: CAPITALS' LANGWAY PLAYS LIKE LINK TO PAST
description: The old-fashioned defenseman doesn't care about the label.

title: CD'S INSPIRE HEATED DEBATE
description: Although the compact disk and the digital recording technology on which it is based have made astonishing gains in public acceptance in a short time, despite the fact that the disks and the equipment to play them are still quite expensive, debate over the musical accuracy of the technology and the disks remains heated, at least on the part of of some engineers, audiophiles and music lovers.

title: CONSTRUCTIVE ART AT PURCHASE, BEARDEN'S FANTASY AT LEHMAN
description: ''CONCEPTS in Construction'' is a survey of geometrical abstraction that is making the last stop of a two-year tour at the State University's Neuberger Museum in Purchase. Numbering about 70 pieces, drawn mostly from the museum's own collection, this is not a roundup of major work: for example, Mondrian is represented by only a scribble on a cigarette package, Frank Stella by a single lithograph. And though subtitled ''1910-1980,'' the display starts with a 1914-1915 drawing, by Kasimir Malevich, and ends with sculptures from 1982 by Jackie Ferrara and George Rickey. But these are minor irritations.

title: A TRUSTEE TAKES ON THE GREENMAILERS
description: LAST June, when Walt Disney Productions paid a hefty premium to buy back Saul P. Steinberg's 11.1 percent equity stake, Jesse Unruh, the treasurer for the State of California, was outraged. In previous months, half a dozen big companies had paid ''greenmail'' to get potential corporate raiders off their backs and, now, he had seen enough.

title: MUSIC: PARNASSUS WINDS
description: Winds of Parnassus - that is, a wind ensemble drawn from the personnel of the Parnassus contemporary music group - gave a splendid first concert Tuesday in Tully Hall. Say what you like about contemporary music (or what you don't like), those who specialize in it are apt to be among the liveliest and most convincing of performers.

title: THE F.B.I.'S MOST UNWANTED SPY CASE
description: Judith Cummings is a correspondent for The New York Times in the Los Angeles bureau.

title: CAP' ON STATE SPENDING IS SOUGHT
description: A BIPARTISAN drive to limit the growth of state spending was announced last week by two Senate leaders, who said elected officials lacked the will to resist spending tax dollars in times of plenty The Senate majority leader, John F. Russo, a Democrat, and the assistant minority leader John H. Dorsey a Republican, said they were co-sponsoring a resolution to be placed on the November ballot, calling for a constituional amendment capping state spending.

title: RISOTTO AND MORE FROM NORTH ITALY
description: THERE is usually a fire going in the brick fireplace near the reception area at Savini, a fairly new northern Italian restaurant in Great Neck. It is an inviting touch at this time of year.

description: To the Finals

description: PURSUING INNOCENT PLEASURES

title: ORCHESTRA 'ADOPTS' SCHOOL FOR THE DISABLED
description: HADDONFIELD FRANK BONANNO stands in front of the classroom, a large, colorful poster in his hands. ''Can anyone tell me what this is?'' he asks, pointing to a picture of a bass clarinet.

title: U.S. MAGAZINE CHRONICLES MUTINY ON A SOVIET WARSHIP IN '75
description: A United States naval magazine published this week what it said were details of a mutiny aboard a Soviet warship in 1975 that ended with an aircraft attack on the ship and about 50 sailors dead.

description: WITH the formation of an Economic Development Advisory Group, New London is examining ideas to revitalize its downtown area.

I would like to read more about the Chase Manhattan vice president who ''takes the children to school, supervises their activities, cooks their meals on weekends. . . .'' Now

title: IT'S BOOM TIME IN WHAT ONCE WAS THE BOONIES
description: When the last $20 million-a-mile stretch of Interstate 78 opens to traffic here early next year, the highway will run uninterrupted from Newark Airport almost to the Delaware River, cutting across the center of New Jersey and opening up the grain fields and pastures of this rural heartland to a development boom pushing out from New York City.

title: FROM FRAGMENTS EMERGE A TOTAL OF 10 SCHUBERT SYMPHONIES
description: Though Schubert composed songs with an astounding skill and rapidity that belied their sophistication, he did not have an easy time with the symphony. No fewer than six symphonic torsos are scattered throughout his career, only one of which has been dubbed ''Unfinished'' by posterity.

title: Bolivia Devalues Peso And Raises Many Prices
description: Bolivia sharply devalued its currency and raised the price of food, gasoline and other items today in an effort to stem the threat of an economic collapse.

title: NEW & NOTEWORTHY
description: CHILDHOOD, by Nathalie Sarraute. (George Braziller, $8.95.) In 71 vignettes the French novelist Nathalie Sarraute, born in 1900, recounts her early years. Reviewing ''Childhood'' last year, Roger Shattuck wrote here: ''In these beautifully paced pages the reader can watch a literary sensibility hunting persistently for that most ridiculed of literary prizes: the truth - about what happened, particularly to ourselves.''

title: Gandhi Holds Meeting With Sri Lanka Envoy
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, seeking to reduce tensions with Sri Lanka, conferred for more than an hour today with a special envoy from President J. R. Jayewardene of Sri Lanka.

title: ALBANY WEIGHS CONTINUING-CARE FACILITIES FOR AGED
description: NEW YORK STATE is considering whether to end its decades-old ban on long-term contractual agreements for nursing care and permit the creation of an unusual form of real estate, the continuing- care retirement community.

title: STOCKMAN TOOK HIS SHOT, AND IT'S STILL RICOCHETING
description: THE swift knife and sharp tongue of budget director David A. Stockman have menaced a good number of sacred cows. Few have protested as loudly as veterans groups did last week when he called the $18 billion-a-year military retirement system ''a scandal.'' The outcry all but drowned out the protests of farmers and educators, whom, in a busy week of castigating, Mr. Stockman had also characterized as greedy special pleaders.

title: KELLOGG SCORES 24 AS KANSAS ENDS MEMPHIS STATE'S STREAK
description: Ron Kellogg dazzled Memphis State with an array of offensive maneuvers while scoring 34 points today to lead Kansas to a 75-71 upset victory.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: ONLY GREAT CHANGES. By Meredith Sue Willis, Scribner's. $15.95.)

title: ROBBERS STAB GUEST TO DEATH AFTER HOLDUP AT A L.I. PARTY
description: Two masked robbers burst into a Long Island home during a dinner party Friday night, shot two guests and later killed a third with a knife before escaping with an undetermined amount of jewelry, the Nassau County police said yesterday.

title: FLESH AND SPIRIT IN BEETHOVEN
description: Beethoven's last quartets best satisfy in concert, where in the heat of performance, the inevitable coarsenesses and miscalculations burn away and are forgotten. Records, on the other, remind us of them with repetitive exactitude.

title: CORRECTION
description: A photograph that appeared with the article about the Caterpillar Corporation last Sunday was printed in error. It showed Len Kuchan, treasurer of the company, rather than George A. Schaefer, the president. Photos of the men appear below.

title: Data Bank;    February 10, 1985

ART;

AS EUROPE LOOKED AFTER THE ARMISTICE
description: ON Armistice Day in 1918, the photographer Lewis Hine set out from Paris with an American Red Cross survey team to tour areas devastated during the four years of World War I. Hine, already well-known for his documentation of child labor and immigrant life, was a pioneer photojournalist whose work appeared in progressive publications. His mission for the Red Cross team was to provide material to aid in United States fund-raising efforts for relief work in Europe.

title: REVOLUTIONARIES IN A REVOLVING DOOR
description: THE VIEW FROM INSIDE

title: RANGERS TIE WITH WHALERS
description: The Rangers may have stopped their free fall tonight as they put an end to their five-game losing streak with a 2-2 come-from-behind tie with the Hartford Whalers at the Civic Center.

title: LIQUOR INDUSTRY DECRIES SALES DROP
description: beverage industries are beginning to feel the impact of the state's aggressive campaign to remove drunken drivers from the highways.

description: To the Editor:

LONG ISLAND OPINION;

WHAT HAS HAPPENED TO LOVE
description: -letter word so popularly

title: Small Cars Toughen Up
description: One attribute that Japanese cars have not been famous for is the ability to withstand crashes. But that seems to be changing.

title: AT YALE, THE 'AFTERTHOUGHTS' OF HOWARD HODGKIN
description: AT the Yale Center for British Art, ''Howard Hodgkin: Paintings 1973-1984'' is making the second of only two American stops in a tour that had its genesis in the artist's display at the Venice Biennale. This is quite a coup for New Haven, since Hodgkin is one of Britain's hotter properties. He has not done badly in the United States either, having had several New York exhibitions that were well-received.

title: RECENT RELEASES OF VIDEO CASSETTES
description: Night Journey Choreography by Martha Graham; music by William Schuman; settings by Isamu Noguchi Home Video Exclusives 29 minutes. $69.50

title: WALKING TOURS
description: The city of New Rochelle, not content with weighing and checking-up its citizens to see that they stay fit in its Shape-Up health program, has issued a series of booklets on walking tours in the area. City Manager

title: WHEN IS VENGEANCE REALLY SATISFACTORY?
description: The trouble with most revenge is not that it demands patient waiting, but that when it does come, it's rarely enough to give complete satisfaction.

title: Pelicans Make a Comeback
description: Brown pelicans, once threatened with extinction from the side-effects of pesticides, have been removed from the Government's endangered species list in Alabama, Florida, Georgia and the Carolinas, the Interior Department said today. But the pelicans are still considered endangered in Mississippi, Louisiana, Texas and California, the department said. It credited the improvement to the removal of DDT and other pesticides from the market.

title: 4 Are Killed in Crash Of Ambulance Airplane
description: Four people, including a patient, were killed today when an ambulance airplane lost power in both engines as it approached an airport and crashed in a pasture, the authorities said.

title: Shopping For Ideas
description: More controversial commodities than New York's consumers generally find at suburban shopping centers are likely to be on display from now on as a result of a court decision that protesters have a constitutional right to hand out leaflets in privately owned malls.

title: WHEN PRO BASKETBALL'S STARS SPARKLED DIFFERENTLY
description: IN the Hoosier Dome in Indianapolis today, pro basketball's best players will have at one another in the National Basketball Association's All-Star Game. Games like this have become a perennial item on the schedules of major league sports, offering fans a chance to see marquee-value names gathered at one venue where, so the theory goes, their collective muscle - and ego - can kick the level of the game up a notch or so.

title: No Headline
description: 'Take Heart, All Pet Lovers' John P. Maloney has caught so poignantly the trauma of putting to sleep ''man's best friend'' in his beautifully written article ('' 'Goodbye, Beauty, Love,' He Said,'' Jan. 20).

title: BATTLE OVER BEACH WAGED IN MONTAUK
description: AN act of vandalism in Montauk has brought to a head the long-simmering feud involving the owner of prime oceanfront property, neighboring residents who have been denied access to the beach and Town of East Hampton officials.

title: PACT BY POST SETS A RECORD IN LIBEL CASES
description: The New York Post has agreed to terminate further appeals of a $470,000 libel judgment, and a libel expert says it is the largest such judgment against a news organization to be affirmed on appeal and not subsequently overturned by higher courts.

title: Miss Dorsey Is Wed
description: Marie Antoinette Dorsey, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. B. Dorsey of Greenbelt, Md., was married yesterday to Gerald Henderson, the son of Velma Henderson of Baltimore. The Rev. William McCoy performed the Baptist ceremony at the National City Christian Church in Washington. Mrs. Henderson was formerly a legislative aide to Representative Mickey Leland, Democrat of Texas. Mr. Henderson, a guard with the Seattle SuperSonics basketball team, was formerly with the Boston Celtics.

title: CHEMICAL BUTADIENE IS SAID TO CAUSE CANCER
description: Federal researchers have urged the Government to re-examine standards for workers' exposure to butadiene, citing new evidence that the chemical, a main component of synthetic rubber, may be a potent cause of cancer.

title: Politics;   DEMOCRATS LOSING IN JUDGESHIP MOVE
description: A CONTINUING refusal by Nassau Republicans to deal with Democrats on bipartisan judicial endorsements could cost Democrats four more judicial seats this year in addition to two they lost last year.

title: 200 at Ethiopia Food Center Were Seized, Red Cross Says
description: An official of the International Committee of the Red Cross said today that about 200 famine victims in Ethiopia had been taken at gunpoint from an emergency feeding center. He said operations at the center had been suspended as a result.

title:
GARDENING;

PROPAGATING YOUR OWN GROUND COVERS
description: A READER notes that buying a sufficient number of ground-cover plants for a large area could be quite costly. This certainly can be true. If one desires quick coverage, it is still the most logical choice. However, if speed is not important, propagating one's own plants may be an alternative.

title: FREE FILM FESTIVAL AT DREW UNIVERSITY
description: MADISON

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: MICHELLE A. DUNE TO MARRY JUNE 15
description: Mr. and Mrs. Steve C. Dune of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Michelle Anna Dune, to Dr. Patrick Elliott Hopper, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony W. Hopper of San Francisco. A June 15 wedding is planned.

title: Reversal Of 4 Forfeits Gives Crown to L.I.C.
description: An 11th-hour reversal of four forfeits has made Long Island City High School the regular-season basketball champion in the Queens I division of the Public Schools Athletic League with an 11-3 record instead of a 7-7 mark. The ruling also has left three other teams - Newtown, Bryant and Grover Cleveland - to contend for the other two division spots in the citywide playoffs that begin Friday.

title: William P. Inch to Wed Anne Roberts
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bruce L. Roberts of Darien, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Anne Drew Roberts, to William Paul Inch, a son of Kenneth W. Inch of Scarborough, N.Y., and Mrs. Donald D. DeJohn of Bedford Village, N.Y. A Sept. 28 wedding is planned.

title: RETARDED GAIN CONFIDENCE IN THE KITCHEN
description: DONALD, a mentally retarded man in his 50's, did not know what celery was until he was enrolled in a training program at the Danbury Regional Center. Now, after working in the kitchen of the center's 406 Restaurant, he can pick celery out of the refrigerator, wash it and chop it for the daily soup special.

title: HEADLINERS ;
description: What a Mother Overheard No movie audience would ever believe such a bizarre plot. A woman whose 21-year-old daughter was shot by a would-be robber happens to overhear a teen-ager tell another boy on a subway train that he had shot someone who ''wouldn't turn loose her bag'' the night before in the same area where her daughter had been attacked.

title: THE STAGE: 'LONG TIME'
description: Some years after graduation, five collegiate friends, upwardly mobile members of the professional class, come together for the funeral of one of their classmates who has committed suicide. Over bourbon and memories, tempers flare and guilt is apportioned. P. J. Gibson's ''Long Time Since Yesterday'' (at the Henry Street Settlement's New Federal Theater) is a black, female, lesser version of ''The Big Chill.''

title: Miss Klinges Has Nuptials
description: Susan Claire Klinges, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Karl G. Klinges of Paramus, N.J., was married yesterday to Martin LeBoutillier 3d, a son of Polly LeBoutillier of Old Black Point, Niantic, Conn., and Martin LeBoutillier of Lyme, Conn. The Rev. Margaret Guenther performed the ceremony at St. James' Episcopal Church in Manhattan.

title: Accord on Climate Extended
description: The United States and the Soviet Union have signed an agreement extending for 10 more years a 1972 accord calling for scientific cooperation on research of environmental influences on the climate.

title: EUROPE CLOSES RANKS ON TERRORISM BUT A FEW GAPS REMAIN
description: West Germany, France and Italy are scrambling to join forces to combat a makeshift alliance of Marxist-inspired terrorist gangs that recognizes no borders in Western Europe. The sudden emergence of what is being called ''Euroterrorism'' has caught some countries by surprise - and at odds.

title: BRIDGE REPAIR: LOSING BATTLE
description: A TWO-FOOT piece of concrete that fell from a bridge on Route 17 in Rochelle Park last September ''left a very noticeable dent on Central Avenue,'' recalls John P. Sullivan, one of the police officers who found the slab.

title: Jet Fighter Crash in Arizona Kills Pilot and Sets Off Blasts
description: An Air Force jet fighter believed to be carrying live ammunition crashed into a cliff in a rainstorm today, killing the pilot, officials said.

description: Nancy van Vlissingen lives in Norwalk.

title: GUITAR: DAVID ZIEGLER
description: David Ziegler, the young American guitarist, studied in Spain and made a well-received recital debut in New York not long ago. Mr. Ziegler played again in New York Wednesday night, this time at CAMI Hall and with only intermittent success.

title: SLANEY, IN LEAD, DROPS OUT
description: It was almost a repeat of last summer's Olympics in Los Angeles, where Mary Decker, the world champion, fell and was injured in the women's 3,000-meter final. Tonight, in the 16th annual Vitalis/U.S. Olympic Invitational indoor track meet, Mary Decker Slaney was leading in the 1,500-meter final when she suffered a cramp in her right calf, dropped out in tears, and had to be carried off by her husband of six weeks, Richard Slaney.

title: Iran Lowers Oil Prices Closer to OPEC Levels
description: Iran has lowered its oil prices in line with those recently approved by the majority of members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, the Middle East Economic Survey reported today.
To them, talking must sound like a kind of purring, which, of course, it is.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Young people are looking for short-term payoffs.'' - Bruce Zimmer, executive director of the Law School Admission Council, discussing declining enrollments. (50:1.)

title: FONDUE: A SWISS CLASSIC
description: A Slightly Wicked View of the Holy See'' (Congdon & Weed).

title: SUING GOVERNMENT: A CURRENT CASE MAY AFFECT RULES
description: A CASE now before the State Supreme Court may be instrumental in making it easier - or more difficult - to win suits against the government.

title: KOCH ASSAILS CUTS IN FEDERAL BUDGET
description: Led by Mayor Koch, a parade of prominent New Yorkers yesterday asked a panel of visiting Congressmen to spare the state from drastic cuts in the proposed 1986 Federal budget.

title: KELLY STRESSES OLYMPIC NEEDS
description: John B. Kelly Jr. called it ''the threshold of a great adventure.'' George Miller talked about ''a new beginning for our Olympic movement.''

title: EXPERT ADVICE ON VALENTINE'S DAY GIVING
description: TO some people, love is blind, and on Valentine's Day many romantics reach blindly for chocolates or flowers for gifts for their lovers. But Dr. Robert J. Sternberg, an expert on love, says people can do better.

title:
INVESTING;

THE PREDICTIONS OF A MARKET TIMER
description: FOR years, institutional investors have rated Robert J. Farrell, chief market analyst at Merrill Lynch & Company, as the top market timer on Wall Street. But even he was caught off guard by the locomotive-like market of January. ''I was bullish about the year but thought we wouldn't start off well,'' he said candidly last week. ''So I was fooled by that rushing out in January.''

title:
ANTIQUES;

WINDHAM SHOW STILL A FAVORITE
description: WHEN the first Windham Antiques Show was produced 25 years ago, it featured 15 dealers who set up their booths in the local fire company hall. Some exhibits were perilously close to the fire engines; those dealers kept fingers crossed against the possibility fire trucks would be called out. They feared the attendant vibrations might cause old glass to fall.

title: NEW ART, NEW MONEY
description: Cathleen McGuigan writes on the arts and entertainment for Newsweek.

title: Cary Chapin Wed To James Stanley
description: At Christ's Episcopal Church in Rye, N.Y., yesterday Cary Neil Chapin, a daughter of Mrs. Lincoln Stevenson of Rye and Neil Chapin Jr. of Sarasota, Fla., was married to James Charles Stanley, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George Stanley of East Norwalk, Conn. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Edward Johnston, assisted by the Rev. Eugene J. O'Brien, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Women's Literary Tradition
description: To the Editor:

title: THE DEAD AND THE DEAF
description: It was just a year ago that Yuri Andropov died in Moscow. For the last month, his successor as General Secretary of the Soviet Communist Party, Konstantin U. Chernenko, has disappeared from public view. So the rumors fly like snowflakes around the capitals of the world, but nobody knows where or how he is.

title: CASINO OFFICIALS DENY BRIBING BAHAMIAN LEADER
description: Officials of Resorts International this week denied channeling bribes to the Prime Minister of the Bahamas. The company operates a casino in that nation.

description: NEW BRUNSWICK JUST a few weeks after this observer cited the Crossroads Theatre Company for a consistent burst of energy and quality, what does the company do?

title: No Headline
description: House Sharing: Things Have Changed I'm glad to see that times have changed (''House Sharing: A Growing Trend,'' Dec. 30). I remember sharing a large house on Long Island with other adults 12 years ago and receiving a far different image from the media and from the neighbors.

title:
CAMERA;

RECENT ADVANCES AID HOME COLOR PRINTING
description: Bob Nadler is a freelance writer and photographer. Until recently, making color prints at home required hours of painstaking darkroom work. Called C-prints, if made from negatives, and R-prints, if made from slides, five chemical steps were needed to process a C-print and eight to process an R-print. No wonder a myth grew up around home color printing that frightened off all but the bravest.

title: Scott Newquist And Aileen Mix Exchange Vows
description: At Central Presbyterian Church in New York yesterday Aileen Katherine Mix, the daughter of Mary Ellen Murphy Mix of Bedminster, N.J., and Nantucket, Mass., and Earl Benjamin Mix Jr. of Basking Ridge, N.J., was married to Scott Crawford Newquist, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lester J. Newquist of Scarsdale, N.Y. The Rev. Katherine Hoffman performed the ceremony.

description: THE small tradesman, often the only personal businessman many of us deal with on a name basis in this world of multinational corporations and supermarkets, is a vanishing breed, they say, but sometimes his vanishing is a little too quick for me to absorb.

description: David Wolper, a Confederate kepi on his desk, told the Warner Brothers publicists assembled in his office that he wanted the initial news releases about his latest mini-series, ''North and South,'' to stress its historical setting in the years before the Civil War.

title: Birds Killed to Stop Disease
description: Federal officials who killed 2,000 birds at a warehouse where a contagious tropical disease was found said Thursday that they hoped it ended the threat to the state's $250 million poultry industry. The threat began last month in Tampa when a parakeet was found to be infected with Newcastle's disease.

title: ATTRACTING PARENTS
description: Three years ago, the Daniel Webster Elementary School in New Rochelle changed its curriculum to focus on humanities, thus becoming a magnet school attracting pupils from all over the city of 73,000 people. Tomorrow at 8 P.M., in anticipation of its fourth year of operations, the school is having an open house to explain its program to prospective parents.

description: A 20- month-old boy being treated at the research hospital run by the National Institutes of Health died last month after hospital personnel gave him an intravenous solution containing an excessive amount of salt, an official there said Friday.

description: To the Editor: I was delighted to read Elaine Block's article on misericords in European churches, ''A Hidden Pageant From Medieval Life'' (Travel, Dec. 30).

title: No Headline
description: When Police Revolt In his book, ''Mayor,'' this is how Mayor Koch recalls the conclusion of New York City's 1980 transit strike, in which he faced down a tough municipal union: ''People jaywalked across avenues to shake my hand and thank me for standing up. New Yorkers were in a kind of euphoria that weekend. They had been called upon to run the gantlet, and they had done it with style.''

description: MIKHAIL BAKHTIN: THE DIALOGICAL PRINCIPLE

title: SPRINGFIELD EASES STIFF SCHOOL ACTIVITIES RULE
description: There was jubilation at Springfield's four high schools Friday after more than 150 students barred from extracurricular activities for having low grades were reinstated when the requirements were relaxed.

title: Peking Official Yields To Student Demands
description: China's Education Minister has admitted that some student protests against bad food and bad teaching are justified, China Daily reported today.

title: Elizabeth Balding To Marry in April
description: Announcement has been made by Barbara Whitney Balding and Bruce Edward Balding, both of Locust Valley, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Balding, to William Fredrick Ruprecht, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Ruprecht of St. Louis. An April wedding is planned.

description: Still finding novelty in his hot streaks, Mike Bossy, after two more goals, said, ''It's great, it never stops being great.''

title: DUARTE PROTESTS REPORTS THAT U.S. FAVORS RIGHTISTS
description: President Jose Napoleon Duarte said Friday that he would complain to the United States Embassy here concerning reports that American officials had openly favored a victory for Mr. Duarte's conservative opponents in coming legislative elections.

title: NEW DISK BRINGS A GRATIFYING 'ELIJAH'
description: Mendelssohn's ''Elijah'' had an extraordinary popularity from its premiere in 1846 until the first half of this century. Even today the oratorio is beloved by a large audience, and it was significant that the New York Philharmonic's four performances in 1979 sold out well in advance. So it is somewhat surprising that it has not been recorded very often. The Schwann catalogue lists only three albums and a one-disk set of excerpts. Now there is an able new version on the Erato label (NUM 751473, three disks). It bears the title ''Elias,'' using the German text, which Mendelssohn set first, although the premiere was given in English in England. Michel Corboz, the Swiss conductor, leads the Choirs and Orchestra of the Gulbenkian Foundation in Lisbon, and the soloists are Edith Wiens, soprano; Carolyn Watkinson, alto; Keith Lewis, tenor, and Benjamin Luxon, baritone.

title: Peace Movement
description: Wayne Peace, a quarterback for the Tampa Bay Bandits until he was traded to the Portland Breakers last Wednesday, abruptly left the Breakers' training camp in Pomona, Calif., Friday and said he would not play in the United States Football League again. He indicated that he would try to win a berth with the Cincinnati Bengals, who own the National Football League rights to his services.

title: AN ACTOR EXPLORES THE FOURTH ESTATE
description: At the scene of a bloody double murder in North Miami last spring, Kurt Russell had a jolting introduction to the seamier side of journalism.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: Rod Steiger won an Oscar for the 1967 ''In the Heat of the Night,'' also voted the best picture. It will be shown Wednesday at 8 P.M. on Channel 11. In accepting his earlier award by the New York Film Critics, the actor said, ''I couldn't have done this part without the understanding and encouragement of my co-star Sidney.'' Nearby, Mr. Poitier looked on, smiling.

title: CHINA ASSAILS U.S. ON POPULATION FUNDS
description: A Chinese official protested the Reagan Administration's decision to withhold a $23 million contribution to the United Nations Fund for Population Activities today, saying the action was ''unreasonable'' and based on false information about China's birth-control policies.

title: UPSTATE COUNTY SETTLES SUIT ON HELPING HOMELESS
description: A lawsuit that sought to force Orange County officials to furnish emergency shelter for the homeless was resolved this week in State Supreme Court here.

title: A WAR BETWEEN THE TASTES

title: No Headline
description: Splurging Youngsters: A Further View The letter of Charles J. Press (Letters to the Long Island Editor, Jan. 13), which decries ''sweeping generalizations'' and a ''stereotype'' of the ''Jewish American Princess,'' and that of Norma C. Senzer (Jan. 20), which recoils at the ''disservice to the Jews of Great Neck'' and others, overreact to the Dec. 16 article ''They Go Shopping, Browsing, Splurging.'' I submit that more damage may have been done to their apparent cause by their comments than by the article.

title: THE RIGHT PLACE FOR FINESSE MAY NOT BE THE FOOTBALL FIELD
description: IT may be time to vacate my premises. Not the apartment I live in, but the assumptions I live by. Either that, or risk a fight with a guy who flattens people for a living.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

AT THE CAPITOL, A RUSH TO KEEP THE PUBLIC ENLIGHTENED
description: THE State Bond Commission, of which Governor O'Neill is a member, is meeting. Outside, a small group of reporters have gathered, waiting for the Governor.

title: DAYS OF CLUBBING SEAL PUPS APPEAR TO BE OVER IN CANADA
description: The commercial clubbing of whitecoated harp seal pups in Canada, which has touched off protests around the world, seems to have ended, sealers and their opponents say.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: STATE SENATOR Daniel J. Dalton says that an ''unfair share'' of cleanup money in Governor Kean's Environmental Trust Fund proposal would come directly or indirectly from taxpayers instead of from ''violators of our hazardous-waste laws,'' and he plans to turn the tables.

title: PHILLIPS AND ICAHN PREPARE FOR A FIGHT
description: Phillips Petroleum is fighting for its life again, this time against Carl C. Icahn. Phillips, characterizing Mr. Icahn as a ''notorious takeover entrepreneur and greenmailer,'' is fighting the bid every way it can - with a new recapitalization plan, for example, and a ''poison pill'' that would require Mr. Icahn to pay as much as $1.5 billion above his original $8.1 billion bid. But Mr. Icahn, indicating he just might swallow the poison pill, continued to lock horns with Phillips. Analysts say that Phillips, still recovering from a bid by T. Boone Pickens just two months ago, may be too weak to fight for long, and may soon have to find a friendly suitor.

title: LABOR'S GRAND ILLUSIONS
description: THE TIME OF RECKoning is at hand. Eight days hence, when 35 chief potentates of organized labor gather around a square of gold-topped tables in Bal Harbour, Fla., to establish priorities for the year ahead, they will be confronted by the consequences of a high-stakes gamble gone wrong. Their losing bet on the Presidential campaign of Walter F. Mondale was the most intense and costly political drive in union history. It was also a fateful warning that, unless organized labor begins to change its ways, and soon, the union movement may not be able to halt its three-decade-long downhill slide, becoming ever more irrelevant to its membership and to the political leadership of the nation.

title: MILITARY
description: To the Editor:

title: A FLURRY OF NEW TAX RULES FOR 1985
description: CAUGHT in a blizzard of paperwork to prepare their 1984 returns, few taxpayers have the energy to worry about their 1985 tax bills this early in the game. But a host of new tax rules were rung in with the new year, and those who take steps now may be able to save money by maximizing the benefit - or minimizing the damage - caused by the changes.

title: REVUE: 'OFFBEATS!,' SPOOF
description: ''Offbeats!,'' the living-room revue that has settled into Michael's Pub for an open-ended engagement, is a lighter-than-air topical spoof that was titled ''Corkscrews!'' in its earlier incarnations. Revived at the club with some updated material, the show is being performed by its creators - the writer and lyricist Tony Lang, the director Miriam Fond, and the pianist Arthur Siegel.

title: ON THE WAY OUT: OUTDOOR NEON SIGNS
description: Vegas Vic, the huge, neon cowboy in front of the Pioneer Club here, still waves his arm and flips his cigarette up and down as he greets strollers with a drawling ''Howdy, pardner.''

title: TOP SCORER KEEPS GOALS IN FOCUS ON AND OFF COURT
description: TO the young men she played against during her summers on the playgrounds of Brooklyn, she was known as ''Little Schoolgirl.'' Now, Anucha Browne is an engaging and articulate 6-foot-1-inch, 165-pound senior at Northwestern University who is the nation's leading scorer in women's Division I basketball. But she has not forgotten to give credit where credit is due.

title: KASPAROV DEFEATS CHAMPION IN 2D STRAIGHT CHESS VICTORY
description: Gary Kasparov scored his second consecutive victory in the 48th game of the world championship chess match yesterday in Moscow.

title: REAL-LIFE ESPIONAGE TAKES TO THE STAGE
description: E.M. Forster once wrote that if he were forced to choose between betraying his country and betraying his friends, he prayed he would have the courage to betray his country.

title: WHEN COUNTING CALORIES FISH MAY BE THE GUILTLESS ANSWER
description: AMONG the many depressing things about this time of year - apart from cold weather, flu and taxes - is calorie counting. Everyone, it seems, is compensating for overindulgence during the holidays. In restaurants it is now de rigueur for half the customers to order nothing but fish - ''broiled dry,'' accompanied by a glass of mineral water and perhaps a salad that has no dressing on it.

title: ADMINISTRATION IS ASSAILED ON RIVERS
description: The growth of the nation's Wild and Scenic River System has slowed dramatically under the Reagan Administration.

title: BUILDING BOOM TRANSFORMS EDISON
description: THREE weeks ago, the engineers, draftsmen, clerks and executives of the Heyward-Robinson Company could look out of their windows on the 94th and 95th floors of the World Trade Center in lower Manhattan on a clear day and see across the lower harbor into Middlesex County.

title: OUTDOORS ;   Auction of Shop A Lure to Anglers
description: ACCORDING to those who are arranging the affair, fishermen from as far away as California will be on hand for the March 22-23 tag sale and public auction of the contents of Anglers' Roost, the late Jim Deren's Manhattan tackle shop.

title: Costs at Brown Up $1,100
description: Tuition and living expenses at Brown University in the next school year will increase $1,100, 8 percent, to just under $15,000, the Brown University Corporation said today. The school's governing body set tuition and fees for the 1985-86 school year at $14,765.

title: ALLIES BACK 'STAR WARS' STUDIES, NOT DEPLOYMENT
description: Most Government officials in Western Europe favor continued research on President Reagan's proposed ballistic missile defense system, but they are overwhelmingly opposed to its deployment, according to a survey by the Congressional Research Service.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER/BRAILLE VOLUNTEERS
description: SCATTERED throughout this county are people who are engaged in a venerable activity, carrying on a venerable tradition. In an age when volunteerism is on the wane, they are volunteers. In an age when even the simplest tasks are accomplished with high technology, they are doing something painstakingly precise by hand.

title: PRISONER FIGHTS MURDER CONVICTION
description: WOODBRIDGE ''WHY me?'' Jimmy Landano asked. ''I don't know. All I know is that I've been in prison for nine years.''

title: STOCKMAN TOOK HIS SHOT, AN IT'S STILL RICOCHETING
description: WASHINGTON

title: DEBATE GROWS ON PROPOSAL FOR A 3 PERCENT HOTEL TAX
description: ''THE first time we tried to get a hotel-occupancy tax,'' said Edward J. Brady, Chairman of the County Board of Legislators, ''it was approved unanimously.'' But it died in Albany, where approval also was needed, he said, ''because the hotels did their lobbying.''

title: ANN FLANDERS: NEW FASHION VOICE
description: It was 4 P.M., and things were beginning to stir at Details, the irreverent, avant- garde fashion magazine that is making waves in New York City. Sitting in her office, near a desk holding a bouquet of purple daisies and four bottles of vitamin pills, was Annie Flanders, the editor and publisher, and she was ready to go to work.

title: NANCY COLEMAN PLANS WEDDING
description: Mr. and Mrs. Martin S. Coleman of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter Nancy M. Coleman to Dr. Medwin Matthew Mintzis, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Irving Mintzis of New York. The wedding is planned for June.

description: Unable to make much of an impression in the Democratic-controlled Assembly, the small Republican minority has formed a ''study group'' to try to attract public support for changes in legislative practice.

description: THE Federal Environmental Protection Agency has approved a request from the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation to allocate money from its $1.6 billion Superfund program in order to provide town water to residents of Sag Harbor whose wells have been contaminated by toxic chemicals.

description: ONE of the main benefits of the Omnibus Housing Act of 1983 - the ability of new tenants to learn promptly whether they are being charged a legal rent - has become a reality, but in a way that many tenants did not expect.

description: A New Jersey appeals court has upheld the constitutionality of a state law requiring a defendant who claims a defense of diminished mental capacity to prove his mind was diseased or defective.

description: The new production of Wagner's ''Tristan and Isolde'' - the ''and'' is correct here, since the performance is given in Andrew Porter's translation - currently on view at the English National Opera, is of interest for two principal reasons beyond the purely esthetic pleasure it provides.

description: Grover Mitchell's 12-piece band, which was formed to provide work for some of Count Basie's musicians when the Basie Band was taking frequent rests during the last few years of the Count's life, is at Lush Life through tonight with performers who are now independent of the Basie Band.

title: Lasting Horrors Of Dr. Mengele
description: Four decades after the fact, Nazi SS doctor Josef Mengele was indicted anew last week for crimes no amount of time will diminish. His accusers were his victims, the maimed and brutalized of Auschwitz, who gathered before a board of inquiry in Jerusalem on the 40th anniversary of the death camp's liberation to testify about the grotesque human experiments performed by the man they called the ''Angel of Death.''

title: MIGRATION SLOWING, STUDY SUGGESTS
description: The Northeast's widely reported population loss may be slowing while the West is attracting fewer new residents, a new study of Government statistics indicates.

title:
THE LIVELY ARTS;

SPREADING THE JOY OF RAGTIME
description: FOR a college professor whose academic specialty is communications, Dave Jasen is uncharacteristically inarticulate when it comes to explaining what it is about ragtime music that has made him devote a great deal of his life to studying, performing and perpetuating this precursor of popular jazz.

DINING OUT;

A TASTE OF INDIA IN MONTCLAIR
description: APPEARANCES are often misleading, particularly where restaurants are concerned. For example, the Taj Palace, a year-old Indian restaurant in Montclair, gives the appearance of being a well-ordered, attractively simple restaurant where the service should be beyond reproach.

title: THE EDUCATION SECRETARY'S MAIN TASK
description: On Wednesday, the Senate confirmed William J. Bennett as Secretary of Education. A few days earlier, President Reagan acknowledged that he no longer planned to abolish the Cabinet-level agency he had chosen Mr. Bennett to lead, even though it is a department he never liked and once hoped to wipe out.

title: JEWISH SETTLERS ARE PUT AT 42,500
description: The total number of Jewish settlers in the West Bank has reached 42,500, many more than most previous estimates, according to a new study just completed.

title: AN APARTHEID FOE CONFIRMS RUMORS

title: 'TAMED REBELS' MAKE GOOD MANAGERS
description: WHAT makes an effective corporate leader? Among other qualities, leaders have an overriding faith in themselves and their own ability to succeed - a faith that may defy the practical odds, in fact. And with this faith, leaders seem to be characterized by a higher degree of ego development than that of the average person. Yet, successful managers do not attain the highest order of ego development - which may be just as well for their corporations.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN SANTE FE?
description: Although Santa Fe is best known for its summer attractions, its location at 7,000 feet in the foothills of the Rocky Mountains also makes it an excellent winter vacation spot, particularly for devotees of skiing and various apres-ski activities.

title: DELI? HE'S SLICED IT; COMEDY? HE'S WRITTEN IT
description: ''USUALLY the most creative thing a writer does is figuring out why not to write or what to do instead of writing,'' said Alan Zweibel.

title: CUOMO ASKS MORE IN 1984-85 BUDGET
description: An inaccurate forecast of welfare costs and last month's huge snowstorm in Buffalo were among items cited by Governor Cuomo in asking legislative approval to add $231.4 million in spending to the current state budget.

title:
ART;

HOFSTRA'S HERITAGE OF FACULTY ART SHOWN
description: HOFSTRA UNIVERSITY'S 50th anniversary has prompted a number of commemorative events. The Emily Lowe Gallery, which functions as the campus art museum, is inaugurating its year of tribute with a fairly lively survey exhibition intended to highlight past members of the fine arts faculty who have achieved a degree of distinction.

title: Karen Clark Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Don C. Clark of Convent Station, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter Karen Leigh Clark to David Michael Brush, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Douglas Brush of Huntington, L.I. Miss Clark and her fiance both graduated in 1982 from the University of Pennsylvania. She is an assistant vice president with IDD Information Services in New York. He is a senior financial analyst with the Phildelphia National Bank.

title: EXPANDING ON MINIMALIST MUSIC
description: ''Minimalism'' in music derived from the minimalist visual arts of the 1960's. Theoretically, the term should apply to any music with sharply reduced elements - the glacially unfolding scores of Morton Feldman, for instance, or Alvin Lucier's eerily pure electronic tapestries.

title: My Life As a Wrong Number
description: I empathized with Bruce Weber's account of his experiences of living in a city in which a more celebrated person has an identical name (''My Life as a Wrong Number,'' Jan. 6). In the District of Columbia area, where I live, the other Bob Rosenthal is a major auto dealer, with numerous outlets in Washington, Maryland and Virginia.

title: GRACE NOTES
description: ONCE, I SAW A FAMILY MENU BOOK THAT HAD BEEN HANDWRITten - in the form of a musical score - by the great Brazilian composer Heitor Villa-Lobos. The ''score'' related to his country's national dish known as feijoada. It had various sections: one marked meat, one rice, another black beans, and so on, each a component of the dish.

title: Zola Budd Sets Mark in 3,000 COSFORD, England, Feb. 9
description: South African-born running star Zola Budd set a British and Commonwealth record for the 3,000 meters today in her international indoor debut for Britain.

title: No Headline
description: Bellcore Proposal Called Ill-Advised The Jan. 27 article about the plans of Bell Communications Research (Bellcore) to build laboratories in the Morristown area where toxic and explosive gases would be stored and used was the most comprehensive on the subject I have seen.

title: Former Steelworkers To Win Severance Pay
description: Workers laid off by the the United States Steel Corporation two or more years ago when their plants permanently closed are to receive severance pay, according to an arbitrator's ruling.

title: WHEN A CONDUCTOR SUBLIMATES HIS EGO TO AN ARTISTIC GOAL
description: Heidi Waleson writes frequently about music and musicians.

title: SMASH THE JUDGES
description: California conservatives, successful in so many elections lately, have picked out their big target for 1986. They will try to remove from the bench three or four of the seven justices on the State Supreme Court.

title: FILM PORTRAIT OF A POLISH GENERATION
description: Six years ago, Wojciech Marczewski returned to Poland after a week-long visit to the United States with the idea for a new film burned into his soul. But given the Polish Government's rigid censorship and harsh treatment of dissent at that time, his idea seemed to be a pipedream, and dangerous in the bargain. ''Such a film,'' he says, ''had no chance of being accepted. My colleagues said I was crazy, that it was my kamikaze film.''

title:
MANAGING CREATIVE PEOPLE;

A SECOND WAY TO THE TOP
description: ANDREW HELLER is the type of employee I.B.M. wants to keep. He was one of the prime researchers on the large-scale I.B.M. 3033 and the PC/XT and has come up with several patentable ideas.

title: Fight Death, Not Life
description: To the Editor:

title: CONCERT: ARGENTO WORK AT CARNEGIE
description: Neville Marriner brought the Minnesota Orchestra to Carnegie Hall Friday with a sample of the new American music he has been commissioning and encouraging: ''Casa Guidi,'' five letters from Elizabeth Barrett Browning to her sister, written from a house in Florence, set to music for Frederica von Stade and orchestra by Dominick Argento.

title: Freighter at Mansion Dragged Closer to Sea
description: A freighter beached behind a mansion was dragged another 10 feet out to sea today, giving Mollie Wilmot, who owns the mansion, her first clear view of the ocean since Thanksgiving.

title: Strong Dollar
description: To the Editor:

title: CABARET ACT: LEE ROY REAMS
description: Lee Roy Reams, the song-and- dance man who originated the role of Billy Lawlor in the Broadway production of ''42d Street,'' has put together an engaging autobiographical cabaret act that is all about a young man from Covington, Ky., who grows up hopelessly smitten with the Great White Way. After coming to New York and winning roles in shows like ''Applause,'' ''Lorelei'' and ''Hello, Dolly!'' the young performer is enough of a success to be able to buy his mother a mink coat.

title: DRIVEN; Saturnalia
description: General Motors has set off a kind of gold rush with its announcement of a new division to produce a new car, the Saturn. But it's a dignified sort of rush, befitting the offices of those involved: governors.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

LET'S HEAR IT FOR THE DANDELION
description: MY sons and I were walking down the main street of Ridgefield a year ago when my 7-year-old burst out, ''Look, Dad!''

title: POSTWAR COMPOSITIONS HAVE NOT ENJOYED GREAT STAYING POWER
description: If there are such things as watershed dates in history,

title: NICARAGUA SAYS ITS FISCAL SHAPE IS 'HELLISH'
description: The Government has announced a 78 percent devaluation of the currency and warned Nicaraguans that ''new sacrifices'' would be required to overcome the country's economic crisis.

title: FUTURE OF A BELLEVUE SITE IS STILL AT ISSUE AFTER 7 YEARS
description: MEMBERS of the Koch administration are talking enthusiastically these days about the potential of land in the Bellevue Hospital complex in the East 20's for new market-rate housing.

title: Four More Years To Make Us Mad
description: To the Editor:

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS Feb. 10, 1985Fiction*1
description: ALMOST PARADISE, by Susan Isaacs. (Ballantine, $4.95.) Three generations of show-biz people play out their destinies on two continents. *2

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;

BEAUTY AND BRAINS
description: ACCORDING to the Roman writer Petronius, ''beauty and wisdom are rarely conjoined.'' But Petronius, of course, could not have known about Westchester where, on Feb. 17, an evening conference designed to share wisdom gained in running local beautification programs will be held.

title: THE WAIT IS WORTH IT
description: DINING at Peter Cheng's in New Haven forces you to determine your dining priorities. If you want to enjoy some of the most remarkable Chinese food you will find in any Chinese restaurant in Connecticut, then welcome! Here the food is the star. This is not a place of candlelight, fresh flowers on a well-napped table, or seductive decor. It is just the opposite. The decor is nondescript, there are long delays between courses and the entire dinner can stretch to two and a half hours.

title: MUSIC: TAFELMUSIK GROUP
description: Tafelmusik, the Toronto-based Baroque orchestra directed by Jean Lamon, makes a persuasive case for the original-instrument approach to 18th-century music.

title: PCB-LADEN OFFICES TO BE VENTILATED
description: For four years, the Binghamton State Office Building, in the middle of this city's downtown business district, has been closed and sealed because of a 1981 electrical fire that spread dioxin and a variety of other toxic chemicals throughout its 18 floors.

title: ;   Indonesia
description: To the Editor: I read with nostalgia your two articles on Indonesia (Travel, Dec. 9). My visit to Java pre

title: Revisionist Baseball
description: Baseball was invented by Alexander Cartwright in New York City, and anybody who doesn't believe it can appeal a ruling issued last week by the Court of Historical Review in San Francisco.

title: FINDING CRUISE BARGAINS
description: Never before in cruise history has there been such discounting as this year. The reason is that many operators of passenger liners are suffering badly because of miscalculations made toward the end of the 1970's. As a result, a huge assortment of bargains is available to coax people aboard.

title: A May Wedding For Susan Eddy
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Harrison P. Eddy 3d of New York and Pleasant Valley, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter Susan J. Eddy to Carl S. Goldfischer, a son of Sidney L. Goldfischer and the late Mrs. Goldfischer of Great Neck, L.I. The wedding is planned for May 11.

title: On Developing All One's Gifts
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: MULLIN HAS 21 AS REDMEN RALLY TO BEAT VILLANOVA
description: Villanova cannot be blamed for thinking there is a touch of the ghost in Chris Mullin. In two games against the Wildcats this season, St. John's all- America senior has seemed to disappear in the first half, only to reappear at a crucial point in the second half and do something otherworldly.

title: American and Four Japanese To Share the Hammer Prize
description: One American and three Japanese scientists will share the $100,000 Hammer Prize for their research and discoveries in the adult T-cell leukemia virus.

title: DROPOUT PROGRAM STRESSES JOBS
description: -year-old from Yonkers, did not like to get up in the morning. So he often missed school, which, he said, ''didn't interest me.'' Two months ago, he dropped out.

title: VENICE'S FORTUNY MUSEUM
description: BARBARA L. MICHAELS is an art historian who teaches at New York University.

title: Water Witching
description: The art of water witching, or dowsing, was put to the test in New York State's North Country in November.

title:
THE REGION;

Falsely Accused, Gross Declares
description: During the preparation of a series of articles in The New York Times on his conduct as New York City's Chief Medical Examiner, Dr. Elliot M. Gross declined many times to discuss specific cases in detail. Last week, however, after the publication of the articles, Dr. Gross called a news conference to dispute allegations that he had produced inaccurate or misleading autopsy reports.

title: CHURCHES OFFERING AN ARRAY OF CONCERTS
description: MUSIC lovers who go to church only for services are missing some fine concert bets. At the First Congregational Church in Old Greenwich, for instance, the second annual ''Sunday Afternoons Live'' series is already under way in the candlelight setting of the auditorium.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS ;
description: Intelligence AideTestifies AgainstWestmoreland

title: Dori Susan Fromer Is Married to Harley J. Frank
description: Dori Susan Fromer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Michael Fromer of New York, was married yesterday to Harley J. Frank, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Frank of New York. Rabbi Israel Miller, senior vice president of Yeshiva University, performed the ceremony at the Pierre hotel.

title: COMPENSATION OF TEACHERS EXPLORED
description: WHILE salaries are considered a major factor in teacher compensation, a recent meeting of the Westchester-Putnam School Boards Association suggested that other issues must also be addressed, including recruiting and keeping teachers, working conditions and job satisfaction. Albert Shanker, president of the American Federation of Teachers, and Louis Grumet, executive director of the New York State School Boards Association, shared the podium to explore the question: ''Teacher Compensation . . . Is It More Than Pay?''

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
description: SHAGGY DOG STORY

title: John Henry Voted Top Horse by a Nose
description: All that the presenter could say after opening the envelope was ''Like old wine. . .'' and then the packed ballroom at the Century Plaza Hotel in Los Angeles erupted with cheers. John Henry, the 10-year-old gelding who has made a career of winning photo finishes, had won another to be named the Horse of the Year for 1984.

title: Pump to Assist Heart Is Modified for Infants
description: A balloon pump designed to ease strain on the heart after cardiac surgery has been modified to work in infants, a doctor says.

title:
DINING OUT;

HARMONY, ELEGANCE IN THE EXURBS
description: MAXIME RIBERA has weathered the difficulties that go with the territory when one opens an exurban restaurant and has emerged with a harmonious establishment. The homey, provincial dining rooms are at once elegant and comfortable. Heavy swag draperies, what must be a totem of elephant miniatures and a magnificently tall and stately flower arrangement helped fill the space attractively. Impeccably appointed tables bear green frosted-glass bowls like melted tallow in which deep pink and purple daisies float. Service is helpful, efficient and courteous, and the food an inspired balance of classic French cuisine sparked by nouvelle touches.

title: University Grants Refunds
description: The University of Pittsburgh has granted tuition refunds to nine students who complained they could not understand the English spoken by their foreign- born instructors. John Bolvin, dean of the university's College of General Studies, said the school's policy was to refund tuition to students who could not understand their teachers and were unable to enroll in another course. Tuition is $88.

title: CONSUMER RATES
Chinese Hotels
description: To the Editor:

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;

LAW IGNORES THE REALITIES OF SCHOOL LIFE
description: THE recent United States Supreme Court decision granting school officials the power to search students and their personal effects ''when there are reasonable grounds for suspecting that the search will turn up evidence that the student has violated, or is violating, either the law or the rules of the school'' represents a setback for the Fourth Amendment and will materially harm the learning environment in New Jersey's public schools.

title: LIQUOR RETAILERS SPLIT ON REGULATION
description: IF THE impact of recent sales declines on New Jersey's liquor industry is a squall, the big guy

title: AGAINST DOMESTICATION
description: DOMINANCE AND AFFECTION

title: Martin Niemoller
description: To the Editor:

title: ARTIST SET FOR STATUE OF GRASSO AT CAPITOL
description: -raising efforts, the Ella Grasso Memorial Statue Committee has commissioned an artist to create a 7 1/2-foot-tall likeness of the late Governor for the Capitol.

title: Channel Traffic Resumes
description: Ferry traffic across the English Channel returned to normal today after unionized seamen on French-flag ferries of the Sealink company resumed work. The strike began Thursday when sailors belonging to the Communist-led C.G.T. union protested plans to change work schedules. They agreed to return to work after Guy Lengagne, France's Secretary of State for the sea, intervened.

title: CORNELL TO STOP GUARANTEEING FULL AID FOR STUDENTS IN NEED
description: Citing a large projected gap between funds and student need, Cornell University said it was planning to end its policy of guaranteeing students that it would meet their requirements for financial aid.

title: Frederic Johnson, Aide To Judge Crater in '30
description: Frederic A. Johnson, the last law secretary to Judge Joseph F. Crater and the lawyer who handled one of the earliest legal challenges to baseball's reserve clause, died Thursday at St. Clare's Hospital. He was 90 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: FATHERS PLAYING CATCH WITH SONS: Essays on Sport (Mostly Baseball). By Donald Hall. (North Point, Paper,$13.50)

title: 'WINTERREISE' RECEIVES AN OPERATIC PERFORMANCE
description: More than most performers, Jon Vickers makes a critic timid about discusing musical details. This titan among singers seems simply not to move in the wretched sphere of sharps and flats and quarter notes. It is utterly impossible to picture him at work in the studio practicing scales and vocalises. Musical preparation, one often feels, begins for him straight off with the struggle of man's relationship to God or the nature of evil and forgiveness, with things like memorizing the rhythms or working on a tough high note somehow subsumed unconsciously in the exalted process.

title: IDEA OF SHUTTING FIRE-TRUCK PLANT SADDENS ELMIRA
description: Once a hub for blue-collar workers and ''gray iron'' industries, this city is now hard- pressed by factory shutdowns, layoffs and the highest unemployment rate in the state.

title: EMIGRES FROM IRAN BEGIN LIFE ANEW IN AMERICA
description: Brig. Gen. Mansour Ardalan, retired, recalls with pride the days when he commanded the Iranian Air Force's First Transport Base in Teheran.

title: Players 2, Expos 1
description: Less than a week after the start of baseball's arbitration season, Montreal players have jumped to a 2-1 lead over the Expos' management. Two pitchers,

title: RISING RENTS LEAD RETAILERS TO BUY BUILDINGS
description: -term leases of five store owners in a large building on Fulton Street in downtown Brooklyn will expire with no chance of renewal, and all will have to move. It is a scenario common throughout the the city, except that this one has a twist: The landlord is also a retailer, a department store that made its first realty investment two years ago when it bought the building.

title: Q AND A
description: Question:

title: RITA FLIEGEL IS MARRIED TO DAVID KESTER, ACTOR
description: Rita Fliegel, the daughter of Carmine Balish of Forest Hills, Queens, and the late Manfried Fliegel, was married yesterday to David L. Kester, a son of the Rev. and Mrs. Lee L. Kester Jr. of Hasbrouck Heights, N.J. Rabbi Bruce A. Goldman performed the ceremony at the Laughing Mountain Restaurant in Manhattan. He was assisted by the bridegroom's father, a retired Reformed Church minister.

title: British Army Defuses Big World War II Bomb
description: British Army bomb experts today defused a one-ton bomb - one of the biggest dropped on England during World War II - but the police said it was still unstable and posed a threat to homes in the area.

title: HUNTING FOR CREATIVE MINDS
description: LAST November, J. Walter Thompson ran a full-page newspaper ad asking would-be copywriters to mail in seven writing samples. The agency still is culling through the 800 replies it received, in hopes that maybe a dozen effective copywriters will surface.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: Audiences at Dance Theater Workshop's Bessie Sch"onberg Theater can visit three eras of dance history this week. Sunday at 3 P.M. and Monday at 8 P.M., the New York Baroque Dance Company, with Regine Astier as guest artist, presents ''Les Caract eres de la Danse,'' with music by Concert Royal. The production concerns the rivalry between Marie Salle and Marie- Anne Camargo, two French ballerinas of the 18th century, and to lend authenticity to this look at the past, great attention has been paid to period makeup, masks, wigs and headdresses.

title: ANDROPOV AND HIS POLICIES PRAISED BY SOVIET
description: The Soviet Union paid glowing tribute to Yuri V. Andropov today, on the first anniversary of his death, confirming his niche in official Soviet history despite the brevity of his 15-month rule.

title: Quarantine on Citrus Ending
description: Tree nurseries may resume shipments of citrus stock April 1 if they meet conditions to control the canker disease that led to a quarantine, Florida officials have announced. The ban applied to about 50 nurseries that were either infested, or had received stock from nurseries that were.

title: AN ARTS EDUCATOR DISCOVERS BASKETS
description: FLORENCE WEICHSEL of White Plains has worked as an art educator, an art therapist and a craftsman specializing in stitchery - ''painting'' with thread. Her most recent love in crafts is basket making, and she surprises herself with the extent of her involvement.

title: MANAGING CREATIVE PEOPLE
description: LAST June, at a ceremonial dinner, International Business Machines awarded $1.8 million as a thank-you to the 48 creative people who developed the PC's disk drive.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

THE BERMING OT THE ISLAND
description: WRITERS are, by profession, voyeurs. From the window by my desk I have, for the last 35 years, enjoyed the view of a flat 23- acre field of grade A Long Island soil. I have watched the subtle changes of color and light with the seasons, the tractors plowing furrows in spring, the crops of potatoes, cauliflower, corn or alfalfa ripening, and a spectacular hunt gathering here on Sunday afternoons in autumn.

title: AFTER PRISON CLOSES, WHAT USE FOR SIGHT?
description: NOW that the Long Island Correctional Facility in Brentwood is scheduled to close by April 1, the question arises: What next for the facility, on the grounds of the Pilgrim Psychiatric Center?

title: THEATER: 'ON THE VERGE,' A COMEDY, IN BALTIMORE
description: Cross the wordplay of S. J. Perelman with the world- in-a-time-warp vision of Caryl Churchill and you might approximate the special flavor of ''On the Verge or the Geography of Yearning.'' In Eric Overmyer's chimerical new comedy at Center Stage, three Victorian lady explorers set out on an adventure that takes them to darkest Africa, highest Himalaya and Terra Incognita.

title: THREE FOOTLIGHT PHILOSOPHERS
description: Ronald Bryden teaches drama at the University of Toronto. THE THEATER OF ESSENCE

title: HOYAS DEFEAT BOSTON COLLEGE
description: With Patrick Ewing an intimidating force under the basket, Georgetown kept Boston College scoreless for three and a half minutes late in the game tonight and came away with a 78-68 victory before a sellout crowd at Boston Garden.

title: Patricia Ashton to Be Wed To Christopher M. Norton
description: Mr. and Mrs. Vincent J. Ashton of Whitestone, Queens; Tobyhanna, Pa., and Lauderhill, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Patricia Ann Ashton, to Christopher Mark Norton, a son of Kathryn Norton of Albany.

title: SETTING A LOFTY NEW STANDARD FOR PICTURE QUALITY IN THE HOME
