description: So much has been said, in this column and elsewhere, about the technical shortcomings of American television that many viewers may have gained the impression that only a radical change in broadcasting standards could improve their picture. This is not so. Even within the legally mandated constraints of the current system, the picture can be bettered by raising the technical standards of home television sets.

title: SYRACUSE BEATS NOTRE DAME
description: Dwayne Washington scored a game- high 20 points and Rafael Addison added 17 today as Syracuse defeated Notre Dame, 65-62.

title: Future Events;
description: Tickets to the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated.

title: UNHERALDED VICTORS
description: There have been 25 head-to- head world team championship finals, and all but three of them have been clashes between Europe and North America. Europe leads in the series 12-10, thanks largely to the great run of the Italian Blue team in the period 1957-75. (Some championships have not been included because the event was a round-robin with no final play- off.)

title: CONGRESSMAN DISPUTES REAGAN ON JOB PROGRAMS
description: Representative Augustus F. Hawkins, the new chairman of the House Education and Labor Committee, has challenged Reagan Administration assertions that its employment training programs have been effective.

title: DINNER AT LA COTE BILGE
description: Christopher Buckley is the author of ''Steaming to Bamboola'' and is an editor-at-large of Esquire. ATLANTIC CIRCLE

title: Miss Brieant to Wed Brian David Clavette
description: Judge and Mrs. Charles L. Brieant of Ossining, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Julia Warfield Brieant, to Brian David Clavette, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Clavette of Manchester, Conn., and De Land, Fla.

title: Distaff Travelers
description: To the Editor: I found Judith Miller's article, ''For Visiting Women, the Welcome Varies'' (Travel, Nov. 18) both informative and accurate.

title: RETURN OF WOUNDED AWAITING
description: WITH snow soon about to give way to sunshine in the world of baseball, teams are scrutinizing ailing arms and legs to determine whether the walking wounded of 1984 will be prepared to play in 1985. The Milwaukee Brewers, for example, have four players returning from injuries and operations whose availability or absence will make an impact on the team's season. The players are Robin Yount, Paul Molitor, Rollie Fingers and Pete Vuckovich, and among them they won the American League Most Valuable Player and Cy Young Awards in 1981 and '82.

title:
ABOUT MEN;

THE WAYS OF A WIMP
description: is the author of the prize-winning novel ''Year of the French.''

title: IMPERFORATED ISSUES-A CHALLENGE FOR COLLECTORS
description: A complete sheet of Great Britain's 1-cent black stamp of 1840 would present a problem to the modern-day stamp user. The stamps could not be separated from each other as easily as contemporary ones are. There were no horizontal and vertical rows of perforations on the sheet and the stamps had to be torn crudely from each other or cut apart individually. These early British stamps bear a likeness of Queen Victoria and are known as the Penny Blacks.

title: CHINESE SHOPS: A SIGNATURE IN STONE
description: CHRISTOPHER S. WREN, who is chief of the Ottawa bureau of The New York Times, was head of the bureau in Peking from 1981 to 1984.

title: THE 'NIGHTMARE' OF BLUEBELL LANE
description: THIS is the second winter of their discontent. It was January 1984 when a few North Babylon families first learned of possible benzene contamination of the air in their homes caused by a 100,000-gallon gasoline leak from a nearby Sunoco service station's underground tanks.

title: RENTAL PROBLEMS IN CO-OPS
description: THE growing number of cooperative apartments owned by outside investors is posing problems of absentee ownership for resident shareholders.

title: THE FRACTIOUS POLITICS OF SCARCITY AND FAMINE
description: In this hamlet of northern Mozambique, Graca Alfandega was still hungry and morose after lunching on cornmeal gruel and wild leaves. It was different in Portuguese colonial days, she said; when drought curtailed the villagers' harvests then, ''there used to be food to buy in the cooperative.''

title: Lebanese Group Warns Of Anti-Cyprus Actions
description: A Lebanese group that seized a Cyprus Airways jetliner for several hours on Thursday threatened to attack Cypriot installations worldwide unless Cyprus releases two jailed Lebanese, a private radio station reported today.

title: DAY 'DAD' LET KOOSMAN HIT
description: EVER since the Yankees acquired Dale Berra as a Christmas present for Yogi Berra, the 28-year-old third baseman has been searching his soul for the answer to the toughest question of all - how should he refer to his father, the manager, in the dugout? Should he call him Skip, as in Skipper, the way most baseball managers are addressed by their players? Or should he call him Dad, the way most fathers are addressed by their sons. And after several wrenching weeks of reflection, the son, according to his mother, Carmen, has arrived at a decision.

title: IMPORTING BEER WITHOUT ALCOHOL
description: WITH the introduction last year of Warteck, an imported non-alcoholic beer, Omni Industries of Greenwich launched a campaign to capitalize on changing attitudes toward drinking.

title: NEW CENTER OFFERS WORKSHOPS TO BATTERED WOMEN
description: The 32-year-old mother of two said that for three and a half years her husband had beat her and her children, wrecked the furniture, wiretapped her home and threatened to kill her if she told anyone what was happening.

title: THE NIGHT THE WASP'S LOST BUFFALO
description: Nelson W. Aldrich Jr., an editor of Inc. magazine, is completing a book on inherited wealth. THE SNOW BALL

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: The best picture books on Imperial Russia - and there are not very many - capture its contradictions. Paradisiacal images of crystal-clear skies and snow-sprayed troika rides compete with those of protesting workers marching toward the Winter Palace and common graves.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: RAGE WITHIN: Anger in Modern Life. By Willard Gaylin. (Simon & Schuster, $16.95.)

title: Headliners ;
description: A Professor Resigns The statement from Harvard last week was brief.

title: CAMBODIAN REBELS REPORT ATTACKING VIETNAMESE FROM REAR
description: Khmer Rouge guerrillas have replied to the Vietnamese Army's attempt to pin them against the Thai border by moving to attack the Vietnamese from the rear, Thai military officials and guerrilla leaders said today.

title: 'SOLDIER'S PLAY'
description: ''They still hate you!'' he screams. Then, he's shot and killed.

title: Relatively Fast Retreat Seen For 40-Mile Glacier in Alaska
description: The 40-mile-long Columbia Glacier in Alaska has started a relatively rapid retreat, casting off four times as many icebergs as it did a few years ago, the United States Geological Survey reports.

title: 24 Die as Polish Ship Sinks
description: Nine crew members of a Polish cargo ship that sank in the North Sea were found dead today, and the search for 15 others was abandoned. The Coast Guard said one crew member was found alive. The 1,155-ton Buska Zdroj sank late Friday night within 15 minutes of issuing a distress call after its cargo of steel shifted in strong winds and heavy seas northwest of Helgoland, the Coast Guard said.

title: HE KNEW THEM ALL
description: THE FLOWER AND THE LEAF

title: Yarborough Seeks Record
description: Next Sunday Cale Yarborough will attempt to complete a task that no stock car racer has ever accomplished, winning the prestigious Daytona 500 three times in a row.

title: WOODSTOCK IN WINTER
description: Even on an ideal winter weekend, when every Vermont town seems touched with magic, Woodstock is special. To the shared legacy of mountains and ice-choked rivers, of red barns casting long shadows in the snow, of slender church steeples and covered bridges, this graceful town in the upper Connecticut valley brings singular attributes that have made it a popular year-round resort for a century.

title: UPSTATE SHOP FILLS CALLS TO MAKE CUSTOM FLAGS
description: --In this Chenango County hamlet, a small store called the Embroidery Shop has done work for the United States Supreme Court, the Central Intellegence Agency and the White House.

title: JOHNSON'S PASSES UNSURPASSED
description: To the purists, it was a performance worthy of high praise.

title: WHAT DACHAU MEANS
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFING;A Grecian Turn
description: Senior Pentagon officials were

title: India Frees Sri Lanka Arms
description: India today released a plane carrying Portuguese arms and ammunition to the Sri Lanka Government, and the two countries agreed to continue high-level talks aimed at ending ethnic violence in Sri Lanka. The Indian Government released the aircraft more than 24 hours after low fuel forced it to land in the Indian city of Trivandrum, 250 miles north of its destination in Sri Lanka.

title: ADVERTISING;People
description: Richard E. Evans was appointed senior vice president and executive creative director of Soskin/Thompson Associates.

title: Jackson Award Given To Inouye by Council
description: The Jewish Community Relations Council yesterday honored Senator Daniel K. Inouye, Democrat of Hawaii, as an ''outstanding advocate of Israel and the Jewish cause'' by presenting him with the first Henry M. Jackson Senatorial Leadership Award.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;The Library Will Put Its Treasures on Display
description: To most, the New York Public Library means books. But it also houses collections of paintings, prints, posters, sculptures, drawings, letters, handwritten scores, photographs, maps and even costumes.

title: HOMETOWN FIGHTS FOR PHILLIPS
description: As the Phillips Petroleum Company sweetened its offer to shareholders in an effort to keep the company independent, the local Chamber of Commerce was working on a sweetener of its own.

title: REDMEN HIT THEIR PACE, PATENTING THE SECOND-HALF COMEBACK
description: After St. John's 70-68 victory over Villanova on Saturday, someone asked Lou Carnesecca how he felt about his team having to rally to win once again. Carnesecca raised two fingers in a V and said: ''It's a win. I'll take it.''

title: Alford Armstrong Perryman, A Dancer and Choreographer
description: Alford Armstrong Perryman, a dancer, choreographer and teacher, died of pneumonia on Jan. 19 at his home in Brooklyn. He was 39 years old.

title: POINTLESS GRAND JURY SECRECY
description: There is a troublesome thread connecting the Bernhard H. Goetz shootings, the death by a police shotgun blast of Eleanor Bumpurs and the death in police custody of the graffiti artist Michael Stewart: each case was subject to investigation and preliminary judgment by a secret grand jury. While these events were generating front-page stories, the secrecy of grand jury proceedings was nurturing an atmosphere in which cynicism about the criminal justice system and accusations of racial bias flourished. The grand jury system, which badly misserves the public interest, should be reformed. In theory, the secrecy of grand jury proceedings protects defendants and the integrity of the criminal justice process. In reality, it does neither in most cases, which may explain why 25 states prefer preliminary court hearings to grand jury investigations. The purposes of grand jury secrecy are to encourage testimony and to protect witnesses; to guard against the flight of suspects who may not know they are being investigated; to preserve the reputations of innocent suspects; and to assure that an unbiased petit jury can later be convened if a suspect is indicted. Thus, grand juries are useful in organized- crime cases, where secrecy may induce informers and gang members to testify, and in probes of corruption among public officials. But what about cases in which a suspect is identified or arrested prior to grand jury proceedings? Here, the reasons for secrecy disappear. In publicized cases in this category, the people's right to know the facts and evaluate the process of justice clearly outweighs any interest in secrecy. In the Goetz case, for example, the key players faced the bright lights of publicity well before the grand jury proceedings. There was no realistic fear that witnesses would either hesitate to testify or be endangered if they did. Normal subpoena power was adequate to compel testimony. The flight of suspects was not a factor, and the protection of Mr. Goetz's reputation was hardly a concern after the publicity he received - and, in fact, courted - after his arrest.

title: GREEK CHIEF FLIES TO MOSCOW TODAY
description: Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou is leaving Monday for an official visit to the Soviet Union, at a time when Greece's relations with the United States are strained anew.

title: WUZZLES' TO 'INSECTOIDS' COME ALIVE AT TOY FAIR
description: Today marks the debut of the animals of Wuzzles, the ''plush people'' of Hugga Bunch, the warring forces of M.A.S.K., the women of the Princess of Power and the ''insectoids'' of Sectaurs.

title: NICEVILLE LIKES ITS MILITARY PENSIONS
description: For as long as anyone could remember, this Gulf Coast community of placid inland bays and mossy oaks was called Boggy Bayou.

title: THEATER: '4 CORNERS' IN THE MIDWEST
description: In ''4 Corners,'' Gina Wendkos, a painter and performance

title: Washington Watch;New Horizons? Baldrige Ready
description: WASHINGTON

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;Flutie's Hideaway
description: As a front-office employe of the Yankees, David Szen has become accustomed to multimillion-dollar contracts. However, never had he experienced the scene he observed at close range last Monday evening in the living room of his apartment in West New York, N.J.

title: MUSIC/NOTED IN BRIEF;Horacee Arnold Leads a Quartet
description: The drummer Horacee Arnold led a bright, nimble quartet Friday at the Jazz Center of New York. With David Friedman on vibraphone, John Purcell on reed instruments and Anthony Cox on bass, the group's sound was virtually transparent.

title: U.S. TOLD TO CLEAN UP OR CLOSE POLLUTED SAN JOAQUIN REFUGE
description: In a move with serious implications for farmers in California's bountiful San Joaquin Valley, state regulators have ordered the Interior Department to either clean up a polluted wildlife refuge or close it.

title: AROUND THE WORLD;Singapore's New Guard Offers More Open Rule
description: Singapore's newly emerging young leaders, shocked by the ruling party's sharp fall in popularity in the general election in December, have promised to run a more open government and listen to opposition views.

title: Expense Claim Withdrawn
description: General Dynamics has agreed to withdraw a bill for $491,840 charged to the Federal Government for 76 corporate flights its chairman, Mr. Lewis, made to his farm in Georgia, The St. Louis Post-Dispatch reported today.

title: SAMPSON LEADS WEST TO VICTORY
description: Julius Erving electrified the crowd with a cradle dunk. Earvin (Magic) Johnson made a seemingly impossible pass and George Gervin hit a 15-foot jumper from the hip.

title: ADVERTISING;Barneys on Its Own
description: Barneys New York, the 61-year-old clothing store, is starting its own advertising department and will therefore be splitting with Chiat/Day, New York, its agency since July. Neil Kraft is its advertising director, having come aboard from Epstein, Raboy Advertising, the Chiat/Day predecessor. Barneys spent about $3 million for advertising last year.

title: NO CHANGE SEEN IN FED POLICY
description: When Federal officials in charge of monetary policy meet tomorrow and Wednesday, they are likely to vote for no change in policy, analysts said, except to validate the small rise in short-term rates that has occurred in the past few weeks.

title: WASHINGTON WATCH;Telecommunications Panel
description: Demand for seats on the House Subcommittee on Telecommunications, Consumer Protection and Finance, headed by Timothy E. Wirth, a Colorado Democrat, is such that the House Democratic caucus has expanded the committee's membership from 15 to 24. Democrats and Republicans each gain four additional seats, producing a 15-9 majority of Democrats.

title: Advertising;Two More Toys From Tonka
description: THE Tonka Corporation, which big creshook off a toy-car-only image with the introduction of its highly successful Gobot last year, is going to try for a double play in 1985 with Pound Puppies and Star Fairies.

title: THE CITY;Plan for S.I. Base Meets Regulations
description: A Navy study has concluded that a plan to base a seven-vessel Navy fleet at Staten Island would comply with Federal laws and would not harm surrounding communities.

title: AROUND THE NATION;Atlanta Mayor Sends Protest to Advertisers
description: Mayor Andrew Young of Atlanta has sent telegrams to the chief executives of the nation's 100 leading corporate advertisers expressing his ''deep concern'' about ''The Atlanta Child Murders,'' a two-part movie being shown on CBS-TV, one part last night and the other Tuesday.

title: MONDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Villanova at Georgetown: After narrowly failing to upset St. John's, the nation's No. 1-ranked team Saturday, Villanova gets a chance at the No. 2-rated team. The Wildcats took Georgetown, then rated No. 1, into overtime last month before losing. (Television - ESPN, 8 P.M.); Brooklyn at Chicago State 7:30 P.M.; C.W. Post at Bloomsburg, 7:30 P.M.; Hofstra at Drexel, 7 P.M.; York (N.Y.) at Medgar Evers, 8 P.M.; Utica at Monmouth, 7:30 P.M.; Queens at Sacred Heart, 7:30 P.M. Dog Show

title: Li Ning Elected Athlete of Year
description: Li Ning, who won three gold medals at the Los Angeles Olympics, today was named China's best athlete of 1984. In a poll conducted by 20 newspapers, television and radio stations in Peking, the 21-year-old gymnast topped a nationwide poll in which 1.6 million people voted by mail. The results were reported by the official Xinhua news agency and state-run television news.

title: STATEMENT BY BOSTON BANK DUE
description: The Bank of Boston plans to issue its first major statement Monday explaining in detail why it failed to report $1.22 billion in international cash transfers, mostly with Swiss banks, a spokesman for the bank said today.

title: A RULING ON WHISTLE BLOWERS PITS U.S. AGENCIES IN DISPUTE
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission is in a battle with the Labor Department over a court decision that critics say would weaken the protection given whistle blowers in the nuclear power industry.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: Dollar Accounts Frozen
description: The Bank of Sudan, the country's central bank, has frozen all dollar accounts in the country's banks to stop large withdrawals of dollars, bankers said today.

title: MELEE AT AIRPORT IN SEOUL PROMPTS NEW ACCUSATIONS
description: The controversy over the violence that broke out last Friday when the exiled opposition leader Kim Dae Jung returned home took a new turn today.

title: HEAD OF N.Y.U. ASSAILS REAGAN ON BUDGET CUTS
description: The president of New York University, Dr. John Brademas, said tonight that President Reagan's budget and tax proposals would devastate America's colleges and universities and ''threaten an entire generation of scholars.''

title: WASHINGTON WATCH;Shipbuilding Decision Nears
description: With commercial shipbuilding in the United States nearly nonexistent, the industry's future rests in the hands of the Pentagon and a decision the Navy is expected to make by March 15. The Navy will order the first billion-dollar model of the new Arleigh Burke class of destroyers, and that could lead to dozens of the ships and tens of billions of dollars in contracts into the next century.

title: ADVERTISING;U.S. McCann Chairman Set
description: After a 22-year upwardly mobile career at Young & Rubicam, John J. McNamara, a mechanical engineer by training, is moving over on March 1 to McCann-Erickson, the flagship of the Interpublic Group of Companies. He will be chairman of the domestic company and vice chairman of the worldwide company. He was president of Y.& R.'s U.S.A. division, which in billings is some three times larger than McCann domestically. He is making the move at age 50 because of ''better opportunities,'' he said. The announcement was made by Robert L. James, who becomes chief executive of McCann Worldwide March 1. Mr. McNamara, called Jay, worked for an engineering company after getting his degree from Yale, then switched to retail as a store manager of Grand Union. Then he saw the light and got a job as an account executive at Ted Bates & Company. He's also an ex-Marine.

title: Jamaica's Pain for Tourist Gain
description: Even very young Jamaicans can remember the bad old days of 1980. The nation was rife with violence and at times seemed on the verge of complete civil disorder. By comparison, the disturbances last month, after the Government raised fuel prices 20 percent, seemed mild, even though seven lives were lost and the capital, Kingston, was essentially shut down for two days.

title: Loretta Young to Star In 2-Hour TV Movie
description: Loretta Young will end 24 years of retirement to star in a two-hour television movie, ''Dark Mansions,'' according to the producer Aaron Spelling.

title: THE FAMILY;A NEW LOOK AT INTERMARRIAGE IN THE U.S.
description: The first comprehensive national portrait of ethnic and racial intermarriage in America is emerging from new research analyzing the 1980 census. The findings have rekindled a longstanding debate among scholars over whether the importance of ethnic identity is waning, or whether it is a powerful factor in national life.

title: OUTDOORS;HUNTING SNOWSHOE RABBITS
description: OPPENHEIM, N.Y.

title: BRIEFS;Debt
description: Browning-Ferris Industries plans to call for redemption of its 12 7/8 percent notes, due 1987.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;Menu Wars
description: Restaurant competition stops at no

title: AROUND THE NATION;Cocaine Confiscations Perplex Florida Officials
description: The authorities in Florida who have seized more than two tons of cocaine recently are wondering whether their war on drugs is a success, or if it means that more cocaine is entering the country.

title: CANADA SETTLES DISPUTE OVER OFFSHORE OIL FIND
description: Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney and Newfoundland Premier Brian Peckford are scheduled to sign a deal here Monday to end a bitter dispute over development of the giant Hibernia oilfield discovered 175 miles off the island province in 1979.

title: Iran Oil Plan Is Reported
description: Iran has set up a committee to implement a plan under which imports from many countries would be limited to half the value of oil the countries buy from Iran, informed Iranian sources said today.

title: CITY BALLET: 'HARLEQUINADE' AND 'STARS AND STRIPES'
description: Nearing the end of its winter season at the New York State Theater, the New York City Ballet looks and acts as fresh as ever, adding to the repertory and presenting role debuts as if the season had just begun. On Saturday afternoon, there was an exuberant performance of ''Stars and Stripes,'' one of George Balanchine's excursions into Americana, accompanied by Hershey Kay's adaptations and orchestrations of marches by John Philip Sousa. The time and mood to which ''Stars and Stripes'' alludes now seem very distant, though they were well epitomized in Lisa Hess's bouncy cheerleader of a ballerina at the head of the ballet's ''First Campaign,'' and in the buoyant assertiveness of Teresa Reyes, new in the role of the ''Second Campaign'' leader.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;Norfolk's Chairman Has Conrail Plans
description: After learning Friday afternoon that the Norfolk Southern Corporation was the Transportation Department's choice to buy Conrail and may become the country's largest rail system, the chairman, Robert B. Claytor, spoke briefly with President Reagan.

title: HOCKEY STRIKE IS OPTION
description: Alan Eagleson, the executive director of the National Hockey League's player association, said today that he is prepared to advise the league's players to strike if certain demands are not met when the association's current collective bargaining agreement expires as early as September 1986.

title: Jaruzelski Due in India
description: Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader, arrives in New Delhi on Monday on his first official visit outside the Eastern bloc, a trip already blemished by reports of Polish involvement in India's spy scandal.

title: Leonard Henry Dies; Was Racing Director
description: Leonard D. Henry, a retired businessman and former military officer who helped found the Jockey Club Research Foundation and served as a director of the New York Racing Association, died of lung cancer last Wednesday while vacationing in Delray Beach, Fla. He was 76 years old and lived in New York.

title: BRIEFING;Following Yonder Stamp
description: King Fahd of Saudi Arabia is holding a black-tie dinner Thursday as part of a state visit, and some of those receiving invitations from the Moslem monarch found it ecumenically encouraging that both the original and return envelopes carried the Postal Service's Christmas stamp with a painting of Mary and the Christ Child.

title: LEWIS IS A MAN ON THE MOVE
description: It is not always easy being Carl Lewis. When you win four gold medals in one Olympic Games, the money is good, the recognition is great and the honors flow. Celebrity does have advantages. It also has a price. Travel can be fierce and days at home infrequent.

title: THE REGION;Hearings to Weigh Shoreham Plans
description: The State Consumer Protection Board today announced plans for two public hearings to consider proposals for a phase-in plan to pay for the Shoreham nuclear power plant.

title: ADVERTISING;'84 Increases Reported For Cents-Off Coupons
description: The Nielsen Clearing House, which acts for manufacturers in redeeming cents-off coupons collected by retailers, also serves as scorekeeper for that area of sales promotion activity. It just came up with its report for 1984, and that is that manufacturers distributed 163.2 billion coupons last year, a 14 percent increase from the previous year. And consumers redeemed 12 percent more than in 1983, or 6.25 billion.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MONDAY, FEBRUARY 11, 1985

title: ADVERTISING;Ohlmeyer Ad President
description: Dean J. Heitler, 44 years old, who was working at Parkson Advertising, the house agency of Nabisco Brands when it became part of the Ohlmeyer Communications Companies, has just been named president of Ohlmeyer Advertising, a subsidiary. A former executive vice president, he replaces Philip Howort, who resigned earlier last week.

title: U.S.-ASIAN TALKS 'CLEAR AIR' ON TRADE
description: Meetings this past week between the United States special trade representative, Bill Brock, and economics ministers of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations ''cleared the air'' on trade disagreements between the two sides, participants said. But at the same time, the ministers called for a more unified regional approach, short of creating commodities cartels, in dealings with Western trading partners and Japan.

title: BRIEFING;Say the Secret Cipher
description: The gift that the National Security Agency presents to retiring members of the Congressional intelligence committees is classier than the Little Orphan Annie Secret Decoder Ring of the 1930's but basically the same piece of equipment. The supersecret cryptographic agency gave one of these ''cipher disks'' to Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York in recognition of eight years of committee service. The paperweight-size plaque carries two revolving wheels, with an alphabet and another in reverse, that enable the owner to work a simple substitution cipher. What's more, the Senator did not have to save up any Ovaltine seals to get it.

title: MANY COMPETE FOR PRINCETON CLUBS
description: Record numbers of Princeton University sophomores carried on one of the school's oldest and most controversial traditions this week when they competed for membership in Princeton's five selective eating clubs.

title: TV REVIEW;MARSHALL MCLUHAN AND HIS IDEAS ON VIEW
description: Marshall McLuhan had ideas. They leaped, skittered and frisked. Often the ideas were expressed in impenetrable prose, and sometimes, when examined, they turned out not to be ideas but whimsies. Usually, however, something was there. Mr. McLuhan, who died in 1980, is the subject of ''Marshall McLuhan: The Man and His Message,'' a thoroughly rewarding documentary on Channel 13 at 10 tonight.

title: CAROLINA DEFEATS L.S.U.
description: Brad Daugherty hit 9 of his team's final 21 points to lead North Carolina to a hard-fought 75-70 victory over Louisiana State in a nationally televised game today.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: OFF THE WALL If it's been a while since you've seen writing or art that inspired a laugh, you are due for a visit to an exhibition of more than 100 cartoons on the sixth floor of Master Eagle Gallery, 40 West 25th Street (691-1660). ''Cartoon '85'' is the second show by the Master Eagle Company, a graphics concern, and the Cartoonists Association, and it fills two rooms with original drawings that have gone on to be printed in magazines and other publications.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: Allegheny Power System Inc., the electric utility holding company, has elected to its board Edward H. Malone, a vice president of General Electric Co. until his retirement this year.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Feb. 11, 1985:

title: HAWKS TAKE THIRD IN ROW
description: Tom Lysiak drilled in a wrist shot in the final period today to give the Black Hawks a 4-3 triumph over the Boston Bruins.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;Microphone Finesse
description: On the basketball court, they can play with professional finesse, but before a microphone even the most accomplished college athletes can dissolve into monosyllabic jelly.

title: AROUND THE WORLD;Thousands Defy Curfew In New Caledonia
description: Thousands of people defied New Caledonia's official curfew tonight to protest independence plans for France's troubled South Pacific territory.

title: Close Encouter with handler, George Ward
description: The Scottie has won best in show 183 times in her career. That is a record. The shepherd won best in show 80 times last year alone, along with 137 herding group awards. Those are records, too.

title: Top Two Advance In Tennis
description: Martina Navratilova, pushed to the limit by Catarina Lindqvist, defeated the 21-year-old Swede, 6-4, 3-6, 6-4, tonight in the fourth round of the $1.8 million Lipton International Players Championships tournament.

title: DETROIT WOOS YOUNGER CAR BUYERS
description: She is about 34 years old and single, most likely a college graduate, and she earns between $30,000 and $35,000 a year.

title: Market Place;Hopeful View For Bicycles
description: LIKE many other domestic industries, bicycle

title: METS' ARCHITECTS LOOKING FOR ROOM AT THE TOP
description: Just about the only people in town who do not think that the Mets must win in 1985 are the Mets. They are not exactly copping a plea. Most of them expect to win, and all of them expect to come close. Frank Cashen, the general manager, even concedes that ''New York is a 'now' town where you've got to win now.''

title: THE CALENDAR
description: Monday

title: WEINBERGER LOBBIES ALLIES ON 'STAR WARS'
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger appealed to Western European nations today to support the Reagan Administration's space weapons program, saying such weapons would promote stability between the superpowers and lessen the risk of war.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE CHIP. How Two Americans Invented the Microchip & Launched a Revolution. By T. R. Reid. 243 pages. Simon & Schuster. $15.95.

title: AROUND THE NATION;Goats From Navy Island Are Put Up for Adoption
description: Goats saved from certain death on a coastal island used as a target for naval guns began new lives today as pets.

title: SPORTS NEWS BRIEFS;North Stars' Ace Lost for Season
description: Tony McKegney, the Minnesota North Stars' leading goal scorer, will miss the rest of the season because of a shoulder separation suffered Saturday, team officials said.

title: TV REVIEW;40 HOURS OF CLASSIC SHOWS CHRONICLE PIONEER ON COAST
description: Chaos, threaded with women's screams, erupts in a crowded hotel ballroom. KTLA's camera is there, zooming in on Larry Scheer as he tells viewers: ''Robert Kennedy has been shot!''

title: SPORTS NEWS BRIEFS;Manhattan Wins Met Track Title
description: Manhattan College, led by its double-gold medalist, Willie McLaughlin, scored 131 points at the 43d Metropolitan Intercollegiate track and field championships at Yale's Coxe Cage.

title: CHINA ALTERS COURSE WITH SALE OF STOCK
description: As the line began forming on a misty morning in mid- January, the survivors of this city's old capitalist class could have been forgiven for thinking they were dreaming the entire scene.

title: 3-YEAR SURVEY FINDS COLLEGE CURRICULUMS IN U.S. IN 'DISARRAY'
description: American colleges and universities have allowed their curriculums to slip into a state of ''disarray'' and ''incoherence,'' putting in question the quality of what the country's college students learn, a major higher education organization charged yesterday.

title: SPORTS NEWS BRIEFS;East German Sets Speed Skate Mark
description: Andrea Schoene of East Germany set a world record in the 5,000- meter race at the women's World Speed Skating Championships today, covering the distance in 7 minutes 32.82 seconds.

title: ESSAY;WHY WE CELEBRATE LINCOLN
description: in the North, at least - celebrate Lincoln's Birthday? Why do we put him on the penny and the $5 bill, erect monuments, listen to political orators quote his words? What was so special about Lincoln?

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;Olympic Obstacle
description: The 1988 Winter Games are three years away, but on Mount Allan outside Calgary, Alberta, where the Olympic ski facilities are being constructed, there is already a spirited competition - between the Olympic contractors and a herd of Rocky Mountain bighorn sheep.

title: RELATIONSHIPS;A FATHER'S WARMTH FOR A SON
description: In days not so old, fathers were distant, if not downright cold, to their

title: The U.N. Today
description: Feb. 11, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: The Pentagon Pension Brawl
description: When struck by Sir Walter Raleigh for telling an appalling truth at a dinner party, his son struck the man beside him, crying ''Box about. 'Twill come to my father anon.'' A similarly discursive free-for-all has erupted in Washington over the appalling truth about the Defense Department: However high costs soar, Secretary Weinberger shows little interest in the many internal reforms that would not only save money but also improve operations.

title: MEXICO TIGHTENS AUSTERITY
description: Mexico, sensing ''negative tendencies'' in its financial situation, is taking a series of emergency measures to keep the hard-fought gains of its economic recovery program from unraveling.

title: U.S. FACES BOMBER CHOICE
description: The fate of one of the Air Force's most cherished weapons, the manned strategic bomber, has reached a pivotal point: Congress must decide this year whether to extend production of the B-1 bomber or forge ahead with a radically new design dubbed the Stealth bomber.

title: MORE NUCLEAR PROLIFERATION, PLEASE
description: Everybody opposes nuclear proliferation. We have signed lots of treaties against it. We have, however, had little success in stopping the spread of nuclear weapons. The few countries we have been able to prevent from acquiring them have been our own allies - including, notably, West Germany. In this, we are making a serious mistake.

title: Grand Juries Protect Rights of the Individual
description: To the Editor:

title: FROM HUMBLE TRICKLES TO BIG POTOMAC FLOWS
description: It may come as something of a surprise to those afflicted by Potomac Fever to learn that the river that gives its name to this political malady of the mighty is of humble origin.

title: BRIEFING;The Medal Stands
description: Acting in behalf of President Reagan, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration has refused to rescind the Distinguished Service Medal that the agency awarded in 1969 to Arthur Rudolph, a German-born rocket expert who was manager of the Saturn V rocket project that ultimately carried astronauts to the moon.

title: NAVY SECRETARY REPORTS ON MEESE
description: Navy Secretary John F. Lehman Jr. informed Senate investigators Friday that he was contacted in 1981 by a staff member from the office of Edwin Meese 3d, the White House counselor, regarding contract problems with the General Dynamics Corporation, a spokesman for Mr. Lehman said today.

title: CONTRACT NEGOTIATIONS START BETWEEN STATE AND WORKERS
description: Amid uncertainty over unresolved Federal and state budgets and disputes over which union represents which workers, New York State has begun to negotiate contracts for almost 200,000 employees.

title: Brock in Japan
description: Japan must act quickly to open its telecommunications market to avoid a serious United States backlash, Mr. Brock, the special trade representative, was quoted today as saying by a senior Japanese trade official.

title: THAT'S WHAT FAITH IS
description: SARASOTA, Fla.

title: CONCERT: 'AZAX/ATTRA' PERFORMED AT CARNEGIE HALL
description: Exotic atmosphere suffused ''Azax/Attra,'' a collaboration by Richard Horowitz and Sussan Deihim performed Wednesday at Carnegie Hall. Mr. Horowitz's music mixes electronic sounds with music for ney, a Near Eastern reed flute. Miss Deihim, who was born in Teheran, Iran, has performed in modern and traditional dance styles and has sung Mr. Horowitz's pieces since 1981.

title: DANCE: DARCI KISTLER RETURNS TO CITY BALLET
description: The New York City Ballet has trained its public to look at a work of art - a ballet - in its entirety rather than to focus on any specific personalities involved. Nonetheless, names do make news, as the old journalism adage goes, and Saturday night's program at the State Theater was special in this respect.

title: Slaney Fears Tear in Calf
description: Mary Decker Slaney reported yesterday that her right calf was giving her ''considerable pain,'' and she feared she had suffered not a muscle cramp but torn tissue. If so, she said, she could miss several weeks of training.

title: ADVERTISING;2 Agencies GetNew Assignments
description: Two agencies picked up big creative-only assignments on Friday. Cunningham & Walsh got its from Aamco Transmissions. And Benton & Bowles was tapped by Jeffrey Martin Inc., the health care and beauty products marketer.

title: LEADING FOE OF APARTHEID SPURNS A CONDITIONAL OFFER OF FREEDOM
description: Nelson Mandela, the leader of the African National Congress, has rejected a conditional Government offer of freedom after more than two decades of imprisonment, his daughter said today.

title: WASHINGTON WATCH;F.D.I.C. Enforcement Plan
description: The three directors of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation - William M. Isaac, the agency's chairman; C. Todd Conover, the Comptroller of the Currency, and Irvine H. Sprague - meet today to consider a staff proposal that could complicate life for wayward banks.

title: THE REGION;Enrollments Drop At Jersey Colleges
description: Total enrollment at colleges in New Jersey has dropped 3.6 percent, with state and county colleges hit the hardest, according to a report by the state's Department of Higher Education.

title: Oak Industries
description: Oak Industries said that unless at least 70 percent of its $230 million principal amount of old debentures are exchanged in a new offer, and unless it arranges an additional $10 million in financing, it does not expect to meet 1985 cash requirements. Oak, which manufactures electronic equipment, said it would be unable to meet the interest payment on the old debentures in April and May. As a result, it said, it may have to file for reorganization or liquidation.

title: BRIEFING;Thunder on the Right
description: Any organization that includes among its leaders such pillars of American conservatism as Richard V. Allen, the former national security adviser; Edwin J. Feulner Jr., president of the Heritage Foundation; Senator Phil Gramm, the Texas Democrat turned triumphant Republican, and Clare Boothe Luce, the grand matron emeritus of the right, should feel perfectly comfortable calling itself the Committee for Western Civilization, as it does. And a group thus named, when planning social recreation, instinctively turns to an Evening of Viennese Waltzing, white tie (optional), as it has. It should also warm the royalist hearts of participants to learn that this affair, scheduled for Saturday at the Organization of American States, will be held ''under the official patronage of their imperial and royal highnesses Archduke Otto and Archduchess Regina von Habsburg.''

title: BRIEFING;In Re T-shirts
description: The words reportedly addressed

title: THE CITY;Attempt at Suicide Is Foiled in Bronx
description: Officers pulled a man back from a suicide attempt yesterday as he was hanging head-first from a fifth-floor window in the Bronx, the police said.

title: HOMELESS POSE PROBLEMS AT GRAND CENTRAL
description: In the past month, hundreds of homeless people have taken advantage of a Metro-North decision to open Grand Central Terminal all night and have been sheltering on cold nights in the terminal's waiting rooms, corridors and other marbled nooks and crannies.

title: 4 Are Killed in Crash Of Ambulance Plane
description: Four people, including a patient, were killed Saturday when an ambulance airplane lost power in both engines as it approached an airport and crashed in a pasture, the authorities said.

title: Treasury Offerings Limited to Bills
description: Treasury financings this week are confined to the bill market, with auctions of new issues due in 3, 6 and 12 months. The absence of note and bond financings is a relief to securities dealers who are still holding large amounts of the $19 billion of notes and bonds auctioned last week by the Treasury.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Who scored more points in his pro basketball career, Jerry West or Oscar Robertson? Which of the two guards fouled out most often?

title: INSTANT REPLAY LIKELY IN U.S.F.L.
description: The use of a television instant-replay system to review certain on-field decisions by officials is likely to become a regular practice during the United States Football League's coming season, according to the new commissioner, Harry Usher.

title: Anne Reznikoff, Executive, Is the Bride of Stan Bratskeir
description: Anne Reznikoff, the daughter of Helga Reznikoff of Hallandale, Fla., and Dr. Marvin Reznikoff of Stamford, Conn., was married yesterday to Stan Bratskeir, a son of Mrs. Irving B. Bratskeir of New York and the late Mr. Bratskeir. Rabbi Donna Berman performed the ceremony at Le Chateau restaurant in South Salem, N.Y.

title: HALF U.S. COUPLES CAN'T HAVE BABIES
description: Nearly half of all couples of childbearing age in the United States are physically unable to have children, as Americans increasingly choose sterilization to limit their families, according to new Government statistics.

title: Bridge:Gentle Wit of Clayton Coots Remembered by His Friends
description: Any club proprietor likes to have regular players, whatever their standard of play. But a player who brings civility and wit to the table is prized above rubies.

title: Futures/Options;Trading Takes The Next Step
description: THERE are options on futures, options that are

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;Black-Jewish Relations: Students' Concern
description: There was a tense silence between

title: LIFE IN SPECIAL POLICE UNIT IS BOREDOM BROKEN BY MOMENTS OF SHEERTERROR
description: As members of the Police Department's Emergency Service Unit, the 35 men of Manhattan's Truck No. 1 Squad have scaled the cables of the Brooklyn Bridge to talk down would-be jumpers, rescued near-drowning victims from the Hudson River and pulled men, women and children from elevator shafts, wrecked cars and the debris of collapsed buildings.

title: Riley Missed His Chance
description: INDIANAPOLIS

title: Israel to Use a Satellite
description: Israel will start transmitting communications signals via satellite next January, using leased equipment, and will operate its own satellite in five years, Yoram Alster, director general of the Ministry of Telecommunications, announced in Jerusalem today. The first Arab satellite was put into space from French Guiana Friday by the European Space Agency.

title: The Long Arm of Taiwan
description: Taiwan calls itself Free China and asks Americans to believe it's not a police state. That asks a lot. Despite limited freedoms and a flourishing free market, Taiwan is a republic only in name. One family, one party and one cause permeate its politics. Its aging leaders cling to views hardened since their flight from the mainland in 1949 and have ruled with martial law ever since.

title: AS PRIVATELY OWNED PRISONS INCREASE, SO DO THEIR CRITICS
description: The bleak landscape of correctional institutions in the United States is increasingly becoming the province of private companies and a few nonprofit groups.

title: ISRAELI JETS RAID PALESTINIAN BASE
description: Seven people were killed and several wounded today in two car-bomb explosions here and in the northern port of Tripoli.

title: THE DEMOCRATS AREN'T BRAIN-DEAD
description: A small but thriving industry has grown up since the 1980 Presidential election. A joint venture of journalists and Democratic officeholders, it is enjoying its most profitable quarter in four years. The sole product: taking the Democrats to task for being a party without ideas.

title: MORTGAGE CASE SAID TO WIDEN
description: The Bank of America, which so far has set aside a loss reserve of $95 million, is not the only financial institution to be damaged in what appears to be a nationwide fraud involving insurance and mortgage-backed securities, according to lawyers close to the case.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;N.Y.U. Expanding To Upper East Side
description: New York University is moving uptown, to the exclusive Dalton School on East 89th Street.

title: MANCINI FIGHTS FOR DESIRE
description: Life goes on, though sometimes, Ray Mancini thinks, life should have imitated art and he should have quit after winning the title. At least, it would have saved him hundreds of punches, dreaded long weeks away from his family and the anguish over killing a man in the ring.

title: DANCE: GONZALEZ TROUPE
description: The Annabella Gonzalez Dance Theater is a choreographic theater of the absurd, and the works that Miss Gonzalez presented last Sunday afternoon at Kiva, 309 Canal Street, were filled with bizarre events.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE;Trustee Loses Case For Milwaukee Road
description: Combat is nothing new to Richard B. Ogilvie. Serving as a tank commander in France during World War II, he was left with a Purple Heart, a Bronze Star and injuries from an exploding enemy shell.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS;MONEY AND DEFENSE
description: PARIS Now that President Reagan has delivered the pre-game pep talk for his second Administration, the serious play begins. It has been widely admitted that there is no feasible way to reduce the skyrocketing deficit except by an onerous tax rise that would take the lift out of the economy, or by a sizable cut in defense spending.

title: OPERA: A NEW 'WOZZECK' CAST AT THE MET
description: Tuesday evening's performance of ''Wozzeck'' at the Metropolitan Opera was sadly under-attended. That could have been because of the snow, or because of some cast changes from the first night, or because of continued audience resistance to the opera itself.

title: MUSIC/NOTED IN BRIEF;Bach, Haydn, Brahms And Collegiate Chorale
description: The Collegiate Chorale had some interesting music to bring us Saturday night, but its concert at St. Thomas Church on Fifth Avenue was defeated by its surroundings - and by the way those surroundings were used.

title: A DEADLY ARMED ROBBERY AT A MODEST HOUSE PUZZLES MANY IN GREAT NECK
description: From his command post on a street corner in Great Neck, L.I., Everitt Campbell was trying to jog the memory of anyone who might have seen or heard something peculiar on Friday night, when two men were shot and a third was stabbed to death as they struggled with robbers who had burst into a dinner party.

title: SPORTS NEWS BRIEFS;Nilsson Captures Slalom in Finale
description: Jonas Nilsson, a 21-year-old Swede, upset Marc Girardelli in the men's slalom today at the World Alpine Skiing Championships.

title: MusicNoted in Brief;Concerto Soloists At Carnegie Hall
description: The chamber orchestra that calls itself Concerto Soloists of Philadelphia visited Carnegie Hall on Wednesday night and proved that it plays well enough to have no need of an ambiguous title. The ensemble is led by Marc Mostovoy, who founded it 21 years ago.

title: Bullets Fired in 1959 Kill Man
description: Two bullets fired nearly 26 years ago finally killed Isaiah Wilcox, the authorities say, and they are looking for his former wife for questioning.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;Diminutive Power
description: Once they were regarded as oddities, but in their second season in the Atlantic Coast Conference, the diminutive guards Tyrone Bogues of Wake Forest and Anthony (Spud) Webb of North Carolina State have earned acceptance.

title: NEW GERMAN TV: IDIOT CULTURE OR BREATH OF AIR?
description: Consolidating his grasp on a dispirited nation, Hitler revolutionized politics through his discovery of the enormous power of the spoken voice carried by radio.

title: SPORTS NEWS BRIEFS;Mile to Furlong In Masters Meet
description: Gary Furlong, who finished fourth last year in the race up the stairs of the Empire State Building, tuned up for this year's event by winning a mile run yesterday in 4 minutes 41.2 seconds. The 31-year-old Furlong, who lives in Queens, will compete in the Empire State Building race Thursday at 10:30 A.M. Yesterday's mile run took place in the 30-35 age division of the Metropolitan Athletics Congress masters indoor track and field championships at the 102d Engineers Armory.

title: AROUND THE NATION;Wyandot Indians Win $5.5 Million Settlement
description: The Federal Government will pay about $5.5 million to descendants of the Wyandot Indians to settle a 143- year-old treaty that forced the tribe to sell their Ohio homes in 1842 for less than fair value.

title: SEGREGATION REPORTED IN FEDERAL HOUSING PROJECT
description: Despite Federal laws barring racial discrimination, most of the nearly 10 million residents of federally financed housing are segregated by race, with whites faring much better than black and Hispanic people, according to a report published today by The Dallas Morning News.

title: SHUTTLE MAY CARRY BONE MARROW INTO SPACE FOR STUDY ON RADIATION
description: Late this summer, a space shuttle will carry aloft 30 pints of human blood, and although it is not on the written protocol for the flight, the shuttle may also carry a sample of bone marrow, a material that some scientists here think might cure victims of radiation in a nuclear war.

title: Mildred Testo Weds Dr. W. B. Sacks
description: The marriage of Mildred Rose Testo, a daughter of Judge Robert J. Testo and Mrs. Testo of Milford, Conn., to Dr. William Bennett Sacks, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph B. Sacks of New Hyde Park, L.I., took place yesterday at the Oronoque Village Country Club in Stratford, Conn. Judge Burton Jacobson of Connecticut Superior Court performed the ceremony.

title: CORRECTION
description: A listing in The Guide yesterday gave an incorrect time for tonight's performance of ''Lohengrin'' at the Metropolitan Opera. It will be at 7 P.M.

title: LISTENING BETWEEN THE LINES
description: Without speeches by Presidents and Cabinet officers, there might be no Government policies.

title: TRAUMA WEEK' BEGINS FOR PARENTS SEEKING A PRIVATE SCHOOL FOR TOTS
description: Regina Kessler, customarily a rational woman, is in a state of high tension this week.

title: MUSIC/NOTED IN BRIEF;Locker and Deane, On Cello and Piano
description: Richard Locker and Alison Deane are a young cello-piano team as interesting for the differences between them as for the similarities. In their concert of duos at Carnegie Recital Hall last Sunday afternoon, each understood the other's gestures well. Changes of tempo were managed together, and in the Beethoven G-minor Sonata both understood when to cede or accept dominance.

title: BOOK PUBLISHING HOUSES ATTRACTING THE TOP YOUNG TALENT ONCE AGAIN
description: After reading a recent profile of Mario Merola, the Bronx District Attorney, Errol McDonald, a 31-year- old senior editor at Random House, went out and signed him up to write a book to be called ''Big City D.A.''

title: Alleghany Assails Choice The chairman of the Alleghany Corporation,F.M.
description: Kirby, yesterday criticized the

title: Unesco Withdrawal Poses Profound Questions for America
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW INSTITUTE TO TREAT PERFORMING ARTISTS' ILLS
description: Injuries and ailments are an inescapable part of the performing arts. To achieve stardom - or simply to make a living - dancers, singers and musicians routinely risk hurting themselves, especially when they force their bodies to do more than they should.

title: AROUND THE NATION;Crews Unable to Enter Mine Where 27 Died
description: Crews from the Emery Mining Corporation Saturday suspended efforts to enter the Wilberg coal mine after failing to reduce high levels of poisonous gas inside.

title: FRENCH COMMUNISTS SHUN CHARGES
description: The French Communist Party, brushing aside a small group's attempts to introduce more open debate and other changes, completed its 25th congress today with the removal of a leading dissenter from the party's Politburo.

title: AROUND THE WORLD;U.S. Team in Laos To Search for Missing
description: A team of United States experts flew to southern Laos today to search for the remains of Americans missing in action from the Vietnam War, a United States Embassy official said.

title: REPACKAGING OF CAR LOANS IS INCREASING
description: Wall Street firms, which have prospered from the repackaging of home mortgages into securities, are now trying to do the same thing for another staple of consumer finance: automobile loans.

title: AROUND THE WORLD;Ethiopian Chief Outlines Steps to End Crisis
description: In a rare address to the nation, the Ethiopian head of state, Mengistu Haile Mariam, has acknowledged that the country's economy is continuing to deteriorate and outlined ''seven urgent measures'' intended to stem the decline.

title: OFFICER PLANS TO ASK FOR A NONJURY TRIAL IN BUMPURS KILLING
description: Lawyers representing the New York City police officer indicted in the shooting death of Eleanor Bumpurs said yesterday that they would ask for a nonjury trial.

title: Show Begins Today
description: Although 11 specialty shows in the metropolitan area caused the principal excitement in the dog show world yesterday, they were only a prelude to the main event, the 109th edition of the Westminster Kennel Club, which begins this morning in Madison Square Garden and tomorrow night.

title: SOUTHERN JOURNAL;THE PEST THEY CALL A WEEVIL
description: For much of the South, the boll weevil is a distant memory. It was more than 70 years ago that the tiny insect devastated millions of acres of cotton bolls and, in doing so, established itself as a permanent fixture of Southern song and folklore.

title: O'Meara Wins in Hawaii for 2 in a Row
description: Mark O'Meara rolled in a 30-foot birdie putt at the 17th hole today to hold off Craig Stadler and capture his second tournament on the PGA Tour this year with a one-stroke victory in the $500,000 Hawaiian Open.

title: U.S. SEEKS MISSILES TO EVADE DEFENSES
description: While the Defense Department has begun research aimed at making Soviet nuclear missiles impotent, a small and secret Air Force program is trying to assure that American nuclear missiles never meet the same fate.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: What freedom am I being offered whilst the organization of the people remains banned? What freedom am I being offered when I may be arrested on a pass offense? What freedom am I being offered to live my life as a family man with my dear wife, who remains in banishment in Brandfort?'' - Nelson Mandela, leader of the African National Congress. (A8:4.)

title: REDDIN AND HIS ROOTS IN 'LIFE AND LIMB'
description: When Keith Reddin's ''Life and Limb'' received a staged reading two years ago, the playwright had a problem. He did not know how to describe the mood of the work to the actors. A friend suggested, ''Donna Reed trapped in a Bertolt Brecht play.''

title: ADVERTISING;Accounts
description: WNEW Radio, Metromedia's flagship station in New York, to Holland & Callaway Advertising.

title: No Headline
description: MONDAY, FEBRUARY 11, 1985 International

title: Times Sells 6-Acre Parcel
description: Harry B. Helmsley and Irving Schneider, president and executive vice president of Helmsley-Spear Inc., have purchased a plot of about 6 acres on Manhattan's West Side from The New York Times Company, it was announced yesterday by Mr. Helmsley, Mr. Schneider and Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, chairman of the Times Company.

title: 4 'Snipers' Were Practicing Target Shooting, Police Say
description: The police said four people arrested here Saturday on suspicion of being snipers were target shooting at a tree.

title: U.S. OLYMPIC GROUPS DIFFER ON SURPLUS
description: The United States Olympic Committee today rejected a proposal to return part of the 1984 Los Angeles Games surplus funds directly to the competing nations, recommending instead the creation of a program to promote international amateur athletics. The program would be administered by the U.S.O.C.

title: Enterprise Zones Deserve a Test
description: The ''enterprise zones'' that the Reagan Administration keeps urging on Congress deserve a fair test. Urban stagnation in some sectors is grave enough to see whether tax reductions and relief from regulation can produce jobs in the most desolate corners. A test is needed also to learn how great the inherent risks of such a program. It is far from clear that the idea justifies President Reagan's prediction of ''new dreams in a million hearts'' and ''a new generation of entrepreneurs.''

title: GRAND JURIES PROTECT RIGHTS OF THE INDIVIDUAL
description: To the Editor:

title: CABARET: LYNNE CHARNAY AT PANACHE
description: Lynne Charnay's cabaret act at Panache, which she will repeat Thursday, Friday and Saturday, is hung on an autobiographical line, an increasingly common device. (Panache is at Avenue of the Americas between 57th and 58th Streets).

title: RANGERS DEFEATED BY THE FLYERS, 3-2
description: The odyssey ended the way it began, with a loss. After dragging across Western Canada, sunny California and the frosty Northeast, the Rangers ended their seven-game trip tonight with a 3-2 loss to the Philadelphia Flyers, finishing their 11-day sojourn with an 0-6-1 record.

title: TV FILM BY PARKS LOOKS AT SLAVERY
description: Born a free black man in the pre- Civil War North, Solomon Northup in 1841 worked as a carpenter and a violinist to support his wife and three children in Saratoga, N.Y. A gifted musician, he attracted the attention of profiteering slave traders who decided they could make money on Northup's talent as well as his physical strength.

title: AT COLUMBIA, 3 DAYS OF ARMS TALKS
description: Some were guardedly hopeful about slowing the arms race. Others felt the chill of a nuclear winter in their bones.

title: IT'S HARVEST TIME AT UPSTATE POND-FOR ICE
description: Five degrees, that's where the mercury in the rust-tinged thermometer at the Crystal View House stuck. There was a bit of wind cooling things off as well.

title: SAUCE FOR MOZAMBIQUE, SAUCE FOR NICARAGUA?
description: To the Editor:

title: BAROQUE' FANCIERS CAN STILL BUY A '55 CHEVY, A PIECE AT A TIME
description: The last 1955 Chevrolet rolled off a General Motors assembly line almost 30 years ago. But they are still in production here, or at least parts of them are, at a small factory that specializes in making components to help restore relics from the heyday of America's love affair with the automobile.

title: MARRYING ACROSS BOUNDARIES
description: For some people the immigrant experience is a living issue, but for many, the fact of intermarriage is simply statistical,'' said Richard D. Alba of the State University of New York at Albany. ''For these couples, there's nothing really remarkable about marrying across the social boundary. It's not such a big deal as it once was.''

title: THATCHER, 10 YEARS AS TORY CHIEF, NOW FACES INCREASING OPPOSITION
description: The long period of domestic popularity enjoyed by Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher since the Falkland war seems to be waning.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE;PRINCIPAL OF MCKINSEY JOINS KIDDER, PEADOBY
description: Donald J. Gogel, a principal in the New York office of McKinsey & Company, the management consulting firm, has been named a vice president and made a shareholder in the merger and acquisitions group at Kidder, Peabody & Company. The appointment is effective Feb. 20.

title: Seeing 'Star Wars' as a Nonnuclear Arrow
description: To the Editor:

title: THE REGION;Infant Recovering After a Transplant
description: A 12-week-old girl who doctors believe is the youngest person to undergo a successful liver transplant was in critical condition today at Yale-New Haven Hospital.

title: O. Pendleton Thomas, Ex-Goodrich Chairman
description: O. Pendleton Thomas, retired chairman of the B.F. Goodrich Company, died Friday at Spring Branch Memorial Hospital in Houston. He was 70 years old and lived in Houston.

title: ANTA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss Anta's year-ago results include operations of Four Seasons Nursing Centers Inc., sold in April, and the Bonray Energy Corp., whose shares were distributed to Anta shareholders in May. The year-ago results also include $7.2 million after-tax writedown on the value of drilling equipment.

title: BERG ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CHAMPION PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes nonrecurring pre-tax gain of $376,000 on the disposition of an idle facility in Grants Pass, Ore. c-After an extraordinary gain of $213,000.

title: NERCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of approximately $3,000,000 from the sale of Alabama coal reserves.

title: Women to Get Hall of Fame
description: A National Women's Athletic Hall of Fame will be established at Smith College, a lawyer leading the project said today.

title: ENDLESS PAIN OF DIVIDED KOREA FAMILIES
description: One can stop almost anybody on the streets of this capital and the odds are high that the person has a relative in North Korea.

title: NASH FINCH CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DEFENSE DEPARTMENT SEEKS MORE MONEY FOR SECRET WEAPONS, ANALYST SAYS
description: The Defense Department has proposed an increase of more than 50 percent in the secret portion of its weapons research and procurement budget, according to a private analysis of Pentagon budget documents.

title: SOUTH KOREA ELECTS ASSEMBLY TODAY
description: A three-week campaign for the National Assembly ended today amid predictions that the ruling party might lose ground in the balloting on Tuesday.

title: FEAR OF MALPRACTICE SUITS SPURRING SOME DOCTORS TO LEAVE OBSTETRICS
description: Faced with a growing number of malpractice claims and the rising expectations of patients, a significant number of the nation's doctors have either abandoned the practice of obstetrics or are seriously considering it.

title: Court Backs Left-Hander
description: A Du Page County Circuit Court jury has awarded $136,700 to a left-handed clerk who was ordered to check out groceries with her right hand.

title: ADAC LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: BRIEFS ;    Debt
description: Chrysler Financial Corp. is issuing $100 million of 12 1/8 percent non-callable subordinated notes, due 1990, priced at 100, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc. The notes are rated Ba-1 by Moody's Investors Service and BBB- by Standard & Poor's.

title: CORRECTION
description: An editorial yesterday referred imprecisely to military pensions at ''half pay.'' Pensions after 20 years of service are half of ''base pay'' - not counting housing and other allowances - or about 35 percent of total compensation.

title: Howard Simpson, 88; Leader of B.&O. Line
description: Howard E. Simpson, retired chairman and president of the Baltimore & Ohio Railroad Company died of a heart attack Sunday at Union Memorial Hospital in Baltimore, where he lived. He was 88 years old.

title: Welfare Chief Sees No Cut in Food Aid
description: The State Social Services Commissioner told legislators today that he did not believe an increase in state welfare grants would prompt a cut in Federal food-stamp payments.

title: NEW STUDY SUSTAINS LINCOLN'S IMAGE
description: After a search spanning nearly a quarter of a century and a lucky discovery in Vermont, a major cache of family documents relating to Abraham Lincoln has finally been assembled for study here in Lincoln's hometown.

title: Jordan Reports an AccordAMMAN, Jordan, Feb. 11 (Reuters) - King Hussein and Yasir Arafat agreed today on the framework of a joint bid for a settlement of the Palestinian issue, the official Jordanian press agency reported.
description: King Hussein and Mr. Arafat, the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, reached the agreement at a working lunch, the agency said.

title: NOTES ON FASHIONS
description: SPRING may not be here yet, but

title: FARM ISSUE: HEADACHES BY THE HUNDREDWEIGHT
description: Sometimes an issue sweeps across Capitol Hill like a blizzard, inundating the lawmakers with public criticism and concern. In the opening weeks of the new Congress, the first problem to burst on the scene is the crisis in farm credit.

Key Rates

Attack by Israeli Planes
description: Israeli Air Force planes attacked what were described as Palestinian guerrilla positions in southeastern Lebanon for the second time in 24 hours today.

description: b-Includes a tax credit of $106,000. c-Includes tax credits of $54,000 for the quarter and $158,000 for the year.

title: STEWART INFORMATION SERVCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a large policy loss of $1,080,000.

title: INQUIRY IS SOUGHT IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: South Africa's official white opposition party is planning to seek a judicial inquiry into police activity in this region after reports of unprovoked police violence in black townships, legislators here say.

title:
BRIEFING;

Who Goes There?
description: Ever since a tourist strolled into the White House behind the Marine Band a few weeks ago, security guards there have become even more careful about admissions.

description: THE New York metropolitan

title: HAMBURGER HAMLETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PROPERTY TRUST OF AMERICA reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,287,000 on the sale of real estate and mortgage notes.

description: William Croasdale, Michael Drake and

title: LAWMAKERS SAY U.S. IS MISUSING AID TO SALVADOR
description: A Congressional caucus accused the Administration today of having supplied ''insufficient, misleading and in some cases false information'' on aid for El Salvador.

title: KANSAS CITY POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Kasparov Postpones Game in Chess Match
description: The 49th game of the world chess championship match between Anatoly Karpov and Gary Kasparov has been postponed until Wednesday, the official press agency Tass reported.

title: REAGAN FAULTS BOTH SIDES IN SEOUL MELEE
description: President Reagan said today that ''bad judgment on both sides'' had led to the melee at the Seoul airport between South Korean security agents and an American delegation accompanying the opposition leader Kim Dae Jung on his return from two years' exile in the United States.

title: S.E.C. CHARGES 5 IN SCHEME TO DEFRAUD BROKERS
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday charged a group of investors with participating in a scheme to defraud some of the nation's largest brokerage firms, including E.F. Hutton & Company, Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. and Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. In a civil lawsuit, the S.E.C. said the five investors in the group bought $10 million of securities without intending to make payment.

title: Beatrice Finishes Sale of 4 Units
description: The Beatrice Companies said that it had completed the sale of its cookie manufacturing operations to a New York investor group, The Prospect Group Inc. Beatrice also said it had closed the previously announced agreements to sell its food-service equipment, agri- products and leather operations. Proceeds from the sale of the four operations totaled about $253 million, the company said.

title: TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 12, 1985
description: Companies

title: Poland-I.M.F. Talks
description: Officials of the International Monetary Fund are here to discuss Poland's wish to rejoin the I.M.F., Zbigniew Karcz of the Finance Ministry said today, according to the daily Zycie Warszawy. The United States lifted its veto after Poland released some political prisoners last July.

title: Article 020906 -- No Title
description: People Express Airlines yesterday reported a $9 million fourth-quarter loss that exceeded analysts' expectations and reflected the strain on the low-cost carrier of its rapid expansion.

title: GRAINGER, W W INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Learning Disabled May Be Depressed
description: A five-year study indicates that the learning disabilities of some children may be caused by depression, a Temple University psychologist says.

title: CAN JUST ANYONE NAME THOSE STARS?
description: AS Valentine's day approaches, several organizations that offer, for a fee, to assign a person's name to a star appear to be doing the celestial equivalent of a land office business. Naming a heavenly body for a loved one, one organization says in its television commercials, is an ideal way to declare one's eternal love.

title: U.S.O.C. Plan Will Be Studied
description: The Los Angeles Olympic Organizing Committee executive board said today it would study a United States Olympic Committee proposal to use $7 million in Olympic surplus funds to establish a ''Friendship Program'' with athletes from other nations.

title: WEDCO TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $49,000.

title: PLEASE, NOT THE CARDINALS
description: By noon yesterday, two people from Long Island had phoned the offices of the football Cardinals in St. Louis to order 1985 season tickets. No, those people are not about to relocate in the St. Louis area. Their phone calls were prompted by the news over the weekend that New York City is exploring the possibility of persuading the Cardinals to fly to a new nest in Shea Stadium, abandoned by the Jets for Giants Stadium last season.

title: ST. LAWRENCE CEMENT CO reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Comings and Goings
description: Kelly Kisio , the Detroit Red Wings center, was suspended for five games in connection with a high-sticking incident Feb. 2 against Quebec. . . .

title: Greek Premier Receives Warm Soviet Welcome
description: Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou of Greece arrived to a warm welcome in Moscow today, saying that improving relations with the Soviet Union were based on ''corresponding views on many international problems.''

title: MACMILLAN BLOEDEL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-There were no share earnings for the latest year because of preferred dividend requirements. c-After an extraordinary loss of $4,300,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary gain of $21,100,000 for the year. Year-ago results are restated to reflect a change in accounting for foreign exchange.

title: VACU-DRY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
$14,500 FOR TEACHERS AIN'T PAY
description: Because the public schools in this city are in trouble, because they are turning out almost as many dropouts as high school graduates, many worried people are trying to raise the public's consciousness about the problem.

title: Britain Rejects Norway Deal
description: Britain has vetoed a $26.7 billion agreement to buy natural gas from Norway's huge Sleipner field in the North Sea, both Governments announced today.

title: Gooden Waits
description: Jim Neader , the agent representing the Met pitcher

title: ;   New York's Crime Problem, Circa 1850
description: To the Editor:

title: McGovern's Campaign Told To Repay Some U.S. Funds
description: The Federal Election Commission today ordered George McGovern's 1984 Presidential campaign committee to repay the Government some $25,000 in Federal matching funds, part of which were used to help pay him a salary when he was seeking the Democratic nomination.

title: WEIGH-TRONIX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CAGLE'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
description: b-After tax credits of $9,000 for the quarter and $124,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss

title: DIA FOUNDATION CUTS ART FUNDING
description: The Dia Foundation, one of the major private funding sources in the field of contemporary art, has drastically cut back on the funding of its projects. It is plagued by a shortage of operating funds and the threat of a lawsuit from the sculptor Donald Judd. Its co-founder and vice president, Heiner Friedrich, has ''temporarily'' resigned, and several trustees have been added to broaden its base of support.

title: THEATER: 'PACK OF LIES' AT THE ROYALE
description: HUGH WHITEMORE'S ''Pack of Lies,'' the new play at the Royale, tells a cold war spy story about KGB agents and purloined NATO secrets, but its author won't settle for entertaining the audience with anything as trivial as a suspense yarn. This is a play about the morality of lying, not the theatrics of espionage, and, in Mr. Whitemore's view, lying is a virulent disease that saps patriots and traitors alike of their humanity.

title: YALTA IN 1985: COLD CITY AND ENDURING METAPHOR
description: An unusually cold winter has frosted the palm trees on the grounds of Livadia Palace, where 40 years ago the victorious Allies signed the Yalta agreement outlining the shape of postwar Europe.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Feb. 12, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: 'MIRACLE PLANT' TESTED AS CATTLE FODDER
description: BY transplanting bacteria from the digestive tracts of Hawaiian goats, researchers are making it possible to test a ''miracle plant'' as fodder for cattle in many parts of the world.

title: SALEM CARPET MILLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of approximately $1,400,000 from the sale of a plant and the disposition of equipment.

title: EVEN HALF WAY IS WRONG
description: Advocates of an interim missile-defense system say it could be in orbit in the early 1990's at a cost that is not mind-boggling. What they don't say is that it would be a house of cards. The foundations of the proposal are the same misconceptions that underlie the entire ''Star Wars'' initiative.

title: BARNES GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $2,540,000. c-Net loss after a loss from discontinued operations of $12,703,000.

description: Take the H train? How about the G?

title: Harris May Show New Switchboard
description: The Harris Corporation, the maker of electronics equipment based in Melbourne, Fla., is expected to introduce a new electronic switchboard today called the Harris 20-20.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;   Computer Leases Back Financing by Sperry
description: The move to repackage loans and other assets into securities took a large step forward yesterday when the Sperry Corporation announced plans to sell $200 million of notes backed by computer leases, through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: Police Fire Rubber Bullets
description: The police used rubber bullets, tear gas and whips to subdue protests today by more than 3,000 schoolchildren in black townships in South Africa's Orange Free State, a police spokesman said.

title: COMMON VIRUS LINKED TO CANCER
description: VIRUSES related to those that cause common warts are coming under increasing suspicion as factors in causing human cancer of the cervix and other types of malignancy.

title: Transactions
description: Signed Mike Boddicker and Storm Davis, pitchers. CLEVELAND (AL) - Signed Mike Fischlin, infielder, to one-year contract. METS (NL) - Agreed to terms with Rafael Santana, shortstop, on a one-year contract.

title: JURY TOLD OF ORDER TO CUT TROOP COUNT
description: Michael F. Dilley, a retired Army major, testified yesterday at the trial of Gen. William C. Westmoreland's libel suit against CBS that he was ordered by a colonel in June 1967 to reduce ''arbitrarily'' estimates of the Vietcong's political cadre.

title: REAGAN HAS ALLERGY SHOTS
description: President Reagan said today that he had completed a set of shots to combat nagging allergies that have plagued him for a number of years.

title: No Death Rate Impact Found In U.S. Study of Agent Orange
description: A new study of airmen exposed to the herbicide Agent Orange in the Vietnam War showed they did not suffer a higher death rate than people not in contact with the chemical, the Air Force said today.

title: GEORGETOWN TOIPS VILLANOVA BY 57-50
description: Patrick Ewing scored 16 points and grabbed 11 rebounds as second- ranked Georgetown held off Villanova, 57-50, in a Big East Conference game tonight.

description: Alice Tully was the guest of honor at a dinner of la Confrerie des Chevaliers du Tastevin last night at the Pierre Hotel.
