The year-ago quarter also includes real estate gains of $1,142,000 and the 6 months net a year ago includes a nonrecurring gain of $6,158,000 from the sale of a unit.

title: Conrail's Net Drops
description: The Consolidated Rail Corporation said today that its fourth-quarter net income fell 23.8 percent, to $89.6 million, from $117.5 million a year ago. Revenues dropped 2 percent, to $$791.9 million, from $808.1 million.

title: Briton Found Not Guilty Of Disclosing Secrets
description: A civil servant was cleared by a jury today of charges that he had disclosed state secrets relating to the sinking of the Argentine cruiser Belgrano during the Falkland war.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Nets vs. Bucks, at Milwaukee, 8:30 P.M. In their last game before the all-star break last Wednesday night, the Nets beat the Bucks, the leaders of the Central Division, 103-93, at Byrne. That stretched the Nets' victory streak to four; they have not lost a game since Darryl Dawkins returned to the lineup. (Television - SportsChannel, 8:30 P.M. Radio - WNBC 660, 8:30 P.M.)

title: JETS' MOVES TO INCLUDE 3-4 DEFENSE
description: A series of major changes to the New York Jets' coaching staff since the end of the 1984 season heralds not only a significant change in the team's playing style, but it apparently precedes many cuts and trades of players.

title: Three Former Officers Sentenced in Philadelphia
description: Three former police vice officers convicted of racketeering were sentenced today to prison terms ranging from three to seven years by a Federal judge who said he had ''no choice'' but to incarcerate them.

title: CLOSING ARGUMENTS MADE IN VIETNAMESE IMMIGRANT'S MURDER TRIAL
description: In closing arguments at the trial of a Vietnamese immigrant accused of murdering a university professor, the prosecution today characterized the defendant as a cold, remorseless killer and told the jury that the evidence called for a verdict of first-degree murder.

description: The latest quarter is 12 weeks compared with 13 weeks a year ago. The latest year is 52 weeks compared with 53 weeks a year ago.

title: Robert Day, 84, Dead; New Yorker Cartoonist
description: Robert Day, a cartoonist who contributed hundreds of drawings to The New Yorker over 45 years, died last Thursday in St. Louis. He was 84 years old and lived in Gravette, Ark.

title: A Budding Clamor
description: Central Ohioans enthusiastically built themselves a fancy international airport several years ago, and with it came a distinctly hearty appeal for a ''dynamic, distinguishing and monumental'' sculpture. After a proper search and competition, Roy Lichtenstein, that durable star of the Pop Art firmament, won the $150,000 commission, and the pessimists wrung their hands and predicted a furor.

title: TANDON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Unocal Corp. Not for Sale' LOS ANGELES, Feb. 11 -
description: Fred L. Hartley, chairman and president of the Unocal Corporation, asserted that the company ''certainly is not for sale.'' Unocal, which has been among the most heavily traded stocks in recent weeks on the New York Stock Exchange, has been the subject of much speculation among Wall Street analysts as a possible takeover target for T. Boone Pickens, the Texas oilman.

description: b-Net income

title: COLUMBIA UNDAUNTED BY LOFTY REDMEN
description: Wayne Szoke, the Columbia basketball coach, knows that his team has little chance of upsetting top-ranked St. John's tonight at Levien Gymnasium on the Columbia campus. But he can't come right out and say that.

title: SUSAN TRIBICH
description: Susan Tribich, the author of a guidebook to Africa and a letters correspondent for Time magazine, died of cancer Sunday in New York.

title: Hanoi Reportedly Will Return Remains of 5 Troops to U.S.
description: Vietnam will turn over to the United States the remains of five people it says are Americans listed as missing in action in the Vietnam War, reliable sources disclosed today.

title: NICARAGUA WAGES BITTER WAR AGAINST MARKET 'PROFITEERS'
description: Even as the guerrilla war on Nicaragua's borders intensifies, the Nicaraguan Government is aiming its sights at what it views as an equally dangerous enemy: the peddlers and small shopkeepers it has classified as ''speculators, profiteers and hoarders.''

description: b-Includes a pre-tax gain of $1,400,000 from the sale of investment securities. c-After a pre-tax charge of $1,300,000 from an increase in the value of employee stock appreciation rights.

description: b-Includes tax credits of $2,497,000 for the quarter and $8,370,000 for the year.

title:
PIE IN THE SKY - OR SPACE DEFENSE?;

IF 'STAR WARS' WORKS
description: The writer Arthur C. Clarke said that every revolutionary idea invokes three reactions: ''It's completely impossible.'' ''It's possible, but it's not worth doing.'' ''I said it was a good idea all along.'' The Strategic Defense Initiative - ''Star Wars'' - is such a revolutionary idea.

title: Chip Maker
description: Texas Instruments Inc. said it had started volume production of its 256k - meaning 256,000 characters of storage - dynamic random access memory chips.

title: CABARET: ANN CALLAWAY
description: ANN HAMPTON CALLAWAY, the singer and pianist who is holding forth Tuesdays through Saturdays at Les Tuileries (40 Central Park South), is a strong, versatile soprano with an engaging sense of humor. Miss Callaway's repertory includes well- chosen, less-known show tunes like ''Fifty Percent,'' from ''Ballroom,'' and ''Old Friend,'' from ''I'm Getting My Act Together and Taking It on the Road,'' as well as jazz standards like ''Twisted'' and original ballads.

title: SERVICEMASTER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HOW TALENT CAN BE NURTURED
description: CONTRARY to popular myth, talent does not automatically rise to the top, like cream in milk. To be translated into outstanding accomplishment, talent must be nurtured in the home, developed by the right kind of teachers and honed by years of continuous training and practice.

title: Lord, Geller Sets Up Direct Marketing Unit
description: Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein has created a new division, LGFE/ Direct Marketing, which will be headed by Barbara E. Corrigan as president. The new division will be based in the agency's Madison Avenue offices.

title: Music/Noted in Brief;   Chamber Orchestra With Claudio Abbado
description: Five years ago, some young musicians who had reached the cut-off age as members of the European Community Youth Orchestra gathered into a smaller group, won corporate support, moved to London and now function busily as the Chamber Orchestra of Europe. With their artistic adviser, Claudio Abbado, they are making their first tour of this country; and Sunday night, with Hildegard Behrens as soloist, they gave a generous evening of Brahms, Ligeti, Beethoven, Mahler and Mozart at Carnegie Hall.

title: ALUMAX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a $14.3 million DISC tax credit for the quarter and year.

title: MULLER OF THE DEVILS MATURING QUICKLY
description: Kirk Muller, the Devils' rookie center who celebrated his 19th birthday last Friday, is holding his own against the older, more experienced players in the National Hockey League. But, to those who know him, that's not necessarily surprising. Ever since he was a child, Muller has played with better and older players.

title: I.R.S. FOCUS ON SHELTERS PUTS STRAIN ON AGENCY
description: Combatting tax shelters has become the main priority of the Internal Revenue Service, but a question increasingly asked is whether that emphasis overstrains the agency.

title: STUDENT CONTEST EVALUATES SPREADSHEET PROGRAMS
description: WHICH electronic spreadsheet is the best? To find out, 10 of the leading software programs were tested last weekend in an unusual marathon showdown.

title: COURT CASE TESTS LAW ON THERAPY INSURANCE
description: Cynthia Bousfield said psychotherapy saved her life. ''I felt like I wanted to give up,'' the 28-year-old secretary and mother of two said. ''I'd probably be on welfare, the children would have gone to the state.''

title: Boston Bank Cites 'Systems Failure'
description: The Bank of Boston said today that its failure to report $1.22 billion in cash transfers with foreign banks stemmed from mistakes by at least 10 to 12 of the bank's departments as well as its auditors.

title: Kodak Reports 74.4% Rise in 4th-Quarter Profit
description: The Eastman Kodak Company, citing the positive impact of its staff-reduction program, reported yesterday that its earnings in the fourth quarter of 1984 climbed 74.4 percent as sales rose 7 percent.

title: PRODUCT ABANDONED BY DIGITAL
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation, responding to reports that one of its key manufacturing facilities was being dismantled, conceded yesterday that it has ceased production of its Rainbow personal computer.

title: Janos Starker to Appear With Schools Orchestra
description: Janos Starker, the cellist, will be guest soloist at a concert of the Independent Schools Orchestra at the auditorium of Trinity School, 101 West 91st Street, at 8 P.M. on Feb. 26.

title: Holiday Closings Today
description: Some banks and Government offices will be closed today in observance of Lincoln's Birthday, but stock and commodity markets will be open. Because of the bank closings in New York, Government securities trading will be limited.

3 Youths Charged In Office Burglary
description: Three Long Island teen-agers have been arrested in connection with a fire and burglary at a State Department of Labor job-service office here late last year, the police said today.

title: PACT ON WATER USE FOR LAKES SIGNED
description: The governors of six states and Quebec's Minister of International Relations signed an agreement today to guard the Great Lakes against possible raids by Southern and Southwestern states.

title: LIVELY SCOTTIE ADVANCES AT WESTMINSTER
description: The two top-winning dogs in America - a strong, agile German shepherd and a perky Scottish terrier - yesterday afternoon hurdled the first obstacles in their bids to take this year's top canine prize as the Westminster Kennel Club opened a two- day run at the Garden.

title: ELATION AND DESPAIR FLOW TOGETHER IN HEART TEST
description: THOUGH the implicit drama of the artificial heart experiment is perhaps as great as any other, its day-to-day events fluctuate between elation and triumph on the one hand and deep discouragement on the other.

title: Welcome Promotions at City Hall
description: Mayor Koch must have been delighted to be able to appoint a woman, Alair Townsend, as a Deputy Mayor just as another woman, City Council President Carol Bellamy, was announcing her candidacy for his job. But favorable political appearances are the least of Miss Townsend's qualifications. She is likely to bring distinction to a job held by four people in seven years, the most recent being Kenneth Lipper, who has resigned to run for the Council presidency.

description: The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced yesterday that it had decided to consolidate its consumer products advertising under one agency, N W Ayer.

title: FAHD ASKS REAGAN TO STEP UP MOVES FOR MIDEAST PEACE
description: King Fahd of Saudi Arabia urged President Reagan today to engage the United States ''more vigorously'' in the search for peace in the Middle East and to support ''the just cause of the Palestinian people.''

description: Effective April 1, 1983, the company changed its financial reporting year- end from March 31 to Dec. 31. Therefore, full year results are not comparable as 1983 figures reflect only 9 months of operations.

BRIEFING;

A Call to Poverty?
description: The Pentagon, it seems, is facing

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;   President Resigns At Midway Airlines
description: Neal F. Meehan is resigning as president and chief operating officer of Midway Airlines, the carrier said yesterday. No successor has been chosen.

title: NURSES DISPUTE AND DEFEND MEMOIR ON LIFE IN VIETNAM WAR
description: The memoirs of an Army nurse who served in Vietnam have sparked a sharp dispute among other Vietnam nurses, who say that the popular book and its planned movie adaptation malign their work in the war zone.

title: A WOMAN, 78, DISARMS A ROBBER IN JERSEY STORE
description: A 78- year-old woman whose small grocery store here had been robbed twice in two weeks grabbed a knife from a youth in a third holdup Sunday and scared him away with her screams, the police said.

title: Chemical's Consumer Rates Cut
description: The Chemical Bank announced yesterday that it was lowering its rates on a variety of consumer loans, including new and used auto and boat loans, unsecured personal loans and home equity loans.

title: James M. Read, 76, Educator And Ex-U.N. Refugee Official
description: James Morgan Read, an educator and former United Nations Deputy High Commissioner for Refugees, died of a heart attack yesterday at New York Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: COST OF MISSILE DEFENSE PUT AT $70 BILLION BY 1993
description: The cost of developing the technology for a defense against nuclear missiles would reach about $70 billion by 1993 but could be as much as $100 billion, two military analysts asserted today.

title: Topics Out of the Cold
description: Hosting the HomelessBefore seeking official help, most of New York City's homeless families try the time-honored unofficial approach, moving in with relatives and friends, even though they themselves may be poor welfare recipients. Formalizing and encouraging that way of providing temporary lodgings could release millions of dollars to build permanent new housing.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Bank of the West, San Francisco, has promoted Donald A. Pelton to senior executive vice president.

title: Baseball Talks Resume Briefly
description: Negotiators for baseball's owners and players met briefly here yesterday, then adjourned until next Tuesday. In the interim, Lee MacPhail, the owners' labor representative, will brief them on the state of the talks for a new basic agreement.

title: Deere Expects Loss in Quarter
description: Deere & Company, the nation's largest farm equipment manufacturer, announced that it expected to report a loss for the quarter ended Jan. 31.

title: UNESCO BUDGET PLAN FAULTED
description: Western members of Unesco assert that the agency's director general is planning to make up the loss of the United States contribution this year from a budget contingency fund instead of returning that excess money to the organization's members.

title: New Rule For Banks
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation today adopted a long- awaited regulation setting a minimum capital standard for banks. Also the agency proposed to require more public disclosure of individual banks' financial problems.

title: Ex-Police Officer Accused in Slaying
description: A retired New York City police officer has been charged with seconddegree murder and assault in the wounding of his daughter's boyfriend and the shooting death of the boyfriend's brother.

title: T-BAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BUSINESS-MINDED HEALTH CARE
description: During a 10-hour period on a recent Saturday, Dr. Edmund Bolton treated 26 patients at the Doctors Officenter in Hanover Park, Ill., a Chicago suburb. ''In the summertime it can go up to 40 when the kids are out of school,'' he said.

title: HALLIBURTON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After provisions for civil antitrust litigation settlements of $37,341,000 for the quarter and $39,023,000 for the year. The company said profit for the quarter and year were reduced by legal costs related to the South Texas Nuclear Project, which cost about $15 million in the fourth quarter.

title: Kosar's Decision
description: Although the National Football League college draft is still some 10 weeks away, Bernie Kosar, the University of Miami quarterback, will likely decide by March 4 - the day spring practice begins for the Hurricanes - whether he will return for his junior season or make himself eligible for the N.F.L. draft.

description: Southern Corporation's subsidiary railroad companies

title: MOSINEE PAPER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SHOREHAM: OLD ARGUMENTS RENEWED
description: New York State and Suffolk County are pressing their case against low- power tests at the Shoreham Nuclear Power Station with two arguments that the Nuclear Regulatory Commission has previously rejected. A decision on whether to allow the $4.2 billion reactor to begin testing at up to 5 percent power could come as early as today. Technically the vote will be over whether such testing can begin before the Long Island Lighting Company, the owner, finishes work on a system to provide electric power to the reactor during blackouts.

title: NEW 'MOUSE' RESIDES ON THE FLOOR
description: MICE have been scurrying around personal computers for about two years now. Though far from dwelling at the side of every machine, these pointing devices, which are used to take over the functions of the cursor keys, have grown in popularity to the point of becoming accepted fixtures. In fact, Apple's Macintosh, which does not have cursor keys, cannot be used at all without a mouse.

title: Sears Will Publicize Safety Kit for Bunk
description: Prodded for a year by the father of a boy killed in a bunk-bed accident, Sears, Roebuck & Company has agreed to publicize a modification kit for the beds.

title: Generals Cut Punter
description: Bob Grupp, the Generals' regular punter last season, was cut from the team yesterday along with 11 other players as New Jersey moved to get down to the required 58 players.

title: TheWill
description: The city said yesterday that asbestos would be removed from 571 sites owned or leased by the city, but that the cancer-causing substance posed no danger to city workers.

title: Judge Frank A. Hooper, 89; Ordered Atlanta Integration
description: Retired Federal District Judge Frank A. Hooper Jr., who ordered and supervised the integration of the Atlanta public school system, died today at his home. He was 89 years old.

title: FCS INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Prices of Treasury Issues Fall
description: Treasury note and bond prices fell as much as half a point yesterday as securities dealers encountered weak investor demand for new Treasury issues sold last week.

title: LEBANESE ATTACKS AGAINST ISRAELIS AND THEIR AGENTS ARE UP SHARPLY
description: At least 30 Lebanese and Palestinians working for Israel in south Lebanon have been assassinated by unidentified gunmen in the last seven weeks, according to Israeli military officials and independent security sources in south Lebanon.

title: Pabst Chairman Copes With New Merger Shift
description: The Pabst Brewing Company said that it had changed its position and would ''strongly support'' a tender offer of $10 a share from the S&P Company, headed by Paul Kalmanovitz, a California brewer. Pabst made its decision after the G. Heileman Brewing Company allowed its $11-a-share offer to expire Friday and withdrew its bid.

title: Singing Thanks For the Melody
description: For Giant fans who may need assurance that the last National Football League season was not a dream - that their favorite team indeed made the playoffs and defeated the Los Angeles Rams before losing to the San Francisco 49ers - relief is only a phone call away.

title: PROSECUTOR WITHDRAWS PLEA OFFER IN BELUSHI'S DRUG OVERDOSE DEATH
description: A lawyer for Cathy Evelyn Smith, who is charged with murdering John Belushi, the comedian, said in court today that he wants to take the case to trial.

title: BARDEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 27
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,422,314, or 80 cents a share, on the sale of land and buildings by the company's U.K. subsidiary. c-Includes a gain of $525,000, or 29 cents a share, from a DISC tax credit.

title: CHIEFTAIN DEVELOPMENT CO reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
On One Condition
description: John Walker of New Zealand intends to be the first man to run 100 sub-four minute miles. According to his carefully-planned schedule, he should achieve that feat on Sunday at Auckland, New Zealand, and for sentimental reasons he has invited his friend and countryman, Rod Dixon, to join him in the race.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS ;   Dollar Reaches a Peak Against Pound, Franc
description: The dollar continued its seemingly relentless rise in foreign exchange markets yesterday, winding up at record closing highs against the currencies of Britain, France, Italy and Canada and at a 13-year high against the West German mark.

description: b-Includes a credit of $2,482,874.

description: A conservative group, Fairness in Media, confirmed today that it is considering a proxy battle to get 1 or 2 seats on the 13-member board of CBS Inc.

description: As the wife of a world leader, she used to come to Washington with bodyguards and an entourage. She has returned as a professor, a private citizen with a cause of her own.

title: CONCORD COMPUTING reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The share earnings and shares outstanding are fully diluted.

title: SWEEPS BRING A FLURRY OF ACTIVITY
description: This week, WCBS-TV's local news operation promotes a piece of film of a heart transplant in full-page newspaper ads. WABC-TV offers the viewer a chance to fill out answers on a ''value test'' that will determine whether a viewer is ''in step,'' and WNBC-TV announces that it is investigating the way it covers the news itself in a populist-oriented series called ''Is Television News Fair?''

description: Reporters have a First Amendment right to attend Federal hearings into the Wilberg Mine disaster as long as other interested parties are being admitted, a Federal judge ruled today.

description: b-After a tax credit of $600,000.

title: Leveraged Buyout For U.S. Steel Unit
description: The United States Steel Corporation said yesterday that it intended to sell its agrichemicals division to the unit's management in a leveraged buyout. Terms were not disclosed.

description: Digital Equipment said it had ceased production of its Rainbow personal computer. Page 32.

title: ALL-STARS GATHER AT N.H.L. RONDUP
description: First the Islander cowhands strode in, then the ones from Edmonton, then others from all over the National Hockey League, and then came the sherriffs - the coaches - one from the East and one from the West. And they all sat down, talking it up as if they were long-lost kinfolk.

title: BALLOONIST AND 5 KILLED IN PLANE
description: Ben Abruzzo, who took part in the first balloon crossings of the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans, was killed along with his wife and four others today when a twin-engine plane he was flying crashed just after takeoff.

title: HEALTH CARE FUND INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Canada Oil Pact
description: The Government today formally ended years of wrangling over the development of Canada's oil-rich east coast by signing an offshore oil and gas agreement with Newfoundland. Prime Minister Brian Mulroney hailed the agreement in principle as the most important pact between Ottawa and St. John's since Newfoundland joined Canada 35 years ago.

title: Diminishing Domain
description: ''Oh, who owns New York?'' The answer to this question, from a college song, used to be ''C-o-l- u-m-b-i-a.''

title: CANADA TRUSTCO MORTGAGE CO reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: Beanpot Crown To Northeastern
description: Mark Lori scored two third-period goals tonight to lift Northeastern to a 4-2 victory over Boston University and give the underdog Huskies their second straight Beanpot hockey title.

title: TO WEAR, MUSEUM PIECES
description: Jenny Bell Whyte, who makes new clothes from old textiles, invited some friends and admirers to her East Side brownstone to show off her work. It wasn't your usual fashion show. Instead of using professional models who move in patterns as complicated as the Rockettes', Mrs. Whyte asked her daughter, a sophomore at Barnard College, and some of her clients to show the clothes. She told the story of the fabrics as the women drifted down the staircase to the parlor showroom, looking as if they were wearing precious jewels and enjoying the experience.

title: Pickens Attacks Phillips 'Poison Pill'
description: T. Boone Pickens, the Texas oilman, attacked the Phillips Petroleum Company yesterday for creating a ''poison pill,'' a device that would make an unfriendly takeover practically impossible.

title: Twins Sign Hrbek
description: Kent Hrbek , the Minnesota Twin first baseman who was just four days away from an arbitration hearing in New York, signed a five-year contract with the club for a reported $6 million. Hrbek had been seeking $1.1 million for 1985 in arbitration, while the Twins had offered $650,000.

title: Talk of a StrikeSeveral players said that for the first time, the word strike had entered the vocabulary of the players association and its executive director, Alan Eagleson. But they doubt that a strike will occur. The players' four-year contact expires in September 1987, but the association can terminate it in September 1986.
description: ''Eagleson came to us and talked about the possibility of a strike,'' said Mark Osborne of the Rangers, who is here as the Ranger representative for players association meetings. ''The players were receptive to it because something has to be done to fix the free-agent system, but nobody wants it and I don't think it will happen.''

title: RESEACHERS IDENTIFY TRUE CLUES TO LYING
description: PEOPLE are surprisingly inept, new research shows, at detecting lies. One reason is that most of the supposed clues to deceit, such as shifty eyes or nervousness, seldom, in fact, accompany a premeditated lie. Another reason is that people generally have not been aware of the more reliable indicators, which psychologists have only now begun to identify.

title: NEW DESIGN MAKES GIANT TELESCOPES POSSIBLE
description: RADICAL new techniques for making giant telescopes are being developed, holding the promise of opening new vistas into the universe. These large-scale optical devices, some of them planned to be more than twice the size of the biggest telescopes operating today, will be able to look far enough out across the universe, and therefore back in time, to record its infancy. They should also be able to look deep into the cores of the Milky Way and other galaxies to seek out the nature of the mysterious ''engines'' generating vast amounts of energy there. Conventional telescopes have been limited in size by the extreme difficulty of casting very large blocks of glass, polishing them into large mirrors of exactly the necessary shape and maintaining that shape despite the effects of temperature and sag as they sweep the skies. The new telescopes, all of them proven in tests but not yet in full-scale operation, are being made possible by such innovations as mass production of large mirrors in swirling baths of molten glass, liquid mirrors formed of large, fast-spinning basins of mercury, and the use of multiple conventional telescopes linked together in the fashion of the large arrays of antennas used in radio astronomy.

title: 2 VIEWS OF STEEL'S FUTURE
description: One recent night several hundred people, many of them rough-faced, unemployed steelworkers, packed the auditorium of a church in Duquesne, Pa., to discuss saving part of the United States Steel Corporation's huge plant there. As people left the hall and chairs were being clapped shut and put away, Ray Chandler, a motor inspector at the works before it closed last year, mused on the future of the aging steel mills that dot the Monongahela Valley. ''If they could save Duquesne, they could start working to save the rest,'' said Mr. Chandler, who is still out of work.

description: UNLIKE most men, millions of women regularly visit doctors even when they believe they are perfectly healthy. They go for checkups and assistance with regard to their gynecological - sexual and reproductive - health. As a result, a woman's interaction with the doctor who provides her gynecological care is likely to be the most important medical encounter of her adult life. This is the doctor who may help her with contraception, infertility, prenatal care, childbirth, menstrual difficulties, breast and hormonal abnormalities, genitourinary infections and other problems and needs.

title: THEATER: 'CRUELTIES OF MRS. SCHNAYD'
description: YEARS ago, Mrs. Schnayd sent her landlords a plum pudding for Christmas. Now, in a more spiteful time, tenants put roaches in the envelopes along with their rent checks - when they send their rent checks. Mrs. Schnayd is the last holdout in a dilapidated slum building the Boynton brothers are trying to sell to a real estate developer. As she sees it, she has life tenancy, and both her tenancy and her life are in jeopardy. The Boyntons' attempt to evict the stubborn widow is the main plot line, but far from the sum total, of David Suehsdorf's new play, ''The Cruelties of Mrs. Schnayd.''

Bidders already include A.T.&T., MCI Communications and GTE Sprint. Bids are due in December.

title: FOR A COOK'S COMPUTER

It conjures up images of sterile, mathematically derived recipes that are about as stimulating as a logarithm chart. But the computer software program shown here, called the Recipe Writer, does not usurp the cook's artistic powers at all; indeed, it might help unleash them by better organizing you and your kitchen tasks.

title: COALITION MANEUVERS

Farrell Jr. walked into the fourth-floor conference room he shares with Assemblyman Albert Vann in Albany's Legislative Office Building and with one sentence changed the face of the New York City mayoral campaign. ''I told him that I'm going to now look to see if I should run, and I would get back to him in 24 hours,'' Mr. Farrell recalled yesterday.

title: EXPLOSION RUINS A PAINT FACTORY IN NORTH JERSEY
description: An explosion and fire destroyed a paint manufacturing plant here today, killing one person and seriously burning another, the authorities said. Two firefighters and a police officer were treated for smoke inhalation.

Sam Bowie, Portland's rookie center, had 16 points, 13 rebounds and blocked four shots. Larry Bird scored 25 points to top the Celtics, who fell to 41-10.

title: 'SOLOMON NORTHRUP'S ODSSEY,' STORY OF A SLAVE
description: ''SOLOMON NORTHRUP'S ODYSSEY'' wants to both enlighten and horrify as it dramatizes the darkest pages of American history. It gives us an earnest and intelligent depiction, although its real subject - the moral effect of slavery - stays just out of reach. It is almost as if the drama's good taste is keeping it at bay. The two-hour ''American Playhouse'' production will be seen on Channel 13 at 9 tonight.

title: WHAM FACING UP TO NEW POPULARITY
description: WHEN the British group Wham steps onstage tomorrow for its sold-out concert at the Beacon Theater, on Broadway at 75th Street, it will no doubt be greeted by the sound of screaming teen-agers. ''There's nothing wrong with teeny- boppers,'' said George Michael, Wham's 21-year-old lead singer and songwriter. ''They're great kids, but the minute you're lumped with teeny- bopper bands, no one listens to the music anymore.''

title: ST. PATRICK'S MARSHAL ELECTION ENDS BID MADE BY A WOMAN
description: The Nassau County Comptroller, Peter King, last night was elected grand marshal of this year's St. Patrick's Day Parade in New York City.

title: SOUTHLAND ROYALTY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago results include a gain of $28,200,000 on the sale of producing oil properties and a one-time charge of $5,600,000 from the writedown of an investment. Results for the latest year include a gain of $1,800,000 on the sale of producing oil and gas properties.

title: SHOREHAM IS GIVEN A PERMIT TO BEGIN LOW-LEVEL TRIALS
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission voted 4 to 1 today to allow the Shoreham Nuclear Power Station to begin testing at up to 5 percent of full power.

title: Plea for Purity
description: With Peter Ueberroth, the commissioner of baseball, ready to poll the nation's fans to try to learn their feelings about the designated hitter, one baseball purist has already begun a campaign to ''alert Americans to the inherent evils of the d.h. and convince them to cast their votes accordingly.''

title: PENNEY ON HARASSMENT
description: The J. C. Penney Company acknowledged today that some of its debt collectors might have harassed credit-card customers whose accounts were overdue.

title: IMPACT OF USING NUCLEAR REACTOR AT A LOW LEVEL
description: Scientists say operating a nuclear reactor at 5 percent of full power is significant because it results in the production of radioactivity.

title: Eagle Chairman Resigns
description: Eagle Computer Inc. said yesterday that Ronald N. Mickwee had resigned as chairman. No replacement was named.

title: West German Aide Defends Nation's Security Reputation
description: A senior West German official said today that the Bonn Government resented American press reports that painted his country as a security sieve through which militarily useful high technology was escaping to the Soviet Union.

title: McGovern's Campaign Told To Repay Some U.S. Funds
description: The Federal Election Commission ordered George McGovern's 1984 Presidential campaign committee on Monday to repay the Government $25,000 in Federal matching funds, part of which were used to help pay him a salary when he was seeking the Democratic nomination.

title: SANMARK-STARDUST INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 10 percent stock dividend paid in December 1984.

title: Larry Flynt Pleads Guilty
description: The publisher of Hustler magazine, Larry Flynt, has pleaded guilty in Federal court to charges that he used threatening and abusive language before the United States Supreme Court. A sentencing date for Mr. Flynt, who entered his plea on Monday, was set for March 11. Mr. Flynt, 41 years old, was removed from the Supreme Court in his gold-plated wheelchair after he interrupted proceedings of the Court on Nov. 8, 1983, by shouting invective.

title: GENERAL GROWTH PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $264,327,000 on the sale of assets and a charge of $15,566,000 for the provision for possible loss on the disposition of real estate. c-Includes gain of $593,000 on the sale of assets. The company attributed its large gains in the latest first quarter to the sale of 19 shopping centers on Nov. 30.

title: CHICAGO'S COUNCIL DUELS MAYOR OVER ETHICS BILLS
description: From all appearances, Mayor Harold Washington has transformed a City Council historically known for corruption and graft into a legislative body that is suddenly concerned about ethics and the spoils system.

title: 'Atlanta Child Murders' Draws Strong Ratings
description: The made-for-television movie about Atlanta's child murders and the conviction of Wayne Williams, which has drawn strong criticism from Atlanta city officials, received high, but not extraordinary, ratings nationwide.

title: RESORTS' CHAIRMAN DENIES AUTHORIZING BAHAMAS PAYMENT
description: The chairman of Resorts International testified Monday that he was ''floored'' last summer to learn that $431,000 in company money had been passed on to the Prime Minister of the Bahamas.

title: MAPPING CHINATOWN, A TIE WITH A DIFFERENCE
description: 1.*Guide to Chinatown The Chinese New Year falls on Feb. 20 this year, and as usual it will be a time for parades and feasting in Chinatown. The festivities always attract flocks of tourists, and anyone who doesn't know the area might wish to take along the new Chinatown Map and Guide, published by Iris' Art Studio. It includes a brief history of Chinatown, information on the Chinese Zodiac (this will be the Year of the Ox), descriptions of the four main cuisines and lists of food and clothing stores as well as restaurants. There is also a walking tour keyed to the map, which is easy to read since the area covered is rather small and the print is large. The Chinatown Map and Guide is printed in black, red and gold on glossy white paper and sells for $2.50 in bookstores or directly from Iris' Art Studio at 146 Sullivan Street, telephone 212-677-9383. 2.*Lucite and Silver Tie Black tie with a difference: This one is made of black Lucite and sterling silver and isn't really a tie at all. It is a hinged neckpiece that a man may wear in lieu of a tie or a woman may wear as jewelry. Tess Sholom of Tess Designs made it originally for her husband because he could never handle the tying of a bow tie and did not like the ready-made ones. Since she is a jewelry and belt designer, she decided to make a matching Lucite and silver cummerbund.

title: OFFICE SPACE OFFERED IN LANDMARK SCRIBNER BUILDING
description: The Scribner Book Companies, the Scribner Book Store and the landmark Scribner Building that held them were sold last year, but the new owners of the 72-year-old building on Fifth Avenue at 48th Street are hoping some of the old Scribner mystique remains long enough to help lease, or possibly sell on a condominium basis, 36,000 square feet of office space on the upper floors.

title: AMBITIOUS TOURNEY SUFFERS DEBUT PAINS
description: When a new car doesn't run properly, the owner can return it to the dealer for servicing. Unfortunately, tennis tournaments do not come with five- year warranties.

title: UNION CARBIDE PLANS TO REOPEN FACTORY IN U.S.
description: The Union Carbide Corporation said yesterday that by April 1 it hopes to reopen a West Virginia plant that produces methyl isocyanate, the pesticide ingredient that killed more than 2,000 people when it leaked into the air at a similar plant in Bhopal, India.

title: DAILY STAPLES OF HONDURAS: WAR AND PLOTS
description: Walking around the slanted streets of Tegucigalpa leaves a visitor wondering how such a tranquil collection of adobe homes perched on the sides of a steep mountain valley could be the scene of so much plotting, scheming, wheeling and dealing.

title: CANADIAN DEFENSE MINISTER RESIGNS IN A SCANDAL
description: Defense Minister Robert C. Coates resigned today after allegations that he and two top aides paid a late-night visit last November to a West German nightclub featuring pornographic movies and nude dancers.

title: Midway Cutbacks
description: Midway Airlines Inc. said it would reduce the number of flights flown by its Metrolink operation by 27.7 percent, effective Friday.

title: OPERA: A RARE PERFORMANCE OF 'EVANGELINE' BY LUENING
description: ''EVANGELINE,'' the only opera by the American composer Otto Luening, received its first New York performance in nearly 40 years Monday afternoon at Bruno Walter Auditorium. This 65-minute work in three acts, based on a poem by Henry Wadsworth Longfellow, has long been one of Mr. Luening's personal favorites, and he devotes a full chapter to its history in his recent autobiography.

description: The Grumman Corporation said that it had signed a memorandum of understanding with the National Aeronautics and Space Administration to develop a research program that would focus on processing semiconductor materials in space.

title: Old Turkeys, Sacred Cows and Pork
description: Representative Morris Udall of Arizona says the idea of merging the two big agencies that build Federal water projects - the Bureau of Reclamation and the Army Corps of Engineers - is just ''an old turkey that comes back every few years.'' He's partly right. It has been around at least since Calvin Coolidge. But if the idea is an old turkey, it has become one because the bureau is a sacred cow.

description: Israel is losing its military edge over its Arab neighbors, according to an analysis published today by the Jaffee Center for Strategic Studies.

title: CONCERT: CHARLES ROSEN
description: CHARLES ROSEN could probably have been a great pianist, but it seems fairly clear he didn't want to. He is a brilliant writer on music - almost without peer in rendering analysis lucid - and an often persuasive advocate of it at the keyboard.

description: There was a time not long ago when mere mention of the team's name evoked images of excellence and excitement. But the images these days are of red ink, recriminations and, possibly, default.

description: Unesco's 50-member executive board opened a politically charged debate today on the consequences of the United States withdrawal.

title: Article 023806 -- No Title
description: The Boston Five Cents Savings Bank yesterday announced a pilot program to sell Federal National Mortgage Association mortgage- backed securities in amounts as small as $1,000.

title: COLLEGES CRITICIZE PLANS TO CUT AID
description: President Reagan's proposed cuts in student aid would force millions of people to drop out of college and would return private universities to their pre- World War II days as elitist preserves, spokesmen for college administrators and students said today.

title: REAGAN'S BUDGETARY MAGINOT LINE
description: About half a century ago, France erected the Maginot Line along its eastern border. Consisting of heavy armor, the most modern fortifications, the latest and most impregnable antitank defenses, its purpose was to keep the German Army out. French soldiers in the meantime were left without a sense of purpose: they (and their welfare) were overshadowed by ''the line.'' Hardware rather than human life was elevated to the highest national priority - and it was hardly surprising, when Germans attacked and walked over the line, that the defending French Army simply melted away. In early summer 1940, Germany hoisted its flag on the Eiffel Tower.

title: POLISH LEADER SAYS JUSTICE WAS SERVED IN THE MURDER TRIAL
description: Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader, expressed confidence today that all those responsible for the slaying of a pro-Solidarity priest last fall had been brought to justice by his Government.

title: COUNSELING FOR MEN AT ABORTION CLINICS
description: Three years ago Darrel Cummings sat in an abortion clinic waiting to join his pregnant girlfriend for counseling before the abortion. When he asked the receptionist about the delay and wondered where his girlfriend was, he was told she had already had the abortion and no, he could not join her. ''I felt we had been through the whole decision-making process together and then suddenly we were separated,'' Mr. Cummings said. ''And there was no one at the clinic particularly concerned about that element.''

title: GAF CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The latest quarter and year nets include extraordinary credits of $4.8 million and $15.7 million, respectively, of which $2.3 million and $8.3 million, respectively, were related to the 1982 termination of the Salaried Employees Retirement Plan. The remaining amounts represent tax credits. The year-earlier quarter and year nets include extraordinary credits of $22.4 million and $25.4 million, respectively, including $21.8 million and $21.8 million, respectively, were from the 1982 termination of the Retirement Plan for Salaried Employees. The remaining amounts are tax credits.

title: 2 EX-COSMOS FEEL SORRY FOR COSMOS
description: Although Steve Moyers was one of the most popular American players on the Cosmos, the once- glamorous team sold him to the St. Louis Steamers Friday for a reported $25,000 to help alleviate part of their financial problems.

title: South African Police Sent to Black Township
description: Additional police officers were sent to a black township today after the death of a black youth who apparently was wounded by rubber bullets fired by the police during rioting the day before.

title: 150 Arrests and Still Going
description: Joseph (Pops) Panczko is hardly shy and the police say he apparently is not retiring either: they just arrested the 66-year- old convicted burglar for at least the 150th time. Mr. Panczko, whose eight- page police record goes back nearly five decades, was freed Monday after posting a $25,000 bond when he was arrested on a burglary charge. ''He is more or less a living legend,'' said Sgt. Phil Watzke, who works near where Mr. Panczko's latest arrest took place.

title: U.S. Approves Plan For Burials in Space
description: The Reagan Administration today approved a proposal by a private concern to send cremated human remains into space.

title: G.E. Contract
description: The General Electric Company's avionic and electronic systems division won a $58.8 million Air Force contract for a long-range radar system, the Defense Department said. The radar will be used in the Distant Early Warning system in the far northern regions of the Western Hemisphere.

title: Lendl Is Toppled by Edberg
description: The Florida Chamber of Commerce is not going to appreciate this at all, especially during a winter when some of the orange crop has become frozen concentrate before being picked. Now, on the heels of last month's frost, the world's best tennis players - the ones with sun-tanned faces and sun-bleached hair - are suffering from windburn at the Lipton International Players Championships.

title: CITY OPERA ANNOUNCES 21 WORKS FOR 1985-86

She also announced plans for a run of the Rodgers and Hammerstein ''Carousel'' in the spring of 1986.

description: In a move that was widely anticipated, the Phillips Petroleum Company announced yesterday that C.J. Silas, its president and chief operating officer, will become chairman and chief executive after the annual meeting on April 30.

title: TRUCKS OF WINTER LOADED FOR SPRING
description: The first sign of spring, a tractor-trailer truck, will appear at Shea Stadium this morning and start the annual ritual. Loading 300 dozen baseballs, 30 dozen bats, 75 helmets, several dozen trunks of baseball equipment, a pitching machine, half a dozen exercise machines, Jean Coen's bicycle and two cartons of fine French wine left by Rusty Staub with the admonition: ''Be Very Careful.''

description: William Crotty, a lawyer from Daytona Beach, Fla., today was named chairman of the executive committee of the Democratic Party's new National Finance Board of Directors by the party chairman, Paul G. Kirk Jr.

title: Behind the Scenes In Musical Theater
description: A look at the world of musical theater from the perspective of the producer will be offered by Bernard Jacobs and Alexander Cohen on March 5 at 8:15 P.M. at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue. The discussion is the first of six dealing with the subject of musical theater that will be held at the Y through April 9.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
description: Through the Progressive Era. By

title: CITY COUNCIL PRESIDENT FORMALLY ENTERS THE RACE FOR MAYOR AGAINST KOCH
description: City Council President Carol Bellamy formally announced her candidacy for mayor yesterday, declaring that the Koch administration was ''tired'' and that she could provide fresh leadership.

title: TALKS IN AMMAM: NEW CHAPTER IN ARAB DIPLOMACY
description: A quick series of Arab diplomatic moves aimed at bolstering the Jordanian-Egyptian peace initiative have been under way, including a meeting here Monday between King Hussein and Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader. The moves coincide with an appeal by King Fahd of Saudi Arabia for the United States resume peace efforts in the Middle East. The maneuverings also come as President Hosni Mubarek of Egypt is preparing to visit the United States early next month.

title: PLAY THE SYRIAN CARD
description: With King Fahd of Saudi Arabia urging President Reagan to renew his efforts for peace in the Middle East, and Israeli forces withdrawing from Lebanon, Mr. Reagan now has a duty to revive the United States peace initiative - but this time, I believe, turning his earlier proposals upside down.

title: MINNESOTA SAYS ABUSE CASE WAS IMPROPERLY CONDUCTED
description: Minnesota will not refile criminal charges against 21 adults once accused of sexually abusing children, the State Attorney General said today. He called the original investigation ''a tragedy,'' saying it had been improperly conducted.

title: NEW HOUSE MAKES OFFER FOR THE NEW YORKER
description: Samuel I. Newhouse Jr., whose company publishes Vogue, Mademoiselle, Vanity Fair and other magazines as well as more than 20 newspapers, has offered to buy The New Yorker magazine.

title: Problems in Japan If Car Quotas End
description: For four years, Japanese auto makers have denounced United States import restraints on their cars. But despite their restiveness under the quotas, manufacturers would face a number of delicate political and economic decisions should the restraints end as scheduled in March.

title: U.S. HAS CONTINGENCY PLAN TO PUT A-ARMS IN 4 COUNTRIES, AIDES SAY
description: The United States has contingency plans to deploy nuclear weapons in Canada, Iceland, Bermuda and Puerto Rico, according to Reagan Administration officials and a Government document outlining the plans.

title: GOLDWATER IS SAID TO PROPOSE 3-YEAR CUT IN MILITARY BUDGET
description: Senator Barry Goldwater, chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, has proposed trimming President Reagan's military budget by $33 billion over the next three years as part of an overall Republican plan to reduce Federal deficits, Congressional sources said today.

description: The police said today that they had recovered most of the $51.4 million worth of securities taken in an armed robbery from Merrill Lynch Canada last December.

title: A Middle Way in Nicaragua
description: President Reagan has given interviewers from The Times a clear, concise statement of his attitude toward the Sandinista rulers of Nicaragua. They betrayed the revolution that Americans cheered for its promise of democracy, he said. They have become pro-Soviet, chased democrats into exile and refused to subject their power to the consent of the Nicaraguan people. The exile army of ''contras,'' therefore, has every reason to fight for democracy. The United States has ample reason to help them.

The same day I talked to a black. He was trying to decide whether the 12 cents in his pocket would cover his bus fare.''

The creation of such an unusual repository, coordinator and expediter of information was prompted by an unusual set of circumstances: five simultaneous inquiries into Dr. Gross's performance. One, initiated by Mayor Koch, was farmed out to an independent special counsel - two lawyers armed with the power to subpoena witnesses and to hire pathologists.

Why couldn't something like this work at the other end, too, he wondered, from Kennedy Airport to hotels or private homes in the city? It is about to, but the planned cost will strike most passengers as more an affront than a service.

Some of the ballet's most charming moments come when the stage is filled with a corps that wheels across it like a flock of antic ballet. But there are striking moments for the seven principals. And the performers made the most of every moment on Tuesday at the New York State Theater.

title: CONCERT: PHILHARMONIC AND ARRAU AT THE PIANO
description: WHEN Claudio Arrau first performed as a soloist with the New York Philharmonic in 1943, Jiri Belohlavek had not yet been born. So, considering the gap in age and experience between the 82-year-old pianist and the 38-year-old Czechoslovak conductor, one would not have been surprised to find their appearance together Wednesday night in Beethoven's ''Emperor'' Concerto going less than smoothly. No serious problems developed, however. Mr. Belohlavek proved to be a sympathetic collaborator with a taut but not bellicose approach, which allowed Mr. Arrau to give a masterly account of the score.

title: FILM: 'RETURN OF SOLDIER,' A STORY ABOUT AMNESIA
description: AMNESIA, a symptom of what once was called ''hysterical fugue,'' or shellshock, was apparently a common trauma of the men who fought in the trenches on the Western Front during World War I. When 24-year-old Rebecca West wrote ''The Return of the Soldier,'' her short, remarkably mature first novel published in 1918, amnesia was not yet the exhausted device it was to become in the novels, plays and two-reel comedies that came out in the years between World Wars I and II.

''The ABC Thursday Night Movie'' will be seen on Channel 7 at 8 tonight.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS

title: 'As You Like It' to Open

The production will run through March 10 and then play in repertory during the company's nationwide tour. The other plays are Wilder's ''The Skin of Our Teeth;'' Philip Massinger's ''A New Way to Pay Old Debts,'' and ''Pieces of 8,'' a collection of short contemporary plays. A grant of $80,000 from the J. C. Penney Company will underwrite the production of ''As You Like It.''

title: THE ART OF CUT PAPER ON VIEW
description: ARTISTS generally use paper as a neutral background, a flat surface for images. But paper can also be an art form unto itself. An exhibition entitled ''Cut Paper'' at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum illustrates the delicacy and skill of this international craft. The exhibition includes more than 150 cut-paper works from 14 countries.

title: Bill on Sales Tax Gains in Hartford

title: TV DOCUDRAMA: QUESTIONS OF ETHICS
description: ''The Atlanta Child Murders,'' the five-hour docudrama that was seen this past Sunday and Tuesday evenings on CBS, could well become the most controversial program of the current television season. The subject, a series of murders of children in Atlanta from 1979 through 1981, is in itself not necessarily contentious. But the strong point of view and techniques of the program have prompted an assortment of Georgia officials and community leaders to criticize the program as being inaccurate and unfair.

Like the expensive one in which James Dean crashed on a California highway, this one ends up totaled, but not before it becomes a dream machine and a moving target. All this takes place not on the familiar Los Angeles freeways of standard- brand television movies but on the roadways of Australia. As seen through the helicopter cameras, the landscape is stunning.

description: Stocks soared to records after a two-day pause. The Dow Jones industrial average jumped 21.31 points, to 1,297.92, after climbing as high as 1,304.66. The close broke the past record, of 1,292.62, set Jan. 29. Broader-based market indicators also rose sharply to new highs. Analysts said the gain represented a strong sense of optimism rather than market reaction to any specific news. (Page D1.)

description: The New Jersey Supreme Court reversed an appeals court decision yesterday that would have reinstated Wesley K. Bell as Mayor of Stafford Township. Mr. Bell, the township's first popularly elected Mayor, was recalled Dec. 6, 1983, and replaced, through a special election, by Carl W. Block.

title: STATE AND SUFFOLK ASK COURT TO BLOCK TEST AT SHOREHAM
description: New York State and Suffolk County yesterday asked a Federal appeals court to block the Nuclear Regulatory Commission from issuing a low-power license for the Shoreham Nuclear Power Station.

REAGAN AND KING FAHD STAND BY THEIR PEACE PLANS
description: President Reagan and King Fahd of Saudi Arabia issued a communique today in which they agreed that a stable peace in the Middle East must provide security ''for all states in the area and for the exercise of the legitimate rights of the Palestinian people.''

title: Woman Enters Plea In Belushi Death Trial
description: Cathy Evelyn Smith, charged with murder and drug violations in the death of the comedian John Belushi, stood silent in court today as her attorney entered her plea of not guilty.

description: Washington has had plenty of snow, sleet and rain lately, but no one is blaming the weather for the problem that the Speaker of the House, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., has encountered in getting mail delivered to the White House.

description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating trading by clients of a New York public relations firm for possible violations of Federal securities laws, according to the president of a New York brokerage house.

title: CBS TRIAL TESTIMONY CENTERS ON 1967 INTELLIGENCE BRIEFINGS
description: Lawyers for Gen. William C. Westmoreland renewed their efforts in Federal District Court in Manhattan yesterday to show that the general had not concealed higher estimates of enemy strength in South Vietnam in 1967.

description: People with no place to live are being removed from Grand Central Terminal, not just in the night hours, but throughout the day, advocates for the homeless said yesterday.

description: Heinz Eric Roemheld, a composer who wrote the hit song ''Ruby'' and won an Oscar for the score of the film ''Yankee Doodle Dandy,'' has died at the age of 83.

title: 11 Dead in Indian Ship Fire
description: At least 11 people were dead and 41 missing after fire swept an Indian passenger liner on a voyage from Singapore to Madras, the Press Trust of India news agency reported today. The report quoted officials as saying the blaze broke out Tuesday on the 17,226- ton Chidambaram, which is due in the southern Indian port of Madras on Thursday. The cause of the fire was not known.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a mechanical error, the text of Carol Bellamy's statement in Metropolitan Report yesterday announcing her candidacy for Mayor omitted three paragraphs. The passage, which concluded her statement, appears today on page B3.

description: Today is a day for celebrating at Ogilvy & Mather Partners Inc., and not just because it is Valentine's Day. Nor is it just because the agency's $80 million in billings last year represented a 15 percent increase over 1983.

title: Grumman SeeksDelay in Bus Sale
description: The Grumman Corporation, seeking to inspect the fleet of its Flxible Model 870 buses bought by New York City, took steps today to delay the Transit Authority's effort to sell the vehicles. The company, which has been sued for $324 million by the city, obtained a show-cause order, signed by Justice Jawn Sandifer of State Supreme Court in Manhattan, directing the city to state in court on Friday why the sale of the buses should not be stopped.

description: A crew entered a smoldering coal mine today for the first time since rescuers were driven out Dec. 22 by a surging fire that took 27 lives, a company spokesman said.

description: Litton Industries and a group of private investors have signed a letter of intent for the purchase of Litton's Itek Graphic Systems division, Litton's chairman, Fred W. O'Green, announced.

description: Canada has no plans to station nuclear weapons on its soil and will not let the United States do so without its prior approval, External Affairs Minister Joe Clark said today.

description: Nat Caldwell, who won the Pulitzer Prize in 1962 for national reporting, was killed Monday when his automobile went off a bridge into a lake at his home, the police said. He was 72 years old.

description: The fund that helped pay the legal bills of unconvicted officials of Richard M. Nixon's 1972 re-election committee is going out of business 12 1/2 years after the Watergate scandals. It has spent nearly $4 million.

title: PRESERVING IRISH COUNTRY HOUSES
description: CASTLETOWN, the first great Palladian house built in Ireland, was begun in 1722 and ''reckoned the finest in this kingdom,'' as one noble visitor observed 50 years later. It boasted elaborate rococo plaster work and, among other fillips, a 140-foot-high obelisk supported by arches and decorated with stone pineapples and carved urns, built as an eye-catching folly two miles across the lawns and gardens in back of the house.

The Republican Party needs such moderates now if it is to serve the public and survive challenges from the Democrats in 1986 and 1988.

title: ART: SURVEY OF PAINTINGS BY MARYAN AT 2 GALLERIES
description: -Expressionism as we are these days, the bizarre, haunting figures of the Polish-born painter Maryan (1927-1977) are much more compelling than when they appeared here in the 1960's and 70's. Out of sync with Pop, Minimalism and Color Field, they seem now to have found their moment. We sense that in a new survey of these powerful paintings - a group of which were last seen at a New York memorial show in 1977 - at the Claude Bernard Gallery, 33 East 74th Street, and the Allan Frumkin Gallery, 50 West 57th Street (both shows through March 2).

title: In the Public Spirit
description: Eight New Yorkers who have contributed to the city's ''economic, social and cultural vitality'' received singular valentines last night.

description: The Social Security Administration is sending notices to 135,000 former disability beneficiaries advising them they may be able to win their payments back under new rules.

description: Three police officers suffered burns yesterday when a Brooklyn woman who reportedly had a history of mental problems threw boiling oil at them as they were trying to coax her out of her apartment, the police said.

title: CORRECTION

It was dismissed Oct. 18 after Pacific Federal, now the Pacific Savings Bank, received a cash settlement from Glacier General.

title: Aquarium Seeks 2 Whales
description: The National Aquarium in Baltimore has asked the Federal Government for permission to capture two Arctic whales this summer for its indoor display pool, officials said Wednesday.

title: Kelso's Offer
description: The Scott & Fetzer Company said that its board had approved the company's definitive merger agreement with an affiliate of Kelso & Company but that the transaction was subject to various conditions, including govermental and shareholder approval. Kelso had made a sweetened leveraged buyout offer of $62 a share, $1 more than the previous proposal, for a total of about $440 million. Scott & Fetzer makes vacuum cleaners and household and industrial products.

title: Brunswick-ICO
description: The Brunswick Corporation said that it expected to conclude a definitive agreement soon to purchase ICO Inc., a Texas oilfield services company, for about $40.4 million. Brunswick, a diversified manufacturer of recreation and industrial products, based in Skokie, Ill., said that under terms being discussed, it would acquire the approximately 5.4 million outstanding shares of ICO stock, valued at $7.50 a share, for a combination of cash and Brunswick common stock.

title: Ready to Take A Few Profits
description: STEPHEN B. TIMBERS, a New York money manager, plans to apply a Shakespearean quotation, ''The better part of valor is discretion,'' to the stock market. His strategy is to prepare to take some profits. As chief investment officer of the Portfolio Group Inc., an independent subsidiary of the Chemical New York Corporation, Mr. Timbers manages $1.5 billion for clients, mostly individuals.

title: NEW YORK BLACKS ERR
description: Sooner or later, every emerging political movement faces a choice. It can subordinate some of its interests to the goals of a larger and potentially more successful, more electable alliance, or it can assert the primacy of its interests, holding out for its principles, even when that means forfeiting a turn in office. Last week, the Coalition for a Just New York, a group of 40 black politicians led by Assemblyman Albert Vann, chose self-assertion at the price of self-destruction, splitting Mayor Koch's opposition for the Democratic nomination and greatly improving his chances of re- election.

description: Over the last few years, Achim Freyer has established himself as the most visionary director and designer in German opera. His new staged production of Handel's ''Messiah'' at the Deutsche Oper in West Berlin - billed as possibly the first theatrical staging in the work's history - does nothing to endanger his reputation.

Most of these date from the great southward push of the 1970's that yielded SoHo and TriBeCa. But many are infants - midtown galleries that have relocated in recent months (or in some cases, years) or brand-new enterprises - and they are gathering on the Broadway edge of SoHo and points east.

title: ESKIMO ARTISTRY AT DANCE THEATER WORKSHOP
description: Dance Theater Workshop has remained a leading outpost of experimentation as the avant-garde has moved farther downtown over the years. This weekend the workshop points up its status with the kind of programs that have extended the familiar limits of dance and theater. Dance has drawn increasingly on theater of distant or primitive cultures in recent years. At its best, that theater suggests ways of moving to new kinds of sounds and hints, once more, at an intense minimalism especially powerful to the artistic sensibilities of the time.

Icahn, the New York financier attempting to take over the Phillips Petroleum Company, told 150 Wall Street professionals that he hoped to announce by today that he had raised ''between $1 billion and $2 billion'' of the $4.1 billion he would need to buy control.

title: Eastern-CF Pact
description: Eastern Airlines said that it would expand its passenger and freight service in an agreement with CF Air Freight Inc., a unit of Consolidated Freightways, and that the new service would enable the carrier to offer ''significantly reduced passenger fares.'' Russell L. Ray, a senior vice president of Eastern, said that the service would increase night flights between Houston and nine other cities. One airline analyst said that the freight carried could pay for the fuel and labor of the flights, enabling Eastern to offer very low fares to such destinations as San Francisco and Los Angeles.

title: People
description: William R. Kelly, a senior vice president and management supervisor with BBDO New York, named general manager of the agency's Detroit office, effective March 1.

title: When Banks Launder Dirty Money Why should bank officers and employees be exempt from the duty to report possible evidence of crime? They claim that privilege, in effect, when they resist Federal pressure to report suspiciously large cash deposits. Washington is right to keep up the pressure.
description: Congressional investigators and the President's Commission on Organized Crime are convinced that too many financial institutions look the other way when customers haul in bags or suitcases of small bills. Too often, the deposit is ''street money'' from illegal drug sales that needs to be laundered - made to appear legitimate by disguising its origin.

title: A RESORTS' LAWYER EXPLAINS 'AWFUL MISTAKE' ON PAYMENT
description: A lawyer in the Bahamas for Resorts International said today that he made ''a boo-boo'' and ''an awful mistake'' last year when he said money channeled to the Prime Minister of the Bahamas had been paid to an intermediary ''on behalf of Resorts.''

description: The Public Relations Center, in

title: PAN AM LOSS WIDER IN 4TH QUARTER AND YEAR
description: The Pan Am Corporation yesterday reported substantially wider losses in the fourth quarter and all of 1984, but said that it expects improved results this year.

description: There are two sides to the story of Livingstone Bramble and the reluctant chicken, just as there seem to be two dominant sides to the prefight character of the World Boxing Association lightweight champion. The chicken story can wait.

5 Held as Plotters In an Adoption Ring
description: Five people have been charged with falsely promising children from Mexico to prospective adoptive parents in 40 states, the authorities said today.

description: Edith Mathis, the Swiss soprano, will make her Carnegie Hall recital debut on Sunday at 3 P.M. in an all- lieder program that will include music by Schubert, Brahms, Wolf and Clara Schumann. Samuel Sanders will accompany on the piano. Tickets are $8 to $15 at the box office, or at CarnegieCharge, 247-7800.

description: NBC News officials said yesterday that Israeli soldiers assaulted and fired shots near an NBC News crew Wednesday before army officers confiscated its news videotape at a bridge in southern Lebanon.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;    ;   Hospital Offering $428 Million Issue In the largest hospital bond financing ever arranged, Presbyterian Hospital in New York City is selling $428 million of bonds through the New York State Medical Care Facilities Financing Authority. The hospital is part of the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center.

title: ART EXPERT DIRECTED POSTWAR RELIEF DRIVE
description: A. Cook Glassgold, an art expert who led relief efforts after World War II and then became administrative director of the New York Hotel Trades Council, died after a heart attack at Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston last Friday. He was 86 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: TELERATE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SAN DIEGO MAYOR'S RIVALS MOVE FOR POLITICAL GAIN AFTER MISTRIAL
description: Political rivals who hope to succeed Mayor Roger Hedgecock scrambled for position today after the Mayor's trial on felony perjury and conspiracy charges ended Wednesday in a hung jury.

title: CAMPBELL SOUP COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 27
DOWNTOWN SCENE: WHAT'S NEW AND FRESH
description: DOWNTOWN is never static. Artists, writers, musicians, performers of every kind keep flocking to the place where culture is constantly being made and remade. In a few years, the young and often ragtag innovators who dominate this scene today may have exchanged their lofts and walkups for the places of power and influence, but by then they will have been replaced by the next band of visionaries.

title: 'POSSIBLE VIOLATIONS' FOUND IN INQUIRY ON POSTAL OFFICIALS
description: Two Government agencies have found ''possible violations'' of conflict-of- interest laws by former Postmaster General William F. Bolger and John R. McKean, the chairman of the Postal Service Board of Governors, according to letters made public today.

title: BANK WAS ASSURED ON MORTGAGES
description: A major Chicago law firm, Lord, Bissell & Brook, told the Wells Fargo Bank two years ago that charges of problems in some of the mortgage- backed securities that the bank was handling ''were incorrect,'' a spokesman for the bank said today.

title: Installment Debt Is Up
description: In December, Americans took on $6.95 billion more in installment debt than they paid off, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. Analysts said this sizable gain showed that consumers were still willing to make big- ticket purchases.

description: Many of the engineers the Transit Authority has hired over the last four years did not go to accredited colleges and have difficulty speaking or writing English, according to a report released yesterday by the State Comptroller's office.

title: FILM: RITES OF YOUTH IN 'VISION QUEST'
description: MOVIES are not like people who, if they're basically nice and decent, can be liked even if they're not very stimulating company. Movies of that order wear one down. They demand attention without giving much in return - amiability is not enough.

title: THOMAS J. FAHEY
description: Thomas J. Fahey, a former advertising sales representative for The New York Times, died of cancer Wednesday at his home in Bronxville, N.Y. He was 78 years old.

title: CHRYSLER ADDS TO RECORD YEAR
description: Three years ago the American automobile industry was on the ropes, with the Big Three companies reporting a combined loss of $1.34 billion for 1981.

title: U.S. TV REPORTER FREE IN LEBANON
description: An American journalist, one of five Americans kidnapped in Lebanon in the past year, gained his freedom today, but it was unclear whether he had been freed or had escaped.

title: DYNALECTRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Sisk Loses in Arbitration
description: The arbitrator who awarded Wade Boggs a $1 million salary for 1985 on Wednesday decided yesterday that Doug Sisk should not earn four times the income he got from the Mets last year.

Whiteman on Gershwin
description: A rare orchestration of Gershwin's Piano Concerto in F by the Paul Whiteman Band will be performed by the Orchestra of St. Luke tomorrow night at 8 at Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street.

description: b-After a gain of $3,025,000, or 17 cents a share, representing the cumulative effect of changing to a different depreciation method. The company said results for 1984 include those of the Liquid Carbonic Corp., which was acquired Aug. 1, for the 5 months since the date of acquisition. The 1983 revenue was restated to conform to reporting methods adopted in 1984.

title: Money Fund Assets Fall Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds fell $1.84 billion, to $213.01 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday. This is the fourth consecutive week of decline in the assets.
description: The 183 general purpose funds registered a decline of $122.2 million, to $63.88 billion.

title: Yes to Shoreham; but Also No
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission has given permission for low-power tests at Shoreham, taking the big nuclear plant another step down the tortuous road to full operation. That's good news. The $4 billion plant should never have been built, but Long Island would now be much better off using it than abandoning it.

title: HOOVER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After tax credits of $912,000 for the quarter and $5,397,000 for the year. c-After tax credits of $298,000 for the quarter and $2,534,000 for the year.

description: ''THE BAY BOY'' is a memory film, autobiographical in tone, that is covered by a scrim of nostalgia.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The two top priorities for us are education and law enforcement.

title: SOUTH AFRICA STOCK SALE BY HARVARD
description: Harvard University said yesterday that it had sold its holding in the Baker International Corporation because the company refused to give the university information showing it adhered ''to reasonable ethical standards'' in South Africa.

title: KOCH RECOMMENDS STIFFER PENALTIES AND MORE PRISONS
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that New York State should adopt tougher criminal penalties even if it meant diverting hundreds of millions of dollars of state and local money to build many more prisons.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: -tie crowd that trooped

title: LISTLESS DEVILS LOSE TO LOWLY WHALERS
description: The Devils were so listless tonight against the Hartford Whalers, a team that had but one victory in its last 15 games, that many in the crowd of 10,123 headed for the exits at Byrne Meadowlands Arena with more than 8 minutes to play.

title: MICHIGAN WINS, STAYS ATOP BIG TEN
description: Roy Tarpley scored 21 points, including 17 in the first half, and Antoine Joubert scored the basket that put Michigan ahead for good late in the game as the Wolverines defeated Iowa, 56-52, tonight to maintain their lead in the Big Ten Conference.

title: EASING THE WAY FOR FLUTIE'S DEBUT
description: Coach Walt Michaels has tried to make Doug Flutie's first game as a General a bit easier, but without success so far. The Generals play their third and last exhibition here against the Orlando Renegades Friday night, and they would like to ease the blitzing by both defenses.

title: A.T.&T. Told to Cut Distance Rates
description: The Federal Communications Commission yesterday directed the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to lower its long-distance rates June 1, when residences begin bearing costs of the telephone system that had been borne by A.T.&T.

title: Profits Scoreboard
description: See accompanying notes for special items. (Loss) * Loss in year-earlier period.

title: SEVERAL LANDS PLEDGE CASH TO UNESCO
description: The Soviet Union and several developing nations said tonight that they would make voluntary contributions to Unesco this year to ease the financial crisis facing the agency as a result of the United States withdrawal.

title: Changes on the Line
description: On the Generals' starting offensive line Friday night, there will be three players who did not start for the team in 1984 - Kari Yli-Renko and Don Maggs at the tackles and Vince Stroth at left guard.

title: REAGAN DROPS PLANS TO TAKE PART IN V-E CEREMONY IN GERMANY
description: President Reagan, moving to avoid a potentially delicate situation, canceled plans today to take part in ceremonies in West Germany on May 8 marking the Allied triumph over the Nazis 40 years ago.

title: FILM: TIMOTHY HUTTON IN 'TURK 182!'
description: TIMOTHY HUTTON has turned into an actor worth watching in anything - even in ''Turk 182!,'' a movie with a sloppily sentimental heart that's as big as the city in which its story takes place. That city is referred to as New York, but it hardly seems familiar. The subway is clean. The graffiti, what there is of it, is printed neatly. The mayor is Robert Culp. The Big Apple trotted out for civic events is Delicious. Everything looks wrong.
