title: A City Mandate for Meltdowns
description: One has to admire the beauty of a snowstorm even in New York City. The soft blanket muffles the din of traffic, fills the potholes and hides, even sculptures the mounds of garbage.

title: Sonic Youth Band
description: Sonic Youth, a New York avant- rock band, will perform tonight at 1:30 A.M. at the Peppermint Lounge, 100 Fifth Avenue at 15th Street (989- 9505). Tickets are $7 before 11 P.M., $11 afterward.

title: Szeryng to Play Bach
description: Henryk Szeryng, the violinist, will play an all-Bach program at the Metropolitan Museum tomorrow night at 8. The program includes the Partitas Nos. 2 and 3 and two sonatas for violin and harpsichord, in E and in G. Tickets are $15. Information: 570- 3949.

title: SUIT IS LOST BY CHILDREN MAYOR WALKER ADOPTED
description: With a glamorous bit of long-ago New York City shining through the dull legal prose, Mayor James J. Walker's adopted children today lost their court fight to find out who their real parents are.

title: 'Life and Limb' Closing
description: Life and Limb,'' a dark comedy by Keith Reddin about the return of a Korean War veteran to American life in the 1950's, will close after the evening performance on Sunday at the Playwrights Horizons. The play, directed by Thomas Babe, will have run for 30 performances and 17 previews.

title: Car Output in Britain
description: British auto production in January slipped to a seasonally adjusted 91,000 units from 92,000 a year earlier.

title: MATTEL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $5,600,000 for the quarter and $24,300,000 for the year, and a gain of $2,157,000 for the quarter and year from the exchange of securities. c-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $170,311,000 for the quarter and $420,671,000 for the year, and a gain of $9,400,000 for the quarter and year from the termination of a pension plan. Mattel Inc. said that fourth quarter results are not comparable because it changed its financial reporting cycle to a calendar year from one ended Jan. 28. Full year results reflect the shift to a calendar year. The unprofitable month of January 1984 was included in the results for both years.

title: CBS SUES TO BLOCK TAKEOVER
description: CBS filed suit yesterday in United States District Court in Manhattan to block the efforts of a group supported by Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, to seek control of CBS and ''end the liberal bias'' of the network's news reporting.

title: PUBLISHING: A SPECIALIST IN PACKAGING BOOKS
description: JOHN BOSWELL is listed in directories as a literary agent, but his specialty is book packaging. That is, he dreams up the idea for a book, writes the proposal and then finds the appropriate person to either write the book or lend his or her name to it.

title: GREATWEST HOSPITALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $156,000. c-After a gain from discontinued operations of $152,000, or 3 cents a share.

title: FILM: 'MAKIOKA SISTERS,' BY ICHIKAWA
description: OF the major Japanese film directors to come to prominence during the years immediately after World War II, Kon Ichikawa (''The Burmese Harp,'' ''Odd Obsession'') has been the one most frequently drawn to the adaptations of well-known literary works, while his contemporaries have preferred to work either from original screenplays or from adaptations that were extremely free.

title: BANK CREDITORS PUT OFF NEW BRAZIL DEBT PLAN
description: Brazil's bank creditors have postponed completion of a restructuring of about $45.3 billion in debt until Brazil returns to compliance with an austerity program monitored by the International Monetary Fund, banking sources said yesterday.

title: Out of Fashion
description: Two years ago, when he paid $4 million to acquire

title: CONCERT: ALL-JAPANESE PROGRAM OF NEW WORKS
description: JAPAN has a thriving musical culture whose arms are large enough and strong enough to embrace both its own traditions and an eclectic internationalism that has produced a crop of highly skilled composers in recent decades. In this country, however, we hear examples of their work so infrequently that it is difficult to form a solid opinion of any but a couple of widely recognized artists. Last night's program at Carnegie Hall took a step or two in the direction of remedying that situation, offering an entire evening of contemporary Japanese works.

title: DOLLARS VS. HISTORY ON A FIFTH AVE. BLOCK
description: They are two small, dignified buildings on the west side of Fifth Avenue, Nos. 712 and 714. Pedestrians pay them little heed, as their stores are shuttered and their offices empty.

title: Inquiry Finds Pasteurization Of Milk May Not Be Foolproof
description: An outbreak of a rare, fatal infection two years ago was apparently caused by bacteria in pasteurized milk, and researchers say their discovery shows the routine purification of milk may not always be foolproof.

title: Northern Telecom

The main products are the Meridian SL-1 and SL-100 integrated services networks, which can serve from 30 to 30,000 users. The systems offer a local area network as well as a new integrated voice-and-data terminal and three new digital telephones.

title: Dr
description: Dr. John E. Franklin Sr., a retired physician who specialized in pediatric oncology, died of a heart attack last Sunday while visiting in Naples, Fla. He was 77 years old and had homes in Manhattan and in Chateaugay, N.Y.

title: ELMHURST BUILDERS CATER TO ASIAN-BORN
description: When Dino Guiducci started building in Queens 30 years ago, he was concentrating on two-family row houses. They sold for about $70,000 in 1955. Usually, they had space on the ground floor that the owner could convert into a second rental apartment. Many buyers would take in two tenants to make the house affordable, although this violated the zoning law.

title: Missouri River Bridge Shut
description: The Highway 15 Bridge over the Missouri River, used by 20,000 vehicles a day, has been closed for a structural flaw. The shutdown is expected to last several weeks.

title: ;   Grumman Picks Officer From Aerospace Unit
description: George M. Skurla, the 63-year-old chairman of the aerospace subsidiary of the Grumman Corporation, was named president and chief operating officer of the parent company. Mr. Skurla replaces Joseph G. Gavin, who becomes chairman of Grumman's executive committee. Mr. Gavin, who is 64, is one year away from the company's mandatory retirement age.

title: GRIDIRON TO LET 'EM EAT LAMB
description: There was a palace revolt at a Gridiron Club tasting dinner Wednesday night. Accusations of bribery and sabotage filled the air as 18 members of the club's executive and menu committees traded insults and jokes over whether to serve beef or lamb at the club's 100th annual dinner in March.

title: Amex Picks No. 3 Man; He'll Focus on Strategy In a restructuring of its top management, the American Stock Exchange promoted Kenneth R. Leibler to the new position of senior executive vice president of marketing, administration and finance.
description: Mr. Leibler, 35, had been executive vice president for administration and finance since 1981. The new job makes him the No. 3 man at the exchange, after the chairman, Arthur Levitt Jr., 54, and the president, Robert J. Birnbaum, 57.

title: 2 MOVIES FOCUS ON NAZI GERMANY
description: PERHAPS because this year marks the 40th anniversary of the end of World War II - an event being officially noted with painstaking diplomacy so as not to embarrass once defeated enemies who are now powerful allies - television is noticeably preoccupied with Nazi Germany these days. Two more television movie examples are available: ''Kojak: The Belarus File'' on Channel 2 tomorrow night at 9, and ''Hitler's SS: Portrait in Evil'' on Channel 4 Sunday at 8 P.M.

title: Stanford Trustees Approve Site for Presidential Library
description: Stanford University trustees gave final approval Tuesday to the 20-acre site proposed for the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library and sent the recommendation to the White House.

title: FILM: FAST FORWARD ,' BY POITIER
description: SIDNEY POITIER'S ''Fast Forward,'' which opens today at the National and other theaters, isn't essentially different from other current movies that seem to have been designed as feature-length music videos. Its principal assets are the members of its bright young cast and Rick Atwell's vigorous choreography, which is not quite as monotonous as the disco- aerobic-acrobatic movements initially made popular in ''Flashdance.''

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: -word,'' as one studio marketing executive describes it: ''Space.'' In the wake of ''Dune'' and ''2010'' and their disappointing showings, not to mention the long shadow cast by ''E.T.,'' science fiction films will be stressing the human aspects of their stories rather than the ray guns. At least that will be true for the next two science- fiction efforts, Paramount's ''Explorers'' and Fox's ''Cocoon,'' both scheduled for summer release and both to have special effects by Lucasfilm's Industrial Light and Magic, although the sci-fi wizardry will not be overemphasized.

title: DOLE SEES BUDGET 'GIMMICK'
description: Bob Dole, the Senate majority leader, said today that the White House budget proposal to eliminate Federal revenue sharing next fiscal year was just a ''gimmick'' to make overall budget cuts total $50 billion.

description: Sports executives from two networks said yesterday that after discussions with Eddie Einhorn on behalf of the United States Football League, they had found that televising U.S.F.L. games starting in 1986 would not be in the best interest of their networks.

title: OLAJUWON DUNKS KNICKS
description: According to a tale that is destined to become a part of basketball folklore, a coach in Nigeria stood atop a chair six years ago to teach Akeem Olajuwon how to dunk. Someone else later taught him that you have to learn how to get the ball before you can dunk. That someone was Moses Malone, the most game's most prolific offensive rebounder.

title: PICKENS-LED GROUP BUYING INTO UNOCAL
description: A partnership led by the Mesa Petroleum Company was disclosed yesterday as the mystery buyer behind the big run-up in the price of the stock of the Unocal Corporation, the nation's 12th-largest oil company. The group said that it had spent about $584 million to buy Unocal stock and that it had agreed to spend up to an additional $616 million for more shares.

description: Festivities marking Washington's birthday are planned this weekend at two sites that served as his headquarters during the Revolutionary War. A free open house and tour will be held on Sunday at 2 P.M. at the Washington Headquarters Museum, Virginia Road, North White Plains.

title: No Complaints
description: The effort to return a pro football team to New York City is being coordinated by the office of Deputy Mayor Robert Esnard. But the man who makes the initial contact is the Consumer Affairs Commissioner, Angelo J. Aponte.

title: HEADED PACKINGHOUSE UNION
description: Ralph Helstein, former president of the United Packinghouse Workers of America who was a longtime trade union leader, died today after suffering a heart attack at his home here. He was 76 years old.

title: CONSOLIDATED NATURAL GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a one-time gain of 82 cents a share from a court decision related to natural gas pricing

title: Gunman Shoots Himself After Campus Siege
description: A man shot two Temple Junior College instructors today and held one hostage for two and a half hours before he fatally wounded himself with a shot in the chest.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information Systems n.a. Not available due to holiday Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Bellamy Leaving M.T.A. Board
description: City Council President Carol Bellamy said yesterday that she would resign today from the board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: 7 JERSEY COMPANIES LISTED IN REPORT ON TOXIC RELEASES
description: A report prepared for a Senate committee says that seven chemical-handling companies in northern New Jersey have released hazardous substances over the last seven years, sometimes accidentally and sometimes as part of their normal operations.

title: AMERICAN BANKERS INSURNCE GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After capital gains of $531,000 for the quarter and $1,731,000 for the year. c-After capital gains of $368,000 for the quarter and $644,000 for the year.

title: HAWAIIAN ELECTRIC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
THEATER: 'THE CRIMES OF VAUTRIN'
description: THE American premiere of Nicholas Wright's play, ''The Crimes of Vautrin,'' based on characters who appear in Honore de Balzac's ''Human Comedy,'' opens the 10th season of the SoHo Rep in its new location hard by the East River on 29th Street. After nine years on Mercer Street, the repertory company has found a home in the auditorium of Bellevue Hospital. The spacious hundred-seat theater is, of course, independent of and has a separate entrance from the hospital.

title: JACKSON OVERTURE TO THE DEMOCRATS
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson says he wants to mend his strained relations with Democratic Party leaders and indicates that many of their differences can be resolved without confrontation.

title: PANEX INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $257,000 from discontinued operations.

title: CLASSIC CLOTHES IN THE 'VILAGE'
description: She was determined, Stella Flame says, that the shop bearing her name avoid ''everything I disliked about all the boutiques I'd ever seen.'' Her shop, which recently opened on a residential street in Greenwich Village, is furnished with Victorian gilt mirrors, an Empire table, plaster Renaissance swans and elaborate shadow boxes.

title: TUCKER DRILLING CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Howard Johnson
description: Imperial Group said that its board was evaluating options for the future of its Howard Johnson Company unit, including possible disposal, and that it intended to make a decision as soon as possible. The company said, however, that some promising developments in Howard Johnson, which is its American hotel and restaurant subsidiary, were being pursued vigorously. In the fiscal year ended Oct. 31, operating profit at Howard Johnson fell 41 percent in sterling terms, the company said, attributing most of the drop to unsatisfactory restaurant business.

title: JUDGE APPROVES PACT IN TEAMSTER FUND SUIT
description: A Federal judge today signed a consent decree settling a seven- year suit by the Federal Government charging irregularities in the operations of an International Brotherhood of Teamsters' health and welfare fund.

title: ATLAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes credits of $638,000 for the quarter and $1,024,000 for the 6 months from reduction in income taxes.

title: Romantic Bus Tour
description: A bus tour devoted to the romantic side of New Yorkers will set off from the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue, on Sunday at 10 A.M. Led by Marvin Gelfand, the tour will stop at sites of famous rendezvous, in areas such as Greenwich Village, the theater district, Sutton Place and Riverside Drive.

title: FILM: BEYOND THE WALLS,' FROM ISRAEL
description: THE Israeli film ''Beyond the Walls,'' a nominee for the best foreign film Academy Award, studies the interaction between Arab and Jewish factions in a maximum security prison. The groups fight each other bitterly, but by the film's end, they also become capable of uniting to defy their captors.

title: Still a Life-and-Death Matter? As Governor Cuomo of New York has recognized, dying nowadays exerts an extraordinary emotional toll on families and physicians as they confront choices inconceivable only a few years ago. Old laws no longer give useful guidance on such questions as when doctors may withhold lifesaving measures from certain terminally ill patients. As a lawyer for a New York City hospital says: ''Our physicians are at sea. There is inconsistency. There is confusion.''
description: The Governor may know that, but he seems to have lost interest. In December he named a distinguished commission to make recommendations on a range of issues associated with the new medical technology. But the group has no executive director and has yet to hold its first meeting. Meanwhile, the tension in many hospitals and homes continues.

title: REXON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
F.W. Woolworth
description: The F.W. Woolworth Company said that it would open two specialty retailing businesses beginning this summer. Joseph F. Carroll, a Woolworth spokesman, said the company would introduce Afterthoughts, a jewelry and women's accessory chain, ''in a major metropolitan area in Ohio,'' declining to elaborate. He also would not say where the company would first locate its Herald Square Stationers, stores in which greeting cards and novelty gifts will be sold.

title: SCRUNITY DISTURBS VALVANO
description: Life in the limelight has lost a bit of its luster recently for Jim Valvano, North Carolina State University's basketball coach.

title: WHEN TASTE OF CHAMPAGNE TURNS SOUR
description: One of the entrants in the seventh race at Gulfstream Park last Friday looked as though he had been entered in the wrong race. It was Our Casey's Boy, a son of Blushing Groom who had shown great promise a year and a half ago as a 2-year-old. He had won his debut in fast time and finished third behind Devil's Bag and Dr. Carter in the Champagne Stakes at Belmont.

title: Saxophone and Piano
description: The saxophonist George Adams and the pianist Don Pullen are leading a quartet - with Cameron Brown on bass and Dannie Richmond on drums - tonight through Sunday at the Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South below 11th Street (255- 4037). Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is an $8.50 cover and a one-drink minimum.

title: Phone Budget Option ;   Is a Wrong Number
description: To the Editor:

title: RANDY WESTON AT HOME FOR 3 BROOKLYN CONCERTS
description: RANDY WESTON, the pianist and composer, was born and grew up in Brooklyn, and throughout a career that has taken him around the world and been highlighted by extended sojourns in Africa, he has kept circling back to Brooklyn.

title: DRUG CROPS ARE UP IN EXPORT NATIONS, STATE DEPT. SAYS
description: The State Department's annual report on worldwide narcotics production shows that in most of the major drug-producing countries, marijuana, coca and opium- poppy crops were larger in 1984 than in 1983.

title: A Look at Tropical Life In 'Lost World of Medusa'
description: Jellyfish in a lake in the Pacific archipelago of Palau have developed a survival stratagem unlike that of other jellyfish around the world. They do not sting and capture prey.

title: Dining Out Guide: Chili
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given.

title: MCHALE SPARKS CELTICS
description: Kevin McHale scored 15 points in the second half and Larry Bird 14 as the Boston Celtics pulled away to defeat the Seattle SuperSonics 110-94 tonight.

title: BUSINESS MEN'S ASSURANCE CO OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an investment loss of $766,000. c-After an investment gain of $2,416,000. d-After an investment gain of $593,000. e-After an investment gain of $4,301,000 and a tax credit of $1,334,000.

title: GENENTECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
AMPCO-PITTSBURGH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $5,105,000 for the quarter and $5,900,000 for year. c-After income from discontinued operations of $88,000. d-Net loss after a loss from discontinued operations of $145,000. The latest fourth quarter and year nets include a gain of $4,475,000 and a tax benefit of $3,700,000 as a result of the sale of most of the company's railcar leasing business. The year-ago fourth quarter and year results included a gain of $3,532,000 on the sale of notes receivable and a provision for plant closings of $1,900,000.

title: THE CITY ;   Chin Is Convicted Of Gun Charges
description: The man whose arrest last February led to the resignation of Schools Chancellor Anthony J. Alvarado was convicted of weapons charges yesterday.

title: Ibrahim and Septet
description: The pianist Abdullah Ibrahim and his septet Ekaya, including the alto saxophonist Carlos Ward and the drummer Ben Riley, will perform tonight through Sunday at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South above Bleecker Street (242-1785). Sets begin at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M.; there is a $10 cover and a $6 minimum. Reservations: 242-1785.

title: Conrail, Unions Reach Wage Pact WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) - Conrail and 10 unions representing 23,000 of its 35,000 union employees have reached agreement on a retroactive wage package that returns the workers' salaries to industry levels, the railroad said.
description: Agreements are expected soon with the remaining unions.

title: Bush Unpacks His Bag
description: Vice President Bush has finally lined up a forum for a major speech outlining the Reagan Administration's views on the African famine, but it took some juggling of his travel plans to do it.

title: MOLSON COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: INTERPUBLIC GROUP OF COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ART: ANNUAL EXHIBITION AT ACADEMY OF DESIGN
description: THERE is a certain urgency to the National Academy of Design's 160th Annual Exhibition. One reason is the quality of many of the works. But it is more than that. The National Academy is one of the few places that can respond to a continuing need for art that clearly believes in composition and craft and feels comfortable in the world around us. With all its limitations, this show confirms the continuing vitality of the kind of work that is the salt of the art-world earth.

title: Swensen in Concert
description: Joseph Swensen, the American violinist who won the first Avery Fisher Career Grant Award in 1982, will play a recital at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue, tomorrow evening at 8.

title: Sales Rise Outpaces Inventories' WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) - Sales of manufactured goods climbed six-tenths of 1 percent in December, double the rate of increase of inventories during the month, the Government reported today.
description: It was the third consecutive monthly gain and followed a 1 percent rise in November. From July through September, sales had fallen as economic growth over all slowed considerably.

title: OFFICER INDICTED IN BROOKLYN IN KILLING OF AN UNARMED MAN
description: A New York City police officer was indicted on a manslaughter charge yesterday for shooting an unarmed man to death on a Brooklyn street last month. The officer said after the shooting that his gun had discharged accidentally.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: IT is not pleasant to see a once-vital restaurant

title: DIGITAL SWITCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a nonrecurring charge of $3.8 million related to the acquisition of Granger Associates during June 1984. c-After a tax credit of $1,019,000.

title: CONCERT: THE GUARNERI QUARTET
description: THE Guarneri String Quartet, which may have been America's premier young chamber group of the 1960's, celebrates its 20th season this year, and has matured into a comfortable middle age. The violinists Arnold Steinhardt and John Dalley, the violist Michael Tree and the cellist David Soyer, who founded the Guarneri Quartet at the Marlboro Music Festival in 1965, still function as a smooth unit; their playing matches tonally and spiritually.

title: SALARY-CAP DISPUTE IN WILLIAMS DEAL
description: The Boston Celtics and the National Basketball Association are in a salary-cap dispute over an offer sheet the Celtics have been negotiating with Ray Williams, the Knicks' free-agent guard who has been sitting out this season.

title: Finalists Are Named For Hemingway Honor
description: Three internationally acclaimed authors - the Russian poet Yevgeny Yevtushenko, the Peruvian novelist Mario Vargas Llosa and the Czechoslovak novelist Milan Kundera, now a French citizen - have been named the three finalists for the first Ritz Paris Hemingway Award.

title: Lloyd Advances
description: After a slow start, second- seeded Chris Evert Lloyd beat West Germany's Steffi Graf, 6-4, 6-2, tonight and joined Martina Navratilova in the women's final of the Lipton International Players Championships tennis tournament.

title: GUN BATTLES IN KANSAS END WITH 4 DEAD AND 4 INJURED
description: Four people died and four others were wounded Wednesday in a running gun battle across 60 miles of northwest Kansas. The shooting spree, which apparently began with a robbery in a restaurant, ended in a farmyard shootout, the authorities said today.

title: CHRYSLER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary gains of $101.5 million for the latest quarter and $125 million for the year-earlier period. c-After tax credits of $883,900,000 for the latest year and $399,000,000 for year-ago period.

title: UKRAINE'S LEADER COMING TO U.S.
description: The Soviet Union's Ukrainian leader, who is a member of the ruling Politburo, will visit the United States next month, it was announced here today.

title: Franklin Ashley Is Dead at 69; Plastic Surgeon to Famous
description: Dr. Franklin Ashley, a plastic surgeon whose patients included Ann-Margret and Phyllis Diller and who reconstructed the faces of deformed Vietnamese and African children, died today in Florida, his biographer said. He was 69 years old.

title: JOHN HUGHES'S 'BREAKFAST CLUB'
description: FIVE kids spending Saturday doing detention time in the high school library: it's not such a spine-tingling situation. But in ''The Breakfast Club,'' which he wrote and directed, John Hughes lets the kids challenge, taunt and confront each other as if this were ''Twelve Angry Men.'' Personalities are dissected; tears are shed. The kids, each representing a different teen stereotype, come to understand each other. They strike up friendships. They denounce their parents. They decide that ''when you grow up, your heart dies.''

title: U.S. AIDE WARNS BANKS ON TAKING CRIME FUNDS
description: Amid continuing reverberations about the Bank of Boston, which is under investigation by a Federal grand jury looking into money-laundering, the chief counsel of the President's Commission on Organized Crime came here today to deliver a lecture on the responsibilities of a bank in a nation at war with organized crime.

title: BACARDI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: All share earnings have been adjusted for the 2-for-1 common stock split, effective May 18, 1984.

title: ADULT VIEWERS CALLED THE KEY
description: After a belated start, it did not take Walt Disney Productions long to show that Donald Duck, Mickey Mouse and Company can be as captivating on cable television as they ever were at the movies or on network TV. But now Disney has to decide whether it can draw in Mom and Dad as well, without diluting the unique magic that has always enchanted the kids.

title: CONVERSE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CONCERT: NEW COMPOSITIONS HEARD AT SYMPHONY SPACE
description: IT is often difficult to assess a

title: AMERICAN MEDICAL BUILDINGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $1,738,000 from restructuring senior notes for the quarter and year. c-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $10,792,707 for the quarter and $16,185,707 for the year.

title: GOULDS PUMPS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NORTH EUROPEAN OIL ROYALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Badillo Lunches With G.O.P. Chief
description: George L. Clark Jr., the Republican state chairman, and Herman Badillo, who dropped out of the Democratic mayoral race last week, met over lunch yesterday to discuss mayoral campaign issues.

title: AMCA INTERNATIONAL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $799,000 for the quarter and $6,722,000 for year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $24,860,000 for the quarter and $35,689,000 for the year. The year-ago figures were restated. All figures are in U.S. dollars.

title: Ryan Says Sore Arm Hurt Passing in '84
description: Because he was trying to land, and then hold, the Jets' starting quarterback job, Pat Ryan played last season with a sore arm that hindered his performance in nearly all of his appearances, he now says.

title: KNOLL INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CORPORATE GIVING FAILS TO OFFSET CUTS BY U.S.
description: Although corporate giving to charity has increased steadily in recent years, it has come nowhere near filling the gaps left by the Reagan Administration's cuts in Government support of social programs, according to those who monitor corporate giving.

title: CONTINUUM CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
KHMER ROUGE BASES REPORTED IN PERIL
description: Thai military officials said today that Khmer Rouge rebels, who have been fighting the Vietnamese in Cambodia for six years, appeared to be on the verge of being driven from their most important bases in western Cambodia along the Thai border.

title: Pollsters on the Right
description: In a letter seeking new subscribers

title: Wider Peacekeeping Role for Unifil in Lebanon
description: To the Editor:

title: SOUTH AFRICA: A NEW PATH?
description: By the standards of his white forebears, President P. W. Botha of South Africa recently came close to heresy.

title: STAGE: A COMOC 'CRATE' AT ENSEMBLE STUDIO
description: WHAT'S a playwright to do when his director, having been firmly instructed to round up a troupe of ''great actors,'' misunderstands and hires a cast of ''crate actors'' instead? Such is the question posed by Shel Silverstein at the start of ''The Crate,'' his new potpourri of ''playlets and songlets'' at the Ensemble Studio Theater. Being a resourceful fellow - as well as a very funny one - Mr. Silverstein thereafter provides his own answer. ''The Crate'' is an evening of loony comic bits set in, on or around a large wooden crate - all performed by eight of the ''greatest and cratest actors who have ever hit the boards.''

title: AT TOY FAIR: ROBOTS, HOOPLA AND HARD SELL
description: Alan Fine went to a cocktail party at Regine's this week in honor of a stuffed something called a Wuzzle. Leonard Wane and Colette Rooney celebrated the Barbie doll's birthday at a black-tie dinner at the Waldorf- Astoria. All three of them watched a $500 robot named Ominibot 2000 make wisecracks and serve diet 7-Up. But they missed the life-size Cabbage Patch Kid dolls who hugged visitors and tried to comb their hair.

title: HARSCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SCREEN: 'MEAN SEASON,' REPORTER VS. MURDERER
description: THE thriller ''The Mean Season'' reveals how much can go wrong for a reporter who enjoys a symbiotic relationship with his source - particularly when the source is a serial murderer who enjoys seeing his name in print. When Malcolm Anderson (Kurt Russell), a reporter for a Miami newspaper, gets his first call from a man later dubbed ''The Numbers Killer,'' Malcolm is stimulated and mildly flattered. The killer, after all, says he likes Malcolm's writing and is offering him quite an exclusive. Malcolm has caught his attention by locating a snapshot of the man's first victim and describing it as ''all that remained of her tragically short life.''

title: SOVIET OFFERS NEW PROPOSAL ON TROOP REDUCTIONS
description: The Soviet Union today unveiled a new proposal in East-West negotiations on reducing conventional forces in central Europe and said the plan could produce movement in the deadlocked talks.

title: Digital's Plans After Rainbow
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation, which earlier this week said it had quit making its Rainbow personal computer, said yesterday that it would announce details next month of a new product that could be used to upgrade the Rainbow and Decmate personal computers. Joe Nahil, a Digital spokesman, said the company had not planned to disclose the new product yet but decided to indicate its intentions now after some Rainbow users inferred that Digital was abandoning the personal computer market.

title: GRAND UNION CO reports earnings for 12wks to Jan 5
description: b-Net loss. The year-earlier results included a store closure provision of $45 million.

title: BOARD REJECTS PLEA ON REMSEN WEIGHT
description: The New York State Racing and Wagering Board yesterday rejected an appeal by the owner-trainer Gil Puentes to overturn the disqualification of his horse, Stone White, who was found to have carried incorrect weight in winning the Remsen Stakes at Aqueduct last Nov. 17.

title: UNITED MEDICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MISTRIAL DECLARED FOR VETERINARIAN ACCUSED OF KILLING DEFORMED SON
description: A deadlocked jury brought a mistrial tonight in the trial of a veterinarian accused of murdering his newborn son minutes after birth by slamming the severely deformed child onto the delivery room floor.

title: Hearing the Echoes
description: Dave Gotkin remembers the crowd, the 16,000 fans in Madison Square Garden and an estimated 3,000 turned away in the streets. He was used to playing in front of 250 fans at the tiny St. John's gym in Brooklyn, and it was not hard to realize a new era had arrived for college basketball.

title: UNITED STATES SUGAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: FASTER '84 MONEY GROWTH
description: The Federal Reserve announced revised statistics yesterday showing that growth in the basic money supply was slightly faster last year than previously reported, and that growth continued at a rapid clip in the three months ended with January.

title: Friday LIBRARY TREASURES
description: Unfolding its rarest treasures, the New York Public Library will display 260 works selected from more than 26 million in its holdings at an exhibition opening today and continuing through May 24 at Fifth Avenue and 42d Street. Some items were chosen for their historic impact, such as a letter from Christopher Columbus reporting his discovery of the New World, others for their beauty, like illuminated manuscripts, still others for their literary significance, including a Gutenberg Bible and Melville's handwritten first draft of ''Typee.'' They can be seen Mondays through Saturdays, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. Information: 869-8089. OF IRANIANS AND OTHERS

title: GOOD NEWS FOR SOUTH AFRICANS
description: The South African Government's announcement that it is suspending its forced resettlement policy will be welcome news to the 10 people at an experimental farm in Natal province called Mdukatshani, which is Zulu for ''The Place of the Lost Grasses.''

title: ART: ROUSSEAU'S WORKS IN SHOW AT THE MODERN
description: THE opening of the Douanier Rousseau exhibition at the Grand Palais last year was a moving occasion - how could it not have been? Not only was Rousseau shown in full and at his best, but he was also honored as he had always hoped to be - as a national hero, in a great museum in his own city, and in the silvery Parisian light.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Sam Rutligiano , who was dismissed as head coach of the Cleveland Browns during the 1984 season but remained under contract to the club, said he had cut his ties with the Browns after turning down an offer of a front-office job. He said he would seek other opportunities after spending a month as a consultant to Italian football leagues. . . .

title: CLAROSTAT MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
JAIL MOVES INTO PROBATIONER'S HOME
description: Jay Match fidgets. He paces the floor, sits for a while at a kitchen table to flip the pages of a textbook for electrical contractors, walks back out into his living room.

title: SABINE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Veteran Says He Saw Mengele as U.S. Prisoner
description: A former United States Army soldier said today that he believes he saw Dr. Josef Mengele, the accused Nazi war criminal, in American custody shortly after World War II.

title: PBA Layoffs
description: Provincetown-Boston Airline will lay off 150 more employees this week and cut the number of flights by 17 percent to get back into the black, a spokesman announced.

title: Diner's Journal
description: IF all goes according to plan, there will be two

title: 1984 Net Rose Sharply At 3 Large Agencies
description: The Interpublic Group of Companies, Foote, Cone & Belding Communications and Grey Advertising reported their results for 1984, which were up 29.1 percent, 29.2 percent and 27.5 percent, respectively.

title: Shoreham License Put Off to Feb. 25
description: The Federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission voted 4 to 1 yesterday to delay issuing a low-power license for the Shoreham (L.I.) Nuclear Power Station for an additional week, until Feb. 25.

title: CARLING O'KEEFE LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an $11,700,000 writeoff of bottles in brewing operations for the quarter and 9 months. c-Net income

title: OWENS & MINOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PETRO-LEWIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income. There were no share earnings for the year-ago 6 months because of preferred dividend requirements.

title: Stevie Wonder Arrested
description: The singer Stevie Wonder, saying he was a ''conscientious criminal'' against oppression, was arrested along with a group of anti-apartheid demonstrators today outside the South African Embassy here. Protests have been held daily outside the embassy.

title: REYNOLDS, R J INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $9,000,000 for the quarter and income from discontinued operations of $92,000,000 for the year, and a gain of $275,000,000 for the quarter and year on the sale of the company's Aminoil unit. cIncludes income from discontinued operations of $27,000,000 for the quarter and $179,000 for the year.

title: ERO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The share earnings results adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split paid Aug. 10, 1984.

title: WORKER-OWNED RATH PACKING MAY BE AT END OF A LONG ROAD
description: It is a weathered, untended visage of Black Hawk, the Sauk chief, that stares from the water tower of the Rath Packing Company in this frozen prairie community.

title: Ex-Officer Is Held in Slaying
description: A former Baltimore police officer, Christie Shipley, has been charged with killing her husband and leaving plastic bags filled with parts of his body around Dover, the authorities said today. Mrs. Shipley, 47 years old, was charged with first-degree murder in the slaying last August of William Shipley, a retired member of the Baltimore police force, the Delaware state police said.

title: SMOKEY ROBINSON COMES TO BROADWAY
description: SMOKEY ROBINSON, the man whose hits with his Detroit high school group, the Miracles, became the foundation upon which Motown Records was built, has finally made it to Broadway. The singer and songwriter whom Bob Dylan is said to have called one of the greatest American poets, will be 45 next week, but he has all the enthusiasm of man 15 years younger. And at Tuesday's opening of an engagement at the Gershwin Theater that extends through Sunday, Mr. Robinson's vibrant, pleading pop-soul tenor was in magnificent condition.

title: IONA HOLDS OFF ARMY, 47-45
description: Iona returned to its swarming man- to-man defense in the last minute tonight and came away with a 47-45 victory over Army at Mulcahy Center.

title: Nazi Suspect Loses Appeal In Fighting Deportation Order
description: An immigration appeals board ruled today that John Demjanjuk, a retired Cleveland automobile worker accused of being a Nazi war criminal, should be deported from the United States.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;   Gannett to Replace 2 Register Officials
description: The Gannett Company said yesterday that the two executives at The Des Moines Register who began what turned into a heated bidding war for the paper and its holding company, the Des Moines Register and Tribune Company, will be replaced when Gannett gains control of the company in June.

title: Films and Videos
description: Winning entries in a film and video competition sponsored by the Brooklyn Arts and Culture Association can be seen this weekend at the Downtown Community Television Center, 87 Lafayette Street. Eight films will be screened tonight, beginning at 7; the other six will be shown tomorrow, also at 7 P.M. Each program lasts three hours and costs $2.50. Information: 966-4510.

title: Memories Linger
description: Don Baylor of the Yankees, who yesterday was named the 15th annual winner of the Roberto Clemente Award for best representing baseball on and off the field, played against the legendary Clemente in the Puerto Rican Winter League in 1970 and 1971. After receiving the trophy, primarily in honor of his work as National Sports Chairman for Cystic Fibrosis, Baylor voiced some recollections about the Pittsburgh Pirates' right fielder who died in a plane crash on Dec. 31, 1972, while on a mercy mission from Puerto Rico to help earthquake victims in Nicaragua.

title: DANCE: THREE PILOBOLUS PREMIERES
description: ''PILOBOLUS Goes to the Movies'' might be the subtitle for the third program Pilobolus Dance Theater is presenting in its current season at the Joyce Theater, 19th Street and Eighth Avenue.

title: DIVIDED OPPOSITION
description: In a politically charged week, the contest for the Democratic nomination for mayor has become just what Mayor Koch's friends wanted and his enemies did not want - a classic division of his opposition and even division within the division. The mayoral candidacies of City Council President Carol Bellamy and Assemblyman Herman D. Farrell Jr., the Manhattan Democratic leader - each with their strengths and constituencies - have at least temporarily split wide open the still forming coalition that most politicians believe is necessary to defeat the Mayor as he seeks a third term.

title: DAVIS IN FINAL WITH MAYOTTE
description: Scott Davis pulled off the final upset of the inaugural $1.8 million Lipton International Players Championships tournament, downing 11th-seeded Tomas Smid of Czechoslovakia, 7-6, 6-4, 4-6, 6-3, tonight to advance to Sunday's men's title match.

title: MODULAR COMPUTER SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a writeoff of $576,000 from the company's 25 percent interest in ATM Computer. c-Net loss.

title: A Talking-To
description: Joe Morgan, the former Cincinnati Reds' second baseman who retired from the Oakland A's last year, is returning to the Reds as a television analyst. But if his former teammate

title: GOODRICH, B.F. CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a pre-tax provision of $12 million to cover expenses associated with phasing out the company's industrial rubber products manufacturing in Akron, Ohio. c-Net income

title: A BOMB OF SUNDAYS

How they wake up smiling and saying, ''Thank the Great Bureaucrat Upstairs, it's Friday''? How they step peppily away from their benches (often before quitting time) on Friday afternoon with spirits soaring.

title: SCREEN: 'FEAR CITY' OPENS
description: The low-down, dirty ambiance of ''Fear City'' should effectively keep it from being seen by anyone outside the hard-core action crowd. However, Abel Ferrara, who directed this and an earlier exploitation thriller called ''Ms. 45,'' has a strongly individual style that almost transcends the genre. For all the violence, sexism and racial slurs that are de rigueur in films of this sort, ''Fear City'' is better than most, and it has elements of originality and visual distinction. It opened yesterday at Loew's State and other theaters.

title: Fed Eases Restraints On Rates
description: The Federal Reserve Board reported today that its policy-making committee agreed two months ago to relax a little its restraints on interest rates and bank reserves - a decision economists long suspected and an important factor in the economy's relative strength since the turn of the year.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: THE FOURTH CIRCLE The last 10 years of the art of Wassily Kandinsky, who died just over 40 years ago, is filling the unique spiral gallery of the Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 88th Street (360- 3500), from the fourth level down to the rotunda. This exhibition, which opened yesterday, is the final one of three that trace the work of the Russian-born artist whose influence on the shape of 20th-century art was so strong, and who was so vital a figure in the development of abstract painting.

title: Occidental Well
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation said that Dhurnal 2, a discovery well in Pakistan, flowed at a rate of 14,777 barrels of light oil and 37.6 million cubic feet of gas a day.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, a Chicago dispatch yesterday about a malpractice report by the American Medical Association misstated the statute of limitations governing malpractice cases. The period in which suits can be filed after an incident varies from state to state; in New York it is two and a half years. With delays in the legal system, it can be extended to as many as 18 years.

title: The Test for Korea's Democracy
description: South Korea and Nicaragua have this much in common: Both are pseudo-democracies, ruled by self-enthroned soldiers who seek legitimacy through token elections. Though both have so far failed in that ambition, the Reagan Administration is plainly eager, for strategic reasons, to apply a looser, lesser standard of judgment in Korea. But the results of last Tuesday's election show what a mistake that would be.

description: ''Glengarry Glen Ross,'' the Pulitzer Prize-winning drama by David Mamet, is to close after tomorrow's performance at the Golden Theater. It will have given 377 performances and 11 previews. A national tour is to begin in Chicago in April.

title: GRILLED CHICKEN TO GO: SEVEN TOP CHOICES
description: Slowly but steadily, grills and rotisseries are overtaking deep-fat fryers in fast-food shops that offer chicken to take out. Five years ago there were fewer than half a dozen of those shops but a recent informal survey uncovered 20 such places in Manhattan. In addition, there are dozens of supermarkets and corner delis that sell chicken on the rotisserie.

title: I.R.S. RELAXES ITS RULES ON USING COMPANY CAR
description: Faced with stacks of complaints from members of Congress and business people, the Internal Revenue Service today released new rules reducing somewhat the tax burden on people who use company cars to commute to and from work.

title: New Pocket Books Chief
description: In editorial and executive changes in the field of paperback publishing, Irwyn Applebaum has been named publisher of Pocket Books, a division of Simon & Schuster. He comes from Bantam Books, another major paperback house, where he served as associate publisher and worked with Jack Romanos, Bantam's former publisher. Mr. Romanos joined Pocket Books last month to head Simon & Schuster's mass market publishing group. Mr. Applebaum and William Grose, editorial director, will report to Rena Wolner, who was named president of Pocket Books several days ago.

Convicted rapists can now be sentenced to hard labor for up to 20 years.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS Auto Racing
description: 27th Annual Daytona 500, at Daytona Beach, Fla. Cale Yarborough and the Ranier Racing Team, who have won this most prestigious race on the stock car circuit for the past two years, are back but they were having trouble with their Ford Thunderbirds overheating since the Busch Clash sprint race last week. Yarborough still made the front row, qualifying second at 203.814 miles an hour. Bill Elliott, also driving a Thunderbird, captured the pole position with a record 205.114 m.p.h. The Rev. Andrew J. W. Mullins performed the ceremony with the Rev. Dr. Arthur Caliandro of Marble Collegiate Church.

Forced into retirement, it became the property of the artist Ona Lindquist, who turned it into a spiffy, gleaming icon. Today, it is the centerwork in the show ''Bent Fabric,'' on view at Thorpe Intermedia Gallery in Sparkill.

title: SHAKESPEAREAN CABARET
description: Will Shakespeare, the lyricist, has a new show in town, his first since the well-received ''Shakespeare's Cabaret'' in 1981. Lance Mulcahy, who was given a Tony nomination for the score he composed to Shakespeare's songs and sonnets at that time, is once again the composer for a sequel called ''Sweet Will: Shakespeare's Cabaret II,'' which is playing at Don't Tell Mama, 343 West 46th Street, Wednesdays through Saturdays.

title: ATTACH ROPES TO U.S. AID TO MARCOS
description: The rallying cry of the Communist- led New People's Army in the Philippines is the ''U.S.-Marcos dictatorship.'' This suggests that the way to defeat the Communists and restore democracy to the Philippines is for Washington to sever its ties to President Ferdinand E. Marcos or, at the very least, condition our aid to an end to human rights abuses,

title: SMALL SPEAKERS ATTAIN NEW LEVELS OF MUSICAL MERIT
description: This, we are told, is the space age. It may not look that way to most New Yorkers. Space is just what they haven't got, and with rents and real estate prices shooting up like a luxury high-rise displacing a row of cozy brownstones, floorspace is becoming a rare resource. Where every square foot counts, fewer people in this town - or others, for that matter - are willing or able to give houseroom to bulky speakers. So, like any other species, loudspeakers have been adapting themselves to the changes in their environment. They're getting smaller. Or, more precisely, a greater proportion of smaller speakers is being sold.

title:
GARDENING;

YES, THE TOMATO IS A FRUIT
description: -standing argument, perhaps better described as a misunderstanding, as to just what one consumes when eating a tomato. Some say that a tomato is a vegetable and justify that classification based on its use. After all, fruits are used as desserts, appetizers, jellies and the like, while vegetables are used in soups, stews and main courses. Therefore, since the tomato is used as a vegetable, it must be one.

title: FLORIO'S DELAY UNSETTLING PARTY LEADERS

title: More ToughTalk FromBudget Director
description: It was a recess week on Capitol Hill, but not around the Executive Branch. Continuing to display the verve of a man with a mission (and, some say, the fearlessness of one who may be planning to resign before the new fiscal year dawns), Budget Director David A. Stockman insisted again that Washington could not and should not rescue financially strapped farmers.

title: A BRITISH WHODUNIT SPOOFS THE POST-DIAGHILVE ERA
description: The librettos of two ballets are described in a book that has recently been published in the United States. The first is outlined as follows: ''It is called 'Table d'Hote.' The action takes place in a restaurant. The backcloth is a bill of fare. On the left is painted the black jacket of the mai^tre d'hotel, on the right one asparagus.'' The music, by a Russian composer named Polyshumudshedshi, provides crunching sounds that could be mistaken for ''heavy footed waiters shuffling'' but which actually represent ''celery.'' The symbolic theme of the ballet is appetite. The choreographer explains: ''Appetites are universal. Man, he is hungry for food, the nations, they are hungry for territory.''

title: HOW TO CARE PROPERLY FOR HOME FIREPLACE
description: -BURNING fireplace can be a real joy for those fortunate enough to have one in their house, but if it frequently smokes or constantly requires attention to keep the fire going, it can also be quite a nuisance.

title: PUTTING ROUSSEAU IN PERSPECTIVE
description: FINDING A LABEL FOR the French painter Henri Rousseau (1844-1910) is a tricky business. The word ''naive'' has for so long been applied to him that it won't come unstuck. True, the term covers his technical awkwardnesses and childlike point of view - Rousseau was self-taught as an artist, and as a man he was by most accounts a gentle, large- hearted innocent. But we might also say that he fit into modern art as a post-Impressionist-without- portfolio. The radiant poetry of his work, and its flat, decorative style in which traditional lighting and perspective play no part, evoke Gauguin and other ''advanced'' artists of his generation.

title: STAGE: JEWISH REPERTORY OFFERS 'CITY BOY'
description: The tipoff about ''City Boy'' at the Jewish Repertory Theater is that no playwright is listed in the playbill. There is an ''author,'' Leonard Michaels, and an ''adaptor/director,'' Edward M. Cohen, but no one is credited as the ''playwright.''

title: ROCK: THE GROUP WHAM IN CONCERT AT THE BEACON

Yet while Mr. Michael kept a smile on his face and a twitch in his hips, he also led a buoyant, hard-working group of 12 musicians and two go-go dancers.

title: Koch on Crime:It's Time toGet Tough

People ''are absolutely fed up'' about crime and they want criminals punished more severely, Mr. Koch told a state commission that is considering changes in sentencing laws.

Motley 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Motley Jr. of Dover and West Falmouth, Mass. A May wedding is planned.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES

Not a flashy orchestral concerto with its obvious action and adventure camera opportunities - a solo piano recital: one pianist, one piano, a handful of great composers, relieved only by the same pianist discussing the music with host Andre Previn.

title: MONTANA DEBATES SEX-BLIND INSURANCE LAW
description: Insurance industry lobbyists and women's groups from around the nation have differed sharply here on a move to repeal a Montana law that requires insurance companies to treat men and women equally. It is the only such state law in the country.

title: CONSUMER RATES

CENTRAL JERSEY NEEDS A BOARD TO PLAN GROWTH
description: THE central corridor of New Jersey is poised for a metamorphosis. The technology hub around Princeton University along Route 1 could soon quietly overshadow California's Silicon Valley, North Carolina's Research Triangle and Massachusetts' Route 128.

title: Moves and Countermoves In November,
description: Gary Kasparov had reason to despair in the world chess championships in Moscow. The defending champion, Anatoly Karpov, was leading the 21-year-old challenger by 5-0 with one game to go.

title: The Follies of Writer Worship
description: I once owned a piece of Somerset Maugham's gate. Well, not exactly Somerset Maugham's gate - it wasn't pillaged from the Villa Mauresque - but near enough. My chunk of literary wood came from the vicarage at Whitstable where Maugham spent part of his unhappy boyhood. Decades later local graybeards with lips untouched by a lie would assure you that they had often seen the future novelist swinging on the vicarage gate. When it fell into disrepair some 20 years ago, I greedily acquired a section of it - a spar about a yard long, with a nail at each end and a thick carapace of white paint. I kept it under the stairs, alongside other pointless yet favored items - the half-finished brass rubbing, the broken typewriter, the tennis racquet with strings burst into a mad spaghetti. From time to time I would take out my private trophy, examine it with half-embarrassed fondness, then put it back.

title: SILENCE BY LAWSUIT
description: BOSTON Britain's Official Secrets Act must be one of the most thoroughly discredited laws in the Western world. The act makes it a crime to disclose any Government information without official approval, even if the purpose is to expose wrongdoing. It intimidates the press and limits public discussion of policy.

description: For those who think of ''Coppelia'' as a countrified morality

title: CORRECTION
description: An article last Sunday about the National Basketball Association's slam-dunk championship on Feb. 9 misidentified the winner. He was Dominique Wilkins.

ART;

REALISM TAKES OVER GREENWICH'S BRUCE
description: YOU can name everything you see in ''The Recognizable Image'' at the Bruce Museum in Greenwich through March 17. This is the major drawing card of this exhibition, which hums at an agreeable level. It is a staunchly conservative undertaking for those who prefer their paint surfaces unrumpled, and emotions kept inside.

title: OLD ROAD SPARKS NEW RIFT

But just when the state has released $14 million for the two-mile project, some residents of Lawrence and the Queens County enclave of West Lawrence, which borders Nassau County, are objecting to the roadway.

title: SHOREHAM GO-AHEAD: THE STORY BEHIND THE VOTE
description: WASHINGTON WHY did the Nuclear Regulatory Commission vote 4 to 1 to allow low-power operation of the Shoreham Nuclear Power Station - assuring potentially costly contamination of the reactor - at a time when substantial doubt exists about full-power operation?

title: PRESERVATIONITS WIN IN CHARLESTON
description: Preservationists here are celebrating a double victory after two major projects planned for the city's historic district were redesigned on a smaller scale more in keeping with the area's distinctive architecture.

title: BRAMBLE KEEPS HIS TITLE BY OUTPOINTING MANCINI
description: A breathtaking if bloody 15-round fight, which began with a skull and crossbones and ended with expressions of love, may have gloriously capped the boxing career of Ray (Boom Boom) Mancini, not with victory but with dignity.

title: ANN-MARGRET PRODUCES YET ANOTHER SURPRISE
description: One of the highest compliments that can be paid to a performer who's been around awhile is that he or she is still capable of eliciting surprise. Ann-Margret, the initially brassy, belting, singing-dancing actress who made her film debut in 1961 at the age of 20, has been more or less surprising us with regularity since 1971, when she won her first Oscar nomination for her work in the bitterly funny Mike Nichols-Jules Feiffer comedy, ''Carnal Knowledge.''

title: Prisons Are Not the Priority
description: ''People are fed up, absolutely fed up'' about crime, Mayor Koch told a commission studying criminal sentences the other day. If he had to choose between spending for prisons and spending for schools, he said, he'd pick prisons. The Mayor is surely right that people are fed up, and there's every reason to spend more on criminal justice. But is he right about prisons? It's far from clear that building more cells is the best way, or even a good way, to fight crime.

title: Miss DePatie Has Nuptials
description: Marianne Lord DePatie, an assistant vice president of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, and John Fouhey, a partner in the New York law firm of Davis Polk & Wardwell, were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Catherine of Siena in West Simsbury, Conn. The Rev. Joseph C. Gengras performed the ceremony.

title: A CENTURIES-OLD STRUGGLE KEEPS SRI LANKA ON EDGE
description: The grisly reports come in from the countryside almost daily. Army convoys are blown up by a bomb or land mine. Civilians are slaughtered in retaliation. In recent weeks, the violence on this beautiful tropical island nation off the southern tip of India seems to have reached new heights.

title: DOCTORS SEE THIRD HEART PATIENT'S 'POSITIVE ATTITUDE' AND CONDITION AS PLUS
description: Murray P. Haydon, the third patient chosen to receive a permanent artificial heart, had a ''very positive attitude'' toward the implant operation that was scheduled for early Sunday morning, his doctors said tonight.

title: HALL OF FAME CHOOSES FIRST MEMBER
description: -year-old Hartsdale resident who describes herself as a ''community activist,'' will be the first woman inducted into the new Westchester County/Avon Women's Hall of Fame.

title: Barbara Sinclair Becomes a Bride
description: Barbara Jean Sinclair, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Bolte Sinclair of Wyckoff, N.J., and Anthony Albert Aguero, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Antonio Aguero of Jackson Heights, Queens, were married yesterday. The Rev. Donner B. Atwood performed the ceremony at the Wyckoff Reformed Church, assisted by the Rev. Steven Ferrari, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: ARMY SEEKING POWERFUL BATTLEFIELD MISSILE SYSTEM
description: The Army wants to double its spending for research on a new conventional missile system that it hopes would work as effectively against enemy tank columns or troops as a small nuclear bomb, according to the Army Chief of Staff.

title: CARE UNDER THE SUN
description: Today, the demand in sun care is twofold: to tan as quickly as possible, and, at the same time, to protect the skin against the sun's damaging effects. As one answer to these demands, Estee Lauder Sun is introducing a new line of sun-care products with a tanning formula called ''Biotan.'' The company says that ''Biotan is not a sun screen, but its action works synergistically with ultra-violet sun filters to increase photo- protection against U.V. rays.'' It further claims that this Biotan complex stimulates the skin to produce more melanin, the component in the skin that interacts with the sun to create a tan. Says Leonard Lauder: ''This key ingredient means a person need spend less time in the sun to acquire a deeper tan.''

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;

FOSTER FAMILIES' DAY
description: They may not be particularly gentle with opposing hockey teams, but when it comes to Westchester's foster families, the New York Rangers are good skates.

title: Tulsa Officials Assail City Rating in Survey
description: City officials are not ready to forgive a professor whose survey of American cities erroneously listed Tulsa as last in two categories.

title: POSH LONDON
description: To the Editor:

title: Victoria Mertens, A Lawyer, to Wed Walter Thorman
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Mertens of Hilton Head, S.C., formerly of New York, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Victoria Bullert Mertens, to Walter Edward Thorman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Ernest Thorman of Wantagh, L.I. The wedding is to be in late April.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Tony Perez , the slugging first baseman who was reunited with his former Big Red Machine teammate,

title: LAWYER SINGS ON STAGE: THEN, IN SPARE TIME. . .
description: NOBODY could be faulted for wondering if there is more than one Beverly Bell Winslow. Sometimes Beverly Bell Winslow is to be found at the venerable firm of Payne, Wood & Littlejohn of Glen Cove, where she is known professionally as Miss Bell, wears ''attorney suits,'' holds the title of partner and specializes in real-state law.

title: FOR FOREIGNERS IN CITY, A WEST SIDE RENDEZVOUS
description: An engineer from China, a photographer from Taiwan and a student from Hong Kong are working together on the planning committee for an event called China Evening.

title: DRUNK, DISORDERLY
description: THE LIFE OF THE PARTY

title: RECOGNITION FOR A WORLD WAR II ADMIRAL
description: Fleet Adm. Chester W. Nimitz will be honored on Feb. 22, with the issuance of a 50-cent stamp in the Great Americans definitive series. The ceremonies will be in The Admiral Nimitz State Historical Park, Fredericksburg, Tex., the town of his birth 100 years ago.

title: Data Bank;    February 17, 1985
No Headline
description: A RUTGERS University history professor and eight state and county college professors have been named to develop college and high school curriculums to help students understand the experiences of immigrants who passed through Ellis Island.

title: Bodine, in a Pontiac, Wins Sportsman Race
description: Geoff Bodine indicated he could be a strong factor in the Daytona 500 auto race by winning the Late Model Sportsman 300-mile event today.

title: VERA B. SCRIBNER
description: Vera Bloodgood Scribner, a horsewoman and the wife of the late publisher Charles Scribner, died of heart failure Friday at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J. She was 93 years old and lived in Far Hills, N.J.

title: Narcotics CropsAre Prospering
description: The United States, as the world's leading consumer of narcotics, has a long way to go before it makes a noticeable dent in the supply. That appeared to be the main message of the State Department's annual report on world production of marijuana, coca and opium.

title: OPERA: RESPIGHI FOR CHILDREN
description: The Chamber Opera Theater of New York gave New York a pen-and- ink sketch of Respighi's ''Sleeping Beauty'' at the Marymount Theater Thursday night. This tiny little children's opera - written in 1922 and intended for puppets - was given here in an unstaged version with piano that swept by its listeners in barely half an hour.

title: Kathleen Kehoe Wed To Bernard J. Mooney
description: At St. Sebastian's Roman Catholic Church in Woodside, Queens, yesterday, Kathleen Marie Kehoe, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Kehoe of Granite Springs, N.Y., was married to Bernard J. Mooney, the son of Frances Mooney of Manhattan and the late James Martin Mooney. The Rev. Robert Frost performed the ceremony.

title: PFIZER TO ANCHOR A REDEVELOPMENT ZONE
description: THERE was a flurry of anxiety in official

title:
CONTINENTAL SAMPLER;

IRELAND
description: People who appreciate traditional Irish clothing should have no trouble finding what they want at Irish Cottage Industries on Dawson Street in Dublin. There, a ready-made or made-to-measure woman's tweed suit or coat costs around $125; skirts start at $25 and fabric begins at $16.60 a yard. Men's jackets are $89, slacks go for $8.50 to $17 and ties are $4.50. Another excellent place for tweeds is Kevin & Howlin on nearby Nassau Street.

title: PARTNERS AT WORK
description: Paul A. Samuelson pondered letting the

title: China Vows More Support
description: China reacted today to Vietnamese military successes in Cambodia by repeating its support for the Cambodian guerrillas and belittling the importance of Vietnam's capture of the guerrilla stronghold of Phnom Malai.

title: PATIENT A FATHER, A NEIGHBOR AND A 'FIGHTER'
description: Murray P. Haydon, a history buff with a will to live, may put his own name into the history books today when he becomes the third patient to receive an artificial heart implant.

title: KEROSENE HEATER SUSPECTED IN FIRE FATAL TO 7
description: Investigators said yesterday that the fire that killed seven people in Wyandanch, L.I., Friday was apparently caused by a kerosene heater that had been accidentally filled with the wrong kind of fuel.

title: Dr. Louisa Castiglia to Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Hannibal L. Castiglia of Great Neck, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter Dr. Louisa M. Castiglia to Dr. Anthony T. Gambino, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Salvatore Gambino of Astoria, Queens. The wedding is planned for July.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: MILL SONG. By William Harry Harding. (Holt, $16.95.)

title: Nancy Quick To Be Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Leslie C. Quick Jr. of Palm Beach, Fla., and Laurel Hollow, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Nancy Jean Quick to Craig B. Gibson, a son of Dr. and Mrs. John Gibson of Winchester and Brewster, Mass.

title: Recent Sales
description: Hopatcong $69,500 *2* 115 Monroe Trail, 5-bedroom, 2-bath, 35-year-old *2* 2-family; living room with wood stove, separate *2* apartment on first floor; taxes $1,579. title: MUSIC: THROAT SINGERS FROM ESKIMO POINT
description: From far northern Canada, four Inuit musicians came to Dance Theater Workshop this weekend to perform what they called ''songs of our grandparents and our grandparents' grandparents.'' The concerts, which concluded with a matinee today (Sunday), presented three kinds of Inuit traditional music - throat-singing, mouth-harp tunes and drum dancing. Comments from the musicians were translated by Charlie Allen.

CONTINENTAL SAMPLER;

SCANDINAVIA
description: After being notoriously expensive in the past, Scandinavia is turning into a bargain for visitors from the United States who are shopping for such items as crystal, furs, porcelain and textiles - and even Japanese cameras.

title: Francine LeFrak To Marry in April
description: Mr. and Mrs. Samuel J. LeFrak of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Francine Ayn LeFrak, to Kirk Mason D'Amico, a son of Carol D'Amico and William Turlay, both of Portland, Ore. A late April wedding is planned.

title: KOREANS HELPING TO REVITALIZE NEWARK
description: NEWARK

title: QUESTIONS ON TOXIC CLEANUP RAISED
description: A Federal investigation has uncovered discrepancies in accounts of a $25 million toxic waste cleanup at the former Chemical Control Corporation plant in Elizabeth, N.J., according to a report.

title: OLD ISSUES, BUT AT LEAST SOME OF THE TALK IS NEW
description: JERUSALEM LAST week was one of those moments in the Middle East when everything and everyone seemed to be in motion. But despite the whirlwind of diplomatic activity spanning three continents it seemed prudent to wonder whether there was much ado about nothing. ''There is a lot more motion than there is movement,'' said Prof. Mark Heller, co-author of the Middle East Military Balance, issued by Tel Aviv University. ''I don't have the sense that there is any grand design or big picture being fitted together.''

title: Red Wing Is Clipped
description: Dave (Tiger) Williams , the most penalized player in the history of the National Hockey League, was waived by the Detroit Red Wings Friday, a day after the Red Wings' coach,

title: MINA BRYAN, JEFFERSON EDITOR
description: Mina R. Bryan, an editor of the collected papers of Thomas Jefferson and the librarian of a rare books collection at the Princeton University Library, died at the Princeton Medical Center Thursday after suffering a stroke. She was 77 years old and had lived in Princeton since 1944.

title: WHY MILAN KUNDERA IS WRONG ABOUT DOSTOYEVSKY
description: MILAN KUNDERA'S recent essay in The Book Review (''An Introduction to a Variation,'' Jan. 6) contained several points which demand a reply. Any dispute in matters of taste usually results in a standoff. Still, the preferences put forth by Mr. Kundera appear to be based not so much on his esthetics as on his sense of history.

title: SOVIET SHEDS NO LIGHT ON HALTED CHESS MATCH
description: Soviet newspaper readers were left in the dark today about the precise circumstances that led to the sudden stopping of the world chess championship.

title: RESTORRATION OF 2 SITES SET
description: TWO distinctive examples of New Jersey's architectural history - a gristmill in Stockton and a 14-room manor in Oxford - will be restored with the help of grants from the F. M. Kirby Foundation of Morristown.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: PUNS. By Walter Redfern. (Basil Blackwell, $14.95.)

title: RIGGING OF SLOT MANCHINES DESCRIBED AT RENO TRIAL
description: Eight people accused of rigging more than 100 slot machine jackpots in Nevada casinos are on trial in Federal District Court here on charges ranging from conspiracy to tax evasion and interstate travel for purposes of racketeering.

title: MAILING LETTERS COSTS 22/ AS POSTAL RATES INCREASE
description: Beginning Sunday, the cost of mailing cards, letters and packages will increase as the United States Postal Service's new rates go into effect on domestic and international mail.

title: SAUDI ENVOY OFF FOR TALKS IN SYRIA
description: King Fahd of Saudi Arabia sent an envoy to Damascus today to tell Syrian leaders that he had come away from his talks here convinced that President Reagan will play a more active role in Middle East peace efforts, a senior Saudi official said.

title: WEST SIDE HOUSING BOOM SPLITS CITY AND COMMUNITY
description: FOUR buildings now under development

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE;
description: COURTROOM DRAMA

title: STAR HIGH-JUMPER EXCELS IN ART,TOO
description: TATIANA SMOLIN spends an average of 12 hours a week with her art work - painting, drawing and photography. The 17-year-old Randolph High School senior says that art creates a diversion.

title: Slowdown in Free Agency SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 16 (UPI) - The big money free agency
description: brought to baseball and basketball has been only an illusion in professional football, according to two top player agents.

title:
ANTIQUES;

THE CAMPBELL TUREEN COLLECTION
description: CAMDEN A PREEMINENT collection of porcelain and silver soup tureens, related serving vessels and ladles is housed in the small, opulent Campbell Museum at the Campbell Soup Company headquarters here.

title: HOW TO RUN FOR MAYOR, PHASE 1
description: EVEN a feisty official like Mayor Koch surely must endure uncomfortably the criticisms that come with public office. But the Mayor undoubtedly took pleasure last week in decisions by two of his foremost critics to challenge him in the Democratic mayoral primary. Despite months of negotiations, leaders of the constituencies most dissatisfied with Mr. Koch failed to coalesce behind a single candidate. So last week Carol Bellamy, the city council president, and Assemblyman Herman D. Farrell Jr., the Manhattan Democratic leader, formally announced their candidacies. Politicians speculate that the two challengers will make the Mayor's re-election more likely by splitting the votes and energies of his opponents. To win the Democratic primary in September, a candidate will have to get more than 40 percent of the vote. If no one does, the two top finishers will compete in a runoff.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: The art of Pierre Bonnard (1867-1947) still falls some way short - in this country, above all - of its rightful place in the Pantheon of 20th-century art. Last year's major exhibition of his paintings, seen first in Paris and later in Washington, D.C. and Dallas, Tex., did not make it into New York and, by comparison with his friend and contemporary Henri Matisse, Bonnard has only a small constituency.

title: MOSCOW'S JUMPY MOOD
description: MOSCOW

title: Authoritarian History
description: To the Editor:

title: Sara Victoria Gadd to Wed Paul Donovan Eardenshon
description: The engagement of Sara Victoria Gadd to Paul Donovan Eardensohn has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. L. Damon Gadd of Palm Beach, Fla., and Waitsfield, Vt.

title: THE OTHER LEADERS IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: With his conditional offer of freedom for the jailed nationalist, Nelson Mandela, State President P.W. Botha seems to have loosened the lid on a Pandora's box among black people, encouraging them to show open support for the banned African National Congress, and displaying the gulf between the leaders accepted by blacks, and those with whom the Government has hitherto been prepared to deal.

title: DANCE: ISLENE PINDER'S BALINESE AMERICAN GROUP
description: Islene Pinder's Balinese American Dance Theater took its audience on a folkloric tour Friday in a loft studio at 88 Franklin Street. To start, there was the story of Iemanja, a sea goddess from Africa who is celebrated in Brazilian legend. Loving and lethal in Norma Ribeiro's ''Iemanja: Mother of the Waters,'' she lures a young fisherman to his grave in the sea, then mourns him.

title: ISLANDERS GAIN TIE IN SMITH'S RETURN
description: Billy Smith's wounded pride showed from the beginning tonight. Hockey's most controversial goalie returned from a six-game suspension for high-sticking, pleaded in vain for the referee to ''protect'' him and appeared nervous and erratic as the Islanders tied the undistinguished Hartford Whalers, 4-4.

title: ITALY
description: Quality leather goods in Italy, though never inexpensive, are especially worth seeking out and buying.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Week in Review on Feb. 3 about Congressional supervision of intelligence operations omitted the attribution of a description of Angelo M. Codevilla, who was until recently on the staff of the Senate Intelligence Committee. The characterization of Mr. Codevilla as an outspoken staff member with close ties to conservative activists was made by Senator Patrick J. Leahy of Vermont and Senator Dave Durenberger of Minnesota.

title: IN EUROPE, IT'S TIME TO BUY
description: LUDINA BARZINI is editor in chief of the Italian edition of Reader's Digest.

title: Bhopal Picture Wins Award
description: An Indian journalist has won an award for the best world press photograph of 1984 with a picture of a victim of the Bhopal poison-gas disaster, the World Press Photo organization has announced. The color photograph, taken by Pablo Bartholomew, showed a dead child. A special prize for feature photographs, the Oskar Barnack Award, was won by a Brazilian photographer based in Paris, Sebastiao Ribeiro Salgado, for a series of photographs on famine in Ethiopia.

title: Hryhorij Osijchuk, a Leader Of Ukrainian Church in U.S.
description: Metropolitan Hryhorij Osijchuk, the spiritual leader of 150,000 Ukrainians in the United States, Britain and Australia, died Wednesday in St. Mary of Nazareth Hospital. He was 87 years old.

title: Catherine Crites Marries in Dallas
description: The marriage of Catherine Ann Crites, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Neil Rush Crites of Plano, Tex., to Stephen Whitney Vittorini, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Carlo Vittorini of Katonah, N.Y., took place yesterday. The Rev. James Dorff performed the ceremony at the Highland Park United Methodist Church in Dallas.

title: 'EXTREMITIES,' DRAMA OF VIOLENCE, STAGED
description: IN William Mastrosimone's violent drama, ''Extremities,''

title: ACADEMY FOR TEACHERS ACCLAIMED
description: AT A RECENT meeting in Washington of leading education officials, New Jersey educators heard grumbling about their state's latest venture in improving education, the Academy for the Advancement of Teaching and Management.

title: YOUTHS GET VIEW OF LIFE IN THE WORKING WORLD
description: Once a week Mia Burgess is at the forefront of medical science.

title: FEAR AND RAVING IN LAS VEGAS
description: CITIZEN HUGHES

description: JOAN LEE FAUST This Week:
