CAMERA;

STILL LIFE PHOTOGRAPHY
description: Lou Jacobs Jr. has written several books on photography.

title: TEACHER IN SPACE? 'WHY NOT ME?'
description: SUSAN FINK of Smithtown used to wonder whether her 14-year-old daughter, Sheryl, would ever tire of listening to a song with the line ''my mother is a space cadet.'' Now, she says, she urges her to play it on her tape recorder - ''for luck.''

title: MANAGERS OF HISTORIC BUILDING SAY FACADE WORK IS REQUIRED BY LAW
description: The management of the Willkie Memorial Building on West 40th Street, a structure that has been called a prime candidate for landmark status, said yesterday that work on carved stone and ornaments on the building's facade was being done to comply with city laws intended to safeguard pedestrians from falling masonry.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: THE nation's vulnerability to chemical accidents, such as the one that killed 2,000 people in Bhopal, India, in December, will be examined tomorrow at a hearing in Newark of the Senate Environment and Public Works Committee. Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, Democrat of Montclair, is a member of the committee.

title: WERNER HERZOG FINDS THE TICKET TO LIFE
description: Helen Dudar writes frequently about the arts.

title: WILL TIGHTFISTEDNESS GIVE NICKLES THE UPPER HAND?
description: Senator Don Nickles had just finished addressing a civic luncheon in this market town in eastern Oklahoma, and Mayor Virgil James rose to ask the first question. What about revenue sharing, he asked, will that program be be cut by Congress this year?

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: MOSCOW RULES. By Robert Moss. (Villarly $16.95.)

title: Q&A
description: My 69-year-old aunt was given a rent reduction in August retroactive to June. I understand now that she has been eligible for a rent reduction under a city program since she was 62. Is it possible she could get a rent rollback retroactive to that date? . . . L. G., Manhattan

title: Sports of The Times;   Flutie and Michaels Survive
description: ORLANDO, Fla.

title: Foes of Apartheid Force Budd to Abandon Contest
description: Zola Budd, the South African native who is now a British citizen, was forced off course by anti-apartheid demonstrators while leading in the English women's cross-country championships today.

title: SterilizationOn the Increase
description: Surgical sterilization has become America's most popular method of contraception. Figures released last week show that almost 39 percent of husbands and wives have been sterilized, up from about 16 percent 20 years ago.

title: TASK FORCE EXPLORES COMPETING DEMANDS ON COUNTY'S OPEN SPACE
description: SIXTY years ago the Bronx River Parkway opened, a 15.5-mile scenic span linking Bronx Park in New York City with the Kensico Dam in Valhalla and making rustic Westchester more accessible. By employing, rather than dislodging parkland, the new roadway demonstrated that progress could be compatible with preservation.

title: Coping With Vietnam
description: Thank you for publishing Edward Tick's article, ''Apocalypse Continued'' (About Men, Jan. 13). Dr. Tick has presented an insightful analysis of a continuing problem. The question of how to cope with the pain and confusion that Vietnam caused and continues to cause so many of us has been dealt with publicly by avoidance and studied ignorance.

title: DEMOCRATS PREPARING FOR CITYWIDE AND BOROUGH CAMPAIGNS
description: While most of the attention in the new New York City political season has focused on the race for the Democratic mayoral nomination, there are already at least a dozen declared and prospective candidates for the party's nominations for City Council president, comptroller and three borough presidencies.

title: INDIAN EDITORS SAY GOVERNMENT THREATENS FREE EXPRESSION
description: A group of leading Indian editors today criticized some Government actions as threatening freedom of expression and said journalism had become a ''risky profession.''

title: BEIRUT CALLER SAYS AMERICAN HOSTAGE IS SENTENCED TO DEATH
description: A caller claiming to represent the Islamic Holy War organization said today that it had sentenced one of its four American hostages to die.

title: FROM ATLANTA TO THE SOUTH CHINA SEA
description: SHERMAN'S MARCH AND VIETNAM

title: President Calls Sandinista Foes Our Brothers
description: President Reagan, seeking to mobilize Congressional support for aid to Nicaraguan rebels, today called the insurgents ''our brothers'' and compared them to such ''freedom fighters'' as Lafayette, Bolivar, von Steuben and Kosciusko.

title: SOMETIMES, IT SEEMS, THE CAMERA DOES LIE. HERE'S HOW
description: Gen. William C. Westmoreland's $120 million libel suit against CBS has given the nation an unusual close-up of how the techniques of film-making and editing can affect a documentary's substance.

title:
GARDENING;

YES, THE TOMATO IS A FRUIT
description: -standing argument, perhaps better described as a misunderstanding, as to just what one consumes when eating a tomato. Some say that a tomato is a vegetable and justify that classification based on its use. After all, fruits are used as desserts, appetizers, jellies and the like, while vegetables are used in soups, stews and main courses. Therefore, since the tomato is used as a vegetable, it must be one.

title: A DATA BASE THAT THINKS BY 'SEEING'
description: FOR someone just becoming acquainted with computers, data bases are often the most intimidating of application. Word processing, after all, is but a fancy, feature filled method of writing.

title: IN CLASSROOMS, THE REACTION IS CHEMICAL
description: OCCASIONALLY a Connecticut College professor leaves the New London campus to set off explosions, start fires and create smells in elementary-school classrooms.

title: RECITAL: ROBERT DICK, FLUTIST, AT MERKIN HALL
description: Two flute recitals this past week have gone well beyond the usual narrow path of such events. First was Robert Aitken playing at Alice Tully Hall last Sunday afternoon; the most recent was by Robert Dick performing his own music and a wide range of other pieces at Merkin Concert Hall Thursday night.

title: U.S. Canceling Anti-Sub Exercise In Its Dispute With New Zealand
description: The United States has canceled a second set of military exercises with New Zealand and said all further security relations with the Pacific ally were under review.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

'ALL OF L.I. DRINKS FROM ONE WELL'
description: I'M going to talk to you today about a problem and an opportunity, both for Long Island. The problem is water. The opportunity, to set in place conditions to ensure that the Island will always have ample supplies of clean water.

title: HARLEM BUILDING BOUGHT BY DETERMINED TENANTS
description: Ten years ago Sarah Moore lived at 401 West 152d Street in Harlem in an apartment building where there was no landlord, no heat and very few tenants.

title: TAKING A CURE ON THE COAST
description: AMANDA MAYER STINCHECUM is a writer and textiles specialist based in Brooklyn.

title: CORRECTION
description: An item in last week's Westchester Journal about a conference on local beautfication programs carried an incorrect date for the event. The conference, sponsored by the Westchester Beautification Committee, is to be held at 7:30 P.M. Feb. 27 at the White Plains Public Library, at 100 Martine Avenue. For more information, call 285-2652.

title: Published Report Says Giants Tested for Drugs
description: The Giants have conducted regular urinalysis tests on players suspected of using illegal drugs or alcohol, a practice that violates the bargaining agreement between National Footbal League owners and the players union, according to a published report.

title: Carrier Completes Sea Trial
description: The aircraft carrier Forrestal cruised into the Philadelphia Naval Shipyard on Friday after successfully completing the first of two sea trials in a $750 million overhaul, Navy officials said. The 25-year-old carrier began a program of repairs in January 1983 designed to add 15 years to her active life. A second outing is scheduled for April.

title: HELPING TENANTS HELP THEMSELVES
description: LAST summer, the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development agreed to spend nearly $6 million to renovate two low-income housing projects in Glen Cove.

title: Pennsylvania Cuts Payments From Medicaid for Abortions
description: After more than four years of litigation, a Pennsylvania law took effect Friday prohibiting the state's medical assistance program from paying for most abortions for poor women.

title: HELEN FRANKENTHALER - FROM STUDIO TO BALLET STAGE
description: Helen Frankenthaler surveyed the wide expanse of her newly painted studio floor and exulted, ''For the past few months it's looked like the backstage of Covent Garden. Now it's my own again.''

title: GROUP AIDING EX-CONVICTS BEGINS RUNNING A JAIL
description: Volunteers of America, which has long operated halfway houses for released prisoners, is now embarking upon an experiment in this suburb of St. Paul. It is operating a jail.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN NEW ORLEANS
description: New Orleans accepts disaster with equanimity. The financial disarray of the 1984 World's Fair, ending last fall in bankruptcy, has already been dissipated by the spurt of development, accelerated by the exposition.

title: CATHEDRALS OF CONSUMPTION
description: THE MALLING OF AMERICA

title:
THE PRODUCTIVITY CHALLENGE;

A FAR BROADER APPROACH IS NECESSARY
description: DO the recent higher United States productivity numbers herald a new era of sustained productivity growth? Economists and other experts are embroiled in controversy over the question.

title: LLOYD LOSES FINAL TO NAVRATILOVA
description: For the woman who has won everything, challenges sometimes have to be a bit contrived. Thus, Martina Navratilova set out today to prove that her loss to Chris Evert Lloyd three weeks ago in Key Biscayne was an aberration, a mis-hit in a string of winners that had enabled her to surpass her friend and rival and become the dominant player in the world.

title: THE NUCLEAR ARMS RACE EXAMINED IN A COLUMBIA CLASSROOM
description: Before Dr. Lynn Sykes could get very far in introducing course C3003y at Columbia College last month, a student raised his hand. ''How much of the course is involved with technological data,'' the student asked, ''and how much on understanding the reasons - the way to get ourselves out of this?''

title: 13 Treated in Newark For Exposure to Smoke
description: Thirteen people were treated for possible exposure to PCB-contaminated smoke today after a transformer containing the suspected carcinogen caught fire and caused a temporary power failure at University Hospital here, officials said.

title: Article 033442 -- No Title
description: Frank A. Messina of Centerville, whose driver's license was suspended 10 years ago, has filed a lawsuit for $5 quadrillion - $5 million billion, that is - against the Pennsylvania Transportation Department, saying the punishment prevented him from getting a job and ruined his reputation. The $5,764,609,563,143,700.48 lawsuit would ''wipe out the whole State of Pennsylvania,'' said Laverna Fountain, a Transportation Department spokesman. She said Friday the department was studying the suit.

title: Soviet Bobsled Leading European Title Event
description: Sintis Ekmanis, steering the No. 1 Soviet sled, twice posted record- shattering times today to take the lead after the first day of the European two-man bobsled championships.

title: Blackburn Leads by 1
description: Woody Blackburn, a struggling veteran who lost his PGA Tour card and had to requalify to play this year, fired a 6-under-par 66 today to take a one-stroke lead into the final round of the Isuzu-Andy Williams San Diego Open.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: WALTER. By David Cook. (Overlook Press, $15.95.)

title: NEIGHBORHOOD FIGHTS SHELTER
description: ''SOMETIMES in my more frustrated moments,'' Sister Evelyn Avoglia said with a sigh, ''I wish a tugboat could push us out into the harbor where nobody would bother us.''

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: STRATEGIC STALEMATE: Nuclear Weapons and Arms Control in American Politics. By Michael Krepon. (Council on Foreign Relations/St. Martin's $25.

title: Easing the Trauma at Schools for Tots
description: To the Editor:

title: A TARNISHED IMAGE AT BANK OF BOSTON
description: The Mystery Deepens.

title: SINCLAIR LEWIS RECALLED IN GROLIER CLUB DISPLAY
description: The two, sometimes clashing, sides of Sinclair Lewis - the man and the craftsman - can be seen in a major exhibition of his life and career that is open to the public now through March 30 at the Grolier Club, 47 East 60th Street.

title: DIVISIONS BESET L.I.U. AS PRESIDENT RESIGNS
description: LIFE at Long Island University has not been simple the last few years. Faculty members say that many factors - including faculty strikes on the Brooklyn campus, a breakdown in faculty-trustee-administration communication, a deficit in 1983 after years of surpluses, an identity crisis and an unresponsive board of trustees - have contributed to deep divisions on the three main campuses.

title: No Headline
description: The Treatment Of Animals Amazing. In one statement, a court-appointed receiver, Helen Rosenblum, has swept away the valid reasons behind her presence at the Hampton Animal Shelter. In the article ''Animal Shelter Reprieve'' (Jan. 20), she is quoted: ''It's a fact that most of these animals would be dead if it wasn't for Mrs. Videla. Whether they'd be better off dead, I don't know. Certain humane groups seem to think so. I haven't reached a decision on that yet. I'm not comfortable with the prospect of euthanasia.''

title: Queens Ironworker Charged In Shooting Death of His Wife
description: A 52-year-old ironworker, apparently despondent over failing health and ''years of marital discord,'' killed his wife in their Queens apartment early yesterday, then held the police at bay for nearly two hours before surrendering, the police said.

title: ELIZABETH'S RX FOR ITS HOUSING
description: ELIZABETH, which has more than its

title: No Headline
description: Looking Back At Executive Race I was somewhat taken aback by the cavalier way in which Frank Lynn, who I consider the dean of Nassau County political reporters, dealt with the three-way Republican primary fight for Nassau County Executive in 1977, involving myself, as the incumbent County Executive, Francis T. Purcell and John R. Dunne (''Dunne's New Post: A Turning Point,'' Politics column, Jan. 27).

title: STATE BACKS HOLOCAUST COURSE
description: TEACHERS throughout New Jersey are being trained in a new program designed to make students aware of the Holocaust.

title: Canada Reviews Relations
description: The Government's voluntary code of conduct for Canadian companies operating in South Africa is being reviewed along with all other aspects of bilateral relations, External Affairs Minister Joe Clark said Friday.

title: HOMES OR SALAMANDERS?
description: THE Eastern tiger salamander is a creature in search of habitat. Descended from the amphibians that dominated life on earth some 345 million years ago, the salamander is now an endangered species, threatened by an ever less habitable world.

title: FOR MICK JAGGER, LIFE AS A SOLOIST BEGINS AT 41
description: One of the fascinations of following Mick Jagger's life and times is the spectacle of rock music's most enduring symbol of voluptuary chic defying gravity year after year. At 41, the Rolling Stones's lead singer can still get away with acting like an insolent Pan pirouetting on a tightwire and flashing come-hither glances designed to inflame every conceivable fantasy. In his impeccably fashionable first solo album, ''She's the Boss'' (Columbia OC 39940), Mr. Jagger is still a kinetic vocal wonder, both leonine and funny, but the lion seems more like a clown than a noble beast. ''She's the Boss'' tantalizes, taunts and puts us on with a dance-oriented set of songs that portray love as a seedy high stakes casino game - a series of comic ploys and bluffs set in a Bohemian high society that Mr. Jagger more than any other rock star has come to represent.

title: Child-Abuse And Children'sCredibility
description: Accusations of sexual abuse of children by a ring of adults made front-page headlines around the country last year, when 24 people in Jordan, Minn. were charged with abusing their own and other people's children, and 27 children were removed from their homes. One man pleaded guilty, but the only couple brought to trial was acquitted. In October, the Scott County attorney, R. Kathleen Morris, dismissed the remaining charges with the explanation that she did not want to release confidential documents involving a murder investigation or submit the children to the emotional stress of testifying in the remaining trials.

title: WHEN MOTHER VENTURED FORTH ALONE
description: PHYLLIS THEROUX lives in Washington.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM DISNEY TO MUSSORGSKY'S 'BORIS'
description: The Empire Strikes Back Starring Mark Hamill, Harrison Ford, Carrie Fisher, Billy Dee Williams, Alec Guinness, and the voice of James Earl Jones; directed by Irvin Kershner, 1980 CBS/Fox Video 124 minutes. $79.98

title: Murcer Dropped
description: Bobby Murcer, the former Yankee slugger who thought he had found a home in the broadcast booth after he left the playing field during the 1983 season, lost his assignment as a Yankee commentator yesterday when it was announced that

title: Some Thoughts At College Level
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A CORRESPONDENT SLIPS HIS CHAINS IN LEBANON
description: NOW four American hostages remain in the hands of Moslem terrorists in Lebanon. A fifth, Jeremy Levin, the 51-year-old Beirut correspondent of the Cable News Network, removed his chains last week and walked through a starry night to his freedom.

title: POWER, GREED AND GLORY ON WALL STREET: THE FALL OF THE LEHMAN BROTHERS
description: FOR YEARS THE RESENTMENT HAD been building. And now, at lunch, it began to erupt. Lewis Glucksman, the co-chief executive officer of Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb, a short, rumpled man with the face of a Russian general, who was disparaged by Wall Street blue bloods as a lowly ''trader,'' Lew Glucksman would leave the lunch table determined to remove Peter G. Peterson, his imperious co-C.E.O. at the venerable investment banking house, from his job. The luncheon took place on July 12, 1983, and the fallout from the explosion it triggered carried the story from the business pages to the front pages.

title: ON THE DECLINE AND DEMISE OF PROFESSIONAL SOCCER
description: IT hurts to say it, but the North

title: Gael Simonson to Marry John Lundeen
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Gordon Simonson of Northfield, Minn., of the engagement of their daughter Gael Barbara Simonson to John Anton Lundeen, a son of the Rev. and Mrs. Joel W. Lundeen of Grand Forks, N.D., formerly of Chicago.

title: Posh London
description: To the Editor:

title: NIMEIRY MAY BE HIS OWN WORST ENEMY
description: The forces of nature and politics have been dealing harshly with President Gaafar al- Nimeiry, posing difficult choices for the United States, a strong supporter of his 15-year-old Government. On almost every front, prospects for Sudan, Africa's largest country and one of the world's poorest, seem bleak.

title: Polluter Purchases Ad to Tell Of Its Illegal Toxic Dumping
description: A company prosecuted for illegally dumping toxic wastes has taken out a full- page newspaper advertisement as part of its punishment.

title: OUT OF THE COLDEST COLD
description: BREAKING WITH MOSCOW

title: USING SWEET WINE ENHANCES DISHES
description: MOST of the time, when wine is called for in cooking, the directions specify dry white or dry red wine, meaning a wine with no residual sugar to sweeten the flavor. The general exception to this, of course, is dessert cookery. Dry wines can be fruity or crisp and austere, light or heavy.

title: NEW & NOTEWORTHY
description: FAMILY PORTRAIT WITH FIDEL, by Carlos Franqui. (Vintage, $5.95.) A disillusioned Cuban revolutionary, Carlos Franqui, recalls Fidel and Raul Castro, Che Guevara, Camilo Cienfuegos and other revolutionary figures in their Sierra Maestra days and during intrigues and factional struggles once in power. Jonathan Kandell commented here last year that ''Family Portrait with Fidel,'' translated by Alfred MacAdam, offers many memorable anecdotes. And, he said, ''rarely has the Cuban Revolution undergone a critique from a left-wing perspective.''

title: THE CASE OF THE 'RELUCTANT SPY'
description: ON FRIDAY, Dec. 5, 1975, while I was Ambassador to the United Nations, a member of the United States Mission to the United Nations asked to see me in my office. He closed the door and reported that Arkady Nikolaevich Shevchenko, Under Secretary General of the United Nations, had told an American in the Secretariat that he wished to defect.

title: Data Update
description: * Rates on most adjustable mortgages are set 1 to 3 percentage points above these indexes.

title: Miss Graham To Be Bride In the Spring
description: Mr. and Mrs. David Kraus of New York have announced the engagement of Mrs. Kraus's daughter, Leslie Beth Graham, to Andrew Lawrence Farkas, a son of Robin Lewis Farkas of New York and the late Suzanne Gold Farkas. A May wedding is planned.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;

VEGETABLE WARFARE: THE UNTHINKABLE ALTERNATIVE
description: WEAPONRY is the topic of the day. People are looking for ways to defend our country but not blow up the world in doing so. Recently the idea of using tomatoes as weapons instead of guns and bombs was introduced to me. After much thought, I have come to the conclusion that using tomatoes as weapons would be both ridiculous and ineffective.

title: BY BUS AND TRUCK WITH CITY OPERA
description: On Saturday night,the New York City Opera's national touring company pay its first visit to its own home town, performing Verdi's ''Rigoletto'' in the BCBC series at Brooklyn College's Walt Whitman Hall. The touring company was founded by Beverly Sills in 1979, with the promise of providing talented young American artists with performing experience.

title: NEW YORK'S NEXT MODERN MUSEUM IS ON THE WAY
description: As of the fall of 1986, if all goes well, Manhattan will have its fourth major museum of modern art. Apart from the Museum of Modern Art itself, which is of course the father and mother of all such institutions, it already has the Guggenheim Museum, which long ago broke free of the restraints indicated in its original name (the Museum of Non-Objective Art). It also has the Whitney Museum of American Art, with its midtown and downtown annexes, together with the New Museum in SoHo and the promised private museum of recent art which Edward Broida, a Californian enthusiast, will shortly sponsor in that same part of town.

title: 3 Ex-Yankees Face Spring Uncertain of Their Futures
description: THE baeball romantics, those fans who ignore the real-world realities that have catapulted the game into another dimension - view spring as a time for rebirth and regeneration. The disabling aches have healed, the poor performances have been forgotten, everybody starts out even. For some players, though, the reality of the present and the future creates a different perspective. For a handful of players who passed through Yankee Stadium for varying periods, the scent in the air is not renewal but uncertainty, the uncertainty of a spring that follows an unstable season.

title: AGAINST THE GRAIN Kernel Knowledge What could be more harmless than throwing rice at newlyweds? This innocent custom started centuries ago in China, where rice is a symbol of fertility. Last week a member of the Connecticut Legislature dared to suggest that the custom be outlawed. Representative Mae Schmidle's bill would make it illegal to ''throw, fling, cast or hurl'' uncooked rice at ''nuptial affairs,'' with a $50 fine for violators. Her complaint is with instant rice. When cooked, it swells up from absorbing the water it's boiled in. But uncooked, which is the way it's usually thrown, it can swell up inside a bird that eats it off the church steps and, she says, the bird dies.
description: A Connecticut Audubon ornithologist says he's not aware of any birds having come to grief from feasting on instant rice after weddings.

title: Lizbeth Hoefer To Wed in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. James Burns Hoefer of Bronxville, N.Y., and Charlestown, R.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lizbeth Hoefer, to Cristofer G. Nauta, the son of Walter Nauta of Chester Springs, Pa., and the late Jill Jones Nauta. A June wedding is planned.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM DISNEY TO MUSSORGSKY'S 'BORIS'
description: Robin Hood Walt Disney Productions 83 minutes. $79.95

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER/BRUSH TO PAPER
description: PLEASANTVILLE WHEN Walter Hahn was in the Navy, he was stationed aboard an air-sea rescue craft patroling the Florida coast. ''The crew wanted me to paint something on the boat,'' he recalled recently. ''Because its tail was always draggin' they said, paint us a dragon. I went back to the base in Jacksonville, and found a couple of books on Chinese art. It was a revelation. I was so fascinated by what I found, I read everything the library had.''

title: BILL TO CURB 'HAPPY HOURS' AT BARS AROUSES DEBATE
description: Legislation to limit ''happy hours'' at bars around New York State is needed to control alcohol abuse and drunken driving, proponents of the bill said at a hearing in Manhattan. Critics, however, labeled the measure unnecessary and unenforceable.

title: PLAY READINGS PRESENTED FOR FREE
description: THIS winter the Hartford Stage Company is offering theatergoers a chance to peek behind the scenes in a series of one-act play readings, theater tours and works-in-progress.

title: Deborah R. Kase To Marry in May
description: Dr. and Mrs. Nathan G. Kase of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter Deborah Ruth Kase to Jonathan Henry Lillian, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Marvin Lillian of Woodbridge, Conn. A May wedding is planned.

title: Gamblers Top Stallions; TV Replay Used Again
description: Jim Kelly completed 15 of 24 passes for 156 yards and one touchdown tonight as the Houston Gamblers defeated the Birmingham Stallions, 20-10, in a United States Football League preseason game.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM DISNEY TO MUSSORGSKY'S 'BORIS'
description: Boris Godunov Featuring Alexander Pirogov and other singers of the Bolshoi Opera Corinth Video 105 minutes. $69.95

description: JERSEY CITY

title: Manolis Paterakis Weds Lucie Warner Broadbent
description: Lucie Warner Broadbent, a daughter of Janet Geraci Broadbent of Hamden, Conn., and the late Robert Benjamin Broadbent, and Manolis Nikolaou Paterakis, a son of Mrs. Nikolaos E. Paterakis of Athens and the late Mr. Paterakis, were married yesterday. The Rev. M. Ronald Chrisner performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in New Haven.

title: Long Shooter Hits Again HUNTINGTON, W. Va., Feb. 16 (AP) - Bruce Morris, who last
description: week hit a field goal from 89 feet 10 inches for the longest shot in basketball history, sank a 22-foot jump shot at the buzzer today to give

title: TWIN PEAKS OF THE BAROQUE
description: Great composers and their music inevitably become icons, so easily worshiped that it can take a leap of imagination to see past the image and glimpse the reality, the miracle of the musical achievement itself. Handel and Bach, those twin peaks of the Baroque, sum up the problem. A few of their better works have become hardly more than venerated relics, so continually and so reverently kissed for three centuries that they have been rubbed smooth. The outline of the work is there for us, but its meaning or meanings tend to fade.

title: BEYOND BOOKS: INNOVATIONS EXPAND SCOPE OF LIBRRIES
description: RYE ALLISON TERHUNE is 2 years old. ''She can't say the word computer yet,'' her mother, Patty, said the other day in the Rye Free Reading Room, ''but she can count every number that's up there.''

title: Welfare for Pets
description: When Animal Charity opened a bread line for needy pets in Youngstown, Ohio, in late 1982, up to 500 pet owners queued up at the organization's headquarters for free food. This led to a ''means test'' last year under which owners who could afford it were asked to pay part of the cost.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: All First Quality And Discounted Merri Jean was established near Gun Hill Road in The Bronx 18 years ago and added a second shop under the same name last September on Central Park Avenue (where Scarsdale meets the town of Greenburgh) with discounted first-quality women's clothes from cruisewear to coats, from major designers and manufacturers.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: STRATFORD
description: IF you want something to eat in Stratford, Conn., you can try the Shakespeare Arms Restaurant or, for more informal fare, Shakespeare Apizza. If your puppy takes ill, the Shakespeare Veterinary Hospital will be happy to tend to it. And if you want to get away for a while, the Shakespeare Travel Center offers vacation advice.

title: 3 Filipino Soldiers Accused Of Killing General's Nephew
description: Three Philippine soldiers were charged today with kidnapping and murdering the nephew of a general accused of involvement in the killing of the opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr.

title: ROCK: JOAN JETT AND THE BLACKHEARTS
description: It would be absurd to pretend that Joan Jett, who with her Blackhearts band appeared for the first of two shows Friday night at the Beacon Theater, represents some startlingly original or even compellingly distinctive epitome of rock-and-roll.

title: Q&A
description: Question:

title: ;   To Raise Consciousnesses About Fat
description: To the Editor:

title: WHEN TH SITE TESTS THE DESIGNER
description: For all that architects are typed, like Howard Roark, as the triumphant and independent makers of a new world, it is frequently true that their really creative moments come not when they design on a blank slate but when they accommodate to existing realities. Indeed, this is often the real test of design talent: almost anybody can make a design in a vacuum, a building that has nothing to do with the realities of a piece of land, an existing building, or a budget. But only the most skillful can make architecture out of situations in which existing conditions sharply limit their options.

title: JERSEY TO COMBAT RADIATION THREAT
description: The first phase of a program to rid nearly 100 homes in suburban Essex County of the radioactive gas radon will begin this spring, end by the fall and require the temporary relocation of several families, according to a state official.

title: FINANCIER NURTURES YOUTHS' DREAMS
description: Eugene M. Lang, an industrialist and philanthropist, moves easily in two worlds. Weekdays, he heads a prosperous business that finances high-technology ventures here and abroad. But Saturdays, he says, belong to his students - a group of teen-agers from East Harlem he encourages with scholarships and personal advice to strive for a college education.

title: HOW AN ACTOR MADE HIMSELF INTO THE VILLAIN EVERYONE LOVES TO HATE
description: During the British television showing of ''The Jewel in the Crown,'' a woman accosted Tim Pigott-Smith in a London street. Brandishing a menacing umbrella at him, she cried ''If you owned a restaurant, I'd come and poison the food.'' This somewhat obscure threat was prompted by the actor's deeply-felt portrayal of Ronald Merrick, the sadistic Police Superintendent whose persecution of the Anglo-Indian Hari Kumar triggers a chain of tragic events in the 14-part Granada series currently enjoying great success on American public-TV's ''Masterpiece Theater.''

title: GREAT FALLS IN THE SPOTLIGHT AT AN EXHIBITION IN WAYNE
description: WAYNE

title: Women's Vote Effort Lauded
description: Despite the defeat of the first woman to run for Vice President on a major party's ticket, women's leaders declared Friday that they won a big victory in 1984 with millions of women registering and voting for the first time.

title: HOLLYWOOD VIRTUE, HOLLYWOOD VICE
description: ''Hollywood Wives'' is what it is - a big, slightly rancid plum pudding. It does not mean to be ''Masterpiece Theater,'' and it would not be nearly as good if it did. It is not the kind of production you recommend to friends, either. On the other hand, you don't have to recommend it; everyone watches stuff like this, anyway, and then pretends they haven't seen it. ''Hollywood Wives'' confirms our prejudices. It deals in consumerism, prurience and Puritanism, and Puritanism comes out a clear winner. Moral Majoritarians complain about television productions like this, but when they do they miss the point. The sex in ''Hollywood Wives'' - mostly implied, seldom consummated - is not pleasurable, and it is practiced only by driven, unhappy people. It's no fun. Increase and Cotton Mather preached sermons in old Boston that said sex was that way, too.

title: MUSIC: DEBUTS IN REVIEW
description: The splendid concert of the ''Trio Sonnerie'' last Sunday at Corpus Christi Church was technically a debut, in that Monica Huggett (violin), Sarah Cunningham (viola da gamba) and Mitzi Meyerson (harpsichord) were making their first appearance as a formal ensemble. But all three (and particularly Miss Huggett) are familiar to those who follow the original-instrument revival.

title: SUBSIDIZING READINESS, NOT RETIREMENT
description: PERIODICALLY, someone pops up with the startling discovery that military pensions are more generous than private retirement plans. This is trumpeted as a scandal, a national disgrace or worse, and the call goes out for reform.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: MACHINERY IN ART

title: REPUTED MOB LEADER IS JAILED WITHOUT BAIL
description: Carmine Persico, the reputed head of the Colombo crime group, was arraigned in Federal court yesterday and sent back to jail.

title: Arbitrage
description: To the Editor:

title: CLASSICAL COMPOSER WITH A PASSION FOR JAZZ
description: Leslie Kandell writes frequently on musical subjects.

title: NEW CASSETTES: FROM DISNEY TO MUSSORGSKY'S 'BORIS'
description: The Roman Spring of Mrs. Stone Featuring Vivien Leigh, Warren Beatty, Lotte Lenya, Jill St. John, Coral Browne; directed by Jose Quintero, 1961 Warner Home Video 104 minutes. $59.95

title: L.I.R.R. Head Voices Pessimism on Talks
description: The acting head of the Long Island Rail Road has said he is ''not optimistic'' about reaching a settlement with the railroad's supervisors and middle-level managers in time to avert a strike this week.

title: Mochary Sequel
description: While Mary V. Mochary was campaigning in New Jersey last fall as the unsuccessful Republican candidate for United States Senator, her husband, Stephen E. Mochary, was in California awaiting a heart transplant at the Stanford Medical Center. Mrs. Mochary joined him the day after Election Day, and Mr. Mochary, a 44-year-old lawyer, received the transplant on Nov. 12.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: NEAR OCCASION OF SIN

title: RERUNS OF A HAPPY LIFE
description: A CLOAK OF LIGHT Writing My Life. By Wright Morris. Illustrated. 306 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $19.95.

title: IN EUROPE, IT'S TIME TO BUY
description: ERICA BROWN is a writer based in London.

title: 23 FOOD OUTLETS LISTED FOR HEALTH VIOLATIONS
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 23 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: Getting TougherOn South Africa
description: The campaign for American colleges to break financial ties with South Africa bore fruit last week when two leading universities announced strong actions regarding two companies doing business in that country.

title: 'TROVATORE' RAISES THE ISSUE OF CONDUCTOR AS HERO
description: The new ''Trovatore'' conducted by Carlo Maria Giulini (Deutsche Grammophon 413 355 2, three CD's, also available on LP) is good, as Italian opera recordings go these days - which isn't good enough.

title: Newhouse WantsThe New Yorker
description: The talk of the town's publishing circles last week was the bid by the Newhouse chain to buy The New Yorker magazine. Samuel I. Newhouse Jr., whose company owns Vogue, Mademoiselle and 22 newspapers, offered to pay $180 a share for The New Yorker Magazine Inc.

title: HONDURAN GIRL LEAVES HOSPITAL
description: HARTFORD

title: New DisclosuresOn Boston Bank
description: The Bank of Boston, for two centuries a symbol to many New Englanders of stability and integrity, spent an unsettled week as the subject of debate among politicians, regulators and former employees on the role of financial institutions in laundering cash for mobsters.

title:
CABLE TV NOTES;

FOR A CHANGE, A SAMPLE OF THE OFFBEAT
description: The charge has been made that cable has lost its way. From within the cable industry and without, sometimes in sorrow and sometimes in anger, observers have contended that cable has fallen from its early promise to provide viewers with real alternatives to broadcast television, and has slumped into purposeless imitation of the broadcast networks that it had set out to supplement.

title: Honor for Moses As a previous winner of the Sullivan Award,
description: Edwin Moses, the hurdler who was voted the nation's outstanding amateur athlete for 1983, is ineligible for the 1984 award. But after his recent ordeal in successfully defending his reputation against a criminal charge of soliciting a prostitute, the award committee decided he could use another vote of confidence.

title: Walesa Is Challenging Poland to Arrest Him
description: Lech Walesa, the Solidarity founder, dared the authorities today to arrest him, and he urged workers to take part in a 15- minute work stoppage this month.

title: FRANCIS L. FILAS
description: The Rev. Francis L. Filas, a leading researcher of the Shroud of Turin, a burial cloth believed to bear the image of Jesus Christ, died Friday night of a heart attack.

title: BARE SHOULDERS
description: The strapless dress is back. More bare-shoulder styles were presented in the recent French couture openings for spring and summer than since the 1950's.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: EIGHT Nassau County libraries that are participating in a federally financed project are seeking volunteers, aged 55 and over, to be trained to provide information services to community residents.

title: THE GREAT GRETZKY, IN PERSPECTIVE
description: On the Oiler bench, Wayne Gretzky was laughing. Not smiling, laughing. The most prolific and most precocious scorer in National Hockey League history had provided the Edmonton Oilers with a 1-0 lead over the Rangers early in the first period Friday night. And when he returned to the Oiler bench at Madison Square Garden, he could be seen laughing as he looked around at his teammates.

title: TEAM PLAYER FUELS NEW SPIRIT
description: FOUR weeks have passed since St. John's went to Georgetown and snatched a victory and the No. 1 ranking from the defending national champions.

title:
DINING OUT;

ON RINGING IN THE YEAR OF THE OX
description: THE Chinese New Year is upon us and, short of joining a parade, what better way to ring in the Year of the Ox than to visit a Chinese restaurant? At some of the Chinese restaurants around the state, patrons can telephone ahead to arrange a festive banquet of specially prepared dishes.

title: AGED GET FREE AID ON 1040'S
description: BETWEEN now and April 15, 3,000 elderly people in Bergen County will receive expert volunteer help in preparing their income-tax returns.

title: Devine in Hall
description: Dan Devine, who coached Missouri to an unbeaten season in 1960 and Notre Dame to a the top national ranking in 1977, has been named to the National Football Foundation's College Football Hall of Fame, along with the late Andy Gustafson, who began his coaching career with Virginia Tech in 1926 and ended it with the Miami Hurricanes in 1963. Devine will be inducted at the foundation's annual awards dinner in New York next Dec. 3 and Gustafson will be honored at a ceremony on the Miami campus this fall.

title:
NUMISMATICS;

SALE OF RARE 1913 NICKEL HIGHLIGHTS AUCTION
description: A 1913 Liberty Head nickel, one of five examples known, brought $385,000 to highlight the year's biggest coin auction. The sale took place Jan. 28-30 in West Hollywood, Calif., and featured the collection of Dr. Jerry Buss, a well-known West Coast real estate magnate and sports entrepreneur.

title: BUSH TONES UP HIS ACT BY TUNING IT DOWN
description: In American politics, it's come to be something of a tradition that a campaigning President sticks to the high ground, leaving the partisan trench warfare to his running mate. Not surprisingly, by Election Day last year Vice President Bush was up to his brightly colored watch bands in controversies involving, among other things, several well-publicized gaffes, a high-pitched campaign style and frequently strained relations with the press.

title: 'Underground' Writers
description: To the Editor:

title: HOME WAS A HOUSE DIVIDED
description: IN SEARCH OF A PAST

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN BEHARVIORAL TRAINING;

HELPING MANAGERS TRAIN THEMSELVES
description: WHEN the last recession hit, one of the first things to get slashed from corporate budgets was travel expenses. Training companies that lived on seminar revenues found themselves starving.

title: Five Youths Hurt by Gunfire After Coast Chinese Carnival
description: Four youths and an 11-year-old boy were hospitalized after being sprayed with gunfire from a passing vehicle after a Chinese New Year carnival Friday in Chinatown. The incident came after a dispute between the victims and members of a gang, the police said.

title: POLITICAL QUERIES BY JUDGE ASSAILED
description: A Federal district judge has come under criticism for asking prospective jurors their political affiliations in a case where political considerations are a key element.

title: 220 ASPIRANTS EXAMINE ART OF THE HEART
description: The setting: Just one week before Valentine's Day. Inside the White Plains Galleria, a refuge from the 16- degree temperature and the blanket of ice and snow that chills that suburban community.

title: Columbia Beaten By Harvard, 59-56
description: Harvard, the No. 1 free-throw shooting team in Division I of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, converted of 15 of 18 attempts last night to hold off Columbia, 59-56, in an Ivy League game at Levien Gymnasium. Joe Carrabino, who paced the Crimson with a game-high 17 points, converted 4 free throws in the final 32 seconds. Harvard (14-4, 6-2) is tied for second place in the league with Cornell, a half-game behind Penn. Columbia (8-12, 4-4) has lost four of its last five games.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of incorrect information supplied, the total number of nights spent ashore in hotels before and after a five-day Yangtze River journey offered by Lindblad Travel on the ship Bashan was misstated in last Sunday's cruise listings. The correct number is 15.

title: Students Contest Searches
description: Two assistant principals will be disciplined for violated school policy by searching 10 students at Lincoln Junior High School after a classmate reported $20 missing.

title: MANY IN THE COUNTY ARE TURNING TO MUSIC LESSONS AS ADULTS
description: STIRRED by deep longings or the desire to conquer, many adults in the county with little or no background in music are engaged in the serious study of a musical instrument. They brave the fear of their family's reaction as well as the humbling of their own egos to seek out a teacher and commit themselves to lessons, some as early as 7:15 A.M. They find time to practice, before work, after work or in brief snatches during the day, enduring comparisons with their more technically proficient, less self-conscious children.

title: MICHIGAN WINS ON LAST SHOT
description: Butch Wade made only one field goal for Michigan today, and he did not think he would get a chance at that one. A pass from Gary Grant surprised Wade, who momentarily fumbled the ball, then rose to the rim to lay it in with 16 seconds left to give the Wolverines a 66-64 Big Ten Conference victory over Minnesota.

title: FRANK BORMAN'S MOST DIFFICULT DAYS
description: MIAMI FOR a man who heads an airline, Frank Borman is the ultimate pilot. His celestial exploits are legendary: America remembers how he read from the Bible on Christmas Eve as he commanded the first manned orbit of the moon. Since then, Mr. Borman's sights have become more terrestrial. For nearly a decade, he has headed chronically troubled Eastern Air Lines, the nation's third-largest carrier. But, in that time, Mr. Borman has failed to break the cycle of crisis that continues to haunt Eastern and has steered the airline dangerously close to financial disaster.

title: A June Wedding For Abby Weiss
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Jack Weiss of Bay Shore, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Abby Helaine Weiss, to Richard Winslow O'Neill 2d of New York and Clermont, N.Y., the son of Dr. Barbara Powell of Rowayton, Conn., and the late Richard O'Neill. A June wedding is planned.

title: THOUGHTS ON REWRITING 'ECONOMICS'
description: ''LET others write a nation's laws if I can write its textbooks.'' These words were not written completely in jest. Textbooks reflect the state of a science. They also help shape the development of a science, and indeed of a nation.

title: Record 43,816 See 76ers Beat Pistons
description: Moses Malone scored 33 points and Julius Erving added 29 as the Philadelphia 76ers beat the Detroit Pistons, 125-114, tonight before the largest crowd in National Basketball Association history.

title: V.A. Hospital in Miami Cleared in Heart Surgery
description: A medical team investigating reports of high death rates among heart surgery patients at Miami's Veterans Administration Hospital has cleared the hospital and the quality of its care, the V.A. said Friday.

title: NEW AID FOR EPILEPSY VICTIMS
description: ''CAN you imagine what it's like to begin each day with the knowledge that somewhere in the course of your travels, you may fall down abruptly, make distorted involuntary movements, become incontinent and not be able to do a thing about it?'' The question is from Ira Brody, executive vice president and member of the board of directors of the Epilepsy Institute.

title: LESSONS FROM '84 U.S. HOCKEY TEAM
description: IT has been almost a year since the

title: INQUIRIES SCHEDULED IN OIL SPILL
description: STATE environmentalists and Coast Guard officials say that the cooperation of nature and fast action by cleanup crews helped to avert a major environmental disaster last week when 225,000 gallons of oil leaked from a Long Island Lighting Company storage tank at Island Park.

title: Why the Deficit Is No Straw Wolf The deficit disaster: Is it all a cry of wolf, a figment of fear, like killer bees heading north? Is it a bearable modern malady, like jet lag? Or is it a real danger, as palpable as the oil shocks that rocked the economy in 1974 and 1979?
description: Professional economists, conservative and liberal, have been talking of a disaster in the making. But while they've talked, America's economy has boomed, inflation has abated and foreigners have given their vote of confidence by investing hundreds of billions in American securities. And while Americans say they worry about deficits, they gave an overwhelming vote of confidence to a President who says he hates deficits yet who has doubled the national debt.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: CHOICES. By Liv Ullmann. (Knopf, $14.95)

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: ON TO THE YALU.By Edwin P. Hoyt. (Stein & Day, $19.95.)

title: Beaucoons Of Words
description: Jim Wayne Miller is quick to admit that he grew up in Appalachia, owns up to South Turkey and Sandy Mush Creeks, but neglects to mention that these are situated in or very near Buncombe County (''Beaucoons of Words,'' On Language, Jan. 13).

title: Psychology and German Society
description: To the Editor:

title: DETERIORATION THREATENS CITY'S HOUSING
description: ''LITTLE preventive maintenance is being done in New York and it is a very big problem,'' said Richard L. Koral, secretary-treasurer of the Apartment House Institute, a school for building owners, managers and superintendents at the New York Technical College of the City University of New York.

title:
INVESTING;

HOW LIKELY IS A MARKET CORRECTION?
description: STOCK markets almost never go up in a straight line. Rallies are interrupted by ''corrections'' of varying magnitudes, where the market gives back some of the recent gains and then takes off again. And when the Dow Jones industrial average fell almost 14 points last Monday and then 10 points on Thursday, some investors wondered whether the stock market, which has rallied strongly for almost five consecutive weeks, was beginning its correction.

title: Kate Knapp Johnson, a Poet, Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Broaddus Johnson Jr. of Bedford, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kate Knapp Johnson, to the Rev. Douglas Stephen Phillips, the associate minister of the Presbyterian Church of Mount Kisco, N.Y. He is a son of Jeanne N. Phillips of Sunbury, Pa., and Gail W. Phillips of Van Nuys, Calif. A June wedding is planned.

title: CONTROL DATA'S FALL FROM GRACE
description: MINNEAPOLIS

title: KEYS OFFICIALS FOR JAMAICA OFTEN WOMEN
description: Edward P. G. Seaga, the serious, almost stern Prime Minister of Jamaica, has a pragmatic appreciation for women.

title: Feb. 17, 1985
description: Fiction

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: MARGARET GEFFKEN, ''65 and going strong,'' is a prime example of what her work is all about. She is executive director of New Jersey's R.S.V.P. (Retired Senior Volunteer Program), based in Trenton.

title: BEAUCOONS OF WORDS
description: Rather than reflecting a spirit of individualism, the inability of southern Appalachian people to express themselves with other than local colloquialisms stems from a lack of education.

title: WHEN A YOUNG PRO SEES ONLY FROM BASELINE TO NET
description: DELRAY BEACH, Fla.

title: Nina C. Wormser Wed To Dr. Stephen Cook
description: Nina Carolyn Wormser, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Mailert Wormser of New York and Stonington, Conn., was married in New York yesterday to Dr. Stephen Standish Cook, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Cook of Kingston, N.J. The Rev. Gary Fertig, assisted by the Rev. John Andrew, performed the ceremony at St. Thomas Episcopal Church.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: AROUND THEW WORLD IN EIGHT DAYS. By Ron Kovic. (City Lights. Cloth, $12.95. Paper, $5.95.)

title: IF THE NEW ZEALAND SYNDROME SPREADS
description: Tiny New Zealand wants to make itself into a nuclear-free zone. Whether or not it actually does so, the issue is far broader than New Zealand: this raises the general question of who we should offer nuclear protection, and under what conditions.

title: DISHES WITH AN EYE APPEAL
description: THE Pink Flamingo has flown and in its place in Norwalk is a new restaurant called Penfield's. In point of fact, the bird has not flown very far. The decor has changed from the 1930's Art Deco style to a spartan, stripped-down look that is unobtrusive, but somewhat devoid of personality. Yet to menu watchers, Penfield's still looks like its previous occupant, with the familiar entree, cappellini with three sauces in the red (marinara), green (pesto) and white (cream) colors of the Italian flag.

title: CUOMO SEES LARGER ROLE FOR DEMOCRATIC GOVERNORS
description: Governors are going to be more and more important in shaping the future of the Democratic Party, Governor Cuomo told 25 attentive Yale University students over a breakfast of orange juice and eggs today.

title: Chrysler Is Issuing 3 Recalls For Fuel or Impact Problems
description: The Chrysler Corporation has announced three separate recalls involving almost 69,000 cars and trucks to check or correct problems related to leaking fuel or rear impacts.

title: Sinn Fein Chief Barred By U.S. a Second Time
description: Gerry Adams, leader of Northern Ireland's Sinn Fein, the political wing of the Irish Republican Army, has been denied a visa to visit the United States, according to State Department spokesman.

title: GARLIC'S MAGICAL BITE
description: Feelings about garlic tend to be divided into intense loathing or sheer delight; we belong to the latter group. We often add a bit of finely minced garlic to salad dressings, and we find that a garlic mayonnaise and related dishes (the a"ioli of France, the skordalia of Greece, and so on) have a special appeal.

title: Kathryn L. Trant Wed To Thomas A. Broge
description: Kathryn Lynn Trant, a daughter of Katherine M. Schuff of Sutherland, Neb., and Richard J. Trant Jr. of Weston, Mass., was married in Northampton, Mass., yesterday to Thomas Alden Broge, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Broge of Wyoming, Ohio. The Rev. John Betlyon, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony in the Helen Hills Chapel at Smith College, from which the bride graduated cum laude.

title: HOLDING ON TO SECOND
description: A jockey whose horse was overtaken in the stretch by an animal on which he had placed a heavy bet would obviously be in big trouble. Similar situations, without any money involvement, can happen in bridge tournaments.

title: O'NEILL'S SEETHING 'INTERLUDE' RETURNS TO BROADWAY
description: When he began outlining ''Strange Interlude'' in the summer of 1926, Eugene O'Neill thought of it, significantly, as ''My woman play.'' As with many of his earlier works, he was digging into his own most secret and turbulent feelings to dramatize a tragic vision of life.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: Black History Month, which occurs in February, will be celebrated with special vibrancy when Dancemobile brings its 10th annual winter series to Symphony Space, Broadway at 95th Street, for 10 performances starting Wednesday. Under the direction of the Harlem Cultural Council and Geanie Faulkner, Dancemobile's low-priced winter performances and summer tours of city streets have fostered the art and introduced some audiences to dance, giving other dancegoers a greater sense of the diversity and continuity of black dance.

title: AN OLD MAN IN FIRM POSSESSION OF HIS SOUL
description: DO LORD REMEMBER ME

title: FOR VACATIONING YOUTHS, EVENTS ABOUND
description: WITH many of the schools in the county closed for vacation this week, various organizations have scheduled activities for young children, teen-agers or all of the family members. Many of the events may be challenging physically, or an enjoyable learning experience.

title: U.S. COAL GROUP PRAISES OTTAWA'S ACID RAIN FIGHT
description: The head of the National Coal Association in the United States has sent Prime Minister Brian Mulroney a letter complimenting him on his decision, in the absence of comparable action by Washington, to move ahead on controlling the pollution that is believed to cause acid rain.

title: JERSEY WELFARE RECIPIENTS GET COMPUTER TRAINING
description: Most mornings, Elizabeth Huribert gets up at 4 A.M. to study microcomputers.

title: CHEMICAL LEAKS INTO HUDSON
description: Between 600 and 1,000 gallons of an industrial chemical leaked from the General Electric silicone plant into the Hudson River in southern Saratoga County, the company said today. An environmental official said that there was no health threat because the chemical had discharged slowly. He added that the chemical, 1,1,1 trichloroethylene, which is used in cleaning fluids, would probably not be detectable.

title: Boston College Triumphs
description: Boston College came from 11 points behind in the final 10 minutes today to upset Villanova, 62-61, on a layup by Michael Adams.

title: BEAUCOONS OF WORDS
description: If Jim Wayne Miller is correct, and the term

title: SPECIAL SITTERS
description: SHREWSBURY FINDING a competent baby sitter can be a frustrating experience. And when a child is handicapped, the difficulties are multiplied, along with the parents' anxieties about leaving the child with someone who may not adequately meet his or her special requirements.

title: CANADA'S NEW ECNOMIC CLOUT
description: Andrew H. Malcolm, who spent four years as The Times's correspondent in Toronto, is now chief of the paper's Chicago bureau. This article is adapted from his book, ''The Canadians,'' to be published by Times Books this month.

title: LEGISLATORS BUSY WITH PROPOSALS FOR NEW LAWS
description: HARTFORD

title: Amy Edmondson Is Wed to a Designer
description: Amy Claire Edmondson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Edmondson of New York and Prouts Neck, Me., was married yesterday to Mark Dunbar Carpenter, a son of the Rev. and Mrs. James A. Carpenter of New York and Greensboro, Vt. The Rev. Robert Haskins, a Roman Catholic priest, assisted by the bridegroom's father, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony in the chapel of the Convent of the Sacred Heart in Manhattan.

title: KENNEDY AIDES TO ATTEND CONFERENCE ON 60'S
description: For three days next month, a good number of the pioneers of the New Frontier will gather at Hofstra University in Hempstead, L.I., to remember John F. Kennedy.

title: Kayaking for Beginners
description: IF the idea of paddling a kayak in coastal waters next summer appeals to you, and your experience with such craft is limited or nonexistent, this is the time to enroll in a course designed to teach you the basic skills of the sport.

title: 'Underground' Writers
description: To the Editor:

title: CABARET: CARMEN MCRAE
description: Carmen McRae's engagement at the Blue Note, through next Sunday, is being advertised as a ''Tribute to Nat King Cole.'' At her second show on her opening night, however, Miss McRae never mentioned Mr. Cole's name nor did she sing any songs associated with him.

title: Out in the Cold
description: Precisely at that hour, Archer Miles, whom I know scarcely at all, smiled at me as I stepped into the elevator and asked, ''Is it cold enough for you?''

title: Mother Fined for Taking Her Son From His Father
description: A judge gave a stern rebuke and a $3,000 civil contempt fine Friday to Betty Lou Batey, who said she was following her fundamentalist Christian beliefs in taking her son from his homosexual father, who had legal custody at the time.

title: NEW ZEALAND A-ARMS FOE: DAVID RUSSELL LANGE
description: Prime Minister David Lange, who rankled the Reagan Administration but won worldwide acclaim from antinuclear groups last week after he refused a port call by a United States destroyer, has been sympathetic to the nuclear disarmament movement for at least two decades. This is not the first time his outspoken stands on issues have irritated American officials. In the mid-1960's, Mr. Lange, then a liberal lawyer, was an outspoken critic of the United States involvement in Vietnam. Later, apparently in response to his antiwar activities, he was denied a visa to the United States.

title:
FARE OF THE COUNTRY ;

GEODUCK: SEATTLE'S TASTY BIG CLAM
description: SUSAN HERRMANN LOOMIS is a food writer who lives in Seattle.

title: A Defense of the Marcos Government
description: I must take exception to the apocalyptic drift of Steve Lohr's article, ''Twilight of the Marcos Era'' (Jan. 6). Consider the following facts: Dr. Parvez Hasan of the World Bank considers the performance of the Philippines during the last decade above average ''in the overall perspective of developing countries and in terms of macro-economic indicators.''

title: A PHOTO FINISH AT TITOGRAD
description: Viktor Korchnoi of Switzerland and Dragoljub Velimirovic of Yugoslavia tied for first place in the Titograd (Yugoslavia) International Tournament, each scoring 7 1/2-3 1/2.

title: STATE WIDENING INQUIRY INTO CAUSE OF L.I. OIL SPILL
description: State officials, saying that initial inquiries had found at least half a dozen environmental violations, have begun a wider investigation into the leak last Sunday of 225,000 gallons of heating oil from a storage tank at a Long Island Lighting Company plant.

title: IMPROVING LONGEVITY MAY HAVE SIDE EFFECTS
description: THE Bible promised a life span of three score and ten, but it wasn't until the 1960's that the prophesy became reality for the average American. Since then, life expectancy has continued to creep upward, following a trend that has resulted in a gain of nearly 30 years since the century began. According to the latest batch of figures, the final 1982 report released last week by the National Center for Health Statistics, life expectancy at birth now stands at 74.6 (although it is still 69.3 for blacks, a rate whites achieved about 30 years ago). How much higher can it go? How much older can we get, if indeed we are getting older rather than simply dying less often in youth? And if evenutally more of us will be around later in life, how will we pay the hospital bills, pensions and Social Security benefits that are already tying Congress up in knots? Three experts discussed the implications of America's increasing longevity last week with Richard Levine, an editor with the Week in Review. Excerpts follow.

title: BARNUM MUSEUM'S RESCUE IS COMPLETED
description: THE long deterioration of the building housing the Barnum Museum in Bridgeport has been halted, thanks to spending by the city.

title: SIDON ERUPTS IN CELEBRATION AFTER PULLOUT
description: This battered port city exploded with joy today as Israeli forces ended 32 months of occupation and the Lebanese Army took over their positions.

title: 'BABY,''BABY'
description: THEATRICALLY, the county is having a ''Baby'' boom. Last season's Broadway musical, which concerns three couples' attitudes about childbirth, opened, almost by default, at the Emelin Theater for the Performing Arts in Mamaroneck last week for five performances.

title:
ART;

FIVE WOMEN WHO PIONEERED IMPRESSIONISM IN AMERICA
description: AMERICAN Impressionism has long been considered a mere imitation of the inspired it. While recent scholarship has done much to elevate the reputations of the foremost artists associated with Impressionism in this country, it cannot be denied that there were numerous American painters who can only be regarded as followers of the trail blazed in France during the 1870's.

title: South African Court Blocks Bishop's Meeting
description: A South African court banned a meeting today in the black township of Tembisa, where Bishop Desmond Tutu, the Nobel Peace Prize winner, was due to speak. The court said the meeting could endanger public peace.

title: SWITZERLAND
description: Some of the diamond-studded platinum watches and matching bracelets that a few elegant jewelers in Geneva and Zurich nonchalantly display in their show windows cost only $12,000 at the present exchange rate. However, if that seems a bit stiff for a souvenir or gift from Switzerland, or if you fear questions from United States customs officials, you can always pick up a Swatch at $18.85.

title: CRIME WATCH IN SOME AREAS IS FOUND TO BE A MISNOMER
description: ORANGE THEY are a familiar sight around the state: A big eye with ''Crime Watch'' printed over it, or a similar sign warning that the neighborhood is protected by block-watchers.

title: FARM EXPERTS SEE A FUTURE OF FEWER AND LARGER TRACTS
description: Spreading hardship is speeding American agriculture toward a destiny of fewer and larger farms.

title: NEW ON MADISON
description: The blue-and-orange scaffolding that now hugs the 17-story brick and masonry building on the southeast corner of Madison Avenue and East 54th Street is not a sign that the commercial structure is undergoing renovation. Rather, it means that the delicate procedure of demolition in this dense commercial neighborhood has begun and that a new building is on the way.

title: CASTRO SAYS CUBAN MISSILE CRISIS HELPED GENERATE DETENTE
description: The Cuban leader Fidel Castro said in an interview broadcast Friday that he believed the fears generated by the Cuban missile crisis of 1962 enabled the United States and the Soviet Union to achieve a period of detente later on.

title: PARIS
description: Now is the time to raid the flea markets of Paris. This year, those marvelous emporiums of everything you didn't know existed and never realized you couldn't live without promise to be more tempting than ever. They will be offering the visitor a chance to pick over the contents of innumerable French attics and cellars.

title: Miss Isbrandtsen To Marry in May
description: The engagement of Andree Isbrandtsen to Robert Phillip Pruett Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Pruett of Greenwich, Conn., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Jakob Isbrandtsen, also of Greenwich. A May wedding is planned.

title: KHMER ROUGE IS REPORTED TO FIGHT BACK
description: Less than 24 hours after Vietnamese troops overran their major bases in western Cambodia along the Thai border, Khmer Rouge guerrillas were clashing with Hanoi's forces deeper inside Cambodia today, according to Thai military reports.

title: THE FOLLIES OF WRITER WORSHIP
description: I once owned a piece of Somerset Maugham's gate. Well, not exactly Somerset Maugham's gate - it wasn't pillaged from the Villa Mauresque - but near enough. My chunk of literary wood came from the vicarage at Whitstable where Maugham spent part of his unhappy boyhood. Decades later local graybeards with lips untouched by a lie would assure you that they had often seen the future novelist swinging on the vicarage gate. When it fell into disrepair some 20 years ago, I greedily acquired a section of it - a spar about a yard long, with a nail at each end and a thick carapace of white paint. I kept it under the stairs, alongside other pointless yet favored items - the half-finished brass rubbing, the broken typewriter, the tennis racquet with strings burst into a mad spaghetti. From time to time I would take out my private trophy, examine it with half-embarrassed fondness, then put it back.

title: THE ROLE OF THE UNIVERSITY PRESS
description: PHILOSOPHICALLY, New Jersey's two university presses are close: Each is devoted to and takes pride in scholarly work. Physically, they are less than 16 miles apart: Princeton University Press is in a Gothic building at 41 William Street, Princeton; Rutgers University Press in a converted 19th-century farmhouse at College and Hamilton Avenues in New Brunswick.

title: Walking the U.S.
description: Rob Sweetgall, a 36-year-old chemical engineer in Newark, Del., took to the road in September to determine the physiological effects of long-distance, long-time walking.

title: COPING WITH VIETNAM
description: Edward Tick overlooks the one group that indeed does feel wholeness and pride at its role in the Vietnam era.

title: TRICKS, DIRTY TRICK AND BLUNDERS
description: MI6

title: Verbatim: Getting on the Team
description: 'I have a feeling that the State Department desperately needs to be vigorously harnessed.

title: V.A. RICCIO, EX-COUNCILMAN
description: Vincent A. Riccio, a former Republican Assemblyman from Brooklyn who became the first Conservative to win election to the City Council, died of a heart attack Thursday while visiting Miami. He was 65 years old and a lifelong resident of Brooklyn.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN BEHAVIORAL TRAINING;

SPECIFIC TOOLS FOR WORKPLACE PROBLEMS
description: NEARLY 40 years ago, The National Training Laboratories Institute held the dozen college professors spent a week exploring their feelings about themselves and each other. They responded enthusiastically to the process, and N.T.L., as it is invariably called started running the sessions with scheduled frequency.

title:
GARDENING;

YES, THE TOMATO IS A FRUIT
description: -standing argument, perhaps better described as a misunderstanding, as to just what one consumes when eating a tomato. Some say that a tomato is a vegetable and justify that classification based on its use. After all, fruits are used as desserts, appetizers, jellies and the like, while vegetables are used in soups, stews and main courses. Therefore, since the tomato is used as a vegetable, it must be one.

title:
LEISURE;

FORSYTHIA IS NOT THE ONLY SHRUB FOR SPRING
description: Dr. John L. Creech, recently retired, was director of the National Arboretum and makes frequent trips for plant exploration.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

WATERBURY: COMPANY TOWN
description: THE financial page carried the news that Scovill Inc. of Waterbury was being acquired by the Belzberg Brothers of Canada. While that report was important to Scovill shareholders and others, any news of Scovill has special meaning to me.

title: About Men;   Hanging Out With Horses
description: Benjamin DeMott,

title: Lilco Ready toThrow Switch
description: Coal plants run on coal, a Long Island Lighting Company executive used to say, and nuclear plants run on paper - the kind that must be filed with Federal regulators. Lilco, which has fought its share of paper battles, won a big one last week.

title: IN EUROPE, IT' TIME TO BUY
description: VICKY ELLIOTT is a writer and editor at The International Herald Tribune.

title:
DINING OUT;

BANQUET TABLES ARE HEAVY FOR 4683
description: TO ring in the Chinese lunar year 4683, many Chinese restaurants are cooking up some festive dishes - special-occasion food that does not appear on the daily menu - in celebration of this year of the ox. Banquet menus incorporating traditional holiday foods, such as sticky rice dumplings, spring rolls (because the new year marks the spring or birth of the year), chicken, fish, pork (especially), cold meat platters, sweet and sticky eight precious rice and a fancy soup, to mention a few, indicate the beginning of holiday festivities that center around Feb. 19, or New Year's Eve.

title: A HILTON FOR ROCKLAND
description: Plans are under way to build a Hilton hotel and conference center on a 17-acre parcel in the sprawling, once-dormant Blue Hill Plaza office park in Orangetown, N.Y.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: COLONIAL MUSICALIA

title: ABUSE OF CHILDREN REPORTED UP IN '84
description: Reports of sexual abuse of children soared nationwide in 1984, according to a new study, but a leader of efforts to stop child abuse said the numbers probably represented only ''the tip of the iceberg.''

title: ROLE OF PUBLIC TV IN STATE IS QUESTIONED
description: TRENTON

title: TWO TALENTS TO MELD IN CONCERT OF OLD AND NEW
description: WHEN two of the best musical groups in Connecticut combine for a concert, it is cause for double delight. The groups are the Fairfield Chamber Orchestra and the Pro Arte Singers of Connecticut and the 4 P.M. program next Sunday is an intriguing one, fusing old works and new, and including scores especially composed for each of the ensembles.

title: THE POSTAL SERVICE IS IN THE BLACK, BUT HARDLY THE PINK
description: On the second floor of a blocklong warehouse on Ninth Avenue in Manhattan, postal workers dump letters onto conveyor belts, which carry them for five stories along a serpentine path of switchbacks, turns and chutes. This is the nation's most modern postal factory, but the other night there was a pile of letters on the floor below one precarious turn.

title: PUSH Dispute
description: At the height of the Democratic Presidential primaries in April 1984, the Federal Department of Education announced that it wanted a social service group founded by the Rev. Jesse Jackson to return $708,431 in Federal appropriations because the funds had been improperly spent.

title: SUFFOLK PROSECUTOR SEEKS THIRD TERM
description: SOME Republican grumbling about Suffolk District Attorney Patrick Henry appears to have been quieted as the 55- year-old prosecutor prepares to run for a third term this year.

title: Future Events
description: Fancy and Plain

title: O'NEILL'S SEETHING 'INTERLUDE' RETURN TO BROADWAY
description: that was difficult enough, given her view of O'Neill as a sort of unconquerable Everest: ''Like Shakespeare, you can never scale him - all you can do is try, as seriously as honestly as you can.''

title: Howard Rubin Is Wed To Mary Jullien Henry
description: The marriage of Mary Jullien Henry, a daughter of Mrs. Samuel Joseph Henry of Phoenix and the late Mr. Henry, to Howard Rubin, a son of Leon Rubin of Boston and the late Laura Solomon Rubin, took place yesterday at the Paradise Valley (Ariz.) Country Club.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

PRIVACY, COMPUTER-STYLE
description: THERE is a little room in our house, not much bigger than a library carrel, which had served the original owners as a bedroom until, adding to the house, they made it into a hallway and dressing room. When we acquired the house, three years B.C. (Before Children), the room held beds for two dogs. Once three children had arrived and filled up other available space, the little room became my study.

title: L.I. VILLAGE IS PUSHING TO QUIT SCHOOL DISTRICT
description: In the midst of a state civil-rights investigation, education leaders in this virtually all-white village said today that they would exercise every legal means possible to create their own high school district and insure that their children attend neighborhood schools.

title:
ANTIQUES;

TRADE FIGURES ARE POPULAR WITH COLLECTORS
description: THE name of the show is familiar; so will be the names of many of the 53 exhibitors planning to take part. The difference is that the first Stamford Antiques Show of the year will be held four months earlier than usual and that it will be set up in the Italian Center on Newfield Street, rather than at Yacht Haven West.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE DAY THE SUN ROSE TWICE: The Story of the Trinity Site Nuclear Explosion July 16, 1945. By Ferenc Morton Szasz.

title:
GARDENING;

YES, THE TOMATO IS A FRUIT
description: -standing argument, perhaps better described as a misunderstanding, as to just what one consumes when eating a tomato. Some say that a tomato is a vegetable and justify that classification based on its use. After all, fruits are used as desserts, appetizers, jellies and the like, while vegetables are used in soups, stews and main courses. Therefore, since the tomato is used as a vegetable, it must be one.

title: DEMOCRATS ASSESS POSITION IN SOUTH
description: In his first outing as the chairman of the Democratic National Committee, Paul G. Kirk Jr. today agreed with a gathering of Southern party leaders that the way to restore the national party's strength in the region was to move it more toward the political center.

title: A New LookIn Rabbis
description: When Amy Eilberg is ordained at the Jewish Theological Seminary in May, she will become the first full- fledged female rabbi in the history of Conservative Judaism. After years of debate, the Rabbinical Assembly, Conservatism's worldwide governing body, last week announced its decision to welcome women into its rabbinate.

title: Zulu Opposes Halt to Investment in South Africa
description: The head of the Zulu tribe, one of the most prominent black leaders in South Africa, has urged American businessmen to continue to invest in that country.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;

 HAPPY BIRTHDAY, GEORGE
description: These days, George Washington's birthday is generally marked by special sales, but back in 1840, folks used to pay homage to the ''Father of Our Country'' with fiery speeches, patriotic songs, processions and parades. Taking this page out of history, the ''residents'' of Old Bethpage Village Restoration today stage such a celebration, complete with an appearance by the Hempstead Light Guards Militia, readings of Washington's Farewell Address and samplings of cider and fruitcake. The festivities begin at 2 P.M. at the restoration on Round Swamp Road. Admission is $3, or $2.50 for Nassau residents, and $1.50 for children.

title: COMPANIES EASING CROWDED PRISONS
description: At a time when nearly two-thirds of the nation's prisons are under court order to ease overcrowding and repair dilapidated structures, the states and localities are turning increasingly to private companies for construction help.

title: Breeding Tells
description: Her mother played on a state championship team and an older sister made it to the state tournament, so it is hardly surprising that

title:
IN SHORT: NON-FICTION;

THEY MADE TOMBS FOR A LIVING
description: One of the most enthralling archeological discoveries in recent decades was the excavation of the 3,000-year-old ''village of the tombmakers'' in what is now Deir el Medina in Egypt. Here, under the shadow of the desert cliffs in which they worked, lived the elite community of skilled craftsmen - stone quarrymen, masons, sculptors, draftsmen, painters and wood carvers - who built the great tombs of the kings. Generation after generation of these villagers left behind a record of daily life in their ubiquitous graffiti and in the meticulous records of their scribes. In ANCIENT LIVES: Daily Life in Egypt of the Pharaohs (Holt, $18.95) , John Romer, who spent 15 years as an archeologist in Egypt, re-creates in rich, sensory detail the rhythms and textures of ordinary life in an extraordinary time and place. We learn what the villagers' houses were like, what they ate and wore, what they dreamt about (there is even a remedy for frightening dreams - a recitation ''accompanied by the eating of fresh bread and green herbs moistened with beer''). We hear of the frantic speed with which quarrymen and artists, working in shifts, prepared a tomb for a royal burial, of feuds between foremen and of workers' strikes when food rations, which had to be brought to the isolated village from across the Nile, were delayed. Some readers may be put off by the dense accumulation of archeological detail. But for those who stay with it, this book has rewards. Mr. Romer can make you feel ''the silence of the desert hissing in the evening air,'' hear the chink of the grave robber's chisel and see artists at work in dark, cavernous chambers lit by flickering oil lamps.

title: Embryo Research Ban Supported in Britain
description: A bill that would ban experiments on human embryos has cleared a parliamentary hurdle, but the Government is expected to prevent it from becoming law.

title: FORDHAM DEFEATS MANHATTAN
description: Tony McIntosh, a senior guard making his final start at Fordham's Rose Hill Gym, scored 20 points yesterday to lead the Rams over Manhattan, 69-55.

title: Chilean LeaderTightens Circle
description: The Reagan Administration has tried quiet diplomacy and public politesse to persuade countries it classifies as friendly, albeit authoritarian, to become more democractic. President Augusto Pinochet of Chile evidently has not been paying attention. He recently extended the state of siege, which imposes tight censorship and authorizes troops to bash demonstrators. Last week, he dismissed Interior Minister Sergio Onofre Jarpa Reyes, a conservative who opposed the extension.

description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. David Albert of Cos Cob, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter Beth Tracy Albert to Harvey Jay Araton, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert Araton of Brooklyn. Miss Albert, coordinator of media relations for the United States Football League in New York, and her fiance, a sportswriter for The Daily News, plan to be married June 16.
