The Rev. Justin Hennessey performed the ceremony at St. Vincent Ferrer Roman Catholic Church in New York.

title: THE STAGE: 'NOSFERATU,' EERIE DRAMA BY CHONG

When they walk across the carpet of their handsome, hi-tech living room, they move with the synchronized grace of fashion models. They and their circle of friends are Calvin Klein ads come to life, but behind the pursuit of flair there is something sinister afoot.

Since then, Conrail's fortunes have turned dramatically, providing a chance for taxpayers to recoup a substantial part of their multibillion dollar investment and for the Government to return a profitable business to the private sector, where it belongs.

One case in point is the apartment of Timothy Macdonald, an executive vice president of Donghia Associates. ''When you work with clients, usually all the art and furnishings are planned as a whole,'' says Macdonald. ''Although I inherited many objects, the rest I bought in a casual manner, as the need arose.

title: TWAIN, IN '85

When the recent opening in Chicago of a stage adaptation of ''Huckleberry Finn'' prompted a new series of demands that the book be banned for being ''racist,'' it was just the most recent skirmish in a conflict that began some 20 years before Twain published the novel. In fact, Twain developed the distinctive brand of irony that characterizes ''Huckleberry Finn'' in response to his discovery that straightforward exposes of racism would be censored.

Let's say she is 5 feet 2 inches tall, wants to be a science teacher, is working hard for grades at a junior college - and cannot dunk a basketball. Can't even dribble one.

title: Perjury Trial Wasn't Perfect, But It's Judged Fair Enough
description: Former Attorney General Paul Douglas of Nebraska was entitled to a fair trial on a perjury charge ''but not a perfect one,'' a state judge ruled in denying his request for a new trial.

Mr. Dolan is a graduate of Boston College and the Columbia Graduate School of Business. He replaces as president Arthur H. Thornhill Jr., who will remain as chairman and chief executive officer. Little, Brown, founded in 1837, became a subsidiary of Time Inc. in 1968.

He got even more help from the fish. They started following him in his rubber raft, fighting to be next on his hook.

description: Just four months after the Argentine Government signed an agreement with the International Monetary Fund, rampant inflation has seriously jeopardized the country's ability to hold to the terms of the financial pact, according to bankers and Government economists.

title: 3 INJURED IN RIOT THAT SENDS MEXICANS FLEEING TO BORDER
description: A riot today that sent 400 protestors fleeing to an already clogged checkpoint at the United States border left three Mexican police officers wounded, one critically.

title: What's in a Name?
description: The National Black Women's

title: COZZENS RELIES ON MENTAL TOUGHNESS
description: WEST POINT, N.Y.

title: A RURAL CHILEAN LEGEND COME TRUE
description: Old legends are still told in the Chilean countryside. One legend explains what happens when a child disappears: he has been kidnapped by witches, and his captors, to insure his servitude, break all his bones, sew together different parts of his body and turn his head around so he must always look and walk backward. His eyes, ears and mouth are constantly stitched up. The creature is called an Imbunche.

title: THE CALENDAR
description: Monday

title: DANCE: NEW WORKS BY MITCHELL ROSE
description: MITCHELL ROSE is calling himself ''the global village idiot'' these days. But a program of his dances, performed on Saturday at Theater of the Riverside Church, suggested that Mr. Rose is moving beyond the inspired dance comedy for which he has been known to an unusual blend of dance and comedy that is entirely his own.

title: Father Held in Crash That Killed Daughter
description: A driver embroiled in a family argument Saturday said, ''I'm going to end it all,'' and swerved his auto into oncoming traffic, killing his daughter and two people in another car, officials said today.

title: Waiting for Donovan
description: While Secretary of Labor Raymond J. Donovan is fighting indictment in New York in a conspiracy case, Ford B. Ford, the department's under secretary, has been running the shop, and aides say he is in full command.

title: UNESCO BOARD ALLOWS THE U.S. TO MAINTAIN AN OBSERVER MISSION
description: The United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, at its first high- level meeting since the Reagan Administration withdrew at the end of last year, decided early today to retain close links with the United States. ,

title: OSTOLOZAGA WINS
description: Louis Ostolozaga of the Westchester-Puma Club and Marilyn Hulak of the Atlanta Track Club earned trips to the Hiroshima 10-kilometer run March 17 by winning the eighth annual New York Road Runners Club's 10-kilometer bagel run yesterday at Central Park.

title: MUSIC: A SCHUTZ TRIBUTE BY EARLY MUSIC ENSEMBLE
description: SATURDAY at Alice Tully Hall, New York's Ensemble for Early Music honored the earliest of the major composers whose anniversaries are being celebrated this year, with a concert centered on music of Heinrich Sch"utz (1585-1672) though ranging widely from him in time and geography. Ten composers were represented by more than 20 compositions, played by 17 performers in almost as many different combinations. In a program so various only a few highlights can be mentioned.

title: Louisiana Chicken Shop Blows Up in Auto Crash
description: A car slammed into a fast-food restaurant Saturday, causing a natural gas explosion that injured 16 people, the authorities said.

title: ;   History Keeps Happening All the Time
description: To the Editor:

title: Dr. Ernest Fincher, 74, Dies; Retired Professor in Jersey
description: Dr. Ernest B. Fincher, a retired professor of political science at Montclair State College, died last Tuesday at Easton (Pa.) Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived on a farm in Hunterdon County, N.J.

title: FRED CORSON, RETIRED BISHOP
description: Retired Bishop Fred Pierce Corson, former president of the World Methodist Council, died Saturday of a cerebral hemorrhage he suffered after a fall last week while he was on vacation here.

title: EDELMAN WRESTLES WITH RISK
description: It may be hard to imagine a company called the United Stockyards Corporation, whose stock symbol is ''COW,'' in Wall Street's fast lane. But Asher B. Edelman, the takeover specialist who controls United Stockyards, says he will make it run like a thoroughbred.

title: Pincay Goes Over 6,000 Victories
description: Laffit Pincay Jr. rode four winners at Santa Anita Park today, and became only the third jockey to win 6,000 thoroughbred races.

title: FEW VACANCIES FOR YANKEES
description: THE IRONY of spring training for the Yankees: Never have they brought so many newly acquired players to camp following a flurry of winter activity, but seldom in the George Steinbrenner years have they opened a camp with a team so set as this one seems to be.

title: Agency Asks Phone Study
description: The Office of Management and Budget says it has put the brakes on Government acquisition of a new $4.2 billion long-distance telephone system until a budget and policy review of the proposal can be made.

title: RANGERS TROUNCE ISLANDERS
description: The faithful knew this would happen all along, didn't they?

title: OFFICIALS SAY SOME DOCTORS FAIL TO CONSERVE VACCINE SUPPLIES
description: Federal officials say that as many as half of the nation's private physicians are failing to conserve scarce supplies of whooping cough vaccine by postponing booster shots.

title: JETS TIE DEVILS, 2-2, ON GOAL BY MULLEN
description: Brian Mullen of the Jets scored the tying goal early in the third period tonight and then the Devils' goaltender, Hannu Kamppuri, withstood a late barrage with some acrobatic saves as the Jets and Devils played to a 2-2 tie.

title: Italy Reports a Plot Against Prime Minister
description: The police have uncovered what appears to be a plot by West German terrorists to assassinate Prime Minister Bettino Craxi, the Italian leader said today during a speech to a Socialist Party conference.

title: WOMEN AND COCAINE: A GROWING PROBLEM
description: The nationwide epidemic of cocaine addiction appears to have caught in its sweep women at all socioeconomic levels, ranging from those who use the drug regularly to those who use it only occasionally. More women are turning up at drug treatment centers and self- help groups looking for a way out.

title: BLACKBURN WINS PLAYOFF IN SAN DIEGO
description: Woody Blackburn ended 10 seasons of frustration on the PGA Tour today when he defeated Ron Streck on the fourth hole of a playoff in the $400,000 Isuzu-Andy Williams San Diego Open.

title: Whither Burns?
description: The American Enterprise Institute is about to quash any lingering doubts about the widely assumed but still unofficial decision of Arthur F. Burns to quit his post as Ambassador to Germany. The conservative research organization has not officially announced it, but the staff says the 80-year- old former chairman of the Federal Reserve Board will reclaim his American Enterprise Institute office in May.

title: MONDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: City University of New York Tournament, opening round, at Nat Holman Gymnasium, 138th Street and Convent Avenue. Games begin at 1 P.M. C

title: THERE ARE BAD DOCTORS, BUTALSO BAD LAWYERS
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 SETS DOWN, MAYOTTE WINS
description: When he reminisces about the giant leap he took these last two weeks, Tim Mayotte will remember how the Lipton International Players Championships was a capsule version of his career. There were the nights of the two-week tournament when he played virtually unnoticed in the unseasonable cold, with a handful of spectators dressed as though going to a football game in Green Bay. And he will remember the ending on national television, when he basked in the warmth of his first professional triumph and applause from a crowd exceeding 7,000.

title: International Suits
description: Senator Dennis DeConcini, Democrat of Arizona, has introduced a bill to deal with another irritant in European-American relations: private antitrust suits for treble damages against domestic and foreign companies that are engaged in international commerce.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Feb. 18, 1985: *2*MONDAY Dana Corp Illinois Tool Wrks *2*TUESDAY American Cyanamid Interpublic Group Amer District Tel Lawter Intl Interfirst Corp V F Corp *2*WEDNESDAY Centex Corp Mohasco Corp First Bank System Northrop Corp *2*THURSDAY Insilco Corp Sherwin-Williams Loctite Corp *2*FRIDAY Americana Hotel&Rty Dexter Corp Brown & Sharp Mfg Harris Corp (Del)

title: ST. JOHN'S DEFEATS DEPAUL
description: St. John's has turned in a number of inspired performances - an overtime victory against Syracuse at the Garden, an upset of Georgetown at the Capital Centre, a comeback victory over Villanova in Philadelphia. But yesterday against DePaul, the Redmen reached an unprecedented emotional pitch.

title: JAPAN'S CAUTIOUS DEREGULATION
description: Almost every day, another bulletin emerges from the dingy brick complex that houses Japan's Ministry of Finance: a decision on the rules for new financial markets, perhaps, or a set of criteria for bond issues.

title: CONVICTIONS OF 3.8% FOUND IN UPDATED DAY-CARE CHECK
description: Fingerprint checks of nearly a third of the current or prospective workers at government-financed child-care programs in New York City show that only 3.8 percent of them have criminal records.

title: Nothing Good or Bad but Thinking Makes It So
description: To the Editor:

title: 'SOME MEN NEED HELP,' ON AMERICAN PLAYHOUSE
description: ''SOME MEN NEED HELP,'' a play by John Ford Noonan, opened on Broadway Oct. 28, 1982. It closed the following night. The same production, starring Treat Williams and Philip Bosco, has been taped for television and can now be seen on public TV's American Playhouse, tonight at 9 on WNET/Channel 13. It still deserves a quick and merciful demise.

title: Washington Watch;   A New Style At Treasury
description: WASHINGTON

title: Salvador Army Accused Of Blocking Food Relief
description: Army commanders in a rebel-dominated region north of the capital have prevented food shipped by the Roman Catholic relief agency Caritas from reaching villagers, the Archbishop of San Salvador said today.

title: SAUDI ECONOMY IS AILING
description: After a breathtaking decade, when rising oil revenues financed more than $550 billion in development programs, Saudi Arabia is in the midst of a somewhat painful period of retrenchment, one that may last through the rest of the 1980's.

title: The Dangers of Sending Undercover Officers Into Our Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: Kuwaiti Women Seeking The Right to Vote
description: Kuwaiti women have renewed a call for voting rights in the only Persian Gulf Arab nation with an elected Parliament, but the few men allowed to vote are resisting the idea.

title: OUTLOOK GRIM FOR SQUATTERS IN NICARAGUA
description: In local slang, they are known as parachutists. They are the landless squatters of Managua, and they have earned their nickname by landing on empty lots in every corner of the Nicaraguan capital and building themselves makeshift residences of wood, plastic and cardboard.

title: CHARLES A. MEHOS
description: Charles A. Mehos, vice chairman and chief financial officer of American Brands Inc., died of cancer Thursday at Stamford (Conn.) Hospital. He was 64 years old and lived in Darien, Conn.

title: Jersey Report Due On Toxic Wastes
description: A state panel charged with finding sites for incinerators and a toxic waste dump hopes to determine by spring how many such centers are needed, the executive director of the Hazardous Waste Siting Commission said today.

title: Britain Sues on Auto Loss
description: The British Government is suing the accountants for John Z. DeLorean, the American former auto maker, for $270 million in a United States court to recoup public funds lost when his Northern Ireland plant failed.

title: Villanova Teams Win Track Titles
description: Villanova, sparked by record performances by Connie Sweet in the shot-put and John Marshall in the 500-meter run, won the men's and women's divisions of the sixth Big East Conference indoor track championship today.

title: RELATIONS SOUR BETWEEN ETHIOPIA AND WESTERN FOOD DONORS
description: Relations between the Ethiopian Government and the Western nations and organizations involved in the famine relief effort here appear to have reached their lowest point since huge amounts of aid began to pour into this country last autumn.

title: Koch Predicts Cut In Offer to Unions
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that because of proposed cuts in Federal aid, the city could no longer afford the contract rejected last week by the firefighters and would reduce its future offer to all municipal unions.

title: Child Lost in Cold Found With Puppies
description: A 2-year-old boy lost for 12 hours in thick woods in subfreezing weather was found unharmed early today huddled in a thicket with his two puppies keeping him warm.

title: New Appointments
description: One duty that is weighing upon Mr. Baker is the appointment of a new chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, a post which William M. Isaac will soon be vacating, and a Comptroller of the Currency to succeed C. Todd Conover, who is also leaving.

title: Mexico Growth Better in '84 MEXICO CITY, Feb. 17
description: The growth rate of

title: Southern Union Gives A Panel Top Authority
description: The directors of the Southern Union Company have removed its president, Fred G. Hansen, from responsibility for daily operations and have replaced him as chief executive officer with a committee of five senior executives.

title: CONTRACTS LET BY ALASKA OIL AREA UNDER F.B.I. SCRUTINY AFTER AUDIT
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation is looking into recent contracting practices of the local government that administers Alaska's oil-producing North Slope in the light of an audit released Feb. 5. It suggests millions of dollars in contracts may have been improperly awarded.

title: War Games Draw Protest
description: About 2,500 people marched through this northern Japanese city Sunday to protest current United States-Japanese military exercises, the police said. The rally, sponsored by the Socialist Party, the Communist Party and the General Council of Trade Unions, was held near the exercise ground of the Japanese Self-Defense Forces in Furano, on Japan's northern island of Hokkaido.

title: Leslie Bodeen Is Wed To John Moriarty Jr.
description: The marriage of Leslie I. Bodeen and John M. Moriarty Jr., who received M.B.A. degrees in 1982 from Harvard University, took place yesterday at the Tamcrest Country Club in Alpine, N.J. Rabbi A. Bruce Goldman and the Rev. Henry Fehrenbacher, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: There Are Bad Doctors, but Also Bad Lawyers
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY ;   American Writers Pay Tibute to Argentine
description: As they often are, politics and literature were intertwined yesterday at a tribute to Julio Cortazar, the late Argentine writer who was also an outspoken supporter of the Sandinista Government in Nicaragua.

title: DATA SOUGHT ON BANK INQUIRY
description: Representative Fernand J. St Germain, chairman of the House Banking Committee, has written to the Comptroller of the Currency seeking more information about how the Government monitored transactions of the Bank of Boston, which has pleaded guilty to violating a law intended to stop money laundering.

title: Ulster Prison Official Slain
description: A senior official of the Maze prison in Belfast was shot to death today as he left St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Cathedral in Armagh after mass, the police reported. A spokesman said Patrick Kerr, 37 years old, had been shot several times at close range.

title: TO PREVENT MAGGIEGATE
description: WASHINGTON A generation ago, when it was revealed in London that a Government minister named John Profumo had lied to Parliament, the Prime Minister honorably resigned.

title: STARS (MORE THAN 100) IN A GALA FOR ACTORS FUND
description: A $5.5-million extravaganza entitled ''Night of 100 Stars II'' took place at Radio City Music Hall last night, and as is often the case in show business, the title didn't spell out the half of it. The night seemed to go on interminably, a good portion of it more like a slowly paced dress rehearsal than a finished production. But by the time the evening ended, not 100 but some 300 stars of varying degrees of brilliance did their bit for an audience of 5,700 and for charity - in this case, the Actors Fund of America.

title: SUIT AGAINST CBS IS BEING DROPPED BY WESTMORELAND
description: Gen. William C. Westmoreland dropped his $120 million libel suit against CBS last night, the network announced.

title: THERE ARE BAD DOCTORS, BUT ALSO BAD LAWYERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Lakers Top Celtics
description: ''This is a new year,'' Magic Johnson said today after scoring 13 of his season-high 37 points in the fourth quarter to lead the Lakers to a 117-111 victory over the Boston Celtics in a battle of last spring's finalists. ''This game was important for our confidence, and it will do us good throughout the rest of the season.''

title: SUCCESS STORIES OF TWO GALLERIES IN EMERGING ART NEIGHBORHOODS
description: THE two art galleries could hardly be more different: One bustles like a department store, the other is quiet as a library. Visitors flock to one, trickle to the other. The art works in one are thick on the walls and floors, sometimes even stacked and piled, while in the other they are kept at a respectful distance, displayed like gems.

title: PIZZA CHAINS' TOUGHEST TURF
description: New York City has long been a kind of paradise for pizzerias. Even allowing for high commercial rents, hundreds of independent pizza shops have been thriving here, with high sales volume in very little space and profits that can reach 80 percent a pie.

title: NAZARETH SENIOR IS STANDOUT
description: Gary Gooden, the New York City scholastic scoring leader in football with 19 touchdowns last fall, scored two impressive sprint victories yesterday in the 58th annual Catholic High Schools Athletic Association indoor track and field championships at the 102d Engineers Armory.

title: Thrift Units' Insurance
description: The United States League of Savings Institutions asked the Federal Home Loan Bank board Friday to consider a plan that would increase the Federal savings and loan insurance fund by $9.5 billion.

title: Nuclear Views of Regulator
description: Peter A. Bradford, chairman of the Maine Public Utilities Commission, says that, contrary to the opinions of some people in the industry, he is not against nuclear power.

title: ASKS DEBT ACCORD
description: The United States has frozen economic aid to the Sudan, and other countries are curtailing their aid in an effort to press President Gaafar al-Nimeiry into overhauling his country's economy, American officials said today.

title: SPANISH EYES TURN TO A SECOND PILLAR OF HERCULES
description: Greek mythology held that Hercules opened the Strait of Gibraltar by parting the twin pillars at its entrance. Today the pillars are associated anew, this time in a tale of diplomatic irony and political fury.

title: MUSIC: ST. LUKE'S PLAYS AMERICANA
description: AMERICANS are so close to their own popular music that they have a difficult time gauging the hurricane force it exerts on 20th-century culture. The Netherlands had its great contrapuntists, the 17th century its blossoming of opera and the 19th its Romantic thrust - and indeed, it may not be presumptuous to imagine future scholars of the most ascetic cast speaking in similarly serious tones about Ellington, Basie, Monk and Paul Whiteman.

title: Walton Is Out
description: Bill Walton, the Los Angeles Clipper center who had been sidelined most of the last seven games with an ankle ailment, was placed on the injured list today. He was hurt in a game at Cleveland on Jan. 29. He had played in 40 consecutive games, his high as a pro, and was averaging 10.3 points.

title: Texas Plant Approved For Methyl Isocyanate
description: The Texas Air Control Board has given E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company permission to manufacture small amounts of methyl isocyanate at its plant in LaPorte, 25 miles from Houston.

title: SMALL HOMES AT LOW COST
description: In the early days of the Koch administration, officials believed they had happened upon an ingenious solution to at least part of the city's chronic housing problem.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: Merger Plan Under Fire
description: Malcolm Baldrige, Secretary of Commerce, faces more high-level flak over his proposal to join the Commerce Department and the office of the United States trade representative into an all- powerful Department of Trade.

title: BURGER CALLS FOR A NEW COURT
description: Citing the growing caseload of the Supreme Court, Chief Justice Warren E. Burger renewed his call today for the creation of an intermediate Federal court of appeals.

title: AMID SIDON'S JOY, A SETTLING OF SCORES BEGINS
description: The past caught up with Mohammed Habli here today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Perfect. It couldn't have gone better.'' - Dr. William C. DeVries, after implating an artificial heart.

title: BANK CREDIT RULINGS CAUSE CONCERN
description: Bankers, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and municipal bond lawyers are dismayed at recent Federal court decisions holding that banks' letters of credit may be obligations that are Government-insured for up to $100,000, like a deposit.

title: UP IS POSSIBLE, TOO
description: PARIS There is perverse comfort in the

title: MET PITCHING VULNERABLE
description: HE is not exactly a voice in the wilderness, but Manager Dave Johnson has hard words for everybody shouting that the Met millennium is here: ''Since last season, our pitching took a couple of steps back.''

title: Argentines to Get Aid In Identifying Missing
description: Two Americans are scheduled to arrive in Buenos Aires Tuesday to help train Argentine scientists for the exhumation and identification of the remains of perhaps thousands of victims of the former military junta's seven- year ''dirty war'' against the left and people it considered subversives.

title: Holiday Closings
description: The nation's stock and commodity exchanges are closed today in observance of Washington's Birthday. Banks and Government offices are also closed.

title: Impeachment as Sole Means to Remove Judges
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;   Fund Officer Fights Poison Pill' Plan
description: Michael Price, a vice president at the Mutual Shares Corporation, a no- load mutual fund, and T. Boone Pickens, the Texas oilman, have this in common: They do not like the ''poison pill'' method of blocking an unfriendly corporate takeover by making the target company's shares prohibitively expensive.

title: Brooks Denies Bid From North Stars
description: Herb Brooks, dismissed four weeks ago as coach of the Rangers, yesterday denied published reports that he would be joining the Minnesota North Stars as coach and general manager.

title: Bringing Women Into the Work Place
description: For 15 women at the Manhattan

title: MULLIN DIGS DOWN AGAIN
description: ON ''Wear Red Day'' at Alumni Hall yesterday, the St. John's spectators responded. They wore red blazers and red dresses, red sweaters and red skirts, red pants and red blouses, red ties and red hats, red socks and red shoes. And by halftime, even Chris Mullin was wearing something red - a red face. Or at least as red as his pasty white complexion will ever get.

title: Import-Quota Report Denied SANTA BARBARA, Calif.,
description: A White House

title: GEORGE WASHINGTON, ON TODAY'S ISSUES
description: Following are excerpts from George Washington's Farewell Address, presented as an editorial in The American Daily Advertiser on Sept. 19, 1796.

title: NEW PLANS TO EXPLOIT THE BEACH
description: Tanned, muscled and usually blond, the lifeguard has been a kind of folk hero to generations of adolescents growing up on the beaches of southern California.

title: BALLET: ANTWERP TROUPE OFFERS PANOV'S 'SISTERS'
description: VALERY PANOV'S ballet version of ''The Three Sisters'' opened the brief engagement of the Royal Ballet of Flanders from Antwerp in Whitman Hall at Brooklyn College Saturday night - and a sizable number of ballet fans were on hand for this New York premiere.

title: STAKING OUT PARKS TO STOP GRAFFITI
description: It was dusk and the blue sedan was parked under a large evergreen tree overlooking the newly renovated bandshell in Prospect Park in Brooklyn. Ted Schulz, a parks enforcement patrol supervisor, was squinting through binoculars at a man in a blue windbreaker lolling about near the benches.

title: Anyone Want Eagles?
description: The wheels are apparently in motion in various attempts to resolve the ownership problems of the Philadelphia Eagles. Lou Guida, an executive with Merrill Lynch in Lawrenceville, N.J., and an owner of standardbred horses, said that he had been reached by a lawyer who wondered if he would be interested in becoming involved with a group that would buy the Eagles from Leonard Tose for $70 million.

title: Starting Early
description: If genes count and starting early helps, it seems likely that Ashley Knight will be a contender on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour, but not for a while and only if she breaks a bad habit she's developed since she began putting a few months ago.

title: FORECLOSURES ON HOMES RISE AS INFLATION FALLS
description: The rate of home mortgage foreclosures has increased to a level close to the record set in the 1973 recession, causing anguish for tens of thousands of Americans evicted from homes for which they can no longer afford monthly payments.

title: Do We Need Grand Juries?
description: As he was quick to recall on becoming the new Chief Judge of New York and its Court of Appeals, Sol Wachtler has long favored eliminating grand juries from most felony cases. He thinks they operate more often as the prosecutor's pawn than the citizen's shield. They would ''indict a ham sandwich'' if the district attorney asked nicely, he says.

title: O'KOREN OUT UNTIL PLAYOFFS
description: The Nets, who had been getting all the right breaks lately, got a bad one Saturday night at the Garden. With Mike O'Koren out, probably until the end of the regular season, the team must begin the search for a replacement at forward.

title: Fire Dept. Faulted On Overtime Pay
description: The New York City Fire Department spent $2.7 million in unnecessary overtime in 1983, State Comptroller Edward V. Regan said in an audit released yesterday.

title: 21 on Trailer Die in India
description: A tractor-trailer rig plunged into a canal in southern India and 21 of the passengers it was carrying died, the Press Trust of India reported today.

title: Judge Rejects a Claim To Part of Dodge Estate
description: A judge has rejected a claim from a woman who said she was the long-lost Siamese twin of an heir to John F. Dodge, who sought part of his $40 million fortune.

title: ENDORSEMENT OF FARRELL SPLITS MINORITY CAUCUS
description: Eight thousand black and Hispanic people from throughout New York State gathered for an annual conference here this weekend, pledging unity yet clashing at times over the New York City mayoral race.

title: What's in a Name?
description: To the Editor:

title: KOREAN PRESIDENT SHAKES UP CABINET
description: President Chun Doo Hwan carried out a major reorganization of his Cabinet today, a week after a new opposition party made major gains in parliamentary elections.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: Fair. You will be hearing it again, and often. It just happens to be one of the best sweater collections in town, and it appeared virtually from nowhere at last week's Designers' Collective showing of fall fashions.

title: LAUTENBERG URGES CONTROL OF U.S. CHEMICAL INDUSTRY
description: Senator Frank R. Lautenberg called today for strict regulation of the chemical industry in the United States, asserting that it had demonstrated a ''potential for catastrophe'' greater than that posed by nuclear reactors.

title: EASY DRESSING FOR SUMMER
description: Summer is not a time for frills and furbelows. In warm weather, women want clothes that are cool and functional - clothes that do not get in the way, in colors that are quiet and unobtrusive.

title: ONE TRUFFLE TOO MANY
description: AFTER years of insisting upon a constant array of the world's most exquisite cuisines, it looks as if scores of Manhattan's rich pacesetters have finally had one too many truffles. They aren't living on hamburgers and french fries, but they are dining more simply, and talking homemade.

title: GETTING HUGHES BACK IN ORBIT
description: When the Pentagon halted payments to the Hughes Aircraft Company on several of its faltering missile and radar programs last summer, Hughes suffered more than a jolt to its reputation as a top-notch military supplier.

title: Carol Brice, 68, a Contralto Who Sang Many Lead Roles
description: Carol Brice, a leading concert contralto for more than two decades, died of cancer last Friday at her home in Norman, Okla. She was 68 years old.

title: EDUCATION ;   THE DISPARITY IN RESOURCES
description: EFFORTS by states to equalize the financial resources of school districts, a major goal of education reformers in the 1970's, have not significantly reduced the gap between the richest and poorest districts, according to school finance experts.

title: Market Place;   Another New Fund At Fidelity
description: FIDELITY INVESTMENTS, the

title: 23 ARE CHARGED ON L.I. AS THIEVES OF CABLE TV
description: A joint investigation by Long Island Cablevision and the Nassau County police resulted in the arrests of 23 owners of homes or businesses on charges of stealing cable television programs, it was announced today.

title: CHESS: GAME'S PRESSURE CAN LEAD TO OPENING THAT'S BUNGLED
description: How often does one hear after a game: ''I don't understand how I could have bungled the opening the way I did. I have played it dozens of times before and I know what's right.'' But it's not what you know in the quiet of your study amid tomes, pamphlets and periodicals on the openings that counts, but what you do under the pressure of play.

title: GUGGENHEIM MUSEUM PLANS TO ERECT AN 11-STORY, $12 MILLION ADDITION
description: The Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum plans to add an 11-story addition to its Frank Lloyd Wright-designed building on Fifth Avenue at 89th Street. The addition, which would cost $12 million, would rise as a slab behind the northern half of the present museum building, with a street entrance on East 89th Street. The architects are the firm of Gwathmey Siegel of New York City.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;   Pet Inc. Chairman Gets Posts at IC
description: -based company, has named Boyd F. Schenk president and chief operating officer. Mr. Schenk has been chairman and chief executive officer of Pet Inc., an IC unit. He will continue as Pet's chairman.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Knicks vs. Milwaukee Bucks, at Madison Square Garden, 7:30 P.M. The Bucks posted their 27th consecutive month of .500 or better ball in January with a 10-3 mark, and Sidney Moncrief, their high-scoring guard, is a prominent reason for that success.

title: CHINA BELITTLING VIETNAM'S ADVANCES IN CAMBODIA
description: The Chinese Government today dismissed recent Vietnamese advances against Cambodian guerrillas as militarily insignificant and said Vietnam would never fulfill its ''vicious aim of perpetual occupation'' of Cambodia.

title: Briton Killed in Germany
description: A British Harrier jump- jet and a West German Starfighter collided in midair today and crashed near the Dutch-West German border, killing the Harrier pilot, the police here said. A police spokesman said the West German pilot was unharmed and a second British pilot in the two-seat Harrier escaped serious injury after parachuting to safety.

title: Professor Seeking Columbus's Body
description: A university professor hopes to use atomic tracing methods on bones and teeth to find the remains of Christopher Columbus.

title: BUSINES DIGEST
description: TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 19, 1985

title: Louganis Wins Sullivan INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 18 (AP) - Greg Louganis, the 1984 Olympic
description: diving champion, won the Sullivan Award as the nation's outstanding

title: BRITISH OFFICIAL DENIES DECEPTION ON '82 SINKING OF ARGENTINE SHIP
description: Britain's Defense Secretary denied today that the Government had misled Parliament over the sinking of an Argentine cruiser during the war in the Falkland Islands, but critics persisted in asserting that there had been an official cover-up.

title: Chile Is Reported Ready To Allow Political Parties
description: A member of Chile's ruling junta said today that he had told a visiting American official that the military Government would legalize non-Marxist political parties this year.

title: Park Incubating Wild Condor Egg
description: A California condor egg plucked from its cliffside nest and taken to the San Diego Wild Animal Park for incubation and a captive breeding program should hatch a few days after Easter, a park spokesman says.

title: JAPAN CALM ABOUT YEN'S FALL
description: Although the dollar's strength has caused widespread concern in the United States, inflaming protectionist sentiments and draining corporate profits, the reaction is very different on this side of the Pacific.

title: FAILURE OF PLAN FOR HOMELESS REFLECTS CITY HOUSING CRISIS
description: For the last year and a half, New York City has offered 50,000 landlords bonuses of several thousand dollars for every additional apartment they rent to a homeless family.

title: Pacific Highway Rock Slide
description: The busy Pacific Coast Highway was closed for 12 hours by a rock slide Sunday. The highway was closed between Las Flores Canyon Road and Topanga Canyon Boulevard after the slide at 4:18 A.M. It reopened at 4:13 P.M.

title: VOTE OF APPROVAL FOR LIPTON TENNIS
description: The Lipton International Players Championships have survived their first test, although any assessment of the new tennis event must begin with the weather, which was one of the two major factors that Butch Buchholz, the tournament chairman, could not control. The other was player participation. John McEnroe and Jimmy Connors, the top two players in world, did not enter the tournament, which has Grand Slam ambitions.

title: View From Thailand
description: According to refugee and American Embassy officials in Bangkok, there have been persistent rumors for at least four months that Laotian refugees have been killed or shot at in attempts to turn back their boats on the Mekong River. Embassy officials say they have checked all such reports and found no evidence to substantiate them.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 19, 1985 International

title: WASTE IN HOUSING COSTS CITED
description: Pentagon auditors, tracing allegations that servicemen and landlords were defrauding a military housing program, have reported that taxpayers paid $49 million in unnecessary expenses in Alaska and Hawaii for two years.

title: 5 KILLED AS BLACKS NEAR CAPE TOWN BATTLE THE POLICE
description: At least five people were reported killed today and 60 injured as the police fought running battles with thousands of demonstrators in a packed squatter camp outside Cape Town.

title: 2 GERMANYS: A NEW CHILL
description: The two Germanys, which a year ago were single- mindedly striving to build a semblance of trust and detente in the heart of Europe, are feuding again.

title: 'BEST I COULD GET,' GENERAL ASSERTS
description: I figured it was the best I could get,'' Gen. William C. Westmoreland said yesterday in a private assessment that contrasted with his public proclamation of victory in the settlement of his libel suit against CBS. ''It was in essence an apology. One does not have to use the word. One apologizes in other ways.''

title: A MORAL CASE FOR 'STAR WARS'
description: President Reagan's proposed strategic defense, known popularly as ''Star Wars,'' promises to bring about a revolution in our national security policy in the next generation.

title: MIXED NEWS ON HEART PATIENTS
description: Reports on the progress of the third artificial heart recipient, Murray P. Haydon, were encouraging today, but the optimism was dampened by an unusually gloomy assessment of the progress of William J. Schroeder, the second recipient of an artificial heart.

title: HOUSE UNIT SETS TAKEOVER HEARINGS
description: A Congressional subcommittee announced yesterday that it would open hearings next week on the impact of corporate takeovers on the economy and shareholders, focusing on the current battle for the Phillips Petroleum Company.

title: Accounts
description: NBC News Division to Pearlman Rowe Kolomatsky.

title: BLINKA AMONG FIVE CUT BY THE GENERALS
description: Stan Blinka, a linebacker and a former Jet player, was dropped by the Generals today as the United States Football League's 14 teams reduced their rosters to 50 players each.

title: THREAT TO CHARGE UNION LEADERS FOR POLITICAL ACTS IS CONDEMNED
description: Labor leaders said today that the Reagan Administration was trying to ''silence free speech'' and harass union members by moving against the heads of the three biggest unions for Federal workers.

title: THE STAGE: 'HANG ON,' A CRYER-FORD REVUE
description: EVER since hitting pay dirt with ''Ain't Misbehavin','' the rollicking Fats Waller revue, the Manhattan Theater Club has been ransacking old song catalogues with the hope of concocting a worthy encore. The company has put on shows celebrating the work of Jule Styne, Harry Ruby and the team of Arthur Schwartz and Howard Dietz, among others, but to no lasting avail. Undaunted by failure - though apparently running out of fitting subjects - the M.T.C. has now sprung ''Hang On to the Good Times,'' a revue anthologizing the canon of Gretchen Cryer and Nancy Ford. Even if the modest Cryer-Ford output justified a retrospective, this misconceived entertainment would be counterproductive: One leaves the theater thinking less of the team's songs than one did upon arrival.

title: PATIENT MAN MAY FINALLY GET A CHANCE
description: There are days now when the change already appears to have taken place. Al Arbour did not direct the Islander practice at Cantiague Park today, Brian Kilrea did. And there are those who think Kilrea, brought in last fall as an assistant coach, will be the team's head coach as early as next season.

title: Chopping More Than Just Lunch
description: Four years ago the Reagan Administration cut $1.5 billion out of the school lunch program, which has for 40 years guaranteed schoolchildren at least one good meal a day. Middle- and upper-income parents wouldn't mind paying more, the Administration said; the schools would cope somehow with a subsidy reduction of 11 cents a meal.

title: DAY BY DAY;   When Tuition Was $250
description: When Oscar Byron went to college

title: VIDEO PRODUCERS DEBATE THE VALUE OF PRICE CUTS
description: In most video cassette outlets, it costs only $24.95 to buy ''Raiders of the Lost Ark'' and only $29.95 for ''Purple Rain,'' but a lot more for ''The Empire Strikes Back'' or for ''Tootsie.'' Just pennies less than $80, to be exact.

title: Transactions
description: Reached a contract agreement with Gary Redus, outfielder. METS (NL) - Reached an agreement with Dwight Gooden, right-handed pitcher, on a one-year contract.

title: BLOOD: A THREATENED RESOURCE EMERGES AS CORNERSTONE OF MEDICINE
description: DESPITE the announcement by Federal officials last week that the long-awaited AIDS blood test would be delayed at least until the end of next month, there still is a palpable sense of relief among many doctors and the public that a reliable test will soon be available.

title: MAINE WOODS NURTURE MOOSE COMEBACK
description: Biologists are completing the first intensive tally of a moose population boom that is being felt as far away as New York, as the once-endangered animal makes a comeback traced largely to the sprouting of new forests where old ones were cut down.

title: When a Community Becomes a Hospital Town
description: To the Editor:

title: Virginia Moves to Raise Drinking Age for Beer
description: The Virginia House of Delegates today approved and sent to the Governor a bill that would raise the legal drinking age for beer to 21 by 1987.

title: PLAYED KEY ROLES IN DEBT ACCORD
description: Argentina announced last night that Bernardo Grinspun, Economics Minister, and Enrique Garcia Vazquez, president of the central bank, had resigned, in a surprise move.

title: SUSPECT IS A PAROLED RAPIST
description: A 23-year-old Barnard College senior was beaten and raped in Riverside Park last night after a man with a knife accosted her as she was jogging and dragged her behind a clump of bushes, the police said.

title: Thatcher Sets Coal Talks
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher has scheduled talks for Tuesday with a delegation of labor leaders on Britain's 49-week-old coal strike. Later that day she leaves for Washington.

title: GOODEN AND METS AGREE ON TERMS
description: Dwight Gooden and the Mets reached agreement tonight on a one- year contract that will guarantee the 20-year-old strikeout pitcher $325,000 with the chance to earn $150,000 more in bonuses.

title: Andersen Suit Denial Issued
description: Arthur Andersen & Company denied today that it had been negligent in the work it performed for the DeLorean Motor Company's plant in Northern Ireland, as the British Government charged in a suit filed in Manhattan last week.

title: GRAFT CASE AND A CONSERVATIVE WIND, BUT 'STROLLER CITY' IS MUCH THE SAME
description: In this prosperous Cleveland suburb the streets are shady, the commuter trains are efficient and the schools are well protected.

title: Caledonian Posts Profit
description: The Caledonian Aviation Group announced today a record pretax profit of $17 million, compared with $3.6 million in 1983.

title: THAILAND SAID TO USE FORCE TO REBUFF LAOTION REFUGEES
description: A United States Senator and refugee experts here expressed concern today over what appears to be a Thai Government decision to use force to turn back Laotian refugees - including many who once fought in the C.I.A.'s ''secret army.''

title: Chief Executive Quits At Mission Insurance
description: The Mission Insurance Group, which has sustained heavy losses in its property and casualty business, said that Louis F. Marioni had resigned as president and chief executive officer.

title: CLUES HINT AT BRAIN'S 2 MEMORY MAPS
description: IRVINE, Calif.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Mike Rogers , the Ranger center who scored three goals and three assists in the victories over the Edmonton Oilers and the Islanders, has been named the league's player of the week. . . . The high jumper

title: JERSEY FIRE CODE EFFECTIVE TODAY
description: The state's new fire code, which goes into effect Tuesday, represents an advance in fire safety and gives New Jersey the toughest regulations in the country, officials said today.

title: Cavaliers Topple 76ers Again, 120-113
description: World B. Free tossed in 35 points today, leading the Cleveland Cavaliers to a 120-113 victory over the Philadelphia 76ers.

title: Lawmaker to Quit Congress For Position at a University
description: Representative G. William Whitehurst, Republican of Virginia, said today that he will not seek another term in Congress and will accept a teaching position here at Old Dominion University.

title: TWO GO ON TRIAL IN HOUSTON FOR ILLEGALLY HELPING ALIENS
description: Jury selection began today in the trial of two people accused of smuggling Central American aliens into this country.

title: 3 Celtics Out The Boston Celtics, who have been among the few teams not hit with many injuries this season, will be without three players, including two starters, at least through the road game against the Denver Nuggets Wednesday night.
description: Robert Parish , the 7-foot center;

title: HIS NOSE KEEPS GROWING
description: I don't know much about John C.

title: U.N. Expects 19 Relief Ships To Reach Ethiopia This Month
description: Nineteen ships carrying 133,000 metric tons of food aid, one-tenth of Ethiopia's total estimated relief needs for 1985, are expected to arrive by the end of this month, a United Nations official said today.

title: Finding Lebanon Terrorism Roots in Iran
description: To the Editor:

title: Grand Juries Work
description: If Permitted the Time

title: JAILS RUN BY PRIVATE COMPANY FORCE IT TO FACE QUESTION OF ACCOUNTABILITY
description: The growing trend toward privately operated jails has led to new questions about accountability and prisoners' rights that are being addressed every day by the Corrections Corporation of America, which operates detention facilities in Texas, Tennessee and North Carolina.

title: Action on Hunger Urged In Lenten Messages
description: Protestants and Roman Catholics were urged today to make world hunger and ''the crisis facing rural America'' the focus of their 40-day Lenten observance, starting with a nationwide peal of church bells on Ash Wednesday.

title: Strong Finish for Dollar
description: The dollar rebounded higher today near the close of foreign-exchange trading in Europe, but it was lower than most of the record levels set last week.

title: Debt
description: American International Group Inc., an insurance company, is offering $100 million of 10 5/8 percent, 5-year Eurobonds, at a price of 100, through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Co.

title: Fatal L.I. Fire Linked To Gasoline in Heater
description: Gasoline mistakenly poured into a kerosene heater has been blamed for a fire last Thursday in Wyandanch that killed seven children, the Suffolk County police said today.

title: NOO YAWK CITY FOUND FROM AFAR
description: Perhaps, as my friends say, it's my way of adjusting to small-town living. Perhaps it is penance for leaving a city that provided two decades of subsidized housing and four free years of college.

title: 25 REPUTED MEMBERS OF CHINATOWN GANG ARE CHARGED WITH RACKETEERING
description: Twenty-five members of a major youth gang in Chinatown were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on racketeering charges for crimes spanning more than a decade, officials said.

title: Bill Auction Begins After Holiday Delay
description: This week's auction of Treasury bills will be held today because the Government securities market was closed yesterday for the Presidents' Day holiday.

title: RAMS FINISH GAME AND ARMY
description: A bomb squad, armed with an explosives-sniffing dog, combed the gym before the game. Security guards, looking for more than smuggled beer, checked all packages at the door.

title: Tug McGraw Changes Lanes
description: When the phone rang in the bullpen during Tug McGraw's career with the Philadelphia Phillies and the Mets, he was always hoping to hear those three little words that only a relief pitcher would cherish:

title: RISKS IN LITIGATION
description: In some ways, the course of General William C. Westmoreland's battle against CBS, which concluded Sunday when his $120-million libel suit against the network was withdrawn, paralleled the tortured path of the war with which he is so closely identified. At the Federal District Courthouse in Manhattan as in Southeast Asia, General Westmoreland waged an expensive, time-consuming battle against a powerful adversary, whose strength he may have underestimated.

title: DAY BY DAY;   Mordant Edge
description: ''Poles have bitter jokes,'' observed

title: BRISCO-HOOKS LOSES TO PHOTO
description: The day after Valerie Brisco-Hooks was ruled the winner of the 400-meter race in the Vitalis/U.S. Olympic Invitational in Byrne Meadowlands Arena, Diane Dixon telephoned her coach to say that she, not Mrs. Brisco- Hooks, had won the race. Mrs. Brisco-Hooks's time had been recorded at 52.63 seconds, an American indoor best. Miss Dixon's time was recorded at 52.64.

title: A General Surrenders
description: General Westmoreland's quest for respect should never have been brought to court and his libel suit against CBS is wisely abandoned. Just a week from a jury judgment, the general surrendered to the evidence that whether or not his superiors in Washington were in fact deceived, he and some of his aides in Vietnam in 1967 manipulated the estimates of enemy strength, apparently for political effect.

title: Reading
description: The book currently commanding

title: ABOUT TOWN: SKIRTS FOR MEN
description: Not a word need be spoken for the initial reaction to come through, loud and clear: ''What have we here, men in skirts?''

title: GUILE AND DECEPTION: THE EVOLUTION OF ANIMAL COURTSHIP
description: -toothed tigers have such large teeth? What was the function of the bizarre crests on the heads of male dinosaurs? Why did the Irish elk have such huge antlers? And for what purpose do male peacocks have such gaudy tails and lions those flowing manes?

title: The U.N. Today
description: Feb. 19, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: 'Star Wars' Plan Criticized
description: West Germany's main opposition leader added his voice today to the criticism of President Reagan's ''Star Wars'' proposal. Hans-Jochen Vogel, parliamentary leader of the Social Democratic Party, told NATO ambassadors at a lunch in Brussels that he shared ''the skepticism voiced in Paris and London'' about the proposed space- based antimissile research.

title: Books: Iwo Jima
description: IWO JIMA. Legacy of Valor. By Bill D.

title: 'DISAPPEARING WORLD' ON CHANNEL 13
description: ''DISAPPEARING WORLD'' is a throwback, a reminder of the old days of educational television. We watch; a narrator informs. The television ethos is austere. In fact, this has its own reward: little separates viewer from subject. We make our own judgments as we see fit.

title: Warsaw Official Links Union Figures to C.I.A.
description: The Interior Ministry's top investigator says he has evidence linking people in the outlawed Solidarity labor movement with Western intelligence operations, including the C.I.A.

title: CASHING IN ON THE OLD GIVE-AND-GO
description: Bob Brooke played center for the first time in his Ranger career Sunday night. And right away, things looked different.

title: DAY BY DAY;   For the Brooklyn Tour, Only a Little Bit Extra
description: In the city that assured ''chutzpah'' a

title: Advertising;   Combating An Image Problem
description: MEDIA GENERAL BROADCAST SERVICES, whose chief business is obtaining broadcast time and print space for advertisers at discount rates, is in the midst of an advertising campaign for itself.

title: Loans Abroad Were Cut Back BASEL, Switzerland, Feb. 18
description: (Reuters) - American banks

title: 'Goat Gap Chili'
description: James S. Brady, the White House

title: A REAL BIG LEAGUER IN THE MONEY GAME
description: Michael Anthony he is not, but Arvid Anderson can now say that he, too, once gave away a million dollars.

title: RECITAL: EDITH MATHIS SINGS
description: THE soprano Edith Mathis presented an engaging program of songs by Schubert, Brahms, Clara Schumann and Hugo Wolf at Carnegie Hall on Sunday afternoon.

title: NOCTURNAL PRIMATE ;   Nocturnal Primate
description: Using her keen hearing and an infrared spotting scope, a Duke University biologist has trooped through the forests of Peru and Paraguay in the dark of the night in search of clues to the little-known behavior of the night monkey, also called the owl monkey, which is believed to be the world's only nocturnal higher primate.

title: Out of Spotlight
description: A college quarterback whose career passing statistics are not far behind Doug Flutie's is waiting patiently for the National Football League draft on April 30, and is content not to have to experience the hoopla and pressure that have dogged Flutie for the last few months.

title: Trade Talks Seen Likely
description: Increasing United States calls for reduction of European trade barriers, mainly in agriculture, will likely lead to discussion of the issue by leaders of major industrial nations at the Bonn economic summit conference in May, Daniel Amstutz, United States Under Secretary of Agriculture, said today.

title: SCIENCE WATCH ;   Telescope in Mothballs
description: The 100-inch telescope on Mount Wilson that for 30 years dominated astronomy as the world's largest is to be mothballed on July 1.

title: John Jay Gains in City U. Tourney
description: Chris Hughes scored 31 points and Courtney Callender got 24 as John Jay took the initial step toward winning its first title by eliminating Medgar Evers, 112-92, yesterday in the 20th City University of New York basketball tournament. Jay's 112 points were a tournament record.

title: HONORING WHATSHISNAME
description: George Washington's birthday is Feb. 22, but the Federal Government has decreed that it will be officially celebrated along with Lincoln's birthday on the third Monday of February as Presidents Day.

title: CANADA CONSITUTION LOOMS AS QUEBEC ISSUE
description: The right of Quebec Province to veto changes in the Canadian Constitution - a document that Quebec has yet to sign - is looming as a potential issue in the next provincial elections.

title: U.S. Lawyers' Group Critical Of Racism Around the World
description: The American Bar Association voted overwhelmingly today to oppose racism around the world, particularly South Africa's use of apartheid to enforce the separation of the races.

title: CREDIT MARKETS ;   Fed's Policy Report Awaited
description: Although many economists are predicting higher interst rates by summer or year-end, fears that the Federal Reserve was encouraging a quick rise in rates have subsided.

title: ON HARD DISKS, MESSINESS WON'T WORK
description: IF the truth must be told, the

title: STAGE: WYLIE'S 'RUDE TIMES'
description: STEPHEN WYLIE'S ''Rude Times'' is a lifeless dirge about the death of an old man, a bare-cupboard geriatric drama at the American Place Theater. Eighty-two and alone, the old man (Tom McDermott) has checked into a Y.M.C.A. and is steadfastly refusing all attempts at ameliorating his loneliness.

title: Topics Changes of Nature
description: Child NeglectThe Federal Government recently squandered an opportunity to contribute to the well-being of children who attend day-care centers. Asked by Congress to draft guidelines for states sharing Federal child-care training funds, the Department of Health and Human Services concerned itself only with the prevention and detection of sexual abuse.

title: Report Sought On Bank Case BOSTON, Feb. 18 (AP) - A
description: House banking subcommittee

title: DOLLAR'S STRENGTH PERSISTS
description: Deaf to the entreaties of governments around the world, the American dollar continues to surge. Making sharp gains yesterday in active European trading, it resumed the spurt of the past two weeks in which it repeatedly broke its own records.

title: SQUEEZE IS ON, AND REPUBLICANS ARE SQUIRMING
description: In the dense cloud of mind-boggling billion- dollar statistics swirling around the Federal budget debate, one simple number stands out. It is 22, the number of Senate seats held by Republicans that will be up for re-election next year.

title: THATCHER TO PRESS ARMS ISSUES IN U.S. VISIT
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher flies to Washington on Tuesday, determined to press President Reagan to do everything possible to make a success of the arms control talks with the Soviet Union that are to open in Geneva on March 12.

title: Tough Requirements
description: Elroy Hirsch , the Wisconsin athletic director, blamed the school's tough entrance requirements for the Badgers' poor basketball record. He said only Northwestern, which is last in the Big Ten, had tougher admission standards than Wisconsin, which is ninth. ''All I ask you to do is compare the entrance requirements of Wisconsin with other schools and that's the major problem we have here,'' Hirsch said.

title: A JOINT STATEMENT ENDS LIBEL ACTION BY WESTMORELAND
description: Gen. William C. Westmoreland and CBS ended their libel suit yesterday with a joint statement that expressed the network's respect for the general's ''long and faithful service to his country'' and the general's esteem for CBS's ''distinguished journalistic tradition.''

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: MUSICAL MEMORIES The exhibitions at the New York Public Library at Lincoln Center, which is sandwiched between the Metropolitan Opera and the Beaumont Theater, are always a treat. It is a library that specializes in performing arts, and it is modern, light and spacious.

title: MUBARAK URGES U.S. TO REVIVE SUDANESE AID
description: President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt said today that the United States was wrong to withhold financial aid from the Sudanese until they straightened out their economy. He said he would recommend that the decision be reversed when he visits Washington next month.

title: SHIITE RADICALS THRONG TO SIDON FOR A BIG RALLY
description: Thousands of armed Shiite Moslem fundamentalists calling for an Islamic republic in Lebanon drove into Sidon today for their own celebration of the weekend Israeli withdrawal.

title: SPYING AT THE U.N.: MEMOIR RAISES AN OLD SPECTER
description: A memoir by a Soviet defector has rekindled a debate in the corridors of the United Nations Secretariat over the extent to which an independent civil service is possible within a world body of sovereign states.

title: PRESS CAUTIOUSLY HAILS WESTMORELAND'S WITHDRAWAL OF LIBEL SUIT
description: Television, newspaper and magazine executives yesterday applauded Gen. William C. Westmoreland's decision to drop his libel suit against CBS and said the outcome affirmed that journalists should examine public issues without having to fear legal action.

title: WHEN A COMMUNITY BECOMES A HOSPITAL TOWN
description: To the Editor:

title: VIETNAM TO COURTROOM
description: Gen. William C. Westmoreland, who was commander of United States forces in Vietnam from 1964 to 1968, filed a $120 million libel suit in 1982 against CBS over a documentary that stated that his command conspired to underestimate reports of enemy troop strength before the Tet offensive of January 1968. Here are some of the events that led to the lawsuit, which General Westmoreland formally ended on Sunday night.

title: FLYERS TROUNCE PENGUINS, 8-2
description: Thomas Eriksson started a flurry of four goals in less than five minutes in the first period as the Philadelphia Flyers defeated the Pittsburgh Penguins, 8-2, today for their fifth consecutive victory.

title: ITS LEASE OF INDIAN LAND EXPIRING, A CITY WORRIES ABOUT THE FUTURE
description: In front of the veterans cemetery in this once bustling river city stands a 6-foot- high stone memorial to an officer who led several raids in a 1779 expedition dispatched by George Washington to wipe out the region's Indians.

title: LABOR AND MONDALE: A SHOW OF LOYALTY
description: The decision to invite Walter F. Mondale, the defeated Democratic Presidential candidate, to speak to labor leaders here demonstrates the laudable goal of loyalty to longtime friends, the leaders say. It would be wrong, they and their staff members say, to interpret Mr. Mondale's appearance today as meaning that the labor movement did not learn from his defeat last fall.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''People with esthetic tastes are constantly losing and this will be a beautiful place to look at.

title: New Chairman Chosen At Dominion Resources
description: William W. Berry will become chairman of Dominion Resources Inc. and its Virginia Electric and Power Company subsidiary, the company said. He will succeed T. Justin Moore Jr., 59, who is retiring May 1.

title: Martin Levine Is Dead at 75; Headed Movie Theater Chain
description: Martin Levine, an active figure in New York's motion picture industry for more than 50 years, died of a heart attack Sunday at St. Mary's Hospital in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 75 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: ;   Lincoln Did Not So Much Choose the War as Accept It
description: To the Editor:

title: LINCOLN DID NOT SO MUCH CHOOSE THE WAR AS ACCEPT IT
description: To the Editor:

title: Of Black Courage
description: Lena Ferguson, a descendant of a

title: Mars Picks Leo Burnett
description: Mars Inc., the worldwide marketer known primarily for its candy products, has selected a third ad agency just as promised. But the surprise is that the agency is the Leo Burnett Company, the Chicago giant, which most people would have considered out of the running because it already had assignments from the Nestle Company.

title: NANCY HAMILTON, LYRICIST, 76, DIES
description: Nancy Hamilton, one of the first women to succeed as a lyricist on Broadway and the producer of an Academy Award-winning documentary on the life of Helen Keller, died yesterday at her home in New York City. She was 76 years old and had been ill for a long time.

title: Fairness on the Air
description: To the Editor:

title: Russians Are a Political Reality in the Mideast
description: To the Editor:

title: WILLIAM J. SUNSHINE
description: William J. Sunshine, a former associate producer of CBS-TV's ''60 Minutes'' and a partner in the Television Design Group, a video and print production company, died of heart failure Friday at Cabrini Medical Center after suffering a stroke. He was 46 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: The Screams at the Border
description: It is no new fastidiousness about American customs regulations that's producing those ghastly long automobile searches along the Mexican border. The searches are an exigency of war - the undeclared war between Latin American drug rings and United States drug enforcement authorities.

title: Craxi and Peres Meet; No Mideast Plan Seen
description: Prime Minister Bettino Craxi of Italy told Prime Minister Shimon Peres of Israel tonight that the time was not yet right for a new Middle East peace initiative.

title: EUROPEAN SOFTWARE AGREEMENT
description: Six European computer makers announced today that they had adopted a software operating system based on one developed by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

title: Nevada Votes on Estate Tax
description: The state Senate unanimously approved a bill today that would pave the way for Nevada to become the last state to pick up its share of the Federal estate tax. Nevada is currently the only state that does not allow itself to be reimbursed for the estate tax paid to the Federal Government by a state's citizens.

title: SCIENCE MAGAZINES FROM U.S. THRIVE IN SOVIET AND CHINA
description: EACH month, 20,000 Russian language copies of Scientific American magazine are snapped up as soon as they hit the streets in the Soviet Union. In Peking, the circulation of Discover magazine, published in the United States by Time Inc., is expected to go above 100,000 by 1986. In Shanghai 50,000 translated copies of the American publication Science News are printed each week.

title: PROUD TRUTH WINS BY A NECK
description: John Veitch, who spent much of the last two years saddling a horse that kept running second to 3-year-olds trained by Woody Stephens, finally turned the tables today with a different colt. He sent out Proud Truth to score by a neck over the Stephens- trained Stephan's Odyssey in the $159,380 Fountain of Youth Stakes for 3-year-olds at Gulfstream Park in a race that stamped the top two finishers as top contenders for the Kentucky Derby on May 4.

title: Bank of Boston to Keep HBM/Creamer
description: After reviewing agencies, the Bank of Boston, which admitted earlier this month that it had failed to file required reports on $1.22 billion in international cash shipments, has decided to stick with HBM/Creamer.

title: HOURS-OLD INFANT FOUND IN BASEMENT
description: A girl believed to be a half-hour to 3 hours old was found yesterday at 11 A.M. in the basement of a building at 1545 Archer Road, near Guerlain Street, in the Parkchester apartment development in the eastern Bronx.

title: Required Reading;   What Taxes Are
description: Representative Andrew Jacobs Jr., Democrat of Indiana, calls it ''tax simplification,'' this essay by Heather Taylor of Indianapolis:

description: Herb Brooks will likely join the North Stars in some capacity next season, but the club has not approached the former Ranger coach about taking over this season, Minnesota's general manager,

description: ''I'm just a country boy,'' Edward I.
