description: Q.

title: Mexicans Seek Refuge In Texas After Riot
description: Eighteen Mexicans sought refuge in Texas today, saying they feared police reprisals after a violent political demonstration near the international bridge on the United States-Mexico border.

title: PORTABLE SCREEN FOR APPLE
description: APPLE introduced its IIc model last year as ''the cuddliest computer we have ever designed.'' But the nine-inch monochrome monitor that goes with the IIc is anything but cuddly, especially if one is trying to tote the whole system from the home to the office or dorm and back. Unlike the sleek and lightweight IIc computer, which fits easily into a briefcase- sized carrying case, the monitor is about as portable as a bowling ball.

title: Back to School
description: After winning 151 games as head coach at Temple from 1973 to 1982, Don Casey yearned to get a taste of professional basketball. He was assistant to Paul Westhead in Chicago for one season.

title: A TOO-LONG NIGHT OF 100-PLUS STARS
description: Somewhere past the midway point of ''The Night of 100 Stars II'' at Radio City Music Hall on Sunday night - a show that began, theoretically, at 7 P.M. and ended at 2 A.M. yesterday - some of the more restless members of the audience became vocal. They had, by that time, waited one hour for the show to begin, sat through repeat performances of several segments, endured 10- and 15- minute intervals between acts and, at times, had their view partially blocked by television cameras.

title: TEXTS OF STATEMENTS ON THE END OF WESTMORELAND'S LIBEL SUIT AGAINST CBS
description: Following are the texts of a joint statement by Gen. William C. Westmoreland and CBS, a CBS statement after General Westmoreland announced that he was ending his libel suit and a statement by General Westmoreland that were made public yesterday. The joint statement, dated Feb. 17, was signed by General Westmoreland; George Vradenburg 3d, the CBS general counsel; Mike Wallace, a CBS correspondent, and George Crile 3d, a CBS producer.

title: A LOCAL BEER NOT FOR EVERYONE
description: SOME of history's most momentous discoveries have

title: Amputee Athlete Ends Coast-to-Coast Run
description: A 22-year-old athlete who lost his right leg to cancer as a child finished a run across the United States today with a dousing of champagne and a jubilant leap into the Pacific Ocean.

title: U.S. Customs Releases Seized Colombian Plane
description: Customs officers released an Avianca Airlines jet today after the Colombian airline agreed to post a $1.98 million bond, to cover the maximum possible fine for carrying more than a ton of cocaine into the United States.

title: CONCERT: CHAMBER MUSIC SOCIETY
description: AN American tribute to the French jazzman Django Reinhardt and a visit from a distinguished French oboist provided most of the interest at the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center's concert Sunday afternoon at Alice Tully Hall.

title: G.O.P. SENATOR SUGGESTS CUTTING MILITARY JOBS TO SAVE $21 BILLION
description: Senator Warren B. Rudman has developed a plan to bring down the Pentagon budget by $21.2 billion over the next three years, mainly by cutting 180,000 support positions from the Defense Department.

title: SMITHSONIAN CONSIDERS A MAGAZINE ON BLACKS
description: Sometime this spring, the Smithsonian Institution plans to decide whether to go ahead with what has been a closely guarded project: the publication of a magazine on the history, art, literature and music of American blacks.

title: A New Act For Mr. Baseball
description: Bob Uecker, who has constructed a comedy career based on his futility as a major league catcher from 1962 to 1967, is about to try a new phase of show business.

title: KOCH, IN WAHINGTON, HAS PRAISE FOR CUOMO
description: Once a political rival, sometimes a political ally.

title: CBS NEWS RELIEVED OF BURDEN OF SUIT
description: CBS News began work today for the first time in three years relieved of the burden of defending the integrity of its 1982 documentary on Vietnam troop strength.

title: McKenna Joins Nets
description: As expected, the Nets signed

title: LOW DRAMA AT DAYTONA 500
description: In 1955, Pierre Levegh's Mercedes-

title: Business and the Law;   Wide Debate Over N.L.R.B.
description: CHICAGO
CULTURE AS HISTORY. The Transformation of American Society in the

title: G.E. Workers Still on Strike
description: About 5,000 employees struck the General Electric Company's jet engine plant for a fourth day today, but 9,000 salaried workers crossed picket lines to work.

title: GROWING FALCON INQUIRY SPURS ARRESTS IN CANADA
description: Nineteen people were arrested in Canada yesterday in connection with illegal trafficking in birds of prey, Canadian officials said. The arrests were an outgrowth of a three-year inquiry by the United States Fish and Wildlife Service in which Canada cooperated.

title: Louis J. Laventhol, Founder Of Accounting Concern, Dies
description: Louis J. Laventhol, a founder in 1923 of the accounting concern that is now Laventhol & Horwath, died of heart failure Thursday in San Diego. He was 86 years old and lived in Philadelphia.

title: BRIDGE: FORCING DECLARER TO TRUMP ISN'T ALWAYS A GOOD MOVE
description: Since ''force or draw out'' is one of the dictionary meanings of the word ''pump'' it is not surprising that it has become the most popular bridge colloquialism for forcing an opponent to trump. Pumping the declarer is nearly always a good move, but the diagramed deal represents an exception of a very unusual type.

title: Doris Hering Is Named Winner of Dance Award
description: Doris Hering, executive director of the National Association for Regional Ballet, will receive the 34th Capezio Award.

title: ONE MAN'S EFFORTS CONSERVE CATSKILLS VALLEY
description: Eight years ago, a tall, thin, soft-spoken man who has dedicated his life to conservation causes came here to a beautiful valley that is pierced by the legendary Beaverkill. He fell in love with what he saw, so he bought a stretch of riverbank.

title: Pennzoil Plugs Well Off Tunisia
description: The Pennzoil Company said it had plugged and abandoned its first exploratory well off Tunisia. The Selim No. 1 well on a 250-square-mile tract in the Mediterranean Sea was tested last October and plugged and abandoned at a total depth of 11,234 feet.

title: Need for Electronic Banking Grows in Germany
description: The order for 1,000 leather jackets took about six minutes to clatter across the telex machine of Dae Woo Handels G.m.b.H., the $100 million-a-year West German trading arm of South Korea's big Dae Woo manufacturing concern.

title: FEDERAL AID POLICY AND U.S. COLLEGES
description: IN his first news conference as

title: FORCES BENEATH THE PACIFIC
description: ONE of the earliest and most dramatic demonstrations of the process in which the motion of great plates of the earth's surface constantly alters the world's geography was recognition that the Hawaiian chain has been formed by movement of the Pacific floor over a ''hot spot'' within the Earth. Its volcanic eruptions have produced the islands one by one.

title: KEY BISHOP DEFENDS VATICAN ON DISAPPROVAL OF CATECHISM
description: The decision to remove the official Roman Catholic seal of approval from a popular adult catechism, ''Christ Among Us,'' was carefully considered and not spurred by conservative pressure, a leading bishop said today.

title: 4 More Signings Four baseball players -
description: Jay Howell of Oakland,

title: DANCE: THE ROYAL BALLET OF FLANDERS
description: ON its previous visits to New York, the Royal Ballet of Flanders has always seemed amiable. Yet there have been times when its dancing was spirited without being stylish, and its repertory has been uneven. Now, the company has a new director in Valery Panov, and Mr. Panov has appointed Woytech Lowski ballet master. If it is still too early to appraise these changes, it certainly can be said the group from Antwerp, Belgium, gave a pleasant program on Sunday afternoon at Brooklyn College.

title: People
Once More With Feeling
description: Sometimes timing can be everything. Last year the Center on

title: THE END OF THE LINE
description: Why should the Reagan Administration, even with its self- created budget crisis, kill a 24,000-mile rail passenger system that carried 20 million travelers last year - including 60 percent of air-rail traffic in the New York-Washington corridor?

title: MUSIC: BLACK WRITERS
description: AN afternoon of music by black composers that says little about black music seems an arbitrary kind of affair. Thus in Selma Epstein's piano recital at Merkin Concert Hall on Sunday we heard six men and women spanning three centuries and for the most part paying homage to European models but remaining tight-lipped about themselves.

title: Quarterly Net Declines 10.8% at JWT Group
description: The JWT Group released its fourth- quarter financial statement yesterday and it featured increased revenues and a decline in net income, which it explained was due to an ''increase in business development spending,'' higher payroll costs and the continuing strength of the dollar.

title: STARTS IN HOUSING UP 14.9%
description: Housing construction in January jumped 14.9 percent from December, for its biggest rise in 20 months, the Commerce Department said today.

title: WINE TALK
description: EVERY comedian wants to play Hamlet and every tragedian wants to be Punchinello. And why not? Take New York's wine makers. For a century and a half, they had a nice little thing going, turning out rivers of sparkling wine and a variety of still wines that, while no match for the wines of California and France, had built a loyal following in the Northeast, in the Ohio Valley and - for some of the Concord - in Puerto Rico and the Dominican Republic.

title: BOBBIE BROOKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 26
description: b-After a charge of $62,000 from the reversal of tax credit.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Aerojet General Corp. , La Jolla, Calif., a manufacturer of aerospace products, has named W.M. Necoechea vice president-finance.

title: ICAHN FILES LIST CITING $1.5 BILLION OF FINANCING
description: Carl C. Icahn, who is trying to take over the Phillips Petroleum Company, yesterday filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a list of about 40 institutions that are providing him with $1.5 billion of financing for his tender offer, his lawyers said. The filing of the list appeared to be an effort to counter repeated assertions by Phillips that Mr. Icahn lacks the financing he needs.

title: PHIBRO-SALOMON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After special charges of $224,000,000. c-Net income which is after special charges of $7,000,000.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;   Partnership Investment Registers a Decline
description: Investments in publicly registered limited partnerships declined 1.2 percent last year, to about $8.25 billion, the first drop in eight years, according to Robert A. Stanger & Company, a Shrewsbury, N.J., investment research firm.

title: DYNAMICS RESEARCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: All share earnings were restated to reflect 5-for-4 stock split last October.

title: DUAL-LITE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $142,000 on the disposal of discontinued operations for the quarter and 6 months. c-After a loss of $356,000 on the disposal of discontinued operations for the quarter and 6 months. The after-tax losses from the disposal of discontinued operations relate to New England circuits, which was discontinued in 1982.

title: Transactions
description: Ed Jurak, infielder, agreed to one-year contract. CINCINNATI (NL) - Signed Eric Davis, outfielder, and Wade Rowdon, infielder. DETROIT (AL) - Signed Roger Craig as scout and special minor league instructor.

title: Georgia Makes Bond Offering A $145.6 million issue of
description: Georgia's general obligtion

title: THE DANCE: BASAEL BALLET IN BROOKLYN
description: THE BASEL BALLET from Switzerland has brought us a ''Coppelia'' with a new wrinkle. No more Carpathian or Galician folk doing their czardas or mazurka while the heroine teaches the hero that artifice should not be mistaken for true love.

title: REDMEN TO FACE EAGLES' CHALLENGE
description: For all the inspiration of its victory over DePaul last Sunday, St. John's faces a Boston College team tonight that has been on a vigorous crusade of its own.

title: CASTLE, A M & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SAVANNAH FOODS & INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $7,365,000 from discontinued operations.

title: MINE SAFETY APPLIANCES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CENTRAL PENNSYLVANIA SAVINGS ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $176,960 from the distribution of the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. preferred stock for the quarter and 9 months. c-No per share earnings are available because the company went public in March 1984.

title: FILM: DANISH 'LADIES'
description: ''LADIES ON THE ROCKS,'' Christian Braad Thomsen's Danish film that opens today at the Film Forum, is a sweet, sort of pint-sized ''Entre Nous,'' about the friendship of two women - aspiring cabaret performers - and their adventures when they take their show on the road. For a feminist movie whose events are often very forlorn, ''Ladies on the Rocks'' is surprisingly cheerful.

title: Chamber Music Concert
description: A free performance of chamber works by Bartok, Henry Cowell, Daniel Gregory Mason and Edward Varese will be presented by the National Orchestra of New York on Feb. 26 at 8 P.M. at McMillin Theater, Columbia University, Broadway and 116th Street. The concert is the first of two free performances sponsored by the university's Fritz Reiner Center for Contemporary Music since its inception last October. The second concert will be on March 1 and will feature music by Edward MacDowell, Douglas Moore, Bartok and Varese.

title: Warning to Pilots From Pan Am
description: Pan American World Airways has warned that it would furlough 299 pilots and shrink its fleet if its pilot union does not accept reductions in 27 percent pay raises that were due them on Dec. 31.

title: GOSPEL: WOMACK AT 80
description: THE Rev. Daniel Womack from Roanoke, Va., and the Fairfield Four from Nashville, Tenn., have been performing jubilee songs since the 1920's. Sunday, they sang and preached the gospel at the Alternative Museum.

title: Player Guilty of Rape
description: Percy Moorman, a North Carolina State freshman quarterback, was found guilty yesterday of raping a female student. Moorman, who was also found guilty of second-degree sexual offense and misdemeanor breaking and entering, is to be sentenced today. He will appeal.

title: DANCE: ALAN GOOD DUETS
description: THE two works choreographed by Alan Good that were presented Monday night at the Merce Cunningham Studio were billed as duets. But for a long time ''The Never Elegant'' was a solo for Francesca Antonini to a softly sighing and humming electronic score by David Meschter. Then it became a solo for Mr. Good.

title: Mortgage Suit Claims Fraud
description: The National Mortgage Equity Corporation, in a suit filed today in Federal District Court, said it was a victim in the mortgage-related scandal that has cost the Bank of America $95 million.

title: WENDY'S INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NEW FRONTIERS FOR YOUNG RESTAURATEURS
description: A FEW years ago John Rossi and his wife, Judyann, would stroll around the city's more elegant neighborhoods and imagine owning a glossy restaurant with a fancy address. Instead, they settled on a homey, $1,000-a-month basement at 317 East Fifth Street and wheeled their secondhand Garland stove up from the Bowery themselves. A year ago, the Rossis opened the doors of the Cafe at Pete's Place, where the food has since received good notices from both restaurant reviewers and the officers from the Ninth Precinct next-door. Their initial investment was $20,000.

title: CRAWFORD ENERGY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FOOD PROCESSOR-BLENDER
description: WITH kitchen equipment, as with automobiles and novels, bigger is not necessarily better. Today's technology can pack impressive power and versatility into small appliances, as illustrated by the attractive and space-saving blender-food processor pictured here, called Rolli, made by the Italian company Bialetti. The company calls it a blender but it really is just as much a small food processor.

title:
Careers;

Computer Jobs Rise At Schools
German Economy Lags
description: The coldest winter in more than 20 years is slowing West Germany's economy and record unemployment probably will persist through February, the Economics Ministry said today. The ministry said it did not expect any significant decline this month in the number of unemployed West Germans, which rose to a record 10.6 percent of the labor force in January. The Federal Labor Office said 2,619,400 West Germans were out of work in January, up by 294,200 from December.

title: EVANGELICAL POP A HIT OF THE RECORD BUSINESS
description: Contemporary pop music with evangelical Christian lyrics is one of the fastest-growing segments of the American recording industry.

title: CRADDOCK-TERRY SHOE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an estimated loss on the disposal of discontinued operations of $650,000. c-Net income after income from discontinued operations of $55,000. The 1983 results were restated to reflect discontinued operations.

description: b-Includes extraordinary gains of $1,712,000 for the quarter and $9,103,000 for the year. c-Includes extraordinary gains of $1,790,000 fo the quarter and $6,613,000 for the year, gains from the sale of discontinued operations of $2,500,000 for the quarter and $3,750,000 for the year, and a loss of $2,500,000 for the year from the discharge of an obligation. Share earnings for the latest year reflect 4,400 warrants that were common stock equivalents during the second half. Results for the latest year include the operations of Regis from May 17, the date of acquisition.

title: Economic Scene;   Washington The Economist
description: IN his Farewell Address, George Washington urged the nation to avoid ''the accumulation of debt, not only by shunning occasions of expense, but by vigorous exertions, in time of peace, to discharge the debts which unavoidable wars may have occasioned, not ungenerously throwing upon posterity the burden which we ourselves ought to bear.''

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Different Goat Cheeses

title: Peter Hofmann to Sing 'Meistersinger' at Met
description: Peter Hofmann, the German tenor, will return to the Metropolitan Opera this season to sing the role of Walther von Stolzing in Wagner's ''Meistersinger von N"urnberg.''

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: THE liver is one of the most versatile parts of a chicken and can be used in p^ates and terrines, in rice dishes and in scores of main courses. A favorite preparation calls for dipping the livers in seasoned flour and then cooking them in oil until crisp and browned. They are then served in a sauce consisting of a dry red wine, chopped vegetables and seasonings.

title: NEW CONCERN FOR LOBSTERS
description: An increase in the number of clawless and one-clawed lobsters turning up in fishermen's traps is hurting New England dealers.

title: Intel to Lay Off 900 Indefinitely
description: The Intel Corporation, citing sluggishness in the semiconductor industry, said it planned to lay off 900 workers indefinitely, including 500 at plants in the Portland area.

title: Inquiry on Giants
description: The National Football League Players Association will investigate reports that the Giants conducted regular urinalyses on players suspected of using illegal drugs or alcohol, the union's executive director said.

title: CTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income after losses from discontinued operations of $2,371,000 for the quarter and $2,664,000 for the year. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $7,604,000 and a loss of $20 million on the disposal of discontinued operations.

title: STORER COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $2,884,000 from the sale of cable systems. c-Net loss after a loss of $1,276,000 on the writeoff of an investment and a loss of $264,000 on the sale of two cable systems.

title: People
World Bank Sets $500 Million Offer
description: The World Bank is offering $500 million of undated floating-rate notes in the Eurodollar market that have no final maturity but may be redeemed by investors. Sales of perpetual notes are unusual, though Sweden and the National Westminster Bank arranged similar financings last year.

title: MCA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Milwaukee Rail Sale Is Still On
description: A Federal appeals court rejected a request from Chicago Milwaukee Corporation stockholders to block sale of the bankrupt Milwaukee Road's freight operations to the Soo Line Railroad Company.

title: COMMUNICATIONS CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BASEBALL OWNERS MAKE PROPOSALS
description: Representatives of baseball's club owners made proposals in nine areas in a negotiating session with the players' representatives in Manhattan yesterday. The areas included maximum salary cut, termination pay, injuries not related to playing and players' rights to veto or demand a trade.

title: CAPITAL HOLDING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After net realized investment losses of $6,433,000 for the quarter and $6,612,000 for year. c-After net realized investment losses of $8,925,000 for the quarter and $1,128,000 for year. The latest quarter and year operating nets include tax benefit of $760,000, or 3 cents a share.

title: Dow Drops 1.43 in Listless Session
description: Stock prices languished in slower post-holiday trading yesterday.

title: AMERICAN LAND CRUISERS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SQUIBB CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said a nonrecurring tax adjustment of $2,700,000 resulting from the Deficit Reduction Act of 1984 added 5 cents a share to 1984 earnings.

title: Beatrice to Sell Eschem Division
description: The Beatrice Companies said that it had agreed to sell its Eschem division to Reichhold Chemicals Inc. of White Plains for $67 million.

title: CUTCO INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NATIONAL CAN MAKES $40 OFFER FOR STOCK
description: The National Can Corporation said today that it and a new employee stock ownership plan would offer $40 a share for 5.4 million shares of the company's common stock. As part of the buyout plan, the company would also issue a new series of preferred stock.

title: Collinsworth Is Free
description: Cris Collinsworth and the Tampa Bay Bandits have terminated their $3 million agreement, freeing the wide receiver to seek a new contract with the Cincinnati Bengals, the National Football League team he stunned two years ago when he signed to jump to the Bandits of the United States Football League this season. The Bandit deal was terminated on Monday, according to the team and Collinsworth's agent,

description: Erbamont N.V., a maker of chemotherapy drugs for treating cancer, said that David W. Ortlieb had ''vacated'' his positions as president and chief executive officer.

U.S. AIDES ASK END TO CAR QUOTAS
description: The Cabinet Council on Commerce and Trade recommended to President Reagan today that the United States let expire next month the ''voluntary'' quotas on Japanese automobiles exported to this country, Administration officials reported.

description: b-Net income. The company said results for the latest year include an after-tax gain of $,820,000 from the sale of property. Year-ago results include an after-tax gain of $1,600,000 from a claim settlement.

description: b-Includes extraordinary gains of $899,000, or 2 cents a share, for the quarter and a tax benefit of $4,116,000 for the year. c-After an extraordinary loss of $1,486,000 for the quarter and a tax benefit of $8,151,000 for the year. Latest results are after a pre-tax charge of $1,800,000 related to the previously announced settlement of shareholder litigation. Year-ago results include a gain of $6,100,000 from the settlement of a 1977 income tax issue.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;   Honeywell Creates Executive Office'
description: Honeywell Inc. said yesterday that it had created an ''executive office'' to be shared by its chairman and chief executive officer, Edson W. Spencer, and its vice chairman, Dr. James J. Renier.

Share earnings reflect a 3-for-1 stock split effected by way of a stock dividend to be distributed March 1.

description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $174,000.

title: Leo Burnett Getting Some Mars Candy
description: There was quite a bit of account movement going on yesterday for the first day after a three-day weekend.

title: HOME COMPUTER IS OUT IN THE COLD
description: FOR more than three years now, it has been the secret of the home computer industry, seldom whispered aloud: No one has figured out how a computer can be truly useful at home. This, after years of research and more than a billion dollars in losses by toy manufacturers and electronic giants.

title: ROBERT PRESTON ADOPTS A COAST FOCUS: FILMS
description: When Robert Preston moved from Connecticut to Montecito, Calif., two years ago, the relocation confirmed a major shift in emphasis in his career.

title: V F CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NORTHROP CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in September.

BUSINESS DIGEST
description: WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 20, 1985

title: A NEW LABEL, LANDMARK, RECORDS JAZZ
description: ''I'VE done the very thing I always insisted I would never do again,'' the seasoned jazz- record-producer Orrin Keepnews admitted somewhat sheepishly during a recent visit to New York from San Francisco. ''I've started another record label.''

title: COUSINS HOME FURNISHINGS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: STEPAN COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After nonrecurring losses from a writedown of a portion of the company's investment in its production equipment for enhanced oil recovery chemicals and for certain products in Europe of $715,000 for the quarter and $2,580,000 for the year, income of $864,000 for the year from a contract substantially performed in prior years, and a DISC tax credit of $1,359,000 for the year.

title: FIRESTONE NET FALLS BY 19%
description: The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company said yesterday that earnings declined 19 percent, to $17 million, or 39 cents a share, in the first fiscal quarter, from $21 million, or 44 cents a share, a year before. The quarter ended Jan. 31.

title: WOMEN IN CLERICAL JOBS BAND TOGETHER TO LEARN 9-TO-5 RIGHTS
description: AS Angela Romano, a secretary in a large Manhattan office, described it, for almost two years her employers bypassed her salary review, saddled her with faulty equipment and rejected her suggestion about the work on the ground that she was ''hired help.'' ''In no other field does experience work against you, but in this field it does - employers often take a younger person who commands less pay,'' said Miss Romano, who is 37 years old.

title: BBC REVERSES ITS CANCELLATION OF 'DALLAS'
description: The British Broadcasting Corporation, apparently yielding to viewer pressure, has decided to restore ''Dallas'' to its schedules, two weeks after dropping the program as part of a battle with its commercial rivals.

title: Article 040074 -- No Title
description: Chesebrough-Pond's Inc., maker of Vaseline, Q-tips, Ragu spaghetti and other nationally known consumer products, announced yesterday that it would buy the Stauffer Chemical Company for $1.25 billion in cash.

title: AMERICAN ADVENTURE reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Profits Scoreboard
description: See accompanying notes for special items. (Loss) * Loss in year-earlier period.

title: Hoyas Rout Pitt; Ewing Hits 2,000
description: Patrick Ewing, becoming only the second player in Georgetown history to score more than 2,000 points in a career, dominated play at both ends of the court as the Hoyas routed Pittsburgh tonight, 70-46, in the Big East Conference. Ewing scored 16 points, blocked 9 shots and grabbed 8 rebounds.

title: BARNWELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: CABARET: JANIS SIEGEL IN A SOLO TURN
description: JANIS SIEGEL, one of the two female vocalists in the pop- jazz group Manhattan Transfer, has a big, sensual voice and an aggressive attack that allows her to slip comfortably back and forth between pop-rock and jazz. But in the first show of a rare two-evening solo engagement at Seventh Avenue South (217 Seventh Avenue South) on Monday, the focus was decisively on the latter.

title: Heublein's Deal Denial Is Upheld
description: The Supreme Court today left intact a decision that corporations may legally deny knowledge of pending mergers before agreement is reached on the price and structure of the transaction.

title: NOW, CHERRY COKE IN A CAN
description: When Diet Coke became the country's third-best-selling drink only two years after its 1982 nationwide debut, officials of the Coca-Cola Company hailed it as ''the fastest-growing major soft drink in history.'' Now, they hope, history will repeat itself with the company's newest product: Cherry Coke.

title: Texaco Canada Offering Increased
description: Texaco Inc. said it had increased the size of its offering in Canada of Texaco Canada Inc. common stock to 14 million shares, from 12 million shares.

title: LIMITED INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 2
description: Results for the latest quarter and year include a nonrecurring charge of 7 cents a share from expenses related to the Carter Hawley Hale tender offer. Results for the 1984 year include a gain of 7 cents a share on the disposal of assets acquired with Lane Bryant. Reporting periods are based on 53 weeks compared to 52 weeks a year ago.

title: An Israeli Film Series Is Set for 92d Street Y
description: The American premiere of the film ''The Rage and the Glory,'' by the Israeli director Avi Nesher, will highlight ''A Lens on Israel: Society through its Cinema,'' a series beginning March 7 at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue.

title: BOOK ON JAPAN DIARIES WINS LAURELS IN TOKYO
description: The diaries that Donald Keene read as a young man - bloodstained, water-bloated memoirs taken from dead Japanese soldiers in World War II - vanished 40 years ago. Though taken from him near the end of the war, they never left his memory. The diaries were the seed of a lifelong fascination with this most intimate of literary forms.

title: TURNER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
COMPTROLLER EXPECTED TO APPEAL BANKING RULING
description: Banking officials said today that the Comptroller of the Currency would almost certainly appeal a Federal judge's halt to further expansion of interstate banking through the chartering of limited-service banks.

title: CREDIT MARKETS ;   Rates Steady in Quiet Trading
description: Interest rates were unchanged to slightly higher in quiet trading yesterday as many credit market participants stayed on the sidelines waiting for the Federal Reserve's chairman, Paul A. Volcker, to review monetary policy in testimony today before the Senate Banking Committee.

title: FROM PARIS, A NEW SNUG LOOK
description: -to-the-body dress was one of the strongest fashions at the recent Paris haute couture showings for spring and summer. Emanuel Ungaro devoted the major part of his collection to these styles, which were immediately dubbed ''mummy'' dresses because of the tautness of the drapery. Some referred to the styles as the bandaged look. The snuggest were those wrapped in a basket-weave effect, clearly outlining the body and not obfuscating any curves.

title: ALTEX OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a writeoff of $251,000 for nonproductive properties and $157,000 for bad debt. c-Net income

title: SAFEGUARD BUSINESS SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for the 1983 quarter and year are restated to reflect an acquisition accounted for as a pooling of interests.

title: BERKSHIRE GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ISLANDERS CONTROL ICE AND BEAT FLAMES
description: One theory of winning hockey views the space in front of the opponent's goalkeeper as a pyramid. Control the ice from the goalmouth to the points and your offense will thrive.

title: ITALIAN SOUPS CHASE WINTER BRRS
description: ITALIANS know that nothing takes the chill

title: CANUCKS SURVIVE DEVILS' LATE RALLY
description: Tony Tanti scored a pair of goals and added an assist tonight to lead the Vancouver Canucks to a 7-5 victory over the Devils.

title: I.B.M. Warns Of Outlook
description: The International Business Machines Corporation, slightly strengthening the warnings it issued last week about its short-term earnings outlook, said yesterday that it expected virtually all of its growth to take place in the second half of the year.

title: Bridge:Bridgette, 2-Handed Game, Is Still Played After 25 Years

For reasons of health, economics, ideology and esthetics, it has become fashionable among a small but growing group of Americans to give up red meat.

title: Washington State

The financing also included non-interest-bearing capital appreciation bonds yielding from 9 percent for bonds due in 1994 to 9 7/8 percent in 1998. The bonds, which will be used to finance multifamily housing, are backed by Federal National Mortgage Association mortgage- backed securities, and are expected to be rated AAA by Standard & Poor's.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: SOME weeks ago Barbara E. Goldsmith of Manhattan went to a downtown rug and carpet store where she found what she considered to be the perfect 9-by-12 multicolored area rug for her new studio apartment. She was told delivery would take four to six weeks - a small price, she remembers thinking, for such a handsome item. She mentally began crossing off the weeks until D-day.

title: HELEN HAYES AS MISS MARPLE ON CBS
description: TELEVISION seems to be in the midst of an Agatha Christie festival. Public television's ''Mystery!'' series is currently offering a run of British- made productions based on some of Miss Christie's lesser known concoctions. And tonight at 9, CBS is bringing back Helen Hayes as Jane Marple in still another whodunit romp, this one entitled ''Murder With Mirrors.'' The net effect of this concentrated activity may be to call undue attention to Miss Christie's flaws - the conservative archness, the snobbery, the plethora of red-herring contrivances - but the better moments can be diverting, especially if, as in this evening's exercise, they are produced with style.

title: State Restraints Lifted

The two Oklahoma state courts, in Pryor and Bartlesville, where Phillips has its headquarters, last week issued temporary restraining orders delaying Mr. Icahn's efforts. In issuing his ruling, United States District Judge H. Dale Cook said Phillips and Mr. Icahn ''agreed to litigate their differences exclusively in Federal court.''

Although a little wine and cheese is on the agenda, Stanley Silverman, the composer and guitarist, will be doing most of the talking. Mr. Silverman, winner of numerous prestigious music awards, studied with Leon Kirchner, Henry Cowell and Darius Milhaud and has composed for films and the stage. His theatrical work includes writing the music for ''Up From Paradise,'' by Arthur Miller, and the Kaufman-Connelly comedy ''Beggar on Horseback'' and directing Virgil Thomson's ''The Mother of Us All.''

Mr. Davis will be present to discuss his work with the audience. The other two concerts will feature Leroy Jenkins and Mixed Quintet on March 19 and Anthony Braxton and Ensemble on March 26.

title: Hanover Bank

Harold N. Langlitz, executive director of the $13 billion teachers fund, said the withdrawal would be completed by March 1. The fund wants to diversify management of its assets, he said.

title: FOR THINKING TROPICAL AND GOING TO THE BEACH
description: 1.*Tropical Dressing It may be February but the fashion world is thinking about the tropics, with all manner of exotic prints and patterns. One example: a long black cotton dress appliqued with a brightly colored parrot on the yoke. Wear the dress for entertaining at home or for dinner at a beach resort. Designed by Oscar de la Renta for Swirl, it is $64 in the loungewear department on the second floor at Altman's. 2.For Camera Fiends Know a teen-ager who likes cameras? She might also like this camera- shaped shoulder bag to carry her lunch to school or her sunglasses and lotion to the beach, come summer. The body of the camera is black, the see-through lens and strap come in orange, green, blue or yellow, and a sliding door in back allows access to the contents. The bag sells for $12.50 at Stephen Anson, 1058 First Avenue (between 57th and 58th Streets). 3.A Robot for Neatness The robot with a heart is actually a child-size shoe bag that should encourage neatness, for what youngster could resist putting away shoes in one of its six compartments? The red heart and lips stand out against a blue body with white hands, feet and antennae. The fabric is a blend of polyester and cotton lined with polyester batting. Made by Fanny's Play House, it costs $24 at Little Senli, 30 Rockefeller Plaza and 672 Lexington Avenue (near 56th Street). 4.

Center, Sonja Flavin's ''For Aalto Scroll Chair,'' 76 by 47 feet, by commission; $1,555. ''G-6,'' right, reissue of a Juan Gris rug; in several sizes, from $1,050 list; Furniture of the 20th Century, through designers.

title: I LOVE A MYSTERY
description: WASHINGTON Today, in this space, we dare to

title: Cooper-Rorer
description: Cooper Laboratories said yesterday it plans to seek the removal of a majority of Rorer Group's board unless Rorer cancels its plan for a ''poison pill'' antitakeover mechanism.

title: FAMILY'S NEDD ASSAYED
description: Americans believe that a family of four needs $302 a week to make ends meet, according to a recent Gallup Poll. Though that was the highest figure reported since Gallup began asking the question in 1937, it is just $2 more than the figure recorded in a similar poll last year.

title: AERONCA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After tax credits of $441,000 for the quarter and $2,001,000 for the year. c-After losses of $250,000 for the quarter and $721,000 for the year from discontinued operations and tax credits of $1,010,000 and $1,790,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The year-ago fourth quarter and year earnings included an unusual pre-tax gain of $1,104,000, or 17 cents a share, after taxes, representing a recovery on the L-1011 program. The 1983 year also includes a gain of $575,000 on the sale of rental property equal to 31 cents a share, after taxes.

title: PLUMBING THE SHALLOWS OF MINIMALISM
description: MUSIC'S latest fad is Minimalism, which seems to be taking over everywhere. It has penetrated even into the Soviet Union, where bemused audiences are subjected to the slow, slow evolution of a chord twisting slowly, slowly in the wind. Composers in the Socialist Realism esthetic of the Russians manage to get away with it, whereas their colleagues in the other arts would be up on serious charges if they attempted the equivalent in their fields.

title: Bucks Win by 1
description: Paul Pressey scored 24 points and Terry Cummings hit for 20, 14 in the second half, as the Milwaukee Bucks extended their winning streak to five games with a 113-112 victory over the Detroit Pistons tonight. All five Milwaukee starters finished in double figures as the Bucks (39-17) extended their Central Division lead over Detroit (32-23) to 6 1/2 games.

title: Debt
description: Baybanks Inc. is offering $30 million of convertible subordinated debentures, due in 2010, priced at 100 through Shearson Lehman Brothers.

title: CUOMO VIGOROUSLY DEFENDS COMMERCE NATION
description: Governor Cuomo today vigorously, and for the first time publicly, defended his nominee to oversee economic development, some of whose credentials were questioned in the last week.

title: THEATER: 'PANIC' AT DANCE WORKSHOP
description: GEOFF HOYLE and Keith Terry are polar icecap opposites and therein lies the key to their New Vaudeville comedy, a double-dip of which is on display weekends at the Dance Theater Workshop.

title: NOTRE DAME, IONA TRIUMPH AT GARDEN
description: Every so often, Digger Phelps, the Notre Dame coach, covered his eyes in a gesture of fear as his freshman playmaker pushed the ball upcourt. At other times, he put his finger to his temple as if to tell Rivers to be smart.

title: REPUBLICAN SENATORS HIT SNAG ON DEFICIT-REDUCTION PACKAGE
description: The push by Republican Senators for agreement on a major deficit-reduction package has run into significant problems in the last few weeks. Some leaders are considering moving ahead even if a consensus can not be reached with the White House or among Senate Republicans.

title: 4 OFFSHORE OIL LEASE SALES OFF
description: The new Secretary of the Interior, Donald P. Hodel, said today that he was delaying or canceling four pending offshore oil lease sales because of ''low industry interest in these areas at this time.''

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;   Insurance Helps to Cut Rates on State's Bonds
description: New York State, benefiting from strong local demand and an insurance policy guaranteeing payment of interest and principal, sold $110 million of new bonds yesterday at interest rates well below those available on other high-grade state and county bonds.

title: FUNTIME INC reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
DONNA STONE PESCH
description: Donna Stone Pesch, founder of a national network for the prevention of child abuse, died of cancer Tuesday at the age of 49.

title: JUDGE SENTENCES ZACCARO TO WORK IN PUBLIC SERVICE
description: John A. Zaccaro was sentenced yesterday to perform 150 hours of community service for his admitted involvement in a fraudulent real-estate transaction that prosecutors said was aimed at yielding millions of dollars for him and several associates.

title: CONCERT: BOSTON CAMERATA PERFORMS
description: THE Boston Camerata has taken a giant step forward toward making musicological matters seem pertinent to the general music lover. Like many other specialists in the performance of early music, the Bostonians have long been making noble efforts to bring medieval, Renaissance and Baroque music to life, and their work has been appreciated by listeners whose interest in history runs high. But it has been difficult for the general music public to get involved in concerns about early music and stylistically correct performances of it.

title: Dallas Land Deal
description: The Gulf Broadcast Company said it and its subsidiaries had agreed to sell about 6,400 acres of undeveloped land near Dallas to the Gibraltar Savings Association for $130 million. The sale is subject to conditions, including the approval by Gulf Broadcast's shareholders of the plan of liquidation for Gulf announced on Feb. 1 and the sale of substantially all of Gulf's television and radio stations under that plan.

description: Washington gourmets do not live by croissants alone. They like their hamburgers, too.

title: Scott Paper Plans
description: The Scott Paper Company said it would spend $220 million for a second advanced-technology paper machine at its mill in Skowhegan, Me., doubling the plant's capacity. The company said start-up is expected in the fourth quarter of 1986. The machine will produce 215,000 short tons a year of coated papers.

title: THOR INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Head of Capitol Air Resigns in a Dispute
description: Capitol Air said yesterday that John H. Jackson had resigned as president and chief operating officer in a dispute over reorganization of the carrier, which has been under protection from its creditors through Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy laws since December. No replacement was named.

title: ;   New Zealand May Have to Be Dropped From Anzus
description: To the Editor:

title: Koch and the Silent Days
description: A silent Mayor Koch? A most curious thought.

title: Sambito Looking For a Tight Spot
description: Joe Sambito, who has had three operations on his left elbow, will report to the Houston Astro spring- training camp in Cocoa, Fla., today with a special goal in mind for 1985: to be sent into a game when it is on the line.

title: Washington Charged
description: Claudell Washington , the Atlanta Braves' all-star outfielder, has been charged with the possession of cocaine and marijuana, according to the police in Walnut Creek, Calif., who said they found small amounts of both in his car after stopping him for weaving in traffic on a freeway early Tuesday morning. Washington, 30 years old, who lives in nearby Orinda, was released on $3,000 bond pending arraignment March 12.

title: Ex-Convict Is Indicted In Rape in Manhattan
description: A Manhattan grand jury indicted a 42-year-old Brooklyn man yesterday on charges of raping a Barnard College senior in Riverside Park, where she had gone jogging early Monday evening.

title: NETS LOSE TO JAZZ IN OVERTIME
description: This is not a time for lessons, but the Nets learned one tonight anyway: Never challenge Mark Eaton. The Nets did, repeatedly, and they lost a 22-point lead and finally fell in overtime to the Utah Jazz, 110-104, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Fill 'er Up
description: When the Detroit Pistons scored points Saturday night by drawing a record National Basketball Association crowd of 43,816 to the Silverdome, several assists were in order. One had to go to the high-caliber play of the Pistons themselves, who continue to challenge Milwaukee's dominance of the Central Division. Another went to the quality of that night's opposition, the always-powerful Philadelphia 76ers.

title: DONALDSON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
KOLLMORGEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ANGELES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

title: Swiss to Aid Insider Inquiry
description: The Swiss Government said today that it would assist in an investigation of suspected insider trading during the takeover in 1981 of the Santa Fe International Corporation, an American oil services company. The decision followed three years of efforts by the United States Justice Department to penetrate Swiss banking secrecy.

title: STOCKS MIXED IN HEAVIER TRADING
description: Stock prices ended mixed yesterday in heavier turnover as traders reacted to statements by Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, concerning Fed policy and the course of the economy.

title: ARGENTINA DENIES POLICY SHIFT
description: The shake-up of Argentina's economic team this week does not signal a change in Argentina's approach to its economic troubles, according to President Raul Alfonsin.

title:
GARDENING;

RUGOSA ROSES FOR CITY SPACES
description: BY labeling rugosa roses ''seaside'' plants, the authors of gardening encyclopedias have robbed city gardeners of a most rewarding class of shrubs. While it is true that they flourish along the shore, versatile and hardy rugosas are also perfectly at home in the city.

title: CRAMER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Starting Over in Argentina
description: When a country's economic strategy proves bankrupt, a change in economic leadership is called for. That alone justifies the resignations of Argentina's Economics Minister, Bernardo Grinspun, and the president of its central bank, Enrique Garcia Vazquez. But there is little indication that this shakeup signals fresh policies rather than merely fresh faces.

title: NEW YORK AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income.

title: TO CONTROL THE PENTAGON
description: Congress has greeted the Pentagon's $313.7 billion budget request with pained evocations of the deficit, angry wavings of $600 toilet seats and bipartisan threats of huge budget cuts. This might seem ominous - except that last year's threats were just as loud and yet a 5 percent increase in defense spending was permitted after all. In fact, in all likelihood, this year too the budget season will end in futility, as Congress once again fails to exercise any real oversight over the substance of defense policy and individual Congressmen interfere disruptively in the detailed management of the Pentagon.

description: Carpentry for Ladies, Educational

title: CURB ON MEDICAL SUITS BACKED
description: With medical malpractice awards soaring in the courts, the State Senate today voted a package of bills that would impose controls in such suits.

title: Army Task Force To Help Hunt Mengele
description: John O. Marsh Jr., Secretary of the Army, has set up a high-level task force to help the Justice Department in searching for Dr. Josef Mengele, the Army said today.

title: Price Rises in Sweden
description: Consumer prices in Sweden rose seven-tenths of 1 percent in January from December and 7.4 percent from a year earlier, Statistics Sweden said today. Inflation in 1984 was 8.2 percent, Statistics Sweden said.

title: ADVICE ON LARGE SCREENS
description: BEFORE investing a hefty sum in a projection television set, all available options should be scrutinized. Three different kinds of projection sets are currently manufactured: one-piece front-projection, two-piece front-projection and rear-projection models.

title: PERES OFFERS TO GO TO JORDAN FOR TALKS
description: Israel's Prime Minister, Shimon Peres, offered today to go to Jordan for peace talks. He said Israel would also welcome a visit by King Hussein.

title: NOTE, BOND PRICES DECLINE SHARPLY
description: Treasury note and bond prices fell sharply yesterday as statements by Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve, apparently heightened concerns that the Fed would encourage higher interest rates this year.

Kuwait Votes for Parliament
description: Kuwaitis voted today for a new Parliament in the only Persian Gulf Arab country with an elected assembly able to initiate laws and change or reject government bills. Only 3.5 percent of Kuwait's 1.7 million people are allowed to vote under a franchise restricted to men over 21, most of whom must be able to trace their roots in Kuwait back to 1920.

description: for shoes and sweaters, mailing boxes and those that fit under the bed - are abundant and serve to make life more organized.

title: 2 Southeast Banks In Merger Accord
description: In an action clouded by uncertainty over the legality of interstate banking mergers, the Citizens and Southern Georgia Corporation and Landmark Banking Corporation of Florida said yesterday that they had agreed to merge. However, the companies said that they had temporarily halted the transaction to resolve ''certain accounting issues.''

title: FOR METS, THE SWEET SMELL OF SUCCESS
description: Dwight Gooden strode into the Mets' locker room today wearing a confident smile, a gold chain and a sleek black sweatsuit inscribed: ''1984 All-Star Game.''

title: Milwaukee Road
description: The Soo Line Corporation said it had completed its purchase of the Chicago Milwaukee Corporation's railroad today for about $570 million. Completion of the sale follows the issuance Tuesday of a court order authorizing it. A competing offer had come from the Chicago and North Western Transportation Company.

title: E-H INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Net Off 46.5% At Hewlett
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company said today that its first-quarter profit totaled $116 million, or 45 cents a share, down 46.5 percent from $217 million, or 85 cents a share, a year earlier. However, the figures for the quarter ended Jan. 31, 1984, included a one-time gain of $118 million stemming from a change in tax law.

title: Good Old Federalism
description: Nine years ago the Supreme Court broke with its own precedents and announced a fragmented, Balkan view of the Union. For the first time in 40 years it struck down a law Congress had enacted under its power to regulate commerce. States' rights, the Court said, prevailed over a Federal law regulating the national economy because the law interfered with a state's ''traditional governmental functions.''

title: Recipient Who Gave Birth Dies
description: A 24- year-old woman who became the first heart transplant recipient known to have given birth when she had a baby girl in September, died today, apparently of cardiac arrest, doctors said.

title: EASING THE BURDEN OF CARING OF A HOME
description: The home where the children were raised affords warm memories for millions of Americans, but as people age that same house can become a burden, with utility bills and maintenance problems that grow over the years.

title: ASTRONOMER REPORTS AN ECLIPSE OF PLUTO BY CHARON, ITS MOON
description: A University of Texas astronomer has reported the first observation of the eclipse of the planet Pluto by its moon, ending a three-year search to prove the moon's existence.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: American Family Corp., Columbus, Ga., a cancer insurance company, said it had agreed in principle to acquire WITN-TV of Washington, N.C., for about $25 million in cash.

title: PEROT SEEKS TO MOVE INDIAN MUSEUM
description: H. Ross Perot, the Texas computer executive, has offered to invest $70 million in the Museum of the American Indian in New York City if the museum's trustees agree to move it to Dallas, according to Edmund Carpenter, a trustee of the museum.

title: SOUTH AFRICA'S IRON HAND
description: After weeks of talk of racial ''reform'' from white officials, the familiar images of South Africa's recent history have reasserted themselves: the police firing on black demonstrators in a crowded squatter camp; the 3 A.M. rap at a flimsy door by a security operative come to search a home and detain those opposed to white rule.

title: American Natural
description: The American Natural Resources Company said its board had authorized the repurchase of up to 2 million of its common shares from time to time on the open market and in private transactions with Goldman, Sachs & Company as its agent.

title: BELLAMY CRITICIZES KOCH ON OVERTIME
description: City Council President Carol Bellamy, saying that overtime spending was ''out of control'' because of ''wasteful, shortsighted management'' by the Koch administration, yesterday called for a new system of monitoring city agencies to hold down overtime costs.

title: SCARSDALE'S CRECHE BAN DEFENDED BEFORE JUSTICES
description: A lawyer for the Village of Scarsdale, N.Y., told the Supreme Court today that local officials should be free to ban Nativity scenes from public property if the displays offend large segments of the community.

title: TUNBRIDGE WARE: CARE AND REPAIR
description: Marquetry has enlivened many a box, panel, tray and table top. This adornment has a long history. But there is one specialized decoration that by the nature of its construction is used on objects too small to be considered practical for more conventional marquetry.

title: GROUPS ZACCARO WILL HELP
description: John A. Zaccaro's 150 hours of community service will be divided among three agencies that serve New York City's young people, its poor and its mentally ill. Officials from all the programs said they hoped to use his real estate background in furthering their social objectives.

title: AMERICAN MONITOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The latest quarter net includes a gain of $1,544,000 from equity in the company's U.K. affiliate, Amil, compared with a $621,000 loss in the year- ago period. The latest 6 months net includes a $1,335,000 gain from equity in Amil, compared with an $898,000 loss a year earlier. The 1983 revenue restated for a reclassification of revenue accounting.

title: CBS PRAISES CRITIC OF DOCUMENTARY
description: The president of CBS News, calling Gen. William C. Westmoreland's libel suit an ''unfortunate episode,'' issued a memorandum of praise yesterday for the CBS executive who found the network's standards had been violated in making the documentary that led to the general's $120 million claim.

title: AIDS AND ITS VICTIMS: SUPPORT NETWORKS GROW
description: David Summers built his nightclub act around an illness he knows may kill him soon. Mathew J. Shebar left his Wall Street law practice to give legal counsel to friends and colleagues he saw dying of AIDS. Sister Patrice Murphy expanded her hospice program to minister to patients with AIDS and their families.

title: NAME'S SAME, SO ONE TOWN GETS HEAT FOR ANOTHER'S FIRE
description: The tale of a firefighting service's refusal to battle a blaze in Salem sent people around the country to their telephones to call in complaints.

title: N.A.A.C.P. Planning to Move Offices in City to Baltimore
description: The board of the N.A.A.C.P. has authorized moving the national headquarters of the civil-rights organization from New York to Baltimore, according to officials of the group.

description: Suit combinations are the building blocks of declarer play, and every expert thinks he knows all there is to be known about the subject.

title: M.D.'S ARE GETTING A RAW DEAL
description: I spent most of January in the hospital. Untreated, my ailment kills 30 percent of those affected; treated, most people survive. As a patient, the thing that struck me most was how many times my doctors visited or phoned to get information about me. I soon learned that the nurses never hesitated about phoning my doctor at any hour of the night or any hour of any holiday if I had a problem.

title: Lily-Tulip Status
description: Lily-Tulip Inc., a maker of disposable food-service products, said it had decided to continue as a publicly traded company after an evaluation of its financial alternatives conducted with Kidder, Peabody & Company. The company had said it would consider alternatives, including the sale of the company.

title: RECITAL: MARION FELDMAN
description: MARION FELDMAN, a cellist active primarily as a teacher locally, gave a good hearty recital Sunday at Merkin Hall. One hopes she is teaching her students to throw themselves into their work with as much vigor as she does.

title: STAGE: AL CARMINES
description: AL CARMINES, whose expansive, gentle portrayal of Walt Whitman in Peter Parnell's historical fantasy ''Romance Language'' was one of this season's most luminous stage performances, has always brought a Whitman-like sensibility to popular music. Over the years, he has composed every imaginable style, freely mixing blues, pop and classical idioms in music that often disregards strict formal considerations in search of a more spontaneous, natural mode of expression.

description: Taking advantage of strong demand for zero coupon securities at this time of year from people establishing Individual Retirement Accounts, the World Bank is offering $1.3 billion of zero coupon issues with 60 different maturities ranging from six months to 30 years.

title: Israelis Raid Village
description: Israeli forces raided a village east of Tyre today in what authorities here described as the opening of a crackdown against Shiite villages harboring anti-Israeli terrorists.

title: FILM: 'BETWEEN WARS'
description: THE travails of a pioneering Australian psychoanalyst, at a time when the profession was regarded in his country with disdain, constitute the unlikely basis for ''Between Wars,'' which opens at the D. W. Griffith today. ''Between Wars,'' yet another undistinguished entry in the current Australian Film Festival, was made 11 years ago and is notable chiefly for the presence of Corin Redgrave in the leading role.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: MEETING THE THUNDER For the United States Army Air Force men of the 99th Fighter Squadron, the 332d Fighter Group and the 477th Bomber Group, the blue yonder was not nearly so wild as the earth they took off from. These World War II outfits were the only all-black air units ever to exist in the nation's military, established after a 1941 lawsuit challenged the Army Air Force's policy of not accepting black men. The training took place in Tuskegee, Ala., and the men were subjected to racial discrimination both on and off of the base. The units saw action in Europe.

title: World Chess Official Declines Comment on Karpov Appeal
description: Florencio Campomanes, the president of the International Chess Federation, said yesterday that he would not comment on an appeal by the world champion, Anatoly Karpov, to have his title match in Moscow with Gary Kasparov restarted.

title: DESIGNING ROOMS FOR PROJECTION TV SETS
description: ABOUT the most serious decorating problem posed by the average-size television set is finding a place for it to be viewed comfortably. But what does the interior designer do with a room that must accommodate a projection television set, whose screen size can be as large as 10 feet, and in which both projector and seating must be placed a precise distance from the screen? Then there is lighting: Most projection television sets must be viewed in movie-theater conditions of darkened rooms.

title: CONCERT: ARS ANTIQUA
description: THE St. Vincent de Paul Church on West 23d Street proved a sympathetic setting for a Tuesday evening program by a group called Ars Antiqua de Paris, for both the church and the music performed possess a beauty that is stark and majesterial, yet full of interest and life.

title: GIFT REGISTRIES: NOT JUST FOR BRIDES
description: -year-old publicity agent for Avon Books, walked into the bridal and gift registry office at Bloomingdale's and selected a host of items for her studio apartment. Accompanied by a bridal consultant and armed with a checklist of products, she traversed the store, examining silverware, fine china and crystal champagne flutes.

title: DRUNKEN DRIVER AND HIS HOST AGREE TO PAY IN JERSEY CRASH
description: In the case that established New Jersey's host liability law, lawyers today agreed to a $172,500 settlement for a woman who was injured in a head-on collision involving a drunken driver.

title: NETWORKS BAR AD ON FEDERAL WASTE
description: The three major television networks have refused to broadcast a public service advertisement offered by Citizens Against Waste, an offshoot of the commission formed by President Reagan to point the finger at waste in Government.

title: Jim Brown Held On Rape Charge
description: Jim Brown, the Pro Football Hall of Famer, was arrested on a charge of rape and sexual battery, the police said today.

description: Leon Durham of the Chicago Cubs learned yesterday that he had failed to gain a record salary in arbitration, but only 15 minutes before Bill Caudill was scheduled to go to arbitration, he learned that the Toronto Blue Jays were willing to pay him $7 million over the next five years.

title: U.S. ENVOY, ENDING CHILE VISIT, AVOIDS ANY CRITICISM OF PINOCHET
description: A high-ranking Reagan Administration official said tonight that Chile still has ''a way to go'' in its political development, but in contrast to recent State Department declarations, the official avoided virtually any criticism of the Chilean Government.

title: LIGHTWEIGHTS PROVIDING THE BEST ACTION
description: Boxing's version of short division provides new weight classes every few teaspoons, but the dilution of talent has not affected the lightweights.

title: O'NEILL'S PASSAGE TO BOSTON
description: For 10 years, Thomas P. (Tip) O'Neill Jr., the Speaker of the House, has been promoting a huge project in Boston that would include more than a mile of depressed highway and a new tunnel between Logan Airport and the thriving downtown area. The price tag now is $2.3 billion, and the state wants the Federal Government to foot some of the bill as part of the Interstate highway system.

title: Berra to Keep Yank Job FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 20 - George Steinbrenner proclaimed today that Yogi Berra would be the Yankee manager this season, no matter what may happen during the season. The announcement was reminiscent of one the Yankee owner made

title: PUBLIC TV JOINS VENTURE TO SEND FINANCE DATA TO COMPUTER USERS
description: In a major effort to find a source of commercial income, the Public Broadcasting Service said yesterday that it was joining with I.B.M. and Merrill Lynch & Company to broadcast stock quotations and financial news to subscribers with personal computers.

title: Koch Again Considers Merging Police Forces
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that he had received a new report by a member of his staff about a possible merger of the New York City Police Department and the Transit Authority Police.

title: MEESE FILIBUSTER GOES ON
description: The Senate wrestled today with the problem of credit-starved farmers but failed to end a filibuster that has blocked a vote on the nomination of Edwin Meese 3d to be Attorney General for the last two days.

description: The share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid Jan. 21.

Laos Joined by U.S. In Sifting Crash Site
description: American and Laotian soldiers dug handfuls of earth from the forest floor today in a search for remains of 13 United States airmen shot down a dozen years ago.

description: Year-ago share earnings are adjusted for a 4-for-3 stock split to be paid in April. The latest quarter and year are based on 16 weeks and 52 weeks respectively compared with 17 weeks and 53 weeks a year earlier.

title: LETTER
description: Barbara Ehrenreich's Hers column of Feb. 7 drew widespread reaction. A sample of representative letters to The New York Times follows.

title: 20 YEARS WASTED, TOP CHINESE SAYS
description: Hu Yaobang, the Chinese party leader, said in a speech published today that the Communists had ''wasted 20 years'' since they came to power in 1949 because of ''radical leftist nonsense'' associated with the ideas of Mao Zedong.

title: HEART RECIPIENT REPORTED BETTER
description: Murray P. Haydon today continued his remarkable recovery from an artificial heart implant. But doctors said William J. Schroeder, the second recipient of an artificial heart, has shown an even more dramatic turnaround in the last few days.

title: DESIGNER RUGS: STRIKING NEW GRAPHICS FOR THE FLOOR
description: TO tread or not to tread on the carpet is the question. Over the last decade, a growing number of designer rugs or art rugs have appeared in New York stores, showrooms and galleries. Because of their artistic images and execution, they could as easily be hung on the wall as placed on the floor.

title: Turkey's Trade Gap
description: Turkey's foreign trade deficit widened by 2.7 percent in 1984, to $3.6 billion, the State Statistics Institute said today. Exports rose 24 percent, to $7.1 billion, while imports went up 15.9 percent, to $10.7 billion.

description: Personal income and consumer spending both climbed a notch last month in modest rises that analysts said were in line with an emerging picture of steady economic growth and low inflation.

title: Alien Sanctuary Case Goes to Jury in Texas
description: A Federal jury began deliberations today in the case of two people accused of illegally transporting Salvadoran aliens.

title: NAVY MAY NOT PAY SOME DYNAMICS BILLS
description: Navy Secretary John F. Lehman Jr. told Congress today that he expects the Navy to refuse payment to the General Dynamics Corporation of at least $10 million in corporate travel that Government auditors believe was improperly billed to the Pentagon.

title: Staying Home
description: The National Hockey League's schedule-maker does his best to avoid it, but on occasion he runs smack into the wall of circumstances. So, in a rarity that has occurred only once before in the three seasons since the Devils abandoned the Rockies for the Meadowlands, all three of the New York area's N.H.L. teams will be playing at home tonight.

title: Michigan Legislature Passes Seat-Belt Bill
description: The Michigan Senate today sent legislation to Gov. James J. Blanchard that would require automobile drivers and front-seat passengers to wear seat belts.

description: The Centex Corporation yesterday named Laurence E. Hirsch as president and chief operating officer of the housing, construction and cement manufacturer, which is based in Dallas. The 39-year-old Mr. Hirsch has been president and chief executive of Southdown Inc., a Houston-based cement, sugar and energy producer, since last spring.

title: SQUASH AND POLITICS: HARDBALL BEDFELLOWS
description: First there was golf, then tennis. Now comes squash as the game in which many of Washington's politicians, lobbyists and other power people mix work with play.

title: Oldest Marine Veteran Dies
description: The oldest veteran of the Marine Corps, who served in World War I and World War II and went around the world with President Theodore Roosevelt, has died. The veteran, Birger F. Westergard, 99 years old, died Monday in a convalescent hospital in Oxnard, Calif.

title: LIQUI-BOX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
The Promise of Westway at Last
description: All is not yet quiet on the Westway front, but it appears that the tortuous process of deciding whether to build an offshore segment of interstate highway in southern Manhattan is nearing the end. The ingenious and dogged opponents of Westway show no signs of making their peace with it, but the Corps of Engineers may issue a dredging permit this week and no plausible challenge is likely on any new grounds. The air will be protected. The river bass will not be destroyed. Midtown streets will not be truck routes forever. And ample capital has also been found for rail transit.

title: Del Tufo Enters Race for Governor
description: Robert J. Del Tufo, a former United States Attorney for New Jersey, announced his candidacy today for the Democratic nomination for governor in the June 4 primary.

title: ACCOUNTING ROLE SEEN IN JEOPARDY
description: Congress was told today that the fundamental public watchdog function that private accountants perform in auditing the books of publicly held corporations is being undermined by conflicts of interest within the major accounting firms and lax oversight by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Corned-Beef Treat
description: On a visit from Orlando, Fla., Hanna and Harold Rosenblum wandered into Kaplan's delicatessen, at 71 West 47th Street. As they waited to give their orders, two stylishly dressed New Yorkers in their mid- 30's squeezed into seats at an adjacent table.

title: U.S.-Soviet Talks End
description: The United States and the Soviet Union ended two days of talks on the Middle East today.

title: CONTRACEPTION BILL ADVANCES IN IRISH PARLIAMENT
description: Ireland's coalition Government narrowly won initial approval in Parliament tonight for a measure to allow the sale without a prescription of contraceptives to anyone 18 years or older.

title: Unarmed Missile Tested
description: An unarmed Minuteman 3 intercontinental ballistic missile was successfully launched today, an Air Force spokesman said. The launching, to a target at the Kwajalein Atoll in the Pacific Ocean, was part of a continuing series to test the Minuteman system, the spokesman said.

description: After losing the lead early in the fourth quarter, Boys and Girls High rallied to defeat William E. Grady, 76-66, yesterday in the second round of the Public Schools Athletic League basketball playoffs. Joe Fennell had 19 points and Eric Brown 17 to lead the victors.

title: Pepsico in India

title: Sinclair Computer
description: Sinclair Research Ltd. said it planned to re-enter the North American market in May with mail-order sales of its QL microcomputer through its Boston- based subsidiary, Sinclair Research Inc. The QL will be offered at a basic price of $499. The company declined to say how many units it hoped to sell in a year. Sinclair ended an arrangement with Timex Inc. last February in which Timex marketed a repackaged version of Sinclair's Spectrum microcomputer in the United States.

title: 5TH VICTIM DIES IN AN ARSON BLAZE AT SOCIAL CLUB
description: A fifth person has died as a result of an arson fire that raced up the front stairs of a social club in Brooklyn early yesterday, trapping the victims inside with no means of escape, authorities said.

The seventh shot, which was the only fatal shot, was fired a year ago today, striking an Amtrak engineer in the head as he walked along the platform between Tracks 20 and 21.

title: HERS
description: to-be acquaintance called me up to tell me how busy she was. A major report, upon which her professional future depended, was due in three days; her secretary was on strike; her housekeeper had fallen into the hands of the Immigration Department; she had two hours to prepare a dinner party for eight, and she was late for her time-management class. Stress was taking its toll, she told me: Her children resented the fact that she sometimes got their names mixed up, and she had taken to abusing white wine.

title: PHILHARMONIC: HANDEL
description: THE composer whose music most consistently and successfully sounds a grandly celebratory air is certainly Georg Frideric Handel. At its exuberant best, with brass braying, drums pounding and choristers close to popping eyeballs and snapping vocal cords, his large-scale works seem to demand that we join in whatever festivity or occasion is being marked. It was easy for a listener to feel at last night's New York Philharmonic concert that he had happened onto a particularly jolly birthday party. And, in fact, that is what it was: the orchestra's observance of Handel's 300th anniversary.

title: Diner's Journal
description: BEER, unlike wine, should be drunk as fresh as possible, and nowhere will you find it fresher than at the Tap Room at the Manhattan Brewing Company, 40-42 Thompson Street in SoHo. The four-month-old brewery - the only beer facility in the city since F&M Shaefer Brewing closed its Brooklyn plant in 1976 - attracts a good-time Yuppie crowd nightly in its cavernous tavern room dominated by massive copper brewing vats. These vats are not for show; they each hold about 7,000 liters of the beer, including a refreshing light ale, a slightly bitter amber ale and a dark, heavy bodied special porter.

title: Salvador Helicopter Crash
description: A Salvadoran Air Force UH-1 helicopter carrying an American military adviser crashed today during a routine training mission, according to spokesmen for the United States Embassy and the Salvadoran Army. The adviser and two Salvadoran pilots were not hurt.

title: ART: THE LANDSCAPE IN 17TH-CENTURY ROME
description: ''LANDSCAPE PAINTING IN ROME 1595-1675'' provides a useful backdrop to ''The Age of Caravaggio,'' now at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Both the paintings of Caravaggio and the development of landscape painting in Rome, the subject of the loan exhibition at the Richard L. Feigen Gallery, reflect the growth of naturalism in the 17th century and the Baroque fascination with light. Both also reflect, though in very different ways, the breakdown of the Renaissance belief in the primacy of man and the Baroque's intense awareness of mortality. Caravaggio's stark dramas are distinguished in part by a penetrating sense of fatality. In landscape painting, human beings are often dwarfed by vast expanses and silenced by the indestructible rhythms of the natural world.

title: CORRECTION

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: ''ANN-MARGRET?'' That, apparently, was the reaction of three stars in ''The Return of the Soldier,'' Glenda Jackson, Alan Bates and Julie Christie, when her name was suggested for one of the film's four key roles. ''They all had odd reactions to the thought,'' recalled Ann Skinner, the film's co-producer, who had suggested Ann-Margret for the role of the hero's plain, spinsterish cousin, Jenny. ''Glenda said, 'If you think she can do it, all right by me.' Alan Bates was more worried. Julie said, 'But she's a Kitty, not a Jenny.' '' Kitty, the hero's vain, self-absorbed wife, is Miss Christie's role.

description: For some, it's already too late. Temporary credit subsidies would do no more than postpone bankruptcy. But aid could come in time for many hard-pressed farmers, and there is a case to be made for giving it - as long as it is tied to fundamental reforms in farm-subsidy programs. Yes, bail out the farmers, if like Chrysler and New York City and other bailout beneficiaries, they agree to strings.

title: THEATER: A FRESH LOOK FOR O'NEILL'S 'INTERLUDE'
description: WHEN Eugene O'Neill's ''Strange Interlude'' opened on Broadway in 1928, it was widely hailed as a revolutionary experiment - a thunderous psychodrama that ushered Joycean modernism and Freudian theory into the American theater. The play won its author his third Pulitzer Prize, had a smash run and spawned two road companies. But 35 years later - as seen in the Actors Studio revival of 1963 - ''Strange Interlude'' had been eclipsed by the O'Neill masterworks that followed it. Not only did many cease to find this work profound or powerful; ''Strange Interlude'' looked so dated that some relegated it to the oblivion of kitsch.

title: ARCHITECTURE: THREE BRIGHT SPOTS
description: THE tendency to view architectural drawings as art objects, which in this day of the architect as media celebrity seems to become ever stronger, is in one sense good for architecture: it reinforces the idea that the art of building design is a fundamental part of our culture. But in other ways, it is not so positive, for when the drawing is seen too much as an object in itself, there is an implication that it, and not the building that it presumably represents, is what really matters. Then the drawing is no longer a part of the process of making buildings, a visual representation of an architect's ideas taking form.

title: Passenger Abandons Cash

Inside the suitcase was some women's clothing and the cash. Mr. Osorio seemed stunned and told the police the money was not his.
