description: A spectacular fire punctuated by explosions destroyed a three-block-long warehouse near a New Jersey waterfront in Port Elizaeth last night, forcing a brief shutdown of Newark International Airport and a one-hour closing of a 15-mile section of the New Jersey Turnpike.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;   Royal Dutch/Shell Names Top Officer
description: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group, the world's second-largest oil company, after the Exxon Corporation, said yesterday that it had chosen L.C. van Wachem to be chairman of its committee of managing directors, its senior governing body. He will succeed Sir Peter Baxendell, who is retiring July 1.

title: SLAKING APPETITES IN YEAR OF THE OX
description: IT has become a custom in recent

title: LYNCH CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
U.N. REPORT SAYS BOTH IRAN AND IRAQ MISTREAT PRISONERS
description: A report by a three-member United Nations study group has concluded that both Iran and Iraq regularly mistreat each other's prisoners of war in violation of the Geneva Conventions.

title: ESSEX CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $2,030,000 for the latest year and $1,378,000 for the earlier period. The 1983 results include a gain of $1,594,000 from the sale of discontinued operations.

title: GENERAL BINDING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss after a loss from discontinued operations of $3,009,000. c-After a loss of $4,769,000 from discontinued operations and an extraordinary gain of $427,000. The latest fourth quarter and year results include an after-tax gain of $415,000 on the sale and leaseback of land and a building in Florida.

title: CHESS AIDE WEIGHS REVIVAL OF MATCH
description: The head of the International Chess Federation raised the possibility today that he might order the world championship match between Viktor Karpov and Gary Kasparov to resume.

title: MEDTRONIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
SOVIET ARMS GROWTH IS DISPUTED
description: The United States Central Intelligence Agency, apparently contradicting Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger, said in testimony made public today that the Soviet Union halved the rate of growth in its military spending starting in 1977.

title: BANKS REVIEW SECRECY COMPLIANCE
description: The First National Bank of Boston's guilty plea two weeks ago to charges that it did not properly report international currency transfers has spurred other major banks to scrutinize their procedures for complying with Federal bank secrecy regulations, officials said yesterday.

title: Mellon Plan Gains
description: The Mellon Bank Corporation said it had received permission from the Comptroller of the Currency to establish a consumer bank in New York.

title: President Says Bible Can Provide Answers
description: President Reagan said tonight that the Bible contains an answer to just about ''every problem that confronts us,'' and denied that he had misused it for political purposes in defending his military budget.

title: Launching of Shuttle Rescheduled for March 4
description: The next launching of the space shuttle Challenger, with Senator Jake Garn of Utah as one of the crew members, has been rescheduled for March 4, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today.

title: DONALD DUCK'S VOICE IN FILMS
description: Clarence (Ducky) Nash, who was the only voice of Donald Duck in more than 150 cartoons and movies over five decades, died on Wednesday of leukemia at St. Joseph Medical Center in Burbank, Walt Disney Productions announced. He was 80 years old and lived in Glendale.

title: NEW ZEALANDERS TO THE RAMPARTS (IT'S FOR RUGBY)
description: Earlier this month, the Government decided to refuse to give an American destroyer access to the country's ports because of the possibiltity that the warship might be carrying nuclear weapons. The action angered the Reagan Administration and raised doubts about the future of New Zealand's military alliance with Australia and the United States.

title: Dining Out Guide: 3-Star French and Italian Restaurants
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times and the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given.

title: PUBLISHING: NEW INTERNATIONAL FLAVOR
description: FOREIGN publishers often complain that Americans translate and publish few foreign books, and the percentage of translations into English is indeed small. But the number of such translations appears to be growing, and the list of current and upcoming books from Pantheon has an exceptionally strong foreign flavor - in particular, a strong French flavor.

title: Hearing on Extradition Of Nazi Suspect Is Set
description: John Demjanjuk, wanted in Israel on charges that he was a Nazi death camp guard known as ''Ivan the Terrible,'' was ordered today to face extradition proceedings in Federal court.

title: Soviet Signs Accord On A-Plant Inspection
description: The Soviet Union and the International Atomic Energy Agency signed an agreement today permitting inspection of some Soviet civilian nuclear plants, but apparently not of advanced types.

title: GREINER ENGINEERING reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

description: b-Net loss.

title: AUCTIONS
description: -century Viennese modern furnishings have been attracting increasing numbers of collectors and posing complex questions - about the identification of designers and producers and about prices these works should command.

title: TRANSFORMATION OF MURRAY HILL 'SLIVER'
description: Next door to the austere, gray East German Mission to the United Nations in the Murray Hill section of Manhattan, a narrow tower 21 stories high is being built that will contain 10 duplex condominium apartments with an average selling price of $1.5 million each.

title: Convicted Lawyer Gets 15 Years
description: A 49-year-old lawyer convicted of a heroin-trafficking charge was sentenced yesterday to 15 years in prison, the maximum term he could have received.

title: TIME INC. WILL BUY MAGAZINES
description: Breaking a nearly 50-year tradition of starting magazines rather than buying them, Time Inc. said yesterday that it would purchase Southern Living, one of the nation's leading regional publications.

title: PALESTINIAN EXTREMIST LEADER IS ALIVE, A PARIS JOURNAL SAYS
description: A French magazine published today what it said was an interview with Abu Nidal, a dissident Palestinian leader who was reported to have died last November.

title: 24-Story Concert
description: Almost Gothic in its intricacy, the

title: U.S.-GREEK STRAINS TURN SMALL ISSUES INTO BIG ONES
description: For many months, senior Greek and American officials have been preoccupied with such matters as labor-management relations at United States military bases and the renewal of a civil aviation agreement.

title: PARAMOUNT PACKAGING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes tax benefits of $152,000 for the quarter and $491,000 for the year, and a loss of $372,000 for the year from the sale of equipment. c-Includes a gain of $436,000 from the termination of an employee benefit plan, a gain of $480,000 for the year from the sale of equipment, a gain of $410,000 for the year from the sale of the company's minority interest in Fres-Co System USA, and a gain of $235,000 for the year from bad debt recoveries.

title: BORDER CHECKS IN KIDNAPPING CASE ANGER MEXICO
description: Diplomatic tensions between Mexico and the United States have risen sharply this week.

title: Betty Ford's Request
description: Many think of the Betty Ford Center in Rancho Mirage, Calif., as a haven for the wealthy suffering from drug and alcohol abuse. But Betty Ford, during a recent visit here with her old friend, Margaret Heckler, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, noted that some older people of modest means were equally in need of treatment and she asked if some way could be found eventually to make them eligible for Medicare payments.

title: BENCH CRAFT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $154,000 from early repayment of debt for the quarter and year.

title: FARR CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a loss of $2,000 on the sale of a Canadian plant. c-Includes a loss of $1.5 million from a plant relocation. d-Includes a gain of $822,000 from the sale of a Canadian plant and a loss of $913,000 from the writeoff of Canadian goodwill.

title: A.M.C. Layoffs
description: The American Motors Corporation said it planned to cut daily car production at its Kenosha, Wis., assembly plant by 15 percent and place 600 hourly workers on indefinite layoff, effective Monday. The company said the steps were part of an effort to reduce inventories in the face of weak sales of subcompact cars.

title: ISRAELI TROOPS BESIEGE 3 VILLAGES IN SHIITE AREA OF SOUTH LEBANON
description: Israeli forces were reported to have besieged at least three villages in southern Lebanon today, rounding up dozens of male residents for interrogation.

title: Caterpillar to Shut Plant
description: The Caterpillar Tractor Company said today that it would close a plant in Joliet, Ill., by 1987, partly because the facility is too far from the company's main factory complex there. Caterpillar said it had not yet decided how many of the plant's 800 workers would be laid off. The plant makes hydrostatic controls, hydraulic pumps and motors and components.

title: OPTICAL RADIATION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
DANCE TROUPES WIN FUNDS
description: The National Endowment for the Arts announced yesterday that $5.8 million will be awarded to 112 ballet and modern-dance companies.

title: EMERY AIR FREIGHT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $1.4 million from a change in the actuarial method for determining annual costs of the company's U.S. pension plans and a charge of $800,000 related to refinancing debt.

title: Archbishop Dermot J. Ryan; Ex-Head of Church in Dublin
description: Archbishop Dermot J. Ryan, a former head of the Dublin archdiocese who had been serving in a high Vatican post, died of a heart attack today, church officials said. He was 60 years old.

title: Gambinos Acquitted In Tax Evasion Trial
description: A Federal District Court jury today acquitted reputed organized crime figures Giuseppe and Rosario ''Sal'' Gambino of tax evasion charges.

title: Charge Dropped Against Coach
description: A burglary charge was dismissed today against a former high school football coach who the police said had been caught breaking into the school building the day after he resigned as head coach last November. Dade County Judge Theodore Mastos accepted a defense motion that the case be dropped because of insufficient evidence.

title: PRESIDENT ASSERTS GOAL IS TO REMOVE SANDINISTA REGIME
description: In the bluntest assertion to date of his Administration's goals in Central America, President Reagan said tonight that his objective is to ''remove'' the ''present structure'' of the Government in Nicaragua.

title: G.M. Callback
description: The General Motors Corporation said it would recall 1,000 workers from indefinite layoff Monday as part of its plan to add a second shift to its car assembly plant at Tarrytown, N.Y., and to increase production at various components operations.

title: ART: FRANCOIS MORELLET, AUSTERE ABSTRACTIONISM
description: Expressionist overload is Fran,cois Morellet, a pioneer geometric abstractionist from France whose work over the last 30 years is on view at the Brooklyn Museum. An artist whose ''systematic'' approach makes even Mondrian look, well, messy, Morellet uses the sparest, most minimal of means to produce art from which all traces of painterly sensibility are eliminated. He takes the eye on a very austere trip.

title: Mexico Oil Prices Stable
description: Mexico's export oil prices for the month of March will remain at the same level as in February, Pemex, the state oil monopoly announced today. Prices will remain at $27.75 a barrel for its light Isthmus crude, and $25.50 for the heavier Maya variety.

title: SCHROEDER 'REAL FINE' IN 2ND EXCURSION
description: William J. Schroeder, the artificial heart patient, waved, smiled faintly and said he was ''feeling real fine'' in his first encounter with reporters since Dec. 9.

title: INDUSTRIAL ELECTRONIC HARDARE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: TWIGGS LEADS DORAL WITH 68
description: There are some golfers who say that when the wind blows strongly the player with a fade has the best chance. There seemed to be support for that argument today as 25-mile-an-hour winds swept the Doral Country Club's Blue Monster course in the opening round of the 24th annual Doral-Eastern Open.

title: Lavish Lifestyle Of a Wheeler-Dealer
description: How lavish a lifestyle is led by one of the richest men in the world? Sunday night's segment of ''Lifestyles of the Rich and Famous,'' the series being shown at 8 on Channel 11, answers this question by following Adnan Khashoggi, the Saudi dealmaker extraordinaire, to a handful of his 35 homes and his yacht and jet. The answer is predictable - very lavish indeed - and so, too, is the once- over-lightly treatment of the wheeling-and-dealing that has given Mr. Khashoggi a personal fortune in the billions.

title: ENGRAPH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SENATOR SEES CONCERN OVER CUOMO NOMINEE
description: The head of the State Senate committee that will consider Governor Cuomo's choice to oversee economic development in New York said today that there was some ''apprehension'' among Senators about the nomination.

title: Topics ;   Seasons and Seasonings ;   Don't Drink the WaterWashington has now issued authoritative instructions on how to cope with one of the great problems of our peripatetic era: that form of diarrhea commonly called turista. Do not, a Government panel warns, take antibiotics, Pepto-Bismol and other popular panaceas unless the condition that would provoke their use already exists. Wait, it said, for those symptoms that no one can mistake. Better yet, avoid those symptoms and their cause - which is to say, E. coli bacteria - by continually reminding yourself of the maxim that should be engraved upon the traveler's mind: ''If you can't boil it, cook it or peel it, forget it.'' All good advice. But if turista is about to become a part of the nation's universal memory bank, let us at least bid it a fitting farewell.
description: Without turista, the English language would have been sadly impoverished. Who is not richer for having known such elegant euphemisms as Montezuma's Revenge, the Aztec Two-Step, Delhi Belly, Barleycorn Sprints, Jimmy Britts and Lurkies? Without turista, the world would have lost countless travelers' tales - of what it is to spend an entire month brushing teeth with Coca-Cola; of what it is to brush with the

title: NORTHGATE EXPLORATION LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: THE Chinese restaurant scene on the Upper East Side has been relatively stagnant in recent years compared with the musical won ton game on the West Side and the ever-changing landscape in Chinatown. The last six months, however, have seen several notable newcomers take root uptown, which is a good omen for East Side residents as well as a boon to purveyors of gray felt wallpaper.

title: Heavy Snowfall in Armenia
description: The worst snowstorm in 30 years whipped into Armenia this week, dumping waist- deep snow that closed roads, pulled down power and telephone lines and damaged farms and factories. In three days, from Sunday through Tuesday, the snowfall in parts of the southern republic was 50 percent greater than the annual average, with winds gusting up to 75 miles an hour.

title: Flutie's Footwork Is Praised
description: Doug Flutie will make his initial impact in the United States Football League on account of his running rather than his passing, according to Rollie Dotsch, the coach of the Birmingham Stallions, and his scout, Bob Gates.

title: TREASURY RATES RISE FOR 4TH DAY
description: Interest rates on Treasury securities rose yesterday for the fourth consecutive trading day as securities dealers vainly tried to attract buyers for the large amount of notes and bonds they hold in inventory.

title: Tate and Grey
description: The saxophonist Buddy Tate and the trombonist Al Grey will lead a quintet tonight through Sunday at the Village Vanguard , 178 Seventh Avenue South below 11th Street (255- 4037). Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is an $8.50 cover and a one-drink minimum.

title: CABARET: SHARON MCKNIGHT
description: FLAMBOYANT female caricature has been a thriving subgenre of cabaret performance ever since the ascent of Bette Midler. And Sharon McNight, a buxom singer-comedienne from San Francisco, who dresses up to look like a box of valentine candy, carries this sort of campy, red-hot mama playfulness to its outer limits.

title: ON HEROES AND 'SLEAZE'
description: He winced at the sight of Thomas Jefferson and Benjamin Franklin doing bank commercials. He bristled at Abraham Lincoln reflecting on a large corporation's wisdom and character. And he was livid to see George Washington on television this week trying to sell Datsuns.

Swift Sets Closings
description: Blaming overcapacity in the pork-processing industry, the Swift Independent Corporation said that it would close two pork plants in Iowa on Sept. 1.

description: Adrian Branch led the way with 20 points tonight as Maryland walloped undermanned Towson State, 91-38, to give Coach Lefty Driesell his 500th career victory.

title: FILM: JOHN LANDIS'S INTO THE NIGHT
description: ED OKIN (Jeff Goldblum) has insomnia, is bored with his job as an aerospace engineer and with life in Los Angeles in general. He loves his wife, Ellen (Stacey Pickren), but the morning she breezily goes off to work with a departing ''Have a nice day,'' he suspects something is up. He's right. When he comes home early that afternoon, Ellen is in bed with another man. What should a guy do?

title: Black Women
description: ''African Diaspora Women,'' a photography exhibition on black women in the Caribbean and the United States, is being shown through March 30 at the Caribbean Cultural Center, 408 West 58th Street.

title: News Summary:   FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 22, 1985
description: International

title: PANEL TOLD OF HEROIN TRADE CHANGES
description: From the Khyber Pass to the cloud-wreathed peaks of Tibet, from inaccessible Mexican ridges to the poppy fields of Asia Minor, the production of heroin and its importation into the United States to meet a growing demand is straining the resources of American law-enforcement officials.

title: REAGAN BACKS SOME AID TO FARMERS
description: President Reagan said tonight that the plight of the nation's farmers was not wholly of their own making and that his Administration ''won't pull the rug out from under anyone instantly.''

description: THE Basel Ballet's second program in its current engagement at the Brooklyn Academy of Music does not come off second best. It is livelier than the first and rightly shows off a fine young company in a triple bill choreographed by Heinz Spoerli, the troupe's artistic director.

title: Jess Gorkin, 71, Editor Of Parade for 29 Years
description: Jess Gorkin, who edited Parade magazine for 29 years until he retired in 1978, died of a heart attack on Tuesday in Longboat Key, Fla., where he had a winter home. He was 71 years old and lived in White Plains.

description: Officials of the Committee for National Security, a relatively small organization pushing for arms control, suspect they have more influence on the Pentagon than one might expect.

GORDON'S 50 YEARS IN THE VANGUARD
description: The Village Vanguard, one of the world's most famous jazz clubs, will quietly note its 50th anniversary tonight, although Max Gordon, who has operated the small, triangular basement club at 178 Seventh Avenue South since its start in February 1935, is not certain that today is the exact date. But the Vanguard's telephone listing - ALgonquin 5-4037 in 1935, transformed in this numerical age to 255-4037 - is 50 years old today, which seemed to Mr. Gordon a good peg on which to hang an anniversary.

title: PERON QUITS AS HEAD OF HER TORN PARTY, BUT INTENT IS UNCLEAR
description: Former President Isabel Martinez de Peron was reported today to have stepped down as head of the Peronist Party, bringing a new element of disarray to Argentina's badly divided opposition movement.

description: The year-ago share earnings restated to reflect a 3-for-2 split of the company's stock distributed Jan. 4, 1984.

description: A trip to Las Vegas, Nev., with international honors beckoning on the horizon, will be on the line in the New York Grand National Team final Sunday at the Prince George Hotel, 14 East 28th Street. The winners will go to the Summer Nationals in July to compete in playoffs with representatives of 24 other districts.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption in Metropolitan Report yesterday with an article about AIDS victims incorrectly described the role of Bob Sheppard. He is an employee of the American Red Cross AIDS Home Attendant Program.

Eddie Thompson Solos
description: The English jazz pianist Eddie Thompson will play solos tonight at 6 at the New School, 66 West 12th Street. Admission is $6. Information: 741-5667. Mr. Thompson and the pianist Roger Kellaway will play duets tonight and tomorrow at 8:30 at Upstairs at Greene Street, 101 Greene Street (925-2415); admission is $10.

title: EAST GERMAN ENTERS GUILTY PLEA TO BUYING SECRET U.S. DOCUMENTS
description: An East German physicist pleaded guilty today to charges that he paid a United States Navy employee $21,800 for classified defense documents, which the authorities said posed no threat to national security. The Navy employee was cooperating with the United States authorities.

title: DOLE ADVISES STATES AGAINST RUSHING TO CUT TAXES
description: Senator Bob Dole, the majority leader, warned today that states with budget surpluses should not rush to cut taxes because Congress would probably approve major reductions in Federal aid to state and local governments.

title: ADAMS RESOURCES & ENERGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After tax credits of $3,000 for the quarter and $1,274,000 for the year. c-After tax credits of $156,000 for the quarter and $1,576,000 for the year. There were no share earnings in the latest fourth quarter after preferred dividends.

title: French Trade Deficit
description: France's foreign trade deficit widened in January to a seasonally adjusted 3.8 billion francs, or $372.5 million, from 661 million francs in December, the Industry Ministry said today.

title: S.E.C. STARTS INQUIRY
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is conducting a ''routine inquiry'' into the Bank of Boston and the Provident Institution for Savings to determine whether the two banks have complied with Federal securities law, a Federal investigator said today.

title: Dwindling Interest
description: Despite all the national attention focused on Doug Flutie's joining the Generals, the impact in and around Orlando, Fla., where the team trains, has been slight.

title: MATTINGLY NEEDS KNEE SURGERY
description: On the eve of the opening of their spring camp, the Yankees received a shock today when they learned that Don Mattingly probably has torn knee cartilage and will undergo arthroscopic knee surgery in New York Friday.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The Strategic Defense Initiative is not an optional program, at the margin of the defense effort.

title: SLAKING APPETITES IN YEAR OF THE OX
description: CHOPSTICKS will clack with extra vigor this weekend as devotees of Chinese food celebrate the New Year in the best way they know: feasting, toasting and more feasting. Happily for restaurantgoers, the Year of the Ox offers more dazzle than a box full of sparklers. New places have been popping up all over town, while the old standbys continue as good as ever. Here is a sampling of some worthy spots, both old and new:

title: Central Soya Stake
description: An investment group with a 5.1 percent stake in the Central Soya Company said it was seeking clearance from Federal antitrust regulators to increase its holdings in the company to as much as 15 percent of the total common stock outstanding. The group is led by Seaborg Inc., an investment concern based in Redondo Beach, Calif., and controlled by the Graziadio family trust of Encino, Calif. Central Soya's stock closed today at $18.875, unchanged, in New York Stock Exchange trading.

description: b-Net loss. The company said its results do not include the discontinued operations of Shasta.

title: MORE CHILD SUPPORT URGED
description: Absent fathers who have incomes of $35,000 or more a year can afford to pay far more in child support than is now being ordered by most state courts, according to a new nationwide study.

description: The Greyhound Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the consumer products division of Purex Industries, a closely held company based in Lakewood, Calif., for $264 million.

title: SPECIOUS THINKING ABOUT THE DOLLAR
description: The Government is hell-bent to cut the deficit in pursuit of its unjust political counterrevolution. Current and anticipated future Federal deficits, it is alleged, are solely responsible for the dollar's economically damaging overvaluation: swing the axe and help the dollar. Nonsense.

title: Seoul Expresses Regret Over Airport Melee
description: The State Department said today that South Korea had formally expressed regret that force was used against Americans accompanying the opposition leader Kim Dae Jung back to Seoul this month. The department said it now considered the matter closed.

title: HISTORY HOOKS HERNANDEZ
description: So many years have gone by, but Keith Hernandez can still remember those deliciously warm afternoons in the summer. The image is indelible: A youngster at a playground, swinging a bat and playing a game that would eventually make him one of the most talented baseball players in the big leagues.

title: New York State to Introduce New Lottery Games in Spring
description: New York State is planning to introduce two new lottery games in the spring, one with a top prize that could reach $50 million, the lottery director said today.

title: CUOMO BARS IDEA OF RESERVE FUND TO OFFSET THE LOSS OF FEDERAL AID
description: Governor Cuomo yesterday rejected the idea of creating a reserve fund to make up for the impact on New York State of potential Federal tax-rule changes and budget cuts. He called such a reserve a ''slush fund.''

title: By John Gross;
description: IN CUSTODY. By Anita Desai. 204 pages.

title: MOYNIHAN AND I.R.A. BACKERS MEET DURING THATCHER VISIT
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan met Wednesday with several Irish Republican Army sympathizers who were protesting the visit of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain. Aides to the New York Democrat said the hourlong meeting broke up without resolution.

title: ARTHUR SIEGEL, MULTITALENTED PIANO MAN OF CABARETS
description: ARTHUR SIEGEL, the singing pianist and composer who helped create ''Offbeats!'' the frothy living-room revue now at Michael's Pub, has been one of the busier figures in New York lately. Earlier this season, the ebullient, witty cabaret veteran and composer of four ''New Faces'' revues turned up at Michael's Pub with the singer Sandy Stewart for a Jerome Kern centennial tribute. Soon after, he returned as accompanist for Kaye Ballard, in her tribute to women songwriters. Now he's back as composer- performer-pianist in a daffy, fast- paced revue that pokes fun at People magazine, anorexia, esoteric New School curricula and other things.

title: U.S.F.L. to Use Replay By The Associated Press The United States Football League announced that it would use instant replay as a means of appealing an official's call for some games
description: during the 1985 season, starting with the game Sunday between the Generals and the Birmingham Stallions. Commissioner Harry Usher said the instant replay, used on an experimental basis in two exhibition games, ''was an idea whose time has

title: Article 044403 -- No Title
description: Tim Raines, the National League base-stealing champion, won a record arbitration salary figure of $1.2 million yesterday in the 13th and final case decided by an arbitrator.

title: ELIZABETHTOWN WATER CO reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Hasn't the Time Come to Stop Blaming OPEC?
description: To the Editor:

title: WARD DECLARES GOETZ DIDN'T SHOOT IN SELF-DEFENSE
description: Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward said yesterday that Bernhard H. Goetz, who shot four young men on a subway train, had not acted in self-defense and should have been indicted ''for some level of assault, right up to possible attempted murder.''

title: CHARTER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Operating earnings c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $41,250,000. d-Net income after a loss from discontinued operations of $2,715,000. The latest fourth quarter results include losses of $49,383,000. The year-ago results include a gain from settlement of claims of $2.5 million.

title: Friday FROM TV TO STAGE
description: Beah Richards, who played Sidney Poitier's mother in the 1967 film ''Guess Who's Coming to Dinner,'' won a Special Emmy in 1979 for her solo performance on public television of ''A Black Woman Speaks.'' The piece, about her career in the theater, was based on her writings, mostly poetry and diaries, and she has toured with it extensively. This weekend, she will give four performances of ''A Black Woman Speaks'' at the Henry Street Settlement's New Federal Theater, 466 Grand Street - at 8 tonight through Sunday and at 3 P.M. on Sunday. Tickets are $8 and the number for reservations is 598-0400. PANIC AT DANCE THEATER

title: MASSMUTUAL INCOME INVESORS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
WILAND SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DUELING 4-YEAR-OLDS WILL MEET AGAIN
description: The Great Rematch, Part II, goes off here Saturday as the Gulfstream Park Handicap, with a few shifts from Chapter I but just as many questions about whether it is much of a rematch at all.

title: Kuwaiti Voters Oust 2 Fundamentalists
description: Kuwaiti voters ousted two prominent Moslem fundamentalists and elected a bloc of leftists in balloting for the only elected Parliament among the Persian Gulf nations, according to the election results announced today.

title: ART: REVIVAL OF GEORGE TOOKER'S 'MAGIC REALISM'
description: EVEN as Abstract Expressionism was germinating in the early 1940's, there was a strong countertrend toward a very specific kind of representation. Usually known as Magic Realism, it was tinged with Surrealism - not the kind feeding Abstract Expressionism, but that descended from de Chirico.

title: Phantom Nicaragua Haunts Washington
description: To the Editor:

title: FIRST GROUP OF CUBAN ALIENS SENT BACK AS UNDESIRABLES
description: Twenty-three Cuban aliens were put aboard an airplane here today bound for Havana, the first of more than 2,700 unwanted Cubans who could be sent back as part of an agreement with the Government of Fidel Castro.

title: HARLYN PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NORTHERN AIR FREIGHT reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $229,786 for the quarter and $311,342 for the year. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $21,969 for the quarter and a gain from discontinued operations of $82,205 for the year.

title: Suspect Is Called Cocaine Queen'
description: Federal agents say a woman arrested this week in California on New York drug charges dating from 1975 was the ''cocaine queen'' of an international narcotics smuggling ring.

title: PARADISE FRUIT CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
EDITORS' NOTE
description: Under this heading, The Times amplifies articles or rectifies what the editors consider significant lapses of fairness, balance or perspective.

title: SENATE SNAGGED ON FARM AID PACKAGE
description: Senate efforts to forge a compromise on emergency credit for farmers reached an impasse tonight after the Reagan Administration sent a letter to Capitol Hill that Democrats termed ''insulting'' and too partisan.

title: VENTREX LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ECONOMY GREW AT A 4.9% RATE IN LAST QUARTER
description: The economy grew at an annual rate of 4.9 percent in the final three months of last year, a markedly faster rebound from its summer slowdown than previously estimated, the Commerce Department said today.

title: REPUBLIC RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
GORDON HAMMETT
description: Gordon Hammett, a radio talk-show host and producer, died Tuesday of a stroke in New York City. He was 61 years old and lived in Jackson Heights.

title: On Making 'Em Say Uncle
description: The imperial Presidency is back. President Reagan will agree to live with a troublesome Nicaragua only if its leftist rulers will surrender. If they don't, then he wants an American-backed proxy army to overthrow them. And if Congress has passed laws that bar this, it is just badly informed and those laws are only ''proposals.''

title: INFOTECH MANAGEMENT reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income.

title: C.I.A. Clarifies Its Testimony On Soviet Military Spending
description: Soviet military spending in 1981 exceeded that of the United States by 45 percent, although the annual increase in Moscow's arms spending has tapered off, the Central Intelligence Agency said today.

title: REXNORD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
NOT SO UP
description: After World War II we had the

title: Navy Defends 5th Season
description: As sports fans probably know, the United States Naval Academy has delayed the graduation of Napoleon McCallum, the greatest running back in Navy history, from June to December so he can play a fifth season of football. Navy Secretary John F. Lehman Jr. is backing the academy superintendent, Rear Admiral Charles R. Larson, in his decision, despite criticism from within the ranks and elsewhere.

title: A Blazing Cake For a 300th Birthday
description: On stage at Carnegie Hall, Marilyn

title: ICOT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: MICHAELS STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income. Year-ago results date from Feb. 25 when Michaels Stores Inc. began operating as a public company.

title: THREE TIED FOR LEAD AT DORAL
description: Tom Kite was the innocent victim of a penalty shot one minute but sank a chip shot the next as he tied Mark McCumber and Gary Hallberg today for the lead halfway through the 24th annual Doral Eastern Open.

title: 'Mild' Justice in Belgrade
description: To the Editor:

title: GERBER SYSTEMS TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
MAYNARD OIL CO reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $280,843. c-Net income after an extraordinary credit of $3,433,000.

title: Aiichiro Fujiyama, 87; Ex-Japanese Politician
description: Aiichiro Fujiyama, a businessman, politician and former Foreign Minister, died tonight at a Tokyo hospital, where he was being treated for an ulcer, a hospital spokesman said. He was 87 years old.

title: TUCSON ELECTRIC POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes income of $26,478,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Connors Upset
description: Top-seeded Jimmy Connors and third-seeded Aaron Krickstein were both upset in quarterfinal matches of the $375,000 Pilot Pen Classic men's tennis tournament today, meaning that none of the top eight seeded players will compete in the semifinals. Connors was overwhelmed in only 62 minutes by 14th-seeded Greg Holmes, 6-0, 6-3. Krickstein fell to unseeded David Pate, 6-2, 2-6, 6-1.

title:
PATENTS;

Warhead Penetrates Armored Vehicles
description: A highly lethal warhead, designed to penetrate armored vehicles, was patented this week. John N. Majerus and William P. Walters of the Aberdeen Proving Grounds in Maryland obtained patent 4,499,830 for the Army Materiel Command.

title: BLOCK ANNOUNCES AUSTERE FARM BILL
description: Agriculture Secretary John R. Block today disclosed details of a farm bill that would gradually reduce farm subsidies, eventually end Government storage of crop surpluses and eliminate direct farm loans from the Government.

title: 4-Letter Names
description: It's been a mystery, even to Ronn Reynolds: where his parents got that first name for him. Reynolds, the 26- year-old rookie catcher on the Mets, always finds himself telling people it's no typographical error - his first name is spelled Ronn, and it's not short for Ronald or anything else.

title: STANDARD MOTOR PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ASTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
KNICKS TOP HAWKS
description: Hope is all that remains for the Knicks, a fading belief that their woeful season can be salvaged by a berth in the playoffs.

title: INTERTHERM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DATUM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $89,000, or 3 cents a share, for the quarter and $187,000, or 7 cents a share, for the year. c-After an extraordinary credit of $144,000, or 6 cents a share, for the quarter and year. The 1983 sales include $1,600,000 from the company's now divested storage systems products business.

title: AMERICAN NATL INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said earnings in the latest fourth quarter and year include a gain of $155,835 from the release of deferred income tax liabilities as a result of the Deficit Reduction Act of 1984. The 1983 fourth quarter and full year results include a tax refund of $12,819,000.

title: Pickens Raises Unocal Stake By Reuters
description: An investment group led by T. Boone Pickens, the Texas oilman, has raised its stake in the Unocal Corporation to 16.6 million shares, or 9.7 percent of the total outstanding, the group told the Securities and Exchange Commission in a filing today.

title: MIDWAY AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge related to certain pre-operating expenses and initial losses of $6,639,000 for the quarter, a charge associated with the discontinued helicopter project of $1,680,000 for the year, and a special credit of $1,170,000 for the year from a gain incurred on the retirement certain long- term debentures.

title: Four Activists Convicted Of Damaging Missile Silo
description: Two Roman Catholic priests and two other people were convicted in Federal District Court today of conspiring to impede the national defense by damaging a Minuteman 2 missile silo.

title: Rolling Out A Littered Carpet
description: From an airplane, the city is breathtaking, sprawling by day, sparkling by night.

title: Work on Facade Allowed to Go On
description: New York City's Buildings Commissioner yesterday permitted work to resume on the facade of the Willkie Memorial Building, a midtown structure regarded as a candidate for landmark status.

title: NOTICES TO BOSTON BANK CITED
description: The First National Bank of Boston, which has maintained that it was not aware until last year of a 1980 law requiring it to report international currency transactions, was the subject of an extensive examination in 1982 by the Comptroller of the Currency that concentrated on its large cash transfers, the Government's chief bank examiner said yesterday.

title: MEXICO REPORTS PLEDGE FROM REAGAN
description: President Reagan pledged to President Miguel de la Madrid of Mexico today that traffic crossing the United States-Mexican border would be returned to normal ''in the briefest possible period,'' Mr. de la Madrid's office announced tonight.

title: Cedeno Sentenced
description: Cincinnati Reds outfielder-first baseman

title: Arco Outlines Plant Cutbacks PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 22 (AP) - The Atlantic Richfield Company is putting part of its Philadelphia refinery in mothballs and cutting the work force by about 25 percent while it seeks a buyer for the money-losing complex, company officials said.
description: In an effort to cut its losses at the facility in south Philadelphia, Arco said it plans to shut down a unit that produces gasoline from semi-refined oil. Closing the unit, called the hydrogen-hydrocracker complex, will eliminate about 50 of the 600 jobs at the refinery, Edward Griffith, Arco spokesman, said. Other changes ''to improve efficiency'' will trim the work force by about another 100 jobs, Mr. Griffith said.

title: TRIAL OF 26 OPENS IN AQUINO KILLING
description: The armed forces Chief of Staff and 25 other men went on trial today in the 1983 assassination of the opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr.

title: Foreign Relations Council Gets Election Proposals
description: Democratic means do not always

title: Letter: On Fighting Crime ;   Federal Efforts Are Winning the War
description: To the Editor:

title: Taiwan Plane's Dive Studied
description: Investigators of the near-crash of a China Airlines jet said today that they were puzzled by evidence showing that three of the plane's engines were still working when the plane dived toward the ocean. Crew members have said all four engines went out.

title: CONSUMER SATURDAY ;   ADVICE ON HELPING ELDERLY
description: Three Federal agencies have acted to aid the elderly. The moves include an effort to reduce the estimated three million accidents a year they suffer in the home.

title: Ford Lifts Prices on Some Cars
description: The Ford Motor Company said today that it was raising the price of many of its large cars, and of some optional equipment, by an average 1.7 percent. That represents an average increase of $200 across the Ford line.

title: KYSOR INDUSTRIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $302,000.

title: Hughes TOW Missiles
description: The Hughes Aircraft Company has said that its Tucson, Ariz., plant has sent its first shipment of TOW missiles to the Army since the company halted production last August because of quality control problems. Hughes said on Thursday that it had recently shipped 750 TOW-2 missiles.

title: Toxic Fumes Overcome Dozens at Boston Hotel
description: Toxic fumes from a malfunctioning boiler room spread through a downtown hotel today, sickening dozens of people and forcing at least 54 to seek hospital treatment.

title: Merger Plan Voted by Chiefs Of Paper and Atomic Unions
description: The boards of the United Paperworkers and the Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers unions have agreed to merge, it was announced Thursday.

title: DATA I-O CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said nonrecurring merger expenses of $900,000 relating to the acquisition of Futurenet Corp. were recorded in the fourth quarter, which reduced 1984 earnings by 9 cents a share.

title: 7-Year-Old Boy Saves Brother's Life With Hug
description: A 7-year-old boy who was taught the Heimlich maneuver by his mother a year ago and practiced on a stuffed monkey used the procedure to save the life of his 4-year-old brother, his parents said.

title: RAYMOND ENGINEERING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Sudden Setback
description: Jerry Holmes, the big-play cornerback who left the Jets in favor of the Pittsburgh Maulers, made it back to the New York area a month ago by signing with the Generals as a free agent. But he is not yet ready to make it back to the regular-season playing field.

title: ALAMITO CO reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
LEGISLATORS SAY REAGAN WILL FAIL ON COVERT AID TO ANTI-SANDINISTAS
description: Republican and Democratic legislators said today that Congress would not approve $14 million in aid for the Nicaraguan rebels, despite a stepped-up drive for it by President Reagan.

title: KOCH'S SHIFTS REFLECT COMPLEXITY OF GOETZ AND BUMPURS CASES
description: In the last two months, New York City has played host to two incidents that have sparked so overwhelming a public response that they have put public officials - never far from controversy - in a particularly hard position. Most have chosen to say something neutral or diplomatic, or to say nothing at all about the matters, among the most uncomfortable and politically risky issues to confront them in some time: the subway shooting of four young men by Bernhard H. Goetz and the indictment for manslaughter of a police officer in the shooting of Eleanor Bumpurs.

title: FLOATING POINT SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
EX-MAYOR SAID TO DIE IN RAID BY ISRAELIS
description: A former village mayor was reported to have died of exposure in southern Lebanon today after Israeli troops kept him and other Lebanese prisoners out all night in the cold.

title: I.B.M. to Raise Rates on Rentals RYE BROOK, N.Y., Feb. 22 (Reuters) - The International Business Machines Corporation said it was raising most equipment rental and lease rates, most program product licensing fees and contract maintenance charges on selected products, as of June 1. It also said there would be an 8 percent increase in systems engineering service rates and a 10 percent increase in per-call maintenance rates, effective immediately.
description: I.B.M. said the equipment rental and lease rates and program licensing fees were being increased 7 percent. Monthly maintenance prices on selected products will be increased by 5, 7 or 10 percent.

title: THRIFT UNIT INSURANCE FEE LEVIED
description: In an effort to strengthen its deposit insurance fund, which lost money last year for the first time, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today that it was going ahead with its plan to impose a special charge on all federally insured savings institutions.

title: HERLEY MICROWAVE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
FORMER POLITICAL ALLIES AT ODDS IN A JERSEY CITY
description: It is hard to believe now, but Nicholas Corbiscello and Sy Vogel once were political allies.

title: Brown Denies Charge
description: Jim Brown, the former running back who was accused along with a female companion of raping a 33- year-old woman at his Hollywood Hills home Tuesday night, said yesterday that he was innocent and would be vindicated in court. Brown described the unnamed complainant as a struggling tennis professional he had befriended, advised and helped financially.

title: COSMOS FOLD INDOOR SQUAD
description: The Cosmos, once the cornerstone of American soccer, said today they had withdrawn from the Major Indoor Soccer League. It was not clear whether they would be a member of the North American Soccer League this summer.

title: MISSOURI PUBLIC SERVICE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ISSAC KASHDAN, CHESS PLAYER AND A MATCH ORGANIZER, DIES
description: Isaac Kashdan, one of the foremost chess players in the United States in the 1930's and 1940's and for many years the chess editor of The Los Angeles Times, died Wednesday at his home in West Los Angeles. He was 79 years old.

title: HEALTH-CHEM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $52,000. c-After net from discontinued operations of $556,000 for the quarter and $2,841,000 for the year d-After a loss of $2,095,000 from the sale of investments in leverage leases, a $1,776,000 writeoff of excess cost over fair value of assets acquired, net from discontinued operations of $553,000, a gain of $7,767,000 from disposal of discontinued operations and a tax credit of $123,000. Figures are net of minority interests.

title: HIGH PLAINS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
2 Investigations Started In Spanish Plane Crash
description: Two investigations have started into the crash of a commercial airliner in northern Spain on Tuesday, a Department of Civil Aviation spokesman said today.

title: DELTAK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Some Things the Baby Boom Doesn't Explain
description: To the Editor:

title: T. H. Neyland Is Dead at 62; Director at Gulf and Western
description: T. H. Neyland, a former senior financial officer of Gulf and Western Industries and a member of the company's board of directors since 1962, died Thursday in Houston after a short illness. He was 62 years old.

title: Austrian Minister Resigns
description: Austria's Minister of Construction and Technology, Karl Sekanina, resigned today after press allegations of financial misconduct. Chancellor Fred Sinowatz said that he had been unable to confirm the allegations and could not believe anything was wrong, but that the reports had hampered the work of the Government.

title: TALKS BREAK DOWN IN SENATE ON LOANS TO ASSIST FARMERS
description: In an outburst of partisan rancor, negotiations to seal a compromise on farm credit legislation collapsed in the Senate early this morning, and the filibuster blocking a vote on the confirmation of Edwin Meese 3d as Attorney General is to continue.

title: SPY LAWS DEBATED IN HEARING ON U.S. WORKER FOR DISCLOSING SECRETS
description: A Justice Department lawyer argued in Federal Court here today that a Government employee who is accused of providing a classified document to a British military magazine had violated the espionage laws because ''foreign agents read that magazine.''

title:
PATENTS;

Cutting Red Blood Cells In Race Horses
description: John H. Boucher of Silver Spring, Md., a veterinarian who conducts research in the flow of blood components in animals, was granted patent 4,500,530 this week for reducing the abnormal red blood cells caused in horses by activity, such as racing.

title: COMPUTER LANGUAGE REEARCH reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Arrau Postpones Recital
description: The pianist Claudio Arrau has postponed his recital at Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday afternoon. Mr. Arrau, who is 82 years old, has the flu, according to Joe McKaughan, vice president for public affairs at Lincoln Center. The concert, the Chilean pianist's only New York solo recital this season, has been rescheduled for May 13 at 8 P.M.

title: EL CHICO CORP reports earnings for 12wks to Feb 8
description: The year-ago results restated for yearend adjustments.

title: INDIAN MUSEUM BACKS PLAN FOR MOVE TO TEXAS
description: The trustees of the Museum of the American Indian voted yesterday to seek an agreement with H. Ross Perot, the Texas computer executive, to move the museum from New York City to Dallas.

title: FEDDERS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $1,124,000, or 9 cents a share c-After a tax credit of $750,000, or 6 cents a share.

title: AVALON ENERGY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $188,000. c-Net income after extraordinary gains of $100,000 for the quarter and $819,000 for the year. d-After an extraordinary gain of $405,000.

title: REAGAN COMMENT CITED
description: The dollar surged again yesterday, this time getting a lift from comments by President Reagan at his news conference Thursday night. The dollar set records against British, French, West German, Italian and Canadian currencies. In the United States, the price of gold tumbled $4, to $295, in reaction.

title: Space Shortage in Geneva
description: Max M. Kampelman, the new chief arms negotiator for the United States, has chosen as his deputy Warren Zimmerman, a career Foreign Service officer who once served as the No. 2 American diplomat in Moscow. Meanwhile, the addition of a third negotiating team to represent the Administration in talks on strategic defense weapons in space, sometimes referred to as ''Star Wars,'' has created an office space crunch in Geneva, the site of the arms control talks with the Soviet Union. The American delegation works out of the Botanical Building in Geneva, and officials are scrambling to find additional office space to accommodate the new arrivals.

title: Francis O. Wilcox, 76; Ex-State Dept. Official
description: Francis Orlando Wilcox, a State Department official in the Eisenhower Administration, died of a heart attack here on Wednesday. He was 76 years old.

title: SHOULD THE LIBRARY THROW THE BOOK AT 'EM?
description: It is now possible to go to jail here for the crime of harboring overdue library books, as 29-year-old Constance Moore discovered recently.

title: TELECOMMUNICATION SPEIALISTS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SNYDER OIL PARTNERS reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Book-Entry Form for U.S. Debt
description: The Treasury Department announced yesterday that, beginning in 1986, it would stop providing engraved paper certificates for Government notes and bonds.

title: NEW LIMIT SOUGHT ON HEART PROGRAM
description: Dr. William C. DeVries said today that the artificial heart program had reached a stage at which he would limit the amount of medical information released about the experimental procedure.

title: Murchison's Chapter 11 DALLAS, Feb. 22 (AP) - Clinton W. Murchison Jr., the Texas oilman and former owner of the Dallas Cowboys, has filed a request for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy laws while he reorganizes his assets and draws up a plan to retire more than $140 million in debt.
description: Philip I. Palmer Jr., Mr. Murchison's lawyer, said that the conversion of an earlier petition for involuntary bankruptcy filed by some creditors was virtually automatic and would allow Mr. Murchison to plan for the orderly sale of some of his assets.

title: Business Groups Urge Cut in Pentagon Funds
description: Two business groups, the Business Roundtable and the National Association of Manufacturers, today called for lower military spending to help cut the Federal budget deficit.

title: PERPETUAL AMERICAN BANK F S B reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: KOCH SUPPORTS BILL ON HEATING OF APARTMENTS
description: Saying that ''a heated apartment is one of the most basic rights of every tenant,'' Mayor Koch joined a group of state lawmakers yesterday in proposing state legislation that would make it a felony for landlords to deny heat to tenants.

title: TROUBLED TIMES AT STAUFFER
description: The Stauffer Chemical Company of Westport, Conn., has had troubles aplenty in recent years. It is saddled with a debt of $314.4 million; its chemicals sector, which accounts for half its sales, has not recovered with the rest of the industry, and its agricultural products sector, which accounts for almost a third of its sales, has suffered in part because of reduced corn plantings and three years of wet planting seasons.

title: Delay on Short Interest
description: The New York Stock Exchange said it would release its short interest report for February on Monday afternoon. The report had been scheduled for release yesterday but was delayed because of computer problems, the exchange said.

title: ROPAK WEST INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DIXON BETTERS 440-YARD MARK TWICE
description: Sometimes it does not pay to listen to your coach. Diane Dixon did not, and as a result, she set a world indoor best and an American record in the 440-yard run last night in the USA/ Mobil Indoor Track and Field Championships in Madison Square Garden.

title: Cruise Missile Test Delayed
description: The second test flight this week of a United States cruise missile over Canada has been postponed until Saturday, a Canadian military spokesman said. The spokesman, Maj. Dick Adam of the Defense Department, said the test, scheduled for today, was delayed because of a problem with one of the aircraft used to monitor the unarmed missile.

title: INFORMATION INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $361,603 for the quarter and $397,028 for the 9 months. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $1,755 for the quarter and $23,920 for the 9 months.

title: SOVIET A-PLANT MOVE PRAISED
description: Reagan Administration officials today applauded the Soviet Union's decision to open some of its civilian nuclear power plants to international inspection, but said they were skeptical of Soviet assertions that the agreement might have implications for arms control.

title: GOOD FENCES MAKE GOOD NEIGHBORS
description: My wife and I were picking daffodils on our neighbor's property when he arrived, surprising us, to open his house for the season. Frank's little pickup truck, his country conveyance, came muttering down the dirt road, jouncing over the humps and potholes. My wife and I stood up sheephishly, clutching fists full of his flowers.

title: CORRECTION
description: A United Nations dispatch yesterday on conditions in Iranian and Iraqi prisoner-of-war camps incorrectly characterized reports of religious pressure on non-Moslem prisoners. The reports referred to Iran only.

title: NEW FOCUS ON JAIL ALTERNATIVE
description: The sentencing of John A. Zaccaro to perform community service for his misdemeanor fraud conviction has focused attention on the growing use of this alternative form of punishment for nonviolent offenders.

title: MATTINGLY UNDERGOES SURGERY
description: Don Mattingly had torn cartilage in his right knee removed by arthroscopic surgery today and is expected to be ready to play in three weeks, the Yankees said.

title: His Past Comes Back To Haunt Thurmond
description: The tables were turned today on the man who holds the record for the longest Senate filibuster, Strom Thurmond, Republican of South Carolina.

title: Nat Adderley Quintet
description: The cornetist Nat Adderley and his quintet are appearing tonight through Sunday at Sweet Basil , 88 Seventh Avenue South above Bleecker Street (242-1785). Sets begin at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M.; there is a $10 cover and a $6 minimum.

title: MUSIC: SCHULLER LEADS U.S. COMPOSERS GROUP
description: The American Composers Orchestra presented an uncharacteristically dreary concert at Alice Tully Hall Thursday night, under the direction of Gunther Schuller. The members of the orchestra - some of the busiest freelance musicians in the city - played with skill, and they were joined by some distinguished soloists: the soprano Christine Schadeberg, the pianist Leo Smit and the clarinetist Richard Stoltzman, among others. Still, it was a long evening, and the blame must be placed on some uninspiring material.

title: DAXOR CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the results reflect a reclassification of its marketable securities portfolio as a current rather than a non-current asset and a resultant recognition on net unrealized losses of $217,986 in 1984 and $345,753 in 1983.

title: 5 in India Reported To Recant Confessions
description: Five suspects in India's espionage scandal were reported to have retracted their confessions today, charging they were tortured into making them.

title: Mr. Sprinkel's Client If President Reagan pays no more attention to his new chief economist than he paid the last one, his selection of Beryl Sprinkel for the post should do no lasting damage. Mr. Sprinkel, nominated to be chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, is a dogmatic monetarist, given to bashing the Federal Reserve System and foreign finance ministers. He may ruffle feathers, but an adviser has little influence if the advisee doesn't listen.
description: The White House says the President will quickly fill all three council seats, and the depleted staff will be rebuilt to ''full strength.'' That's nice.

title: COMPANY NEWS ;   URANIUM HALT TIED TO UNC WRITE-OFF
description: UNC Resources Inc., a producer of nuclear components and minerals, said yesterday that it was discontinuing its uranium mining business and as a result would take a $152 million charge in its 1984 fourth quarter.

title: INA CLAIRE, 92, WHO BROUGHT COMIC ARTISTRY TO STAGE ROLES
description: Ina Claire, one of the most celebrated performers of high comedy on the American stage, died Thursday at her home in San Francisco. She was 92 years old.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: Under this heading, The Times amplifies articles or rectifies what the editors consider significant lapses of fairness, balance or perspective.

title: BLUEFIELD SUPPLY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GOULD INVESTORS TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

LOUIS HAYWARD, 75, SWASHBUCKLING HERO IN ADVENTURE FILMS
description: Louis Hayward, a dashing actor with silky manners who made his reputation playing swashbuckling heroes in movies during the 1930's and 40's, died of lung cancer yesterday at Desert Hospital in Palm Springs, Calif. He was 75 years old.

description: Negotiators for the Long Island Rail Road and its supervisors reached a tentative contract agreement yesterday, averting a strike threatened for midnight last night.

title: 2 Sought in Gem Robbery
description: The holdup of an antique store in which $2 million in diamonds and jewelry was taken was probably the work of two professionals who had a specific plan, the authorities said Thursday. Two men handcuffed five employees of Red Door Antiques in west Odessa Wednesday and escaped with $2 million in loose diamonds and jewels.

title: LAOS REMAINS OF G.I.'S CALLED HARD TO IDENTIFY
description: American military officers indicated today that it would take at least a month to begin identifying remains found at a site in Laos where an American gunship crashed during the Vietnam War.

title: MEYERS PARKING SYSTEM reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $1,026,000.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Lawrence Taylor, the Giants linebacker, was ordered by a North Carolina court to buy a house worth at least $70,000 and pay $900 a month to support a 4-year-old girl he fathered while a student at the University of North Carolina. . . .

title: Asking for Help

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: SHANKER 'CLARIFICATION'
description: Labor leaders who have been migrating for years to the east coast of Florida for their winter conferences say they have never seen anything quite like it.

title: ABC REPORTER MAY SUE WRESTLER WHO HIT HIM
description: John Stossel, a reporter for ABC's ''20/20'' magazine program, says he may sue the professional wrestler named ''Dr. D.'' The blond, bearded wrestler, who is 6 feet, 6 inches tall and weighs 268 pounds, hit Mr. Stossel on both sides of the head, leaving him, Mr. Stossel says, with possible permanent pain and buzzing in his ears.

title: Nicaragua Accuses U.S.
description: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra accused President Reagan today of carrying out a policy of ''war, terrorism and aggression against the people of Nicaragua'' and of ''attempting to manipulate and confuse the people of the United States'' about the nature of the Sandinista revolution.

title: GENERALS LOOKING TO YOUNG PLAYERS
description: The signing of the center Kent Hull to a new three-season contract was a significant move for the Generals. It was a signal to the other young players that the Generals will try to keep their young talent from defecting to the National Football League.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: SECOND THOUGHT Isn't Life Wonderful,'' D. W. Griffith's 1924 silent film about poverty, hunger and debasement in post- World War I Germany, had two endings. The first was grim: potatoes grown secretly in a forest by a young couple who plan a meager feast are stolen; the couple are pursued and robbed as they try to retrieve what remains of the crop, and they are left once again with nothing. But within a few days, Griffith tacked on a happier scene, showing the couple a year later, still surviving and glad to have each other.

title: CHERNENKO MISSES AN APPEARANCE ON ADVICE OF DOCTORS, SOVIET SAYS
description: The Soviet public was officially advised that Konstantin U. Chernenko had stayed away from an important speaking engagement today ''on the recommendation of his doctors.''

title: CLUES SOUGHT IN NIGHTLONG FIRE AT JERSEY PORT
description: Pockets of flame and scores of small explosions persisted throughout the day yesterday as officials sought the cause of a spectacular nightlong fire that destroyed a sprawling warehouse on the New Jersey waterfront at Port Elizabeth.

title: Free Vintage Rock
description: Rock Around the Dock,'' a free series of rock concerts, begins tomorrow at 5 P.M. with Tommy James and the Shondells at the South Street Seaport in Lower Manhattan.

title: ATOMIC REACTOR SHUT IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: South Africa's only nuclear power station, which employs some American personnel, has been closed indefinitely because of flaws in water-carrying stainless steel pipes, the state-run company that operates it said today.

title: RANGERS START FAST AND WIN
description: Sparked by four first-period goals, including the first of three by Peter Sundstrom, the Rangers pinned an 8-3 defeat on the Pittsburgh Penguins tonight and opened a 5-point lead over the Devils for fourth place in the Patrick Division.

title: STAGE: EDWARD SAKAMOTO' 'MANOA VALLEY'
description: It is a bright, sunny day in August 1959 and Tosh Kamiya and his relatives are gathered to toast Hawaii's statehood. In keeping with the spirit of that event, Edward Sakamoto's ''Manoa Valley'' at the Pan Asian Repertory Theater honors traditional family values. Although there are domestic differences, optimism is endemic. Even before the happy ending, one knows instinctively that the Kamiyas will come through.

title: REDMEN FIRE UP SYRACUSE
description: St. John's faces Syracuse Saturday afternoon in a game that students and residents of this area are calling the biggest of the season. The Carrier Dome record for attendance is 32,520, and officials think this game may break that mark.

title: 2 Are Charged in Connection With Fatal Crash in Brooklyn
description: Two Brooklyn men surrendered to the police yesterday and were charged in connection with a hit-and-run accident in which a 14-year-old girl was killed Wednesday near her home in the Bay Ridge section of the borough.

title: METRO'S TRAINS ESERVE A VALENTINE
description: ''Welcome aboard the breadline train to Shady Grove. Next stop Woodlawn Park and the National Zoo.''

title: Police Union's Offices In Manhattan Bombed
description: A bomb exploded at the office of the Patrolman's Benevolent Association in lower Manhattan early this morning, the police said, and a group calling itself the Red Guerrilla Defense claimed responsibility, saying the bombing was in protest of the union's support of officers indicted in the deaths of blacks.

title: COSTS OF MOVING M.T.A.'S AIDES CALLED TOO HIGH
description: Newly hired transit executives have run up ''unreasonable or excessive'' moving expenses, a report says, and Mayor Koch has asked the chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to take measures to recoup the money.

Did Transit Police officers beat him to death after his arrest for graffiti-marking? Was the Medical Examiner's investigation satisfactory? How dependable is the management of the Transit Police?

description: Almost all the competitions sponsored by the Greater New York Bridge Association are played for blood. Everyone is determined to win, and crackling criticisms sometimes pass across the table when something has gone wrong.

title: Decision on Ray Williams Due
description: Dave DeBusschere, the Knicks vice-president in charge of operations, said that he saw no point in procrastinating in making a decision concerning free-agent guard Ray Williams, who signed an offer sheet with the Boston Celtics on Thursday.

title: Betty Cage Resigning As City Ballet Official
description: Betty Cage, general administrator of the New York City Ballet, will resign effective April 30, the company has announced. Miss Cage joined City Ballet in 1947 and became its ''labor negotiator, certified public accountant, legal expert, mother superior, confessor, psychiatrist,'' in the words of Lincoln Kirstein, City Ballet's general director.

title: Teachers' Union Calls For Strike in Mississippi
description: Mississippi's largest teachers union has called for a statewide walkout starting Monday to protest the Legislature's failure to provide teachers a $7,000 raise over two years.

title:
PATENTS;

Reducing A Cold's Duration
description: WASHINGTON

title:
PATENTS;

A Device to Detect Presence of People
description: A Government physicist, working on his own time, has invented a device to detect the presence of the human body. Michael Hacskaylo, who was granted patent 4,500,784 this week, expects the device to be used for such purposes as finding lost children in woods, although military applications are likely as well.

title: CREDIT MARKETS ;   Yields Of Bonds Up Again
description: Short-term interest rates were little changed yesterday, but bond yields continued to rise and have increased by about half a percentage point in the last five trading sessions.

title: Merrill Lynch Has Datacast Stake By Reuters
description: The Financial News Network said Merrill Lynch & Company had invested $4 million for the purchase of a major position in Datacast Inc., a company formed to carry financial information within the network's television signal to 18 million cable viewers.

title: SOME THINGS THE BABY BOOM DOESN'T EXPLAIN
description: I was pleased by your editorial critical of Charles Murray's ''Losing Ground: American Social Policy 1950-80'' and its use by advocates of major cuts in Government social spending. It is Mr. Murray's contention that Government social programs have actually hurt minorities and the poor in the last 20 years; yet his analysis is riddled with inaccuracies and omissions, even beyond those that the editorial points out.

title: MOBIL SALE OF UNITS WEIGHTED
description: The Mobil Corporation said yesterday that it was considering selling its poorly performing businesses. The announcement came at a special shareholders meeting at which four anti-takeover measures were approved.

title: BOARD OF REGENTS PROHIBITS COPORAL PUNISHMENT IN PUBLIC SCHOOLS
description: Corporal punishment was banned in New York State public schools yesterday by the State Board of Regents, after a debate of several months over whether it had the authority to take such action.

title: ETHIOPIAN MUSIC
description: Seleshe Damessae, an Ethiopian singer and performer on the krar (six-stringed lyre), will offer a concert to benefit famine relief in Ehtiopia tonight and 8 at the Alternative Museum, 17 White Street, 966-4444. Tickets are $10.

title: WORK HALTED ON ROAD TO CARTER LIBRARY IN ATLANTA
description: The bitter battle over the 2.4-mile parkway that is to serve the Carter Presidential Library has taken a new turn, with a state judge halting work on the project.

title: A REFINED ERA PASSES AT DUNHILL'S HUMIDOR ROOM
description: Housekeepers, messengers, chauffeurs and all manner of hired help are bounding up the plush carpeted staircase at Dunhill's on Fifth Avenue these days, dispatched forthwith to fetch their employers' cigars.

title: Two Lead in TucsonTUCSON, Ariz. (AP) - Betsy King, the top money winner on the 1984 LPGA tour, and Anne-Marie Palli shot two-under-par 70's, each getting an eagle, to share the lead after the second round of the $175,000 Tucson Open. After matching their first-round scores, the leaders were at four-under 140 after 36 holes over the 6,212-yard Randolph Golf Course.
description: Judy Clark and Lisa Young also scored 70 and were one stroke behind the leaders at 141.

title: SMITH CONTINUES 'LONG GOODBYE' AS BATTLE OVER MEESE RAGES ON
description: As the Senate struggled through a fourth day of a filibuster blocking the confirmation of Edwin Meese 3d as Attorney General, the outgoing Justice Department chief, William French Smith, prepared for departure and was honored at parties.

Cuts at Texas Instruments Texas Instruments Inc. said yesterday that it plans to extend its work- schedule cuts in its semiconductor operations through the second quarter of 1985, because demand for its components has not revived.
description: The Dallas-based company, which laid off about 2,000 workers in December, said that slack demand is ''adversely affecting revenues and margins in Texas Instruments' semiconductor operations.'' Michael Rice, a spokesman for the company, said ''no further layoffs are currently planned,'' adding that most of the work cuts affect overseas plants.

title: CATHOLICS, JEWS: 20 GOOD YEARS
description: Twenty years ago this October, Roman Catholic bishops, at the Second Vatican Council in Rome, repudiated the deicide charge against the Jews and condemned anti-Semitism. Their landmark statement, ''Nostra Aetate'' (''In Our Times''), declared that Jesus's death ''cannot be blamed upon all the Jews then living, without distinction, nor upon the Jews of today.'' The Church ''deplores the hatred, persecutions, and displays of anti-Semitism directed against the Jews at any time and from any source.''

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
THE NON-REFLECTING MAYOR
description: Mayor Koch says he has a duty to comment on everything. He says the public wants to know what he thinks about all aspects of the universe. But when his dawn-to-dusk commenting creates an unanticipated protest or contributes to racial tensions in the city, he blames the problem on someone else. Most recently he has been blaming the press. This is odd, since reporters are the people he lives for. Without them, who would record his comments? How would his opinions get on radio and television and into the newspapers, all of his daily sustenance?

title: Meredith Monk Films

title: Tuning Out Interruptions
description: It's called ''One on One,'' and its devoted listeners believe that it is the best radio call-in sports show in the New York area. From 11 P.M. to 2 A.M. on Saturday and Sunday nights, a rotating group of student-hosts on the staff of Fordham University's WFUV-FM engage in dialogue with telephone callers whose interest is generally limited to the bread-and- butter sports - baseball, football, basketball and hockey - but whose strength of opinion frequently knows no limits whatever. And therein lie the seeds of a problem.

Guidry, looking no different from when he enjoyed winning seasons, appeared at Fort Lauderdale Stadium today to begin spring training with the rest of the Yankee pitchers.
