description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $1,511,000. c-After income from discontinued operations of $462,000. d-After a loss from discontinued operations of $7,998,000. e-Preferred dividend requirements exceeded final net income. The 1983 fourth quarter earnings included a gain of $2,068,000, or 25 cents a share, from the sale of real estate.

title: CITICORP PLANS TO BUY LONDON DEALER
description: Citicorp increased its presence in the London financial markets today by agreeing to buy Seccombe, Marshall & Campion, a specialist firm that deals in the short-term money market.

title: GENERAL REFRACTORIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a reversal of tax benefit of $100,000. c-After a tax benefit of $800,000. d-Net loss

title: FOOD CO-OPS IN A STRUGGLE
description: In this university-dominated city known for its alternative ways of life, shopping at the co-op was once an article of faith. Not only was the co-op owned by local residents instead of by distant capitalists, but also its emphasis on natural foods, product boycotts and consumer activism gave it a central role in the educational and political life of the community, especially during the 1960's and 1970's.

title: APACHE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $213,000 for the quarter and $93,000 for the year. c-After net from discontinued operations of $372,000 for the quarter and $1,553,000 for the year.

title: NORSTAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TRADING IS SLOWER
description: Stock prices fell moderately yesterday, reflecting continued concern over remarks by the Federal Reserve Board's chairman, Paul A. Volcker, that the Fed had ended its easing of credit conditions and fears that interest rates would rise.

title: AMTRAK TO PRESS FOR FEDERAL AID
description: Amtrak, opposing President Reagan's plan to halt Federal support, said today it would ask Congress to renew its subsidy in 1986 at this year's level, $684 million.

title: BUCKHORN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $2,943,000 for the quarter and $4,856,000 for the year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $666,000 for the quarter and $3,844,000 for year.

title: New Zealand Warned About Role in Alliance
description: A top State Department official warned New Zealand today that its refusal to permit a port call by United States ships carrying nuclear weapons amounted to abandonment of its operational role in the Anzus alliance.

title: Salant Corp. Files Under Chapter 11 The Salant Corporation, a diversified apparel producer, said that it had filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy laws. The company also said that separate bankruptcy petitions would be filed by its subsidiaries, the Obion Company and the Thomson Company Inc. The company listed liabilities of $75.1 million and assets of $106.5 million.
description: Salant said that its board had also approved agreements with the Manufacturers Hanover Commercial Corporation for a secured credit facility under which Salant, Obion and Thomason may borrow up to $17.5 million, subject to bankruptcy court approval. The company said that sum, if approved, would allow the three concerns to finance their 1985 business plans.

title: Books of the Times;   AFRICA DESPOILED
description: THE RAPE OF SHAVI. By Buchi

title: POOR DEFENSE TRIPS UP NETS
description: For nearly three weeks, the Nets seemed to be building toward something important. But now two games that should have been routine victories have become disheartening losses, the latest being tonight's 131- 127 loss to the Golden State Warriors at Byrne Meadowlands Arena. It was only the third victory on the road in 28 games this season for the Warriors.

title: WINNERS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SMITH LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Six Charged in Inquiry Of Philadelphia Police
description: Two Philadelphia police officers and four former officers were indicted today by a Federal grand jury on charges of extortion and conspiracy to protect illegal vice activities.

title: TENNESSEE NATURAL REOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
UPPER MICHIGAN CITY BUOYED BY ROLE AS A NEW OLYMPICS TRAINING CENTER
description: The designation of Northern Michigan University as the nation's third Olympic training center is being welcomed here as a bit of good fortune for an area that has not had much in recent years.

title: EASCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The latest fourth quarter results include a pretax charge of $3.7 million related to a hand tool plant shutdown. The latest year results include pretax charges for unusual items of $16.2 million. The 1983 results include a pretax gain of $2.1 million on the disposal of plants and businesses. The results for all periods have been restated to reflect the acquisition of the Oxwall Tool Co. in October 1984 on a pooling of interest basis.

title: President Contradicts Study Sent to Congress
description: President Reagan contradicted his own report to Congress when he said Thursday night that Moscow violated strategic arms agreements in converting old ballistic missile submarines to fire nuclear cruise missiles.

title: LABOR'S STUDY: BLEND OF OLD AND NEW
description: Confronted with difficulty after difficulty, the American labor movement has taken a long, serious look at itself.

title: INVESTORS INSURANCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results include realized investment gains of $2,180 in the latest quarter and $38,142 in the latest year.

title: HOTEL PROPERTIES reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $695,000, or 42 cents a share, on sale of property.

title: ECKERD, JACK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 26
Israel MakesHussein an Offer
description: Simply by holding their first meeting devoted to the Middle East in seven years, the United States and the Soviet Union last week made diplomatic waves. Israel, which is determined to keep the Russians out of regional peacemaking, tendered a new offer of direct talks to King Hussein of Jordan. ''We are not looking for a show - we are looking for a dialogue,'' said Israel's Prime Minister Shimon Peres. He said he was ''ready to go to Amman,'' the Jordanian capital, or to see the King in Jerusalem so Hussein can ''announce whatever is on his mind.'' The allusion was to the King's agreement this month with Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, on a framework for negotiations with Israel.

title: 15 HURT
description: A bomb exploded at an entrance to the Paris branch of the British-owned department store Marks & Spencer as it opened for business today, killing a man and wounding 15 other people, the police said.

title: STUDENT LOANS IMPERILED, STATE TOLD
description: TRENTON

title: Sports of The Times ;   U.S.F.L. Replays Not That Simple
description: IT seems so simple. Beginning

title:
GARDENING;

ANNUAL SHOWS BRING A BIT OF SPRING
description: IT seems that the spring flower

title: Pakistan to VoteThe Zia Way
description: Gen. Mohammad Zia ul-Haq seized power in Pakistan in 1977 and has ruled under martial law ever since. Voting tomorrow and Thursday for a National Assembly and provincial legislatures could be a step toward civilian rule, as General Zia has promised, but none of his opponents believe it.

title:
ANTIQUES;

ONE-DAY SALE IN DANBURY NEW SIGN OF SPRING
description: ON next Sunday, so far as the burgeoning spring antiques season is concerned, March is expected to roar in like a lion when a new one-day sale makes its debut. Titled ''The Collector's Eye,'' the show will be held in the convention hall of the Hilton Inn in Danbury.

title: Shared Blame,Shared Costs
description: When the New Jersey Supreme Court decided last June that a host was liable for the automotive smash- ups of drunken guests, critics questioned how the ruling would be applied. They got their answer last week, when lawyers in the case that prompted the decision - a collision in which a woman was seriously injured - agreed to a $172,500 settlement.

title: Drunkenness Cited in Crash
description: The driver of a van that collided with a bus carrying a high school basketball team, injuring 15 people, has been cited for drunken and negligent driving, the police said. The bus was carrying the Chicago Calumet High School team home Friday night after a game at Chicago South Shore High School. Most of the injuries were slight, the police said, but the driver of the van, James Wheatley, 32 years old, had serious facial injuries.

title: JEROME ROBBINS CONTINUES A CITY BALLET TRADITION
description: Jerome Robbins's choice of Minimalist composers Philip Glass and Steve Reich for two of his ballets has perhaps seemed provocative with respect to the New York City Ballet's recent musical policies. Against a background of ballet festivals conceived by George Balanchine in tribute to Tchaikovsky, Ravel and Stravinsky, and against a repertory whose music increasingly harks back to the 18th and 19th centuries, the repetitive reductive sounds of a barely 20-year- old musical trend may look like slim pickings.

title: Advising Barkeeps
description: The New Jersey Division of Alcoholism began in October to give advice to people who were more accustomed to dispensing it: barkeepers.

title: MX REVERSAL BY AUSTRALIAN ISN'T POPULAR
description: Prime Minister Bob Hawke appears to have suffered a significant loss of public support over his reversal of an earlier pledge to Washington to allow the use of Australian bases to monitor an MX missile test.

title: 50 Said to Die in Fire On Crowded Indian Train
description: A train crowded with wedding passengers caught fire today in Madhya Pradesh and 50 people burned to death, the United News of India said.

title:
PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW;

THE CLOSE-UP PUSHED TO ITS LIMIT
description: Art historians who do not take abstract painting very seriously have a little trick that they use in slide lectures. They photograph a small, insignificant passage of brushwork from a painting by a long-forgotten, once-very-successful Salon painter - say, Paul Chabas, whose coy, sentimental nude, ''September Morn,'' shocked public opinion in 1912. They then present this blown-up detail as a work by a new abstract painter. The subject of the original painting is lost, the loops and swirls of paint take over, and the superficial resemblance to an abstract painting of the 1940's and 50's can be very striking.

title: Brush Fires in Florida Brought Under Control
description: State foresters reported today that the newest series of brush fires in Florida, including one that charred more than 4,000 acres, were under control, but cautioned that a shift in wind could rekindle some of them.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: Theatergoers who like to keep up with adventurous talents - even at the price of seeing imperfect works - would be well-advised to take a flyer on two of Off Broadway's most recently arrived productions. Both ''3 Guys Naked From the Waist Down,'' the musical at the Minetta Lane, and ''Coming of Age in SoHo,'' the Albert Innaurato comedy at the Public Theater, collapse in their second acts. But the first acts of these shows are lively indeed - and are likely to prove significant way-stations in their idiosyncratic authors' still-developing careers.

title: Susan M. and Dianne M. Clair, Sisters, Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Raymond A. Clair of Wantagh, L.I., have announced the engagements of their daughters Susan Marion Clair and Dianne Marie Clair to Peter Franklyn Lucey and James Skinner Wenk, respectively.

title: SENATE APPROVES MEESE TO BECOME ATTORNEY GENERAL
description: The Senate voted today to confirm Edwin Meese 3d as Attorney General, more than a year after he was first nominated by President Reagan.

title: A RCIPE FOR SUCCESS
description: For reasons that are not entirely clear, top-ranked bridge partnerships consisting of players who are married to each other are quite rare. And when they do occur, marital difficulties are not uncommon. From Ely and Josephine Culbertson on, a majority of these marriages have ended in divorce.

title: DANCE: JOAN LOMBARDI
description: The Joan Lombardi Dance Company and Novensemble appeared on Thursday at the Theater of the Riverside Church (Riverside Drive at 120th Street) in the most frustrating of programs. Miss Lombardi has a fine company of dancers, and her taste and intelligence are reflected in the dances' muted themes and in the costumes and sets. She works with interesting new music scores, played on stage for two dances by Shem Guibbory, a violinist with a most appealing presence.

title: 'EVERGREEN' REFRESHES AN OLD THEME
description: No basic plot is more enduring in the pop marketplace than the one tracing a steady and juicily melodramatic progression from rags to riches. It has worked deliciously in old movies like ''Mrs. Parkington'' and ''The Valley of Decision.'' It has been milked shamelessly in countless radio and TV soap operas doing variations on women from obscure mining towns possibly finding happiness with worldly aristocrats. It continues to be a staple of TV mini-series. More recent examples include ''A Woman of Substance'' and ''Ellis Island.'' And tonight at 9 on NBC, it is trotted out once again in the three-part ''Evergreen.'' The second and third episodes will be broadcast tomorrow and Tuesday, also at 9 P.M.

title: GROUPS PROTEST NUCLEAR SHIPMENTS
description: SEEKING to halt the shipments of radioactive nuclear wastes that have been moving through Westchester in recent weeks, local citizens groups have stepped up pressure on county, state and Federal Government leaders, calling on them to justify the shipments and to explain safety procedures.

title: DANCERS DISPLAYING A DRESSMAKER'S ART
description: THOUGH hundreds of thousands of people have watched dancers perform in costumes crafted by Kitty Daly, her name remains unfamiliar. She likes it that way, preferring to work behind the scenes from her home in Washington.

title: BEEF WITH AN AIR OF SWITZERLAND
description: The setting was Charmey, a tiny town in the Alpine foothills of the Fribourg region of Switzerland, and we were sitting in the carnotzet, or traditional cellar, of the Hotel Cailler, a modern inn of creosoted pine built to resemble a mountain chalet. It was evening, the end of a long day's motoring along winding, dipping, occasionally precipitous mountain roads. With the cool and light wine for which the Swiss are famed, it was suggested that we might like to try a plateful of the local dried beef called B"undnerfleisch.

title:
GARDENING;

ANNUAL SHOWS BRING A BIT OF SPRING
description: IT seems that the spring flower

title: DESDEMONA'S DEATH THROES, CONTINUED
description: At the risk of beating a dead soprano, I must return to a matter I thought I had dispatched quietly in a recent piece: the stifling of Desdemona in the Metropolitan Opera's ''Otello.'' I should have known better. For some reason, this is the sort of discussion that sends normally quiescent readers flying to their writing desks, eager to agree or disagree, often at dissertational length. Who would have thought there were so many people out there with fervent, reasoned opinions on the subject of Otello's modus operandi? In the Met production, you recall, the death weapon was a pillow wielded by the crazed Moor, but I suggested that the libretto's simple stage direction, ''he stifles her,'' could be stretched to include more theatrically plausible possibilities, including strangling.

title: The Director: Running the C.I.A.
description: Joseph Lelyveld's article on William Casey's stewardship of American intelligence correctly describes my efforts to improve the collection and validation of intelligence information (''The Director: Running the C.I.A.'' (Jan. 20). The article does not mention that every one of my objectives came to be shared by the majority of both Congressional intelligence committees and that their initiation became part of the Congress's authorization of the intelligence budget for the 1985 fiscal year.

title: NICARAGUA HAS A POSTWAR BABY BOOM
description: From the Sandinista leadership to peasant families, this country is experiencing a baby boom.

title: O'NEILL TO SIGN LEGISLATION LIFTING TAX ON CLOTHES COSTING UNDER $50
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill said this week that he would sign legislation to remove the 7.5 percent state sales tax from articles of clothing costing less than $50.

title: License or Cohabitation Agreement, Couples Need a Contract
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 WOMEN SEEN AT SITE OF BLAST
description: The law-enforcement authorities investigating a bombing near the offices of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association said yesterday that two women were seen more than a week ago removing and replacing a ceiling tile in the bathroom outside the office.

title: OLYMPICS STILL HAUNT FOSTER
description: ''Listen,'' Greg Foster said without prompting. ''This is no rivalry. How could it be a rivalry? I beat him 21 times. He beat me once. And once I didn't finish. Does that sound like a rivalry to you?''

title: CHILEAN OPPOSITION FRUSTRATED AND UNCERTAIN
description: An opposition politician here recalls 1980 as one of the worst years in Chile, a time when he was so depressed for several weeks that he could not leave his home.

title: RIVER LIFE, A CLOSE-UP VIEW
description: SAMUEL G. FREEDMAN reports on theater for The New York Times.

title: Heart Patients Show Progress
description: William J. Schroeder may be spending his last weekend in Humana Hospital Audubon where he and the world's only other artificial heart recipient are recuperating.

title: Data Bank;   February 24, 1985
STAGE: CITY JAZZ TROUPE
description: It wasn't just jazz. The program that the New York City Jazz Company offered Thursday night in the Theater of the Riverside Church also included Spanish, disco and musical comedy dance. And in addition to dancing, the members of this new group sang songs and spoke dialogue in a one-act play. They did everything with reasonable proficiency, yet to little avail.

title: AN INSIGHT INTO KANDINSKY'S LAST DECADE
description: Some of the most memorable sounds ever heard in a museum were made by Rudolf Serkin in 1972 when he played Beethoven's Opus 109 in the Guggenheim Museum to mark the 80th birthday of Justin Thannhauser. Everything about that 25-minute concert was right. Mr. Thannhauser and Mr. Serkin were very old friends. As a benefactor of the Guggenheim, Justin Thannhauser (1892-1976) comes second only to its founder, Solomon R. Guggenheim. Vasily Kandinsky is the presiding genius of the museum's collections, and it was at the Thannhauser Gallery in Munich that there was held in 1909 the inaugural exhibition of the New Artists' Society of Munich, of which Kandinsky was co-founder and president.

title: Drought and Damage Dry Up Parts of the Delaware Canal
description: The familiar sight of canoeists paddling down the Delaware Canal may not be so familiar for this summer because the canal is drying up in the drought the area is suffering, according to officials.

title: NEW TYPE OF POWER SUPPLY TESTED IN JERSEY
description: A small generating unit that turns natural gas into electricity and produces thermal energy for space or water heating is being testing at the Alcan Aluminum Corporation's plant here.

title: A FRESH INTEREST IN PERSONALITY TESTS
description: Last summer, H. Paker Sharpe, Inc. administered the Berkman Method-a widely used personaity questionaire to Larry Lagerhausen to see if it should hire him as an insurance salesman. At his former job Mr. Lagerhausen had sold only $260,000 worth of insurance in six months. But the Berkman test indicated ht he would thrive if closley supervised and recognized for his achievements.

title: HUNGER THREATENS ANOTHER AREA IN ETHIOPIA
description: This is a remote place, isolated within the barren, wind- swept expanses of southeastern Ethiopia. Yet even here, the symbols of this country's allegiances, conflicts and afflictions can be seen.

title: Claire B. Breene, Reporter, to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. James K. Breene Jr. of Bryn Mawr, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter Claire Bailey Breene to Lawrence Remi Gendron, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis R. Gendron of Claremont, N.H. A September wedding is planned.

title: CONCERT: JEROME KERN'S 'OH, LADY!'
description: ''Oh, Lady! Lady!'' --second in the series of concert presentations of three Jerome Kern 'Princess' musials being offered at Carnegie Recital Hall to celebrate the 100th anniversary of Kern's birth-reinforces an impresion that emerged from the first, ''Oh, Boy!''

title: OPERA: 'MEISTERSINGER:' SOPRANO MAKES DEBUT
description: The Metropolitan Opera's first ''Meistersinger'' of the season took a while to warm up, but an uncut production that lasts nearly five and a half hours provides plenty of kindling time. After a fairly routine and occasionally downright dreary couple of acts, Friday evening's performance finally gave off enough sparks to make the waiting worth while. There were several bright spots, but none brighter than the singing of Mari Anne H"aggander, a Swedish soprano making her Metropolitan debut.

title: JOURNEY TO ABDYOS AND DENDERA
description: DENA KLEIMAN is a reporter on the metropolitan staff of The New York Times.

title:
DINING OUT;

A FRENCH CONNECTION IN WARREN
description: LE CHRISTOPHE, in the Somerset County community of Warren, is the latest in the wave of interesting new restaurants to open in New Jersey. Owned by French- born Michel and Yolande Cocordans, and named for their 2-year-old son, Christophe, the 7-month- old French restaurant has already attracted a following among those who appreciate good food and can afford to indulge their taste.

title: SENATE OPENS WAY ON AID TO FARMERS
description: A battle- weary Senate finally resolved one acrimonious dispute today over farm credit measures, but the lawmakers set the stage for another skirmish over the same issue next week.

title: WRITING AT THE BOUNDARIES
description: SOME years ago the poet David Antin stopped writing poems and began talking. He would go into a public space, turn on his tape recorder and to all appearances talk off the top of his head. Mr. Antin has an interesting and capacious mind, and his talking was pretty lively. These ''talk pieces,'' as he calls them, belong somewhere among a standup comedian's rap, a storyteller's fable and a formal lecture. Mr. Antin's manner is relaxed and the progress of his talk seemingly random. I say ''seemingly'' because his casual manner belies a more serious intent. That intent has something to do with the nature of audience expectations - the way we expect a poet to read his poems, a lecturer to follow a reasoned argument, a performance artist to ''do'' something. Mr. Antin defeats all these expectations and provides something else, and as anyone who has witnessed one of his talks can testify, the experience can be stimulating in all sorts of ways that poetry readings, lectures and performances seldom are.

title: World Best in High JumpBERLIN, Feb. 23 (AP) - The Olympic silver medalist, Patrik Sjoberg of Sweden, set a world indoor best of 7 feet 9 3/4 inches for the men's high jump Friday night during an international meet in West Berlin. The Olympic champion, Dietmar Mogenburg of West Germany, finished second at 7-7 1/4 and a teammate, Carlo Thranhardt, who had held the indoor mark, was third at 7-6 1/2. Thranhardt had set the mark of 7-9 1/4 on Feb. 24, 1984 during this meet.
description: The 20-year-old Sjoberg, who competed despite the flu, cleared 7-9 3/4 on his third and final attempt. Before that, he cleared 7-4 1/4 and 7-6 1/2 on first attempts and 7-8 on his second try.

title: BOARD APPROVES 3 PERCENT TAX ON HOTEL ROOMS
description: THE Westchester Board of Legislators voted last week to impose a 3 percent tax on hotel occupancy to raise funds for mass transportation in the county. But the measure still needs approval in Albany, where a similar proposal, designed to aid county tourism and the arts, died last year.

title: FEW CROPS MATCH THE FIERY TASTE OF CHILE PEPPERS
description: Since the tiny jalapeno peppers looked appetizing, I decided to add a generous dollop to my hamburger.''I wouldn't do that if I were you,'' the New Mexico Tech student warned, as he rushed toward me with a glass of water. The imps of Satan already had started a fiery fandango in my mouth.

title: Kosher Conflict
description: For 15 years, Miami Beach was the only city in the nation with a kosher inspector on its payroll. After he was dismissed in late 1983 in a job dispute, a public debate arose over whether the post was needed.

description: TTHE DANCE IN MIND: Profiles and Reviews 1976-83.By Deborah Jowitt. (Godine, $19.95.)

description: Fiction*1

title: Deborah Lunder To Wed Physician
description: A June wedding is planned by Deborah Ruth Lunder, an associate at the Boston law firm of Goulston & Storrs, and Dr. R. Alan B. Ezekowitz, a research fellow at the Harvard Medical School and at the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute in Boston. Mr. and Mrs. Bruce A. Lunder of Boston have announced their daughter's engagement to a son of Dr. and Mrs. Kalman Ezekowitz of Durban, South Africa.

description: * Rates on most adjustable mortgages are set 1 to 3 percentage points above these indexes.

description: PAUL WEST's most recent book is ''Out of My Depths: A Swimmer in the Universe'' (Anchor Doubleday).

description: Nigel Short, the British champion, defeated the United States champion, Lev Alburt, by a lopsided 7-1 score in the first United States-United Kingdom Match of Champions, in Foxboro, Mass.

title: LET'S LOOK AT HOW TO TEACH TEACHERS
description: -training programs in New Jersey have been under attack for more than a year. The attack was initiated by the state's Commissioner of Education, Dr. Saul Cooperman, who has jurisdiction over these programs.

title: Lilco PlanRuled Illegal
description: Engineers at the Shoreham nuclear power plant successfully completed initial low-level tests last week. Just days later, however, two high-level decisions made it clear that the future of the $4.2 billion reactor was still very much in doubt.

title: BIRDWATCHERS MAY HARASS EAGLES
description: EACH winter this decade, more and more bald eagles have migrated to Connecticut to find food in unfrozen waterways. Each year, too, more residents realize this and try to catch a glimpse of the national bird.

title: Holly Randolph, a Paralegal, to Wed Edward Sperry, a Student, in August
description: Dr. and Mrs. William Charles Randolph of Manitowoc, Wis., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Holly Jean Randolph, to Edward Leavenworth Sperry, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leavenworth Porter Sperry Jr. of Middlebury, Conn. An Aug. 17 wedding is planned.

description: ROBERT PACKARD is a professor of the humanities at Stevens Institute of Technology.

description: DESPITE the best will in the world, it appears that Governor Kean's Master Teacher Plan is going to have something less than its originally expected impact.

title: L.I. ICED TEA: A NEW KICK
description: A POTENT alcoholic drink called Long Island Iced Tea is sweeping the Island's bars as well as watering spots across the country, but some bartenders and restaurant managers are expressing concern that the drink is so powerful they have to keep an eye on clients and at times cut them off.

description: Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige has charged that several Government agencies were ''tolerating a massive giveaway program'' that enabled the Soviet Union to acquire military and technical secrets.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: In 1962, Eddie Thompson, a British jazz pianist, came to the United States and stayed here for a decade, playing for three years at the now legendary Hickory House on 52d Street, as well as at Birdland, the Embers, the Village Vanguard and the Top of the Gate. In those days Mr. Thompson's playing was colored by his fascination with the be-bop style of Bud Powell and the virtuosic challenge of Art Tatum as well as the block-chord approach used by a fellow Britain, George Shearing.

title: 10 Food Outlets Cited by City
description: The City Health Department last week released a list of 10 food establishments cited for violations of the health code.

title: DOWNSTAIRS: A SOUTHERN ACCENT
description: THE less formal of the two restaurants at Sarsfield's in Rockville Centre is called the Grill and Oyster Bar, although a variety of oysters is not available and only a couple of dishes are even prepared with them. Relatively little of the food is actually grilled. (The more elaborate restaurant at Sarsfield's, the Escoffier Room upstairs, was reviewed last week.)

title: The GeneralEnds His WarAgainst CBS
description: In a surprise decision that was widely interpreted as a surrender, Gen. William C. Westmoreland last week dropped his $120 million libel suit against CBS. The court battle ended after 18 weeks of testimony with a joint statement in which the network expressed respect for the general's ''long and faithful service to his country'' and the general expressed his esteem for CBS's ''distinguished journalistic tradition.''

Synagogue was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Amy Elizabeth Faust, the daughter of Jack Faust of Long Beach, Calif., and Myrna Faust of Jamaica Estates, Queens, to Peter A. Miller, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph A. Miller of Englewood Cliffs, N.J. Rabbi Arthur Hertzberg, assisted by Cantor Kurt Silberman, performed the ceremony.

description: THE new president of Southern Connecticut State University, Michael Adanti, says he is more than just a former Ansonia mayor and car dealer trying to run a university.

description: Miss Ostern and her fiance, second- year students at the Boston University School of Law, both graduated from the State University of New York at Binghamton.

description: He got to play only two minutes and he scored only 2 points in Houston's 117-103 victory over the Portland Trail Blazers Friday night, but when the game was over,

title: Soviet Icebreaker Is Trying To Rescue Trapped Whales
description: A Soviet icebreaker reached more than 1,000 white whales trapped in coastal ice off northeast Siberia, but the crew was doubtful the whales could follow the ship to safety, the Communist Party newspaper Pravda reported today.

title: Mungo's Passing Stirs Memories
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: 'BABY' IS A NATURAL FOR THE SMALL STAGE
description: ''BABY,'' which is about having or not having one, has made the smoothest of transitions from the Broadway stage, where perhaps it never really belonged, to more intimate environs, where it seems right at home.

title: DUKE DEFEATS GEORGIA TECH
description: Faced with elimination from the crowded Atlantic Coast Conference regular-season race, Duke broke open a close game in the second-half to defeat Georgia Tech, 67- 62, today.

title: The Importance Of Caravaggio
description: I am writing in praise of Frank Stella's article, ''On Caravaggio'' (Feb. 3). Nothing can be better than an artist writing on art - so we remember Leonardo, Dante, Whistler, Vasari. VALERIA BORGHI

title: Heart Disease Tied to Poverty
description: Heart disease is far more likely to kill poor people than the affluent, but it is unknown whether inadequate health care or an unhealthy lifestyle is chiefly to blame, a researcher for the American Heart Association says.

title: A FAST BREAK AND NEW STAR SPARK ENTHUSIASM FOR NAVY
description: A NAVAL officer dropped by the athletic department at Ricketts Hall last week to inquire about tickets to the Army-Navy game yesterday. His request came at a time when officials were trying to figure out how to fit an expected crowd of 6,400 midshipmen, cadets and others into the 4,700-seat Halsey Field House.

title: GRANDPARENTS AND DIVORCE
description: IN the last seven years, Edith and

title: Miss Lewis Is Affianced
description: Judge and Mrs. William Burke Lewis of Riverside, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Catherine Linehan Lewis, to Kent Yantis Whitaker, a son of Dr. and Mrs. William R. Whitaker of Kettering, Ohio. A summer wedding is planned.

title: GOVERNORS MIGHT BACK CUTS IF MILITARY BEARS SOME
description: The nation's governors have reached a consensus to support Federal budget cuts and elimination of some programs by the Reagan Administration if military spending is further restrained, leaders of the National Governors' Association said today.

title: NETS BEAT PISTONS
description: In the final minutes, the ball always seems to wind up in Otis Birdsong's hands, even when he would prefer not to have it.

title: NOT TO BE A PRIEST
description: Anthony DePalma

title: CLERICS OFFERING SUPPORT ON AIDS
description: A group of Protestant, Roman Catholic and Jewish leaders, in a joint statement of concern, have called on the public ''not to stand in judgment'' of AIDS victims, ''but to grow in compassion'' for them.

title: Spinks Knocks Out Spears in 3d Round
description: ''Rocky'' doesn't play, not in real life. Today's version of the movie fantasy, starring Rocky Balboa's brother-in- law, ''Paulie,'' was a short subject that ended with the harsh reality of the Spinks Jinx.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: LARCHMONT
description: LARCHMONT enjoyed something of a

title: TAKING DEATH CASE TO HIGH COURT
description: AT 10 A.M. tomorrow Thomas Boyle of Stony Brook is scheduled to stand before the justices of the Supreme Court of the United States in Washington and argue the case of Bobby Caldwell v. the State of Mississippi.

title: GUARNERI STANDS FOR DURABILITY
description: Which is the greater feat - that the instruments of Giuseppe Guarneri have endured for 250 years or that the string quartet which bears his name has lasted 20?

title: 50 YEARS LATER - OH, HOW THEY DANCED
description: THE INVITATION bore the unmistakable script of a professional calligrapher. Every loop was perfect, every flourish on the finest-grade ivory paper a work of art.

title: Bid to See Testimony On Schumer Is Denied
description: A Federal judge has denied a request by the Brooklyn District Attorney's office to be given access to testimony before a Federal grand jury during an inquiry into allegations of election misconduct in a campaign of Representative Charles E. Schumer of Brooklyn.

title: YESTERDAY'S STARS LOSE THEIR LUSTER
description: SINCE the stock market began to rally in August 1982 some of the best-performing stock groups have been those that performed the worst in the inflation-wracked 1970's. And some of that decade's biggest winners are now under- achievers on the stock market.

title: Josephine Killeffer Engaged
description: Announcement has been made by Robert A. Killeffer of New Canaan, Conn., and Josephine MacMillan Killeffer of Chapel Hill, N.C., of the engagement of their daughter, Josephine Ahara Killeffer, to David Crowell Cruthers, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald M. Cruthers of Norwich, Conn.

title:
GARDENING;

ANNUAL SHOWS BRING A BIT OF SPRING
description: IT seems that the spring flower

title: MAN-MADE SNOW A BOON FOR RESORTS
description: LIKE farmers tilling their soil, workmen in two tractor- driven snow tillers lumbered across the ski slopes at Mohawk Mountain in Cornwall, scraping and churning up hard-packed, frozen snow.

title: AN ERA ALIVE WITH EXCITEMENT: CITY COLLEGE-N.Y.U. AT THE GARDEN
description: I SPENT a nostalgic afternoon recently at

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: You may not think of the New York Public Library as being an art museum, but it's in the business of collecting and exhibiting art all the same. It first made a place for fine- art prints in 1899, and beginning a few years ago, when Julia Van Haaften started to discover treasured photographs nestled in its many nooks and crannies, the library has been cataloging and showing camera-generated prints as well.

title: BRITISH REALTY BECKONS U.S. BUYERS
description: WHEN Douglas Coppola, a New York investment banker, and his wife, Denise, learned early this year that they were being posted to London, they immediately contacted Denise LeVan, European referral director at the local offices of Sotheby's International for advice on London properties.

title: Boom in HouseForeclosures
description: The only sure thing in the housing market is that sure things can lead to disaster. A few years back, many families stretched their budgets to buy houses at high interest rates, figuring that if times got tough, they could always sell and make a profit.

title: Miss Connelly, Banker, Weds Paul N. Leitner
description: Martha Mary Connelly, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John P. Connelly Jr. of Birmingham, Mich., formerly of Upper Saddle River, N.J., was married yesterday to Paul Nicholas Leitner, a son of Mrs. Richard A. Glander of Madison, N.J., and the late Frank N. Leitner. The Rev. George F. Bardes performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York.

title: MEMORIES OF VIETNAM WAR ARE SHOWN IN HARTFORD EXHIBIT
description: NOT all the memories that Jacques von Schneden brought home after three years in Vietnam were bad. He recalled, for instance, the time he and four Vietnamese friends took a jeep and roamed the countryside as tourists, instead of soldiers.

title: CHOOSING RIGHT SANDPAPER FOR JOB
description: ALTHOUGH everyone refers to it as ''sandpaper,'' none of today's abrasive papers actually are made with sand. The oldest and least expensive kind is flint paper, which is coated with quartz crystals, a natural mineral that looks like sand, so it is likely that this is where the name came from.

title: Easter Sales Blues
description: An early Easter always spells trouble for the apparel industry, because it shortens the spring selling season. But the fact that Easter Sunday this year, April 7, comes two weeks earlier than in 1984 is only one reason apparel makers, importers and retailers are in deep trouble.

title: Rachel Lee Is Married To Ara K. Hovnanian
description: Rachel Robertson Lee, a daughter of Mrs. Edwy Lee of Houston and the late Mr. Lee, was married at the Adolphus Hotel in Dallas yesterday to Ara K. Hovnanian, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kevork S. Hovnanian of Rumson, N.J., and Palm Beach, Fla. The Rev. Dr. William Carl of the First Presbyterian Church in Dallas performed the ceremony.

title: MUSIC: LUKAS FOSS IN SECOND 'MEET THE MODERNS'
description: As a conductor, Lukas Foss possesses enormous energy, indefatiguable good will toward all schools of contemporary music, questionable taste and a seeming indifference to the finer points of orchestral playing. That makes for lively looking (on paper, in advance), odd-sounding concerts.

title:
IN SHORT;

 Why They Look Beautiful
description: Joseph B. Walker began his career as a cameraman in 1919. But he is also an inventor. In THE LIGHT ON HER FACE (ASC Press, P.O. Box 2230, Hollywood, Calif. 90078, $19.95), by Mr. Walker and his wife, Juanita, we learn that as a teen-ager he assembled radios and later created the television zoom lens.

title: NO-FRILLS HOTEL
description: A little more than a year ago, Holiday Inns announced the creation of a no-frills chain of franchised hotels to be known as Hampton Inns. With four hotels in the new chain already in operation and 75 more on the drawing board, the company recently approved the first in the line to be built in Connecticut.

title: THE UNION MOVEMENT LOOKS IN THE MIRROR
description: The executive council of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. assembles here for a few days every winter on the Florida coast, far removed, it would seem, from the woes of the workaday world.

title: AN ODD PLAY THAT WORKS
description: WHAT is happening at Long Wharf Theater's Stage II is a process in reverse. Customarily, when a new play is put on at a regional theater, its creators are on the lookout for commercial producers who are, in turn, on the lookout for new scripts.

title: A CATALOGUE OF THE WEEKEND'S CONCERTS
description: I am all for a wide diversity of

title: Miss Schuster Marries Lief Rosenblatt
description: Marla Ann Schuster, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Benjamin Schuster of Dayton, Ohio, and Palm Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Lief Dov Rosenblatt, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Franklin D. Rosenblatt of New York and South Egremont, Mass. Rabbi Avi Schulman performed the ceremony at the Schuster home in Dayton.

title: JAZZ SINGER REFINES THE SCAT SINGING TRADITION
description: The foundations for the art of scat singing appear to have been firmly established 60 years ago when Louis Armstrong expanded on his instrumental improvisations by singing parallel lines of nonsense syllables, exemplified in the title of his 1926 recording with his Hot Five, ''Skid- Dat-De-Dat.'' Since then, many variations of Mr. Armstrong's approach to vocal improvisation have been used. Ella Fitzgerald imitates the sounds of various instruments in her scat singing, and Slam Stewart turned scat singing into a self-contained duet by humming in unison with the notes that he bowed on his string bass.

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: The Ultimate 'Swan Lake'

title: SAILING ALONG THE NILE
description: JUDITH MILLER is the Cairo bureau chief of The New York Times.

description: IN

description: JERSEY CITY

title: ACTOR FAMOUS FOR HIS VOICE
description: Alexander Scourby, the actor and narrator whose resonant voice brought the world's great literature to the blind of America, died suddenly Friday night in Boston. He was 71 years old and lived in Newtown, Conn., and Manhattan.

title: Only Forever
description: The owners of the Royals like to keep their stars in Kansas City, and with

title: A Different View of Orwell
description: To the Editor:

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: OH, to be a novelist with a feeling for Long Island. What a book there would be in our long string bean of an island filled with countless peas, each with its own majestic and beautiful name that evokes an image in itself.

title: Mollie McNickle, Student, Is Wed
description: Mollie McNickle, the daughter of Lieut. Gen. Marvin L. McNickle, U.S.A.F., retired, and Mrs. McNickle of Arlington, Va., was married yesterday to Warwick Scott Wheeler, a son of Alexander B. Wheeler of Bryn Mawr, Pa., and the late Susan Scott Wheeler. The Rev. John I. Jessup 3d, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Bolling Air Force Base Chapel in Washington.

title: Dense Fog Strands Travelers At Chicago's O'Hare Airport
description: About 10,000 travelers were stranded at O'Hare Airport today because dense fog blanketed much of northern Illinois for a second day.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: 'I Have Loved a Ghost'

title: Agencies SayO.K. to Westway
description: Westway, the much-delayed highway and development project planned to run along the lower westside of Manhattan, leapfrogged over three exhausted Federal agencies last week in the battle for a construction permit. The Environmental Protection Agency, the Fish and Wildlife Service and the National Marine Fisheries Service dropped their formal objections after recommending that an independent study be undertaken of the effect of the construction project on striped bass in the Hudson River.

title: Samuel Reckford to Wed Miss Spencer
description: Lieut. Col. William A. Spencer, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Spencer of Salt Lake City have made known the engagement of their daughter Susan Spencer to Samuel Philip Reckford, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth J. Reckford of Chapel Hill, N.C. The wedding is planned for June 10.

title: A TOUGH ASCENT FOR JAPANESE WOMEN
description: WHEN Mitsuko Anzai was 25 years old and still answering telephones and booking tickets for her travel agency employer, she took a step that astounded her colleagues: She asked for a promotion.

title: INDIAN TONGUES COMING BACK TO LIFE
description: It was only a small start when Russell Old Man walked through his grandmother's door and said, ''Too- yo thoo.''

title: REDISCOVERING A POTTER
description: George E. Ohr, an eccentric master ceramist who worked in Mississippi at the turn of the century, was described by contemporaries as the mad Biloxi potter. Then, as now, even his sharpest critics regarded his twisted, folded, ruffled and pressed, paper-thin clay pots as among the most original.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: THE Metropolitan Transportation Authority is

title: CONNECTION ON 5TH
description: When a company outgrows its offices and there is no vacant space in the building into which it can expand, the conventional solution is to pack up and move on. But an unusual leasing arrangment will allow Tri- Star Pictures, a Manhattan-based film company that now occupies the 12th floor of 711 Fifth Avenue, to push through into space on the 12th floor of the building next door, 717 Fifth Avenue.

title: GENERALS FACE STIFF CHALLENGE
description: The Generals, who improved through acquisitions from the merged and disbanded teams of the United States Football League, may have come a step closer to the Baltimore Stars, the Eastern Conference's top team last season but one that stood still.

title: HOW FAR CAN THE CONCEPT OF SELF-DEFENSE BE STRETCHED?
description: Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward's comments last week on the indictment of Bernhard H. Goetz were a further reminder that the line between excessive force and self defense can depend greatly on one's point of view. The case of Mr. Goetz, who shot four black youths on the subway, and that of Officer Stephen Sullivan, who killed Eleanor Bumpurs during an attempt to subdue her and remove her from her Bronx apartment, have become public issues in the broadest sense: witness the Commissioner's contention that Mr. Goetz should have been indicted for assault and the mass protest by police officers when Officer Sullivan was indicted for manslaughter.

title: Constance A. Crabtree to Marry Terence Markey
description: Constance Anne Crabtree, the vice president of Sentinel Leasing Inc. in New Rochelle, N.Y., and Terence Farley Markey, a vice president of investments with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in New York, plan to be married March 30.

title: THE WORLD THAT LUTHER MADE
LOW-POWER TESTING: SHOREHAM GETS READY
description: BARRING a successful appeal to the Federal courts by Suffolk County and New York State, the Shoreham Nuclear Power Station will be in low-power testing soon. As this weekend began, the plant was under repair - a situation common to the industry - but was expected to be ready to start operations as early as tomorrow.

title: MUSIC: DEBUTS IN REVIEW
description: Carol Smith, a British soprano who won one of last year's Concert Artists Guild awards, sang an unusually vivid program at Carnegie Recital Hall on Tuesday night. Miss Smith has strength, intelligence, intensity and a well-focused voice, and if her equipment remains as it is today, she should certainly create a strong career for herself.

title: THE FED DRAWS FIRE FROM MANY FRONTS
description: It is often said, and just as often denied, that the Federal Reserve, like the Supreme Court, reads election returns. As a Congressional Budget Office report noted two weeks ago: ''Several empirical studies have concluded that the Federal Reserve has been generally responsive to the President's economic program in the post-World War II period.''

description: To the Arctic

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE TRUMAN SCANDALS AND THE POLITICS OF MORALITY. By Andrew J. Dunar. (University of Missouri, $24.)

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: HOORAY FOR SNAIL!

title: MUSIC CHANNEL SEEKS MATURE VIEWERS
description: Does New York City need a second non-stop music- video service? The answer is an unequivocal yes for John Gault, president of Manhattan Cable Television, where Video Hits One, the 24-hour-a-day music-video service catering to viewers aged 25 and older, will begin broadcasting in Manhattan on Friday, two months after its debut elsewhere in the country. Manhattan Cable is the franchise that serves the borough south of 72d Street on the East Side, and 79th Street on the West.

title: Bank of Boston'sFurther Troubles
description: Two weeks after the Bank of Boston's head-on collision with Federal currency-reporting regulations, William L. Brown, chairman and chief executive officer, last week conceded that his bank might have been used by an organized crime family to launder as much as $2 million in cash. He blamed underlings who had displayed ''very poor judgment.''

title: Bandits Rout Renegades TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 23 (UPI)
description: Gary Anderson rushed for

title: South AfricaGets ToughWith Dissidents
description: The reformers deferred to the policemen in South Africa last week. With recent moves by the white-minority Government, cracks had appeared in the seemingly frozen policy of apartheid.

title: Extraterrestrial Dump
description: To the Editor:

title: THE DIRECTOR: RUNNING THE C.I.A.
description: Although the President can choose the director of the Central Intelligence Agency, the other top C.I.A. officials are career men who've been a part of this ''fraternitylike'' organization through many administrations. Mr. Lelyveld's article would have us believe that every four years these professional intelligence agents redirect their priorities and goals to suit the new Administration. But these men are the very sources who keep the President, and their own director, informed as to why and where defenses are needed and deployed. Are we to believe that their own bias doesn't prevail in how, and even when, the reports are delivered? Is it not then these

title: THE WESTMORELAND CASE: A BROKEN WEST POINT TIE
description: Gen. William C. Westmoreland's decision to settle his libel suit against CBS last week was prompted, according to his friends, by his demoralization over damaging testimony by his former aides and his feeling that, however right he was, he was in a ''no-win situation.''

title: A GOOD TIME WAS HAD BY HIM
description: BARON PHILIPPE

title: MICHIGAN NEARS BIG TEN TITLE
description: Antoine Joubert, coming off the bench, scored 14 of his 18 points in the second half to lead Michigan to its 12th straight victory, a 75-73 Big Ten triumph over Michigan State tonight.

title: EFFECT OF ACID RAIN ON TREES IS SOUGHT
description: EXCEPT for limited and inconclusive studies by Rutgers University on pine trees in the Pine Barrens, little money has been spent in New Jersey on assessing the effects of acid rain on trees, including sugar maples.

title: CORRECTION
description: Two photographers were incorrectly identified in last Sunday's Business Section. Gerald Davis took the photo of Frank Borman accompanying the Eastern Air Lines article. Thomas Moon took the photo of Paul A. Samuelson and William D. Nordhaus, which appearde with the article about the new edition of 'Economics.'

title: SPREADING THE EQUITY AROUND
description: RETRIEVING DEMOCRACY

title: Big, Big Plans
description: With a Dec. 21 date, the Independence Bowl in Shreveport, La., can't expect to compete with the New Year's Day bowls for the top football teams in the country, but that doesn't bother the bowl's organizers. At the Independence Bowl, football takes a back seat to patriotism, and the game sometimes seems an afterthought to the elaborate halftime ceremonies built around the presentation of the Omar N. Bradley Spirit of Independence Award, named for the general who became the first recipient in 1977.

title: Argentina ShiftsEconomic Team
description: Argentina's inflation rate in January alone was 25 percent. With that kind of performance, the international banking community, which Argentina owes $45 billion, was pleased though not completely surprised by the resignations last week of the Government's two top economic officials.

title: COUTURE CARRIES ON
description: IT SEEMED LIKE THE OLD DAYS, when anyone who was anyone in fashion simply

title: HOW THE SENATE VOTED ON MEESE
description: Following is the roll-call vote by which the Senate confirmed President Reagan's nomination of Edwin Meese 3d as Attorney General today:

title: Eager Robertson An Early Arrival
description: Andre Robertson arrived in the Yankee spring camp today like the guest who invited himself to dinner.

title:
ART;

IT ALL BEGINS WITH A PHOTO
description: ''PHOTOGRAPHY, Plus or Minus,'' the current exhibition at the Hempstead Harbor Artists Association's two galleries in Glen Cove, is designed to prove the point that photographic techniques have many experimental applications beyond conventional darkroom manipulation. Work was solicited from both the association's members and nonmembers, resulting in a wide-ranging selection of pieces by 26 artists, including everything from orthodox photographs to images that defy such simple categorization.

description: Bay allowed the Jets to score in

title: A TIME FOR DISCOVERY IN GYMNASTICS WORLD
description: NEXT weekend marks a very special occasion for the sport of gymnastics. Once again, the most prestigious international gymnastics competition in the United States, the American Cup, will take place with more than 40 athletes from 15 countries participating. Several things make this event special:

title: ON CABLE TV: BEST FILMS
description: New and old, classic and modern, four films of exceptional merit dominate the cable choices during the coming week.

title:
ART;

PRINTS CONFIRM STELLA'S MASTERY
description: SOME have proclaimed Frank Stella to be the greatest living artist. Others, though admiring, have adopted a wait-and- see attitude.

title: ROYAL RUMANIAN MOVIE MAKER
description: THINGS I DID . . . AND THINGS I THINK I DID

title: EAST 12TH MERGER
description: Lower Fifth Avenue below 14th Street and the side streets leading off it have long been a mixed domain of residential and commercial uses. But the demand for housing in that part of Manhattan is especially strong and now developers are converting commercial space there into residences.

title: DID THE HEART OF ORWELL'S '1984' GET LOST IN THE MOVIE?
description: Have the makers of the film ''1984'' succeeded in transposing into cinematic form the startling originality of one of the 20th century's most famous novels? For those who have not read George Orwell's classic book, the story we see on the screen is, frankly, meager. If all we knew of Orwell was this movie, he would be considered a futuristic writer of pessimistic temperament and mediocre talent. Orwell's mordant verbal evocation of the horrors to come is simply not translated into visual terms.

title: BOARD TOLD TO IGNORE ECONOMICS IN CASINO RULING
description: A state official told the Casino Control Commission this week that ''economic consequences'' should not be considered in deciding whether to renew Resorts International's license to operate a casino in Atlantic City.

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: Star of Midnight

title: BIG COATS IN CLASSIC LINES
description: Who is that behind those dark glasses (and, more important, underneath those large coats)? Some of this winter season's fashion pacesetters, who are wearing a stylish crossbreeding of two classic overcoats, the Ulster and the Chesterfield.

title: CATHOLIC TASTE GIVES VARIETY TO A NEW LABEL
description: The American composer and educator Gunther Schuller is best known for his advocacy and practice of third-stream music, which brings together jazz and ''serious'' musical elements and which reached a rarefied level of establishment acceptance when Mr. Schuller's opera ''The Visitation,'' which made use of third-stream techniques, was performed some years ago by the Metropolitan Opera. In essence, Gunther Schuller's philosophy calls for equal treatment of all different types of music - jazz, pop, ''classical,'' ethnic - and this is highly laudable. Similarly laudable is the aim of his music publishing house, Margun Music, to bring this catholicity to its catalogue, which features an interesting mixture of jazz, blues, third stream, ''classical'' - including early music and works by past and present American composers - and teaching materials.

title: FOR NORTH BERGEN, A RIVERFRONT 'VILLAGE'
description: TEN years ago, Michael R. Zemsky, a

title: First of CubansSent Back Home
description: Only hours after the last legal obstacle to their deportation was lifted last week, 23 Cuban aliens were put on board a chartered Boeing 727 at Dobbins Air Force Base northwest of Atlanta for a two-hour flight to Havana. The 23 men, 16 of whom had asked not to be returned to Cuba, are the first of more than 2,700 refugees who the Government of Fidel Castro has agreed to repatriate, in return for Washington's resumption of a normal immigration policy.

title: Filipinos Try to Rescue A Kidnapped Bishop
description: Troops sealed off escape routes today around the rugged hills of the southern Phillipine brushland, where an armed gang vanished after kidnapping a Roman Catholic bishop and his companions on Friday.

title: Miss Sloan, an Architecture Student, To Be Wed to Arthur Lichtenberger
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward W. Sloan 3d of Farmington, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Elisabeth Hunter Sloan to Arthur Weston Lichtenberger, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur T. Lichtenberger of Westfield, Mass. A July wedding is planned.

title: ChinatownIndictments
description: For more than 10 years, Federal prosecutors say, a gang called the Ghost Shadows has terrorized the Mott Street section of Chinatown, extorting money from restaurants and other businesses, shaking down those who run illegal gambling parlors and committing robberies, kidnappings and murders. The fear of retaliation has been so great that many Chinatown residents have been reluctant to press charges against gang members.

title: Adapting to Rents
description: To the Editor:

title: CAMBODIAN REBELS ARE PUSHED INTO THAILAND, AND A CORNER
description: After a three-month sweep of their bases by Vietnamese troops, it was time last week for Cambodia's displaced guerrilla armies to reassess their strategies. Aware of their need to maintain political and military credibility and foster a more effective unity if their war is to continue, the three loosely allied rebel groups are already making changes.

title: A Flight From DangerMexican elections often go like this: the ruling party wins, the opposition cries fraud, and soon everything is back to normal. But in Piedras Negras, a town on the Texas border, nothing has been the same since
description: Dr. Eleazar Cobos of the National Action Party was declared the loser in a close vote for mayor on Dec. 2.

title: OFFICES FOR YONKERS
description: A three-story facility that until last year was a careers training center for students in the Yonkers school system will be turned into an office and commercial building.

title: U.S. SUSPENDS FUNDS FOR ATLANTIC CITY TRAIN
description: The Reagan Administration, citing inaction by New Jersey, has deferred $30 million in Federal funds for the Atlantic City-Philadelphia rail line, apparently dooming the rehabilitation project.

title: HER WORDS, HIS MUSIC
description: Theirs is a world of music, poetry and literature - not government and politics. Yet for nine years they have lived in a city that dances to a political tune without feeling like outsiders.

title: Roberta J. Tabell Wed to a Banker
description: At St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Pennington, N.J., yesterday Roberta Jane Tabell, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Tabell of Princeton, N.J., was married to Robert McCook Jordan Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jordan of Scarsdale, N.Y. The Rev. John Belmont performed the ceremony.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER/ONE CROWDED HOUR
description: WHITE PLAINS IT was 6 o'clock at Corniche, and

title: MALCOLM FRAGER, REFLECTIVE MUSICIAN
description: Malcolm Frager's appearance with the New York Philharmonic this week as the soloist in Bartok's Third Concerto is something of a homecoming. But for him it is more significant than that. Although he has performed with the Philharmonic often since 1960, the deeper connection for him is with this week's guest conductor, Erich Leinsdorf. They have been close friends ever since Mr. Leinsdorf gave Mr. Frager his start as a soloist with the Boston Symphony Orchestra at Tanglewood in 1962.

title: Kite Among 3 Leading Doral
description: Tom Kite, a co- leader after two rounds of the 24th annual Doral-Eastern Open, bogeyed the eighth and ninth holes today and then parred the last nine holes to remain a co-leader after three rounds. But the 35-year-old Texan, who won this tournament a year ago, shared the lead this time with two different players - Bill Kratzert and Frank Conner. All were at 4-under-par 212.

title: 2 Reputed Gangsters Killed By Gunmen at Track in Japan
description: Two reputed gangsters were slain at a bicycle track in southwestern Japan today, four weeks after the slaying of Japan's most powerful underworld leader raised fears of a gang war.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: So highly did the Incas of the Andean region prize their own woven textiles that in the 16th century, retreating from battle with Spanish conquistadors, they would burn entire warehouses of cloth rather than leave it to the enemy. The textiles - among the most beautifully woven and dyed fabric produced in the Western hemisphere - were not only used for clothing, but for other purposes, among them as a means of exchange to strengthen social and political ties.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: TENNIS CLASSIC

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;

SELF-HELP DIRECTORY
description: Under the auspices of the Westchester Self-Help Clearinghouse, the network of self-help support programs in the county, more than 200 such groups have been established in the five years since the clearinghouse was established as an affiliate of the Westchester Jewish Community Services.

title: CONSUMER RATES
GLORY DAYS END FOR PHARMACEUTICALS
description: LAST month, the privately held Swiss drug company, Hoffmann-LaRoche, dealt a harsh blow to its American work force: Disappointed by the flow of new products here and preparing for the imminent expiration of its lucrative patent on Valium, the company said it would lay off 1,000 employees, more than 12 percent of its American payroll.

title: MONTCLAIR ACTS TO REVITALIZE DOWNTOWN
description: MONTCLAIR

title: FACADE'S FATE: A CONTEMPORARY FABLE
description: FRED FACADE, who hailed from Idaho, had been living on Long Island for a couple of months. His lack of sophistication and differing values sharply contrasted with those of Long Islanders. He was unable to make any friends at school, let alone meet any girls.

title: MOROCCO SUMMONS WEST SAHARA TRIBES TO SHOW ITS CONTROL

title: ALL STEMED UP
description: NOUVELLE CUISINE HAS BROUGHT MUCH TO THE American kitchen: uncommon combinations of flavors; new concepts of food presentation; revised cooking techniques. Vegetables and fish, for instance, are prepared with far greater care - based in large part on techniques from the Orient - and are no longer cooked ''to death,'' as they often were in traditional French cooking. Concurrently, the introduction of the food processor has facilitated the preparation of many dishes - mousses, quenelles and the like that were once the reserve of exclusive restaurants - in the family kitchen.

title: TIME FOR DIVINIG RODS IN CALIFORNIA
description: Late this year the big pumps of the Central Arizona Project will start to spin, sending a river of water over mountain and desert to Phoenix. With the first rush of water, a new age in the long history of the Colorado River's nurturing of the dry Southwest will begin, and the states in its basin are already scrambling to meet the change.

ROWLAND WATTS of Pleasantville has spent most of his working years as a lawyer fighting for social justice and the rights of individuals. For these goals and his efforts to fulfill them, he recently received first prize in the 1984 Durfee Awards.

title: LEBANESE ARMY IS HAILED BUT NOT AS CONQUERER
description: Seldom has an army been more loved for less. When the Lebanese Army's new 12th Brigade rolled into Sidon last weekend, ending 32 months of Israeli occupation, it was not so much a military maneuver as a carnival, with cheering civilians piled high atop the tanks and grinning soldiers sporting carnations in their rifle muzzles. A sheep was ritually slaughtered in celebration.

The book has gained a wide readership throughout England and the world, and last fall, Crown Publishers brought out a 25th-anniversary edition. When Richard Adams visited Mr. Lee to interview him, he began by asking about his village today.

title:

A PLAINTIFF ILL-USED

It was almost certainly their call, since the lawsuit had little to do with Gen. William C. Westmoreland's honor. From the beginning, the trial was about politics and represented a crude attempt by ideologues to rewrite the history of the Vietnam War.

title: JOBS REPORT LEAVES HIGH-TECH BEHIND

title: WHEN BUYING BLANK TAPE, PRICE DOESN'T ALWAYS EQUAL QUALITY
description: You can always believe your own eyes. If one brand of video tape gives you a better picture than another, that evidence is incontrovertible. But unless you assume the task of checking out all tapes available, you limit your choice and may miss a bet. Besides, impressions gained from informal sampling tend to be vague. Controlled tests with precise measurements provide surer guidance to VCR viewers in quest of the best.

They have bobbed in and out of favor in past years, amid controversies over whether existing tests were racially or sexually biased, whether they were true indicators of job aptitude, and whether they violated an individual's right of privacy. Companies keep seeking tests that guarantee a harmonious marriage between the employer and the employed.

A FLAT TAX WOULD STIMULATE GROWTH

And when the dollar was weak and the French were shipping us dreadful stuff at unconscionably high prices and even Beaujolais was out of sight, what slaked our thirst? Zinfandel. Zinfandel was there when we needed it. Now the old zin is in trouble, and it's time for its friends to stand up and be counted.

As of now, there is no fourth candidate to fill out the category, unless the Tony committee cares to consider the Andre De Shields narcissistic night-club act, ''Haarlem Nocturne,'' as a Broadway venture.

title: THE HARDEST BIRTHDAY GIFT I EVER GAVE
description: I DID not really have a choice. When my daughter said that all she wanted for her 21st birthday was for me to quit smoking, the pressure was on. She gave me more than a month's notice, warning me around Christmas that Jan. 26 would be my cutoff day. The days until then stretched before me as a far distant horizon does on a long car trip. I agreed to her wish with hardly a second thought. A lot can happen in 31 days. I would be like Scarlett O'Hara and worry about it tomorrow.

title: Teaching Sex to Schoolchildren
description: Until a decade ago, a parent's reluctance to give a child the ''facts of life'' was still the stuff of comedy. Today there's no humor in that hesitation. Parents' chief concern then was with the misinformation eagerly provided by precocious classmates. Now it extends to the message sent by movies, television, advertising and the kind of lyric that one used to hear only on so-called party records. However elaborately cloaked, the message is simple: ''Do it.''

The film opens at Loew's New York Twin on Friday, five days, as it happens, before its director's 38th birthday.

title: A CROP OF CD BEETHOVEN CONCERTOS

Surprisingly - given the number of Beethoven cycles that might be transferred profitably (in both the artistic and financial senses) - challengers of Mr. Brendel's monopoly have been slow to arrive. So far only one more cycle has turned up, a revealing set featuring Rudolf Serkin, with Seiji Ozawa and the Boston Symphony (Telarc CD-88061-5, three CD's).

title: ECONOMIC COUNCIL GETS A NEW LEADER
description: Beryl W. Sprinkel's appointment to be chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, if confirmed, could infuse new life into that institution, which fell into disuse after the departure last summer of the last chairman, Martin S. Feldstein. While Mr. Sprinkel's monetarist views are in conflict with the dominant supply- side bent of the Reagan Administration, friends and associates say that Mr. Sprinkel is not likely to disagree publicly with the President. Some analysts note, however, that public debate might be healthier.

title:
ART;

GENIAL TROMPE L'OEIL SHOW
description: WHEN art intended to fool the eye succeeds, you feel like applauding. And when it fails you feel you have license to berate it. More than any other art form, trompe l'oeil depends on perfect execution. It's based on trickery but as with a sideshow, we willingly submit to being duped, for we are taken out of our expected routine.

title: ISLANDERS DEFEAT BRUINS, 7-1

Six different players scored, and for once, all the parts of the team's game fit like a complete set.

Grace & Company, steps out of his limousine and into the elegant turn-of-the-century building on Fifth Avenue. He is there to address a roomful of wealthy businessmen about his war on waste in Washington. ''I'll talk for a few minutes,'' he promised, ''then answer questions about this government stuff.''

title: Recent Sales

4 VERDICTS ON THE WESTMORELAND CASE AGAINST CBS;

CBS ISN'T BLAMELESS
description: There was a sad and somewhat hollow ring to Gen. William C. Westmoreland's claims of victory in his two-and-a-half year battle with CBS to save his honor and punish the network to the tune of $120 million. The network has indeed won. The general has capitulated. But there is something unpleasant about the way CBS is gloating in victory. In their joint statement, CBS and General Westmoreland said they ''believe that their respective positions have been effectively placed before the public.'' That is probably true. But it has been done at a cost of millions of dollars and considerable anguish on both sides. That alone makes gloating seem inappropriate. In fact, had ''The Uncounted Enemy: A Vietnam Deception,'' the documentary over which the court battle was fought, been produced in a less polemical fashion, with more concern for standards of fairness, the public would undoubtedly have been better served and the lawsuit would probably have been avoided. The reason is that CBS almost certainly misled viewers by reducing an extremely complex situation to an unrealistically simple thesis - that General Westmoreland ''cooked the books,'' conspiring to deceive the President about enemy troop strength so that he could continue pursuing an immoral and unwinnable war. Even if you buy the CBS thesis, as some knowledgeable observers do, the question still arises, why produce the show in such a one-sided way? After all, there are many equally knowledgeable observers who consider the thesis absurd in its simplicity.

title: Way ClearedAnd MeeseIs ConfirmedFor more than a year, the Senate had considered the nomination of Edwin Meese 3d to become Attorney General, challenging the former Presidential counselor on everything from his lawyers' fees to contentions that he found Government jobs for some people who had helped out him financially. But last week, his confirmation was blocked until Democrats and Republicans resolved their differences on an entirely unrelated concern yesterday.
description: The delay began when Senate Democrats from farm states opened a filibuster aimed at tying a vote on Mr. Meese to emergency farm credit legislation. Although a tentative agreement was worked out Friday that would have increased loans to farmers for spring planting and made them easier to obtain, the deal fell victim to partisan rancor. The filibuster continued yesterday, but late in the afternoon, the new Senate majority leader, Bob Dole, and the Democrats' leader, Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia, announced another deal: Friday's agreement would go forward, and the amendments that Democrats and Republicans wanted would be attached to an African relief bill tomorrow. That immediately cleared the way for Mr. Meese's confirmation, by a vote of 63 to 31.

title: Dr. Carter Romps On Gulfstream Dirt
description: After a year afd a day, Dr. Carter finally won another race on the dirt today, but his three-length victory in the $281,300 Gulfstream Park Handicap failed to erase the feeling that the big gray colt is not what he used to be.

title:
4 VERDICTS ON THE WESTMORELAND CASE AGAINST CBS;

A COURT'S NO FORUM
description: In the aftermath of my decision to withdraw my libel suit against CBS in return for its acknowledgment that I had conducted myself faithfully and in a patriotic and loyal manner, I have received positive and negative responses from those who supported me in my effort. Perhaps the most significant lesson I have learned is this: a court of law is not the proper place for deciding matters of historical significance or indeed judging the motives of those who played important roles in history. However, as my case and several others have recently demonstrated, this country and its citizens, public and private alike, need some nongovernmental, nonjudicial forum where complaints against the media can be heard, judged and redressed. This is not an indictment of our legal system. All who participated in my case, including the defendants and their counsel, conducted themselves in a proper manner. But one cannot recreate a major historical event in the courtroom. As for the CBS Reports television program ''The Uncounted Enemy: A Vietnam Deception,'' I know that it was biased, misleading - far from objective. But that sometimes occurs in journalism, which properly seeks to expose misdeeds, bad judgments, acts against the public interest. And sometimes an overzealous reporter or producer gets carried away with what he or she perceives or believes to be the facts and comes up with what one would consider irresponsible reporting.

title: ALL UP AND DOWN THE WHOLE CREATION
description: SCIENTISTS refer to themselves as authors, yet few achieve a place on the shelf labeled ''literature.'' Although they may publish hundreds of articles in journals aimed at other scientists, most never overcome the barriers of intelligibility separating scientists and the public. Stephen Jay Gould (''Hen's Teeth and Horse's Toes''), Carl Sagan (''Broca's Brain'') and Lewis Thomas (''Late Night Thoughts on Listening to Mahler's Ninth Symphony'') are well-known exceptions, although even they have been accused of addressing primarily those who already know what scientists are talking about.

title: IN SHORT
description: A. W. Clemmons, real estate developer and sometime theatrical agent, is a solitary in his private life, someone whose anger has led him to ''swipe a clear radius around himself,'' who feels a ''sense of communion in empty houses.'' We are given to understand that his problem is womankind. Estranged from his wife, Clemmons lives and works in Boston Corners, a town made famous by the brutal prizefight held there in the last century. As the novel opens, Clemmons is surprised to learn that his daughter Milly intends to get married in the very spot on the field where the boxers spilled each other's blood. The field thus becomes the central metaphor of this well-told chronicle, a way of summarizing Clemmons's struggle with the females in his life - women ''who took a part of him into themselves . . . so that gradually the original disappeared into them.'' The protagonist does not seem to recognize this white-hot misogyny for what it is; his vision is continually blurred by sentimentality (his toothsome daughter Daisy, for him, has eyes like ''Christmas mornings''), and the true shape of his rage is often reduced to a childish or hysterical notion of responsibility. When he contracts a social disease, he imagines that it has been produced by ''every woman he has ever known''; climbing a dangerous ladder, he tries not to listen to his mother and daughter - because their warnings, in the past, have supposedly caused him to fall. It seems that the institution of family will always make Clemmons uncomfortable, no matter how often he wanders back into its ambiguous warmth; the pleasures he lives easily with, by contrast, are the embers of an eternal adolescence, sly promises of fire in the ash pits of the everyday.

title: REAGAN HURLS THE HARSHEST BROADSIDE YET AT NICARAGUA
description: WASHINGTON WITH Congress preoccupied by budget deficits and the plight of the farmer, the Reagan Administration suddenly thrust Central America onto center stage last week with a series of attacks on the Sandinista Government of Nicaragua. In a campaign of escalating polemics aimed at generating pressure on Congress to resume aid to Nicaraguan rebels, President Reagan and Secretary of State George P. Shultz made four major declarations in seven days. So strongly did they challenge the legitimacy of the Nicaraguan Government that some influential members of Congress wondered if this could be a prelude to a diplomatic break with Managua. Some Administration officials said the aim was to avoid a situation that could force a break.

title: EUROPE FINDS MORE TO LIKE IN 'STAR WARS'
description: PARIS FOR a long time, America's leading allies looked at President Reagan's Strategic Defense Initiative with reluctance, skepticism, and confusion. It was unfeasible, or a new round in the arms race, or another case of the United States's throwing technology at a problem when its political ingenuity fails. But as the March 12 start of the United States-Soviet arms talks in Geneva nears, an important time for allied solidarity, a less critical attitude toward the space-based defense system seems to be emerging. Judged by the disputes of the past few years over gas pipelines or Olympic boycotts, Star Wars has the feel of potential vexation, but hardly that of trans-Atlantic divorce.

title: Kate S. Schecter And Ari H. Roth To Wed in June
description: Kate Sara Schecter and Ari H. Roth plan to be married in June, her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Jerrold L. Schecter of Washington, have announced.

title: TAPE OFFERS A GLIMPS INSIDE CHICAGO POLITICS
description: Nothing warms up a long cold winter in this fractious prairie city like a good political brawl. And aficionados of Chicago's brand of rock 'em-sock 'em politics saw the start of another melee here this week over a secretly taped meeting between Mayor Harold Washington and a candidate for the City Council.

title:
ANTIQUES;

MORRIS MUSEUM: DECORATIVE ARTS
description: MORRISTOWN ONE OF the ultimate cachets in collecting antiques is the conferral of ''museum quality'' status. Next weekend, a selection of 220 such antiques, most of them on loan from homes in the Morristown area, will go on view here in an eight-week exhibition entitled ''The Decorative Arts Tradition in the American Home: 1700-1900.''

title: G.O.P. CAN'T GET A WORD IN EDGEWISE
description: Warren M. Anderson, the majority leader of the New York State Senate and the most powerful Republican in the state government, formally laid out his party's plans for tax cuts last week. The audience consisted of a handful of reporters and several dozen civic-group members meeting in the back room of the Albany Public Library.

title: FORCE, NOT DIALOGUE
