description: BOSTON The white minority regime that

title: PARISIAN PLEASURES
description: Few women will actually own these clothes, but what was exhibited at the spring couture shows sparkled with original ideas destined to reach a far broader audience.

title: SCIENTISTS QUESTION STUDIES ON NUCLEAR ACCIDENTS
description: A scientific panel has told the Nuclear Regulatory Commission that it should not, without doing much more research, reduce current estimates of how much radiation would be released in a nuclear accident.

title:
DINING OUT;

A NEW ROCHELLE FAMILY AFFAIR
description: SAPARITO'S is now heading into its 17th year. The longevity of this restaurant in New Rochelle says a lot about the place. The operation is a family and extended- family affair, as the enthusiastic group in the photo mural at the restaurant's entrance will attest. In the pretty front dining room, set among lots of bricks, picture windows look out over the illuminated, peaceful landscape of an adjoining apartment complex. A partitioned bar, a tiny dining platform, a charming front alcove and mirrors in the right places divide into intimate areas what might have been a sprawling, aimless room.

title: M.I.S.L. Going On Without Cosmos
description: The Major Indoor Soccer League will continue this season with a revised schedule now that the Cosmos have withdrawn.

title: Fertilizer Pressures
description: Farmers will use more fertilizer this season - hoping that higher crop yields and sales volume will offset weak market prices. But that does not mean fertilizer prices are heading up.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: WHILE the debate continues in the Legislature over measures to protect freshwater wetlands for the first time, a study by the New Jersey Audubon Society says that one of the richest and most extensive wetlands habitats, Troy Meadows in Morris County is threatened by development.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: PARTICULARS OF MY LIFE, THE SHAPING OF A BEHAVIORIST and

title: THE MALPRACTICE CRUNCH AT ST. PAUL
description: THERE are something like 16,000 of them. They arrive at a rate of about 14 a day, one every hour and a half. They are about broken bones and damaged kidneys. Some are almost funny - about misplaced sponges, chipped teeth. But others are tragic - about lives made wrong that can never be made right again.

title: How to Jail More and Have Worse Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: From Big BirdTo Big Board
description: Noncommercial television, under increasing pressure to find fresh sources of income, last week entered into a commercial venture that it hopes will bring it tens of millions of dollars. The Public Broadcasting Service, the distribution arm of America's 300 public stations, announced that it was joining with I.B.M. and Merrill Lynch to broadcast stock quotations and financial news to subscribers with personal computers.

title: It's Still Star Wars
description: President Reagan has a wish about ''Star Wars,'' the new missile defense system to which he gave his energetic blessing two years ago without any public debate whatsoever. ''I wish whoever coined that phrase would take it back again because it gives a false impression of what it is we're talking about.'' And as William Safire reports in proposing a rename-it contest in today's Times Magazine, the Administration is obsessed with the search for a name that can make this radical weapons program palatable.

title: A COMPUTER TELLS WHERE TO FIND FUN
description: CHILDREN in Hartford between the ages of 10 and 18 are going up to a computer called Rec-Trek and telling it that they are bored.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a film distributor's change of plans, a picture caption and an article on page 21 of the Arts and Leisure section today and a film listing in The Guide, section 2A, carry outdated theater information for ''The Sure Thing.'' It opens this Friday at the Gotham, Loews State, Loews 34th Street Showplace and Loews 83d Street Quad.

title: GENSCHER YIELDS REINS OF EMBATTLED BONN PARTY
description: Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher stepped down today as chairman of the Free Democratic Party, making way for an untested politician who faces the task of reviving the party's fortunes.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN PALM BEACH
description: JON NORDHEIMER is chief of the Miami bureau of The Times.

title: OFFICIAL POLISH UNIONS BACK PROTEST BY SOLIDARITY
description: Labor unions controlled by the Communist Party, in an unusual move, joined the outlawed Solidarity union today in protesting Government-proposed increases in food prices.

title: Miss Jordan, Henry Clark Are Engaged
description: Jennifer Bennett Jordan, an associate with the New York law firm of Lord, Day & Lord, and Henry Crawford Clark, an architect with Butler Rogers Baskett Associates, an architectural firm in New York, plan to be married June 1.

title: CHINA CLIPPER
description: The change in international airmail postage rates effective last Sunday caused a rush of new stamps and postal stationery to accommodate the increases. Two new airmail postage items honor the same historic airplane: the famed China Clipper used by Pan American Airways to open transpacific mail routes in 1935.

title: JERSEY ADVOCATE AND A UTILITY REACH ACCORD ON ATOM PLANT
description: The state's Public Advocate and the Public Service Electric and Gas Company announced an agreement this week to allow the Hope Creek nuclear plant to seek a Federal operating license without long hearings that could drive up its cost and delay its operation.

title: COME ON AND SEE THE WINGED LADY
description: NIGHTS AT THE CIRCUS

title: LYSSA SCHWARTZ ENGAGED TO WED DANIEL GOLDBERG
description: Dr. and Mrs. Stanley N. Schwartz of East Hills, L.I., have annnoucned the engagement of their daughter

title: Transit OfficersAre Indicted inStewart Death
description: Transit police officers arrested Michael Stewart in 1983 for scrawling graffiti on a wall in a subway station. He died 13 days later. For two years the cause of his death has been debated by politicians, medical examiners, prosecutors and grand jurors. Indictments were handed up last week against six of the 11 police officers who held Mr. Stewart prisoner that night.

title: CAVALIERS BEAT BUCKS, 128-106
description: Johnny Davis scored 23 points to pace eight Cleveland players in double figures tonight, and the Cavaliers defeated the Milwaukee Bucks, 128- 106.

title: Correction
description: A review of ''The Orwell Mystique,'' by Daphne Patai (Feb. 3) incorrectly identified a book by George Orwell selected for the Left Book Club. The book was ''The Road to Wigan Pier,'' selected in 1937.

title: Q&A
description: Question:

title: Turkish Avalanche Kills 8
description: An avalanche caused by an unusually heavy snowfall crushed a house in a village in Diyarbakir Province, killing eight members of the family and injuring three, the Hurriyet news agency reported Friday.

title: HOW THE PAST MIGHT FEEL
description: THE DARK BRAIN OF PIRANESI

title: CLINT EASTWOOD, SERIOUSLY
description: John Vinocur is the Paris bureau chief of The New York Times.

title: MISCREANTS QUICK WITH METAPHORS
description: PENANCE FOR JERRY KENNEDY

title: Mary S. Weiser Is Wed To Raymond E. Deitch
description: Mary Susan Weiser, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Edward H. Weiser of Sussex, N.J., was married yesterday to Raymond Erwin Deitch, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Deitch of Southfield, Mich. Rabbi Paul Silton officiated at the Steuben Athletic Club in Albany.

title: 'One Foot In a Green Past'
description: Sharon Lyon Emmanuel writes of her desire for ''a clean and safe land'' (Opinion Page, Jan. 27). For those people who have one foot in a green past, nostalgia has a tendency to overwhelm. It makes us feel sorry for our children.

title:
CAMERA;

PROPER MOUNTING
description: Print mounting is a practical first step in the presentation of photographs. They lay flat within a frame or can be free- standing with an easel back or hung directly on a wall with double-sided mounting tape. Mounts also protect prints in storage or when handled extensively during presentation.

title: FUZZY SOUND? HUM OR HOWL? SOME HOME REMEDIES
description: Like other music makers, sound systems are occasionally indisposed; they have their off days and develop symptoms of various kinds. Most such problems are due merely to minor ailments and can be cured without professional help. Unfortunately, among the ready home remedies for ailing stereo systems, there is no general palliative - the electronic equivalent of aspirin. Specific dysfunctions require specific treatments. So let me suggest likely cures for common complaints.

title: SCHOLASTIC TRACK RECORD SET
description: Paul Steele, an 18-year-old Jamaican-born senior at Prospect Heights High School in Brooklyn, ran the first 200 meters in 24.2 seconds and passed the 400-meter mark in 51.2 on the way to a national indoor scholastic record of 1 minute 20.5 seconds for 600 meters yesterday at the Public Schools Athletic League track and field championships.

title: CUOMO CALLING FOR FLEXIBILITY IN PUBLIC UNIVERSITY BUDGETS
description: Governor Cuomo called this week for giving the State University of New York and the City University of New York greater flexibility in managing their budgets.

title: HOW TO INCREASE YOUR BOOK CONSUMPTION: A RADICAL PROPOSAL
description: Today no one reads, at least not for pleasure. This is because, while it used to take two years to cross the continent and now it takes only an afternoon, it still takes five hours to read a chapter of Melville, even on that train in France that goes so fast. When I mentioned to a friend that I had completed a volume of Churchill's memoirs, she looked at me as if I had told her that, instead of driving my car to work, I carry it: ''Why didn't you just watch 'The Winds of War'?'' she asked. ''Eight nights, 22 hours, a lot of skin.''

title: FASHIONING A SPECIAL STEED FOR MIDDLEBURY CAROUSEL
description: IN November, the family that has

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: WE CAN'T All BE HEROES, YOU KNOW. By Linda Anderson. (Ticknor & Fields, $14.95.)

title: GOING, SEEING, MUNCHING
description: On hand to see the ''Killing Fields'' when it opened at the Sunrise Multiplex Cinemas in Valley Stream were Evelyn Barnett and Evelyn Lipson of Brooklyn. They come every Sunday for the early show, not especially because of the $2.50 price (tickets otherwise generally cost $4.50), but ''because we feel safer in Valley Stream,'' Mrs. Barnett said.

title: The New Mythology ;   Of Old and Affluent
description: To the Editor:

title: THRILL OF A SNOWSTORM IS IN THE EYE OF THE BEHLDER
description: I suspect that there are two ways to

title: THE FIGHT IS ON TO SAVE LOCAL AID
description: In the usually abstract world of intergovernmental relations, general revenue sharing, which sends Federal funds to local governments, is said to be in a category with Elvis Presley's blue suede shoes. Washington, local officials say, can abuse them by cutting programs they like. But their bottom line is ''don't step on my revenue sharing.''

title: DECLINE SLOWING FOR DEATH RATE OF U.S. INFANTS
description: Federal officials say they are concerned about a slowdown in the decline of the nation's infant mortality rate.

title: 'On Lon Gisland' Provokes a Laugh
description: Often, over the years, I have read articles in newspapers and magazines that I've laughed and cried over, and have always meant to write to the editor to make my feelings known, but have never done so. However, I would really feel remiss if I behaved accordingly with reference to Barbara Klaus of Rockville Centre (''On 'Lon Gisland,' Where Dreams (They Said) Come True,'' Opinion Page, Jan. 20).

title: Retton in Top Form
description: In her first official competition since the Los Angeles Olympics,

title: SITTING ON CASH
description: Lower stock prices would be acceptable to one group of investors. For the past two months, managers who call themselves ''value'' managers have been complaining that stocks had advanced too far, too fast.

title: A TIME OF DECISION NEARS ON NUCLEAR WASTE
description: A fork- lift operator carefully unloads barrels and crates from the back of a truck, keeping his body away from the containers. He stacks them neatly on the bottom of a trench as technicians and inspectors from the state, armed with radiation detectors, look on.

title: Judge OrdersZaccaro toPay With Time
description: A 20-minute appearance in a Manhattan courtroom last week may or may not have ended what one of John A. Zaccaro's lawyers called his ''season in the light.''

title: GROWING UP MISUNDERSTOOD IN TODAY'S AMERICA
description: It's 10 P.M. Do you know where your children are? Do

title: Janet Leigh Figg To Become Bride Of E. F. Kelly Jr.
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. James Alfred Figg Jr. of Leesburg, Va., and Inverness, Ill., of the engagement of their daughter, Janet Leigh Figg, to Edward Francis Kelly Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kelly of Rye, N.Y. The wedding is planned for April 13.

title: Watergate Wiretaps
description: To the Editor:

title: Linda de Groot Affianced
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Rudy de Groot of Sparks, Nev., of the engagement of their daughter, Linda A. de Groot, to John Gregory Calotta, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles J. Calotta of Suffern, N.Y.

title: Robert Kristofik Will Be Married To Drew Moseley
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard Curtis Miles of New York and Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Miles's daughter, Kathryn Drew Moseley, to Robert Michael Kristofik, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Kristofik of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., and Casselberry, Fla. A June wedding is planned.

title: MAJOR SAVINGS BOOST POPULARITY OF 15-YEAR MORTGAGES
description: NOBODY minds saving tens of thousands of dollars, which is one reason why 15- year fixed-rate mortgages have zoomed in popularity with borrowers during the past two years. Lenders and investors are more than willing to meet the growing demand for the 15-year loans, which involve much less risk than conventional loans that can lock them into a fixed rate of return for 30 years.

title: Canadian Skater Breaks Track Record for 1,000
description: Gaton Boucher of Canada shattered the 1,000-meter track record today at the 14th world sprint speed skating championships.

title: MUSIC: ANDRE WATTS IN FISHER HALL RECITAL
description: Andre Watts has something rare among pianist - a sort of hotline between the inner passions and the keyboard that not only conveys images of sound but that can actually make the piano roar, sob, even giggle when the mood so demands. It is an impressive gift.

title: Sports of The Times;   Pete Rose at Spring Camp
description: TAMPA, Fla.

title: NEW UNIT FOR RETARDED OFFERS TRAINING
description: WHEN the Association for the Help of Retarded Children dedicates its new day training center in Brookville today, Helen Kaplan will be a step closer to her goal. As a leader of the agency for the last 36 years, she has made it the association's stated objective ''to provide for the retarded from the cradle to the grave.''

title: HUDSON GROUP BACKS STUDY OF TUMORS ON FISH IN RIVER
description: The Hudson River Foundation has awarded 10 research and education grants totaling more than $300,000, including one for a project seeking to learn why tomcod in the river have such a high rate of tumors.

title: International
description: SUNDAY, FEBRUARY 24, 1985 A joint approach to peace with Israel formulated by Jordan and the Palestine Liberation Organization has been outlined in the text of an agreement between Jordan and the P.L.O. that was made public by Jordan. It specifies five principles upon which their ''bid for joint action'' should be based. A key provision includes ''total withdrawal'' by Israel from ''the territories occupied in 1967 for comprehensive peace as established in United Nations and Security Council resolutions.'' (Page 1, Column 2.)

title:
VIEW FROM THE NEW YORK FED;

ON ARRIVING: CUT THE FEDERAL DEFICIT
description: Last month, E. Gerald Corrigan took over as president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, succeeding Anthony M. Solomon. Both have influenced monetary policy for years and they are expected to keep doing so, although Mr. Solomon has retired. Here is some of their current thinking.

title: NO MORE FAMOUS VICTORIES
description: THE OXFORD BOOK OF WAR POETRY

title: PREGNANT WOMAN AND 2 SONS DIE IN QUEENS BLAZE
description: A pregnant woman and two of her children were trapped in an attic and killed yesterday when flames roared through their single-family home in Queens. Neighbors helped rescue three other children and a man from the burning building.

title: Nola Beldegreen Engaged
description: The engagement of Nola Beth Beldegreen, a fashion and beauty merchandising editor with Glamour magazine, to Scott Alan Weisman, an associate with the New York law firm of Parker Chapin Flattau & Klimpl, has been announced by Joane Beldegreen of Cliffside Park, N.J., mother of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Weisman of Norwalk, Conn. Miss Beldegreen is a daughter also of the late Robert A. Beldegreen.

title: SUSHI AT A REASONABLE PRICE
description: WHEN the Japanese restaurant Sakura in Westport was new two and a half years ago, it consisted of two dining concepts: a traditional restaurant with several private tatami-mat rooms, and in a separate section, a Japanese steakhouse with numerous tabletop grills. Since then Sakura has added a a sushi bar. Considering that a mere handful of sushi bars are to be found in Fairfield County, it seems appropriate to review Sakura's sushi bar as a separate entity.

title: D'AMATO SUGGESTS SEVERAL AS JUDGES
description: Frank X. Altimari, a Federal district judge on Long Island, has been recommended for appointment to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit by Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato.

title: Folly to Be Unbelted
description: To the Editor:

title: DISGRUNTLED BEIRUT AIRPORT GUARD HIJACKS PLANE FOR 5 HOURS
description: A disgruntled airport guard demanding a promotion hijacked a Lebanese airliner for five hours today, threatening to crash it into the presidential palace. The drama ended with the hijacker disappearing, apparently into nearby shantytowns.

title: HARRIET TUBMAN AS OPERA HEROINE
description: This Friday in Norfolk, Va., the curtain will go up on a new opera noteworthy on several counts. It represents a joint commissioning venture by England's Royal Opera (Covent Garden) and the 10-year-old Virginia Opera Association; the first stage work on an American subject by Thea Musgrave, the Scottish composer who now makes her home in Norfolk; and the third opera in an ongoing working collaboration of a sort far less common than it once was: between a noted composer and an active, standard-repertory opera company.

title: Imports . . . and Imports
description: After drawing down swollen inventories of foreign goods last summer and fall, American importers, loaded with even stronger dollars in the final quarter of 1984, went on another buying spree in abroad.

title: THE IMPORTANCE OF CARAVAGGIO
description: I read Frank Stella's essay as a welcome call for painting to dare being great again. The abstraction of today is barren and the new realism is limp.

title: FACTORS FOR CO-OPS TO WEIGH
description: WITHIN the next year or so, many cooperative corporations will have to refinance the mortgages on their buildings.

title:
GARDENING;

ANNUAL SHOWS BRING A BIT OF SPRING
description: IT seems that the spring flower

title: KNICKS DEFEATED BY LAKERS, 119-114
description: It was just about a year ago when Kareem Abdul-Jabbar convinced himself that his time had passed. He said it was time to leave quietly, so that his skills wouldn't fade before the critical eyes of the world. Yet, he was wrong about himself, and he hasn't stopped proving himself wrong.

title: TOOL ORDERS UP 12.1 PERCENT Orders for American-made machine tools rose 12.1 percent in January from a year ago, the industry's trade association said yesterday.
description: But the National Association of Machine Tool Builders added that the net orders for January of $211.9 million represented a 17 percent drop from December's levels. The association attributed the decline to a surge in year- end orders.

title: D.D.B. in Portugal
description: Doyle Dane Bernbach International is opening its first office in Portugal, to be called Doyle Dane Bernbach & Guerrerio Publicidade. Portugal becomes the 11th European country where the publicly held company has an office. The new Lisbon office's client roster features Seagram and Polaroid, a pair of longtime D.D.B. supporters.

title: THE THIRD PAYOFF
description: WASHINGTON Three lawful payoffs await those

title: Two Koreans Struggle On the Upper West Side
description: Isolated by geography, metier and

title: PUSH COMES TO SHOVE FOR DOLE
description: One night last week, as the Senate struggled to find a compromise on farm credit measures and break a filibuster blocking the confirmation of Edwin Meese 3d as Attorney General, Senator Robert Dole of Kansas, chatting with reporters just off the Senate floor, said: ''I do not intend to be pushed around.''

title: Javits Is Hospitalized With Lung Problems
description: Former Senator Jacob K. Javits was admitted to New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center yesterday morning after suffering severe breathing problems. He was reported in fair and stable condition.

title: RECORD FOR KELLY
description: Brian Sipe, the quarterback the Generals traded to the Jacksonville Bulls when Doug Flutie was signed, suffered a shoulder separation at the end of the first quarter today in the Bulls' 22-14 victory over the Baltimore Stars.

title: Democrats, Woo
description: Kirkpatrick Back

title: HARRAH, DISSATISFIED WITH NEW POSITION
description: Uncomfortable, unwanted, unneeded.

title: FOLKLORE THRIVING IN CITIES
description: Folklore generally conjures images of banjos, corncob pipes and tall tales told by the light of a waning fire. But not to most modern folklorists, who say that folklore, thinly disguised, continues to thrive in urban settings.

title: What H.U.D. Says
description: And What It Does

title: Landmark's Teachings
description: IN emerging as a New York landmark with the

title: Poor Housekeeping Is Given As Reason for Wife's Murder
description: A man charged with shooting his wife to death told the police he was provoked by her poor cooking and sloppy housekeeping, officers said.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
description: THE PENTAGON AND THE ART OF

title: CONCERT: REQUIEM, BY LLOYD WEBBER
description: -century music is so beset by quarrelsome factions that composers who mediate between them deserve our full attention. Andrew Lloyd Webber, maker of ''Cats,'' ''Evita'' and other successful popular entertainments, took his skills into a very different world of style on Sunday night and brought us a Requiem, one of the most solemn and ancient of musical forms.

title: Venezuela Balks at Terms
description: Venezuela is resisting pressure from foreign banks to insert a definition of how the private sector debt would be repaid under the terms of a rescheduling of $20.75 billion of public sector debt, Mauricio Garcia Araujo, a member of the Government debt negotiating team, said in an article today in the Caracas daily newspaper, El Nacional.

title: DANCE: GALLMAN'S NEWARK TROUPE
description: SINCE 1967, the Harlem Cultural Council's Dancemobile has brought dance to the city streets. For the last decade, it has also offered indoor performances, and, in honor of the 10th anniversary of this series, it is presenting concerts, through March 3, at Symphony Space. Saturday night's program was shared by Gallman's Newark Dance Theater and the International Afrikan-American Ballet.

title: FAINT GLEAM OF PEACE
description: CAIRO President Hosni Mubarak has prepared with extra care for his trip to Washington next month. The stakes are high for Egypt, but his mood is remarkably relaxed. He evidently feels things are moving again in the Middle East, and that there is now a chance of another break in the long Arab-Israeli impasse.

title: QADDAFI TELLS BLACKS TO REVOLT
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, today urged black American servicemen to leave the military and create a separate army because the United States ''must be destroyed.''

title: DANCE: CALABASH TROUPE OF BROOKLYN
description: THE 10th annual Dancemobile Winter Series opened on Thursday at Symphony Space, where it will run through March 3, with a joyous explosion of dance, music and general high spirits engendered by the Calabash Dance Company. There were dances from Africa and Brazil. The music was played on traditional instruments. But the company proudly proclaims itself as Brooklyn-born and bred. And what made the performance stand out - and fit perfectly with Dancemobile's aim of celebrating black American dance and history - were the performers' tough and breezy high spirits. They were pure New York.

title: OPERA: 'CON PASQUALE'
description: THE new production of Donizetti's ''Don Pasquale'' by the Opera Ensemble of New York makes for an engaging evening of musical entertainment. Wednesday night at the Lillie Blake School Theater, a captivating group of players under the direction of Michael Recchiuti brought this celebrated

title: People
MUSIC: OPERA EBONY, 2 NEW WORKS
description: OPERA EBONY presented two new works at the Aaron Davis Hall in Harlem Sunday afternoon - both concerned with oppression, suffering, hope and eventual liberation.

title: Sandra Soupios Is Married
description: Sandra Dianne Soupios, the daughter of Marion Soupios Shichman of Great Neck, L.I., and the late Spero V. Soupios of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married yesterday to Kevin Michael Patrick of Westport, Conn., a son of Mrs. Carmen Gilberti of Sarasota, Fla., and the late Robert John Patrick of Westport. Archbishop Iakovos performed the ceremony at the Greek Orthodox Church of Our Saviour in Rye, N.Y. He was assisted by the Rev. Theodore Baglaneas.

title: GABLE TO J.R. WITH AVA GARDNER
description: The barefoot contessa wore rubber thongs. She walked over the cream carpet at the Waldorf Towers, which was the same shade of cream as her calves, in a pair of tight watermelon- pink toreador slacks. Above the slacks was a cherry-colored sweatshirt with a sequined letter A over one breast, and above the red sweatshirt was a hot-pink scarf, above which was the face of Ava Gardner.

title: Hawkey Going To Bloom Unit
description: Penelope J. Hawkey, longtime member of the McCann- Erickson creative leadership, is leaving the agency to become president and creative director of Bloom/New York, the local branch of the Bloom Companies of Dallas.

title: Karen Eisenstadt Wed To Cary Steven Reich
description: Karen Marcia Eisenstadt, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Eisenstadt of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Cary Steven Reich, a son of Etta Reich of Brooklyn and the late Marvin Reich. Rabbi Marc Schneier performed the ceremony at the Rainbow Grill in New York.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MONDAY, FEBRUARY 25, 1985

title: CANADIENS DEFEAT ISLANDERS IN OVERTIME
description: It could not have been predicted that the night would end with Brent Sutter sitting in his locker stall, not moving, with Bryan Trottier pacing and muttering, with Coach Al Arbour closed up in his office.

title: Test of Cruise Missile Put Off Again in Canada
description: A test launch of an unarmed United States cruise missile over the Canadian Arctic was postponed today for the third straight day, prompting frustrated protesters to pack up and go home.

title: STALLIONS TOP GENERALS, 38-28
description: By the time Doug Flutie settled down and began to work his magic for the Generals today, their game against the Birmingham Stallions had been lost.

title: CONFIRMING A CHILD IN A FAITH
description: THE ancient religious rituals of

title: WORK HAD PREMIERE IN 1744
description: Handel composed ''Semele'' in one month, between June 3 and July 4 of 1743, a year after the first performance of ''Messiah'' and shortly after his second stroke. The work, in effect an opera or masque disguised as an oratorio, had its premiere at London's Covent Garden opera house on Feb. 10, 1744.

title: Truman Takes Title
description: The long reign of Brooklyn Tech as girls' indoor track and field champion of the Public Schools Athletic League came to an end yesterday. Harry S. Truman High School of the Bronx ended the seven-year title streak of Tech when it tallied a winning total of 141 points at the 102d Engineers Armory.

title: JAZZ: BLUE NOTE REUNION AT TOWN HALL
description: BLUE NOTE RECORDS, a jazz label that has been dormant since the 1970's, marked its rebirth Friday with five-and-a-half hours of music at Town Hall. The concert brought together musicians from Blue Note's glory days in the 1950's and 1960's and from the label's new roster - two groups that overlap with such fine musicians as the drummer Art Blakey, the pianist McCoy Tyner and the guitarist Kenny Burrell.

title: Emerson in Settlement
description: The Emerson Electric Company has agreed to repay the Government $325,000 to settle a case involving reported overcharges to the Defense Department, it was disclosed Friday. The Government maintained that between 1974 and 1978 there was a bid- rigging and kickback scheme run by certain suppliers of electronic components to Emerson's Electronics and Space division in collaboration with former Emerson employees.

title: An Orderly Draft
description: The Dominican Republic has been so fertile a baseball training ground in recent years that a pretty fair team could be assembled from its exports who now dot major league rosters. Among them are Mario Soto, Damaso Garcia, George Bell, Julio Franco, Pedro Guerrero, Alejandro Pena, Tony Pena, Juan Samuel, Pascual Perez, Tony Fernandez, Rafael Ramirez, Cesar Cedeno, Joaquin Andujar and Rafael Santana.

title: PRINCETON'S HONOR CODE CHALLENGED BY A STUDENT
description: For the first time in the 92-year history of the Princeton University honor code, the university this year allowed the enrollment of a student who did not sign a statement promising to comply with the code.

title: U.S. AND JAPAN IN BATTLE TO EXPAND AIR SERVICE
description: When American and Japanese negotiators sit down at the bargaining table Monday, the Americans will find themselves in an anomalous position - for a change, they will be the ones defending themselves against charges of closed markets.

title: ISRAELIS BESIEGE NINE LEBANESE VILLAGES
description: Israeli soldiers besieged at least nine Shiite Moslem villages in southern Lebanon today, continuing their crackdown on the underground resistance.

title: MANY YOUTHS, FEARING FOR SAFETY, CARRY WEAPONS AT CITY'S HIGH SCHOOLS
description: Traveling between his home in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn and his classes at Boys and Girls High School never bothered Darryl Johnson. He said he always felt safe on the block he called ''my home'' and in the school he called ''my high.''

title: Accounts
description: * New Woman magazine to Ogilvy & Mather Partners.

title: Debt Issues
description: Ameritrust Corp. filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an offering of up to $200 million of senior subordinated debt.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: Capitol Industries-EMI, Hollywood, a distributor of phonograph records, has named Fred Willms president of Picture Music International, a video production subsidiary.

title: There Must Be an Easier Way to Sue and Defend in Libel Cases
description: To the Editor:

title: An Amnesty Proposed On Unpaid State Taxes
description: A three- month amnesty program for delinquent New York State taxpayers would be set up this year under a proposal announced today by Republican leaders in the State Senate.

title: Inflation Rate 5% in Britain
description: Britain's annual inflation rate rose to 5 percent in January, an increase from the December rate of 4.6 percent, the Government reported Friday.

title: Advertising;   CBS Toys Combining Accounts
description: A DECISION has been made by CBS Toys to consolidate all the advertising for its five divisions in one agency, and Towne Silverstein Rotter will be the beneficiary of that move. It means adding another $10 million in billings to the $10 million the agency already had from that client.

title: Message from the Vatican
description: It came on elegant ivory paper with the crimson insignia and a large watermark identifying the sender as the ''Secretatus Status'' or Secretariat of State of the Vatican. In 16 brief lines, Agostino Cardinal Caseroli made it clear to the Federal Communications Commission that the Vatican was concerned over the Reagan Administration's plan to open up Intelsat, the international telecommunications system owned by 109 countries, to outside competition.

title: OPERA: A RARE 'SEMELE' BY HANDEL
description: IT is difficult to imagine, in this

title: PREDICTING INTEREST RATES IN '85
description: In the absence of any compelling reasons that the Federal Reserve should aggressively wrench interest rates higher or lower, many economists expect that the course of rates this year will be determined largely by the behavior of the economy - much as in 1984.

title: SPORTS WORLD Specials;   . . . Or Any at All
description: Tracy Sundlun, the president of the Metropolitan Athletics Congress, met for several hours on Friday afternoon with Angelo Aponte, the chairman of the City Consumer Affairs Commission, and with representatives of the City Planning Commission, discussing, according to Sundlun, ''the feasibility of constructing and maintaining a multisports indoor training and competition facility in New York.''

title: Outer Space II
description: With Senator Jake Garn of Utah scheduled to take off Sunday on the next space shuttle flight, the Senate Committee on Banking, Housing and Urban Affairs, which he heads, has decided not to hold sessions for two weeks.

title: Photographic Official For RKO to Get Award
description: Linwood G. Dunn, longtime head of photographic effects for RKO, will receive the Gordon E. Sawyer Award for his contributions to movie technology at the Oscar ceremony on March 25, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences announced last week.

title: ROYAL DUTCH IN SHELL ACCORD
description: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group said yesterday that it would increase by $2 a share the amount it paid stockholders of the Shell Oil Company in a tender offer for the company last year, in exchange for dismissal of a lawsuit by shareholders who complained that the offer was inadequate.

title: A Port in Ethiopia Receives 40,000 Tons of U.S. Wheat
description: Forty thousand metric tons of American wheat, the largest single consignment of grain ever sent to this drought- afflicted nation, arrived at the Red Sea port of Assab this weekend, the United Nations World Food Program's office here announced.

title: FOR CHIEF'S CROWN, AN UNHURRIED ROUTE TO LOUISVILLE
description: HALLANDALE, Fla.

title: OFFICER KILLS MAN ON SUBWAY
description: A man was shot dead by a New York City police officer on an elevated subway platform in the Bronx yesterday afternoon, the police said.

title: Bridge:Organizer of Pro-am Event Smoothly Balances the Field
description: Balancing can be a tricky bidding operation for players. It can also be a tricky planning operation for organizers.

title: NATIONWIDE PATTERN BEING FOUND IN HUGE LOSSES ON BAD MORTGAGES
description: As they sift through piles of documents, bankers, lawyers and law-enforcement officials are concluding that startling losses by the Bank of America on mortgages reflect a pattern of defaults across the country. And they say that losses from the defaults have stung other California institutions and cheated mortgage investors around the nation.

title: Tatham-Laird Shop Promotes 2 Executives
description: William E. Ross, 54 years old, of Tatham-Laird & Kudner in Chicago has been named chairman, replacing Jerome F. Birn, who retired in December. Mr. Ross's former title of chief operating officer goes to William Youngclaus, 45, who will carry the additional title of managing partner. The announcement was made by Charlotte Beers, the chief executive officer.

title: COST OF LIBEL SUITS PROMPTS CALLS TO ALTER SYSTEM
description: The public debate over libel law that raged with special intensity in the recent trials pitting Gen. William C. Westmoreland against CBS News and Ariel Sharon against Time magazine has often seemed a standoff between two warring camps.Those who side with the press say the risk of a costly libel suit could deter news organizations, particularly smaller ones, from reporting aggressively on controversial matters. Those who side with critics of the press say libel law makes it too hard for officials and others to protect their reputations against falsehoods. Both camps think the law should be changed, but in opposite directions.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: MCCUMBER WINS DORAL BY 1
description: Mark McCumber stuck to his guns in the belief that the ball he drove on the 18th hole was not lodged high in a palm tree as some fans in the gallery believed. He insisted the ball was about 50 yards right of the tree, where he had aimed his drive, and he located it there after refusing to climb the tree to look for it.

title: New Editor at Scribner's
description: Christine Pevitt has been named editor in chief of Charles Scribner's Sons, a position created as part of a reorganization at the publishing house.

title: Saint Jean, in Shorts
description: Invitations to a brunch yesterday

title: Futures/Options;   An Innovation Causes Uproar
description: OF all the innovative options markets that have opened or have been proposed in recent years, none has so rattled the commodities industry as the cash-settled gold options that the American Stock Exchange plans to start trading in early April.

title: Leslie Canfield Is Wed To Jeffry Lyn Perlman
description: At Adas Israel Congregation in Washington yesterday Leslie Jeanne Canfield, the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Ernest S. Canfield of White Plains, was married to Jeffry Lyn Perlman, a son of Mrs. Jack Perlman and the late Mr. Perlman of Valdosta, Ga. Rabbi Stanley Rabinowitz performed the ceremony.

title: MUBARAK SUGGESTS ARAB-ISRAEL TALKS WITH U.S. AS HOST
description: President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt urged the Reagan Administration today to invite Israel and members of a joint Jordanian- Palestinian delegation to the United States to lay the groundwork for direct peace talks.

title: KIRKPATRICK'S SUCCESS
description: Whatever the ultimate judgment on Jeane J. Kirkpatrick's four years as chief American delegate to the United Nations, she has had more influence on America's policies there than any of her 16 predecessors. She took the job believing her assignment was to protect and enhance ''the legitimate aspirations of the American people'' in an organization that, she felt, had begun to treat us as ''the bad guys.'' She leaves it convinced that whereas ''four years ago, the United States was isolated and humiliated . . . that is not easy anymore.''

title: Retract Those Claws!
description: At a recent opening of a photographic display of Presidential children, Lynda Johnson Robb recalled the time she took Alice Roosevelt Longworth on a private tour of the White House in the Johnson Administration.

title: PICKENS'S INVESTMENT IN UNOCAL
description: Fred L. Hartley has been both unconventional and conservative, delivering what many analysts describe as steady, above-average results during the nearly two decades that he has run the Unocal Corporation.

title: 'BUNNY'S TALE' FROM GLORIA STEINEM
description: ''ALL women are Bunnies,'' the former Playboy Club waitress finally realizes, ''but it doesn't have to be that way.'' The insight is hardly overwhelming, but the speaker is Gloria Steinem, prominent feminist spokesperson, and that is inspiration enough these days for a television movie.

title: NEW STUDIES ARE PLANNED ON TREND TOWARD PRIVATELY OPERATED JAILS
description: The chairman of a House judiciary subcommittee and a Justice Department official say they will conduct separate, extensive studies of privately operated correctional facilities.

title: REPORT CRITICIZES U.S. ON AIDS
description: The Reagan Administration's spending for research into AIDS, acquired immune deficiency syndrome, has not matched the deadly disease's designation as the country's top health priority, according to a new Congressional report.

title: YOUNG ETHIOPIAN STOWAWAYS EMBRACE A NEW LIFE
description: To his classmates at Port Richmond High School on Staten Island, Biniam Hadjue is ''oh yeah, the soccer player.'' Some distinguish him by his great front kick.

title: BUSINESSMEN LOOK TO AID WEST BANK
description: On the West Bank of the Jordan River, a region brimming with antagonism and conflicting aspirations, a group of about 40 American businessmen of Jewish and Arab descent has created an uproar with its plans to promote economic development.

title: DOLE SAYS BIGGEST HELP TO FARMERS WOULD BE CUTTING BUDGET DEFICIT
description: Senator Bob Dole today told legislators from the Farm Belt that the best thing the Government could do for farmers was to reduce the Federal budget deficit.

title: Hakuhodo to Handle Toyotomi Advertising
description: Another announcement related to goods from the Land of the Rising Sun concerns Toyotomi America, another marketing company, which has shifted the advertising responsibility for its Toyostove and Toyoset lines to Hakuhodo Advertising America, a subsidiary of a Japanese company.

title: ZIA SAYS HE'LL YIELD MANY OF HIS POWERS AFTER ASSEMBLY VOTE
description: President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq promised tonight that he would soon relinquish many of his powers in governing Pakistan to the National Assembly that is to be elected this week.

title: PAKISTANI IN U.S. SOUGHT TO SHIP A-BOMB TRIGGER
description: The Government of Pakistan operated inside the United States for nine months in an attempt to illegally obtain timing devices whose main function is to trigger nuclear bombs, according to court documents and Federal officials.

title: ALCOTT'S LATE EAGLE ASSURES VICTORY
description: Amy Alcott sank a 12-foot eagle putt on the 18th hole today for a one-shot victory over Betsy King in the $175,000 Ladies Professional Golf Association Circle K Tucson Open.

title: No Headline
description: MONDAY, FEBRUARY 25, 1985 International

title: CAPITAL HUMOR
description: Serving in Congress can be a heady affair, but as at least two of its members can testify, there is always someone around to puncture an inflated ego.

title: Crime in Casinos Down 10% Despite Adding Another Hall
description: Crime in casino-hotels dropped more than 10 percent from 1983 to 1984, despite the opening of another gaming hall last year, officials said.

title: West Wins, 11-7, As Zungul Excels
description: Steve Zungul of San Diego, the leading scorer in Major Indoor Soccer League history, scored three goals, including two in the final four minutes, to give the West an 11-7 victory over the East today in the league's sixth annual All-Star Game.

title: Outer Space I
description: With the Congressional moratorium on testing of anti- satellite weaponry expiring on Friday, a bipartisan group of more than 100 members of the House plans to send President Reagan a letter this week asking that he extend the ban on his own initiative, at least through the early stages of the arms control talks scheduled to begin March 12 in Geneva.

title: ART COLLECTOR SUES WHITNEY MUSEUM
description: An art collector is suing the Whitney Museum to regain possession of the paintings, drawings and writings by the American artist Morgan Russell that the donor gave to the museum in 1978.

title: KNIGHT 'SORRY' FOR OUTBURST
description: Coach Bobby Knight of Indiana said tonight that he was ''deeply sorry'' for angrily hurling a chair across the court during Saturday's 72- 63 loss to Purdue.

title: Rorer Group's Chief Could Face a Key Test
description: John W. Eckman, chairman and chief executive officer of the Rorer Group Inc., is acting like a lot of top executives these days: Mr. Eckman does not like thinking about going through a hostile takeover fight, and has introduced a ''poison pill'' provision to guard against that possibility.

title: What Not to Do About the Dollar
description: The dollar continues to defy reason and remedy. Its value is too high, the experts say. That inflates imports, hurts exports and makes everyone nervous about a sudden collapse. Indeed, Britain's Prime Minister Thatcher warns of a possibly ''brutal'' shakeout.

title: Intentions Made Known
description: One of the more curious filings at the Securities and Exchange Commission last week was a submission by a Washingtonian named Larry Napoleon Cooper, who proposes a leveraged buyout of the Mobil Corporation.

title: Market Place;   Bullish On Foreign Stocks
description: BAILARD, BIEHL & KAISER INC. of San Mateo, Calif., takes a positive view of investment opportunities in foreign securities markets. ''Our asset allocation in that sector is now 15 percent for individual accounts and we plan to increase that to 20 percent within the next several months,'' Ronald W. Kaiser, a senior vice president, said Friday. ''About one-half of our foreign stocks are Japanese companies, with the remainder concentrated in Europe.''

title: 'STAR WARS' MEANS ONLY TROUBLE
description: Rarely has an American strategic revolution been initiated in circumstances as likely to lead to enormous difficulties with the public, the Soviet Union and the allies as ''Star Wars'' - President Reagan's Strategic Defense Initiative.

title: REDMEN'S LATE LAPSES IRK CARNESECCA
description: About 25 minutes after St. John's had defeated Syracuse, 88-83, on Saturday for its 19th consecutive victory, Coach Lou Carnesecca emerged from the Redmen's locker room. He rasped an apology for the delay and proceeded as if nothing unusual had happened.

title: HEADED LATIN UNIT OF READER'S DIGEST
description: Robert C. Sanchez, former president of the company that publishes the Central and South American editions of Reader's Digest, died Saturday night at his home in Miami after a long illness. He was 81 years old.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: TWO WORLDS Gerry Mulligan, the saxophonist and composer who has been an important figure in jazz since the 1940's, has been performing in recent years with symphony orchestras. Last year, he wrote a piece that reflects a meeting between the two worlds. It is called ''Entente for Baritone Saxophone and Orchestra,'' and is described by Mr. Mulligan as a rhapsody that allows the soloist the option of ''an improvisational approach.''

title: MONDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Connecticut at Boston College , 8 P.M. (Television - ESPN, 8 P.M.);

title: HOMELESS SHARE GOSPEL OF THE POOR DURING LENT
description: Annie Q. stepped up to the ornate stone pulpit of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine yesterday, looked down the nave at hundreds of well-groomed and well-dressed people, and delivered a sermon on what it means to be homeless.

title: Where Mrs. Thatcher Faltered
description: When Prime Minister Thatcher is good, she is very good, as in her speech to Congress last week. She offered a rousing defense of Western freedoms and a skillful accounting of her Conservative Government's record. On sticky alliance matters, she relied on indirection to speak for Europe without unsettling her friend, President Reagan.

title: Met Preparing a Gallery For Japanese Art
description: Reaching across the globe for the

title: THE DANCE: 'COPPELIA' FROM BASEL
description: THE young man and woman who are lovers in traditional versions of ''Coppelia'' are very different characters in Heinz Spoerli's production, performed by the Basel Ballet at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Gone are the usual savvy peasants, and in their place are a male student and a professor's daughter, both confused and both in love with illusions. Neither is a terribly pleasant type. But Gilma Bustillo and Weit Carlsson, who took over the roles of Antonia and Franz on Saturday night, made them surprisingly sympathetic.

title: ;   Americans of Hispanic Origin
description: To the Editor:

title: OPERA: 'RIGOLETTO'
description: SCARCELY had the New York City Opera National Company left town on its 30-stop tour of North America than it was back in the city, at least for the night. The City Opera is traveling with a new, simply wrought and eminently portable production of Verdi's ''Rigoletto,'' and Saturday night it set up shop at the Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts at Brooklyn College.

title: Texas Abortion Clinics Patrolled After Fire
description: Police stepped up patrols at abortion clinics throughout the Dallas area after arson destroyed a clinic in this suburban community.

title: Measles Causes Quarantine At Christian Science College
description: Missourians employed at a Christian Science college in Illinois where students refuse to be vaccinated have been told to stay off the campus until a measles epidemic ends.

title: Irwin R. Blacker Dies at 65; Author Taught Screenwriting
description: Irwin R. Blacker, the author and screenwriter who taught some of Hollywood's most accomplished writers, directors and producers, died Saturday. He was 65 years old.

title: Gentlemanly Conducting
description: To the Editor:

title: Halloooooo
description: The Republic of Benin is a tiny

title: Subway Capitalism
description: Two subway peddlers were displaying their wares atop large cardboard cartons when they spotted two transit police officers.

title: A Westchester Officer Shot Dead in Yonkers
description: A Westchester County police officer was shot and killed last night after he stopped a car while on patrol in Yonkers, the police said.

title: FLUTIE DEBUT: NO BOUQUETS
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala.

title: OPERA: 'POSTCARD FROM MOROCCO'
description: THERE have been many stagings of Dominick Argento's ''Postcard From Morocco'' since its first performance in 1971, but it is doubtful that any of these have rivaled the recent Juilliard American Opera Center's production - which this reviewer saw Friday night - for originality, professionalism and sheer visual beauty.

title: JOGGERS, STROLLERS AND DINERS GET AN EARLY TASTE OF SPRING
description: The fruit trees are still bare and the herb gardens are banked with protective straw, but New Yorkers and tourists flocked to the Cloisters yesterday to savor the sudden, untimely promise of spring.

title: MOSCOW TV SHOWS CHERNENKO VOTING
description: Soviet television showed Konstantin U. Chernenko casting a ballot today, in his first appearance in almost two months.

title: Unwanted Pregnancies, Unwanted Children
description: To the Editor:

title: Sweden Gets Ready For Big War Games
description: Sweden massed 22,000 soldiers on its border with Norway today in its largest military exercise since World War II, aimed at showing it is ready to repel attacks from the west as well as the east.

title: YOUNG ENGINEERS TEST STRENGTH OF THEIR BRIDGES
description: The prize for esthetics went to a delicate-looking truss bridge, painstakingly crafted along its whole 17 inches. Kevin Burke, a high school senior from Baldwin, L.I., posed for pictures with his balsa wood-and-glue creation.

title: Four More Years in Chile?
description: The Reagan Administration is reconciled to four more years of military dictatorship in Chile and not even embarrassed to say so. That is the incredible message delivered there this week by Assistant Secretary of State Langhorne Motley. He rests easy with the Pinochet regime's plan to permit no elections until 1989. No one should be either alarmed or fooled by Washington's recent refusal to vote for new international loans to Chile. That was only an empty gesture intended to impress liberals in Congress.

title: DANCE: CAROLYN LORD
description: A TALL, serene column of a figure, dressed in black, Carolyn Lord moved with a mesmerizing slowness and concentration along a diagonal path across the stage of the Danspace at St. Mark's Church in a performance on Friday. She then subsided into a huddle at the corner, her arms folded like white bars across her bowed body. It was a magical moment, as Miss Lord's moments on stage tended to be. But there were not enough of them.

title: Western Samoans Give Leaders a Wide Victory
description: The governing Human Rights Protection Party won a landslide victory in general elections Saturday and will have about two-thirds of the seats in the next Parliament, election officials said today.

title: WOMEN WIN THE PRIZE OF LAW PARTNERSHIP
description: A small but growing number of women are moving into the jealously guarded centers of power, money and prestige in the private sector of law. As partners in large law firms, these women are making an average of $200,000 a year, commanding corner offices with their names in gold on the door and working in the mainstream of the profession - as corporate lawyers and litigators - rather than in traditional female fields such as trusts and estates. Some are earning reputations as ''rainmakers'' by bringing in new business.

title: Curfew Follows Tumult In a Town in India
description: A curfew was imposed today in the western Indian town of Dig after the police shot and killed six people when a crowd surrounded a building where police officials were meeting, the Press Trust of India said.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Feb. 25, 1985: *2*MONDAY Dayco Corp United Illuminating San Diego Gas&Elec Watkins-Johnson *2*TUESDAY Angelica Corp Munford Inc Borg-Warner Corp National Gypsum Brockway Inc New England Elec Brush Wellman Revlon Inc Gannett Co Westvaco Corp Merck & Co *2*WEDNESDAY Bowater Inc Pennsylvania Pwr&Lt Cenergy Corp Philip Morris Conwood Corp Reading & Bates Deere & Co Stanley Works First Va Banks Wolverine Worldwide *2*THURSDAY Ametek Inc Interlake Inc Arvin Indus Louisiana Gen Svc Emhart Corp Shell Oil Co Ex-Cell-O Corp Union Pacific *2*FRIDAY Blair(John) & Co Green Mountain Pwr

title: Police Shoot Charging Ram
description: A ram that butted a woman who died later of her injuries was shot and killed after it charged officers investigating the case, a Los Angeles County sheriff's deputy said.

title: Mandlikova Surprises Lloyd
description: Hana Mandlikova, who stopped Martina Navratilova's 54-match winning streak to win the Virginia Slims of California tournament last year, ended four years of frustration against Chris Evert Lloyd with a 6-2, 6-4 triumph today in the final of the $150,000 tournament.

title: U.S. SAID TO BE CAUTIOUS ON NICARAGUA POLICY
description: The Reagan Administration renewed its campaign for covert aid to the Nicaraguan rebels after concluding that open aid could cost the United States the support of its most important allies in Central America, according to senior Administration officials.

title: West German Sets Best in the Jump
description: Dietmar Mogenburg of West Germany, the Olympic champion, set the world indoor best in the men's high jump, clearing 7 feet 10 inches today during an international track and field meet.

title: Dutch to Quit Venture
description: The Government has canceled plans to enlarge its 36.5 percent share in a fledgling Dutch transmission company partly owned by Volvo A.G. of Sweden and Fiat S.p.A. of Italy. Instead, the Economics Ministry said Friday, it has entered into talks to dispose of the Government's interest in Van Doorne's Transmissie N.V.

title: 2 YEARS AFTER MASSACRE, SALVADORAN SEEKS JUSTICE
description: Adrian Esquino Lisco has been waiting two years for justice, but now, he says, his patience and his faith are beginning to run out.

title: National Can's Plan For Posner
description: The National Can Corporation is known in its industry as ''a hard blocker and tackler,'' according to Frank W. Considine.

title: NO DATE FOR PINIELLA TAKEOVER
description: Lou Piniella, heir apparent to Yogi Berra as the Yankees' manager, said today that he looks forward to being a major league manager and believes he can handle the job, but he emphasized that he has no thought of snatching the job from Berra.

title: Who Files Medical-Malpractice Claims?
description: To the Editor:

title: 4 Convicted for Their Attack On a Minuteman Missile Silo
description: Four people who damaged a Minuteman 2 nuclear missile silo with a jackhammer say they were not surprised by their convictions on charges of conspiring to impede national defense.

title: Washington Wtch;   Monetarists Gain Influence
description: WASHINGTON

title: Suspect in Kidnapping Is Said to Flee Mexico
description: A Mexican suspected in the kidnapping of a United States drug agent left Mexico over the weekend with the help of Mexican police officers, an American official said today.

title: Larger Quarters . . .
description: The coach's locker room is a converted coal bin, and it has been years since the building's 10,000 seats have been enough to accommodate demand. But when the University of North Carolina basketball team moves into a new 21,500-seat arena next season, the team, its fans and Coach Dean Smith can be forgiven if they miss the ramshackle William D. Carmichael Jr. Auditorium, where the Tar Heels have played their home games since 1965.

title: U.S. ENCOURAGED BY NEW INTEREST IN MIDEAST TALKS
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that they were encouraged by the revived interest in negotiations being expressed by Jordan, Egypt and Saudi Arabia. But they said there had not yet been sufficient movement for the United States to begin a new Middle East initiative.

title: Bache's Jacobs Party Adviser Harry A. Jacobs Jr., chairman of Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., is expected to be
description: elected chairman of the Democratic Business Council, an advisory arm of the Democratic

title: Change at Bantam
description: Stephen Rubin, executive editor of Bantam Books, has been appointed editorial director, supervising adult fiction and nonfiction. He will report to Linda Grey, who previously was named Bantam's publisher and editor in chief. Mr. Rubin joined Bantam last May after working as an editor at Vanity Fair and serving as director of Writers Bloc, a news feature syndicate. Bantam, a paperback house, also publishes hard-cover books.

title: A RABBI IN HIS SYNAGOGUE (BUT THIS IS ETHIOPIA)
description: The synagogue in this northern Ethiopian village is a one-room stone building with wooden shutters over the few windows and a metal Star of David mounted on the roof.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We have a special ticket. One week in New York and one week in Antigua, but at the moment I don't think there's much point in going to Antigua.''

title: WILLIAMS STARS IN OLD SPOT
description: The idea was born out of necessity, but it did not take Stan Albeck, the Net coach, long to realize it was an idea best forgotten.

title: Question Box
description: -game winner with the Yankees? Did he ever win a World Series game for them?

title: Skor, the Candy Bar, Plans Ads for Adults
description: When one thinks of candy bar advertising, one usually imagines a Saturday morning kiddie extravaganza on television in an environment of hectic cartoons. But that is hardly the case for Skor, a confection (''Milk Chocolate Covered/Crisp Butter Toffee'') being marketed by Hershey Chocolate.

title: KAYPRO, AMID LAYOFFS, ISSUING NEW COMPUTER
description: The Kaypro Corporation plans to introduce a new computer today that is compatible with the PC-AT computer being sold by the International Business Machines Corporation.

title: REMEBER THE ALAMO
description: He was born in the Bronx, but a certificate on the wall of Russell A. Rourke's Pentagon office declares him to be an honorary citizen of Texas. Senator John Tower of Texas, while chairman of the Armed Services Committee, arranged that distinction several years ago after watching Mr. Rourke leap from the crowd and pinion a wild-eyed man who was disrupting a meeting of the committee.

title: Federal Agency Grounds A Kansas Airline
description: The Federal Aviation Administration has revoked Capitol Air Service's operating license, grounding the commuter airline for the second time in 11 months.

title: FLYERS BEAT FLAMES
description: Brian Propp and Ron Sutter each scored a goal and an assist tonight as the Philadelphia Flyers defeated the Calgary Flames, 4-1, for their seventh straight victory.

title: Suspect Reported to Admit Taiwan Plot in a U.S. Slaying
description: A man accused in the slaying of a Chinese-American journalist has told a United States investigator that he was a spy for Taiwan and plotted the killing with intelligence officials, The San Francisco Examiner reported today.

title: 200 FORMER PLAYERS APPLAUD HARSHMAN
description: For Marv Harshman, the University of Washington basketball coach, Saturday night was one of nostalgia and satisfaction. But for other coaches, like George Raveling of Iowa and Lou Henson of Illinois, it was a night of frustration.

title: 'Foul!' Cry Referees
description: Out-of-state boxers are still allowed to fight in Atlantic City, and out-of-state boxing fans are not turned back at the New Jersey border. But since December, out-of-state boxing referees and judges seeking work at the gambling resort have been out of luck.

title: British Retail Prices Up
description: British retail prices rose four-tenths of 1 percent in January from a month earlier and 5 percent from a year earlier, the Government said Friday.

title: NORWEGIAN DIPLOMAT FACES TRIAL TODAY IN SPYING CASE
description: The trial of Arne Treholt, a well-connected Norwegian diplomat accused of spying for the Soviet Union and Iraq, will begin here Monday.

title: OUTDOORS: A SHOW TO INSPIRE HUNTERS
description: IF the Northeast's recent spate of

title: MUSIC: RICKY SKAGGS
description: -bred singer and multi-instrumentalist who is based in Nashville, is the most commanding figure of a movement within country music to restore traditional values to a genre increasingly dominated by Hollywood production values and songwriting styles.

title: A CHARACTER ACTOR FINDS STARDOM IN 'INTERLUDE'
description: The central character in Eugene O'Neill's ''Strange Interlude'' is the mercurial Nina Leeds, who becomes the magnet for three men in her orbit - husband, lover and worshipful old friend, Charles Marsden. In the British revival of the play at the Nederlander Theater, ''old Charlie'' comes close to dominating the five-hour evening because of the performance of Edward Petherbridge. In London, both he and Glenda Jackson, who plays Nina, shared acting awards.

title: MUSIC: MUNICH GROUP
description: HOW many concerts have we heard in which orchestras survive mediocre leadership and make believable music in spite of it? Just the opposite seemed to be happening at the Metropolitan Museum on Thursday - an ensemble of limited ability brought to credibility by a skilled and sensitive conductor.

title: IN ALBANY, GREAT POWER IS HELD BY THE UNELECTED
description: The sign on the desk says simply, ''THEY'' - as in ''THEY won't let me.''

title: Goldin Seeks Modifications In Jury-Duty System in City
description: Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin called yesterday for changes in the jury-duty system in courts, both city and state, in New York City to reduce the time that prospective jurors spend waiting to be considered for juries.

title: TAX BATTLE LINES ARE DRAWN SLOWLY
description: The opening shot in the legislative battle over revising the Federal tax system will be fired this week, but it will be weeks or even months before the battle is fully joined.According to Treasury Department officials, Secretary James A. Baker 3d will break no new ground when he testifies Wednesday before the House Ways and Means Committee in the first Congressional tax hearing of the year. But Administration officials said Mr. Baker and President Reagan remain fully committed to pressing hard for enactment of sweeping tax legislation this year.

title: REPLAY RULE NOT TESTED
description: The television camera did not get a chance to second-guess the referees today, but not because the Generals' coach, Walt Michaels, did not at least try.

title: MUSIC: LEONARD RAVER, ORGAN
description: LEONARD RAVER'S organ recital at the Riverside Church Sunday afternoon offered two pieces out of the ordinary. One was the ''Dismas Variations'' by McNeil Robinson, a narration in music of Christ's Passion whose seven variations offer colorful, wildly varied and abrupt mood swings ranging from muted unrest to abject outcries.

title: Treasury to Auction 5-Year Notes
description: In addition to today's regular auction of new bills due in three and six months, the Treasury has scheduled a $7 billion auction of new five-year notes for Tuesday.

title: The Missing Bus Mystery For the last year
description: 850 practically new Grumman buses have been parked in a Brooklyn field waiting for someone to buy them. So far, there have been few interested shoppers. And New York City is suing Grumman for $320 million, which includes the $92 million it paid before deciding that the buses were unsafe and unusable here.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;   A Challenging Role At Bank of Boston
description: George R. West has been in the insurance business for 30 mostly quiet years, and has spent a good part of the last six of them in his duties as a director of the Bank of Boston Corporation.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Feb. 25, 1985 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: TORRENT OF PRINT STRAINS THE FABRIC OF LIBRARIES
description: We're drowning in information and starving for knowledge,'' said Rutherford D. Rogers, who knows more about the strange new world of research libraries than most people know about the papers on their desks.

title: GOVERNORS URGING ONE-YEAR FREEZE IN FEDERAL BUDGET
description: Democratic and Republican governors, united in opposition to President Reagan's budget proposal, today called for a one-year freeze of all Federal spending except for programs to aid the poor.

title: BIG BOARD, PACIFIC TIE PROGRESSES
description: The Pacific Stock Exchange would become a wholly owned subsidiary of the New York Stock Exchange under a proposal that members of both exchanges are being asked to consider. The link could be the first step toward establishing the Big Board as the driving force behind eventual round-the-clock trading in the stocks of American corporations.

title: EXECUTIVE BREAKING AWAY
description: Three years ago, Thomas Watson was earning a six-figure salary supervising 4,000 people as a vice president of the Olin Corporation, the chemical and metals conglomerate. He hoped to become the company's president.

title: PAKISTANIS ADMIT GAINS IN URANIUM TECHNOLOGY
description: Pakistan has consistently maintained that it has no intention of developing a nuclear bomb and that all its nuclear work has gone into research and development of technology for peaceful purposes.

title: HARDEN AND WEAVER FOR PRESIDENT?
description: In this town of the politically fickle, there is one voice that has managed to stick.

title: Rosner Has Rejoined Lord, Geller Agency
description: Having resigned last Nov. 30 from Herman & Rosner, the ad agency he helped to found, Charles Rosner was free to rejoin Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein, which he has done.

title: FATHER'S ADVICE REMAINS GUIDE FOR GOODEN
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.

title: POSSIBILITY OF PARTNER FOR ICAHN
description: Carl C. Icahn, the New York multimillionaire who is trying to take over the Phillips Petroleum Company, is negotiating with one or more companies seeking to ''become involved, deeply involved'' in buying Phillips, Wall Street sources said yesterday.

title: U.S. FAULTED ON CUBAN ALIENS
description: Nearly two thousand Cuban refugees held in state prisons throughout the country were omitted from a list of aliens scheduled to be deported to Cuba, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato said yesterday.

title: DOWNSTATE PRESSING FOR HYDROPOWER
description: Officials from New York City and its neighboring counties have declared that they will go to court if necessary to force the State Power Authority to give them a share of the state's inexpensive hydroelectric power.

title: Summerlike Weather Brings Floods in East By The Associated Press
description: Floods closed roads and forced hundreds of people from their homes yesterday as a winter marked by record cold and highway-blocking snow took an abrupt weekend break. In the eastern quarter of the nation, summerlike temperatures set records.

title: All of Sanyo Business Going to DYR Agency
description: Sanyo Electric of Compton, Calif., the Japanese manufacturer's marketing arm in the United States, has decided to consolidate all its advertising in DYR, Los Angeles, the joint venture of Dentsu, the giant Japanese ad agency, and Young & Rubicam, America's largest.

title: SHAMIR CALLS JORDAN-P.L.O. PACT IN NO WAY AN 'OPENING TO PEACE'
description: Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir said today that the agreement between King Hussein of Jordan and the head of the Palestine Liberation Organization, Yasir Arafat, in no way amounted to an ''opening to peace.''

title: REPUBLICAN INROADS PUT TEXAS DEMOCRATS ON EDGE
description: Last year was rough for Texas Democrats, but Joe Longley believes the damage is not permanent.

title: 3 Injured Mets Resume Practice
description: The Mets' first three minor casualties of spring training all returned to work today.

title: GEORGIA ENDS SLIDE AGAINST KENTUCKY
description: Horace McMillan tipped in a missed free throw with 18 seconds to play today as Georgia, winning in Lexington for the first time since 1923, beat Kentucky, 79-77, to retain a share of the Southeastern Conference lead.

title: Quiet Bravery of Foreign Service Personnel
description: To the Editor:

title: Chip Producer's Stock Tumbles
description: After a delayed opening, the stock of Texas Instruments Inc. opened on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday morning at $110.50. That was $7.25 below its closing price on Friday.

title: No Sour Grapes
description: Peter Ueberroth gets good marks from Hank Greenberg for the commissioner's effort, through a series of surveys, to learn fan sentiment about the designated-hitter rule and thereby help determine whether it ought to be instituted in the National League or scrapped in the American. ''The d.h. should never have been brought in the way it was,'' the former slugger says. ''It is the only major playing rule about which the two major leagues differ. I give Ueberroth credit for trying to resolve the problem.''

title: TURNOUT IS MODERATE IN PAKISTAN'S ELECTIONS
description: Pakistanis voted in moderate numbers today in a parliamentary election that opposition leaders had hoped would produce a nationwide boycott.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Feb. 26, 1985 ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL

title: LEFT HAND VS. RIGHT HAND
description: The left hand, if the Reagan Administration may be said to have

title: IN LINCOLN'S POCKETS
description: President Lincoln was not immune to flattery, as witness the fact that he had tucked nine complimentary newspaper clippings into his wallet before heading to what was to be his fatal rendezvous at Ford's Theater.

title: U.S.-Japan Set
description: The United States will face Japan in the first round of the Davis Cup tennis tournament March 8-10 in Kyoto, the Japan Lawn Tennis Association said today.

title: MOYNIHAN, AS A FELLOW AT COLUMBIA, REVELS IN A RETURN TO CAMPUS LIFE
description: ''But sir,'' said the student during a seminar on ethnicity that was unusually lively for a Monday morning class, ''it looks like ethnic lines have eroded in New York. Jews, for example, are more assimilated than ever.''

title: Continental Illinois Adds Three Directors
description: Continuing to reshape its board, the Continental Illinois Corporation and its subsidiary, the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company of Chicago, elected three new directors yesterday.

title: DEEPER CUTS NEEDED TO MEET G.O.P. DEFICIT GOAL
description: Senate Republicans, who are still struggling to assemble a deficit-reduction package, will get some bad news Tuesday.

title: 3 at Lion Group Indicted
description: The three principal officers of Lion Capital Group have been indicted on felony charges in connection with a scheme to bilk school districts and others out of more than $40 million last year, New York State's Attorney General, Robert Abrams, said today.

title: U.S. AND COMPANIES SET CAMPUS CENTERS FOR SUPERCOMPUTERS
description: The National Science Foundation said today that it would spend $200 million to create supercomputer centers at four of the nation's leading universities. The move is the broadest Federal effort yet to promote research using advanced computer technology.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information SystemsSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: NICARAGUAN SAYS REAGAN THREATS KILLED PEACE BID
description: A senior Nicaraguan Government official said today that President Reagan's recent threats against his country had killed the Contadora negotiations for a regional peace treaty in Central America.

title: Xerox China Plans
description: The Xerox Corporation has taken the first step toward forming a joint venture later this year for the production of copiers in China, Xerox said.

title: Coming and Goings
description: The Cosmos will hold a news conference today to discuss their plans for the outdoor season. The club's officials,

title: Mindanao Bishop is Freed
description: Army troops stormed a hideout of Moslem rebels today and rescued Bishop Federico Escaler of Ipil and eight of his companions held hostage for three days. Bishop Escaler was en route to Zamboanga from his diocese 70 miles to the north, when the rebels kidnapped his party on Friday.

title: AIDE BIDS U.S. END 'DOUBLE STANDARD' ON ARMS ACCORDS
description: The Defense Department's top arms control official said today that it was ''a great mistake'' for the United States to continue honoring past accords with the Soviet Union while Moscow was violating ''quite important provisions'' of those agreements.

title: POLAND, FACING PROTEST, EASES FOOD PRICE RISES WARSAW, Feb. 25 (Reuters) - The Polish Government today abandoned plans for across-the-board food price rises in the face of protests from official labor unions and the outlawed Solidarity movement.
description: The Government said it would replace the price rises with gradual increases cushioned by cash compensation for the low-paid.

title: Bullish on Flutie
description: And where was Donald Trump when his $7 million investment stepped onto the field Sunday at Birmingham and tried to start paying dividends?

title: Scrimping on the Superfund
description: The problem of abandoned toxic waste dumps is not going away. New dumps are still being discovered faster than the known sites can be contained. Already some 20,000 dumps have been tallied, and the poisons leaking from them threaten neighborhoods and ground water throughout the country. Yet the Superfund program to clean up toxic wastes is about to expire without having done more than scratch the surface. The Environmental Protection Agency's proposals for renewing the fund are ingenious but inadequate.

title: New Kodak Unit
description: The Eastman Technology Inc. unit of the Eastman Kodak Company said it had formed a new division, called Beta Physics, to manufacture and market electronic components.

title: LEGISLATOR HOPEFUL ON TAX PLAN
description: Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, said last night that the time was ripe politically this year for a complete restructuring of the Federal income tax system, and he urged business leaders not to stand in the way of such legislation.

title: No More Amateurs With Guns
description: ''You've got to teach them how to get the gun out quickly. You can't have a guy fumbling with the weapon, trying to get it out of his pocket and dropping it. Crimes happen too quickly for that.''

title: PLEA BARGAIN SET IN STEALTH CASE
description: An aerospace engineer charged with trying to sell United States military secrets to the Soviet Union plans to enter a conditional guilty plea to espionage because he is ''very sorry for what he did,'' his attorney said today.

title: The Egyptians Are Coming
description: Ashraf Ghorbal, former Egyptian Ambassador to Washington, arrived in the capital the other day to begin laying the groundwork for President Hosni Mubarak's visit next month. Mr. Ghorbal, who was stationed in Washington from 1974 until late last year, has an especially good relationship with American officials and is well-versed on the complex issues Mr. Mubarak is expected to raise with President Reagan.

title: DOLLAR REACHES FURTHER RECORDS AS GOLD SLUMPS
description: The dollar surged to record highs yesterday, encouraged by Washington's apparent reluctance to intervene in foreign-exchange markets to force the dollar down.

title: IN TIDY TOKYO, A BLEAK BOWERY BECKONS LOST MEN
description: There are no clear signposts to Sanya, home of this city's outcasts.

title: TRESPASS CHARGES AGAINST APARTHEID PROTESTERS ARE DROPPED ON EVE OF BOSTON TRIAL
description: All charges were dropped today against a Nobel laureate and 11 other protesters against South Africa's policy of racial separation, just as their trial was about to begin.

title: 4 REFUSE TO TESTIFY ON AQUINO
description: Four witnesses failed to appear today in the trial of 25 military men and a civilian in the killing of the opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr.

title: A New Archivist?
description: The most coveted job available

title: New Zealand's Leader Arrives on Visit to U.S.
description: Prime Minister David Lange of New Zealand arrived here today to defend his nation's ban on port calls by nuclear warships. The policy has strained relations with Washington and shaken the Anzus military alliance.

title: MARGERY M. WELLES
description: Margery Miller Welles, a sports journalist and biographer of the boxer Joe Louis, died Sunday in Charlotte, N.C., after a long bout with cancer. She was 61. Mrs. Welles, a graduate of Wellesley College, had ''Joe Louis: American'' published in 1945. A boxing buff, she said she also hoped the favorable portrait of the black world champion would help build respect between the races.

title: Stocks Retreat, but Dow Gains 1.66
description: Stock prices, depressed by the recent increase in interest rates, ended mixed yesterday, in a continuation of the directionless trading that has characterized the last few sessions.

title: Fact and Fiction Blur
description: In a TV Twilight Zone

title: AROUND THE NATION ;   3 Former Cadets Plead Guilty in Hazing Death
description: Three former cadets at Texas A&M University today pleaded guilty to reduced charges in the hazing death of a fellow cadet last summer.

title: Cruise Missile Tested Over Canadian Arctic
