description: An unarmed cruise missile was successfully launched over the Beaufort Sea today in the weapon's second free-flight test over the Canadian Arctic in less than a week.

title: 500 FLEE FLOODS IN SUBURBS OF BUFFALO
description: More than 500 residents of Buffalo suburbs left their homes today as heavy rain and melting snow caused the worst flooding of Ellicott Creek in 25 years.

title: Debt Issues
description: Branch Corp. filed a $30 million offering of convertible subordinated debentures, due in 2005, through underwriters led by Robinson-Humphrey Co.

title: Stockades and Barbed Wire for Criminals
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 AGENCIES REPORT SOVIET ARMS SPURT
description: Analysts for the Central Intelligence Agency and the Pentagon said today that there was evidence of a sudden spurt in Soviet spending on weapons procurement for the first time since the mid-1970's. But the agencies differed sharply on the pace of this latest buildup and what it meant.

title: New Debt Problem At Castle & Cooke
description: Castle & Cooke Inc. said today that it would not be able to pay interest due March 1 on some public debt unless it can reach an agreement by then with its private unsecured creditors.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Chesebrough-Pond's Inc., Greenwich, Conn., a manufacturer of consumer products, has elected Richard P. Scheifele as a director.

title: Peru Ousts 1,200 Policemen
description: Interior Minister Oscar Brush said today that 1,200 policemen had been dismissed for committing crimes.

title: Alaska Seeking Money Sources
description: Falling oil prices have led Alaskan officials to explore new ways of financing their state's operating and capital budget.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Knicks vs. San Antonio Spurs , at Madison Square Garden, 7:35 P.M. George Gervin and the Spurs make their only visit of the season to the Garden.

title: Air 1-Zenith Plan
description: Air 1 Inc. said Zenith International Airlines Inc. has agreed to exercise its option to acquire 90 percent of Air 1.

title: Jays Sign Allenson
description: The Toronto Blue Jays have signed

title: PERES CAUTIOUSLY WELCOMES CALL FOR DIRECT MIDEAST TALKS
description: Prime Minister Shimon Peres today cautiously welcomed President Hosni Mubarak's call for direct negotiations between Israel and a joint Jordanian- Palestinian delegation.

title: Montana Balks Convention
description: The Montana House of Representatives has refused to call for a constitutional convention to consider an amendment requiring a balanced Federal budget.

title: Oil-Reserve Problems
description: To the Editor:

title: Farrakhan Disavows Call By Qaddafi for Army
description: The Rev. Louis Farrakhan, the leader of the Nation of Islam, today repudiated an offer made Sunday by Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, to arm black American soldiers so they can form a separate army to destroy ''white America'' and set up an independent state.

title: Bethlehem Loss
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation said that it expects to incur a loss of between $60 million and $80 million in the first quarter of this year. This compares with a loss of $54.6 million in the comparable period a year ago. The company made the statement in announcing that it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an offering of five million shares of new common stock to be underwritten by Salomon Brothers Inc. Bethlehem, the nation's third-largest steel company, after United States Steel and LTV Inc., said results for the rest of 1985 would depend on President Reagan's program to curb foreign imports of steel.

title: Next-Best Thing To Redmen Fans
description: Want a ticket to the St. John's- Georgetown game at the Garden tomorrow night?

title: STRUCTURAL CHANGES AT Y.& R.
description: IT is going to be impossible for the

title: CASE REFUSED FOR BISEXUAL IN LOSS OF JOB
description: The Supreme Court today refused to hear an appeal by a public high school guidance counselor who lost her job as a result of disclosing to her co-workers that she was bisexual.

title: Woods Merger With Sunshine The Sunshine Mining Company said it had agreed in principle to merge the Woods Petroleum Corporation into one of
description: its units in a transaction the

title: AN ARTISTS' COLONY IS EMERGING IN NEWARK
description: In this gritty city, saddled for two decades with an image of urban blight, a community of artists is emerging.

title: CREDIT MARKETS ;   Prices Steady; Demand Weak
description: Weak investor demand for Treasury notes and bonds continued to plague the market in Government securities, though prices did manage to rebound from their lowest levels to close unchanged or slightly lower.

title: 6 Killed in Lebanon Blasts
description: Two bomb-laden cars exploded in a densely populated Shiite Moslem suburb of Beirut at nightfall today, and the police said six civilians were killed and 30 were wounded.

title: LONG RETIRING FROM SENATE AFTER NEARLY 4 DECADES
description: Senator Russell B. Long, one of the last and the most colorful of the Senate's Southern power barons, announced today he would not run for re-election in 1986, ending a career that will have spanned nearly four decades.

title: Required Reading;   Televising the Court
description: If a randomly selected group of average citizens were asked whether Supreme Court proceedings should be televised, I am sure most would answer ''Yes'' or perhaps ''Why not?'' If, however, instead of responding to an abstract question, they were given the opportunity to view four hours of oral argument on live television on a daily basis, I feel sure they would exhibit a rather decided preference for soap operas, grade B movies or even sumo wrestling. For the most part, what happens in our courtroom is not high drama for the average viewer.

title: 24 on Coast Are Charged With Illegal Fish Sales
description: A six-month investigation ended today with the arrest of 24 people accused of illegally selling tons of salmon, steelhead, striped bass and sturgeon to undercover agents in a fake fish market.

title: SMITHKLINE IS FINED FOR FAILING TO REPORT SIDE EFFECTS OF DRUG PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 25 (AP) - The SmithKline Beckman Corporation, the pharmaceutical concern, was placed on two years' probation today and ordered to give $100,000 to a child abuse program for failing to promptly report side effects of a drug blamed in 35 deaths.
description: Federal District Judge Edward Cahn also ordered the company, which pleaded guilty to 34 charges filed last summer, to provide 500 hours of community service in the case, which involved Selacryn, a blood-pressure drug.

title: A.M.C.'s Profit Falls In Quarter
description: The American Motors Corporation said today that although 1984 was its first profitable year since 1979, its earnings declined 58.1 percent in the fourth quarter.

title: A SUDDEN REVIVAL IN LATIN DEBT FEARS
description: Barely weeks after Latin America's debt crisis showed signs of easing, financial uncertainty has suddenly reappeared in the region, provoked by the problems that several key governments are facing in putting into effect austerity programs.

title: Dupree Surgery Seen
description: Marcus Dupree , the $6 million halfback for the Portland Breakers of the United States Football League, was hospitalized with a serious injury to his left knee that, a team doctor said, will probably require surgery. Team officials said Dupree would be out at least four weeks, and might be lost for the rest of the season.

title: JOHN P. CUNNINGHAM, ADMAN
description: John P. Cunningham, retired chairman of the Cunningham & Walsh advertising agency, died Saturday while on vacation in Christiansted, St. Croix, V.I. He was 87 years old and lived in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

title: Norfolk Plans Divestiture
description: The Norfolk Southern Corporation and two smaller railroads have reached a tentative agreement on a track divestiture plan required under a proposed merger of Norfolk Southern and Conrail, the Transportation Department said today.

title: Comcast to Offer Convertible Issue
description: The Comcast Corporation, which operates cable communications sytems and provides background music services, is offering $40 million of convertible debentures today through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Brothers.

title: TARIFF SNAG IN TALKS WITH JAPAN
description: American negotiators today failed to win agreement with Japan on ending its barriers against imports of forest products. The talks will resume in mid-March.

title: 4 Arrested in Kidnapping Of U.S. Agent in Mexico
description: Four men have been arrested in connection with the abduction of a United States drug enforcement agent, the federal judicial police said today.

title: REAGAN POLICY, MOSCOW-STYLE
description: At last, President Reagan has made it official. As he told the nation last week, he wants the Government of Nicaragua to ''say uncle'' and surrender to the United States-supported guerrillas trying to overthrow it.

title: U.S. JURY REPORTED INVESTIGATING 2 EX-EMPLOYEES OF BOSTON BANK
description: Two recently retired employees of the Bank of Boston are under investigation by a Federal grand jury on suspicion that they may have helped the city's organized crime family launder money through the bank, according to sources familiar with the inquiry.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: Air Express International Corp., Darien, Conn., said it and Consolidated Freightways Inc. had agreed to settle litigation arising from the August 1983 termination of a proposed merger.

title: NEW YORK ;   BREAKING UP THE GANG
description: They're breaking up that old gang

title: Western Plans Toy Unit Bid
description: The Western Publishing Company, a leading producer of games and a publisher of children's books, will soon make an offer of between $400 million and $500 million for the toy operations of General Mills Inc., Richard A. Bernstein, chairman of Western, said yesterday.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the Phillips Petroleum Company, quoting Wall Street sources, erroneously reported an effort to join with Carl C. Icahn to buy Phillips. The Pennzoil Company, cited in the article, denied yesterday that it was talking with Mr. Icahn or considering a hostile takeover of Phillips. A corrective article appears today on page D4.

title: Learjet to Revive Production Line
description: The Gates Learjet Corporation said that it would immediately resume production of its Learjet 30 series because of an increase in its order backlog. The company said that its assembly line for commercial aircraft in Wichita, Kan,. which was closed last fall, would resume production but that the step would only lead to moderate increases in employment.

title: MEESE SWORN IN AT WHITE HOUSE
description: Edwin Meese 3d today assumed the office of Attorney General in a private swearing-in ceremony at the White House, then spent much of the day in briefings with top Justice Department officials.

title: Micron Staff Cuts
description: Micron Technology Inc. said that because of severe price pressure in the dynamic random access memory chip market, it plans to cut in half its current labor force of 1,250. The semiconductor manufacturer also said that it would devote a greater percentage of its resources to its 256K on- chip electronically error-corrected chip.

title: THE SPIRITED ROCKCOR BATTLE
description: For every Carl Icahn and Phillips Petroleum, there are a Rockcor and an N. Norman Muller.

title: NEW WILDERNESS RULES MAY REOPEN DISPUTE
description: New rules issued today by the Interior Department for administering its wilderness areas may reopen the battle of the wilderness between conservation groups and the Reagan Administration.

title: RAY WILLIAMS OBTAINED BY CELTICS
description: Ray Williams, in whom the Knicks invested heavily last season, became a Boston Celtic yesterday. In return for the Knicks' not exercising the 15- day right of first refusal that New York held after the guard signed an offer sheet last Thursday with the Celtics, Boston gave New York its second-round choices in the 1985 and 1986 college drafts.

title: EGYPT PLANS, THEN DELAYS, ENVOY'S TRIP TO ISRAEL
description: Egypt today announced, and then delayed, the sending of a senior envoy to Israel as President Hosni Mubarak's personal representative.

title: ARGENTINE ACTIVIST, AT U.N., DENOUNCES CHILE
description: Adolfo Perez Esquivel, Argentine human rights activist, met today with Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the United States delegate, to express concern about rights violations in Chile and elsewhere in Latin America.

title: Braves' Outfielder Can Join Team
description: Claudell Washington, the Atlanta Braves outfielder arrested Feb. 18 on suspicion of drug possession, today was allowed to travel to Florida for spring training, his attorney said.

title: Bush Reproaches Ethiopians and Russians
description: Vice President Bush bluntly condemned the Ethiopian and Soviet Governments today, saying their response to the famine in Ethiopia was ''shocking.''

title: OTHER SOPHOMORE ON THE METS' STAFF
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.

title: SENATE DEMOCRATS PROPOSE FARM CREDIT PLAN
description: Senate Democrats pressed forward today with their courting of farm state voters as they proposed two amendments that would make it easier for farmers to obtain loans in time for spring planting.

title: METS SEEK PITCHING STABILITY
description: The change startles even the Mets: The opening game of last season was pitched, and lost, by Mike Torrez. Then came six straight victories by Ron Darling, Walt Terrell (twice), Dwight Gooden, Tim Leary and Craig Swan.

title: No Headline
description: TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 26, 1985 International

title: 22 KILLED IN FRENCH MINE BLAST
description: An explosion, possibly caused by escaping gas, ripped through a coal mine near the West German border today, killing 22 men as they worked more than half a mile underground, a mine spokesman said.

title: 500 General Electric Workers Strike at Philadelphia Plants
description: More than 500 workers today struck three General Electric plants.

title: THE VILLAGE VOICE, NEAR 30, CONFRONTS SIGNS OF CHANGE
description: As The Village Voice nears its 30th birthday and wrestles with its impending passage into middle age, its owner, Rupert Murdoch, has been looking for a new editor and considering an offer to buy it.

title: CELTICS' 6TH MAN MOVES UP TO START
description: Following the tradition begun by Frank Ramsey and furthered by John Havlicek, Kevin McHale is the Boston Celtics' sixth man. When a game begins, the square-shouldered, 6-foot-10- inch, 225-pound McHale is on the bench awaiting Coach K. C. Jones's call. It usually comes when the Celtics need more rebounding, shot blocking or rest for one of the front line starters - Cedric Maxwell, Larry Bird or Robert Parish. McHale has done his job so well that he was selected the National Basketball's Association best sixth man last season. He also commands a reported $1 million a year for what he calls ''my job.''

title: VASQUEZ RETURNS AS A WINNER AGAIN
description: Racetrack faces leaned over the rail around Jacinto Vasquez, as if they had popped out of a Dick Tracy comic strip. One face was fat with a cigar in the middle and the words came out in loud splats, ''Welcome back, baby. Baby, baby, you're great.'' A long face with bony shadows and obviously belonging to the owner of a winning ticket, shouted: ''Jacinto, are you as happy as I am now?''

title: TROUBLES GROW FOR S.E.C. AIDES
description: Questions about the future of the Securities and Exchange Commission's enforcement chief were raised today in the wake of a report on his marital and financial problems.

title: MENGELE LINK IN DRUG TRAFFICKING IS REPORTED IN C.I.A. DOCUMENTS
description: The Central Intelligence Agency began receiving reports in 1971 that Dr. Josef Mengele, the Nazi war criminal, was heavily involved with partners in illegal narcotics trafficking in Paraguay, according to declassified Government documents.

title: RESERVOIRS LOW, CITY ANNOUNCES DROUGHT WATCH
description: New York City declared a drought watch yesterday as accumulations of rain and snow remained at levels far below normal in the upstate watershed areas that supply most of the city's drinking water.

title: AROUND THE WORLD
description: A leading African spokesman said today that the continent was ''going through one of the darkest periods of her history'' and was ''looking with anguish toward the future.'' The spokesman, Ide Oumarou of Niger, departing chairman of the Council of Ministers of the Organization of African Unity, cited the spread of internal conflict and the deterioration of Africa's economy as the most alarming trends.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;   A New President Chosen by Boeing
description: The Boeing Company said yesterday that Frank Shrontz had been named president.

title: CASINOS' HOPES IN ATLANTIC CITY
description: Casino hotels are busily expanding in Atlantic City, but this winter has proved disappointing. Occupancy rates were down, in some cases sharply, taking a toll on gambling revenues. Still, the industry and the analysts who follow it express confidence about the rest of the year.

title: Pakistan Calls Atom Program Peaceful, a U.S. Official Says
description: The State Department, responding to reports that Pakistan tried to get timing devices whose main function is to trigger nuclear bombs, said today that the Pakistani Government has given assurances its nuclear program is ''peaceful in intent.''

title: People
description: D. Kyle Felt has been elected an executive vice president of Warwick Advertising.

title: BRITAIN'S MINERS FLOCKING TO WORK
description: Striking miners flocked back to work today in numbers unprecedented since their walkout began almost a year ago.

title: RANGERS POUNDED BY JETS
description: The Rangers hit the three-quarter mark in their schedule last night and simultaneously hit the low point in their season in a humiliating 12-5 loss to the Winnipeg Jets at the Garden.

title: MANY ECONOMISTS HOLD FEDERAL POLICIES HAVE CONTRIBUTED TO FARM CRISIS
description: With the best of intentions, the Federal Government has been trying to help American farmers since the Department of Agriculture was established 123 years ago.

title: KNIGHT'S OUTBURST SCRUTINIZED
description: Last summer, not long after Bob Knight's Olympic experience reached its golden conclusion, C. M. Newton, the staff member who had offered suggestions throughout the grueling process, had one last idea. ''I said, 'This would be a great year for you to take a sabbatical,' '' Newton, the Vanderbilt coach, remembered yesterday. ''They give sabbaticals to professors. Why not basketball coaches? You could give clinics. You could go to Europe. Take a year and get away from it. Do what you want to do.''

title: Let's Let Nicaragua Be Nicaragua
description: To the Editor:

title: University of Vermont Restricts Alcohol Ads
description: As if the alcoholic beverage folks were not having enough problems with their advertising down in Washington, where a growing number of people want to ban such advertsing altogether, up at the University of Vermont new rules have been issued governing on-campus promotion of such drinkables.

title: Cards' Post for Maxvill
description: Dal Maxvill 's lifelong love affair with the St. Louis Cardinals entered a new phase yesterday when the former shortstop was named the team's general manager. ''I've been a Cardinals fan since I was 3,'' Maxvill said.

title: Checkbook Politics
description: Geraldine A. Ferraro, the 1984 Democratic Vice-Presidential candidate, has been drawing criticism from various quarters for her decision to film a Diet Pepsi television commercial that is to be aired next month. But as it turns out, she is not the only political figure to become involved in a commercial advertising campaign this year.

title: Nazi Suspect's Case Delayed
description: Extradition hearings for Andrija Artukovic, accused of being a Nazi war criminal, were postponed today for a second time by a Federal magistrate who said the ailing 85-year-old man was temporarily unfit to understand the proceedings. Magistrate Volney Brown Jr. ordered Mr. Artukovic returned to a naval hospital for another evaluation Wednesday. He has already been judged competent to undergo extradition to Yugoslavia to stand trial on war crime charges, but his ability to sit through the hearings varies day to day.

title: 'President's Park'
description: At budget hearings the other day, Representative Bruce F. Vento, chairman of the Subcommittee on National Parks and Recreation, was surprised to discover that a $2.2 million budget item earmarked for ''President's Park'' in fact had nothing to do with national parks.

title: TELEVISING WARM CALL TO THE COLD
description: Sports events in Florida that reach a national television audience in the dead of winter are a powerful sales tool for tourism. Nothing spurs abrupt calls to the travel agent in Northern states faster than a screen full of professional golfers or tennis players cavorting under the Florida sun.

title: A NEW WAY OF VOTING: YEA OR NAY, THEN SUE
description: When the House of Representatives told Rich McIntyre that he could not serve as Congressman of Indiana's Eighth District until after an electoral investigation was complete, the Republican candidate did what more and more politicians are doing to relieve their frustrations. He filed suit.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''There's simply no justification, for example, for the Federal Government, which is running a deficit, to be borrowing money to be spent by state and local governments, some of which are now running surpluses.''

title: PRESIDENT URGES GOVERNORS ACCEPT CUTS IN U.S. FUNDS
description: President Reagan told the nation's governors today that there was ''no justification'' for Washington to continue aiding state and local governments when some have surpluses and the Federal Government has a deficit.

title: Citicorp Withdraws Bid
description: Citicorp said yesterday that it had withdrawn an application to the Federal Reserve Board to underwrite corporate bonds, commercial paper, mortgage-related securities and municipal revenue bonds. A spokesman for the bank, Susan Weeks, said the application, which was made in December, would be resubmitted ''soon, possibly as early as this week.'' A source close to Citicorp said the application would be modified to clarify terms under which it could conduct the underwriting.

title: Asset Value As a Cushion
description: ''DOING well in a bull market is no trick,'' according to Michael Price. ''Everyone makes money in bull markets. Keeping it and earning 15 percent, plus or minus, in bear markets is what really counts. That is our goal at Mutual Shares.''

title: ST. JOHN'S ASSISTANT KNOWS HIS PLAYERS
description: A day before St. John's was scheduled to meet Syracuse in a much anticipated game in the Carrier Dome, Ron Rutledge watched the Redmen wind down what had been an unusually spirited practice session.

title: UConn Wins
description: Earl Kelley and Ray Broxton each scored 21 points tonight to lead Connecticut to a 74-68 upset of Boston College in the Big East Conference.

title: STOCKMAN THE PLOWMAN
description: David A. Stockman, the budget director, is the latest remote observer to conclude that the ''farm problem'' reduces to the proposition that there are too many farmers. This licenses the further proposition that it is good for agriculture when a lot of farm families go broke and lose their farms. If Wendell Berry, author of ''The Unsettling of America'' and ''The Gift of Good Land,'' is a writer and farmer. Mr. Stockman were speaking for himself, he could be ignored. What matters is that he is representing an attitude that has been dominant in the offices of agriculture since Ezra Taft Benson was Secretary, in the Eisenhower Administration. Mr. Stockman, a key member of an Administration that would abandon farmers to the justice of the market, assures us that the continuing dispossession of thousands of farm families is merely a matter of good economics: ''that is the way a dynamic economy works.'' These ''disinvestments'' Mr. Stockman says, are therefore to be ''encouraged,'' and he suggest that they are compensated for by ''massive explosions of new jobs and investments . . . occurring elsewhere, in Silicon Valley.''

title: The Editorial Notebook;   An Old-Fashioned Death
description: In January, during the week that Dena Kleiman's series of articles, ''Prolonging Life: The New Dilemma,'' appeared in this newspaper, one of my neighbors lay dying.

title: TEACHERS STRIKE IN MISSISSIPPI
description: Teachers in four Mississippi school districts defied a statewide restraining order and went on strike today, protesting a lack of support from Gov. William A. Allain and the Legislature for a raise of $3,500 a year. It was the first strike by teachers in Mississippi history.

title: PENNZOIL DENIES TALKS WITH ICAHN
description: The Pennzoil Company denied yesterday that it was negotiating with Carl C. Icahn, the New York financier, to become involved in trying to take over the Phillips Petroleum Company.

title: TRIAL STARTS FOR A NORWEGIAN DIPLOMAT ACCUSED OF SPYING FOR SOVIET
description: A Norwegian diplomat accused of espionage asserted to the police that he had been blackmailed with photographs taken at an orgy in Moscow, the High Court was told here today by the State Prosecutor on the first day of the diplomat's trial.

title: SHOREHAM RULING IS NOT OVERRULED
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission, meeting in closed session today, decided to take no action on last week's ruling by its appeals board that invalidated a license for the Shoreham nuclear plant to begin low-power testing.

title: ;   How Much Research to Sustain Us in 50 Years?
description: To the Editor:

title: Curfew Is Extended In Western Indian Town
description: A curfew has been extended until Tuesday in the western town of Dig, where 7 people have been killed and more than 200 injured in the last week, the Press Trust of India said today.

title: JERSEY'S WATCHDOG OVER CASINOS: THOMAS ROGERS O'BRIEN
description: When the Casino Control Commission decides Tuesday whether to renew the license of Resorts International, it will be acting on the recommendation of the Attorney General's division of gaming enforcement. And the foundation of the division's recommendation that the license be revoked was built by the director of the division, 46-year-old Thomas R. O'Brien, according to Attorney General Irwin I. Kimmelman.

title: Lincoln in Springfield
description: To the Editor:

title: MSGR. J. H. FITZPATRICK
description: Msgr. James H. Fitzpatrick, senior vice president for the Hospital Association of New York, died of cancer Thursday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan.

title: BLAKE TYLER NEWTON Jr.
description: Blake Tyler Newton Jr., who headed major life insurance industry associations for 18 years, died yesterday at his home in Washington after a long illness. He was 69 years old.

title: GENERALS SEE MORE OF FLUTIE IN FUTURE
description: The Generals' plans on how best to incorporate Doug Flutie into their customary offense were blown away in the opening game Sunday in Birmingham after the Stallions went ahead, 31-7. But it was only then that the Generals began to play well.

title: Keep the Job Corps: It Works
description: The Reagan Administration is a relentless critic of Great Society programs that don't work. Why, then, is it so eager to eliminate the Job Corps, which does?

title: ALL OVER TOWN, CUOMO GRABS FOR THE THUNDER
description: Standing on President Reagan's front lawn today, Governor Cuomo called the President ''intransigent'' for rejecting a budget deal with state officials.

title: SOME GOVERNORS WARN ON FOREIGN INVESTMENT
description: Fearing a technology drain and objecting to what they called a lack of reciprocity, several Western governors expressed concern today over increased foreign investment in the United States.

title: School Bonds Set From Austin, Tex.
description: The Austin, Tex., Independent School District is offering $45 million of bonds with yields ranging from 5.50 percent for maturities in 1986 to 9.50 percent in 2000 through underwriters led by the Interfirst Bank, Dallas.

title: EX-DEFENSE CHIEFS BACK MILITARY REVAMPING
description: Six former Defense Secretaries today called for increased joint control of the nation's military to restrain rivalries among the Army, Navy, Air Force and Marines.

title: POLAND EXPELLING U.S. ARMY ATTACHE
description: Poland ordered the expulsion of a United States military attache today for taking photographs in a restricted military zone, the Government spokesman, Jerzy Urban, announced.

title: ENGINEER WAS 78
description: Dr. John G. Trump, a retired teacher and engineer, died Thursday at his home in Cambridge, Mass., after a long illness. He was 78 years old.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;   State Power Authority In $270 Million Offering
description: A $270 million financing for the New York State Power Authority was tentatively offered yesterday with a maximum yield of 9 7/8 percent for bonds due in 2009, according to underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

title: Ad Pages Up 1.1%
description: The Publishers Information Bureau, a sister organization of the Magazine Publishers Association, reported yesterday that in January its members' publications carried 9,260.54 pages of advertising, an increase of 1.1 percent from the same month last year, while revenues were up 6.1 percent to $283.7 million.

title: ABC, U.S.F.L. DIFFER ON SPRING SEASON
description: Christmas comes but once a year, at least until television figures out how to make it quarterly. Football used to be seasonal, too.

title: French Utility Has Loss
description: The state-owned gas utility, Gaz de France, reported a loss of 3.02 billion francs, or $270 million, in 1984, up from a loss of 2.38 billion francs in 1983, a spokesman said today.

title: Woman Is Arrested After 18 Months on Run
description: The only woman ever on the United States Marshal Service's 15 Most Wanted list was captured after more than 18 months on the run, at a motel where she had been hiding with her two children, the authorities said.

title: G.M. Unit's Stock Posts Decline
description: The class E common stock of General Motors' Electronic Data Systems subsidiary dropped $3.75 yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, closing at $67.75.

title: Overweight Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Comings and Goings
description: Larry Travis , assistant athletic director at Georgia Tech, was named athletic director at Kansas State, replacing

title: CABINET AIDES OUT IN PAKISTAN VOTE
description: Voters dealt an unexpected rebuff to President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq on Monday by turning seven of his Cabinet aides out of office in elections to a new National Assembly, according to returns announced today.

title: SANDINISTA UNVEILS NEW INITIATIVE
description: In a meeting with five visiting Roman Catholic bishops from the United States, President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua tonight unveiled what he described as a major new initiative to reduce tensions with the United States.

title: Syracuse Wins in Rally
description: Rony Seikaly's five straight field goals snapped Syracuse out of a first-half scoring slump as the Orangemen rallied tonight to beat Pittsburgh, 80-72.

title: News Summary;   WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 27, 1985
description: International

title: WESTVACO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
The Heavy-Hearted TO THE LIVING SECTION:
description: Robert Farrar Capon may be a romantic gastronome but his idea of a Valentine's luncheon is the antithesis of an aphrodisiac. After a meal such as that described (''For Romantic Luncheons, Four Easy-to-Cook Recipes,'' Jan. 30), lovers might want a hefty dose of Alka-Seltzer and then a long digestive sleep, alone. Aside from exuding the unromantic aromas of garlic powder, pepperoni, sardines and other assorted seasonings, what well-intentioned, enlightened lover would not feel pangs of heartburn and remorse at having served a fat-laden meal guaranteed to constrict the beloved one's heart, clog his (her) arteries and ruin a svelte figure?

title: FIRST FARWEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $457,000 for the quarter and $756,000 for the year and a tax credit of $250,000 for the quarter and year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $537,000 for the quarter and $1,239,000 for the year

title: The Dollar's Strength Is Really a Sign of Europe's Weakness
description: To the Editor:

title: ZEFFIRELLI IN REHEARSAL IS A ONE-MAN 'TOSCA'
description: The next best thing to seeing ''Tosca'' at the Metropolitan Opera is watching Franco Zeffirelli playing all the parts himself.

title: HAVERTY FURNITURE COS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
There's No Business Like Monkey Business
description: There were no flowers, or sentimental souvenirs when Bernadette Peters left the cast of ''Sunday in the Park With George'' - on Sunday, of course.

title: BRIEFS
BIG, BIGGER, THE BIGGEST
description: In the hoopla and hysteria, tonight's

title: CREDIT MARKETS ;   Bond Prices Rise Modestly
description: Treasury bond prices rose modestly yesterday after six consecutive trading days of falling prices that increased yields about half a percentage point.

title: NELSON RESEARCH & DEVELOPMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $3,622 from the reversal of a tax credit. c-Net income includes tax credits of $178,526 for the quarter and $209,666 for the year. Corrected from Saturday, Feb. 16th editions.

title: Sales Network For Promotion
description: The man who set up the only European network of sales promotion agencies while working for Young & Rubicam is now going to do it again - and for the rest of the world to boot.

title: MUST AMERICA BE UGLY?
description: Budgets - whether family, business or national - always reveal more truth than any finely spoken words. The raw numbers in the 1986 Reagan budget clearly belie the President's made-for-TV rhetoric.

title: BANKAMERICA REALTY INVESORS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $6,895,000 on the sale of investments for the quarter and 6 months. c-Includes a gain on the sale of investments of $876,000.

title: DOWNEY SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $2,131,000. The latest quarter net reflects an additional $1.7 million income tax payment which reduced profit by about 36 cents a share.

title: REUTERS HOLDINGS PLC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $1,500,000. c-After an extraordinary charge of $21,900,000.

title: Consumer Prices Up By 0.2%
description: Consumer prices, reflecting an across-the-board moderation, inched up by two-tenths of a percentage point in January, the Government reported today, buttressing analysts' predictions that 1985 will be a fourth consecutive year of modest inflation.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: -anniversary celebrations the Bloomingdale House of Music is presenting a series of concerts by its 45-member teaching staff. The 500 students are mostly from Manhattan's Upper West Side.

title: Vornado Shares
description: Vornado Inc. said it had repurchased 187,800 of its common shares in unsolicited broker transactions and that its board had authorized the purchase of up to an additional 500,000 shares when market conditions deem it advisable. Before today's transaction there were 3,567,090 shares outstanding. The shares of Vornado, a real estate leasing concern, closed at $40.125 today, down 50 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Pan Am In Accord With Pilots
description: Pan American World Airways announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement with its pilots' union for a new contract.

title: BARBIE TRIAL, DUE THIS YEAR, LIKELY TO BE NARROW IN SCOPE
description: French prosecutors expect to try Klaus Barbie for crimes against humanity by the end of the year, but the case they have developed against the former Gestapo chief of Lyons will not involve the torture and murder of France's greatest Resistance hero.

title: Chicago Alderman Re-elected In a Race Marked by Taping
description: An Alderman supported by Mayor Harold Washington easily won re-election today in a contest marked by the secret taping of an attempt by Mr. Washington to coax a candidate to withdraw from the race.

title: U.S. AGAIN PUNISHES NEW ZEALAND IN PORT DISPUTE
description: Prime Minister David Lange said today that the United States had cut back on sharing intelligence information with New Zealand in the latest retaliation for his Government's refusal to allow nuclear- capable Navy ships in its ports.

title: Paris Shift on Investing
description: The French Government is doubling, to 10 million francs, or about $1 million, the amount that foreign companies will be able to invest in France without needing approval, Finance Minister Pierre Beregovoy said today.

title: AUTHOR WINS APPEAL ON DOCUMENTS
description: An appeals court ruled yesterday that an author need not produce his notes and papers to support the contents of his book. The decision reversed a Federal District Court ruling handed down last December against Antoni Gronowicz, author of ''God's Broker,'' a biography of Pope John Paul II that had been withdrawn from bookstores after its publisher termed it ''fraudulent.''

title: Man Accused of Sex Attacks On Children in His Apartment
description: A 27-year-old former movie usher who offered food and shelter to runaway youths was arrested yesterday on charges of raping one girl and sexually abusing six boys and youths who stayed with him in his Brooklyn apartment, the police said.

title: LIZ CLAIBORNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid Nov. 16, 1984.

title: Islanders Await Return of 'Rock'
description: The one comforting thing for a team that loses a major player to injury is that the teammates can always say, ''Just wait until he gets back.'' The Islanders, to their credit, have made no such alibis this season. But they are waiting and wondering about the effects of Ken Morrow's impending return. ''What he is, is a rock,'' says Kelly Hrudey. ''And right now, we could use a rock.''

title: OPTICAL COATING LABORATORY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $4,055,000, or 69 cents a share, on the sale of an investment. c-Includes a gain of $219,000, or 4 cents a share, from discontinued operations.

title: I.R.S. Calls Protests Defused
description: The Internal Revenue Service said today that it now had the ''tax protest movement'' under control.

title: AUXTON COMPUTER ENTERRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $69,000 for the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: BLESSINGS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $136,400, or 12 cents a share, for the quarter and $837,200, or 77 cents a share, for the year. c-After net from discontinued operations of $1,245,800, or $1.15 a share.

title: S.E.C. ENFORCEMENT CHIEF QUITS, CITING PUBLICITY ON DIVORCE TRIAL
description: John M. Fedders, the head of enforcement at the Securities and Exchange Commission since mid-1981, resigned today amid widespread publicity that he beat his wife.

title: AFTER THESE MESSAGES
description: The first defeated Vice-Presidential candidate to star in a television commercial was William E. Miller.

title: FARM BELT SENDS LOBBYISTS TO CAPITOL
description: Hundreds of lobbyists from the Farm Belt descended on Congress today as the Senate continued to debate two proposals designed to make emergency loans more available to farmers this spring.

title: FASHION BY MAIL ORDER AND CHILDREN'S SPONGES
description: 1.*Accessory Catalogue ''The Siri Vail Collection'' is a mail- order catalogue of accessories by a woman who was formerly director of accessories for Macy's Herald Square. The spring catalogue, her second, includes bags, belts, scarfs, hair ornaments, hats, shoes, hosiery, sunglasses, watches, gloves, jewelry and even some clothing items such as T-shirts and sweaters. Miss Vail believes that accessories are easy to order by mail because size is rarely a problem - and she has a point. But what makes her catalogue really special is her eye for fashion. Thus her jewelry for spring includes long chains and pearls with Maltese crosses, heavy bangles and oversized earrings. Hosiery includes dotted and lace pantyhose as well as colorful anklets, and there is an assortment of silk mufflers in a rainbow of colors. To order the catalogue, which is illustrated with color photographs, send $2 to Siri Vail Collection, 5551 North Long, Chicago, Ill. 60630. 2.*Scrub-a-Dub Fun How to encourage a child to scrub- a-dub-dub: Provide colorful sponges shaped like pigs, teddy bears, frogs, ducks or sea shells. When wet, the sponges expand to double their size and ooze suds scented to go with the color. Red smells like strawberry, orange like orange cream, yellow like lemon, green like spearmint, blue like peppermint, purple like black raspberry and pink like bubblegum. Prisma makes the sponges, which are $3 each at Soap Scents, 245 East 77th Street. 3.*For Heavy Luggage A luggage pull that holds up to 300 pounds has to be one of the most practical things.

title: WAYNE-GOSSARD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and after a loss of $757,578 for the year from discontinued operations.

title: Coast Bank Sets Retail Revamping
description: The Bank of America today announced a major reorganization of its retail banking operations to prepare for deregulated, worldwide competition in financial services and to regain lost market share in its home market in California.

title: Yugoslav Loan Pact
description: The International Monetary Fund has reached agreement with Yugoslavia on a new standby credit of $300 million, a source close to the talks said today.

title: Gromyko Appeals to Italy
description: Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union, who is visiting here, called on Italy today to oppose the space-defense system proposed by the United States.

title: GENERAL PHYSICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
COFFEE GRINDER-BREWER
description: THERE was a time when coffee making at home was a simple affair. One bought a can of ground beans from the grocery, placed some in an aluminum or steel drip pot and poured in hot water. In recent years, coffee cognoscenti have said this is not enough; they maintain that the morning brew is a complex and rewarding beverage that should be chosen and treated with the respect usually reserved for fine wine.

title: JUSTICES BROADEN RIGHTS OF INDIGENT IN INSANITY PLEAS
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that a state must provide an indigent criminal defendant with free psychiatric assistance in preparing an insanity defense if the defendant's sanity at the time of the crime is seriously in question.

title: AUDIT CITRES MISUSE OF CREEDMOOR PATIENTS' FUNDS
description: State auditors charged yesterday that officials at the Creedmoor State Psychiatric Center in Queens had misused $121,000 in patients' money, spending some of it to refurnish part of the hospital so it would pass inspection last year.

title: BLACK CIVIC CLUB WEATHERS A 20-YEAR ECLIPSE
description: Forty years ago, during the era of ''whites only'' theaters and art galleries in much of the nation, Jack and Jill was an elite social club that held teas and cotillions and private film showings for the children of the black middle class.

title: FPA Interest Of 25% Bought An undisclosed investor
description: bought about 25 percent of the

title: SISK IS A MET WITH SOMETHING TO PROVE
description: In a buoyant and almost bubbling training camp, if there is one member of the Mets who has something to prove this spring, it is probably Doug Sisk.

title: GULF BROADCASTING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $2,343,000. c-After income from discontinued operations of $410,000. d-After a loss from discontinued operations of $3,208,000.

title: WRITERS AND PRODUCERS REACH CONTRACT ACCORD
description: Ending years of negotiations and lawsuits, the Dramatists Guild and the League of New York Theaters and Producers announced yesterday new standard contracts for the production of plays and musicals and the settlement of all legal disagreements between the two groups.

title: Sumo Match In the Garden
description: Sumo wrestling, as practiced in Japan, will come to New York for the first time June 14-16, officials of the Japan Sumo Association announced yesterday. The three-day tournament at Madison Square Garden will include about 40 Japanese sumo wrestlers complete with the ritual and music that accompany the 2,000-year- old sport.

title: REAGAN FAMILY-PLANNING AIDE QUITS
description: Marjory E. Mecklenburg, the Federal official who led the Reagan Administration's efforts to reshape the nation's family planning programs, resigned today, according to a spokesman for the Department of Health and Human Services.

title: Paid For by Pravda
description: Some readers of The Washington

title: EMPIRE AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BIG AIRLINES' REGIONAL LINKS
description: When James McManus flew from Syracuse to London recently, he took an Empire Airlines flight directly to one of Pan American World Airways' gates at Kennedy International Airport in New York City and then boarded a Pan Am trans-Atlantic jet just a few hundred yards away.

title: Turkish Cypriot Leader Criticizes Greek Premier
description: The Turkish Cypriot leader, Rauf Denktash, has accused Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou of Greece of bringing about the failure of the United Nations- sponsored negotiations for a settlement of the Cyprus problem last month in order to sustain his claim for continued American arms aid.

title: MAINE UTILITY OMITS QUARTERLY DIVIDEND
description: The Maine Public Service Company, citing continued uncertainties of the Seabrook nuclear plant, said yesterday that it would omit its quarterly dividend that would have been paid April 1.

title: Japanese Agency Holds 5.1% of Ally & Gargano
description: Dai-ichi Kikaku, the Japanese advertising agency, has disclosed in a required Securities and Exchange Commission filing that it owns 5.1 percent of the stock of Ally & Gargano, the outstanding creative agency that went public in December 1983.

title: More Teachers Join Strikes in Mississippi
description: More Mississippi teachers joined wildcat strikes today, forcing an unscheduled holiday for approximately 14,000 children, and decisions tonight by teachers in four more counties to walk out could affect 18,000 more children by Thursday.

title: SITE OF CAFE DES DUEX MAGOTS IS SOLD
description: Rene Mathivat has operated the Cafe des Deux Magots for 20 years. He bought the property today at an auction and declared that the legendary Left Bank haven for writers like Jean- Paul Sartre and Ernest Hemingway would not become a ''fast-food joint.''

title: DOROTHY O. SCHUBART
description: Dorothy Obermayer Schubart, a painter, died at her home yesterday in Manhattan.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Nets vs. Atlanta Hawks , at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 7:35 P.M. Dominique Wilkins, the N.B.A.'s reigning slam-dunk champion, is averaging 30 points in three games against the Nets this season, two won by the Nets. (Television - Sports Channel, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WNBC 660, 7:30 P.M.)

title: AGENCY SAYS DEFICITS WILL TOP REAGAN ESTIMATES
description: The Congressional Budget Office projects that even if Congress approves all the spending cuts proposed by President Reagan, the annual Federal budget deficit will remain around $185 billion for the rest of the decade, according to a report to be made public Wednesday.

title: Macy's Net Rises 3.7% In Quarter
description: R.H. Macy & Company, New York's largest retailer and an operator of department stores in other areas, yesterday reported a 3.7 percent gain in net income for its fiscal second quarter, ended Feb. 2. Net income was $101.1 million, or $1.98 a share, against $97.5 million, or $1.93 a share, the year before.

title: A PLAN FOR CHEAP SEAFOOD
description: After two years of research, scientists at the Smithsonian Institution say that sea farming in tropical waters has enormous potential for producing cheap, plentiful supplies of fish for a hungry world.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;   Bond Sales by 3 States Get a Warm Reception
description: A flurry of bond sales by California, Ohio, and New Mexico totaling $379 million was well received yesterday as securities dealers offered the new bonds with yields that were higher than for similar issues sold last week, when five states came to market with $646.6 million of bonds.

title: East German Film Wins Berlin Festival Award
description: ''The Woman and the Stranger,'' a film about a love triangle during World War I, today became the first East German production to win the Golden Bear, the top award at the Berlin International Film Festival.

title: AMERICAN PRECISION INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
2 Deaths May Be Linked To Measles at College
description: Although tests are incomplete, some health officials believe two students at Principia College may have died of complications from measles in an epidemic at the Christian Science school.

title: Momentary Confusion
description: The story had a tragic ending. But

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: HOW much should you weigh? Are those 5, 10, even 25 extra pounds you're lugging around really damaging your health or just marring your self-image? If you have lived for years on ''the rhythm method of girth control,'' as Dr. Jean Mayer has so aptly put it, does it make any sense to try yet again to lose weight in the hope that this time you will succeed in keeping it off?

title: VARO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income. Share earnings for the latest 9 months include 31 cents a share for a nonrecurring reduction in income tax for the company's domestic international sales corporation.

title: Bridge:New York Players Accuse National League of Sexism
description: A suit was filed in Los Angeles Monday by five New York bridge experts, accusing the American Contract Bridge League of violating their civil rights under California's Unruh Act and asking $1 million in damages.

title: IMMIGRATION ABUSES ALLEGED
description: High-ranking officials of the Immigration and Naturalization Service interfered with investigations into alleged corruption by agents, according to a Justice Department report made public by immigration agency officials today.

title: THE FLAVORS OF VIETNAM RE-CREATED IN AMERICA
description: THERE is a Vietnamese specialty called cha gio, spring rolls of ground pork, crab meat, onion, garlic and seasonings, wrapped in thin rice paper, that I first tasted 20 years ago in Paris. It made such an impression that a few years later I traveled to Saigon to taste it at the source. The trip was more than worth the effort.

title: Taiwan Says Suspect Worked at Spy Agency
description: Taiwan acknowledged today that a local gang leader charged with murdering a Chinese-American writer in California was employed by its military intelligence agency.

title: SPACE AGENCY REACHES AGREEMENT WITH AIR FORCE ON SHUTTLE FLIGHTS
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration, worried about its dwindling launching business, has succeeded in persuading the Air Force to book one-third of all space shuttle flights.

title: ABRAMS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net income The share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid Jan. 4, 1985.

title: VARCO INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Marsh Unit Head Quits The Marsh & McLennan
description: Companies said yesterday that

title: Debt Issues
description: American Express Overseas Credit Corp. is issuing $:30 million of 11 3/8 percent bonds in the Euromarket at a price of 100, through underwriters led by Morgan Grenfell & Co..

title: WANTED: PATRIOTIC SNITCHES
description: Tax dodgers beware!

title: Dollar's Action Abroad
description: Despite its late drop in New York trading, the dollar closed in Europe today at records against the pound, the Italian lira and the French franc, at 13-year highs against the Dutch guilder and West German mark and at a 10-year high against the Swiss franc.

title: THE LATEST IN HEART ATTACK RESEARCH
description: ''MY HEART, YOUR HEART'' is not directed specifically at the middle-aged male; its appeal is broader than that. Still, who will relate most to Jim Lehrer when he describes his heart attack, and then says it wasn't worth it? Mr. Lehrer, stricken last year at age 49, does not hector, but he will make those middle-aged men think. The program will be seen on Channel 13 at 9 tonight.

title: The Amtrak Worth Saving The Reagan Administration wants to eliminate subsidies for Amtrak, which this year totaled $684 million. That is harsh medicine. But in a time of budgetary restraint, subsidies for the little-used intercity rail service have become increasingly hard to defend.
description: Happily, the withdrawal of Federal aid does not have to mean the end of passenger service in the densely traveled corridors where trains are really needed. Indeed, once Amtrak is freed of the political baggage that comes with Government subsidies, it might flourish.

title: S.O.S. From I.C.C.
description: The Interstate Commerce Commission, the center of controversy over deregulation and reregulation of the railroad industry, is expected to notify its 1,000 employees this week that they face a one- day-a-week layoff for 28 weeks starting in April if Congress does not approve a supplemental budget request for $4.8 million. The furloughs would have the effect of a 20 percent pay cut at an agency that has been hit with several rounds of permanent layoffs in recent years.

title: CHICAGO PNEUMATIC TOOL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
description: b-After utilization of certain domestic and foreign operating tax credits of $1,468,000 for the quarter and $2,485,000 for the year. c-After utilization of certain domestic and foreign operating tax credits of $253,000 for the quarter and year. d-After loss from discontinued operations of $26,000. e-Net loss after loss from discontinued operations of $12,468,000.

title: G.M. Saturn Plant
description: The chairman of the General Motors Corporation, Roger Smith, said he expected a decision by May 1 on where the company would locate the plant for its new Saturn auto subsidiary. Mr. Smith said that more than 100 localities had expressed an interest to G.M. in having the plant.

title: CLC OF AMERICAINC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After gains of $622,000 for the quarter and $1,555,000 for the year on the purchase of the company's 6 percent debentures and early extinguishment of certain river transportation debt. c-After income of $1,174,000 representing the reversal of a reserve previously established for the machinery distribution companies, which were sold in February 1984, for the quarter and year. d-After a $718,000 credit from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

description: There are 30,000 skulls in the Smithsonian and T. Dale Stewart Jr. knows them all.

title: TENNESSEE'S PITCH TO JAPAN
description: Nissan. Toshiba. Bridgestone. Sharp. Matsushita. Tabuchi. In these parts, the names of Japanese manufacturers are getting to be as familiar as Jack Daniel's and the Grand Ole Opry.

title: WINE TALK
description: CARE for a little Plum Crazy? I'm afraid it's nonvintage. Or would you rather a sip of Sausalito Sling? We also have Bahama White, Calvin Cooler, Vino Coolada, Cactus Jack and about 50 others. What am I talking about? Why, wine coolers, of course; the hottest new item in the wine and spririts world since Lambrusco burst on the scene almost a decade ago.

title: LONG'S FAREWELL SHAKES POLITICIANS IN LOUISIANA
description: Louisiana politicians were in a state of shock today, a day after learning that the most powerful of their number, Senator Russell B. Long, would not seek re- election.

title: Paper to Close Next Month
description: -SALEM, N.C., Feb. 26 (AP) - The Sentinel will end 99 years as a daily newspaper when it publishes its last issue March 29, the newspaper announced today. Joe Doster, publisher of The Sentinel and its sister paper, The Winston-Salem Journal, said the decision to cease publication of the evening paper was based in part on declining reader interest. Last year its circulation was about 32,000. Mr. Doster said 37 of the company's 422 full-time and 126 part-time workers would lose their jobs.

title: DETREX CHEMICAL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, a front- page article and headline on Monday about a pattern of mortgage defaults incorrectly described the region involved. The defaults have been largely confined to California and the Southwest, although mortgage investors across the country have been affected.

title: Housing Needs More Than Capital
description: To raise decent roofs over the heads of thousands of needy New York families, Governor Cuomo and Mayor Koch have separately proposed a huge new investment of up to $4 billion. The Governor would borrow against the future earnings of the Battery Park City Authority. The Mayor would sell the Port Authority's World Trade Center or ask it for larger payments in lieu of taxes.

description: The war between the merchants in

title: PETROLITE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
COMPARABLE WORTH AMONG DIFFERING JOBS: HOW IT'S FIGURED
description: The head of the United States Civil Rights Commission has called it ''loony.'' The Reagan Administration has warned that it could have disastrous budget implications, and some private employers dismiss it as a crude disruption of free-market mechanisms that will wreak havoc in the workplace. The object of this derision is comparable worth, a theory backed by women's groups as a means of overcoming generations of discrimination in the way salaries are set.

title: Chemical Bank Shift From Product to Image
description: To many of us natives, the phrase ''the neighborhood'' conjures up visions of the more important things in life - such as stickball between parked cars and Johnny-ride-the- pony, both played against a background that frequently included an ''el'' or a much more humble skyline. Life was less four color and more black and white.

title: QUAKER CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings are adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split effective Jan. 30, 1985.

title: GETS SOUTHLAND CASE
description: A jury in Federal District Court in Brooklyn was sequestered last night after failing to reach a verdict in the trial of two Southland Corporation executives charged with conspiring to bribe New York State tax officials to fix sales-tax cases. The cases involved the company's 7-Eleven convenience store chain.

title: Reuters Posts Rise in Profits
description: Reuters Holdings P.L.C., the world news and information organization, today announced pretax profits of $86 million in the year ended last Dec. 31, a 34 percent rise from 1983.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: CONTINENTAL DRIFT. By Russell Banks. 366 pages. Harper & Row. $17.95.

title: BRITISH LAND OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest second quarter and 6 months earnings reflect a gain of $3.7 million on the closing of a transaction involving the 315 Park Avenue South office building here in the city. The year-ago earnings include the sale of a property and a mortgage in the first and second quarters, respectively.

title: PSYCHIATRIST AND FORMER EDUCATOR
description: Dr. Francis J. Braceland, former chief psychiatrist of the Institute of Living, in Hartford, and an international leader in psychiatry, died of heart disease Saturday at Sarasota Memorial Hospital while vacationing in Sarasota, Fla. He was 84 years old and lived in West Hartford, Conn.

title: HALTING OF WORLD CHESS MATCH IS AFFIRMED
description: The president of the International Chess Federation said today that he had turned down a formal request from the world champion, Anatoly Karpov, to reconsider the halting of the championship match with Gary Kasparov.

title: A German Lesson ;   For Every Nation
description: To the Editor:

title: NORTHEAST UTILITIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Court Upholds Wrappers For 'Harmful' Materials
description: The city may require shops that sell sexually explicit magazines, books or recordings considered ''harmful to minors'' to keep the material under wraps, Federal District Judge Harry MacLaughlin ruled Monday.

title: ARMSTRONG HAPPY TO BE NO. 2
description: Mike Armstrong has seen the numbers: $10 million for six years for Bruce Sutter, $7 million for five years for Bill Caudill, $4.3 million for four years for Bob Stanley. Notable money for notable relief pitchers. Armstrong, though, never expects to be such a notable reliever nor to earn such notable money.

title: Howard K. Richmond; Designed Life's Cover
description: Howard K. Richmond, the art director who contributed the distinctive logotype and red background for the cover of Life magazine when the publication started in 1936, died last Friday after a brief illness at his home in Southbury, Conn. He was 85 years old.

title: Treatment for Norris
description: Mike Norris , the Oakland A's pitcher who was arrested and charged with possession of cocaine on Feb. 13, has entered a drug rehabilitation program and has been responding well to treatment, according to his lawyer,

title: DANIEL SCHORR WEIGHS MERITS OF CABLE TV
description: Nine years ago this week, Daniel Schorr, one of the best-known network correspondents in America, was relieved of his duties as a CBS reporter after he passed a House intelligence report to a newspaper. Almost 60 years old, a newsman with a reputation for tough reporting and personal abrasiveness, he was, many said, finished in the broadcast world.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: STEAK au poivre has always struck me as a gastronomic curiosity, for its flavors seem to contradict the accepted rules of seasonings. Preparing a genuine steak au poivre involves what seems to be an unconscionably large amount of coarsely ground pepper. Use a proportionate amount of pepper in almost anything else - a tomato sauce, a soup or casserole, for example - and the dish would almost certainly be written off as a casualty.

title: COMMERCIAL SHEARING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
PLANS OF COSMOS MAY BE STYMIED
description: The Cosmos today announced plans to play 15 to 18 international soccer matches this summer at Giants Stadium, but they may have difficulty getting permission for such games.

title: STAGE: EKKEHARD SCHALL
description: -in-law and a leading actor with the Berliner Ensemble, Ekkehard Schall is a keeper of the family flame. It is evident from his concert performance, ''An Evening with Ekkehard Schall,'' that the flame burns fiercely. In his American debut, the East German actor stresses - sometimes to the point of stridency - Brecht's role as political provocateur.

title: GOVERNORS URGE U.S. BUDGET CURB
description: The nation's governors today urged a slowing of Federal spending, including that for the military and Social Security, after their Democratic majority narrowly failed to make the attack on President Reagan's budget policy even stronger.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We recognized long ago that mere access to the courthouse doors does not by itself assure a proper functioning of the adversary process, and that a criminal trial is fundamentally unfair if the state proceeds against an indigent defendant without making certain that he has access to the raw materials integral to the building of an effective defense.'' - Associate Justice Thurgood Marshall. (A18:1.)

title: ALL SEASONS RESORTS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Girl Testifies at Hearing On Preschool Sex Abuse
description: The first girl to testify in the preliminary hearing on charges of sexual abuse at the McMartin Preschool said today that she had been molested by three teachers and that one of them had stabbed a turtle to show her what would happen to her if she talked about it.

title: Officers Back Sale Of Pantry Pride
description: Pantry Pride Inc.'s management will recommend to its board of directors next week that control of the supermarket and retail company be sold to MacAndrews & Forbes Holdings Inc., a closely held New York- based maker of cigars, chocolate, flavorings and film processing materials. MacAndrews & Forbes already holds 8 percent of Pantry Pride's common shares and has options to buy another 10 percent.

description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information SystemsSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: CURBING MOB CHIEFS
description: For 53 years a secret, seemingly impenetrable group called the commission was what the authorities now call the guiding force behind organized crime in New York and other major cities in the country. Through occasional whispers gleaned by electronic eavesdropping and uncorroborated tips from informants, law-enforcement officials suspected that the leaders of the five traditional crime groups in New York met regularly as the commission to resolve disputes and distribute routinely millions of dollars in criminal spoils.

title: SUSPECT NAMED IN ROAD SLAYING OF A POLICEMAN
description: The search for the killer of the Westchester County police officer who was shot Sunday night after stopping a car for a traffic violation focused today on the former husband of the car's owner.

title: Rates Increase At Citicorp Sale
description: Interest rates rose at Citicorp's regular weekly auction of commercial paper, the bank holding company announced yesterday.

title: DEVILS FALL SHORT WITH 2 IN 3D PERIOD
description: There is frustration and nervousness when two hockey teams with three-game losing streaks meet, as was the case with the Buffalo Sabres and the Devils tonight at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: albeit larcenous - little lady may be in action again. She last appeared in Diary when she made an unexpected dash into a movie theater clutching the $5 bills several under-17 lads had given her to purchase their tickets to an R-rated film.

title: U.S. INDICTMENT SAYS 9 GOVERNED NEW YORK MAFIA
description: A Federal racketeering indictment charged nine men yesterday with participating in a ''commission'' that governs the five organized-crime ''families'' in New York City.

title: Minebea Purchase
description: The Justice Department announced it did not intend to challenge the proposed acquisition of New Hampshire Ball Bearing Inc., based in Peterborough, N.H., by the Minebea Company of Tokyo. J. Paul McGrath, Assistant Attorney General in charge of the antitrust division, said that the department concluded after an extensive investigation that the acquisition did not raise sufficient competitive concerns to warrant an antitrust challenge. The companies reached agreement last summer on a $110 million buyout offer.

title: JERSEY PANEL RENEWS RESORTS CASINO LICENSE
description: After a heated 12-day hearing into bribery allegations, the New Jersey Casino Control Commission voted 3 to 1 today to renew Resorts International's license to operate its Atlantic City casino.

description: The authorities said today that they were prepared to develop the Crossroads squatter camp outside Cape Town as a black residential area, apparently abandoning earlier plans to raze it.

description: The Justice Department's prosecution of defendants arrested in last fall's extensive undercover operation against poaching of trophy animals in the Yellowstone Park area entered its first full day today with the defense contending that the Government had exploited economic difficulties to entrap defendants in illegal hunts.

description: I was looking at a jam jar this morning - a fancy imported one. It contained plum jam, made by Nelson's of Aintree, in England. Good show: Nelson's, like James Keiller & Son of Scotland and Frank Cooper Ltd. of Oxford, puts out a superior product. No chemical tricks in this jam.

title: Zimbabwe Bishop Says Mugabe Backers Killed 5
description: A Zimbabwean opposition leader charged today that five members of his party were dragged from a train Sunday evening and shot dead by supporters of Prime Minister Robert Mugabe.

description: The Koch administration moved yesterday for the appointment of an arbitration panel to set the terms of a new contract with the city's firefighters.

description: When the rent on her beauty salon was increased two years ago from $1,500 to $2,300 a month, Isabel Rodriguez knew there was no way she could bring in enough revenue to cover the new rent.

description: Paul A. Volcker, the Federal Reserve chairman, said today that the dollar's spectacular rise in world currency markets was inhibiting the central bank's conduct of monetary policy.

description: The Reagan Administration, rejecting proposals for delay or compromise, began an high-level lobbying effort today to win a showdown on the MX missile next month.

title: KNICKS BEAT SPURS AS KING SCORES 41
description: The Knicks have been a very dependable team this season in one dubious respect - on most nights, their offense has collapsed, often for several minutes. But last night, against the San Antonio Spurs, the collapse never came.

title: Advertising;   Competing Brands Of TV
description: WHEN advertisers and agencies deal with the video media, said Susan Gianinno, a candidate for a Ph.D. in developmental psychology, they are no longer dealing with a commodity category but rather with one made up of brands that compete for attention and loyalty.

title: AMERICAN MAGNETICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Economic Scene;   The Flight To the Dollar
description: AFTER soaring to record heights this week, the dollar fell back yesterday. But the soaring dollar still promises to reach new altitudes this year. Before falling and later recovering a bit in New York yesterday, it rose abroad to 3.47 against the West German mark, and some traders and analysts think it could climb to 3.6 marks or perhaps all the way up to 4 marks. And the British pound fell as low as $1.04 before rising to $1.06; a buck for a pound seems inconceivable to those who can remember when the pound was worth nearly $5.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;   Norwest Chooses Outsider as Chief
description: Reaching outside its own managerial ranks, the Norwest Corporation announced yesterday that it had elected Lloyd P. Johnson, currently vice chairman of the Security Pacific Corporation, as president and chief executive officer.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a mechanical error, a chronology on Feb. 19, recalling events that led to Gen. William C. Westmoreland's libel suit against CBS, omitted a heading. The heading - 1975 - should have preceded the April 17 reference to Representative Paul N. McCloskey's charge that the military ''deliberately concealed'' the size and nature of the enemy before the Tet offensive. The fall of Saigon (April 30), the article by Sam Adams in Harper's magazine (May) and the House committee's investigation (September-December) should also have appeared under the 1975 heading.

title: MAKING JICAMA A HOUSEHOLD WORD
description: TEN years ago in the produce sections of American supermarkets, exotic meant avocados and Belgian endive. Now the shelves are piled high with pyramids of curious new fruits and vegetables. Brilliant and subtle colors, strange shapes and textures and unfamiliar fragrances beckon the shopper's attention. Carambolas (caram-BOH-las), or star fruit; prickly cactus pears; hot and sweet peppers of all shapes and sizes; arugula; kumquats; passion fruit, and water chestnuts share space with more familiar brussels sprouts, grapefruit and iceberg lettuce. There are fresh button mushrooms and shiitakes as well as wild mushrooms from distant mountain forests, and the kiwi, an exotic fruit of mysterious antipodal origin, has become as common in some areas as the humble apple.

title: Erving Passes Hayes
description: Julius Erving of the Philadelphia 76ers passed Elvin Hayes to become the third-leading scorer in pro basketball history.

title: American Brands Fills Vacant Financial Post
description: American Brands Inc., the tobacco company that is diversifying into consumer goods and financial services, said yesterday that William J. Alley, a former insurance executive, had been named chief financial officer.

title: ...AND AS COMPLICATED AS TRYING TO FIND A TICKET
description: Even without That Sweater, the people have recognized Lou Carnesecca this week - the taxi drivers, the kids, the elite, and not-so-elite- looking. ''I'd think a group of guys want to beat me up,'' said the basketball coach at St. John's University. ''And they'd say, 'Good luck.' ''

title: U.S. OFFICIALS ASSERT MEXICO PLANS TO FREE 3 IN DRUG ABDUCTION
description: The United States Embassy said today that the Mexican authorities are expected to release three suspects they arrested in the kidnapping of a United States narcotics agent.

description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's decision today that indigent defendants are entitled to free psychiatric assistance in preparing an insanity defense.

title: Solidarity Activists Call Off Planned Strike
description: Underground Solidarity leaders and the outlawed union's founder, Lech Walesa, called off a 15-minute national strike today after the Government's decision not to increase food prices.

title: Conoco Lifts U.S. Oil Price
description: The Conoco Inc. subsidiary of E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company said today that it would increase the price paid for crude oil produced in the United States by $1.50 to $2.15 a barrel on March 1.

title: Head of Detroit News Hints at Going Public
description: As president of the 112-year-old Evening News Association, corporate parent of The Detroit News, Peter B. Clark has his hands full.

title: Second Effort
description: His first game after an absence of three and a half years is now behind him, and it offered evidence that Don Reese has made it much of the way back as a professional football player - an astonishing achievement, given the length of his hiatus and the nature of his recent past.

title: ISRAEL BARS BEIRUT-BASED JOURNALISTS FROM ENTERING SOUTH LEBANON
description: The Israeli Army today banned Western journalists based in Beirut from entering territory it controls in southern Lebanon.

title: AYDIN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest year results include a one-time charge of $750,000 in connection with a conversion of the company's domestic international sales company subsidiary to a foreign sales corporation.

title: ARMS NEGOTIATOR URGES PERSISTENCE
description: The Reagan Administration's new chief arms control negotiator said today that the United States and the Soviet Union ''must try to find a formula under which we can live together in dignity'' even though the negotiations were likely to be difficult.

title: ORDERS FOR DURABLES UP BY 3.8%
description: Business orders for durable goods jumped 3.8 percent last month, the Commerce Department said today. Analysts said the report was evidence of strong economic growth in the months ahead.

title: Helicopter Case Report
description: The United States Customs Service had intelligence information that could have prevented the illegal shipments of more than 80 American-made helicopters to North Korea, according to an internal report by Commerce Department officials investigating the shipments.

title: FORBES FAMILY SHARES A LIFETIME OF COLLECTING
description: Malcolm S. Forbes breezed through the Forbes Magazine Galleries the other day for one more preview of the eclectic displays of toys, trophies, American historical autographs, Faberge treasures and Franco-Prussian war paintings that fill the newest of New York's mini-museums. The Forbes Galleries, occupying the main floor of the Forbes Building, 62 Fifth Avenue, at 12th Street, will open to the public today and can be visited free of charge, Tuesday through Saturday, from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M.

title: SALO BARON-ANOTHER DAY'S WORK
description: As he nears his 90th birthday in May, Salo Wittmayer Baron is not yet finished with his life's work.

title: Nights to Forget
description: The latest breathtaking descent in the Rangers' roller-coaster season came Monday night at the Garden. It was a 12-5 battering at the hands of the Winnipeg Jets, and, although the club's records are somewhat incomplete for seasons before 1946-47, it apparently marked the most goals the Rangers had given up at home since a 13-3 loss to the Boston Bruins on Jan. 2, 1944.

title: GIRL IS REVIVED AFTER VAN SINKS IN FRIGID WATERS
description: A 14-year-old Brooklyn girl was in critical condition at Coney Island Hospital yesterday after a van she was riding in plunged into the Mill Basin in the Flatlands section Monday night, killing her four teen-age companions.

The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: Bank of Boston Reiterates Denial on Employees
description: The Bank of Boston said today that it stands by its earlier statement that no one in the bank benefited from its dealings with the city's organized crime family, despite reports that a Federal grand jury is investigating two of the bank's recently retired employees for helping the underworld group launder money.
