description: The Federal Government last month registered the smallest monthly deficit of the fiscal year that started in October, the Treasury reported today.

title: Time for a Change Suffers a Broken Leg
description: Only seconds after completing a brilliant workout that seemed to signal a return to top form, Time for a Change took a bad step and fractured the cannon bone in his left front leg this morning at Hialeah Park. The injury probably means an end to the 4-year- old colt's career, according to Angel Penna, his trainer.

title: Scott & Fetzer Interest Cited
description: An investment group led by the New York arbitrager Ivan F. Boesky stated, in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, that it holds 5.5 percent, or 633,800, of the common shares of the Scott & Fetzer Company, and that 140,000 of those shares were bought between Dec. 28 and Feb. 19. Scott & Fetzer, a Westlake, Ohio, company that markets a variety of consumer products, including World Book encyclopedias and Kirby vacuum cleaners, last year rejected an offer of $60 a share, or $420 million, from the Boesky group.

title: OF WORMS, OWLS AND RED HERRINGS
description: To dig, or not to dig. That is the question.

title: Americans in Mali Crash
description: Two Americans were among the 51 victims in the crash of an Air Mali plane near Timbutku, Mali, last Friday, the United States Embassy said today. The embassy confirmed the deaths of Joseph Jacquellart, a resident of New York state and his wife, who was not an American citizen. Mr. Jacquellart's hometown was not immediately available.

title: DOLLAR PLUNGES IN LATE U.S. TRADING
description: The dollar plummeted yesterday, leaving traders divided over whether its long march upward had stalled.

title: STANDING OUTSIDE THE NEW YORKER AND LOOKING IN
description: WE heard from a friend yesterday that The New Yorker magazine was throwing its 60th annual anniversary bash at the Pierre Hotel. Since the rumor mill has been churning with talk of long faces at the magazine about the possibility that it is being sold to Samuel I. Newhouse, Jr., we thought we'd amble over and politely listen to the party talk.

title: Penalizing the Wrong Students ''No qualified student who wants to go to college should be barred by lack of money.'' That's how Richard Nixon, in a special 1971 message to Congress, stated an important Federal policy: Equal access to education, including the ability of lowincome students to attend elite colleges.
description: President Reagan now proposes a dramatic reversal of that principle. He's right in wanting to cut off people who are profiteering on subsidized loans. But for the most part, his proposals are misguided. They would hurt poor kids by capping Federal aid at $4,000 a year, squeeze a lot of middle-class kids out of the loan programs and mock the Republican notion of an opportunity society.

title: WOMAN GETS HIGH U.N. POST
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar today announced the appointment of Mercedes Pulido de Briceno as Co-ordinator for the Improvement of the Status of Women at the United Nations. The position will carry the title of Assistant Secretary General.

title: A Special Envoy From Egypt Meets Senior Israeli Officials
description: A special envoy representing President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt met with senior Israeli officials in Jerusalem early today, the Israeli radio reported.

title: Dupree Out for Season
description: Marcus Dupree , the highly paid running back who suffered a severe knee injury in the Portland Breakers' opening-game loss to the Arizona Outlaws Sunday, underwent surgery yesterday, and afterward the club said the operation had been successful but that Dupree would be out for the season. For Dupree and the Breakers, who are playing in their third city in three United States Football League seasons, the loss of the star running back was especially upsetting. Dupree, who left Oklahoma early in his sophomore season and signed a five- year, $6 million contract with the Breakers, had just recovered from a series of hamstring injuries that marred his rookie season last year and had continued to bother him during training camp.

title: Interfaith Weddings TO THE LIVING SECTION:
description: Ari Goldman's article (''Interfaith Couples Pick Ways to Wed,'' Feb. 6) names some of the ways in which interfaith couples choose to marry, but omitted one: asking a Unitarian Universalist minister to officiate.

title: PAN AM LOBBY IS UPGRADED IN EFFORT TO RAISE RENTS
description: About 100,000 people, as many as live in Trenton, pass through the cavernous lobby of the Pan Am Building every day as they enter and leave Grand Central Station. They may pause to shake off their umbrellas or buy a newspaper, but most are hardly aware that they have passed from the station into another building.

title: Pressure on Flutie
description: Doug Flutie, the Generals' celebrated new quarterback, said today that the expectations held for him by others outside his team had been excessive and that he felt burdened by them.

title: Vietnam Memorial Pledge
description: With the 10th anniversary of the

title: Market Place;   What Might Mobil Sell?
description: WHEN Rawleigh Warner Jr., chairman and chief executive of the Mobil Corporation, announced last Friday that the oil giant had asked Goldman, Sachs & Company to review all of its business operations, he said the move could possibly result in the sale of some of its businesses. Mr. Warner said then, and a company spokesman repeated yesterday, that no specific subsidiaries had yet been selected.

title: ARTISTS JOIN IN EFFORT FOR FAMINE RELIEF
description: ON March 11, Columbia Records will release ''We Are the World,'' a new song written by Lionel Richie and Michael Jackson and performed by a chorus of 45 pop stars calling themselves USA for Africa (United Support of Artists for Africa). Roughly 90 percent of the proceeds from the single and an album to be released April 1, as well as a full- length video and related merchandizing, will be donated to African famine relief. Another 10 percent will go to fight homelessness and malnutrition in the United States.

title: Town Outlaws Wood Stoves
description: The Town Council Monday night declared a six-month moratorium on new wood stoves and made plans for gradual elimination of existing wood-burning stoves and fireplaces. Officials say the smoke is polluting the air.

title: Careers;   A Squeeze On Middle Managers
description: THE unemployment plight of

title: Fat People Tend to Eat Less Than Others

title: Eagles Talks Ended
description: Ed Snider , owner of the Philadelphia Flyers, said he had abandoned his efforts to buy an interest in the financially troubled Philadelphia Eagles. The announcement came a week after Snider said that he and a group of investors, including

title: 14-MEMBER STAFF IS NAMED IN INVESTIGATION OF CORONER
description: Two lawyers named by Mayor Koch to investigate the New York City Medical Examiner's Office said yesterday that they had appointed a 14-member staff and might conduct public hearings on charges that the office produced misleading autopsy reports in police-custody deaths.

title: DOCTORS SAY HUNGER IS EPIDEMIC IN U.S.
description: Hunger has reached epidemic proportions nationwide, leaving up to 20 million people vulnerable to illness and fear because of economics and ''conscious'' Government policy, a group of doctors and public health experts said today.

title: AQUANAUTICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

title: CONFESSIONS DENIED IN OSLO TRIAL
description: A former Norwegian diplomat accused of spying for the Soviet Union and Iraq asserted today that the confessions disclosed Monday by the State Prosecutor at the opening of his trial here were false.

title: IT'S A SIMPLE AS NO. 1 AGAINST NO. 2...
description: This time there will be no tricky formulas. No debates on whether No. 3 should move up, or No. 2 should move over or No. 1 should slide down.

title: UEBERROTH MAY SEEK OWNERS' RECORDS
description: In a departure from past labor practice, Commissioner Peter Ueberroth told baseball's club owners today that he would order them to ''open their books'' completely to the Players Association if negotiators for both sides thought it ''would be helpful'' in achieving a collective bargaining agreement.

title: LUBRIZOL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Includes a pre-tax gains from non-consolidated companies of $103,000 for the quarter and $3,163,000 for the year. c-After pre-tax losses from non-consolidated companies of $93,000 for the quarter and $3,686,000 for the year, and a pre-tax gain of $10,458,000 for the year on the sale of investments.

title: USE LEVERAGE ON PAKISTAN
description: President Zia ul-Haq of Pakistan desperately hopes that the parliamentary elections held Monday will help legitimize his rule among foreign benefactors - particularly the United States, which provided him with some $620 million in economic and military aid this fiscal year. In fact, he has given only the vaguest assurances that martial law will soon be lifted, and the elections, in which political parties and effective campaigning were banned, are unlikely to move the country toward a significant democratic opening. If anything, they will probably further entrench an unpopular leader who is abandoning the rule of law and using Islam to justify his miltary government.

title: AMERICAN INTEGRITY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said it went public in January 1984.

title: RISE IN DEATHS WITH 3-WHEEL VEHICLES WORRIES SAFETY OFFICIALS
description: Federal consumer safety officials have become concerned over a rapid rise in accidental deaths involving three-wheel recreational vehicles.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A table in Business Day on Friday with an article about the gross national product omitted the percentage increases for two measures of inflation in the fourth quarter of 1984. The fixed-weighted price deflator rose 3.4 percent; the implicit price deflator rose 2.8 percent.

description: Latest quarter is 14 weeks compared with 13 weeks for the year-ago quarter. The latest 6 months is 27 weeks compared with 26 weeks for the year-ago 6 months.

description: Despite steady improvement the last four seasons, Loyola University basketball has played second fiddle in Chicago to DePaul.

description: b-After a loss of $54,000 from discontinued operations. c-After a gain from discontinued operations of $794,000.

title: FRANCE IS WARMING TO 'STAR WARS' IDEA
description: Foreign Minister Roland Dumas of France described the space-based defense plan of the United States today as having ''seductive elements'' for public opinion because, he said, it replaces an offensive nuclear strategy with a defensive one.

title: LIFE IN THE SPOTLIGHT: AGONY OF GETTING BURNED
description: One of the most vexing, recurring problems for official Washington, and for the national press, is how to deal with reports of private misdeeds or failings of public officials.

title: TINA TURNER CAPTURES THREE GRAMMY AWARDS
description: Tina Turner won three Grammys tonight, including record of the year, and her hit ''What's Love Got to Do With It'' picked up another as song of the year.

title: Local Costs Rose 0.1% In January
description: The Consumer Price Index for New York and northeastern New Jersey increased by one-tenth of a percentage point in January, continuing a steady rate of increase that has characterized it since last September, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: Skybus Relocation Plan
description: Skybus Inc., which recently bought Denver- based Frontier Horizon Airlines, has proposed to move its headquarters to Atlanta and to offer nonstop service from Atlanta to six cities.

title: B&B Direct Changes Its Name to Direct Inc.
description: To encourage the appearance of independence, B&B Direct, the direct marketing subsidiary of Benton & Bowles, has changed its name to Direct Inc.

description: Albert Larman, 48 years old and with credentials that could stretch from Chicago to St. Louis, has taken that route himself to become vice chairman and creative director of the office there of D'Arcy MacManus Masius.

title: A RECORD NUMBER OF DONORS CONTIRBUTE TO NEEDIEST CASES
description: The 73d annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund will end tomorrow with a record number of donors - more than 13,400 - contributing more than $2,445,000 to help New York City's distressed and impoverished residents.

O'NEILL TURNS AGAINST REAGAN
description: House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. today attacked President Reagan's latest statements on Nicaragua, accusing him of going back on his word that the United States does not impose its will on other countries by force.

description: b-After a tax credit of $669,000. The share earnings reflect 2-for-1 stock split paid Feb. 1.

description: The City Council approved a resolution today urging a halt to construction on the Presidential Parkway, the controversial road planned to serve Jimmy Carter's Presidential library.

description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $2,114,000 for the quarter and $1,796,000 for the year.

title: Dow Rises 8.61 in Broad Rally
description: A rally late yesterday lifted stocks broadly, and the Dow Jones industrial average ended with a 8.61 gain, at 1,286.11.

description: The company is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges.

description: A new magazine called ''American Heritage of Invention and Technology'' will be published three times a year beginning in May by American Heritage, the magazine announced.

description: To the Editor:

title: European Fog Causes Chain-Reaction Crashes
description: Heavy fog obscured highways in Belgium, the Netherlands and West Germany today, and the police said about 375 cars and trucks piled up in several separate accidents.

title: Transfers to Continue For Gifted Youngsters
description: After a long dispute, Community School Board 2 in Manhattan has voted to continue for at least a year to let parents send gifted children and their siblings to special programs at schools outside their neighborhood, particularly to Public School 6.

Share earnings figures represent earnings per American Depositary Share (ADS) which is equivalent to 10 shares of common stock.

title: UNUSUAL WINNER IN FILMS
description: The simple dress and shy manner of Rainer Simon - director of the East German film ''The Woman and the Stranger,'' which received the highest award at West Berlin's International Film Festival yesterday - appeared in sharp contrast to the self-conscious glitter of most festival participants. But his wiry gray hair, thick black glasses and intense gaze gave the 44-year-old director an eccentric look not often seen on the streets of East Berlin - the look, perhaps, of an East German Woody Allen. ''Others have said that,'' he conceded, smiling and obviously pleased with the comparison.

title: SANTA ANITA COS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Grumman Order
description: The Grumman Aerospace Corporation, a subsidiary of the Grumman Corporation, won a $109.1 million Navy contract for full-scale development of F-14A aircraft avionics and radar, and the reconfiguring of F-14A engines to other specifications, the Defense Department said.

title: Greek Tanker Strafed in Gulf
description: Three Iranian warplanes strafed a Greek supertanker today off Qatar, salvage executives reported. The brief attack may have been a mistake, shipping agents said, because the vessel was reportedly bound for the Iranian terminal at Kharg Island to load crude oil.

title: U.S. PREMIERE FOR HYMN TO STATUE OF LIBERTY

Volcker Urges Return of Equilibrium
description: The Federal Reserve's chairman, Paul A. Volcker, appearing increasingly worried about the strong dollar, outlined today a series of steps that the United States and other industrial countries could take to help restore ''competitive equilibrium'' in trade and currencies.

description: To the Editor:

title: HENRY CABOT LODGE, 82, IS DEAD
description: Henry Cabot Lodge, the articulate Massachussetts Republican who was United States delegate to the United Nations, Ambassador to South Vietnam and a three-term Senator, died yesterday at his home in Beverly, Mass., after a long illness. He was 82 years old.

description: St. John's 19-game undefeated streak, and probably its five-week reign as the nation's top-ranked team, came to a crushing end last night as second-ranked Georgetown defeated the Redmen, 85-69, before 19,591 at Madison Square Garden.

B. Trudeau, and the playwright Ernest Thompson, among several other familiar contemporary writers.

description: It was an off night at Bennett's bar at the Jefferson Hotel and Sydney Lehman wasn't where she usually is - at the piano.

Union Camp's board immediately elected Raymond E. Cartledge, 55, president and chief operating officer, to succeed Mr. McLaughlin.

title: DEMOCRACY ELUDES THE MAURITANIANS
description: The military officer who took power in a coup in December says Mauritanians must first be educated before the country can be turned over to democracy.

title: INDIAN RELOCATION PLAN HAS TROUBLES
description: Ten years ago Congress tried to solve a century-old dispute between the Hopi and Navajo Indians by dividing up 1.8 million acres they once shared in the high desert of northeast Arizona. Those on the wrong side of the line, 12,000 Navajos and 75 Hopis, had to move.

title: Like Like It's time to rescue ''like.''
description: Not the teen-age, you know, like word, that teachers so dislike, used like ''uh'' as an empty filler. Not as an ungrammatical conjunction, as in ''Winston tastes good, like a cigarette should.'' The word now in distress is the preposition ''like,'' as in ''Some supposed dangers fade quickly, like the missile gap or the window of vulnerability.'' This clear, simple usage is fading quickly too, the victim of banishment by fearful writers.

title: ART OF KABUKI MAKEUP: THE ACTOR'S THE CANVAS
description: The actor painted his face mime-white, covering his eyes as well his mouth. He sponged the surface dry, then, with a tiny brush he inked in his eyebrows and lips. Dipping a brush and his fingers into black and red - the only colors he used - he created violent expressions for himself, swirls that radiated from his nose to his forehead. With every stroke, the actor's face became darker and more menacing.

title: Building Up 2% in January
description: Contracting for new construction increased by 2 percent in January, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $215.1 billion, it was reported today by theF.W. Dodge division of the McGraw- Hill Information Systems Company.

description: After five years of steady growth, the Washington Opera today announced a sharp cutback in productions for the 1985-86 season.

description: The three movies that make up George Lucas's ''Star Wars'' trilogy - ''Star Wars,'' ''The Empire Strikes Back'' and ''Return of the Jedi'' - will be shown together at movie theaters for the first time March 28. The one-time- only showing in eight cities is part of an effort to promote the reissue of ''Return of the Jedi.''

description: The Uniformed Firefighters Association will be joining a bargaining coalition of unions representing other uniformed employees in an effort to negotiate new contracts with the city, the chairman of the coalition, Philip Caruso, said yesterday.

There were 12 weeks in the latest quarter and 52 weeks in latest year, compared with 13 weeks and 53 weeks for the year-earlier quarter and year, respectively.

title: STATE DEPT. BUREAU IS INSTRUCTED NOT TO SPEAK TO A TIMES REPORTER
description: The director of the State Department's Bureau of Politico-Military Affairs has ordered his staff not to talk to a New York Times correspondent, Leslie H. Gelb, who wrote that the United States had contingency plans for placing nuclear weapons in Canada, Iceland, Bermuda and Puerto Rico.

title: A NERVOUS DAY IN CURRENCY PITS
description: When the opening bell sounded this morning, telephones to the foreign currency traders here at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange were ringing off their hooks, with investors rushing to place orders.

description: ''What we have to agree is to negotiations in Cairo under the hospitality of the Egyptian President, with American participation, and with a Jordanian-Palestinian delegation without the P.L.O. - without declared members of the P.L.O. - and an Israeli delegation - and let's move ahead.'' - Prime Minister Shimon Peres of Israel. (A1:2.)

title: 3-State House Vote On Aid to Farmers
description: Following are the positions of representatives from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut when the House today approved a proposal to provide emergency aid to farmers. A ''yes'' represents a vote in favor of the proposal and a ''no'' represents a vote against it; ''xxx'' means not voting.

title: NEW CALEDONIAN RIGHTISTS DEFY FRENCH AUTHORITY
description: France, which has been trying to settle ethnic tensions in the Pacific territory of New Caledonia, has in the last few days faced a clear movement of defiance to its authority from anti-independence forces on the island.

title: Dr.Work on Nietzsche
description: Dr. Rose Pfeffer, a professor of philosophy who was an authority on Friedrich Nietzsche, the German philosopher, died of a heart attack yesterday at her home in Manhattan. She was 76 years old.

title: CHRONAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SCIENCE MEDALS AWARDED TO 19
description: President Reagan presented 19 National Medals of Science today, telling those honored that they had made ''an outstanding contribution to our way of life and our future.''

title: PERES TELLS AN ENVOY OF MUBARAK ISRAEL BACKS CALL FOR DIRECT TALKS
description: Prime Minister Shimon Peres told Egyptian envoys here today that Israel supported President Hosni Mubarak's call for direct talks between Israel and a delegation of Jordanians and Palestinians, Government officials said.

title: U.S. Will Not Prosecute Youths in Computer Tap
description: Four teen-agers who used home computers to tap into a space agency computer at the Marshall Space Flight Center will not be prosecuted, United States Attorney Frank Donaldson announced today.

title: DETSCO INC reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Activist Takes Own Life
description: A 73- year-old founding member of the Association for the Right to Die with Dignity, Marguerite Liegeois, killed herself last week after having sent a letter to the association's members explaining she was in declining health and ''the only way to a dignified and upright death is to voluntarily interrupt life,'' the association said today. It did not disclose the manner of suicide.

title: Navy Plans Shipyard Layoffs
description: The Navy has frozen the work force at its eight shipyards and plans to reduce it by 5,100 people by the end of the year to save money, the service said today.

title: 3 Gang Leaders Indicted By Taiwan in Murder
description: Three gang leaders were indicted today on charges of killing a Chinese- American writer in California.

title: DR. FARROW R. ALLEN
description: Dr. Farrow R. Allen, former associate director of surgery at Sydenham Hospital, died of a heart attack Friday at his home in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. He was 87 years old.

title: REALISTIC CERAMICS
description: THEY may not be new, but they're somehow more irresistible than ever.

title: NEW YORK TELEPHONE RATE OVERHAUL
description: The New York Telephone Company is expected to propose a sweeping overhaul of its rate system today. Under the plan, rural New Yorkers would bear more of the cost of local telephone service, city dwellers would bear less, and businesses would no longer subsidize residences through high long-distance rates.

title: 'I TOLD PATRICK'
description: During the Olympics in Los Angeles last summer, one of Bill Wennington's friends at St. John's visited the 7-foot center, who was playing for Canada's team.

title: INDUCING SELF-RELIANCE IN EGYPT
description: Egypt's request for a $1 billion increase in American economic and military aid next year obliges Washington to re-examine its ties with Cairo before President Hosni Mubarak visits in March.

title: Long and the Lobbyists
description: ''Dear Friend,'' began a political fund-raising letter sent out last Friday by a group of Washington tax lobbyists. ''The Senator is up for re-election in 1986.

description: b-Net loss

MONDALE SAYS HE WAS TIRED, NOT DEPRESSED, BY CAMPAIGN
description: Walter F. Mondale, in his first extended interview since his landslide defeat by President Reagan last fall, said it took ''a long time to adjust'' after a campaign that left him ''bone tired.''

title: Dow Falls 5.08 as Volume Contracts
description: Stock prices fell yesterday, hurt by a decline in bond prices reflecting further weakening of the dollar.

title: E.E.C. Curbs On Canada
description: The European Economic Community has drawn up a list of special retaliatory tariffs on Canadian exports in the latest stage of a mounting trade dispute over European beef and footwear, community officials said today.

title: SEAT-BELT LAW IN JERSEY TAKES EFFECT TOMORROW
description: New Jersey on Friday becomes the second state in the country, after New York, to require people riding in the front seats of cars to wear seat belts.

title: Roemer Film Showing
description: ''Nothing but a Man,'' a 1963 movie directed by Michael Roemer, will be shown tonight at 7 o'clock as part of the Studio Museum in Harlem/Davis Center for the Arts Festival, at Aaron Davis Hall on the City College campus, at 138th Street and Convent Avenue.

title: U.S. GENERAL SAYS NICARAGUA REBELS CANNOT WIN SOON
description: The retiring commander of American military forces in Central America said today that the Nicaraguan rebels were incapable of overthrowing the Sandinista Government in ''the foreseeable future'' regardless of whether they received American aid.

title: Sicilian Slain by Mafia
description: Mafia gunmen today shot and killed a businessman, Pietro Patti, and wounded his 9-year-old daughter, the police said.

title: Top-Rated Bonds From Missouri
description: A $95 million issue of Missouri general obligation bonds was offered yesterday with yields ranging from 5.25 percent for bonds due in 1986 to 7.20 percent in 1990, 8.30 percent in 1995 and 9.30 percent in 2010, through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: SUPREME COURT UPHOLDS E.P.A. ON CLEAN WATER EXEMPTIONS
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that the Environmental Protection Agency may, under some circumstances, exempt individual industrial plants from full compliance with nationwide limits on toxic discharges into sewage treatment facilities.

title: ITALIAN ASKS FOR DIALOGUE ON 'STAR WARS'
description: Prime Minister Bettino Craxi says the success of arms negotiations in Geneva could depend on the willingness of the United States to show sensitivity to Soviet ''preoccupations'' over President Reagan's proposed space defense system.

title: 2 SYRIAN HIJACKERS SURRENDER
description: Two Syrians being deported from West Germany hijacked a Lufthansa airliner today and forced it to land here. Agents posing as a reporter and a lawyer persuaded the pair to surrender after a five-hour standoff, authorities said.

title: PHH GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
GTI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Kellogg Expansion
description: The Kellogg Company said it would invest $100 million to expand the production capacities of its main breakfast cereal plant. Construction is to begin this summer. The project represents the largest single capital investment in the facility's 79- year history.

title: STATES DEBATE REQUIRING USE OF BELTS
description: The decision by Transportation Secretary Elizabeth Hanford Dole to seek state laws requiring the use of seat belts has touched off one of the strongest lobbying efforts ever seen in statehouses around the country.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
Order for Pneumo
description: IC Industries' Pneumo Corporation subsidiary said that it had received a $162 million order from the General Dynamics Corporation for production of flight control actuators for the F-16 fighter aircraft. title: PHILADELPHIA SHOW: A FLOWERY CLASSIC
description: PHILADELPHIA ng of t SOMETIME late Friday night, the mud should be hosed from the five acres of floor, the bulldozers and forklifts should disappear and the final flowers should be in place. By 8 Saturday morning, 160 horticultural judges will have arrived at the annual spring rite of the Philadelphia Flower Show. The show, first held in 1829, will open to the public Sunday and will run through March 10 at the Civic Center, near the University of Pennsylvania campus. There will be more than 50 displays by nurseries, florists, plant societies and garden clubs, along with nearly 600 competitive horticultural classes and 83 trade booths. The sponsor is the Pennsylvania Horticultural Society, which says this is the largest indoor flower show in the world. The theme is "A Touch of Britain - Our Garden Heritage," a reference to the Royal Horticultural Society's Chelsea Flower Show in London, the closest world-class competitor to the Philadelphia show. While both shows attract many visitors - last year the Philadelphia had 230,000 and the Chelsea 240,000 - the two have one major difference: in Philadelphia, almost all the plants must be forced, while at Chelsea, which is held in May, spring species are in bloom naturally. "To exhibit in March, most nurserymen must force twice as many plants as are needed to insure a good selection," said Jane Pepper, president of the society and manager of the show. A sense of sharing seems to permeate this year's event: two distinguished British guests, the gardener and author Rosemary Verey and the flower arranger Sheila MacQueen, have been invited to serve as judges and speakers. Also on hand from England is Geoffrey Ace, who heads the landscape construction department of the Merrist Wood Agricultural College in Worplesdon, Surrey, England. The college's exhibits have won six consecutive gold medals at Chelsea and have so impressed Ed Lindemann, designer of the Philadelphia Flower Show, that he arranged for Mr. Ace and four students to participate in the show. For months, the Merrist Wood group has planned its exhibit, working by mail and telephone with its counterparts at Mr. Lindemann's alma mater, the Delaware Valley College of Science and Agriculture in Doylestown, Pa. This week, under Mr. Ace's guidance, students from both schools were laying a precise stone edge for the undulating bed of thyme, artemisia, candytuft, columbine and the other plants. At the foot of the Civic Center's central escalator, the Philadelphia society's display is being created in association with Gale Nurseries of Gwynedd, Pa. Charles Gale Sr., the owner, said the exhibit will include a boxwood knot garden and a parterre of ageratum and begonias, as well as an arborvitae hedgerow framing a formal rose garden. Mr. Gale is also very proud of his use of what he calls "the classic British gardening trick" of interplanting clematis and climbing roses. No British-inspired flower show would be complete without quaint cottages. Rose Valley Nurseries of Media, Pa., is working on a thatched- roof model. The "thatch" is hay, since according to the nursery's owner, Wayne Norton, "the half-acre of reed required for a thatched roof is nearly as hard to find here as it is in England." Gardeners might spend an extra moment at this display, because rather than the classic cottage garden of flowering perennials, Mr. Norton is planting ornamental grasses, sedges, rushes and reeds. Meadowbrook Farm of Meadowbrook, Pa., will execute a series of dooryard gardens with whimsical potted topiaries of ficus and ivy, but the most naturalistic garden will be that of Vick's Wildgardens of Gladwyne, Pa., which will include a running stream and some 35 tons of rock. When asked how his design fit in with the show's theme, Albert Vick Jr. answered spiritedly: "There's no relation to the theme. My display is a touch of America, with flora that is native to this part of the country." The Philadelphia Civic Center is at 34th Street and Civic Center Boulevard. Tickets are $6.50 for adults, $3.25 for children under 12. Hours are 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. Sundays, 10 A.M. to 9:30 P.M. Monday through Saturday. The Civic Center is a 15- to 20-minute walk from the 30th Street Amtrak station; during the show, shuttle buses will operate every 15 minutes, at 85 cents a ride in exact change. - GARDENING

MUSIC: GUARNERI QUARTET AND PETER SERKIN, PIANO
description: THE divorce rate in string quartets, as in other intimate unions, is distressingly high. After all, even marriage partners do not dare to shut themselves up in small rooms for hours at a stretch and argue out such life-and- death details as whether Haydn wanted his trills to begin on the principal or the auxilliary note. A husband and wife can get along quite amicably even if they disagree about the necessity to slavishly follow Beethoven's metronome markings. But such tensions and thousands more like them must be thrashed out daily by string quartets. Detente may be possible over the short run, but eventually some member will stand up, snap his instrument case shut and declare his independence. He or she has always wanted a solo career, anyway, and now is the time to go for it.

title: FILM: AUSTRALIAN 'CLINIC'
description: NO listing of the all-time great comic premises will ever mention ''The Clinic,'' an Australian film about the antics of doctors, nurses, counselors and patients at a venereal-disease clinic. There's only one way such a story idea can have found its way to the screen: through a screenwriter, Greg Millin, who worked in a similar establishment in Sydney long enough to start thinking the place was funny. Apparently no profession is beyond the screenwriter's purview these days, however much it ought to be. A comedy about ditch-digging by an ex- ditchdigger might make a worse idea, but not by much.

title: Warrant Issued InKillingofOfficer
description: Westchester investigators seeking the killer of a county police officer say they have a warrant for the arrest of a suspect, Alex J. Mengel, a former security guard.

title: Debt Issues
description: First Boston Corp. is privately placing 72.5 million francs of 6 1/8 percent subordinated notes priced at 100 on the Swiss capital market, through Credit Suisse. The notes are due in seven years nine months.

title: TELEPICTURES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SCHROEDER FOUND TOO WEAK TO LEAVE
description: William J. Schroeder is too weak to be discharged from the hospital this week as planned and is still suffering from ''periods of disorientation,'' his doctors said tonight.

title: BOOKBINDER'S FETE STIRS MEMORIES
description: It happens all the time. A group of diners decides to go for lobster or clams or oysters at Bookbinder's, the famous old seafood restaurant that for some devotees is almost as much a Philadelphia landmark as Independence Hall.

title: ROCK: STING IN CONCERT
description: WITH a new band and a handful of new songs, Sting offered the first glimpse of his latest project in three sold-out shows this week at the Ritz. The crowds came to hear (and sing along with) Sting's songs from the multimillion-selling records he has made with the Police; he obliged, while also testing the material for an album due this summer.

title: Changes At Marsh Questioned
description: Bruce W. Schnitzer's resignation as president of the Marsh & McLennan Companies' principal subsidiary provoked widespread speculation in insurance circles yesterday on the reason for the move. But Mr. Schnitzer said, ''It's not really terribly complicated.''

title: HARDLY INDIAN HISTORY
description: Perhaps it's churlish to examine the philosophy of a man who offers to put up $70 million to rescue the Museum of the American Indian, even if he conditions his gift on moving the great collection from New York City to Dallas. But what leaves one agape is H. Ross Perot's declaration that a museum devoted to the Native American experience in the United States is a valuable way to illustrate that ''man has made remarkable adaptations to changing conditions.''

title: Preserving History
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: BIG V SUPERMARKETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PAR TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Transactions
description: TUESDAY BASEBALL

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Metropolitan Report on Monday about a series of Lenten sermons on the homeless, scheduled by the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, misidentified the founder of Women in Need. She is Rita Zimmer.

title: Datapoint Suit
description: The Datapoint Corporation said it had filed suit in United States District Court and a state court charging that the investor Asher B. Edelman has violated antitrust law in his attempt to replace the Datapoint board. The suit claims that Mr. Edelman's group would create interlocking directorates with two other companies: the Mohawk Data Sciences Corporation and Management Assistance Inc. Datapoint said that it competed with both in the computer equipment market.

title: Key Rates
description: * Kenny Index, Kenny Information SystemsSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: RENT-A-CENTER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: The company said 1984 second quarter and 6 months results have been restated to reflect the acquisition of the limited partnership interest in 22 limited partnerships acquired Nov. 28, 1983.

title: William Charles Oursler, 71; An Author and Commentator
description: Will Oursler, an author, lecturer and radio commentator who wrote frequently on religious and inspirational subjects, died Jan. 7 at a nursing home in New York City after a long illness. He was 71 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: PAUL HARRIS STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 2
WALBAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for the 1983 year include a gain of $391,000 from the settlement of a litigation.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES ;   Utah Utilities Offering $80 Million Bond Issue
description: The Utah Municipal Power Association, comprising 21 municipal-owned utilities in the state, is offering $80 million of revenue bonds through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Times Co. To Buy Paper
description: The New York Times Company announced an agreement in principle yesterday to acquire The Santa Rosa Press-Democrat, a Sonoma County, Calif., morning daily newspaper with a circulation of 73,000 copies on weekdays and 81,000 copies on Sundays. The acquisition is the Times Company's first on the West Coast.

title: WHAT COUNTRY IS IT?
description: BOSTON It could happen at Moscow airport.

title: A Bad Memory Returns to Mets
description: The news crept in on cat's feet. Down near the bottom of the page that newspapers devote to sports statistics, under the ''Transactions'' heading, this listing appeared yesterday:

title: HOOPER HOMES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $328,477.

title: STEVENS, J P CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 2
description: b-After a charge of $4,700,000 for costs of restructuring certain operations.

title: Sound Advice
description: It was a terrific season for Walter Payton, and when it was over he had extended his career rushing total to 13,309 yards - 997 more than Jim Brown's old National Football League record. But a sure place in N.F.L. history has not been enough to alter Payton's perspective about the league he plays for, or the reasons for playing at all.

title: MAGNETIC HEAD CORP reports earnings for Year to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: KDI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FLAKEY JAKE'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The prior year figures include the period from March 3, 1983, the company's date of inception, to Jan. 1, 1984.

title: FROM A PEKING HOTEL RESIDENCE, VIEWS OF A CHANGING CHINA
description: DURING the two and a half years that I lived in Peking, I read from time to time a memoir of life in the Chinese capital in the 1930's - a book that never failed to make me feel I had been born too late.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: Under this heading, The Times amplifies articles or rectifies what the editors consider significant lapses of fairness, balance or perspective.

title: PACKAGING SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Lilco Seeks 3.8% Rise In Electric Rates in '86
description: The Long Island Lighting Company today asked the State Public Service Commission to approve a 3.8 percent increase in electric rates next January.

title: COMPLIANCE WITH SEAT-BELT LAW, OFTEN GRUDGING, REPORTED UP IN STATE
description: Since Jan. 1, about 3,000 citations have been issued to motorists for failing to buckle up under New York's new mandatory seat-belt law.

title: FUELS PROGRAM IS 'A WASTE,' STOCKMAN TELLS BUDGET PANEL
description: David A. Stockman, the Federal budget director, said today that the synthetic fuels program was a ''waste'' but that the Reagan Administration was not proposing to eliminate it because of a compromise last year in the Senate.

title: Delay for Minebea
description: New Hampshire Ball Bearings Inc. said the proposed acquisition by the Minebea Company, of Japan, previously scheduled to be completed at a shareholders meeting Thursday, had been indefinitely delayed after a review by Japanese authorities. A spokesman said she did not know how long completion of the transaction would be delayed.

title: SEVEN OAKS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
No Headline
description: THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 28, 1985 International

title: Islanders Lose, 3-1
description: Lanny McDonald scored two goals 30 seconds apart in the final 37 seconds and assisted on another tonight to give the Calgary Flames to a 3-1 victory over the Islanders.

title: Mets Set Chain of Command
description: The Mets staged their first full workout of spring training today, with more stars on the field and more fans on the sidelines than at any time in recent years. And, from the opening speech by the manager, they went to great lengths to deny that they were headed for a fatal collision of egos.

title: Research on Nerve Gas Suspended in Cambridge
description: Nerve gas research was suspended today at the laboratories of Arthur D. Little Inc., a day after a judge upheld a ban on testing chemical warfare agents in this densely populated city.

title: GOETZ SPOKE TO ONE YOUTH, THEN SHOT AGAIN, POLICE SAY
description: After shooting at four young men on a Manhattan subway train last December, Bernhard H. Goetz said to one of them, ''You don't look so bad, here's another,'' and shot at him again, according to a police report made public yesterday.

title: EDDIE ZIGO ON MOVIE SET RELIVES SON OF SAM CASE
description: The scene called for Martin Sheen to search a car he suspected of belonging to Son of Sam, the killer who terrorized New York City in 1977. In his role as a police detective, Mr. Sheen strode up to the car, reached out as anyone might normally do, and opened the door.

title: Alford Backs Knight
description: Bobby Knight's temper tantrums might be unseemly, but according to

title: SOUTHLAND ENERGY reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After a pre-tax gain of $500,000 on the sale of an investment. c-After a loss of $1,397,000 on the sale of an investment.

title: ESTERLINE CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $326,000. The year-ago first quarter revenue restated for discontinued operations.

title: Tailor and Lyricist Among Undefeated
description: Most boxers would rather fight than work. There are exceptions. The work ethic is probably best personified by Larry Holmes and Marvelous Marvin Hagler, champions who know what it is to work for a living. The heavyweight champion drove a truck and worked in a car wash. Hagler, the middleweight champion, held jobs in a shoe factory and on construction gangs.

title: REGAL INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
U.S. SAYS BOSTON BANK KNEW OF RULE ON CASH
description: A vice president of the Bank of Boston was told by Federal bank regulators as early as 1982 that the bank was not in compliance with international currency reporting regulations and the official promised to correct the situation, Treasury officials said today.

title: Strike Has Crumbled, British Government Says
description: The Government declared today that more than half of Britain's coal miners were at their jobs and that the nation's longest strike had crumbled after a year of violence and bitterness.

title: Pacers Defeat Knicks, 108-106
description: Clark Kellogg scored 21 points tonight and drew praise for his defensive work against Bernard King, who scored 28, as the Indiana Pacers beat the Knicks, 108-106.

title: OR TOWNS
description: Great literature, wrote the British poet A. E. Housman should ''do some good to the reader: must quicken his perception though dull, and sharpen his discrimination though blunt, and mellow the rawness of his personal opinions.''

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: A PASSION FOR ENGLISH VICTORIAN ENRICHES A NEW YORK APARTMENT
description: JIM DALE, the actor, was homesick for his native England. So he decided to bring a little bit of England to New York. As a result, he and his wife, Julie, a gallery owner, have turned their East Side apartment into something resembling one of their favorite London haunts, the Victoria and Albert Museum.

title: NATIONAL GOLD DISTRIBUTORS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $53,948 related to start-up costs for the company's first five new retail outlets.

title: FARMERS AT IOWA RALLY SOUND CALL FOR FEDERAL AID
description: In buses, cars and pickup trucks, worried farmers from across the Middle West and from as far as Tennessee gathered here today to sound a theme and send a message to policy-makers in Washington.

title: Canada's Defense Post Filled By Its Deputy Prime Minister
description: Deputy Prime Minister Erik Nielsen was named today as Canada's new Defense Minister, replacing Robert Coates, who resigned earlier this month after a furor erupted about a visit he had made to a West German striptease club.

title: Still One Mideast War Too Late
description: Jordan, backed by Egypt and Saudi Arabia, claims to have won the P.L.O.'s consent for negotiations - presumably with Israel but maybe only the United States. The tortured language of King Hussein's agreement with Yasir Arafat bears only a faint resemblance to the terms of Camp David and the Reagan Plan and is far from a realistic basis for negotiation. But if pro-American Arab leaders say it is a step forward, that's reason enough for the United States and Israel to embrace it as that.

title: Scalped Tickets and Matching Sweaters
description: Outside, it was cold and windy and the scalpers were getting $150 or more for a ticket - when the cops were not getting the scalpers first.

title: REMOVING MILITARY'S TOXIC WASTE WILL COST BILLION'S, OFFICIAL SAYS
description: It will cost $5 billion to $10 billion to clean up hazardous waste disposal sites at military installations, a representative of the Defense Department said today.

title: OLD-TIME BRAZILIAN POLITICS VEXING THE PRESIDENT-ELECT
description: Even before he takes office next month as Brazil's first civilian President in 21 years, Tancredo Neves is finding his efforts to form a government complicated by the resurgence of political activity after years of military rule.

title: INTRUDERS AT EAST NEW YORK HOME SHOOT 3 FATALLY AND WOUND SEVEN
description: Three people were shot to death and seven others, including two children, were wounded when at least two gunmen burst into a home in the East New York section of Brooklyn shortly after midnight this morning and began shooting indiscriminately, according to police and medical officials.

title: HERS
description: SOMEONE has to stand up for wimps. It used to be that the worst you could say about a man was that he was a brute, a Neanderthal and possibly out of touch with his feelings. Then, with the swiftness of cultural change in the microchip age, disapproval shifted to the man who appeared to be too sensitive, soft and accommodating to the interests of others. ''Wimp,'' which must be one of the creepiest little syllables in the language, leaped from obscurity to become the ultimate term of masculine derogation.

title: BONNEVILLE-WEST CORP reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: PENSION OFFICIAL AT A STATE FUND WILL LEAVE POST
description: The official who oversees New York State's $23 billion employee pension fund said today that she had decided to resign.

title: A Restructuring Takes Toll at Mickelberry
description: The impact of the restructuring of the Chicago office of Cunningham & Walsh after the loss of the Brown & Williamson Tobacco Company account in October has been felt in the fourth-quarter earnings of the Mickelberry Corporation, its holding-company parent.

title: G.O.P. GROUP PLANS EARLY DRIVE TO UNSEAT 30 HOUSE DEMOCRATS
description: In a drive that will start 18 months before the next Congressional elections, the National Republican Congressional Committee is planning to spend from $4 million to $5 million to attack the legislative records of 25 to 30 House Democrats.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS ;   Dollar Turns Steadier In New York Trading
description: The dollar steadied in New York trading yesterday, after plunging in Europe. Traders said volume was very light, as most banks generally stayed on the sidelines because of uncertainty over the dollar's next move.

title: TRUMP EVICTION DISPUTE TAKEN TO STATE HEARING
description: After years of delay, tenants of a Central Park South apartment building and lawyers for its owner, Donald Trump, yesterday brought their bitter eviction dispute to a formal state hearing.

title: Judge's Ruling Backs Von B"ulow on Evidence
description: A crucial statement by a defense attorney that was used to convict Claus von B"ulow of trying to kill his wife cannot be used in his retrial, a judge ruled today.

title: Couple Charged In Death of Girl, 2
description: A married couple have been charged with murdering a 2-year-old girl whom the state had placed in their custody after her natural mother was sent to prison upon pleading guilty to breaking the girl's legs.

title: THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 28, 1985   Markets
description: European central banks sold $1 billion or more of dollars, sending the dollar plunging for the second straight day. The turnaround follows the dollar's ascent to ever-higher records throughout most of February. The central banks timed their move to take advantage of the dollar's slide on Tuesday. (Page A1.) The dollar steadied in later New York trading. Traders said volume was very light. (D20.)

title: SILICON VALLEY WAITS FOR RELIEF
description: The sales revival that Silicon Valley's chip makers have been waiting for appears to be several months away. As things are going, the computer chip manufacturers probably will do no better this year than match last year's production, industry analysts say.

title: Rumors Prove Wrong At Interpublic Group
description: In response to rumors and reports concerning changes in the high command at the Interpublic Group of Companies, Philip H. Geier, chairman and chief executive, said that J. Donald McNamara, the president, who was reportedly leaving, will in fact sign a regular one-year employment contract when his current one runs out in March. It is the ''normal extension,'' Mr. Geier said.

title: WASHINGTON HOMES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Share earnings for the year-ago quarter and 6 months have been restated to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid Jan. 18.

title: DNA PLANT TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: WILLIAMS STARTS LIFE ON THE CELTICS
description: One of the first things Ray Williams did upon arriving at Boston Garden yesterday afternoon was to look down at the floor in front of his new locker. There, sitting neatly side by side, were his sneakers, his new green sneakers. For a moment, he just stood there and stared. ''They took my old white ones and just painted them over,'' he said. ''They looked weird. It was just a used pair, but they'd done a good job. They looked brand new. They'll be the last thing I put on.''

title: KAY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HAMPTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The were 13 weeks and 52 weeks in the latest quarter and year, respectively, compared with 14 weeks and 53 weeks in year-earlier periods.

title: NICARAGUA SAYS IT WILL SUSPEND ARMS BUILDUP
description: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra announced today an ''indefinite moratorium'' on the acquisition of new arms systems by his Government and said Nicaragua would also send home 100 Cuban military advisers.

title: Intervention: How It Works For foreign exchange traders
description: flush with dollars, and confident that the dollar will rise,

title: Longer Training Urged In Report on Teachers
description: Teacher training should refocus on the liberal arts, college education programs should be lengthened and more prospective teachers should be recruited from minority groups and professional fields, a report on teacher training says.

title: THE SECOND TIME AROUND OFFERS NO HONEYMOON
description: After being rocked on their heels into the politics of passivity by President Reagan's landslide re-election, Congressional Democratic leaders have begun to frame the outlines of a more assertive legislative strategy.

title: SANDS REGENT reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said it made its initial public offering on Jan. 11.

title: AMTRAK POLICE ON STRIKE AT 10 NORTHEAST STATIONS
description: The police officers who patrol 10 Amtrak stations from Boston to Washington went on strike at 8 P.M. yesterday, leaving some of the stations with minimal police security.

title: Article 059277 -- No Title
description: To the Editor:

title: SCOTT SCIENCE & TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Peace Pipe at the U.N.
description: The seven-foot-tall bronze figure proffers a peace pipe skyward, but only vaguely in the direction of the United Nations, and just missing the green-glass Secretariat and General Assembly Buildings. They are slightly south of the pipe, across First Avenue.

title: AGENT ORANGE PAYMENTS PLAN LIMITS THE NUMBER OF AWARDS
description: A long-awaited master plan for the distribution of a $200 million Agent Orange settlement fund to aid Vietnam veterans who claim to have been harmed by the herbicide was filed yesterday in Federal District Court in Brooklyn.

title: HARRAH SENT TO RANGERS
description: On the day the Yankee regulars arrived in camp, Toby Harrah, who had lost his status as a regular, departed. The Yankees granted Harrah's wish today and traded him to the Texas Rangers for Billy Sample, an outfielder, and a minor leaguer to be named. Sample had asked the Rangers to trade him.
